column2: Richard Colon, known as Crazy Legs in the break-dancing world, is the host of “Lunch Breaks,” a show on the Web that combines hip-hop music and wholesome cooking.

Here are some of the dozens of changes that Fiat made to get the 500 into the United States. Some were required under federal regulations and some because of the tastes of Americans.
Fiat had to make a few changes to the European version of its 500 to meet federal safety and emissions rules. For example, alterations had to be made to the engine and the fuel-filler door was moved.
The designer of the new Fiat 500 drew inspiration from the man who created the original in 1936 and the Cinquecento of 1957, perhaps his crowning achievement.
In the new Fiat 500, the company is using a newer valve-throttling system instead of the conventional engine system found in most vehicles.
Fiat is using intake-valve throttling in the 500, but some automakers are skeptical about the benefits of the technology.

With Oscar-winning movie stars shifting from the big screen to computer screens, the quality, the appeal and the cost of Web video appears to be rising.
“They’re wrong a lot, those experts. History is littered with their failed predictions. Whole books can be filled with them. Many have been.”

After a long on and off courtship, “we knew this was it.”
The bride is the founder of a blog about fashion, beauty and social events, and the bridegroom is the vice president of a home furnishings showroom.
The couple met at New York University, where they each received a medical degree.
The bride works for the furniture brands Ducduc and New Traditionalists; the bridegroom, whose great-grandmother started Lane Bryant, runs Fashion to Figure, a retail chain for plus-size women.

PERHAPS the only things more varied and numerous than the New York lottery games one can throw money at are regular players' strategies for choosing numbers. Whether it's Powerball or Take 5 or Mega Millions, everyone seems to have a surefire method. Some rely on dreams to furnish numbers; others consult the license plates of parked, or passing, cars. Leonardo de la Cruz, right, who owns a store two blocks from the world headquarters of the Lubavitcher movement in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, said 99 percent of his customers were Hasidic Jews. ''And 99 percent of them play 770,'' he said, a reference to the building's address, 770 Eastern Parkway. ''Always. That's their favorite pick.''

PACIFIC SLIM At the Blue Pearl boot-camp spa in Laguna Canyon, you're put through your paces in style. I never thought I would be excited to see a van, especially a white, 15-seat Ford E-350 Super Duty XLT. (I fancy myself more of a vintage-Jaguar kind of girl.) But after a few days hiking the hills above Laguna Beach, Calif., which looked innocuous in the distance but felt like Kilimanjaro as I walked up them, the sight of Blanche, as I named her, at the end of the trail was pure ecstasy. I'd been at Blue Pearl Laguna, a new holistic retreat (read: boot camp) nestled in Laguna Canyon, for three days and 30 hours worth of yoga, hiking, gym workouts, more yoga, tai chi, nutrition lectures and very little food. I'd traded my Lanvin and Louboutins for a frightening bush hat, dirt-colored hiking shoes and one of those water backpacks with a tube that leads to your mouth. I no longer bothered to brush my hair. Or apply mascara. I had turned into someone I didn't recognize. I had become sporty.

If the scenes of the devastation from the tsunami and earthquake and nuclear crises weren't enough to motivate you to give to the Red Cross relief efforts, United and Continental Airlines have come up with another enticement: frequent flier miles. The two airlines, now owned by one holding company, are offering 250 bonus miles to people in their frequent flier programs who give $50 to the Red Cross through April 30 and 500 bonus miles to those who give $100 or more.

TIMOTHY EGAN Think back to ... oh, all of one week ago. The mercenaries of Muammar el-Qaddafi were closing in for the slaughter of people trying to take a breath of the same Arab Spring air going around Tunisia and Egypt. Had Obama done nothing, as the Dennis Kucinich fringe Democrats and the Ron Paul isolationist Republicans wanted, the blood of civilians would be filling the streets of Benghazi. The regime had promised to chase its own citizens into closets and butcher them.

An article last Sunday about the ties between State Senator Carl Kruger and the Turanos, a Brooklyn family with a mansion in Mill Basin, Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to the street where the family had a home in Canarsie. It is Glenwood Road, not Avenue.

Taking their cue from the food-truck trend, a number of upscale hotels have initiated food trolleys. Among them is the Four Seasons Resort Palm Beach, where twice each afternoon, the hotel's caipirinha cart makes its way around the pool deck dispensing Brazilian cocktails made to order chaise-side ($12).

FIRST, a bit of comics history: Superman long believed he was the sole survivor of his doomed planet. He later discovered that Kandor, a Kryptonian city, had remained intact thanks to an archfoe who had miniaturized it (and placed it in a bell jar for an extreme collection of alien real estate). Still with us? The artist Mike Kelley's book ''Kandors,'' which was released this week, is a photographic chronicle of his decade-long work reproducing various eerie depictions of Kandor in immense, handblown glass bell jars. The work, which Mr. Kelley began in 1999 as part of an exhibition about millennial change, uses ''an out-of-date image of the future'' represented through technological advancements. ''Kandors'' (Hirmer, $49.95) is available at amazon.com.

SCHAAP--Madeleine (nee Gottlieb). On February 28, at 73, in New York City, after a long illness. Beloved mother of Jeremy and Joanna Rose Schaap, grandmother of Katherine. Graduate of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts; CNN reporter. Donations can be made to the ASPCA.

For a taste of real Swedish design, forgo Ikea's flat-packed boxes and the kitsch-filled shops that line Stockholm's atmospheric old town. The best places for original wares in Sweden's capital are located along the broad boulevards north of the city center in Vasastan, a low-key neighborhood that rarely appears on tourist itineraries. Predictably, many places specialize in Scandinavian minimalism, but in a way that reflects the aesthetic of this eclectic area, where the design-minded shops intermingle with traditional Swedish bakeries, Turkish food markets, antiques stores and clothing boutiques from up-and-coming designers. INGRID K. WILLIAMS

SCHUSTACK--Shirley Conrad, on March 24, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Robert P. Schustack and the late Dr. Milton Conrad. Devoted mother of David and Judy Schustack, the late Joan Schustack and Holly and Jeff Conrad. Adored grandmother of Amy and Gregory Smith and Robert J. Schustack. Dear great-grandmother of Elanna and Benjamin. Also survived by many nieces and nephews and their families. Services were held. She will be dearly missed.

That phrase, word for word as dictated, begins the ''Duino Elegies,'' among the most estimable long poems of the 20th century. And that story, recounted by the princess in her letters and repeated in almost every account of Rilke's life, sums up much that's distinct and singular about Trieste and its environs: its isolation, wedged as it is on the far eastern coast of Italy, between a steep limestone escarpment and the deep blue sea; its fierce weather mitigated by solid comforts; its muted splendor; and its reputation as a haven for distinguished exiles, outsiders and eccentrics - especially writers, of whom Trieste has hosted a great many. Aside from Rilke, there was Casanova, whose memoirs end with his sojourn in Trieste, and Stendahl, who served as a consul here, as did Richard Burton (the half-mad explorer, not the actor), who disliked the place and bided his time by translating the Kama Sutra and the Arabian Nights. Johann Joachim Winckelmann, the pioneering German art historian, died here - murdered by a robber in his hotel room. At the age of 20, Freud spent some time in the city, dissecting eels as part of his medical training. The poet Filippo Marinetti started his Futurist movement here, with an evening of theater, readings, manifestos and mayhem. James Joyce accomplished most of his life's work while teaching English to Triestini, and Italo Svevo was born and raised here. The great travel essayist Jan Morris chose Trieste as the subject of her final book, and its subtitle - ''The Meaning of Nowhere'' - perhaps gives some insight into why, of all these figures, only Svevo was a local. Trieste is where you go to reinvent yourself, to be left alone, if you want - or not, if you don't.

London: There's a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists. All over town, hoteliers are bringing aging buildings back from the scrapheap with striking revamps. What were once debauched and dreary addresses are the upscale lodging of the future.

More than 2,000 young Burmese gathered on the lawn of the Mya Yeik Nyo Hotel in Yangon last month for a Valentine's Day hip-hop concert. In many places, the scene would have been unremarkable. But Myanmar has been ruled by a military junta for decades; its anti-Western, conservative culture is marked by political and sexual repression. In 2005, the government drew international criticism when it suspended the magazine Han Thit (New Style) for running a Valentine's Day celebration advertisement. But on this occasion, among the young at least, the mood was uninhibited. Boys kissed girls. Girls kissed girls. They chanted aloud, dressed in jeans and sneakers and miniskirts, fueled by whiskey and beer. ''I want to change things, but here, if you say something, you're either dead or in prison for 200 years,'' one participant, the son of a retired colonel, said. ''So what do you do besides take advantage of this life?''

Alexandria Schmidt, 18: A Marine told us that a perfect score was 70 seconds. I was going to try to hang there as long as I could. One of the Marines said that when you sing a song in your head, it really helps you through pain. ''Old MacDonald'' was what came into my head. I made it 30 seconds. I definitely could have gone 45 seconds if I hadn't started laughing. I heard a Marine shout, ''Don't let go,'' and it made me laugh, and it made me lose my song, and that's when I started slipping. I do choir and drama -- I don't do sports, so I was actually pretty impressed by myself. I think I was the longest up there, except maybe for this one itty-bitty girl who was just floating up there because she's so tiny. Whenever I had tried to do that at the gym, I couldn't even pull myself up. I figured I did it because of the Marines. I don't want to be a Marine -- I just have respect for them. They do so much for us, so I told myself: I can do this. I can try.

AHERN--Bishop Patrick D.D. The D'Urso family gives praise and thanks to God for the life of an extraordinary priest and beloved friend, His Excellency Patrick Ahern, D.D, who was "a Special Gift from God." A Priest for over 65 years, Bishop Ahern served as secretary to two cardinals in the Archdiocese of New York, first Cardinal Spellman and then our saintly Cardinal Cooke, and was appointed bishop by Pope John Paul VI in 1970. Bishop Ahern's priesthood was truly an imitation of Christ and a reflection of his deep love for the Blessed Mother and St. Therese of the Child Jesus, whose spirituality, humility and great joy radiated in his smile, good humor, and authentic compassion for all people, especially disabled. The D'Urso family cherishes many happy memories of times shared with Bishop Ahern on all of our March birthdays with Bishop Sheridan and particularly our Christmas dinners over 12 years, when Bishop Ahern became part of our family. We will always treasure those beautiful, unforgettable moments of joy and are forever grateful to Bishop Ahern for his invaluable friendship. I will never forget Bishop Ahern traveling all the way to Pennsylvania for my beloved mother's funeral 20 years ago, as Cardinal O'Connor was on his way to Rome. Our family has restored many items in the Papal Sacristy of the Vatican Museums. Among them are two chests of Leo XIII in honor of two treasures of our Church, Bishop Patrick Ahern and Bishop Patrick Sheridan who served our Church so faithfully for so many years. the Church has truly lost a Great Priest. What a consolation that Our Lord would receive Bishop Ahern into eternal life on the 41st anniversary of his ordination as bishop and on the Feast of St. Joseph. St. Therese must have showered him with rose pedals, as the angels brought him to meet Our Lord. Jesus must have said to him, "Well Done, Good and Faithful Servant." We love you dearly, Your Excellency. We will never forget your smile, and you will always be in our hearts! With dearest love, prayers and admiration, Florence B. D'Urso and family.

Now that Hyderabad, India, is booming as a business hub (Microsoft, among other tech giants, is here), the city is looking past the stuffed suits and angling for the jet set. Its history rivals that of the more popular Jaipur, with distinct architecture from the Nizam rule and a mining heritage that gave us the Kohinoor diamond. A flurry of new openings - boutique hotels, upscale restaurants and shops catering to stars of the local Telugu film industry, known as Tollywood - is moving the metropolis into the spotlight. STAY The newest Park hotel (22 Raj Bhavan Road; 011-91-40-2345-6789; theparkhotels.com), part of the Indian chain of boutique-style properties, has 270 rooms overlooking Hussain Sagar Lake, many of them suites by designers like Rohit Bal, Manish Arora and Jean-Francois Lesage.
COTTINGHAM--Alice Luisa, August 2010. Alice was devoted to her family, her friends, and her profession. She is greatly missed and we mourn the loss of a truly splendid person. Carrolyn & Colleagues

In the city's parks, the crocuses and jonquils are out and the forsythia and magnolias are budding. On March 18, the season jumped the gun, and in the 77-degree heat, winter coats disappeared and spring fashion took over, from the classics to the hot Marc Jacobs T-shirt. The stores at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street were dressed in their best; at Louis Vuitton, the ostrich windows are amazing. In Central Park, a soap-bubble artist mesmerized children with his deft hand. Six days later, the parks were again covered in a light snow, but by then it was officially spring, and some New Yorkers had already moved on to summer.

Howard's Other Side Every player looks to improve during his career, but the Orlando Magic would probably be happier if Dwight Howard, above in a dispute with the referee John Goble, would stop his improvement at collecting technical fouls.

TAYLOR--James W.,92, of Westfield, NJ, on March 23, 2011. During WWII, he worked in the Allison Division of General Motors, building engines for Curtiss P-40 fighter planes. In 1951, he joined the consulting firm of Booz, Allen and Hamilton, where he was president. Preceded in death by wife, Mary Lou Taylor, survived by four children and five grandchildren. Funeral 10am, Monday, March 28, 2011, The Presbyterian Church in Westfield, NJ.

Forever enshrined by the Beatles, the city of Hamburg is a fab foray into sex, beer and rock 'n' roll. In April of 1961, an English art-school screw-up and musician named John Lennon stepped into a doorway in the St. Pauli neighborhood of Hamburg, Germany, and had his image snapped by a local photographer named Jurgen Vollmer. That black-and-white picture is now an iconic symbol of the days when Lennon and his band - hopped up on Holsten beer and over-the-counter uppers called Preludin - played marathon shows, fraternized with strippers and, along the way, became the Beatles, forever enshrining Hamburg's improbable place in the rock cosmology. As Lennon put it, ''I grew up in Hamburg, not Liverpool.''

These easy-on-easy-off flats will put you into the airport-security fast lane (and let you step out in style once you've landed). This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
SCHULMAN--Irving. A friend of great integrity and humor, we will miss him. The Club

On the day after the Triangle fire, the scores of victims were laid out in a makeshift morgue set up at the so-called Charities Pier off East 26th Street. Many were burned so badly that they were almost impossible to identify. Newspaper accounts at the time said that 100,000 people lined up there to examine the bodies, though most of the crowd were not relatives, but the curious -- morbid voyeurs. The actual relatives sobbed or shrieked or walked away in frozen anguish, left with memories of people who were mostly young and barely formed. Some seldom spoke again about those they had lost.

WISE--Barbara S.,known to friends and family as Barbi, died in Las Vegas, NV on March 23rd. She was a significant fixture of the downtown art and theater worlds for decades. Barbi was born in Waco, Texas on November 20, 1929. In 1952, while performing as Desdemona at the Cleveland Playhouse, she met her future husband, Howard Wise. In 1960, Howard opened the Howard Wise Gallery on 57th Street, and the family moved to New York. Barbi returned to the theater in the 1970s, performing in many avant garde productions in New York and Provincetown. In 1989, Barbi became president of the board of EAI, a nonprofit started by Howard in 1971 to support video as an art form. She also served on the boards of the Castle Hill Center for the Arts in Truro, MA and Theatre for a New City in New York. Barbi is survived by her son, David Wise, daughter Juliet Ruiz, stepsons Daniel Wise, and Jeremy Wise as well as granddaughters Johanna and Benna Wise-Levine, Brooke DeMarco, and step-granddaughter Rebecca Matalon. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

FORT--Marion Knox Barthelme died March 22, 2011, after a long fight against cancer. She was very much beloved by all in the community, and will be greatly missed. A Houston resident since 1983, she was passionate about reading, writing, and the visual arts, and was vibrant, engaged, and tireless in promoting and developing these art forms here and elsewhere. She was Vice President of the Board of Trustees of The Menil Collection, and Chairman of Nominating and Governance Committee there. She joined the Inprint board in 1990, served as President and Chairman, and remained very active on their University of Houston Liaison Committee. In February, Inprint honored her, along with others, for her many contributions to creative writing and literature. Marion was also a board member and past President of "Gulf Coast: A Journal of Literature and Fine Arts," and honored at their last annual Gala; as well as a former board member of the Chinati Foundation; the Alley Theatre, where she was also honored for her work on their Gala evening; and an Advisory Board member of the Houston Seminar. She was a freelance writer, and formerly a correspondent for Time Magazine for many years in New York, before moving to Houston with her husband, Donald Barthelme, who taught creative writing at UH. Her works include the book "Women in the Texas Populist Movement: Letters from the Southern Mercury." Marion was born, and grew up, near Baltimore, Maryland, and received a BA in International Relations and French from the University of Wisconsin, and subsequently a MA in History from Rice University. Her husband John F. "Jeff" Fort survives her, as do her daughters Katharine and Anne Barthelme, step children Jeff, Alexandra, Tucker, and Elizabeth Fort, and sisters Vaughn Schwarz and Fran Butler. The memorial service will be on Thursday, March 31, 2011 at four o'clock in the afternoon at the Rothko Chapel, 1409 Sul Ross, Houston, Texas 77006. A reception will follow at the family's residence. Donations in lieu of flowers can be made in her memory to: The Menil Collection, 1519 Branard, Houston, Texas 77006.

East No. 2 NORTH CAROLINA and No. 4 KENTUCKY are college basketball royalty, but their paths to the regional final have not been easy. The Wildcats have needed two game-winning shots from Brandon Knight, while the Tar Heels escaped with a 3-point victory over Washington. Both teams have talent, with the North Carolina freshman Harrison Barnes perhaps the most talented of all. A key may be Kentucky's Josh Harrellson, who was able to hold his own against Ohio State's Jared Sullinger. Will he be able to do so against Tyler Zeller?

YOUNG--Dorothy Lena, 103, of Tinton Falls, NJ, formerly of Ocean Grove, NJ, entered into eternal rest on March 20, 2011. A philanthropist, artist and Broadway performer, she was the last surviving assistant of Harry Houdini. She funded scholarships and the Dorothy Young Center for the Arts at Drew University in Madison, NJ. She was predeceased by her second husband, Gilbert Kiamie. She is survived by her son, Robert E. Perkins, Jr., three grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's United Methodist Church, 80 Embury Avenue, Ocean Grove on Saturday, April 16, 2011 at 4:00pm. Donations in her memory may be made to the Dorothy Young Scholarship for the Arts at Drew University, c/o Advancement Office, 36 Madison Avenue, Madison, NJ 07940.

One of the primary pleasures of travel magazines is that they teach us how to explore the world with efficiency and grace. Sometimes this is in the spirit of escapism and fun, and sometimes it serves other purposes. Sean Penn's decision to spend most of the past year in Haiti trying to provide housing, health care and basic services to 50,000 people left homeless after the earthquake of January 2010 adds extraordinary heft to the notion that travel is more than tourism. What I find most moving in Zoë Heller's remarkable profile of Penn (''The Accidental Activist,'' Page 82) is the actor's commitment to that country and its citizens, and his fundamental belief in the beauty that lies there beneath the devastation. Joumana Haddad is another star -- she is considered the Oprah of Lebanon -- who sees bright possibilities in dark times. Haddad is an editor, journalist and commentator whose embracing of eroticism and women's sexual expressiveness has made her a controversial figure in Beirut. Nina Burleigh traveled to that city to interview Haddad, and the story she brought back (''Sex and the Souk,'' Page 64) is a riveting view of a society in flux.
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel takes a week off to look back at the places (and the meals) that he wishes he could revisit.

From one side of the stage would glide Bess Houdini, wife of the master magician and escape artist, draped in a billowing gown like Marie Antoinette. From the other side would prance Dorothy Young, dressed as a courtly boy page in ruffled silk. At center stage, they would swirl into a minuet, then draw back the curtain as Houdini -- to the triumphal tones of ''Pomp and Circumstance'' -- stepped forward in tails to begin his flash-magic routine of drawn scarves and flapping birds.

The seaside town of Margate, England, a thriving summer playground until its decline in the 1970s, is counting on the Turner Contemporary to revive its fortunes. Opening April 16, this striking museum - designed by David Chipperfield and named for the painter J. M. W. Turner, one of Margate's famous visitors - has already spurred new galleries, pubs and cafes, as well as the restoration of Dreamland, a 1920s amusement park down the road. And it has inspired a lyrical new work by Tracey Emin, who grew up in Margate. Her pink neon sculpture ''I Never Stopped Loving You'' hangs adjacent to the museum. (Hundreds of people showed up to cheer its installation last year.) ''There is more of an appetite for contemporary art here than you might imagine,'' says Victoria Pomery, the Turner's founding director. The inaugural show presents six artists whose works relate to a little-known Turner canvas depicting the Soufriere volcano on St. Vincent. ''We want to help audiences get a better sense of the contemporary through the historical,'' Pomery says. ''And we will always have a Turner presence.'' Adds Emin, ''The other nice thing about the Turner is that it will have a really beautiful cafe, so people like my 82-year-old mum can go and look out at the sea and have a nice cup of tea.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The seminal restaurant St. John opened in 1994, inspiring a slew of like-minded restaurants to revive English cooking and butchery.

Anton Corbijn is perhaps best known for his moving pictures, be they feature films (''The American,'' ''Control'') or music videos (his award-winning 1993 short for Nirvana's ''Heart Shaped Box''). But recently Corbijn has made a return to his roots as a portraitist, including this issue's cover shot of Sean Penn. ''With Sean I worked very fast,'' he says. ''He brings everything I need to the table.'' Among his current projects -- he has worked with Depeche Mode as its visual director for two decades -- Corbijn is also designing a logo for his hometown, The Hague. Wells Tower

London: There's a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists. In a city that once considered book talk to be gauche in the extreme, people currently speak of little else. Literary salons are sprouting all over: in sawdusty pubs, at clubs with rooftop pools, at art centers and in private drawing rooms. Many are closed to the public, but travelers can get a taste of highbrow London at a pair of popular gatherings.

London: There's a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists. Raising the Bar Stodgy old pubs and the suds they serve are being replaced by London's new wave of cocktail labs, distilleries and microbreweries. Lounge Bohemia (1E Great Eastern Street; 011-44-772-070-7000; loungebohemia.com), the appointment-only speakeasy hidden between a kebab shop and a newsstand, serves libations like the Old Castro (cigar-infused rum served over vanilla candy floss) in a space filled with Czech Modernist furniture. And at a discreet spot at 69 Colebrooke Row (011-44-754-052-8593; 69colebrookerow.com), Tony Conigliaro (above) tinkers in his upstairs laboratory to supply his downstairs bar with cocktail ingredients like essences of rose petal. Supplying such watering holes is the new artisanal distiller Sipsmith (27 Nasmyth Street; 011-44-208-741-2034; sipsmith.com), which makes small batches of dry gin and barley vodka, and Meantime Brewing Company (Blackwell Lane; 011-44-208-293-1111; meantimebrewing.com), which crafts pilsners and ales from bog myrtle and wormwood.

BERLIN--Jerry, 89, passed away peacefully on March 13th in Michigan at the sides of his brother, Robert, and niece, Ellen Mahoney. Raised in Newark and born the eldest child to Molly and Louis, Jerry was a lifelong New Yorker. Educated at the University of Chicago and earning an A.B., he remained a proud alum. Jerry spent his career at sea as a merchant marine, captaining ferries between the Cape and Islands during some summers. When not at sea, he split his time between his residence in Greenwich Village, and by the side of the late Mary O'Brien of New Jersey, to whom he was a devoted partner for more than three decades. A voracious reader and prolific writer eschewing television - Jerry consumed letters from family and friends made around the world and remained a loyal correspondent. Using a Smith Corona, he produced a treasure trove of letters, aphorisms, poems, and manuscripts. He also served as an enthusiastic and generous editor and reviewer for his literary friends. Jerry lived life like a native New Yorker. A consummate world traveler and global thinker, he consistently promoted the value of education and bemoaned the state of this country's education system. Sitting on the front stoop of his Village brownstone, he befriended countless people, often learning about their journeys to America. A doting uncle, he loved children and quickly won them over with his rollicking nature. Jerry is the brother of Robert Berlin, of Beverly Hills, Michigan and the former Arthur Berlin of Evanston, Illinois. He is survived by his nieces Ellen Mahoney of Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, Linda Berlin of Burlington, Vermont, and Leslie Starsoneck of Raleigh, North Carolina and by his nephews Stephen Lewin-Berlin of Acton, Massachusetts, and Andrew Berlin of Gloucester, Massachusetts.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the prospects for Japan's psychological recovery from the series of recent disasters misattributed a quotation about the management of information during the Chernobyl nuclear accident in Ukraine in 1986, an issue for which Japanese officials have also been criticized. It was Adriana Petryna, a professor in the anthropology department at the University of Pennsylvania -- not Susumu Hirakawa, a psychologist at Taisho University in Tokyo -- who said, ''Mismanagement of information creates consequences down the line.'' And a picture credit misstated the name of the company that provided the photograph of recent destruction in Japan to Reuters. It is Kyodo News, not Yomiuri.

The Youth Issue: It's both a straightforward description of what you're about to read and a more evocative phrase -- as in, What exactly is our issue with youth? Not with the concept (which everyone seems to be pretty much eternally enamored of) but with the demographic. Judging by recent cultural portrayals, we are currently befuddled by and/or terrified of the young -- whether they're cold-eyed, ambitious automatons (Jesse Eisenberg's take on the friendless Mark Zuckerberg in ''The Social Network'') or vaguely threatening, hypercompetent agents of our obsolescence (Saoirse Ronan in the coming ''Hanna,'' in which she plays a teenager trained to murder Cate Blanchett, her surrogate pseudo-mom). Meanwhile, the young (or at least those youths who aren't busy fomenting historic revolution overseas) are often lumped together as a drifting generation, faced with a bankrupt government, genuinely dire employment prospects and a generally dismal tomorrow. We're repeatedly told that they are distracted and listless, their brains hot-wired and short-circuited by an overload of neurally frazzling technologies. None of which will be confirmed, or even supported, on the pages that follow. Because if these youths -- a pair of tech geniuses (and best friends), a soccer sensation, a tween idol, a poker phenom and a generally upbeat crew of California high-school students -- are lost, or drifting, or facing futures even bleaker than today, it certainly hasn't registered with them. But then, this is the enduring gift of youth, when we ''post-youths'' shut up long enough to listen: not to what we can tell them, but to what they will tell us.

SCHENKEL--Edward, passed away on March 18th, 2011 at 88 years old. Brother to the late Arnold Schenkel; survived by sister-in-law, Barbara Schenkel, nephews Jeffrey (Janet) and Robert (Yukiko), great-nephews P.J. and Mark, and great-niece Stephanie. Eddie was a WWII navigator, flying over two-dozen missions. He became an accountant after the war, and retired as a High School teacher. We got to know him best during the later part of his life, and are very grateful for that. He will be missed.

London: There's a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists. If there's one upside to the down economy, it's the proliferation of vintage clothing shops. And some of London's latest boutiques are reusing and recycling in high style. The standout is Lucy in Disguise (10-13 King Street; 011-44-207-240-6590; lucyindisguiselondon.com), the shop and beauty salon opened by the pop star Lily Allen (above left) and her sister Sarah Owen (above right). Upstairs is a smart selection of pieces by Ossie Clark, Chanel and Dior, among others; downstairs there's a blow-dry bar run by Bumble & Bumble and a Wah Nails Bar. Hurwundeki (98 Commercial Street; 011-44-207-392-9194; hurwundeki.com) takes a similar approach - it's a salon-shop hybrid carrying yesteryear clothing with a steampunk flair (along with its own designs) - while Pelicans and Parrots (40 Stoke Newington Road; 011-44-203-215-2083; pelicansandparrots.com) throws taxidermy owls and Castiglioni-ish lamps into its mix of '80s jean jackets and Polo dresses.

BERGEN--Robert L.,Jr. Died at home in South Hadley, MA on Tuesday, January 11, 2011 with his family at his side. Born in Bayshore, NY on October 29, 1929, he was the son of Robert and Alice Bergen. Bob was a cum laude graduate of Williams College and a Ph.D. from Cornell University in 1955. As a material scientist for Uniroyal, headquartered in Middlebury, CT, he obtained many patents for the company. Later, Bob became the Director of Research and Development at Uniroyal. His biography is in the Who's Who of America. During his 30 year residence in Bethany, CT, Bob took a leadership role in church and community. He also taught math and started the chemistry department at the University of New Haven. Six years ago, he and his wife moved to Loomis Village in South Hadley, where Bob took an active role in the financial committee. Bob will be missed by his wife of 59 years, Betsy (Field), along with their four children, Beryl Field Bergen and her husband Henry Field of Framingham, MA; Alice Muh and her husband Robert of Littleton, NH; Robert Bergen III and his wife Francine of Bethany, CT; and Jennifer Bergen and her husband Bill Richardson of Cairo, Egypt. Bob is also survived by his six grandchildren: Brian, Christopher, Rebecca, Stephen, Robert IV, and Kevin, along with four great-grandchildren: Jonas, Colin, Nora, and Abigail. He is survived by his brother, Dr. Frederick Bergen and his wife Margaret Ann and their four children. A celebration of Bob's life will be held on Saturday, April 2 at 11am at First Church of Christ, 511 Amity Rd., Bethany, CT. A reception will be held after the service at the Church. Donations in Bob's memory may be made to the following: The American Red Cross or Holyoke Hospital, Hospital Drive, Holyoke, MA 01040, or Stony Brook Community Church, 36 Hadley St., S. Hadley, MA 01075, Please visit: www.beersandstory.com to sign the online guestbook and express condolences.

An article last Sunday about Japan's crisis and the financial markets misstated part of the name of the journal in which Robert N. Stavins, a Harvard professor, wrote about the ''tragedy of the commons'' -- the quandaries that arise when people, acting in their own self-interest, pose a threat to the common good. It is the American Economic Review, not the American Economic View.

There is an almost clinical sobriety to the photos in Todd Eberle's new book, ''Empire of Space'' (Rizzoli, $85). Culled from Eberle's 30-year career and presented in pairs, the pictures force you to consider the visual kinship between disparate subjects: a Jeff Koons sculpture begins to look like a tomato; Granny's plaid sofa becomes a Frank Lloyd Wright ceiling; and an old I.B.M. computer morphs into the United Nations Secretariat tower. Eberle says that after making this book, he finds such parallels everywhere: ''It's incredible to have a new way of seeing the world.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

PRITCHETT--James Turner. Passed quietly at home in New York on March 15 at the age of 88. Mr. Pritchett was born in Lenoir, NC where he briefly practiced law before beginning a long and rich life in the theatre. Notably, Mr. Pritchett portrayed Dr. Matt Powers on the daytime serial "The Doctors" from 1963-1982, for which he won a Best Actor Emmy in 1978. On Broadway, he starred in "Two For the Seesaw" in 1959 and appeared "Sail Away" in 1961-62. He appeared in national tours of "Auntie Mame" with Sylvia Sydney in 1958 and "Other Peoples Money" with Tony LoBianco in 1991. He began his television career on the daytime serial "The Secret Storm" and then "As The World Turns" before his 19 year run on "The Doctors." He also worked extensively in regional theatre throughout his life, and appeared in numerous television commercials and film. Mr. Pritchett served in World War II where he earned a degree in meteorology. He met his wife Cynthia as they starred together in a production of "Guys and Dolls" in her home state of Michigan. He was a devoted family man, sharing with his family his zeal for travel, and love of nature and sports. He will be remembered by many for his playful nature and sharp wit. He will be deeply missed by his loving family, wife Cynthia, daughter Laura, son-in-law Priest Dimitri, daughter Shelley, son Kyle, daughter-in-law Claudia, and grandchildren Yevgraf, Vassily and Theodora. Mr. Pritchett will be laid to rest in a private service in upstate New York where he and his family enjoyed many happy years.

Fifth Avenue is the undisputed divider of the city's street grid: east of Fifth is East, and west of Fifth is West. But Scott M. Stringer, the borough president of Manhattan, recently noticed that every bus stop sign along Fifth Avenue by Central Park seemed to be wrong: a stop across the avenue was identified as ''5 Avenue & West 84 St.'' And similar signs continued along the length of the eastern edge of the park. Mr. Stringer is demanding that the apparent errors be fixed, but is there an error at all? The signs sit on the west side of Fifth Avenue, so they are technically in the western zone of the street grid. Can West 84th Street exist on the west side of Fifth Avenue, even if the street itself begins on the other side of Central Park? Readers had their own opinions. Here are a few:

Beloved husband of Marilee, loving father of Clark Reiner and Mary Barnes and father-in-law of John Barnes, cherished grandfather of Mimi and John Paul Barnes. Retired Partner at White & Case LLP, Knight Commander of the Order of St. Gregory the Great, Knight Commander of the Order of Pope St. Sylvester, past President of the American Association of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta. Friends may call Sunday, March 27 from 3-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York City. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, March 28 at 11am at The Cathedral of Saint Patrick, The Lady Chapel, Fifth Avenue at 51st Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Path to Peace Foundation, 25 East 39th Street, New York, NY 10016.

FINKENSTAEDT--James Clements, retired vice-president of William Morrow Publishers, died on March 19, 2011, in Paris in his 91st year. Mr. Finkenstaedt, who was born in Grosse Pointe, Michigan, was educated at St. Paul's School, Concord, New Hampshire and Harvard College. A captain in the Marine Corps during the Second World War, he took part in the initial landing on Okinawa and then served in China. He joined William Morrow in 1952 of which he later with his partner Lawrence Hughes became an owner. During the 1960s he served on the editorial board of The Liberator, a black revolutionary magazine and was influential in the publishing of books by such well known authors as Amari Baraka and Nikki Giovanni. During the 1970s he founded and managed a Morrow office in Paris for the acquisition of works by European writers, including famous French chefs, especially Michel Guerard and Jean and Pierre Troisgros. He is survived by his wife, Rose Lindsay Harvey Finkenstaedt, his daughter Isabel Finkenstaedt Schelameur, his grandchildren, Catherine, Rose Lindsay, James III, Thomas Finkenstaedt, Pierre, William Luke and Rose Schelameur, his sister Mrs. Page Wodell of Lyme, Connecticut and his brother Reverend Harry S. Finkenstaedt of Gainesville, Virginia.

WERTHEIMER--Helen of Andover, MA on March 23, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Walter Wertheimer. Devoted sister of Dr. Harry Wachen. Cherished cousin of Margot and Edith. Adored aunt and grandaunt of many nieces and nephews. Services at Temple Emanuel, Andover, MA on Monday,March 28 at 10:30am.
LIPMAN--Samuel. My dearest Sandy, wherever I may go you are always in my heart. Love, Your Miss Penny

To help travelers avoid the pileup of indistinguishable black bags on the luggage carousel, Tumi has enlisted the graffiti artist John Matos to decorate a group of its lightweight Vapor cases. Matos, who goes by Crash, started spray-painting walls in the Bronx in 1975 and was showing in galleries and museums by the 1980s. For the Tumi project -- which will be limited to 1,000 of each case in the four-piece collection -- Matos explains that he ''didn't sit there thinking, What would be cool on a Tumi bag?'' If he'd thought of himself as just a tagger for hire, he says, ''the work wouldn't have come out as good.'' $445 to $595; tumi.com. BRUCE PASK

LEET--William A.,on February 22, 2011, a New York lawyer for more than 40 years, passed away peacefully at Syosset North Shore Hospital in New York. Survived by his adoring wife of 20 years, Carol. Loving father of Alicia Stammer and Bradley Leet. Caring step-dad to Lorraine Romanelli and Christopher Daley. Doting grandfather to Billy and Jamie Stammer, Isabella and Elizabeth Romanelli and Connor Daley. Devoted owner of Molly and Anabelle. Bill loved the arts, politics, great books and mostly his family, friends and partners. We all will miss Bill's intense intelligence, great laugh and genuine curiosity. Memorial Service to be held on April 2, 2011 at 11am at the Roslyn Presbyterian Church, 140 East Broadway, Roslyn, NY 11576. (516-621-3139). Donations in Bill's honor can be made to the William A. Leet Memorial Fund, 240 Hamlet Drive, Jericho, NY 11753. Donations will be used to award scholarships to local artists.

PSATY--Milton R.,91, on March 25, 2011. His beloved wife of 69 years Beth, was at his side, devoted to him. Loved and revered, survived by daughters Renee (Marshall) Geller, Carol (Charles) Edinger, Rhoda (Stuart) Holzer; sister, Reba Wist; grandchildren Brian, Corinne, Dean, Jayson (Stacy), Daniel (Patricia), Brooke (Chris), Craig and Leah (Ethan); great-grandchildren Sage, Reece, Hudson, Ava, Liza, Shelby, Dylan, Brooklyn and Charlie; niece, Ronda Chaney and nephew Andrew Wist. Born in Brooklyn to immigrant Jewish parents, Milton lived the American Dream. As a teenager he worked in his fathers small roofing shop. At 17 he started his own business which became one of the premier waterproofing and restoration contractors in New York. He and Beth met as teenagers, married in 1940, and were life long inseparable lovers. His twinkle, his charm, his quiet and powerful presence will always be with us. Contributions in his memory may be made to Community Synagogue of Rye, NY.

T: TRAVEL The cover article this weekend about the actor Sean Penn and his charitable efforts in Haiti refers incorrectly to his relief group. It is known legally as J/P Haitian Relief Organization, not Jenkins/Penn Haitian Relief Organization. (When the group first came together, the J referred to Diana Jenkins, a philanthropist and entrepreneur, a co-founder.)

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the amateur-wrestling movie ''Win Win'' misspelled the surname of one of the actors. He is Alex Shaffer, not Shafer. And another caption and the headline referred imprecisely to the place in which amateur wrestling takes place. It is on a mat, not in a ring.

McLEAN--Robert Ludlow, age 79, died peacefully at home on March 22, 2011. Colonel McLean graduated from Princeton University in 1952, and earned his MBA from New York University. He served in the army as a guided missile officer, and remained in the Army Reserves for over 30 years. After his active military duty, he was an engineer at the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory's thermonuclear fusion experiment, followed by a distinguished career in finance for 40 years. He was Chairman of the Alumni and Friends of Princeton University ROTC, Chairman of Squadron A, governor of The St. Andrews Society, the Robert Burns Society, and the Association of the U.S. Army. He is survived by his wife, Linda Durfee McLean, two daughters, Elissa McLean and Maggie McLean Suniewick, and three grandchildren. Memorial Service at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street, Tuesday, March 29, 2011 at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in his memory to Cure PSP, 30 E. Padonia Road, Suite 201, Timonium, MD 21093, or at CurePSP.org

THE NEWS Prime Minister Stephen Harper's Conservative government in Canada was toppled by a no-confidence vote, forcing a new election. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Harper ruled for five years without a majority in Parliament, mainly by maneuvering to keep rival parties from joining forces against him. They toppled him once before, in 2008, but he rallied to win a fresh mandate in the election that followed. This time may be different: the no-confidence vote also included a rare finding of contempt of Parliament, and there were hints that the left-of-center parties might manage to form a coalition.

Enormous suitcases, a digital camera and fashion-pack friends like Hamish Bowles and Christian Louboutin are constant companions for the on-the-dash textile designer Carolina Irving, whose finds in souks and museums inspire her delicately patterned, vintage-looking pastels. Born in Miami to Venezuelan parents and raised in Paris, she developed a passion for antique textile design in college. ''My fabrics look old, hand printed, vegetable dyed,'' Irving says. ''A modern twist isn't me at all.'' VALERIE STIVERS-ISAKOVA

THE fashion designer Carmen Marc Valvo and his partner, Christian Knaust, the president of Mr. Valvo's couture house, were famous among their friends for hosting enormous cocktail parties in their apartment on the 28th floor of the Majestic on Central Park West. Enormous, as in 200 people on average, Mr. Knaust said. But with both of them approaching 60, the couple decided it was time to simplify their lives and sell the sprawling 10-room co-op, where partygoers could take in park views from four different corners.

DAVIS--George Linn, passed away March 2, 2011. Born in Des Moines, Iowa to James Cox Davis and Elizabeth Linn Davis on July 9, 1934, he grew up in Washington, DC and Cleveland, OH. He graduated from the University School in Cleveland (later a Trustee), Yale University Class of 1956 (Editor of the Yale Banner), and Harvard Business School Class of 1958. A recognized expert in credit analysis, cash flow lending, and risk management, he was a successful senior executive in financial services at First National City Bank (New York and Sydney), First National Bank of Chicago, and returned to New York as Group Executive of the National Division of Citibank overseeing corporate and investment banking. In 1990 he founded Scarborough Partners, Inc. to provide consulting, litigation support and interim management. He was appointed by US regulators as CEO of First American Bankshares in Washington, D.C. to restructure the bank post B.C.C.I. ownership issues; later he served as Chairman and CEO of Banco de Venezuela International in Miami. He served on corporate and non-profit boards including Sealy, Inc., Syscon and Wyndham Foods Inc., and as Chairman of the National Stroke Association, Chairman of the Chicago March of Dimes, Director of The Lincoln Park Zoological Society and Trustee of the Central Park Conservancy. He is survived by his beloved wife of 43 years, Mary Graham Davis, five sons, James, Elliott, George, Stephen and Thomas and their wives, twelve grandchildren and his brothers James C. Davis III and Clark P. Davis. His sister, Linn Davis Swain, predeceased him. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, May 10th, 2011 at 3pm at St. James Episcopal Church, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the George Davis Memorial Fund at the National Stroke Association, 9707 East Easter Lane, Centennial, CO 80112 or www.stroke.org/ georgedavismemorial.

Joumana Haddad, ''the Oprah of Lebanon,'' is flirting with a fatwa. In the Arab world, suddenly she's everywhere, a dark-haired, golden-eyed looker sashaying onto talk shows in stiletto heels, provoking Hezbollah with her contempt for Shariah law, penning newspaper columns and books about Arab gender politics, publishing a racy magazine and flashing a winning smile as a judge on Lebanon's ''Celebrity Duets.'' This Arab Queen of All Media is more nighttime than afternoon, and she's definitely not a girlfriend. A poet and the cultural page editor of the Lebanese daily An-Nahar, she started publishing Jasad (''body'' in Arabic), a quarterly erotic magazine, in 2008, with articles by intellectuals and poets about masturbation, homosexuality, fetishism and polygamy alongside antique photos of nude Arab boys luxuriating in voluptuous Ottoman settings and close-ups of female genitalia. Tame fare by Western standards, but guaranteed to steam the turbans, especially with a woman behind it.

COOPER--William Charles, M.D.,Professor Emeritus of Ophthalmology, Department of Ophthalmology at New York-Presbyterian Hospital Weill Medical College of Cornell University, died Thursday, March 24th in Englewood, NJ. He was 80. He graduated magna cum laude from Franklin and Marshall College where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. He received his M.D. degree from Cornell University Medical College in 1956 where he was elected to Alpha Omega Alpha honorary society. He served his internship at University Hospitals of Cleveland, following which he entered the U.S. Army as a Captain, serving in Germany. His Ophthalmology residency was taken at Edward S. Harkness Eye Institute of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center where he remained for 24 years before returning to his alma mater in 1984. In 1988 he was named Medical Director, New York Hospital Queens Eye Center. Dr. Cooper served on numerous committees including the Admission Committee of Cornell University Medical College, and was Director of Resident training in the Department of Ophthalmology. He published many scientific articles and was considered an authority in Ophthalmic Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery. Additionally he was a specialist in Graves disease and plastic surgery of the orbit and was the inventor of the Cooper Tube used in tear duct drainage. A Founding Member of the New York Orbit Society, he also served as President of New York Ophthalmological Society and the National Eye Study Club. He was a board member of Knickerbocker Country Club, the Englewood Field Club and the Englewood Community Chest. Survived by his wife of 55 years, Elizabeth (Slater); daughters Elizabeth Tracy Cooper and husband Peter Drippe' and Colleen Robertson Cooper and husband David Bloom; and five grandchildren: Cooper and Paige Drippe' and Courtney, Jack and Griffin Bloom. Dr. Cooper was a deeply loved husband, father, grandfather and friend and inspiring professor to countless residents. His sharp wit and humor will live on through the many lives he touched. According to his wishes, the body was cremated; there was no funeral service. Those wishing to remember him may do so by donating in his honor to the Franklin & Marshall Fund in support of Scholarships, P.O. Box 3003, Lancaster, PA 17604-3003 or the Residency program at New York Hospital Queens, www.nyhq.org, Ways to Give W.C. Cooper NYHQ Eye Center Educational Fund.

''The most highly acclaimed show on television and it can't get back on the air? Unacceptable.'' Roberta Lipp, who with her sister Deborah operates a ''Mad Men'' fan site. The show's next season may not start until late 2011 or early 2012 because of money disputes involving the creator, the studio and the network. ''It's pretty much a goat rodeo until someone sorts it out.'' Drew Sievers, chief executive of mFoundry, which makes mobile payment software for merchants and banks. Banks are competing with carriers and companies like Apple and Google for a piece of the mobile payment market.

COOPER--William C.,M.D. We mourn the passing of our colleague, friend, and former director division of Ophthalmology, William C. Cooper, M.D. Dr. Cooper was a member of the New York Hospital Queens' medical staff for more than 17 years, prior to his retirement last fall. He was the first director of the Queens Eye Center and was instrumental in modernizing and expanding the NYHQ Eye Service. He also served as Professor of Ophthalmology at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University. During his tenure at the Queens Eye Center, he treated thousands of community members to help preserve and protect the gift of their eyesight. As a generous, gifted scholar and clinician, he taught countless medical students and residents to do the same. A number of his former students currently serve in clinical leadership positions around the country. On behalf of our trustees, administration, employees and medical staff, as well as the dedicated physicians and staff of the NYHQ Eye Center, we offer our deepest condolences to his wife Elizabeth Cooper, his two daughters and his grandchildren. In memory of his lifelong passion for teaching, the Dr. William C. Cooper NYHQ Eye Center Education Fund has been established. Donations may be made via www.nyhq.org/ways--to--give. George F. Heinrich, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees Stephen S. Mills, President & Chief Executive Officer John E. Sciortino, Senior Vice President & Chief Operating Officer Stephen Rimar, M.D., Senior Vice President & Chief Medical Officer William G. Wolff, M.D., Chairman, Medical Board Jack M. Dostoyevsky wrote about the magic of a change of place. And as Adan Jodorowsky can attest, it doesn't hurt to change your name and your language while you're at it. In 2004, in a cheap hotel in Mexico City, the 31-year-old singer (and the son of the cult filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky) was reborn as Adanowsky after taking part in a shamanic ritual. But it wasn't until he left his native Paris for Chile and translated his lyrics from French to Spanish that he and his career started to go places. Lately, he splits his time between Mexico City, Los Angeles, Paris and anywhere the tour for his melancholy new album, ''Amador,'' takes him. Catch him if you can. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

METROPOLITAN Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Ruth Sergel, who started a project to write the names of victims of the the Triangle Waist Company fire in chalk in front of the places they lived, described incorrectly two plays written by her father, Christopher Sergel. An adaptation of ''Winesburg, Ohio'' ran briefly on Broadway in 1958, and an adaptation of ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' never played on Broadway. So neither of them were ''Broadway hits.''

BERGER--Adolph J. (Ady), 81, passed away at his home in Miami, Florida on March 25, 2011. He was a pure, righteous and honorable man who brought grace to the world. He graduated with Masters Degrees from the Tuck School of Business and the Thayer School of Engineering at Dartmouth. He leaves his wife and loving partner of 55 years, Helene Reiback Berger. He was a proud and devoted father to Dr. Mark Berger (Dr. Victoria Green Berger) and to Dr. Bonnie Berger (Dr. Tom Leighton) and loving grandfather to Emily and Madeline Berger and to Alexander and Rachel Leighton. Ady came to South Florida in 1957 and founded Pasadena Homes together with his brotherin-law, Leonard Miller. Together they built the company into one of Broward County's leading home builders and land developers. He was President of the South Florida Builders Association and served on numerous charitable and community organizations over the years, including the Greater Miami Jewish Federation. Donations may be made to the Helene and Adolph Berger Family Foundation of the Greater Miami Jewish Federation, 4200 Biscayne Blvd., Miami, FL 33137.

PFLASTER ROSNER--Claire. The management, brokers and staff of Warburg Realty mourn the unexpected loss of our beloved colleague Claire Rosner. Claire was unique. First and foremost a sculptor, Claire had a long career as an agent - a job at which she excelled when she put her mind to it. Impervious to technology, funny, quirky, head strong, warm and charming, she will be impossible to replace in our office and our hearts. We extend all our sympathy to her husband Felix Pflaster, her son David, daughter Victoria and her grandson Judah whom she lovingly referred to as "Mushkie". The world will be a less fun and interesting place without Claire in it.

Marietta Ladies', Men's and Children's Wear has been part of my neighborhood in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, for over half a century. Hand-lettered signs fill the display window (''Heavy sox, $1.50 a pair''). Inside, the walls are lined with honey-colored wooden drawers stuffed with bras and pajamas. Two elderly brothers run the shop, which they inherited from their mother. I often go in to buy T-shirts (rung up on a cash register that, like the brothers, is old but still working). When my friend and I walked by the store, she remarked that she loved it. I told her I did, too, especially because the brothers were perversely opposed to raising prices and you could get a three-pack of men's briefs for $5. She laughed and said: ''Oh, I've never actually been inside. But I like the idea of it. It really adds character to the neighborhood.''

The question ''Would you like iceberg ice in ''your water glass tonight?'' is the kind typically reserved for destinations of rarefied pomposity. A boutique Japanese cruise liner, say, or a nightclub in Moscow that only the oligarchs know about. But not in the interior of a Dodge Caliber doing the speed limit on Grenfell Drive, a highway lined by fir trees, the odd birch and an almost ridiculous number of moose. You find Grenfell Drive on the Northern Peninsula, a tip of land that shoots northward off the shore of Newfoundland, Canada. I was not here to see, or taste, icebergs. My quarry, also of the ocean and also having to do with dinner, was far more rare. I was on my way to a fishing lodge to eat an Atlantic salmon.

Roubaix, France, an old textile town near Lille, has stitched its fabric-driven past to the fashion-driven present. As part of its Maisons de Mode initiative, the regional government recently helped turn a disused cinder block warehouse into Le Vestiaire (right; 27 rue de l'Esperance; maisonsdemode.com), a complex of shops and ateliers for emerging designers. Stephane Martello, a k a Mister Crochet, knits Etsy-chic pieces like a tiered turtleneck capelet. The dapper designer Eric Garde at Sakal does a wide range of sleek overcoats for men and women in everything from fine wool to faux-fur pile. The shop Mercredi (Wednesday, a half day for many happy French schoolchildren) has tot-size flannel shirts and pinafore dresses. And at Rhum Raisins (in a separate Maisons de Mode cluster at 101-107 avenue Jean Lebas), the three lovely Vermeulen sisters make pretty, structured clothes like a navy crepe dress with an empire waist and pleated skirt, and a sleeveless faux-fur patchwork minicoat with a stole collar. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

We will be based out of Kiev but are having a hard time narrowing down what other city we should visit there as our time is rather limited. Is it better to fly between cities to save time, or travel by train or bus?

When you stand in the middle of Times Square, it is easy to forget that the colonists settled in New York City because of its bounty of natural resources. Before there were skyscrapers and restaurants, the city's wealth was measured in flora and fauna. Early Dutch sailors were disoriented by the scent of wildflowers wafting out to sea from Manhattan. Even today, forests, marshes and meadows cover nearly one-eighth of the city. But it is not a safe haven for flowers. Of 1,357 native plant species documented in New York City's history, only 778 remain here. There are various reasons for their disappearance, but always the causal factor is human -- a pest we accidentally introduced, a habitat we made unwelcoming or destroyed altogether. Our urban lives are impoverished in their absence. Here is a selection of plants that have vanished from the city. Some thrive elsewhere; others are barely hanging on. And one has recently reappeared in New York City, a signal of hope in a concrete landscape.

FOR the last month, blogs have noted the similarity between the Proenza Schouler PS1 bag and the Target Mossimo Messenger bag. But on Wednesday, the Proenza designers, Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, became aware themselves when Mr. McCollough's sister in California e-mailed a photo of the Mossimo bag at her local Target. The designers say they are disappointed with Target. To be sure, the bags are not 100 percent identical. The Mossimo bag ($34.99) is made of fake leather, while the PS1 ($1,595 for the medium-size version) is genuine leather. The placement of the straps is slightly different, and the PS1 uses a distinctive metal fold-down closure whereas the Target model has an ordinary turn-key closure.

ROGERS--Adele Lefkowitz Manus, Of West Palm Beach, FL and Monmouth Beach, NJ, passed away on March 15. She was born December 30, 1924. She was the daughter of Max and Esther Lefkowitz of Manhattan, NY. She attended Julia Richmond High School and graduated Syracuse University Magna Cum Laude. She was a member of The Palm Beach and Navesink Country Clubs and a women's champion golfer. She was a smart, stunning, elegant woman and a timeless beauty with a big heart and a zest for life that was contagious amongst anyone who knew her. She is survived by her daughter, Jane von Richthofen; her son-in-law Rene von Richthofen; granddaughter Ann Jonas; her children Bart and Cindy Rogers, John Rogers, Marcy Rogers and her eight grandchildren and great-granddaughter. Quattlebaum Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, FL, (561)832-5171, is in charge of services.

Whether you're a Twitter user like Lady Gaga (millions and millions of followers) or, say, me (2,600 and growing!), you're always aware of roughly how many people follow you. It's just how people keep score on the site and compare themselves to friends and colleagues. But it turns out that counting followers is a seriously flawed way to measure a person's impact on Twitter. Even Twitter's co-founder, Evan Williams, made the point to me recently: someone with millions of followers may no longer post messages frequently, while someone followed by mere tens of thousands may be a prolific poster whose messages are amplified by others.

JUST when we thought it was time to put the Manic Panic away for good, Technicolor hair resurfaced on the fall runways. While performers like Nicki Minaj need no encouragement, the fashion world's collective obsession with the 18-year-old catwalk newcomer Charlotte Free -- easily recognizable by her shock of hot pink hair -- is proof of its sartorial cred. According to Didier Malige, the hairstylist who started it all at Proenza Schouler's spring 2010 show, ''The influence definitely comes from the street: people who surf or people who have very light blond hair and they play with the color.'' Suddenly, the seasonal vacillation between blond and brunet for models like Britt Maren and Siri Tollerod seems like such a snooze. HOLLY SIEGEL

The Left Bank's notorious Nazi lair has a new owner. Mazel tov? Last September, I was ensconced in red velour, seated in the grande salle of the Hotel Lutetia, on the Left Bank in Paris. I had just stumbled in from the hotel's chrome-accented brasserie, where I downed a half bottle of Sancerre and six Belon oysters, almost precisely where Simone de Beauvoir, in 1940, wrote a love letter to Sartre, whom she addressed as ''Most dear little being.''

ACKERLEY--Barry Allan. Entrepreneur, husband, father and grandfather, died early in the morning on March 21st. He was 76. Born in Des Moines, Iowa, Mr. Ackerley earned his B.S. in Business from the University of Iowa in 1956. He served in the United States Army from 1956 to 1958 and was stationed at Fort Dix, New Jersey. Mr. Ackerley's distinguished career in media and advertising began in New York in 1958 in sales for Better Homes & Gardens magazine. In 1963, he joined Stoner Outdoor Advertising and found his calling. He proved himself a highly capable operator with a strong acumen for business and in 1965, the Garvey Family of Kansas asked him to launch and operate Advan, a new outdoor advertising company that began with operations in Fresno and Bakersfield, CA and expanded in San Francisco and Oakland, CA. After building Advan into a highly successful and profitable business, Mr. Ackerley founded Golden West Outdoor with operations in Sacramento, CA and Colorado Springs, CO. In 1972, he was approached by his friend and fellow outdoor advertising colleague, Karl Eller, who asked him to run his national sales office for Combined Communications, an outdoor and broadcast media company based in New York. Ever the entrepreneur, in 1975 Mr. Ackerley purchased Obie Media in Seattle, WA. This company would become the foundation on which a national media and entertainment empire would be built, one day becoming The Ackerley Group, Inc., listed on the New York Stock Exchange. In 2002, when The Ackerley Group, Inc. was acquired by Clear Channel Worldwide, the company owned and operated 18 television stations, five radio stations and outdoor advertising operations in six states and over 20 markets. In 1983, Mr. Ackerley purchased the Seattle SuperSonics of the National Basketball Association to ensure the team would remain in Seattle, WA. Over the next 18 years, the Sonics became the region's most successful professional sports franchise. During his tenure as Owner, the Sonics appeared in the NBA playoffs 13 times which included four Pacific Division Championships, one Western Conference Championship and an appearance in the 1996 NBA Finals. Ever the innovator, Mr. Ackerley was one of the first sports owners in America to broadcast the team's games on both radio and television stations that he owned reaching more Sonics fans than ever before. Following the creation of Full House Sports & Entertainment under Mr. Ackerley's leadership, two successful sports franchises were launched: the Seattle SeaDogs of the Continental Indoor Soccer League who would win the 1997 CISL Championship and the Seattle Storm of the Women's National Basketball Association. Mr. Ackerley's record of community service and philanthropy both professionally and personally spanned over three decades and impacted communities across America. Through Ackerley Corporate Giving, the philanthropic arm of The Ackerley Group, the company annually contributed six percent of its annual gross revenues in cash and in-kind services to the communities it served. Additionally, in 1997, Mr. Ackerley and his wife Ginger established The Ginger and Barry Ackerley Foundation which focuses on early childhood education throughout the state of Washington. Mr. Ackerley was the recipient of many lifetime achievement awards. Among them were the Roosevelt High School (Des Moines, Iowa) Alumnus of the Year and the Sigma Chi Fraternity's Significant Sig Award. Along with his wife Ginger, Mr. Ackerley received the Corporate Council for the Arts Lifetime Achievement in the Arts award, the Anti-Defamation League's Torch of Liberty Award, Junior Achievement's Stanley O. McNaughton Award and became a Laureate of the Puget Sound Business Journal's Hall of Fame. Mr. Ackerley was deeply devoted family man. He enjoyed boating in the Pacific Northwest with his family; summers on San Juan Island with his grandchildren and winters in the California desert with family and friends. Mr. Ackerley is survived by his wife Ginger, his daughter Kim Ackerley Cleworth, his two sons Christopher and Ted Ackerley and seven grandchildren Henry, Atty, Charlie, Anabelle, Benjamin, Hunter and Ashley. Memorial services will be held at 12:00pm on Thursday, April 7th at St. Mark's Cathedral, 1245 10th Avenue East, Seattle, WA with the Rev. Doyt L. Conn, Jr. presiding. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be directed to: Eisenhower Medical Hospital/Foundation 39000 Bob Hope Drive, Rancho Mirage, CA 92270.

When Hotel Americano opens next month in New York, it will be the 11th hotel in 11 years from Grupo Habita, a company not well known north of the border but considered Mexico's boutique hotel pioneer in the Ian Schrager mold. The Americano is also the company's first venture stateside, a 56-room property in a 10-story building designed by the Mexican architect Enrique Norten (who also designed Hotel Habita, the company's first property in Mexico City) with interiors by the Parisian designer Arnaud Montigny. On an industrial block of gallery-packed west Chelsea, the hotel is well poised to be an art-world home base. ''Because of where it's located it has to be a little bit industrial, a little bit gritty,'' says Carlos Couturier, co-founder of Grupo Habita. Norten's design for the glass building includes metal mesh cladding and an exterior elevator that ferries restaurant patrons from street level directly to the rooftop restaurant and pool. (A separate, interior elevator provides access to guest rooms.) A modern ethos - whether with a vintage bent or one more of this century - permeates both public and private spaces. Guest rooms feature Kengo Kuma-style, low-to-the-ground platform beds and black vinyl Zanotta bean bag chairs alongside less aggressively slick accouterments like touch-tone phones, denim bathrobes by Loden Dager (which also outfitted the staff) and harmonicas for sale in the minibar. In-room iPads are loaded with music as well as the Hotel Americano version of a city guide, with regularly updated listings of things to do, both in the ZIP code and beyond. Some north-facing rooms have views of the Empire State Building, but to Couturier, ''the best rooms in the house are the ones where you're looking at fire escapes. That's how you know you're in New York, not Paris or Shanghai.''

SANDIFER--Lucie Eveleen Dourif, August 27, 1919 to March 12, 2011. Born in Haute Savoie, France and raised in Paris, she was the daughter of Major Henri Dourif and Eveleen Huillard Dourif of Paris and Huntington, West Virginia where Major Dourif co-founded the chemical and color company, SUCO. She graduated from Vassar College in 1941 with a BA in English, and later from Columbia Teacher's College with an MA in Early Childhood Education. She maintained a lifelong interest in children, education and France. During the war, she taught at Greenwich Settlement House in New York City, and was active in French war relief efforts. In 1945, she married Navy Lt. John Seay Sandifer, a graduate of Yale School of Architecture and the Beaux Arts in Paris. Following the birth of their first child, they moved from New York City to Greenwich, CT where the family grew to five children: Henri-Philippe of Guilford, CT; Michael of Greenwich, CT; Claire of Paris, France; John of Paris, France, and Nicole of Durham, CT. In Connecticut, Lucie Sandifer taught French at St. Mary's, and the Greenwich High School for many years. She was also active as President in the Alliance Francaise of Greenwich, and she was a founding member of the French American Aid for Children in New York City, serving as its President from 1955 to 1965. She was married for sixty-one years to her husband, who predeceased her in 2007. Later in life, they devoted considerable energy to restoring La Tourbeille, the family home in the Dordogne region of France. She is survived by her five children, ten grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.
T: MEN A book excerpt on March 13 about the life of Yuri Gagarin, a Soviet cosmonaut, misspelled the name of a luxury resort where he and other cosmonauts stayed in 1961. It is Tesseli, not Kissely.

Most people keep their New Year's resolutions simple: exercise, save money, volunteer. Mya Henry and Eric Werner took on something more challenging - they made a pact to leave New York and open a restaurant in Tulum, Mexico. Last December, after seven months of planning, building and traveling around the country in search of antiques, they opened Hartwood, which they describe as ''Mexican farmhouse rustic.'' Werner, who cooked at Peasant in Manhattan and Vinegar Hill House in Brooklyn, helms the kitchen, while Henry, who worked for the Soho Grand Hotel, runs the front of the house. Henry blames her naivete for fueling their project. ''I've never worked so hard in my life - despite being in this paradise.'' Minnesota catcher Joe Mauer has won three American League batting titles and was the A.L.'s most valuable player in 2009. He is the cover athlete for MLB 11 the Show, the new PlayStation game that features 3-D technology. Mauer, 27, who signed an eight-year, $184 million extension with the Twins before last season, was in Manhattan recently to promote the game. Q.Do you consider yourself the best player in baseball?A.I consider myself to be a good baseball player, definitely. I think there's more important things out there than just saying, ''I'm the best.'' I'd like to be on the best team and win the World Series. I'm confident in what I can do, and I work hard at trying to become better and better.Q.Before you signed an extension with the Twins, did you consider the possibility of being a Yankee?A.I'd be lying to say that I didn't. It's something that you're curious about when you consider testing the free-agent market, but looking back on it, I always wanted to be a Twin because I grew up in Minnesota. My ultimate goal is winning a World Series, and I think we can do that in Minnesota, so I'm happy to stay home.Q.What is it like to have grown up in Minnesota and now be its biggest baseball star?A.It's pretty crazy. It's great to be able to have my parents and grandparents at every home game; it's something I value a lot. To see your family and friends around all the time, it's pretty neat. Everyone still treats me the same, and I wouldn't have it any other way.Q.Who are some of the toughest pitchers you have faced?A.Obviously, there are a lot of great pitchers, a lot of guys who go out there and everything seems to be working for them. C. C. Sabathia seems to have a lot of those days, and others who come to mind are Zack Greinke and Felix Hernandez. They always seem to be on top of their game.Q.Jorge Posada of the Yankees will be used as a designated hitter and not catch as often as he used to. Do you dread that fate late in your career?A.Jorge has been a great player for a long time, and it's pretty amazing to see what he has been able to do over his career. But he's a little bit older, and you can't play baseball forever. I think when I get to that point where I'm not catching as much, hopefully I can help the team in other areas.Q.What is your forecast for the Twins' season?A.We're going to go out and try and win the division again and try to get back to the playoffs. That's our goal every year, and we feel like we have a good shot to do that. My main goal is to put a World Series ring on my finger.Q.You have had trouble hitting home runs at Target Field. Are you worried about that?A.Well, it was a new park for us, and much like David Wright at Citi Field, I had some trouble getting used to a new park. I'm not too concerned about hitting home runs, so I'm not going to adjust my swing. I'm more concerned about winning ballgames.Q.With the Metrodome roof collapsing during the football season, are you happy the Twins are no longer playing there?A.Yeah, I'm happy we're out of there. I don't know what we would have done if we had to play a full season there. I'm happy to be playing baseball at Target Field, outdoors. It's pretty good.Q.Who was your baseball idol growing up?A.I really admired Kent Hrbek and Kirby Puckett, I enjoyed the way they played the game. Hrbek was a Minnesota guy who played at home, like me, and Puckett always had a smile on his face, so they would be my favorites.
Theater Jason Zinoman

KLYVER--Lydia Matkovic, 69, of Southport, CT passed away peacefully on March 23, 2011 at Memorial Sloan Kettering in NY. The cause was lung cancer. Born January 30, 1942 in Queens, NY, she was the daughter of the late Ivo and Ksenija Matkovic. Lydia was a Realtor for Nicholas H. Fingerlly Real Estate. She was also an active volunteer in the community serving on many charity boards including the Junior League of Fairfield and the Near and Far Aid. Lydia loved cooking, entertaining, playing tennis and golf and most of all spending time with family and friends. She is survived by her loving husband of 47 years, Dan; sons Kenneth of Nashville, TN, Adam and Todd of Southport, CT and daughter Janna Klyver Cord of Quogue, NY. She also leaves behind her seven beloved grandchildren: Eleanor, Thatcher, Samuel, Brooks, Hayden, Nicholas and Sadie. Lydia will be deeply missed and remember always for her passionate dedication to her family and friends. A memorial service will be held Thursday, March 31st at 11am at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, CT. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10065
