Related: Adventures in Humanitarian Tourism On a hot morning in January, at the Petionville Internally Displaced Person camp in suburban Port-au-Prince, Haiti, a four-wheel dirt bike pulled up outside the tent hospital, bearing an elderly woman with a deep gash in her cheek. While a group of medics assisted the patient inside, Sean Penn ambled over from under a tree where he had been having a meeting with one of his camp workers. He walked with a slightly bowlegged cowboy gait, a walkie-talkie crackling at his waistband, a cigarette dangling from his mouth. Having glanced into the tent and ascertained that the situation was in hand, he turned his rather dour gaze on a newly arrived reporter. Penn has never had conventional movie-star looks, but he does have the arguably superior gift of a magnificently interesting face. When he is in grooming mode, he tends to shellac his hair into a high, rather splendid, Little Richard-style pompadour, but today, as on most days in Haiti, the hair had been allowed to collapse into a dusty quiff. With his big, arrow-shaped nose and his heavy eyelids hanging at half-mast, he emanated the slightly sinister allure of a fairground carny. ''You ready to see the camp?'' he muttered.

Humboldt's atmospheric caprices echo the character of a county that proudly resists any consensus about what constitutes a sane or normal way of life. A five-hour drive north from San Francisco, Humboldt is a mostly rural coastal region a little less than twice the size of Delaware, inhabited by 129,000 or so artists, back-to-the-landers, outdoorsfolk, slow-food entrepreneurs and urban refugees who found the Upper Haight too staid. The county is also home to a large community of people whose knack for growing high-quality marijuana has made ''Humboldt'' a sacred word to dope smokers worldwide. Cannabis cultivation is more or less rampant throughout the county, though the outdoor industrial-scale plantations lie mostly in southern Humboldt (''SoHum,'' to locals), where rough-hewn settlements give off an aura of people being up to something. A fair proportion of homes visible to highway traffic have additions built of plastic sheeting. Much of SoHum's population lives up rutted, hillside tracks where tourists, locals caution, would be most unwise to venture on their own.

There's a lot that goes into opening a new school in New York City. For the Department of Education, the process demands several layers of discussions and decisions that include finding a place for the school, fine-tuning its academic mission and, especially in the case of high schools, settling on a name that will make it stand out in a crowded, competitive field. Among the city's nearly 1,600 schools, there are more whose name includes ''academy'' (199) than ''preparatory'' (40). There are more that have ''arts'' (55) than ''science'' (42); more ''leadership'' (35) and ''studies'' (23) than ''learning'' (22); more ''urban'' (26) than ''park'' (21).

David Burke (above), the American chef with a mini-empire of restaurants and an outsize personality, is showcasing his talents at 35,000 feet. Through April, he is designing dishes for first and business classes on intercontinental Lufthansa flights out of Germany, part of the airline's ''Star Chef'' program. MUENSTERBERGER--Werner, a noted Freudian psychoanalyst, collector of African art, and prolific author in the fields of psychology and art, 97, died on March 6, 2011. Holder of three doctorates, in medicine, anthropology, and art history, he was longtime associate professor of psychiatry at Downstate Medical Center, State University of New York, and also taught at the universities of Columbia, Baylor, and Cologne. In 1947, he arrived in the U.S., from his native Germany where he had spent 18 months in hiding during World War II, to establish his psychoanalytic practice. His patients included many well-known figures in politics and the arts and he continued to consult with patients until his death. He began collecting African art at the age of 13, was author of several books, including his best-known work, "Collecting: An Unruly Passion," published in 1994. Dr. Muesterberger is survived by his associate and companion, Celestin Clamra; two stepdaughters, Helene Jackson Magill and Rev. Posy Jackson; his beloved dachshund, Mandy; and by many friends and admirers worldwide. A celebration of his life will be held in mid-April in New York; for information, please email clamra@yahoo.com.

PALERMO--David S.,81, died March 3, 2011 at home in Larchmont, NY, after a long illness. Born in Norwood, MA, August 21, 1929, to Alfonso and Carolyn Palermo. Beloved husband of 30 years of Marion Gindes, loving father of Scott, Craig, Lynn, and Lisa Palermo, and step-daughter, Jessica Hornstein, grandfather to 11 grandchildren, and brother of Mary Jane Wallace and the late Penual Allan. He held a Ph.D. in Experimental Child Psychology from the State University of Iowa (now University of Iowa). Conducted pioneering research in child cognitive development and language acquisition. Author of over 100 scholarly works and a book, Psychology of Language. Retired as Professor Emeritus from the Pennsylvania State University. In retirement, he continued to pursue his passion for photography. A kind and generous man, he will be missed. He donated his body to the Columbia University Medical School.

In this week's Critics' Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Katsuhiro Otomo's 1988 animated film "Akira." The film takes place in a post-apocalyptic neo-Tokyo filled with teenage motorcycle gangs, protesters, violent revolutionaries and more. "'Akira' defies genre," Mr. Scott says. "It's a boy's adventure wrapped in a detective story tucked inside a nuclear allegory surrounded by a dystopian fable." Although the film moves rapidly through these ideas, "it does so in the service of creating a sublime and radical new art form," adds Mr. Scott. Have you seen "Akira?" Please share your thoughts.

In a January item about the expansion of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament from 65 to 68 teams, I cited the recent Final Four appearances by George Mason and Butler as evidence that midmajor teams might have a case for some of the extra at-large bids. I went on to write that "underdogs make great stories and are very popular. It stands to reason, the more chances they get, the more they'll capitalize."

The news magazine "60 Minutes" and reality shows on Sunday topped the night's ratings in prime time for CBS. Although Nielsen's estimates are imprecise because of a 17-minute overrun of the network's late-afternoon coverage of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament, the preliminary results show "60 Minutes" leading the night over all with about 13.4 million viewers. The rest of the CBS lineup drew slightly smaller audiences: "The Amazing Race" (roughly 10.9 million), "Undercover Boss" (11.8 million) and "CSI: Miami" (10.6 million). ABC ranked second with solid results for "Secret Millionaire" at 8 p.m. (10.5 million) but low ratings at 9 and 10 for reruns of "Desperate Housewives" (4.7 million) and "Brothers & Sisters" (2.7 million). NBC was close behind in third, and Fox was fourth.

Atticus Finch, the heroic lawyer at the heart of Harper Lee's Pulitzer Prize-winning "To Kill a Mockingbird," is best remembered for his colorblindness in the face of small-town racism. In his 1962 Oscar-winning portrayal of Atticus, Gregory Peck wore a pair of tortoiseshell-style spectacles that aptly symbolized the clarity and wisdom so central to his character.

The traditional box score is a tool primarily designed to measure offense, and as a result, the work of some of the N.B.A.'s top defenders can go unnoticed. Without a quantitative point of reference to indicate who is succeeding on defense, an accurate assessment often requires a deliberate viewing approach. Nick Collison's rotations and Toney Douglas's  blanketing of ball-handlers may not show up in an easily countable form, but those who know where to look can see the quiet defensive impact of either player.

When Jonathan Ive, Apple's senior vice president of industrial design, was a boy, a Braun juicer designed by Dieter Rams (above) made a big impression: "At a glance, you knew exactly what it was and exactly how to use it." So it's fitting that Ive, whose own work reflects the German master's principles, wrote the introduction to "As Little Design as Possible: The Work of Dieter Rams," to be published by Phaidon in June. Written by Sophie Lovell and Klaus Kemp, the book examines Rams's "less but better" philosophy, as illustrated by the hundreds of products (like the coffee grinder shown here) that he produced for Braun, as well as by the iconic 606 shelving system for Vitsoe, still in production after 50 years. On May 2, the Vitsoe shop at 33 Bond Street will open an exhibition of early 606 pieces, while Braun is producing watches - including the one shown here - inspired by models that Rams and Dietrich Lubs designed in the 1970s. The Smithsonian's National Museum of African American History and Culture has withdrawn its controversial offer to spend $750,000 on 1949 murals of early black Californians. The African-American painters Charles Alston and Hale Woodruff created the scenes for the lobby of a Los Angeles insurance company's headquarters, designed by the architect Paul Williams, who was also African American. Preservationists opposed the plan to remove the canvases, commissioned by the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company, which is being liquidated. The Smithsonian's statement withdrawing its offer, issued over the weekend, was announced at a court hearing on Monday. (The hearing  settled the fate of Golden State's archive, which will be going to UCLA.) Further proceedings in the next few months will decide if the paintings, which have been appraised at up to $5 million, stay onsite. The museum stated that it is "pleased to learn that members of the arts and cultural community of Los Angeles are working to retain" the paintings.

Many of those filers, the Internal Revenue Service says, should begin getting their refunds in April.

One of the great pleasures of reading Roberto Bolaño is reading Roberto Bolaño on reading. On the New York Review of Books blog is an excerpt (found via 3Quarksdaily) from "Between Parentheses," a collection of his essays, articles and speeches, translated by Natasha Wimmer and due out next month from New Directions. In it, Bolaño recounts a youthful adventure in book stealing - his favorite, "Pierre Louÿs, with pages as thin as Bible paper," but also Champfleury, Samuel Pepys, the Goncourt brothers, Alphonse Daudet and Rulfo." A version of this unusual shoplifter's library finds its way into the beginning of "The Savage Detectives," giving readers of that novel the double pleasure of recognition.

One reason the grotesque is so compelling is its ravaged beauty. Bound up in the distorting horror, at least in art, is an absurdity that also makes its appearance rather comic. All of those elements are in play in David Altmejd's dazzling new show at the Andrea Rosen Gallery, where decapitated heads grow glittering crystals, fossilized angels are crucified within the walls, and agglomerations of human ears ornament plexiglass cages swarming with jewel-like, plastic bees.

Next month, the Indianapolis Museum of Art will open to the public the house that Eero Saarinen designed for the industrialist J. Irwin Miller and his wife, Xenia, giving design pilgrims one more reason to visit Columbus, Ind., the mecca of Modernist architecture that Miller sponsored. The stone- and glass-walled house, which Saarinen completed in 1957, includes about 14 acres of landscaping by Dan Kiley and meticulously preserved interiors by Alexander Girard, who sank the world's first conversation pit into its living room. The Eames Aluminum Group chairs were designed for the Millers, whose dining table was a precursor to Saarinen's Tulip pedestal series. The couple lived in the house until their deaths (his in 2004, hers in 2008) and left behind a portrait not just of enlightened 20th-century arts patronage but of family life as well. "It's not like the Farnsworth House, which was a weekend getaway, or the Glass House, which is purely an architect's personal expression of his ideas," says Bradley Brooks, the museum's director of historic resources. "It had to accommodate entertaining and employees and five kids, and yet it was still resolved so beautifully.

When the Denver Nuggets traded Carmelo Anthony and Chauncey Billups to the Knicks for Raymond Felton, Wilson Chandler, Danilo Gallinari and Timofey Mozgov, it was almost guaranteed that the Nuggets were going to drop out of the tight playoff race in the Western Conference. But the exact opposite happened as the Nuggets went 12-4, solidifying their place in the playoff picture. Not only that, but the Nuggets now have the most efficient offense in the N.B.A., scoring 109.8 points per 100 possessions (the league average is 104.3 points per 100 possessions).

The story of a veteran director sharing the spotlight at a long-running film festival with his spouse and her directorial debut could have been the premise of an Edward Burns movie, if it weren't also his reality at the 2010 Tribeca Film Festival, which saw the debut of his ninth film, "Nice Guy Johnny," as well as "No Woman No Cry," the first by his wife, Christy Turlington Burns. But this year Mr. Burns gets a platform all to himself: the festival's organizers said on Monday that the closing night film of its 2011 program would be "Newlyweds," which Mr. Burns wrote, directed and stars in. It is the latest in a series of films (including "Ash Wednesday," "Looking for Kitty" and "Purple Violets") that have made their debuts at Tribeca.

The common tool is to "seed" highly ranked players or teams, so that they do not play each other prematurely.

Independent voters make up an influential voting bloc that frequently decides elections, but they are an unpredictable bunch. In 2008, just over half of independent voters threw their support behind Barack Obama and Congressional Democrats, yet by the election of 2010, they had swung back to supporting Republicans for Congress. Now, just a few months into the new Congress's term, more than twice as many independents approve of the job the president is doing than they do of the job Congress is doing, according to the latest CBS News poll.

Aviary, the 64-seat experimental drinks den scheduled to open April 1, is already well known to anxious cocktail geeks. But a second, much more secretive bar tucked underneath has so far gone largely unnoticed.

The Republican assault on the Environmental Protection Agency, including a proposed bill to repeal the agency's recent finding that carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases pose a threat to human health and welfare, goes too far, write two former E.P.A. chiefs, both appointed by Republican presidents. "Amid the virulent attacks on the E.P.A. driven by concern about overregulation, it is easy to forget how far we have come in the past 40 years," William D. Ruckelshaus and Christine Todd Whitman write. Will Swenson, a Tony Award nominee for his performance in "Hair" (2009) and a star of the new Broadway musical "Priscilla Queen of the Desert," will direct an independent film adaptation of Carol Lynn Pearson's play "Facing East." In the play, a Mormon couple grapple with their faith after the suicide of their gay son. Ms. Pearson, whose 1986 memoir, "Good-bye, I Love You," told the story of her husband's struggle to come out as a gay man and his eventual death from AIDS, also wrote the screenplay. Mr. Swenson has personal reasons for working on this project: "Getting through my own adolescence as a young Mormon was challenging as it was, but watching my best friend struggle with his identity as a gay teenager was heartbreaking," he said in a statement from the producers. Production is expected to begin in the fall. A percentage of the film's profits will be donated to the Trevor Project, a nationwide crisis and suicide prevention help line for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and questioning youth.

Tom Burr's delicately considered work comes in many forms. Recently he's been meticulously fastening blankets of various sizes, colors and textures with upholstery tacks to large, 6-foot-by-6-foot wooden panels. Another favorite medium is radiators. On view in his studio at this moment are four or five of them, which were sourced from a massive lot in New England and have all been treated to look similarly worn. One such radiator sits on a simple pedestal and is dressed in the artist's favorite old, gray Margiela sport coat. This subtle piece is distinctly not over the top, but it definitely takes you somewhere.

If you're a movie studio looking to change the subject from Zack Snyder's current movie, one surefire way to do it is to slip out a little news about his next one. Over the weekend, when Mr. Snyder's new fetishized fantasy-adventure, "Sucker Punch," failed to get off the ground, selling just $19 million in tickets on a budget of at least $80 million, Warner Brothers Pictures countered with an announcement that Mr. Snyder had found the actress who will play Lois Lane in his coming Superman movie. Amy Adams, an Academy Award nominee for "The Fighter," "Doubt" and "Junebug," will play that fearless Daily Planet reporter and sometime paramour to the Man of Steel and his alter ego, Clark Kent. In a statement to The Hollywood Reporter, Mr. Snyder described Ms. Adams as "one of the most versatile and respected actresses in films today" with "the talent to capture all of the qualities we love about Lois: smart, tough, funny, warm, ambitious and, of course, beautiful."

Come April, Prague wastes no time shedding its winter coats, joyfully ushering in spring with a swirl of pastel streamers, frisky, star-crossed lovers and dozens of hand-painted Easter eggs. The ancient tradition of men (playfully) "whipping" women with decorated willow sticks in exchange for plum brandy and colored eggs may be on the outs these days, but elements of the practice are still very much a part of the Eastertime fun and games. Willow sticks, painted eggs, as well as a wide assortment of beverages are all on tap at the city's festive outdoor markets, which run through May 1 (daily, from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m.).

Rather, it's that, of the first 89 picks to be made, a full 12 of them (or 13.5%) belong to the Tampa Bay Rays.

THAUER--Peter Ernest , a retired attorney, age 71, died on March 24, 2011 at his winter home in Vero Beach, Florida. Born in New York, he was a resident of Saddle River, New Jersey. He was the only child of Ernest Moritz Thauer, president of FAO Schwartz and Rose Adele Thauer, a homemaker and grew up in Oradell, New Jersey. He was a graduate of Blair Academy, Princeton University and The University of Chicago Law School. He served as Assistant General Counsel at Avon Products and most recently as Senior Vice President, Law and Environment and General Counsel and Secretary of Cambrex Corporation in East Rutherford, New Jersey. Mr. Thauer was the devoted husband of the late Nancy Weny Thauer, loving father of son Peter Beck and his wife Elizabeth Thauer of Ridgewood, NJ, and Susan Bradford and her husband C. Louis Moravec III of Philadelphia, PA. He was the cherished grandfather of Kristen and Jenna Thauer and Amelia Moravec. Peter enjoyed golf and was a member of Arcola Country Club and John's Island Club. He also loved to read, travel and spend time with his family and friends. A memorial service will be held Friday, April 1, 2011 at 11:00am at St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church, 169 Fairmount Road, Ridgewood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, New York 10018. Services: C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ.
HANDLER--James Lawrence. March 28, 1968 - March 4, 2011. Jimmy, our beautiful brother, all our love forever and ever. Your adoring sisters, Amy and Beth

Facebook is seeking out Mr. Gibbs ahead of an initial public offering planned for early 2012, these people said.

FERRARO--Geraldine. With profound sorrow Fordham Law School mourns the passing of Geraldine Ferraro '60, loyal alumna, former assistant district attorney, congresswoman, ambassador, and the first female and Italian-American Vice Presidential candidate of a major political party. A New York City schoolteacher, Geraldine attended Fordham Law in the evening and was one of two women in her class. Throughout her career she broke down barriers and inspired a generation of young women. She was fearless in challenging injustice and tireless in devoting herself to those in need. Her life was the embodiment of the School's motto "in the service of others". She will always remain at the heart of our community. We express our deepest sympathy to her family. Michael M. Martin, Interim Dean, Fordham Law School
SAHN--Dorothy Siegal. She was the ultimate New Yorker. I will miss her and the wonderful times we shared. Carol

Politicians define themselves by choosing enemies, and exemplars. Suddenly, President Obama's choices on Libya are reshaping his profile in unpredictable ways as he heads into the 2012 election season. The president and his advisers have already highlighted the central factors that influenced Mr. Obama's decision to act militarily, a process he plans to explain more fully to the nation at 7:30 p.m. Monday.

Banks pouring money into technology funds, wealthy clients and institutions clamoring to get pieces of start-ups, expectations of stock market debuts building -- as Wall Street's machinery kicks into second gear, some investors with memories of the Internet bust a decade earlier are wondering whether this sudden burst of activity spells danger for the industry once again. With all this exuberance, valuations are soaring. Investments in Facebook and Zynga have more than quintupled the implied worth of each company in the last two years. The social shopping site Groupon is said to be considering an initial public offering that would value the company at $25 billion. Less than a year ago, the company was valued at $1.4 billion.

HELFAT--Lucile. We deeply mourn the passing of Lucile Helfat, mother of Jonathan N. Helfat, an esteemed senior member of our Firm. We extend our condolences to Jon and his wife Robin, who both gave loving care to Lucile in her final years, and to their children, Joshua and his wife Abigail and their son Jacob, and Benjamin and his fiance' Kate, and to Jon's brother Mark and his wife Mendy. Lucile was a devoted wife to Bernard for 64 years, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She lived her final years at home with dignity, surrounded by her family. Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston & Rosen, P.C.

FORT MYERS, Fla. - Curtis Granderson's recovery from a strained right internal oblique muscle is progressing rapidly, raising the possibility that he could play Thursday at Yankee Stadium against the Tigers. Granderson, scheduled to take batting practice Monday, would have to hit against live pitching before being cleared, and the Yankees would have only one exhibition game remaining, on Tuesday.

FORT MYERS, Fla. - Any hope Pedro Feliciano held of being available for opening day vanished Sunday, when continued tightness in his left triceps forced him to abort a scheduled throwing session. Feliciano has not pitched in a game since March 9, when soreness developed the day after he said he put himself through an intense upper-body workout. He is all but certain to land on the disabled list for the first time in his nine-year major league career.

LIBYA American and European forces carried out a ninth day of airstrikes on Tripoli and other strongholds of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, including his tribal homeland of Surt. Rebels seeking the leader's ouster recaptured two important refineries, at Brega and Ras Lanuf, as well as a strategic port in the east, setting the stage for a decisive battle for Surt. NATO formally agreed at a meeting in Brussels to take over the entire military mission, allowing the American military to begin reducing its presence in the coming days. SYRIA The government blamed armed gangs for killing 12 people in the northwestern port city of Latakia in previous days, and promised to lift its decades-old emergency law. An address by President Bashar al-Assad was announced, but he remained out of sight while the government sent out competing messages of compromise and crackdowns.
TRENT--Bertram J. March 28th, 2007. Four years today forever loved, forever missed.Geraldine, Bruce & Michael

If reality television could be considered an economic indicator, then perhaps the recovery is finally under way. Slowly. Two networks are betting on shows based on entrepreneurs competing for seed money for their business ideas. NBC's ''America's Next Great Restaurant'' features aspiring restaurateurs trying to impress a panel of judges to win financing for a new chain. And ABC has reintroduced ''Shark Tank,'' in which entrepreneurs try to get backing from a panel of venture capitalists who bet with their own money -- in exchange for a piece of the action.

Alondra de la Parra, a dynamic young Mexican conductor and graduate of the Manhattan School of Music, founded the Philharmonic Orchestra of the Americas in 2004 to promote performers and composers from the Americas. On Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall she turned the spotlight on Pro Mujer, a development and microfinance organization that helps women in Latin America and has disbursed more than $885 million in loans averaging $260 each. The benefit concert, at which the co-founders of Pro Mujer, Lynne Patterson and Carmen Velasco, spoke from the stage, celebrated the organization's 20th anniversary.

Managers who have drafted Buster Posey, above, a catcher for the San Francisco Giants and the National League's 2010 Rookie of the Year, can only hope that he matches his 2010 season batting average of .305.

Magazine publishers have already looked to tablet computers to prod consumer excitement. Now it's the music industry's turn, as artists and record labels rush to develop iPad applications that revive and expand the idea of the traditional album and, they hope, entice fans to buy more than just a track or two. The Universal Music Group has teamed up with a video company, Eagle Rock Entertainment, to create iPad versions of films about classic albums like Nirvana's ''Nevermind,'' with social networking features that allow fan commentary. This month, Bjork announced that her next project, ''Biophilia,'' will encompass ''music, apps, Internet, installations and live shows.''

DANA--James Dwight, of East Hampton, NY died peacefully on March 20, 2011 at age 80. Husband of Pamela. Father of Ike, Meg, Hope, Will, Tim and Chris. Grandfather of eleven. Brother of William Dale Dana. Graduate of The Hotchkiss School, Princeton University, and Harvard Law School. A Memorial Service will be held at noon on April 11th at St. Luke's Church, East Hampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be sent to The Hotchkiss School, PO Box 800, Lakeville, CT 06039, to benefit the Class of 1949 Scholarship.

SAHN--Dorothy Siegal of New York, NY passed away Saturday, March 26, 2011 at her home in Manhattan. Dorothy was born on April 23, 1930 to Esther and Alfred Greenblatt. She was married to her loving husbands, Arthur Sahn for 29 years and Abraham Siegal for 16 years. She is survived by her sons, Adam (Susan) of New City, NY; Jonathan (Kathy) of Boca Raton, FL; and Eric (Amy) of Redwood City, CA. Nana had a very special place in her heart for her seven grandchildren, Andrew, Max, Jordan, Samantha, Erin, Zachary and Lucas. She treasured and loved being surrounded by her family. Her beautiful and generous heart touched everyone she met. She loved life and lived life to the fullest. Nana loved Broadway Shows, collecting art, and traveling the world. Nana, because of you, we have beautiful memories to last a lifetime. We cannot imagine our lives without our precious Nana. She was the strength of our family and will always be remembered for her kind and loving ways. Funeral services will be at: Sutton Place Synagogue at 11:30am on Tuesday, March 29, 225 East 51st St., New York, NY. Please send any donations in her memory to: JBFCS Mishkon Programs, 135 West 58th St., Suite 6, New York, NY or VNSNY/Hospice Care, 7th Floor, 1250 Broadway, New York, NY, 10001.

Since the 1980s, the publication of a Jean M. Auel book has often called for enormous print runs - about one million copies - and elaborate displays in the front of bookstores to draw in readers. But to prepare for the release on Tuesday of ''The Land of Painted Caves,'' Ms. Auel's sixth book in the best-selling ''Earth's Children'' series, her publisher retooled the usual campaign for the digital age.

Has Hollywood just found another big teenage film franchise? Media Rights Capital, a prominent film financier and production company, has snapped up the rights to the Trylle Trilogy book series by Amanda Hocking, the 26-year-old self-publishing wunderkind. The company plans to make three novels into two movies, and Terri Tatchell, a co-writer of the hit science-fiction film ''District 9,'' is already at work on the screenplays. ''Amanda has created such a fresh, unique, fabulous world, and I am absolutely dead set on bringing it to the screen without compromising any of that,'' Ms. Tatchell said by telephone from Vancouver, Canada.

MUENSTERBERGER--Werner, a noted Freudian psychoanalyst, collector of African art, and prolific author in the fields of psychology and art, 97, died on March 6, 2011. Holder of three doctorates, in medicine, anthropology, and art history, he was longtime associate professor of psychiatry at Downstate Medical Center, State University of New York, and also taught at the universities of Columbia, Baylor, and Cologne. In 1947, he arrived in the U.S., from his native Germany where he had spent 18 months in hiding during World War II, to establish his psychoanalytic practice. His patients included many well-known figures in politics and the arts and he continued to consult with patients until his death. He began collecting African art at the age of 13, was author of several books, including his best-known work, "Collecting: An Unruly Passion," published in 1994. Dr. Muesterberger is survived by his associate and companion, Celestin Clamra; two stepdaughters, Helene Jackson Magill and Rev. Posy Jackson; his beloved dachshund, Mandy; and by many friends and admirers worldwide. A celebration of his life will be held in mid-April in New York; for information, please email clamra@yahoo.com.

To begin the season Thursday, the Yankees will face the right-hander Justin Verlander of Detroit and his 98-mile-per-hour fastball. So the hitting coach Kevin Long -- and batting-practice pitcher -- was asked if he could add about 40 m.p.h. to his pitches over the next few days. ''It's not in there,'' Long said, pointing to his left arm. ''I'm not like Venditte.''

LOS ANGELES - Larry Cohen has issues - 17 pages' worth - with ''J. Edgar,'' the movie now being shot here by Clint Eastwood for Imagine Entertainment and Warner Brothers with Leonardo DiCaprio in the title role as J. Edgar Hoover. Mr. Cohen is a writer and director who was in the news when his sister, the publicist Ronni Chasen, was murdered last year, and whose ''The Private Files of J. Edgar Hoover'' was released in 1977 with Broderick Crawford in the lead. He has now compiled a lengthy critique of the new Hoover film, based on his reading of a screenplay by Dustin Lance Black, who won an Oscar for ''Milk.''

Goldman Sachs had the starring role last week in the insider trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam when its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, testified about a former Goldman director who had possibly leaked confidential information to Mr. Rajaratnam. Next up, Morgan Stanley.

''Hong Kong Flu Hits Bay Ridge,'' screamed the headline. And just in case readers in December 1968 were not already alarmed, a smaller headline below warned: ''It's Upon Us!'' The headlines often shouted from The Home Reporter and Sunset News, every week grabbing readers in Bay Ridge, Dyker Heights, Sunset Park, and other Brooklyn neighborhoods in a way that belied the contemplative, formal man who published them. Mr. Isakovic's experiment with controlling a 5000-square foot screen in Times Square with his phone, which Bits wrote about yesterday, hit a snag when he tried to stream live video. STREICHER--Judson L.,87, of Chester, New York and Delray Beach, Florida, died peacefully in his sleep on Saturday, March 26, 2011. Born in Brooklyn on July 22, 1923, he was a proud alumnus of Poly Prep Day School in Brooklyn and Yale University. He honorably served in the U.S. Navy in World War II. Mr. Streicher was a revered Wall Street executive, the senior member of J. Streicher & Co. LLC, a family-owned and operated brokerage business founded by his father more than a century ago, and a Member of the NYSE for over 50 years. A lifelong animal enthusiast, Jud typified all that is good in the sport of dogs. He was kind to everyone he met in a career spanning more than 50 years, as a judge in obedience trials throughout the country before retiring with emeritus status in 2000. His guidance and leadership encompassed such well-known clubs as the American Boxer Club, where he earned the Lifetime Achievement award in 2001; the Westchester Kennel Club; the Westminster Kennel Club; the Tuxedo Park Kennel Club; the Port Chester Obedience Club; The Palm Beach Dog Fanciers Association; and the Peggy Adams Animal Rescue League. In 2010, he received a Certificate of Honor from the American Kennel Club for service as an AKC delegate for the entire first decade of the 21st Century. Through Galanjud Kennel, he and Gale bred and showed Boxers and an occasional Standard Poodle in both conformation and obedience, winning several obedience and Best in Show titles. Jud was the 9th recipient of the Langdon Skarda Award in 2004. The couple raised miniature horses at their farm in Chester, and enjoyed a long career in thoroughbred race horses through Streicher Stables and Centennial Farms. He loved this sport of kings and savored victories at many tracks. With his beloved Gale, Mr. Streicher traveled extensively throughout the world. He enjoyed lacrosse, swimming, and backgammon and had a passion for photography and golf. He was a loyal fan of NY football Giants and the NY Mets baseball team. Jud's honest, quiet strength, undying friendship and loyalty above all else are the character traits of this man; the world has lost a true gentleman. Mr. Streicher is survived by his wife of 67 years, Dorothy Gale; a daughter, Katherine O'Brien; a son, James Streicher; and his Standard Poodle Danny. In lieu of flowers, kindly send donations to: Take the Lead, (P.O.Box 6353 Watertown, NY 13601), the Peggy Adams Animal Rescue League (3200 N. Military Trail, West Palm Beach, FL 33409), and The ASPCA.

It was shortly after noon on Inauguration Day, and Abraham Lincoln was standing on a wooden portico teeming with dignitaries on the western side of the Capitol. In his hands were his inaugural address and his trademark stovepipe hat. He fumbled awkwardly with the hat, first placing it beside him on the floor, then picking it up as the growing throng forced him closer to the front. As his friend Edward Baker introduced him to the massive audience, he shifted the hat from hand to hand, uncertain what to do with it. Finally Senator Stephen A. Douglas, his old Illinois rival and closest challenger in the recent election, "who had been looking on quietly, and apparently with some apprehensions of a catastrophe to the hat, said, 'Permit me, Sir,' and gallantly took the vexatious article and held it during the entire reading of the Inaugural!"

When an Italian priest and his cadre of nuns founded the Munyaga Health Center in 1986, it was a barebones operation. Tucked among the rolling green hills and small mud homes of eastern Rwanda, the health center had limited services; the nearest source of potable water was five miles away, and kerosene lamps were often the only source of light. The center's most expensive technology was an array of solar cells to provide power for part of the day.

Let's face it - as trendy as taxidermy has become, it can also be a little creepy. Enter Anna-Wili Highfield (above), a Sydney, Australia-based artist whose hand-painted paper bird and horse sculptures are a perfect vegan alternative to the formaldehyde-filled, flea-bitten critters inhabiting hip hotels, restaurants and bars. Formerly a scenic painter at Opera Australia, the 30-year-old Highfield made her first "fairy wren" in 2008. Since then, she has created scores of avian and equine wonders out of thick cotton paper and copper or brass wire. Highfield doesn't have a gallery, but thanks to a few mentions in design magazines down under, there's a sizable waiting list for her work. Hermès recently commissioned two large Pegasus sculptures for its store in Brisbane, but despite this haute horsy endorsement, the artist's favorite winged muses aren't of the hooved variety. "Raptors fascinate me," she says. "Hawks, eagles, owls - they have an intensity that I try to capture in my pieces. I like to think they look alive." Go to annawilihighfield.com.

If anyone knows how to mark an occasion, it's the Italians. For the 50th anniversary of the Salone del Mobile, the fair that has come to be the epicenter of the global contemporary design market, they're turning Milan into a giant stage to display what they do best. Among the attractions will be a retrospective of Italian design, co-curated by Alberto Alessi, at the Triennale Design Museum and an eight-room installation, designed by Denis Santachiara, at the Piazza Duomo that highlights "creative potential channeled through scientific principles." The Salone even has a smartphone app, which you can find at cosmit.it. Ultimately, though, the fair is about selling furniture, and when this year's 2,500-plus exhibitors gather from April 12 to 17 to show off their latest innovations, that should provide excitement enough.

Baselworld 2011, the yearly watch fair concluding this week in Switzerland, took a walk down memory lane, revisiting classic models and vintage styles, and making the most of the "return to heritage" trend pervasive in the global fashion and accessory markets these days. This post-recession "looking back to move forward" strategy, which was also a theme in January's S.I.H.H. luxury watch show in Geneva, has led to retro styling, smaller sizes and a return to basics in the new timepieces being exhibited. Although there were some truly remarkable Jules Verne-ian time tellers to satisfy hard-core collectors, it seems that the more general relaxing of the count of every millisecond, the slightest inaccuracy of a tourbillon-free watch, allows for a stolen moment. A breather.

The Times's new digital-subscription system went global at 2 p.m. E.S.T. yesterday, and I am in a state of high-revenue readiness. Coincidentally, Nicholas Carlson (@nichcarlson) of Silicon Alley Insider had an item on Monday morning about a very interesting report, "Who Says What to Whom on Twitter," from Shaomei Wu, of Cornell University, and three researchers at Yahoo. They found that a fairly small number of people who use Twitter generate an awful lot of the posts. As with many things Webby (e.g. Wikipedia), Twitter empowers a small set of superusers. It also extends the reach of existing elites - specifically celebrities and us old-media peeps (joined by new-media bloggers).

Late last year, the artists and rug designers Brad Davis and Janis Provisor of Fort Street Studio traveled to Morocco to shop for the tribal rugs known as boucherouites, which are made of everything from wool to synthetic fabrics to scraps of plastic. The rugs' abstract, wildly colorful, intensely personal designs make them catnip to creative types like Davis and Provisor. They came home with 33 rugs, which they are exhibiting at their SoHo showroom for two weeks beginning April 28. Along with the boucherouites, the show will include the spoils of one of the couple's frequent trips to China, where Fort Street's factory is located: seven Chinese art rugs from the 1980s, including one by LeRoy Neiman that depicts the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. One of President Obama's recurrent rhetorical tropes during the 2008 campaign was the "false choice" maneuver, in which he would distance himself from straw men of the left and right to better sell himself as a post-partisan figure. He made the same move last night, defending his administration's Libya policy by distancing himself from the "some" who "question why America should intervene at all," and the "others" who "have suggested that we broaden our military mission beyond the task of protecting the Libyan people, and do whatever it takes to bring down Qaddafi and usher in a new government." The proper course, the president argued, lay somewhere in between, with an intervention designed to save civilian lives, prevent a destabilizing refugee crisis, and "stop Qaddafi's forces in their tracks," without committing American power (and American troops, and American money ...) to the task of changing Libya's regime outright. In certain cultures, voodoo objects were commissioned to solve anything that vexed you - from failed crops to failed romance. Approximately 100 such tools of divine intervention are at hand this month when the Fondation Cartier in Paris presents "Voodoo" (April 5 to Sept. 25), an exhibition culled mostly from the collection of Jacques Kerchache, a legendary curator and champion of primitive art. The show's focus is on the Republic of Benin, where voodoo orginated, and the objects can be mind-boggling in their dense, everything-but-the-kitchen-sink assemblage. But according to the exhibition's co-curator, Leanne Sacramone, we can now only imagine the circumstances of their creation. The figure above, made of wood, rope, animal bones, terra cotta pots, plants, feathers, cotton threads, shells, cloth, hair, beads and chain, might have done wonders for a fashion designer in need of inspiration.

During a lengthy debate on the wisdom of my Mike Stanton pick in the fourth round of the 14-team Yahoo! Friends and Family League, a couple of the commenters panned the pick, citing the possibility that Stanton would struggle would because of his low contact rate and get sent down to the minors. They estimated the chance at 20 percent. Whether that's true (I think 20 is too high, and if so, that would mean he was playing badly enough to get sent down, which means getting sent down would hardly make things worse), the argument boils down to this: "Stanton is a bad pick in the fourth round of a 14-team mixed league because his non-injury-related floor is too low." Setting aside the merits of the argument about Stanton in particular (which are laid out in detail in the debate linked above), I think the argument misses a key point generally.

YAEGER--Betty Sylvia. Betty Sylvia Yaeger, died Saturday, March 26, 2011 in her Palm Beach, Florida home following complications from a stroke suffered the previous November. A former fashion model, Betty maintained a strong interest in fashion, owned an art gallery and was an avid collector and admirer of art while additionally playing an active role in the stock market. She was an active member of New York and Palm Beach High Society, remaining a social butterfly until the very end. Charismatic as ever, she loved regaling friends and family with stories of Paris, Coco Chanel, rebuffing the advances of Orson Wells and meeting The Pope in 1958. Her strong will, sharp wit and enthusiastic opinions were balanced out by her sophistication, her charm and her grace. She took great pride in the successes of her family and would brag about her daughter and granddaughter to anyone whose ear she had. A remarkable woman, she loved life and made certain she lived it to the fullest. She is survived by her daughter, actress, Tina Louise and her granddaughter, novelist and screenwriter, Caprice Crane. Funeral services will be held at 2:00pm, on Tuesday, March 29, 2011 at The Episcopal Church of Bethesda-By-The-Sea. New York services are still being arranged.

PRETTYMAN--Noreen McGuire Ph.D. Noreen McGuire Prettyman Ph.D., of Washington, D.C. and Ocean City, MD died on March 25, 2011 after a series of long illnesses, including sarcoidosis. She was 56 and is survived by her beloved husband, prominent District of Columbia attorney E. Barrett Prettyman, Jr. She was the cherished daughter of Gladys McGuire Bower of Washington Township, NJ, and the late James F. McGuire, former Mayor of Northvale, NJ, where Noreen was raised. She is also survived by three sisters and one brother: Kathleen (Theodore) Gershon of Princeton Junction, NJ; Nancy (Louis) Sheffler of Harrington Park, NJ; Louise (Thomas) Quinn of Sparta, NJ; and James (Stephen Coy) McGuire, Jr. of Boston, MA; two stepchildren, E. Barrett "Ty" (Mary) Prettyman III of Fairfax, VA and Jill Prettyman (Rainer) Lukoschek of Houston, TX; three step-grandsons, four nephews, two nieces, and six great-nephews. Noreen received her BS from The College of New Jersey, her Master of Education from Boston College, and her PhD from The American University. She held senior offices at the University of Delaware where she was Dean and at The American University before moving to George Mason University, where she was a member of the University Life Advisory Board until her untimely death. Her career at Mason spanned more than a decade. During this time she made a lasting impression on everyone with whom she interacted, holding several positions within University Life and the Office of the Provost, eventually becoming Executive Director of Student Academic Affairs and Director of the University Scholars program. The university recognized her achievements by naming the Dr. Noreen McGuire Prettyman Scholars Center in her honor. Noreen was a mentor, teacher, motivator and lifelong learner who continued to be actively involved with the Mason community and volunteered her time and expertise in various capacities. Throughout her tenure at Mason she found great joy in seeing students grow and develop, and the University established the Phoenix Award in her honor to recognize a rising Mason professional who exhibits this same quality, as well as the many other traits Noreen embodied in all that she did each day. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Dr. Noreen McGuire Prettyman Scholars Center at George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, Virginia 22030, or The Washington Home Hospice, 3720 Upton Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20016. The family received visitors at the Joseph Gawler's Sons Funeral Home, 5130 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, D.C. on Sunday, March 27 from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial was offered on Monday, March 28, 2011 at 11am at The Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament, 3630 Quesada St., NW, Washington, D.C. followed by interment at Rockville Cemetery, Baltimore Road, Rockville, MD. A memorial mass will also be held at St. Anthony's R.C. Church, Paris Avenue, Northvale, NJ on Saturday, April 2, 2011 at 11am.

Here are some early reactions to President Obama's speech on Libya from around Capitol Hill, the Internet, cable television and Twitter. A spokesman for House Speaker John A. Boehner said the speech ''failed to provide Americans much clarity.'' Brendan Buck, the spokesman, said: ''Unfortunately, Americans waited a long time to get few new answers. Whether it's the American resources that will be required, our standards and objectives for engaging the rebel opposition, or how this action is consistent with U.S. policy goals, the speech failed to provide Americans much clarity to our involvement in Libya. Nine days into this military intervention, Americans still have no answer to the fundamental question: what does success in Libya look like?''
OBITUARIES An obituary on Saturday about the guitarist Melvin Sparks misstated the date of his death. It was March 15, not March 13.

STREICHER--Judson L.,87, of Chester, New York and Delray Beach, Florida, died peacefully in his sleep on Saturday, March 26, 2011. Born in Brooklyn on July 22, 1923, he was a proud alumnus of Poly Prep Day School in Brooklyn and Yale University. He honorably served in the U.S. Navy in World War II. Mr. Streicher was a revered Wall Street executive, the senior member of J. Streicher & Co. LLC, a family-owned and operated brokerage business founded by his father more than a century ago, and a Member of the NYSE for over 50 years. A lifelong animal enthusiast, Jud typified all that is good in the sport of dogs. He was kind to everyone he met in a career spanning more than 50 years, as a judge in obedience trials throughout the country before retiring with emeritus status in 2000. His guidance and leadership encompassed such well-known clubs as the American Boxer Club, where he earned the Lifetime Achievement award in 2001; the Westchester Kennel Club; the Westminster Kennel Club; the Tuxedo Park Kennel Club; the Port Chester Obedience Club; The Palm Beach Dog Fanciers Association; and the Peggy Adams Animal Rescue League. In 2010, he received a Certificate of Honor from the American Kennel Club for service as an AKC delegate for the entire first decade of the 21st Century. Through Galanjud Kennel, he and Gale bred and showed Boxers and an occasional Standard Poodle in both conformation and obedience, winning several obedience and Best in Show titles. Jud was the 9th recipient of the Langdon Skarda Award in 2004. The couple raised miniature horses at their farm in Chester, and enjoyed a long career in thoroughbred race horses through Streicher Stables and Centennial Farms. He loved this sport of kings and savored victories at many tracks. With his beloved Gale, Mr. Streicher traveled extensively throughout the world. He enjoyed lacrosse, swimming, and backgammon and had a passion for photography and golf. He was a loyal fan of NY football Giants and the NY Mets baseball team. Jud's honest, quiet strength, undying friendship and loyalty above all else are the character traits of this man; the world has lost a true gentleman. Mr. Streicher is survived by his wife of 67 years, Dorothy Gale; a daughter, Katherine O'Brien; a son, James Streicher; and his Standard Poodle Danny. In lieu of flowers, kindly send donations to: Take the Lead, (P.O.Box 6353 Watertown, NY 13601), the Peggy Adams Animal Rescue League (3200 N. Military Trail, West Palm Beach, FL 33409), and The ASPCA.

POLANS--Lawrence, passed away Sunday, March 27, 2011. A private service was held. Mr. Polans is survived by his three sons, Ira (Christina), Eric (Sara), and Michael Polans; one daughter Leah Polans, and three grandchildren; Harrison, Spencer and Maxwell.

THE ARTS A critic's notebook on Monday about New Directors/New Films misidentified the Attenborough brother whose nature documentaries are referenced in ''Attenberg,'' a movie in the film series with a title that misstates the surname. He is David Attenborough, not Richard.

SAO PAULO, Brazil -- ''We use zero leverage.'' Luiz Otavio Magalhaes, the founding partner of one of the most successful private equity firms in Brazil, was trying to explain his business model to me. His leveraged buyout firm, Patria, easily garners more than 20 percent returns annually. That kind of performance attracted the attention of Steven Schwarzman, whose Blackstone Group bought a 40 percent stake last year.

CHARNEY-FISCHER--Susan, nee Berkowitz on March 26, 2011. Tragic loss of beloved twin sister of Alice Opell, sister-in-law of H. Barry Opell, MD, loving wife of the late Bob Fischer, devoted Aunt and loving friend. Gone too soon and will be sorely missed.

A picture caption on Monday with a music review about a tribute to the songwriter Alex Chilton, who died in March 2010, misidentified the musician in the top right corner of the group image. He is Will Rigby -- not Noah Levy, who was not pictured. (Mr. Rigby and Mr. Levy are both drummers.) (Go to Article)

Goldman Sachs's elite partners have sold $108 million in shares in recent months, driving their total ownership stake in the Wall Street firm down to almost 10 percent, from 11.2 percent. The sales are a small yet significant dilution of the influence the partners have over the firm. Part of the power of the Goldman partnership is the stake they own collectively, and the agreement they have made to act in unison on shareholder votes. The next annual shareholder meeting has not been set, but it is typically held in May.

SCHORR--Norman. The Overseas Press Club of America mourns the death of Norman Schorr, an OPC member for 56 years and the driving force behind the Freedom of the Press Committee. His spirit will remain alive as the OPC continues to protest mistreatment of journalists.

FERRARO--Geraldine. Blank Rome is deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and former colleague, Geraldine Ferraro. Gerry was a great friend and wonderful partner to all of us at Blank Rome. Gerry brought her deep commitment to justice, equality and community service to our firm. Through her courage, energy and high spirits, she left an indelible mark on our culture and history. Our deepest sympathy is with Gerry's family during this time.

DALY--Mary F. The faculty and staff of the Department of Surgery mourn the passing of Mrs. Mary F. (Bonner) Daly, beloved wife of our former Surgery Chairman, Dr. John M. Daly. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband John, her children John Jr., William, Brian, Timothy, Patrick and Maureen, her grandchildren, Liam and Leo, and to all her family and friends. She will be sorely missed. Fabrizio Michelassi, MD Professor and Chair Department of Surgery Surgeon-in-Chief NYP/Weill Cornell Medical Center

NEW YORK An article in some editions on Saturday about the closing of a furrier in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misstated the age of the owner, Irving Feller. He is 83, not 81. Because of an editing error, the article misstated, in some editions, the location of Fiorella H. LaGuardia High School of Music and Art and the Performing Arts, where Mr. Feller's daughter teaches. It is in Manhattan, not Queens.

A dancer and a documentary filmmaker on Monday received this year's Martin E. Segal Awards, which recognize emerging artists associated with Lincoln Center. Meaghan Dutton-O'Hara, a ballet student, and Laura Poitras, whose first film, ''My Country, My Country,'' was nominated for an Academy Award, were honored at a luncheon that celebrated the 25th anniversary of the Segal Awards at Lincoln Center's Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse. The recipients - selected by the School of American Ballet and the Film Society of Lincoln Center - each received $7,500 to be used for career advancement and future study.

More than 10 million Americans suffer from anorexia, bulimia and other eating disorders. And while people tend to think such problems are limited to adolescence and young adulthood, Judith Shaw knows otherwise. A 58-year-old yoga instructor in St. Louis, Ms. Shaw says she was nearing 40 when she decided to ''get healthy'' after having children. Soon, diet and exercise became an obsession.
SAHN--Dorothy. The best pal I ever had. RUR

HAAGA--John C.,79, of New Canaan, CT and Naples, FL passed away peacefully on March 25. Former executive of Union Carbide. Beloved husband of Luanne and Pauline (deceased). Survived by children Diane, Susan, Patricia (Adam), Robert. Loving grandfather of Matthew, Kelin, Emily, Claire, Jenna. Mass of Christian Burial on Tuesday, 10am, St. Patrick Church, Bedford, NY.

9 P.M. (13), 10 P.M. (49) MONEY AND MARCH MADNESS With the Final Four now set for this year's N.C.A.A. men's basketball championship, ''Frontline'' delves into the multibillion-dollar business of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and its brand of amateur sports. Lowell Bergman interviews Sonny Vaccaro, above, a former marketing executive at Nike, Adidas and Reebok who helped bring about the commercialization of college basketball, which last year resulted in a $10.8 billion, 14-year contract for the tournament with CBS and Turner Broadcasting. Now Mr. Vaccaro is leading a class-action suit aimed at getting college athletes, who traditionally have not been paid, a piece of the pie, and accusing the N.C.A.A. of preventing players from profiting from the use of their images and likenesses in licensed merchandise. Other ''Frontline'' segments include a portrait of Ai Weiwei, a global art star armed with a video camera and a growing Twitter following who is sometimes called China's Andy Warhol; and an interview with Brian Manning, the father of the imprisoned former military intelligence analyst Pfc. Bradley E. Manning, who maintains that his son did not hand over secret government documents to WikiLeaks. 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS: THE STORY SO FAR Were Mike Catherwood and Lacey Schwimmer really told to tone down the sexual tension -- off the dance floor? Are Karina Smirnoff haters willing to ease up on their vitriol in support of the beloved Ralph Macchio, a k a the Karate Kid? And can Kirstie Alley continue to live up to her own hype? This special peels away the costumes and the spray tans on the 11 couples competing for the mirror-ball trophy before the first celebrity pairing is eliminated, at 9.

President Obama's aides have settled on the location of a campaign headquarters in downtown Chicago, with his re-election effort poised to open early next month by raising money and building a political organization for the 2012 presidential race. While the president remains in Washington, his re-election team will be situated more than 700 miles away on an upper floor of One Prudential Plaza, a few blocks from where Mr. Obama delivered his 2008 victory speech on election night in Grant Park.

BROCK--Marjorie. October 11, 1922-March 28, 2011. Adoring wife of predeceased husband Herbert and loving brother Win Goodman, mother of Peter and Andrew, grandmother of Colby (Mario) Gulano, Jarrett, Derek, Alex, and David Brock, mother-in-law to Janice. Funeral services will be held at Star of David Funeral Chapels, West Palm Beach, Florida (561)627-2277. Contributions may be made to: the Alzheimer's Association or to: Hospice of Palm Beach County.

The subterranean sonnet may be getting a comeback. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has entered preliminary talks to revive Poetry in Motion, the acclaimed series of subway poetry placards that inspired literary education programs around the country. The series was phased out in 2008.
BUTLER--Michael Domenick. 3/29/2006. Its been 5 years, but it feels like yesterday because you live in my heart as always. Marie Katerina

An article on Saturday about waiting lists for kindergarten in New York City public schools gave an inaccurate figure, provided by the Department of Education, for one school's waiting list. As of Friday, the waiting list for Public School 87 on the Upper West Side had the names of 29 children; it was not the case that no children were on the waiting list.

The story of a veteran director sharing the spotlight at a long-running film festival with his spouse and her directorial debut could have been the premise of an Edward Burns movie, if it weren't also his reality at the 2010 Tribeca Film Festival, which saw the debut of his ninth film, ''Nice Guy Johnny,'' as well as ''No Woman No Cry,'' the first by his wife, Christy Turlington Burns. But this year Mr. Burns gets a platform all to himself: the festival's organizers said on Monday that the closing night film of its 2011 program would be ''Newlyweds,'' which Mr. Burns wrote, directed and stars in. It is the latest in a series of films (including ''Ash Wednesday,'' ''Looking for Kitty'' and ''Purple Violets'') that have made their debuts at Tribeca. A news release from the Tribeca Film Festival described ''Newlyweds'' as ''a chronicle of modern marriage'' that follows ''a newly wedded couple whose honeymoon period is upended by the arrival of the husband's wild-child baby sister and the crumbling marriage of the wife's meddlesome sister.'' In addition to Mr. Burns, the cast includes Caitlin Fitzgerald, Max Baker, Marsha Dietlein Bennett and Kerry Bishe. The film is to have its premiere on April 30 at the Tribeca Performing Arts Center at the Borough of Manhattan Community College. The full festival runs from April 20 through May 1.

An article on Saturday about stiff competition in the hiring of young software engineers misstated the academic calendar at Stanford University, whose computer science graduates are in particularly high demand. It is divided into quarters, not semesters. The article also misstated the relative ages of several programming languages. Java is roughly contemporaneous with PHP and Ruby; it is not older. Python predates those three languages by several years; it is not a ''newer'' programming language.

ABELSON--Mort S.,of Fairfield, NJ died on March 28, 2011. He was 87. Services 1pm, Wednesday at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman, 68 Old Short Hills Rd. in Livingston, 973-422-0600. Mr. Abelson was the beloved husband of Dorothy (nee Livingston) and the loving father of Nancy Shannahan and the late Michael Abelson. Contributions in his memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

The Books of The Times review on Monday about ''The Troubled Man,'' a detective novel by Henning Mankell, misspelled the given name of the character who is the troubled man of the title. He is Hakan von Enke, not Haken.

RITTENBERG--Laurence H.,77, of New Rochelle, died March 26, 2011. Loving husband of Elinor, father to Bruce (Faith), Suzanne and Steven (Stacey). Proud grandpa of four. Service takes place March 29 at 1pm at Riversville Cemetery in Greenwich, CT. Please send donations in Larry's memory to Prize4life.org.

O'BRIEN--Joseph "Jay" Falmouth, MA, March 24. Wife Carmen, sons Stephen, Justin, daughter Jennifer. Burial March 31, Maryrest, Mahwah. Donations, All Hallows High School.

FRONT PAGE An article on Wednesday about a severe population drop in Detroit, using information from three demographers, erroneously attributed a distinction to Detroit. Its 25 percent loss from 2000 to 2010 was the biggest percentage loss over the last decade for any American city with more than 100,000 people, other than New Orleans. It was not the biggest percentage loss for such cities in any decade. (That distinction belongs to St. Louis, which lost 27.2 percent of its population between 1970 and 1980.)
5:10 p.m. | Updated Harry & David, the purveyor of fruit-filled gift baskets, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday as part of an effort to reorganize its troubled finances.

RICHARDSON--Dr. John J.,74, died on March 27 of lung cancer. A retired podiatrist affiliated with St. Vincent's Hospital, he gave sensitive care and comfort to thousands of patients over the course of his long career. Jack was a fifth generation Greenwich Village resident with a fierce loyalty to his neighborhood, a selfless provider for his family, an avid collector of medical antiques, and a prolific craftsman of wooden boxes. A devoted husband to the late Mary Ann Richardson, his unstinting care of her during her 16 year illness was one of his life's finest accomplishments. He is survived by his daughter, Martine Sacks, MD and her partner, A.J. Zelada: his son, Justin Richardson, MD and his husband, Peter Parnell; and his granddaughters, Lita Sacks and Gemma Parnell-Richardson. Viewing: Reddens, 325 W. 14 St., Wednesday 7-9pm, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral: St. Patrick's Old Cathedral, 263 Mulberry St., Friday 1pm.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has named a new director of its Concert & Lecture series to succeed Hilde Limondjian, who retired from the post last year after programming 41 seasons and more than 9,000 events. She is Limor Tomer, executive producer for music at the classical music radio station WQXR-FM and adjunct curator for performing arts at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York. The appointment is effective on May 2, Thomas P. Campbell, the director of the museum, announced on Monday.

TOTHY--Julia Klar. Passed away peacefully March 25 at age 99. Beloved wife of the late Paul Tothy, mother of Andrew and his Mary and grandmother of Stefanie (Chris) and Peter (Alison). Devoted great-grandmother of Julia, Jason, Samantha, Daniel and Zachary. Her cosmetic therapy patients remained friends even after her retirement in 2009. We will remember her always for her humor, perception, kindness and warmth. Gifts in memory of Julia can be made to Moses Brown School, 250 Lloyd Ave, Providence, RI 02906.

BUSINESS DAY A map on Friday with an article about a new type of nuclear power plant under construction in Shidao, China, gave the wrong location for the nearest big city, Rongcheng. It is about 25 miles north of Shidao, not near Beijing.

YOUR MONEY An article in the special Your Money section on Thursday about Marina Sturm's efforts to catch up on retirement savings at the age of 55 misstated the name of the university where she is an assistant professor of music. It is the University of Nevada, Las Vegas -- not the University of Las Vegas.

STREICHER--Judson L. The Passing of Jud Streicher marks the end of an era that began when he partnered with Bert Fagenson on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange in 1951. Joined by Jerry Frankel several years later, the three partners built the foundation of what would become one of the largest specialist firms at the NYSE. Jud was the last surviving member of that magnificent trifecta. He was a world traveler, accomplished backgammon player, breeder of championship horses, poodles and boxers, but above all a consummate gentleman and a true and loyal friend, particularly to those who needed a helping hand. He and his partners exemplified the NYSE motto, "your word is your bond". Our heartfelt condolences go out to Jud's partner in life, Gale and the rest of the Streicher family. He will be missed by all of us who knew him. The Former Managing Partners of Fagenson Frankel & Streicher, Steve Amsterdam, Jim DeMaira, Robert Fagenson, Larry Frankel, Paul Frankel

New York's Public Theater on Monday announced its second consecutive summer of casting a repertory company of actors in its two Shakespeare in the Park productions, ''Measure for Measure'' and ''All's Well That Ends Well,'' which will run June 6 to July 30 and, as usual, offer free tickets to most playgoers. As the Public did last summer in Central Park with ''The Merchant of Venice'' and ''The Winter's Tale,'' most of the actors will perform roles in each of the productions, though there is no individual actor with the star power Al Pacino brought to ''Merchant.'' Some of these pairings, ideally, can add resonance and a sense of fun for both the actors and the audience members.

If you're a movie studio looking to change the subject from Zack Snyder's current movie, one surefire way to do it is to slip out a little news about his next one. Over the weekend, when Mr. Snyder's new fetishized fantasy-adventure, ''Sucker Punch,'' failed to get off the ground, selling just $19 million in tickets on a budget of at least $80 million, Warner Brothers Pictures countered with an announcement that Mr. Snyder had found the actress who will play Lois Lane in his coming Superman movie. Amy Adams, an Academy Award nominee for ''The Fighter,'' ''Doubt'' and ''Junebug,'' will play that fearless Daily Planet reporter and sometime paramour to the Man of Steel and his alter ego, Clark Kent. In a statement to The Hollywood Reporter, Mr. Snyder described Ms. Adams as ''one of the most versatile and respected actresses in films today'' with ''the talent to capture all of the qualities we love about Lois: smart, tough, funny, warm, ambitious and, of course, beautiful.'' Warner Brothers had previously announced that Mr. Snyder's Superman movie, planned for a 2012 release, would starHenry Cavill (of ''The Tudors'') as the title red-and-blue hero, and Kevin Costner and Diane Lane as his adoptive parents, Jonathan and Martha Kent. No word yet who might play other familiar characters like Perry White or Jimmy Olsen, or who would be the villains of the film. (Here's hoping that unlike ''Sucker Punch,'' it won't be the critics.)

FERRARO--Geraldine. Marymount Manhattan College mourns the passing of its distinguished alumna, Geraldine Ferraro '56. She led a life of service - to her family, to her community, to her nation. Her dignity and dedication to her principles, her commitment and courage to be the trailblazer for women in public service will not be lost with her passing. Her path-breaking accomplishments will be cherished by those who knew her, and will be admired by those who will continue to benefit from her life well-lived. The family requests that contributions in her name be made to the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary, 50 Wilson Park Drive, Tarrytown, NY 10591. Judson R. Shaver, Ph.D. President Marymount Manhattan College

INTERNATIONAL A picture caption on March 20 about President Obama's visit to Brazil misidentified the Brazilian official accompanying Mr. Obama as he arrived at the Palácio do Planalto in Brasília. She is Ambassador Maria De Lujan Caputo Winkler, the ceremonial chief of Brazil's Ministry of Foreign Affairs -- not President Dilma Rousseff.
I refused to wait for the images of slaughter and mass graves before taking action. PRESIDENT OBAMA, in a speech defending the American-led military assault in Libya. [A1]

A former colleague of Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund manager on trial on insider-trading charges,told federal agents that he saw the brother of Mr. Rajaratnam remove notebooks from the fund's offices on the day of Mr. Rajaratnam's arrest, according to court papers filed Monday. The trial of Mr. Rajaratnam, who the government contends earned $45 million by trading on illegal stock tips, entered its fourth week in Federal District Court in Manhattan. And much of the interesting action at the trial on Monday was revealed on the court's docket rather than in the courtroom itself.

GOODMAN--Mimi, died on March 28, 2011, "ageless". Dear sister of Janet Levine and sister-in-law of Dr. David B. Levine, fabulous Aunt to Dara, Josh and Adam and great-aunt to Althea, Dylan, Rachel and Samantha. Living life on her own terms whether in New York or Marbella - a talented sculptor who loved the arts. Donations in her memory to a charity of choice are appreciated.

STREICHER--Judson L. The Westchester Kennel Club reflects with respect and with gratitude, with fondness and with sorrow on the passing of Juddie Streicher, our Chairman Emeritus. The decades of his leadership as our President contributed extensively not only to the substance of our organization, but to the sport of pure-bred dogs. He provided us great enjoyment; he has bequeathed us a rich legacy.

Updated 4:25 p.m. | The sentencing of Alan G. Hevesi, the former New York State comptroller convicted in a pay-to-play pension scandal, was delayed for at least one week as the presiding judge stepped aside from the case on Monday. Mr. Hevesi's lawyer, Bradley D. Simon, had asked the judge, Lewis Bart Stone of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, to recuse himself from sentencing Mr. Hevesi because of a personal relationship the judge had with Mr. Simon's father. Justice Stone is the executor of Mr. Simon's father's will and the trustee of his trust; Mr. Simon and his father have long been estranged.

STEIN--Dora, 89. Formerly of Sunnyside, NY, died Friday, March 25. Beloved wife of the late Jacob, devoted mother of Victor, Anita (Wayne Olinzock), and Marion (Craig Savel). Proud grandmother of Matthew, Andrew, and Amy Olinzock. Graduate of Hunter College 1942. She will be remembered for her generosity, humor, and math skills. The family wishes to thank the nursing and care staff at Albany Medical Center, Neurology Unit. Donations may be made in her name to Hadassah or the charity of your choice.

HELLER--Norman Norman Heller, July 3, 1927-March 25, 2011, corporate executive, gifted photographer, impassioned jazz enthusiast, beautiful swimmer, enthusiastic sailor and skier, exemplary husband, father, and grandfather, died of pneumonia, age 83. His life was an extraordinary, inspirational journey from Brighton Beach, Brooklyn--where he met the love of his life, Rosalyn Breg Heller, on the elevated subway platform when they were both headed to the NYU Heights campus--to homes in Los Angeles, California; Livingston, New Jersey; Stamford, Connecticut; London, England; New York, New York; Highland Beach, Florida; and finally, Maplewood, New Jersey. The son of a jeweler who'd immigrated alone from Austria as a boy, and the grandson of a woman who peddled fish from a cart on the Lower East Side, he rose to become one of the first Jewish executives at a major American corporation and one of the first Jewish members of the University Club. As Senior Vice President, Western Hemisphere of PepsiCo International in the 1970s and later as President and Chief Executive Officer of PepsiCo Wines and Spirits, International through 1987, he helped introduce Pepsi to the USSR and Eastern Europe and first imported Stolichnaya Vodka in the west. He loved business, but was a cultured intellectual with passionate interests in the arts, especially. Ever positive, his favorite word was "phenomenal," and he was, above all, phenomenally devoted to his wife of 62 years, his sister Judy Coleman, his three children, Karen Abada, Nanci McAlpin, and Matthew Heller, and their spouses, and his six grandchildren--all of whom adored and survive him. There will be a memorial in June, to be announced.

Bryson Voirin, a doctoral student at the Max Planck Institute for Ornithology in Germany and a fellow at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute, is posting at nytimes.com/science from Panama, where he studied sleep in three-toed sloths. The sloths I find seem to always be at the top of the tallest tree, out on the thinnest of limbs. To climb up into the canopy, I shoot a line around a strong branch, using an eight-foot slingshot that would make Dennis the Menace quite jealous. Then, after hauling up a climbing rope, I rig up my mechanical ascenders and inch my way skyward.

When he was in Finland in 1978, Mikhail Baryshnikov fell in love with a painting in a gallery -- a panoramic cityscape of St. Petersburg by the 19th-century artist Petr Petrovich Vereshchagin -- and bought it. ''I used to live right behind the Hermitage, so it was a personal icon for me,'' Mr. Baryshnikov said in a telephone interview. ''But now it's time for someone else to take ownership of it.'' So he recently donated the painting to the Baryshnikov Arts Center, which he established in 2005. Now the center is selling it at Sotheby's in New York on April 12 and the proceeds - it is expected to bring $300,000 to $500,000 - will go to benefit new programs.

Amazon.com plans to introduce a service that will let people upload their digital music to the Web and access it from browsers on any computer and from Android phones. The service, known as a music locker, was expected to be available to Amazon account holders by Tuesday. Amazon will offer a Web-based hard drive backup service called Cloud Drive, where people can store documents, photos, videos and music.

As Twitter tries to manage its explosive growth, two of the company's founders have traded roles. Jack Dorsey, who conceived the idea for Twitter but was ousted as chief executive in 2008, said on Monday that he was returning to the company as head of product development. He has remained a Twitter director but has not been involved in daily operations.

PARIS - The French economy is popularly viewed as sclerotic and sheltered, but government data released Monday - as well as the testimony of a number of global chief executives - suggest the opposite. Italians, though, might beg to differ.

BIANCHI--Lois, 76, died peacefully in her home on March 24. New Yorker to her core, TV producer, educator, founding member of New York Women In Film, Fulbright teaching fellow in Croatia, loving sister to Sylvia, aunt of five, great-aunt of six, great friend and mentor to many. Lois touched the lives of all who knew her and will be profoundly missed. Donations in her memory may be made to: Planned Parenthood of NYC, 26 Bleecker St; Friends In Deed, 594 Broadway; Music-Theater Group, 10 Jay St, Brooklyn.

YEMEN An explosion at an abandoned weapons factory in southern Yemen killed at least 110 people, in the latest sign of an ominous loss of government control in the country's outlying areas. Government forces have abandoned their posts in parts of northern and southern Yemen. But some officials said the government withdrawals might be a ploy to warn supporters of President Ali Abdullah Saleh about the consequences if he were to fall from power. LIBYA A barrage of tank and artillery fire repulsed the westward charge of the rebel forces near Bin Jawwad, the city directly east of Surt, one of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's most crucial bastions of support. Meanwhile, the American military warned that the insurgents' rapid advances could quickly be reversed without continued coalition air support. We all have regrets, but new research suggests the most common regret among American adults involves a lost romantic opportunity. Researchers at Northwestern University and the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign collected data from 370 adults in the United States during a telephone survey.
