GRANT--Stanley J.,"Bud", 83, of Manhasset Hills, formerly of Douglaston and Southampton, NY on March 6, 2011. World War Two Veteran United States Marines. Devoted spouse of the late Eleanor Beers-Grant and Suzanne Gobel Stabnick. Loving father of Suzanne Grant McCarthy (Richard, MD), Robert (Renee), Richard (Kacki), Thomas (Karen), Joanne Grant Sicilia (Pasquale) and Stephen, MD (Lisa). Loving grandfather of 21 and proud great-grandfather of two. Brother to the late Robert T. and brother-in-law to Kathleen. Beloved uncle to Kathleen Grant Murphy, Robert, MD, Michael and Meredith Grant Reynolds. Fond and special friend to many. He was a graduate of Saint Michael's High School and Saint Francis College (Brooklyn, NY). Founder and CEO of The Friends of The Congressional Glaucoma Caucus Foundation. www.glaucoma congress.org) Long-time employee of Upjohn/Pharmacia Corporation and previous Regent member of Wagner College and New York Hospital Division of Queens. Visitation Fairchilds, Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Monday and Tuesday 2 to 5pm and 7 to 9pm. Mass of Resurrection 10am, Wednesday Saint Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment immediately following at Saint John's Cemetery, Queens Village. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Bud's name to Saint Ignatius Retreat House, 251 Searingtown Road, Manhasset, New York 11030.

DEMPSEY--Ellen. The Fund for the City of New York celebrates the life of our friend and colleague, Ellen Dempsey, who died March 23rd. Ellen was a pioneering social entrepreneur who dedicated her life to provide support and services "by teachers for teachers". Through Impact II in New York, the Teachers Network nationally and TeachNet in the UK and Ireland, she created programs that benefited over 1.5 Million teachers. A force for good, she will be missed by her devoted friends and colleagues and teachers everywhere. Dall Forsythe, Chairman of the Board Mary McCormick, President Fund for the City of New York

In late March and early April 1861, ballplayers in dozens of American towns looked forward to another season of play. But they were not highly paid professionals whose teams traveled to Florida or Arizona for spring training. Rather, they were amateur members of private organizations founded by men whose social standing ranged from the working class through the upper-middle ranks of society. There were no formal leagues or fixed schedules of games, although there were regional associations of clubs that drew up and enforced rules for each type of bat and ball game. Contests between the best teams attracted large crowds (including many gamblers), and reporters from daily newspapers and weekly sporting magazines wrote detailed accounts of the games.

The silent star of the 1948 hit film "Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House" is a handsome Colonial with bright clapboard walls and dark shutters. Cary Grant and Myrna Loy co-starred as the New York City adman Jim Blandings and his wife, Muriel - up-to-date apartment dwellers whose relationship with early-American style personified the hopes and struggles of moviegoers from coast to coast. The Blandings' country home became so popular that Kellogg's cereal boxes offered a cardboard cutout model, and Manhattan charity fund-raisers oversaw the construction of a full-scale Dream House knockoff on a vacant lot in Midtown. As the backdrop for a 1949 fashion photo in Cosmopolitan magazine, the suburban colonial parked at the corner of 48th and Fifth now seems quaintly surreal, but at the time it was shot, this "back to the New Look" tableau would have made perfect sense to passers-by.

We're all focused right now on Libya and budget battles at home, but this story from Bangladesh just broke my heart and outraged me -- and offers a reminder of the daily human rights struggles of so many women and girls in villages around the world. A 14-year-old Bangladeshi girl, Hena,allegedly was ambushed when she went to an outdoor toilet, gagged, beaten and raped by an older man in her village (who was actually her cousin). They were caught by wife of the alleged rapist, and the wife then beat Hena up. An imam at a local mosque issued a fatwa saying that Hena was guilty of adultery and must be punished, and a village makeshift court sentenced Hena to 100 lashes in a public whipping.

The attackers and defenders of Marie Antoinette have been going at it for more than 200 years. She may be the most written-about woman in the history of the world. But the real historical figure has lost out to our picture of her as "Madame Déficit," the queen who wouldn't wear the same dress twice. It is the extravagance of her reign - 90 dresses in a year from one dressmaker alone - that makes her the metaphor of choice for critics of tyrants everywhere. As Noreen Malone recently put it in Slate, "a handful of rulers' wives" in Syria, Jordan and elsewhere in the region "became fashion magazine darlings here and symbols of inequality back home," cast as "the Middle East's Marie Antoinettes." The strangest evocation of this image, an indication of just how detached it has gotten from its source, was a comment in Ha'aretz concerning the protests in Egypt: "Mubarak and his thugs are the Marie Antoinettes of the Middle East." Picture that, if you dare.

I'm pretty sure you don't know what "head and tail bands" are. I didn't, anyway: I had never heard the term before, and if I'd ever seen one, I hadn't noticed it. They're the tiny strips of cloth that lie at the top and bottom of a book, between the back of the paper and the spine. They were originally meant to cover up imperfectly hand-cut pages, but now that commercial bookbinding is done by machine, they've become mostly decorative, and most books don't have them anymore.

A Texas prosecutor's proposal that Willie Nelson sing his way out of a recent arrest for marijuana possession has all but gone up in smoke after a judge there rejected the idea. Kit Bramblett, the county attorney for Hudspeth County in West Texas, had suggested that Mr. Nelson pay a small fine and sing "Blue Eyes Crying in the Rain" at the courthouse as punishment after his arrest at a border stop in Sierra Blanca, Tex., on Nov. 26, when a Border Patrol agent smelled pot on his tour bus. Mr. Bramblett acknowledged that his suggested sentencing would still need to be approved by a judge.

Courtney Applebaum, 24, studied social theory at the New School - which is, in crucial ways, ideal training for an interior decorator. Her relationships with clients can be intensely personal, and it shows in the spaces she creates. "I don't want people to walk into a space and say, 'Courtney did this,' " she says. "I just want it to be beautiful, and for the people who live there to be comfortable." The Los Angeles native already has half a dozen projects under her belt and at least that many in the works, some very high profile. But while her taste can be daring, she is the picture of discretion. The only names you'll hear her drop are those of Prouvé and Nakashima.

LUKINS--Richard Alden, 74, died unexpectedly March 28, 2011 of acute myeloid leukemia. Former owner and president of security guard companies, most recently Advantage Security. Graduate of Princeton University 1958. Vice Chairman of the Board of the Joyce Theater, NYC and board member of The Weantinoge Land Trust, CT. Survived by his wife, Karen Fry, daughters Annabel (Peter Stelling) and Molly (Brian Burke) and his grandchildren, Bailey and Matthew Burke. Donations in his honor to: the Joyce Theater or Weantinoge Land Trust. Memorial service and gathering Friday, April 8, 11:00am at the Joyce Theater, 175 8th Avenue, NYC.

When the filmmaker Whit Stillman released his last movie, ''The Last Days of Disco,'' it was 1998, and he was on pace to produce a new film roughly every three years (while Chloe Sevigny was still an intriguing ingenue for whom the title ''The Brown Bunny'' had no meaning). Times have changed, and while it feels as if whole civilizations have come and gone, Mr. Stillman is at last about to put out a fourth film. Sony Pictures Classics said on Tuesday that it would release ''Violet Wister's Damsels in Distress,'' which was written and directed by Mr. Stillman, whose previous films include ''Metropolitan'' and ''Barcelona.''

HICKEY--Lawrence Francis, Lawrence Francis Hickey, 90, died peacefully at home in New York City. Cherished husband of the late Jean Hogan Hickey, his bride of 56 years, adored father of Elizabeth Hickey Lavin of Pelham Manor, NY, Frank Hickey, Magee Hickey Salembier and Jane Hickey Sexton, all of New York City, and beloved father-in-law of Tom Lavin, Rick Salembier and Mason Speed Sexton. He was the devoted grandfather of 11: Tom, Kate, Meg, Jack and Janie Lavin, Lily and Floy Salembier, Mason, Buckman, Keats and Daisy Sexton and beloved grandfather-in-law of Scott Phillips. He was a special friend of Miao Hua Zhou. He was lovingly cared for by Felicidad Collado, Astou Diop, Nur Purnamawaty and so many others. Mr. Hickey, born in Brooklyn, was a graduate of the University of Notre Dame class of 1942. He served in World War II as a lieutenant senior grade USN in the Pacific. He received the William D. Reynolds Award in 1992 from Notre Dame and was the Notre Dame Club of New York "Man of the Year" in 1993. He also received an Honorary Degree of Doctor of Humane Letters in 1995 from St. John's University. After retiring from his family's concrete business, M.F. Hickey Company, which was founded by his grandfather in 1896, Mr. Hickey spent the last three decades helping the mentally retarded and emotionally disturbed children of New York City. He served on the Board of the Kennedy Child Study Center for decades. Mr. Hickey was head of the Parish Council, Eucharistic Minister, lector, and altar server at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church. He was also a member of the board of Astor Services for Children for many years. During that time, he oversaw the purchase and renovation of a two-room, Victorian Gothic schoolhouse known as "The Little Red Schoolhouse." It was renamed in honor of him and is now called the Lawrence F. Hickey Center for Child Development, a therapeutic early childhood development program. In addition, Mr. Hickey was a past president of the Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter, The Amateur Comedy Club and The Jones Wood Association. He was chief Honorary Usher and a lector at St. Patrick's Cathedral, a Knight Equestrian of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem and a Knight of Malta. The Daughters of Charity recognized him for his work at the Kennedy and Astor facilities by naming him an "Affiliate" of the Order in 1990. Mr. Hickey was a member of the Friends of Cardinal Cooke Guild and an early member of the Bishop Fulton J. Sheen Foundation promoting the case for sainthood. When asked why he spent his retirement years helping others, Mr. Hickey wrote: "Lessons learned on the campus of Notre Dame, from my Irish Catholic background, and a tour of 49 months in the Navy in WWII, convinced me that we all must help God's less fortunate." And in his final years, nothing made him happier than to be surrounded by his large and adoring circle of family and friends in his weekend home in Millerton, New York. The wake will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Thursday from 6 to 9pm. The Funeral Mass will be held at Saint Patrick's Cathedral at 10am, Friday. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Lawrence F. Hickey Center for Child Development, 4010 Dyre Avenue, Bronx, NY 10466 or the Kennedy Child Study Center, 151 East 67th Street, New York, NY 10065.

WASHINGTON -- Elizabeth Warren, who is overseeing the beginnings of the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, will confront some of her chief antagonists on Wednesday when she addresses a gathering at the United States Chamber of Commerce, the business lobbying group that has adamantly opposed the existence of the agency. ''I've had more teasing about this meeting than I've had in a long time,'' Ms. Warren is scheduled to tell the gathering, according to excerpts of remarks released late Tuesday. ''You can imagine the analogies: Nixon to China, Daniel in the Lion's Den, Senator John Kennedy speaking before Protestant ministers.''

When Willie Nelson found himself in trouble with the Internal Revenue Service in the 1990s, it nearly cost him everything he had. Opponents of a plan to move the Barnes Foundation and its world-renowned art collection from a Philadelphia suburb to a downtown museum quarter asked a Pennsylvania judge on Tuesday to reconsider his 2004 ruling to allow the relocation, arguing that a 2009 documentary about the court case, called ''The Art of the Steal,'' revealed new evidence that the judge did not have when he made his decision. The 2004 ruling by Stanley R. Ott of the Montgomery County Orphans' Court permitted the foundation, which had struggled financially, to go against the wishes of Albert C. Barnes, who built the collection and stipulated that no picture in it could be lent, sold or moved from the walls of the galleries that he built for it in Merion. Judge Ott said at the time that he considered the move ''the only viable alternative'' to save the Barnes from bankruptcy, but opponents argued that the foundation's troubles had been overstated.On Tuesday a lawyer for the Friends of the Barnes Foundation, a community group that opposes the move, asked Judge Ott to reconsider the decision because of statements that Michael Fisher, who was Pennsylvania's attorney general when the case was heard, made in the documentary suggesting that though his role was to represent the public, including opponents of the move, in the case, he had applied pressure to help ensure the move. Mr. Fisher said in an interview in the movie that he communicated with officials at Lincoln University, who controlled the Barnes Foundation board, and warned them that his office ''would have to take some action'' to change the composition of the board unless they agreed to the move, which was sought by members Philadelphia's political establishment.

DEMPSEY--Ellen, educational leader, sister, aunt, cherished friend, dedicated professional and founder, president and CEO of the Teachers Network, died on Wednesday, March 23rd in New York City. She was 74. Ellen graduated from Russell Sage College with a B.A. in psychology and from NYU with an M.A. in English Education. She began her career in the classroom, teaching English in a public school in NYC's Chinatown. After receiving an M.S. in Guidance and Counseling from Hunter College, Ellen became a guidance counselor in East Harlem. Ellen recognized that to improve the quality of education, new approaches were necessary. She acted on her belief and became the director of IMPACT II. She then founded and became the first president of the Teachers Network, an international not for profit with affiliates across the United States, as well as in Ireland and the United Kingdom. For 30 years Teachers Network recognized and rewarded creative classroom instruction with direct grants to teachers and by promoting teacher networks. Among Ellen's additional accomplishments were her role as executive producer of "Take an Idea and Go Creative" and "Where Have All the Teachers Gone," which aired on public television; development of "The Teachnet Project;" and the development of the award-winning website: teachersnetwork.org. Ellen received the Apple Polisher Award from the Association for A Better New York and the Educational Leadership Award from the Educational Administrators Association (AFL-CIO). She has served on the board of directors of A+ for Kids Teacher Network (WWOR-TV), was a consultant for WWOR-TV and Business Week Magazine on the television show "Our Future at Risk." She is survived, and will be dearly missed by her brother Burt Blustein, her nephews, Michael and Glenn Blustein, and her step-sons, James and George Dempsey, and their respective families, and by myriad friends and colleagues, and innumerable teachers and their students who benefited from her vision and commitment. A scholarship to be used to continue her work to be called "The Ellen Dempsey Memorial Scholarship" is being established. For details contact Linda Goldstein at LindaNGoldstein@gmail.com.

Christopher J. Dodd excoriated movie pirates, complained about the exclusion of many American movies from China, and generally did what's expected of a brand-new chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America in his inaugural speech about the state of the movie industry: Played the cheerleader. ''I passionately believe there remains no better way to see a movie than in a theater, and no more important relationship for our studios to maintain than the one we have with you,'' Mr. Dodd told theater executives and others at the CinemaCon convention in Las Vegas on Tuesday. Earlier this month, Mr. Dodd took charge of the motion picture association, an industry trade group, after a long career in politics. In his first major public address, Mr. Dodd said he was not unduly alarmed by a sharp drop at the box-office, as domestic ticket sales fell by about 19% in the first quarter of 2011 compared to the same period last year, according to figures from Hollywood.com, an entertainment Web site that tracks ticket sales. ''I for one do not believe the sky is falling,'' Mr. Dodd said, according to a copy of remarks prepared for the occasion. On the positive side, he said one in five dollars spent at the domestic box-office now comes from 3-D screenings, pointing to the power of new technology.

Brian O'Connell, who helped found Independent Sector, an organization that represents the interests of charities, foundations and nonprofit giving programs in the United States, often before Congress, died March 21 at his home in Chatham, Mass. Six of the dogs - a mother and four young puppies, as well as a 4-month old puppy - were given to rescue agencies that find adoptive owners, he said.

When Radiohead announced its new album, ''The King of Limbs,'' last month, it did so in the high-tech, media-smart way its fans have come to expect: a brief note online, followed by a rush when the songs were made available for download a day earlier than expected. Phase 2 of the promotion is a lot less 21st century. On Tuesday, the day that CD and vinyl LP versions of ''The King of Limbs'' were released (along with another release of the download), the band distributed copies of a free 12-page newspaper called The Universal Sigh at 61 locations around the world, including three in Manhattan. Although there's little in the newspaper that explicitly advertises the album (the title and a few scattered lyrics are all that one reader/listener could find on a quick perusal), its existence to some extent also promotes yet another iteration of ''The King of Limbs'': a deluxe edition, which costs about $50 and includes two vinyl records, a CD, a download and artwork ''all in a special 'newspaper' format,'' the band said.The Universal Sigh was released at 1 p.m. on Tuesday, and at about 1:20, the Times Square distribution spot was fairly quiet. Three young people, one with an old-fashioned paperboy bag slung over his shoulder, held up copies of the paper and asked passers by, ''Are you a Radiohead fan?'' Most people apparently weren't, because a reporter worried about being 20 minutes late to the release had an easier time getting a copy than one usually would for discounted Broadway tickets at the TKTS booth.

When Tyler Anastopoulos got in trouble for skipping detention at his high school recently, he received the same punishment that students in parts of rural Texas have been getting for generations. Tyler, an 11th grader from Wichita Falls, was sent to the assistant principal and given three swift swats to the backside with a paddle, recalled Angie Herring, his mother. The blows were so severe that they caused deep bruises, and Tyler wound up in the hospital, Ms. Herring said.

SYRIA President Bashar al-Assad's government resigned in what may have been a prelude to other concessions in a speech Mr. Assad is expected to give on Wednesday, part of an expanding effort to address protests against his authoritarian rule. The gesture was seen as a significant, if symbolic, action in a nation where the leadership rarely responds to public pressure and where decisions are made by Mr. Assad and his inner circle. LIBYA Emboldened by the coalition's airstrikes, the rebels appeared for a moment to have captured the contested coastal town of Bin Jawwad. But then a shell exploded just 200 yards from the city's western gate, a reminder that the better-equipped forces supporting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi could still blast the rebels with impunity from beyond the reach of their surveillance or guns. Within two hours, the rebels were fleeing out of town to the east. By the late afternoon, the colonel's forces pushed past Bin Jawwad and attacked the oil town of Ras Lanuf, which the rebels had retaken only on Sunday.

(CUNY) CITY TALK ''From Shirtwaist to Wisconsin: Labor Unions and the American Worker,'' a two-part special repeated at 4:30 and 9:30 p.m., explores why unions, which advanced as a result of the fire at the Triangle shirtwaist factory and are at the core of the creation of America's working class, are now increasingly being viewed as ''the enemy.'' SHEPHERD--Dr. Herman R. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Albert B. Sabin Vaccine Institute note with deep sorrow the passing of our Founding Chairman, friend and colleague, Dr. Herman (Shep) R. Shepherd at the age of 89. Shep died peacefully after a brief illness. He is survived by his beloved wife of 68 years, Carol Ruth Shepherd and their four children. Shep was proud of having grown up in Brooklyn. He received his Bachelor of Science degree from Cornell University and later served in the U.S. Army during World War II. He received Honorary Doctorate degrees from Villanova University and The George Washington University. He was internationally renowned for his pioneering work in aerosol technology, which resulted in pivotal breakthroughs in a variety of areas, most notably in the treatment of asthma. Shep was a close friend of Dr. Albert B. Sabin, the discoverer of the oral polio vaccine, whose lifelong work in the field of vaccines inspired Shep to found the Sabin Vaccine Institute, along with Dr. Sabin's widow, Heloisa Sabin. Dr. Shepherd served as Chairman of the Institute's Board of Trustees for over 15 years and as its President for eight years. He was passionately committed to the Institute's mission to reduce the needless suffering of the world's poorest one billion people from vaccine-preventable and neglected tropical diseases. Under his visionary leadership, the Institute is developing new vaccines, advocates for the use of existing vaccines and helps provide treatments to hundreds of millions of people around the globe. He will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Carol Ruth, his children John, Marjorie, Elizabeth and Benjamin, his extended family and many friends and admirers.

It's Opening Day at Yankee Stadium, so naturally the big buzz up in the Bronx today is all about the snake that escaped from the zoo last weekend. I kid, of course. In fact, the buzz is dying down, because the latest reports indicate that the wayward Egyptian cobra has been found, which will certainly dampen the burgeoning snake fever that was gripping the globe, what with the lack of any real, hard news out there these days. I've always considered shoe catalogs to be a relatively safe pleasure, if only because a new pair of shoes - unlike new clothes - can be counted on to provide a jolt of fashion without leaving one breathless with anxiety. Or so it used to be until the appearance of Bergdorf Goodman's spring shoe catalog. From the first item on, which is a crazy quilt of a Dries van Noten sandal that rings in at $920, it is clear that one should beware all enterprises requiring new shoes. Which is not to say that there isn't the occasional bargain, such as a Manolo Blahnik ballet flat for $665 (!) But if you're looking for the kind of footwear that will knock somebody's socks off (e.g., Azzedine Alaïa's bootie, above), the new normal hovers around $2,000. And then there's Alexander McQueen's gold T-strap wedge, set on a heel that's five and a half inches, and calls for an outlay of $3,495. If you think too hard about any of this, it can make you weep.

Georges Dambier, whose work is the subject of a delightful exhibition at the Bonni Benrubi Gallery on East 57th Street (through May 14), liked to use Paris as the backdrop for his fashion photographs. Or Cannes or Marrakesh. This was the postwar world of jazz clubs, existentialists, cheap travel, uncrowded streets, beautiful cars, artists and, of course, Paris couture. With his Rolleiflex, Mr. Dambier, who will be 86 on Tuesday, captured all of this with honest joie de vivre, publishing his fashion images in French Elle. And he worked with some of the era's great beauties: Suzy Parker, Dorian Leigh, Bettina, Marie-Hélène Arnaud, Capucine, Ivy Nicholson and a young Brigitte Bardot.

The topic of our discussion today is -- spoiler alert! -- the careful use of spoiler alerts. For readers unfamiliar with the term, it is occasionally inserted in prose or conversation, and not infrequently in reviews of movies or plays, to indicate that a key plot point is about to be divulged that some may prefer to remain in ignorance of. It gives the reader a chance to shut down all systems rather that discover that Mary is really the long-lost sister of Rose, that a freak accident will claim the life of John just when it looks as if things might turn out all right, that in fact the whole traumatic episode was really just a dream!

On April 1, the gallery space at the Southern California Institute of Architecture in downtown Los Angeles will become a disco. This isn't an April Fool's joke - it's "Disco Silencio!" (Silent Disco), an exhibition that runs through May 5. The architect Barbara Bestor, an alumna of the institute, and her firm have designed what they call "a plywood polyhedron of hedonism." Incorporating technologies of surface deception inspired by World War I Razzle Dazzle camouflage, which used bold graphic and anamorphic surfaces to mislead enemy bombers about the size, speed and direction of warships, the crew at Bestor Architecture built an overscaled plywood polyhedron structure in the gallery space. They covered it with a lively graphic surface embedded with fragments of mirrored disco ball, that emblem of 1980s night life, which also distort the space by refracting light. Bestor, whose firm operates under the contemporary manifesto that everyone should experience strange beauty every day, combines deception and illusion of both the serious and the frivolous kind in "Disco Silencio!"

The other day my daughter came home from school excited about having read the book "Sadako and the Thousand Paper Cranes." She grabbed the book out of her backpack, opened it to the end, and told me to read the last line. I did, and then had to read the whole thing (it doesn't take long, though you have to get an actual bound copy; the Google book is partial). The true story of Sadako Sasaki is well known in Japan, and the book by Eleanor Coerr is a staple of elementary-school curricula and class projects in the United States, so chances are you know the basic outline: A Japanese girl gets leukemia as a result of radiation from the bombing of Hiroshima. A friend tells her that if she folds 1,000 paper cranes, her wish to be made well will come true. I couldn't find much about Eleanor Coerr online beyond that she was a Canadian who had spent time in Japan, and died last year at age 88. She wrote in spare, descriptive prose, and I understand why my daughter was stunned by the last line. Here it is, in context:

With the "American Idol" judges having saved Casey Abrams from elimination a week ago, the same slate of 11 competitors faced off again on Wednesday with two hours of musical trials, this time performing the songs of Elton John and Bernie Taupin. The performances attracted an average audience of 23.6 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. for Fox, according to Nielsen's estimates, producing far higher ratings than any other program on that night. Fox easily won the night over all with CBS in second place, NBC in third, followed by ABC in fourth. CBS earned its best ratings at 9 p.m. with "Criminal Minds" (12.9 million), but drew a solid 10.6 million at 8 for "Survivor: Redemption Island." CBS's spinoff "Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior" (9.3 million) led the 10 p.m. hour ahead of "Law & Order: SVU" on NBC (8.3 million) and "Off the Map" on ABC (4.2 million). NBC garnered 4.2 million at 8 for "Minute to Win It" followed by a rerun of "SVU" at 9 (3.6 million), while ABC broadcast sitcom repeats from 8 to 9:30 prior to "Mr. Sunshine" at 9:30 (4.1 million).

In the last 24 hours, we've learned three important things about the Libyan rebellion. First, judging by events on the battlefield, its fighters probably won't be able to topple Qaddafi's government unless we find a way to significantly step our support. Second, we've already offered them more support than anyone realized, since it turns out that the C.I.A. has been assisting the rebel leadership since well before the United Nations resolution that officially justifies our involvement in this conflict. And third, the jihadist presence within the rebellion, while not dominant by any means, may nonetheless be real and meaningful - and growing apace, perhaps, as the civil war drags on.

The gun-toting federal marshal Raylan Givens, the litigator Alicia Florrick and the consulting detective Sherlock Holmes may not share much when it comes to righting wrong-doings, but television series featuring those characters were all named winners of the 70th annual George Foster Peabody Awards on Thursday. Peabody Awards, bestowed by the University of Georgia Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication and recognizing excellence in electronic media, were given to the FX series "Justified" and the CBS drama "The Good Wife," as well as "Sherlock: A Study in Pink," a 21st-century spin on Sherlock Holmes seen on the PBS series "Masterpiece/Mystery!" Other winners included the HBO movie "Temple Grandin," about that autism advocate, as well as the World War II mini-series "The Pacific" and the Spike Lee documentary "If God Is Willing and Da Creek Don't Rise," about life in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, both shown on that cable network. C-Span was named the winner of an award for its searchable video library and CNN for its coverage of the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico; Peabodys also went to the arts series "American Masters" for "LennonNYC," about John Lennon, and "Elia Kazan: A Letter to Elia," directed by Kent Jones and Martin Scorsese.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

By the calendar it has been spring for more than a week, but the Manhattan farmers' markets remain in winter mode, and our home vegetable bin contains onions (and their kin), carrots, parsnips, celery root and not much else. These, of course, are the foundations of many a dish, so there's no ground for complaint. Yet with company coming, I needed to come up with a delicious and, preferably, unexpected first course. A slice of onion tart is always a nice way to start a meal -- who could ever get tired of onions? Plus, I had already cooked a couple of pounds of onions in butter, and these were waiting in the refrigerator (keeping cooked onions at the ready is a great time saver, as they can kick-start innumerable preparations).

There probably won't be many New Yorkers mourning the death of the security roll-down gate, that unlovely after-hours face of the city's storefronts. In 2009, the City Council, citing high rates of graffiti, voted to begin slowly phasing out the gates in favor of rolling grilles, which allow passers-by to look into store windows and do not provide the same kind of metal canvas for spray-can artists.

In our weekly "Poetry Pairing" series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem's themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

Precocious and self-possessed, Charlotte Perriand was a girl among men, admitted to the ranks of the architects whose names would become synonymous with the new century, at an age when her outlook on design and the world was still in formation. In what would prove to be one of Modernism's signal images, she reclines in the chaise longue she designed in collaboration with Le Corbusier and his cousin Pierre Jeanneret. It was, in Le Corbusier's utopian terms, a "machine for resting in," and as if to remind us that it's the chair, not the woman, being presented for our consideration, her face is turned away; she is at once familiar and unrecognizable. That the design of their now-famous furniture was for many years attributed to Le Corbusier alone, that most of her architectural projects never made it past the drawing board, that her far-ranging commissions defied easy classification, that her most significant projects are either gone or off the beaten path: all this only contributed to the enigma. Now, 12 years after her death, at 96, "Charlotte Perriand: Photography: A Wide-Angle Eye," by Jacques Barsac (5 Continents Editions), offers an intimate glimpse of the woman and the workings of her mind.

Almost everything about the psychiatric process is apparently open to interpretation, even the status of a television series about it. On Wednesday night, reports surfaced that HBO had canceled its drama "In Treatment," which has starred Gabriel Byrne as the psychotherapist Dr. Paul Weston, and featured a rotating roster of actors including Hope Davis, Debra Winger and Mia Wasikowska as his patients. Dianne Wiest and Amy Ryan also starred, as Dr. Weston's own therapists. And while a cigar is sometimes just a cigar, HBO seemed to suggest that this cancellation was not necessarily a cancellation. In a statement, the network said: "It's true that we have no plans to continue with 'In Treatment' as previously formatted. However, we are in continued conversations with the executive producers to find another way to continue telling these rich stories."

Nathan Myhrvold keeps busy. The former chief technology officer of Microsoft is an executive at DreamWorks Animation, once studied with Stephen Hawking and donated Tyrannosaurus rex fossils he uncovered in Montana to the Smithsonian. He was profiled by Malcolm Gladwell, is a pal of Bill Gates and spent the last several years working on "Modernist Cuisine," an encyclopedic six-volume compendium of cutting-edge cooking that is not only one of the most expensive cookbooks ever published (the list price is $625, though it's available on Amazon.com for a mere $461.62) but also one of the heaviest, a fire-door-stopper that tips the scales at more than 40 pounds. An initial print run of 6,000 editions has already sold out.

Digital technology and the Internet aren't for early adopters and tweens anymore. That's great, but it's led to a new problem for a lot of grown-ups: They've become the first line of tech support for their parents. For most people, debugging someone else's problem - usually done remotely - is an exercise in exasperation. Especially when that someone changed your diapers, put up with your teenage years and now expects payback.

Freie Internationale Tankstelle, or FIT, is back in Berlin, offering passersby a "fueling station for the creative spirit" in the most unlikely of art venues: a gas station. Founded in 2002 by the artist Dida Zende, FIT sits just off the beaten path on a leafy street in Prenzlauer Berg. The station itself dates back to the 1920s, a quirky historical monument that Mr. Zende has transformed into what he describes as an "inverse white cube" for contemporary artists.

In Today's Times:--Covert operatives from the Central Intelligence Agency are in Libya gathering military intelligence that the United States and its allies hope to use to "bleed" dry Col. American officials cautioned, though, that the Western operatives were not directing the actions of rebel forces.

Audio-component maker JBL announced this week its OnBeat iPad speaker dock. Costing $150, the OnBeat can increase the iPad's audio output while also charging the tablet. A USB port can connect the dock to a computer, so it can charge, amplify and sync an iPad at the same time. If you are someplace where all your music is on your iPad and you want to fill a room with its sound, then a dock like this makes sense. But for home use, there are probably better and less expensive options. If you have a Wi-Fi network at home, you can connect your home stereo (and all of its speakers) to your iTunes library by buying an Airport Express from Apple for $99. You can then control the music from your computer, iPod Touch, iPhone or iPad using Apple's free Remote app.

Zahi Hawass, who resigned as Egypt's minister of antiquities less than a month ago under criticism for his close ties to former President Hosni Mubarak, was reappointed to the post on Wednesday, Agence France-Presse reported, citing an Egyptian news report; Mr. Hawass, reached by phone, confirmed his reappointment. Mr. Hawass, a powerful figure in the world of Egyptology, was promoted to a cabinet position in the early days of the uprising, and drew the animosity of the revolutionaries by saying at the time that Mr. Mubarak should be allowed to hold power for another six months. He also said that Egypt's museums and archeological sites were largely secure and that cases of looting were very limited. In the weeks that followed, that turned out not to be the case: several dozen objects were stolen from the Egyptian Museum in Cairo during a break-in on Jan. 28 - many have been recovered, though 37 are still missing - and hundreds more were taken from tombs and warehouses elsewhere in Egypt.

FERRARO--Geraldine. While the world knew her as a trail blazer, which she was, and an inspiration and role model for women, which she was, to me and to her legion of friends, colleagues and admirers, she was a true and loyal friend, who never let fame go to her head. From our first meeting in 1977 when she was an Assistant District Attorney in Queens, and I was Chief Assistant, we stayed in touch, exchanging family and professional news, always encouraging and supportive of one another and our mutual commitment to public service. She will be profoundly missed. Joseph Fisch

Q.Something happened on my Mac laptop, and now I can't see my entire desktop at once. The screen also moves over when I move the mouse to the edge. I tried adjusting the Display preferences, but that didn't help. What might be causing this?A.The Mac has a number of accessibility options built into its software to aid users with vision and hearing impairments. One of these options is the Zoom feature, which magnifies the screen and can be activated (sometimes accidentally) by pressing the Option-Command-8 keys on the keyboard. To check if Zoom feature inadvertently got turned on, press the Option-Command-8 keys to see if the setting reverses itself. You can also turn it off by going to the System Preferences area, clicking Universal Access and clicking the Zoom button to Off.

TUCSON -- Representative Gabrielle Giffords is still in the hospital, but some of her most ardent backers are so enamored of the idea of her running for the Senate that they describe the inevitable campaign commercials: the deep-voiced narrator recounting what happened to her, the images of her wounded, then recovering and speaking into the camera alongside her astronaut husband to call on Arizonans to unite. These supporters say they do not want to get too far ahead of themselves, and make clear that Ms. Giffords, who was shot in the head, is still relearning basic tasks and might emerge from the hospital with neither the same political abilities nor aspirations that she had before. And publicly, her closest aides say the only thing they care about is her health.

CLARKE--Mary Clorinda (Toto), 94, a former resident of Gramercy Park, died March 7, 2011, and a funeral mass was held at Historic Old St. John's Church, Utica, on March 29th. She was born March 4, 1917 in Utica, daughter of the late Dr. Thomas Wood Clarke and Angela Clorinda Tracy. She graduated from Manhattanville College in 1938 and then enrolled in a Masters program in English at Oxford University. She studied there until the fall of 1939 when the outbreak of World War II forced her to return stateside. Once back in New York, she worked for US military intelligence on Governors Island until 1945. Toto continued to live in New York City for the next forty-plus years. After completing a Masters in English at Columbia University, she spent the next thirty years, working for New York Life Insurance Company, becoming the managing editor of the New York Life Review. She moved back to Utica in 1989. A poet, historian, and author, Toto had a great interest in the American Revolution. In the 1960s, she wrote two books, "The American Revolution 1775-83" and "Young America Republic", for British school children. McGraw-Hill later reprinted in hardcover her book on the Revolution. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sunset Wood Foundation, 118 Genesee St., New Hartford, NY 13413.

A Texas prosecutor's proposal that Willie Nelson sing his way out of a recent arrest for marijuana possession has all but gone up in smoke after a judge there rejected the idea. Kit Bramblett, the county attorney for Hudspeth County in West Texas, had suggested that Mr. Nelson pay a small fine and sing ''Blue Eyes Crying in the Rain'' at the courthouse as punishment after his arrest at a border stop in Sierra Blanca, Tex., on Nov. 26, when a Border Patrol agent smelled pot on his tour bus. Mr. Bramblett acknowledged that his suggested sentencing would still need to be approved by a judge. Unfortunately for Willie Nelson fans in Hudspeth County, Judge Becky Dean-Walker told The Associated Press that Mr. Nelson can plead guilty without going to court and giving an impromptu performance, adding that she believed Mr. Bramblett was making a joke ''and it got out of hand.'' For those who don't remember, ''Blue Eyes Crying in the Rain'' is track No. 5 on Mr. Nelson's 1975 album ''Red Headed Stranger.''

SCIENCE TIMES The Global Update article on Tuesday, about the World Health Organization's first list of 30 essential medicines for maternal and child health, misstated the form the agency recommended for the administration of two drugs. It called for magnesium sulfate to be given in injectable form, not as Epsom salts, which have the same chemical makeup. The agency left unspecified a form for the antibacterial agent chlorhexidine digluconate; it did not specify soap. O

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. - Jason Bay has not played in a major league game since July 25, missing the final 63 games of last season because of the lingering effects of a concussion. It was not until the off-season that the symptoms subsided completely. Bay then had a decent spring training, batting .333 in 16 games, but without a home run.

To the Editor:Your article ''Virtual Visitation Rights''(Sunday Styles, March 20) discussed Facebook's value in developing relationships between children and their absent parents. Facebook appears to be an easy solution to the distance problem by suggesting presence:a parent can be informed of day-to-day details and be available for ''chat'' whenever child and parent are logged on.While this seems like a positive step, as a college student living away from home for the first time I have found it serves no meaningful purpose and only compromises the depth of the parent-child relationship.The flippant nature of Facebook conversations cannot replace the greater value found in phone conversation or letter writing.MEGAN JENSEN Minneapolis

FOREIGN An article on March 8 about Libyan military attacks on rebel forces misstated a British television correspondent's description of a March 4 assault by government forces on the rebel-held city of Zawiyah, as published in the March 7 edition of The Daily Telegraph, a British newspaper. The correspondent, Alex Crawford of Sky News, the only journalist present in Zawiyah on March 4, told the newspaper that residents marching toward a funeral had been fired on by soldiers, not by government snipers. She also said someone told her there were 25 to 30 tanks in a column she had witnessed shelling the city; she did not count the number of tanks herself. And she described a person she had seen apparently learning how to fire a rocket-propelled grenade in defense as a young man, not a young boy. T

KENTZ--Frederick C. Jr.,Hon. Frederick C. Kentz, Jr., retired Judge of the Superior Court of NJ, passed away on March 25, 2011. He resided in Spring Lake, NJ and Vero Beach, FL. Judge Kentz was born in Summit, NJ. He was a graduate of the Pingry School, Georgetown University and Fordham University School of Law. He was admitted to the New Jersey Bar in 1944. He was appointed a Juvenile and Domestic Relations Judge in 1966 by Governor Hughes, and then a Superior Court Judge in 1973 by Governor Cahill. He went on to serve as Presiding Judge, Chancery Division, in Union County, until his retirement in 1989. He then served as a recall Judge until 1999. Judge Kentz was predeceased by his wife, Rita. He is survived by his four children, Maryanne Kentz Sea, Ecuador, Frederick (Rick) C. Kentz III, Chatham and Spring Lake, NJ, Patricia (Patsy) Kentz Ondo, Reston, VA, and Andrew W. Kentz, Washington, DC, and four grandchildren. Visitation will be at O'Brien Funeral Home, Wall, NJ on Friday, April 1st, 5-8pm. The Funeral Mass will be at St. Catharine's Church, Spring Lake, NJ on Saturday, 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Rita O'Brien Kentz Scholarship Fund, c/o The Oak Knoll School, 44 Blackburn Road., Summit, NJ 07901.

Sometimes engineers get excited about things without stopping to ask the question: Why? Why is this better? Why would anyone want this? Such questions, it would appear, were not asked in the labs of Acer. Its latest offering, the Iconia, is one of the most bizarre products to ever make it to production. The Iconia, when closed, looks like a laptop. When opened, however, all is revealed: the Iconia is actually two 14-inch touchscreens joined at a hinge.

William LeRoy and his lawyer trudged up a short flight of dusty stairs in a former factory on a dead-end street in Queens. Behind a steel mesh barrier, a man in a pork-pie hat waited at a counter with his ledger. He had heard something about Mr. LeRoy. ''Oh, you're the sign guy,'' he said. ''Go out to the loading dock out front.''

BEIJING -- The Experimental Theater of Central Academy of Drama is tucked away in a warren of ancient streets named for goods long ago sold there -- Fried Bean Lane and East Cotton Alley -- that nowadays are lined with small shops and cafes. Never easy to find, the theater was particularly forbidding on a frigid evening in late January, when the gate to the entire complex stood locked and guarded, opened only to those in possession of a printed invitation to the event within: a dress rehearsal for the Beijing Dance Theater's adaptation of ''Jin Ping Mei,'' or ''The Golden Lotus.'' The piece had its premiere last weekend at the Hong Kong Arts Festival, which commissioned it.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York's rejection of the American International Group's offer to buy back $15.7 billion worth of mortgage securities poses a big problem for the insurer, the company's chief executive said on Wednesday. Instead of selling the entire Maiden Lane II portfolio of securities back to A.I.G., the New York Fed instead has chosen to sell off pieces over time, potentially opening up the sales process to other bidders.

COOPER-MULLIN--John Fulham, died of pancreatic cancer at his home in Irvington, New York, on March 29, 2011. He was 58. John was born February 10, 1953, in Cleveland, Ohio, to Margaret Fulham Mullin and Samuel Stephen Mullin (deceased). He graduated from St. Ignatius High School in Cleveland in 1971 and graduated cum laude from Bowdoin College with a degree in History and Economics in 1975. At Bowdoin John was an outstanding thespian, winning the George H. Quinby Award and the Abraham Goldberg Prize. In 1979 he received an MBA from Columbia Business School. John was a Managing Director at Rothschild, Inc. from 1989 until 2000. He left to establish Redwall Partners, a firm specializing in international transactions and recapitalizations. A division of RP&C International (Securities) Inc., Redwall has offices in New York and London. John was a founding member of the Irvington Education Association and served on the Irvington Business Committee as well. He was a member of The Scarsdale Congregational Church and served as treasurer of Broadway Housing Communities. He was a regular in the Irvington men's Sunday morning basketball game and an avid biker, kayaker, and skier. John was blessed with a beautiful singing voice that brought joy to many. He loved debate and never shied away from a political discussion. He is survived by his college sweetheart and wife Alison; their daughters Emma, Clara, Elizabeth, and Rebecca; his mother; his brother Sam and his sisters Ann, Mary, Margaret, and Barbara and their spouses; his mother-in-law and father-in-law Gloria and Wally Cooper; his sister-in-law Julie and her spouse; and his twenty-one loving nephews and nieces. Funeral services will be held at The Scarsdale Congregational Church, One Heathcote Road, Scarsdale, on Saturday April 2, at 10am. Donations in his memory may be made to Broadway Housing Communities, 583 Riverside Drive, New York, NY 10031. Broadway Housing is a non profit committed to providing innovative permanent housing for individuals and families in the greatest need.

Q.My eyes ache badly if I read for more than a moment in sunlight, and or under fluorescent lights and flat computer screens. Because of this, I use incandescent bulbs and cathode-ray tube monitors, but I now want to buy a smartphone and a tablet computer. Will these screens also make my eyes to hurt? A.Staring at any type of computer screen for a certain amount of time can cause eyestrain for many people. First, just to get your medical bases covered, you may want to schedule an appointment with your eye doctor for an examination, as well as for professional ergonomic advice on how to deal with eye fatigue when using electronic displays.

PETERS--Vincent J.,Cushman & Wakefield mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Jimmy Peters, our former president, CEO and Chairman. A memorial service is planned at St. Patrick's Cathedral Thursday, April 7, at 10:30am. Until the time of his death, he was a vice chairman of C&W. His passion for real estate motivated and inspired generations of brokerage professionals and helped shape urban skylines and revive central cities from coast to coast. He joined C&W at age 17 in 1940, served four years in the US Marine Corps. during WWII, including two years fighting in the Pacific, before returning to C&W. He led Cushman & Wakefield from 1976 to 1982. Together with his brothers, Leone J. Peters (1911-1988) and Anthony J. Peters (1916-2010), he was instrumental in the expansion of C&W from a New York company into a national powerhouse. Throughout his career, he spearheaded the initial lease-up of more than 20 million square feet of office space nationwide. In New York, he held the distinction of having won REBNY's Most Ingenious Deal of the Year in 1975 and 1985. Outside of real estate he was dedicated to a wide variety of charitable endeavors and among other honors was the recipient of the Anti-Defamation League's Norman Tishman Human Relations Award "for his outstanding contributions to industry and to the civic and philanthropic life of the American community." He was born in Brooklyn in 1922, the youngest of six brothers and a sister. We extend our sympathy to his entire family, including his wife Antoinette (Toni), his children Judy Sylvan and Eric Peters, as well as his grandchildren, Aron and Laura Sylvan.

BALL--Margaret R.,93, formerly of 32 Russell Street, Great Barrington, died Sunday March 27, 2011 at Berkshire Place, Pittsfield, MA. She was a 1938 graduate of Radcliffe College and a member of the Phi Beta Kappa Honor Society. She worked as a Biochemist for Harvard Medical School for 44 years from 1939-1983. She was a member of the Emma Forbes Cary Guild of Radcliffe; she also served as its President, and was also a member of the Irish Genealogical Society. Margaret also collaborated in particular with Dr. Francis Moore, renowned surgeon at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, Boston on the effects on body fluids in surgical trauma, as well as other bio-chemistry studies. Funeral Services for Margaret R. Ball, who died March 27, will be held on Friday April 1, 2011 with a Liturgy of Christian Burial at 11:00am at Our Lady of the Valley Church, Sheffield. Family will receive friends at a calling hour preceding the funeral from 9:30-10:30am at the Birches-Roy Funeral Home, Great Barrington.

SYRIA After the most severe unrest that the country has experienced in decades, President Bashar al-Assad delivered a much-anticipated speech. But despite expectations that he might call political reforms, Mr. Assad instead showcased his firm grip on power and declined to offer concessions.

Most of us have an image of the turnaround guy. For some, the term can conjure up images of an unfeeling taskmaster, exemplified by Albert Dunlap, known as Chainsaw Al, who applied his famously ruthless methods to companies like Scott Paper and Sunbeam in the 1980s. Recently, however, I had the good fortune to meet not one but two men who put to rest my stereotype of the turnaround guy as Rambo in pinstripes. John Newman recently retired from turnaround work after 15 successful engagements. His efforts took him across the country, where his clients ranged from closely held businesses to some of the largest agricultural cooperatives in the United States. Lynn Hartrick has been helping midmarket business owners with turnarounds, transitions and liquidity events for 14 years. Both men have many of the same outward qualities, including impeccable listening skills and a genuine desire to fix broken companies. I asked them about the work they do and what advice they have for small-business owners.

Last week, we published a case study reviewing Leon Rozenblit's recent decision to hire a senior sales representative at Prometheus Research, a data-management company he founded in New Haven. Unfortunately for Prometheus, a strategy that seemed promising proved too pricey to sustain. Dr. Rozenblit said that due diligence done by the sales rep, Peter Harker, led Prometheus to change the way it marketed its data-management software, HTSQL, to new clients. ''Initially, we were trying to pitch it as a tool I.T. guys could use,'' Dr. Rozenblit said. ''We started with the geeky message, we have this Web-native query language, and it's awesome! And people said, 'What does that mean and why should I care?' We thought customers should want to build Web applications with HTSQL to enable data sharing, but customers didn't care about that. They cared about how fast they could get reports.''

A federal court judge on Wednesday dismissed a suit brought against the billionaire Steven A. Cohen by his former wife - ending a highly public chapter for the secretive hedge fund manager. Patricia Cohen brought the case in late 2009, claiming that her ex-husband, the founder of SAC Capital, hid millions from her during their divorce 20 years earlier. Ms. Cohen filed suit under a civil version of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO, a law typically employed in organized crime prosecutions.

His humor, wisdom and limitless intellectual curiosity will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife, Carol, his children, Alicia Stammer and Bradley Leet, his stepchildren, Lorraine Romanelli and Christopher Daley, and his grandchildren, Billy and Jamie Stammer, Isabelle and Elizabeth Romanelli and Connor Daley. Donations will be used to award scholarships to local artists.

Updated: Medicare announced on Wednesday that it would pay for Dendreon's prostate cancer drug Provenge, whose $93,000 price tag had ignited debate about the cost and effectiveness of cancer drugs. Success came quickly for SolTec Electronics. The company, which Dawn Gluskin founded from her living room and financed with her savings and retirement accounts in 2008, sells hard-to-find electronic circuit board components, such as semi-conductors and integrated circuits to companies operating in the electronic manufacturing and aerospace industries. By 2009, SolTec had annual revenue of $700,000. In 2010, it moved into office space in Rockledge, Fla., hit $2.7 million in revenue, and secured a $150,000 line of credit. SolTec, according to Ms. Gluskin, helps clients when traditional distributor relationships break down. Given the rapid pace of technological advance, critical components in a supply chain can suddenly become obsolete. Many manufacturers also have trouble keeping up with demand, which can result in long lead times as they wait for parts. In addition, counterfeit parts have flooded the global market, which is why SolTec tests all components in its lab before sending them to customers.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- The Afghan Taliban are showing signs of increasing strain after a number of killings, arrests and internal disputes that have reached them even in their haven in Pakistan, Afghan security officials and Afghans with contacts in the Taliban say. The killings, coming just as the insurgents are mobilizing for the new fighting season in Afghanistan, have unnerved many in the Taliban and have spread a climate of paranoia and distrust within the insurgent movement, the Afghans said.

LOS ANGELES RODARTE is on a roll. Over the last year the fashion brand, created in 2005 by the sisters Kate and Laura Mulleavy, made headlines not only for its distinctive ready-to-wear collections but also for its first foray into costume design. The company created some key attire for the Oscar-winning film ''Black Swan'' as well as the dress the movie's star, Natalie Portman, wore to the Academy Awards ceremony -- where she took the year's best-actress statuette for her portrayal of a ballerina on the edge. HICKEY--Lawrence Francis, Lawrence Francis Hickey, 90, died peacefully at home in New York City. Cherished husband of the late Jean Hogan Hickey, his bride of 56 years, adored father of Elizabeth Hickey Lavin of Pelham Manor, NY, Frank Hickey, Magee Hickey Salembier and Jane Hickey Sexton, all of New York City, and beloved father-in-law of Tom Lavin, Rick Salembier and Mason Speed Sexton. He was the devoted grandfather of 11: Tom, Kate, Meg, Jack and Janie Lavin, Lily and Floy Salembier, Mason, Buckman, Keats and Daisy Sexton and beloved grandfather-in-law of Scott Phillips. He was a special friend of Miao Hua Zhou. He was lovingly cared for by Felicidad Collado, Astou Diop, Nur Purnamawaty and so many others. Mr. Hickey, born in Brooklyn, was a graduate of the University of Notre Dame class of 1942. He served in World War II as a lieutenant senior grade USN in the Pacific. He received the William D. Reynolds Award in 1992 from Notre Dame and was the Notre Dame Club of New York "Man of the Year" in 1993. He also received an Honorary Degree of Doctor of Humane Letters in 1995 from St. John's University. After retiring from his family's concrete business, M.F. Hickey Company, which was founded by his grandfather in 1896, Mr. Hickey spent the last three decades helping the mentally retarded and emotionally disturbed children of New York City. He served on the Board of the Kennedy Child Study Center for decades. Mr. Hickey was head of the Parish Council, Eucharistic Minister, lector, and altar server at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church. He was also a member of the board of Astor Services for Children for many years. During that time, he oversaw the purchase and renovation of a two-room, Victorian Gothic schoolhouse known as "The Little Red Schoolhouse." It was renamed in honor of him and is now called the Lawrence F. Hickey Center for Child Development, a therapeutic early childhood development program. In addition, Mr. Hickey was a past president of the Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter, The Amateur Comedy Club and The Jones Wood Association. He was chief Honorary Usher and a lector at St. Patrick's Cathedral, a Knight Equestrian of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem and a Knight of Malta. The Daughters of Charity recognized him for his work at the Kennedy and Astor facilities by naming him an "Affiliate" of the Order in 1990. Mr. Hickey was a member of the Friends of Cardinal Cooke Guild and an early member of the Bishop Fulton J. Sheen Foundation promoting the case for sainthood. When asked why he spent his retirement years helping others, Mr. Hickey wrote: "Lessons learned on the campus of Notre Dame, from my Irish Catholic background, and a tour of 49 months in the Navy in WWII, convinced me that we all must help God's less fortunate." And in his final years, nothing made him happier than to be surrounded by his large and adoring circle of family and friends in his weekend home in Millerton, New York. The wake will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Thursday from 6 to 9pm. The Funeral Mass will be held at Saint Patrick's Cathedral at 10am, Friday. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Lawrence F. Hickey Center for Child Development, 4010 Dyre Avenue, Bronx, NY 10466 or the Kennedy Child Study Center, 151 East 67th Street, New York, NY 10065.

The spy novelist John le Carre was chosen as one of 13 finalists for the Man Booker International Prize, the prize committee announced in Sydney on Wednesday. His response? No, thanks. A 370-year-old painting that belonged to a Jewish art dealer who fled the Netherlands around the time of the Nazi invasion in 1940 will be returned to his family by the J. Paul Getty Museum, The Associated Press reported. The painting, ''Landscape With Cottage and Figures,'' done by Pieter Molijn around 1640, belonged to Jacques Goudstikker, a prominent dealer who died in a fall on a ship while fleeing the Nazis with his wife and son. His collection was looted, and some of the art ended up in the hands of the Nazi leader Hermann Goering, according to the Associated Press report. In a written statement released Monday, museum officials stated: ''Working in cooperation with representatives of the Goudstikker heirs, the Getty's research revealed that the painting was in Goudstikker's inventory at the time of the invasion in 1940, and that it was never restituted after World War II. Based on its findings, the Getty concluded that the painting should be transferred to the heirs.''

BOLLON--Vincent J. Washington, D.C. Long-time labor leader and former New York City fire fighter and fire officer Vincent J. Bollon, 77, passed away March 28 at his home in Fairfax County, Virginia. Bollon served as General Secretary-Treasurer of the International Association of Fire Fighters from 1988 until 2010, making him the second-longest serving principal officer in the 92-year history of the IAFF. He retired in January 2010. Bollon joined the FDNY in 1959, fulfilling his ambition to be a New York City fire fighter. During his firefighting career he served as a fire fighter in the busiest fire station in the Bronx and as a fire officer in the busiest fire station in Harlem. He was awarded FDNY's Medal for Bravery, twice; and presented with meritorious medals for service on nine separate occasions. Bollon was an extraordinary union leader going back to his first election in 1975 as the Financial Recording Secretary for Uniformed Firefighters Association (UFA) Local 94. After his promotion to Lieutenant in 1977, he continued his union service to Uniformed Fire Officers Association (UFOA) Local 854 and was first elected to the Local 854 Executive Board in 1978 and served as the President of Local 854 for eight years. He was also first vice chairman of the largest fire fighter pension fund in the United States and Canada from 1980 to 1988. Most recently he was chairman of the NFPA Pension Fund and a trustee on the Fairfax County, Virginia, Uniformed Retirement System. While in New York City, Bollon was instrumental in enacting legislation for fire fighters throughout the State of New York, protecting their benefits and their occupational health and safety. In addition, he drafted and helped secure the passage of the New York State First Line Supervisors Law, which provides officer training at state expense for newly promoted first line supervisors in all New York State paid fire departments. He also served on the boards of directors for the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA), New York State Fire Safety Advisory Board, New York City Fire Museum and John Jay College. During Bollon's 21 years as the IAFF General Secretary-Treasurer he succeeded in implementing new programs, processes and tools to assist local union leadership with financial, membership and accounting issues. He worked diligently to grow union membership, not just in finances and numbers, but in influence within the North American labor movement. He leaves his wife, Linda; his children Janice and her husband Ron Roveto, Suzanne Bollon, Chrysee Bollon, and Kathleen and her husband Walter Scott; and his grandchildren Jennifer, Steven, Matthew, Nicholas, Caitlin, and Brianne. The wake will be held on Saturday, April 2nd and Sunday, April 3rd from 2:00 to 4:00 and from 7:00 to 9:00pm at the St. James Funeral Home - South Chapel, 829 Middle Country Road, Route 25, St. James, New York 11780; telephone: 631-584-7200. The Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday April 4th at 10:00am at the Saints Philip and James Roman Catholic Church, 1 Carow Place, St. James, New York. Interment will follow at St. Raymond's Cemetery, 2600 Lafayette Avenue, Bronx, New York. For more information go to www.iaff.org

A little knowledge is a dangerous thing; a lot of it can be deadly. Such was the case on the eve of the Civil War. Among all the events that touched off the great conflict - John Brown's raid in 1859, Abraham Lincoln's presidential victory in 1860 - there is one that has been strangely ignored by most historians. True, it was less dramatic than the others. It occurred when enumerators traveled from door to door throughout America, counting up Easterners and Westerners; Northerners and Southerners; blacks and whites; freemen and slaves. The numbers that they came up with helped to split apart the Union.

With just over two weeks left before Tax Day, many people have yet to deal with the annual ritual of preparing tax returns. In an attempt to make it quicker and more efficient, the Internal Revenue Service continues its Free File program for filing federal taxes online. Taxpayers with a gross adjusted income less than $58,000 can use free tax preparation software provided by the agency's partners. People with larger incomes can use the Free File Fillable Forms, which are electronic versions of the traditional paper worksheets. Both options are available here.

Sebastian Errazuriz, the Chilean-born designer and artist, became famous for his Bilbao shelf, in which a real tree branch was attached to a wall to create an organic display unit. In his latest design, the Metamorphosis shelf, Errazuriz really goes out on a limb. The inspiration for the limited-edition Baltic birch plywood shelf (which is hand-carved by the Italian company Horm) came from his grandmother's ivy-covered garden. "The dark branches that crawled along the walls were so thick that I would use them as natural shelves for my garden toys," Errazuriz said. Given the $75,000 price tag, however, your spade and trowel had better be by Fabergé.

My cigarette days are well over but the name Latakia still brings up physical memories of "Turkish" tobacco. The Syrian port city was part of the Ottoman empire, is very near the Turkish border, and has a long connection with the tobacco trade. It's in the news now for protests against the government of Bashar al-Assad. Latakia is particularly interesting because the town and province are the heartland of the Alawites, a Shiite sect that produced the ruling Assad family and much of the current governing elite. (In the wake of the Ottoman collapse in the early 20th century, there was an on-again-off-again Alawite "state" based in and around Latakia until 1944, when it integrated with Syria.)

Two finalists were eliminated from "American Idol" on Thursday, Naima Adedapo and Thia Megia, as a results episode of the Fox reality show attracted an impressive 22 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. The audience for "Idol" lifted Fox far ahead of its network rivals on the night and provided a boost to Fox's hidden-camera special with Howie Mandel, "Mobbed," which delivered a solid 10.8 million viewers at 9 p.m. following "Idol." ABC's "Grey's Anatomy" (12.7 million) edged past CBS's "CSI" (12.5 million) to lead that time slot, but CBS ranked second for the night over all, earning its best ratings at 10 with "The Mentalist" (13.9 million) and strong results at 8 and 8:30 for the sitcoms "The Big Bang Theory" (11.7 million) and "Rules of Engagement" (8.2 million). ABC was third as 6.3 million tuned in to "Wipeout" at 8 and 7.6 million at 10 for "Private Practice." NBC placed a very distant fourth with mostly repeats of its comedy line-up. On Bravo on Wednesday, the eighth season finale of "Top Chef" delivered 2.8 million viewers, slightly more than the audience who watched the series' prior season conclusion (2.7 million).

My colleague Eric Platt has just informed me that our ledger of 2011 college admissions figures has more than doubled since we put up our first draft on Wednesday. It now includes 75 institutions. It's an eclectic, difficult-to-pigeonhole list, and as you'll see, the newest entries include Babson, Caltech, the College of New Jersey, Julliard, Penn State, the University of Connecticut and Vassar. I won't pretend to even speculate on the trends that can be sifted from these early returns -- which, of course, are but a snapshot of the nation's 2,000 four-year colleges -- but they surely provide a frame of reference for those of you who have been accepted, rejected or deferred. As you've done all week, I hope you'll continue to tell us your stories, either in the comment stream accompanying the chart, or at the virtual kitchen table accompanying our post on fat and thin envelopes.

In this week's Book Review, I consider the most recent - and most ambitious - effort to compile a dictionary of English-language slang. But such efforts have been underway for centuries. Several months ago, Oxford University's Bodleian Library republished the earliest known foray: "The First English Dictionary of Slang, 1699," with an introduction by John Simpson, chief editor of the Oxford English Dictionary. No. 1 on our hardcover list this week is "Justice League of America: Dark Times," written by James Robinson and illustrated by Mark Bagley. It features a matchup between two teams of costumed heroes: the Justice League and the Justice Society of America. This adventure has links to "Brightest Day," the latest event story from DC Comics about 12 resurrected heroes and villains. One of those heroes, Jade, has ties to both teams. She is the daughter of the Golden Age Green Lantern, one of the founders of the Justice Society, the first comic-book super-team who have had adventures since 1940. Jade was also the significant other of a modern day Green Lantern (Kyle Rayner), a former member of the Justice League.

It's impossible to describe Judy Kameon's career in 25 words or less. Kameon, who lives and works in Los Angeles, has been a painter, a retailer, a stylist-costumer and (for two weeks) the proprietor of an underground restaurant. Today she's a garden designer who has created domestic landscapes for clients like Sofia Coppola, Mike D of the Beastie Boys and the hotelier Sean MacPherson, and public ones for the fashion houses Marc Jacobs and Balenciaga as well as the Parker Palm Springs hotel. In addition to her design firm, Elysian Landscapes, she owns Plain Air - a company that makes Modernist-influenced outdoor furniture - with her husband, Erik Otsea, a photographer. All these lives inform her current one, in which she is a combination designer/artist/plant geek/avid cook/hostess/mother hen who is happy to describe the properties of a particular variety of cactus in her garden while she offers a plate of freshly baked scones or negotiates a play date for her 5-year-old son. For Kameon, it all grows together.

Parents of small children probably know James McMullan as the creator (along with his wife, Kate) of the popular picture book "I Stink!" about the nightly rounds of a profoundly disgusting but hard-working New York City garbage truck. He is also enshrined in disco lore for the paintings he did more than 30 years ago for New York magazine that became the visual inspiration for "Saturday Night Fever." But these days Mr. McMullan is much better known for the elegantly expressive show posters he makes for Lincoln Center Theater. And this week a large selection of those posters - for plays and musicals like "Ah! Wilderness," "Carousel" and "South Pacific" - went on display near the theater they helped promote, at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, on Lincoln Center Plaza off Amsterdam Avenue near 64th Street. The posters, as well as preliminary sketches, photographs and watercolor and gouache studies, will remain on view at the library through June 11, and on April 4, Mr. McMullan will join fellow theatrical graphic artist Frank Verlizzo, known as Fraver, at the library for a discussion about the living art of poster-making.

In his testimony on Capitol Hill yesterday, Secretary of Defense Robert Gates made what amounted to an eloquent, even impassioned case against United States involvement in Libya. He highlighted the weakness of the rebel forces: Calling them an opposition is “a misnomer,” he suggested, describing the rebels as “very disparate, very scattered,” “lacking command and control and lacking organization,” and “pretty much a pickup ballgame at this point.” Their “governance capacity” for a post-Qaddafi Libya, he added, is “limited, if not nonexistent.” He put great stress on America’s pre-existing commitments: “I am preoccupied with avoiding mission creep, avoiding an open-ended, very large scale commitment in this respect … The last thing this country needs is another exercise in nationbuilding.” And he basically threatened to resign if the White House somehow decided to send ground forces into Libya: “Not as long as I’m in this job,” he said, when asked about the possibility of putting (non-C.I.A.) boots on the ground.

He taught in a school that in those years was peppered with the children of liberals, socialists and communists, where the students themselves vigorously refused to crouch during air-raid drills and protested outdoor nuclear testing. Yet Arnold Canell stood at the front of the classroom quoting William F. Buckley Jr. and his National Review, slyly enjoying the provocative disparity of views.

Jennifer Campbell is 39 years old and is 26 weeks pregnant with her second son. Her first, who is now two-and-a-half, was born prematurely at 29 weeks (28 weeks, six days to be exact), and her high-risk obstetrician is using the tools available to keep that from happening again. One of those tools is a drug called "17P," which, until recently, cost $10 for each weekly injection. But a few weeks ago the name of the drug changed to Makena and the price went up to more than $1,500 per shot, which would have brought the cost to $30,000 for Ms. Campbell's four-month treatment, she explained to me in an e-mail.

The Brooklyn Flea moves outdoors this weekend and finds a new home on Sundays. All the vendors will still open at the flagship Fort Greene location, 176 Lafayette Avenue (between Clermont and Vanderbilt Avenues) on Saturdays, but the Flea will be located in Williamsburg on the waterfront, 27 North Sixth Street (Kent Avenue), on Sundays. Among the food vendors making a debut are Brooklyn Bangers, a sausage-sandwich concept from Saul Bolton, the chef of Saul and the Vanderbilt, and Fany Gerson’s Dough, where a variety of her doughnuts with hot chocolate will be sold on both days. Christina Tosi from Momofuku Milk Bar also joins the mix with sweets like grapefruit and hibiscus jam. Oystergirl, from the folks behind Mary’s Fish Camp, will shuck oysters, for $1.50 to $3 each, Saturday only. The Kings County Jerky stand and pies from Rachel’s Pies will also operate on Saturdays. The new Sunday-only vendors at the waterfront include Sam Mason’s Empire Mayonnaise, where he will debut artisanal-made mayonnaise served with fries; organic handmade pastas from Rochester, N.Y.-based Flour City Pasta; sweet and savory Czech-style pastry pies from Frgal; smoked meats from Mile End; sandwiches from Saltie and various soups from Sea Bean Goods. The Flea will move back indoors at the former Williamsburgh Savings Bank in November.

"I'm faster than my Xerox," said the artist Ruben Toledo. "Drawing is like thinking for me, so when I'm not drawing it's like I'm not breathing." At last night's "Art Talks" at the Louis Vuitton boutique in SoHo, Toledo - and, shouting from the audience, his wife, the designer Isabel Toledo - spoke with T's editor in chief Sally Singer on subjects as varied as cooking, monsters and the creative process. The intimate group included the fashion icon Iris Apfel, the M.A.C. chief executive John Demsey and the fashion scribe Kim Hastreiter (whom Toledo jokingly dubbed a bad role model). The setting was flanked by oversize sketches from Toledo for Louis Vuitton's new city guide to New York.
