My first daughter was only 2 when I learned I was having twins, and so I still remembered clearly how giddy people were when I was pregnant with her. They'd gleefully tell me tales of 30-hour labors, leaky bladders, struggling marriages. Not so with multiples. From the beginning, people reacted badly to the news. It was as if I had the plague and were coughing in their living room. One friend was openly angry. Some wanted to know exactly what to do to avoid this happening to them. Others just wrinkled their noses as if I'd stepped into a dog-deposited mess. "No," they said. "Really?"

Dinder House, a historic Georgian building in Somerset, England, is like a child's drawing of a house: three stories high, with floor-to-ceiling windows and a slate roof. Completed in 1801 for the Rev. William Somerville (think Jane Austen), it sits on 23 acres of landscaped and walled gardens, in a valley with a Constable-worthy view of the church spire in the village after which it is named. Like many large old English houses, Dinder House was converted to commercial use (in this case by a shoe company rather than, say, a hotel) in recent times, but in 2004 it was bought by Chris and Jo Mycock, the owners of a successful I.T. company. Four years (and five architects) later, they finally moved in, once the soul of the building had been restored - as a family house, for a modern family - by the London designer Ilse Crawford.

HICKEY--Lawrence Francis, Lawrence Francis Hickey, 90, died peacefully at home in New York City. Cherished husband of the late Jean Hogan Hickey, his bride of 56 years, adored father of Elizabeth Hickey Lavin of Pelham Manor, NY, Frank Hickey, Magee Hickey Salembier and Jane Hickey Sexton, all of New York City, and beloved father-in-law of Tom Lavin, Rick Salembier and Mason Speed Sexton. He was the devoted grandfather of 11: Tom, Kate, Meg, Jack and Janie Lavin, Lily and Floy Salembier, Mason, Buckman, Keats and Daisy Sexton and beloved grandfather-in-law of Scott Phillips. He was a special friend of Miao Hua Zhou. He was lovingly cared for by Felicidad Collado, Astou Diop, Nur Purnamawaty and so many others. Mr. Hickey, born in Brooklyn, was a graduate of the University of Notre Dame class of 1942. He served in World War II as a lieutenant senior grade USN in the Pacific. He received the William D. Reynolds Award in 1992 from Notre Dame and was the Notre Dame Club of New York "Man of the Year" in 1993. He also received an Honorary Degree of Doctor of Humane Letters in 1995 from St. John's University. After retiring from his family's concrete business, M.F. Hickey Company, which was founded by his grandfather in 1896, Mr. Hickey spent the last three decades helping the mentally retarded and emotionally disturbed children of New York City. He served on the Board of the Kennedy Child Study Center for decades. Mr. Hickey was head of the Parish Council, Eucharistic Minister, lector, and altar server at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church. He was also a member of the board of Astor Services for Children for many years. During that time, he oversaw the purchase and renovation of a two-room, Victorian Gothic schoolhouse known as "The Little Red Schoolhouse." It was renamed in honor of him and is now called the Lawrence F. Hickey Center for Child Development, a therapeutic early childhood development program. In addition, Mr. Hickey was a past president of the Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter, The Amateur Comedy Club and The Jones Wood Association. He was chief Honorary Usher and a lector at St. Patrick's Cathedral, a Knight Equestrian of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem and a Knight of Malta. The Daughters of Charity recognized him for his work at the Kennedy and Astor facilities by naming him an "Affiliate" of the Order in 1990. Mr. Hickey was a member of the Friends of Cardinal Cooke Guild and an early member of the Bishop Fulton J. Sheen Foundation promoting the case for sainthood. When asked why he spent his retirement years helping others, Mr. Hickey wrote: "Lessons learned on the campus of Notre Dame, from my Irish Catholic background, and a tour of 49 months in the Navy in WWII, convinced me that we all must help God's less fortunate." And in his final years, nothing made him happier than to be surrounded by his large and adoring circle of family and friends in his weekend home in Millerton, New York. The wake will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Thursday from 6 to 9pm. The Funeral Mass will be held at Saint Patrick's Cathedral at 10am, Friday. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Lawrence F. Hickey Center for Child Development, 4010 Dyre Avenue, Bronx, NY 10466 or the Kennedy Child Study Center, 151 East 67th Street, New York, NY 10065.

WILSON--Lanford. The Officers, Board and Staff of Dramatists Play Service mourn the passing of our dear friend and client. We proudly publish and represent all of Lanford's plays, including the Pulitzer Prize winning Talley's Folly which is soon being revived on Broadway. Lanford was discovered in the 1960s at the beginning of the Off-Off and Off-Broadway movement by the legendary play agent Audrey Wood who recognized his unique ability to truthfully capture humanity in his writing which he displayed with love in all his characters. Lanford was one of the founding members of the famed Circle Repertory Company where many of his plays premiered and then quickly became staples of the American Theatre. From his short plays including the groundbreaking The Madness of Lady Bright, through Balm in Gillead and The Hot L Baltimore, and Talley's Folly and Burn This, we were always deeply moved by what Lanford wrote. Whether it's in a black box in Alphabet City, a university auditorium or a Broadway Theatre, Lanford will still be here with us. Dramatists Play Service, Inc. Stephen Sultan, President

HICKEY--Lawrence F. The Amateur Comedy Club notes with sorrow the death of distinguished Honorary Member Larry Hickey, on March 28 in New York. Larry joined the Club in 1954, and as such was among our most senior members. He was elected an Honorary Member in April 1991. We extend condolences to his family.

8:27 p.m. | Updated Live Nation Entertainment, the concert and ticketing giant created by the merger of Ticketmaster and the promoter Live Nation, has emerged as a bidder for the Warner Music Group, according to a person apprised of the bidding who spoke only on the condition of anonymity because the process was intended to be confidential. Live Nation's chairman is Irving L. Azoff, whose long history in the music business includes a stint as chairman of MCA Records. He also controls Front Line Management, which manages the careers of more than 200 acts, including the Eagles and Christina Aguilera.

Billy Joel has canceled a memoir that was scheduled for release in June, his publisher, HarperCollins said on Thursday. ''The Book of Joel'' had been written and edited when Mr. Joel backed out of his contract this week. HarperCollins acquired the book in 2008 for $3 million. Mr. Joel is expected to return the portion of the advance that he has already received. Mr. Joel told The Associated Press in a statement that writing the book made him realize that he was ''not all that interested in talking about the past.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

HELLER--Norman. The Board of Directors and staff of Hebrew Hospital Home of Westchester mourn the loss of our esteemed Board Member. Norman served on the Board for over 20 years until his health began to fail. His keen financial mind was invaluable as he served on our Finance Committee. In addition he served as President of the Hebrew Hospital Home Foundation for many years. His sage counsel will be truly missed. Our sincere condolences go out to his dear wife Lynn as well as to Karen, Nancy, Matthew and his grandchildren. Arnold Goldstein, Chairman Mary Frances Barrett Chief Executive Officer

The former N.F.L. players union asked a federal judge in Minneapolis on Thursday to impose damages against the league for the way it negotiated to be paid $4 billion in TV revenue during a lockout. The dissolved union wants the court to deny the league access to that money. The filing is a response to U.S. District Court Judge David S. Doty's ruling last month that the league acted to ''advance its own interests and harm the interests of the players'' when it renegotiated its television deals.In those deals, the league gave the networks new rights in the 2009 and 2010 seasons without asking for extra money while ensuring the flow of television money in 2011 in the event of a work stoppage.

GINSBERG--Alfred, of New York, NY died at 87 at his sunny Miami home. Born in Vienna he fled Nazi occupation at 16. Tragically losing his parents in the war, Alfred became a self-reliant young man. He proudly served in the US Army in WWII and was awarded the Purple Heart. He was an avid traveler and a hard working entrepreneur. Alfred you will be missed for the love, wisdom, and goodness you shared with us, your loving family, Hee-Ja, Charles and Richard. Services Sunday 10:30am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

COOPER-MULLIN--John F. The Board of Directors and staff of Broadway Housing Communities mourn the passing of our friend and Board Treasurer since 2003. John's ready wit, intellect and generosity of spirit were striking attributes. His powerful integrity combined with astute sensibility for others made him a most trusted and loyal guide. We'll miss his irrepressible humor and keen wisdom most of all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Alison, his daughters and family. The Rev. John M. Felice, O.F.M., Board Chair Ellen Baxter and Mary Ann Villari, Exec. and Managing Directors

ANAGNOST--Dino, on March 30, 2011. Maestro Anagnost is survived by his business partner of 45 years, John Kordel Juliano of New York City and Livingston, NY, a brother Dick Anagnost, a sister Debra Anagnost, a sister-in-law Demetria and three nephews Alexander, Stavros and Dimitri, all of Bedford, NH. Dr. Anagnost was music director and conductor of The Little Orchestra Society of New York for 32 years. During that time he touched the lives of thousands of children with his uniquely designed concerts. He also created innovative and compelling concerts for adults, including the well known Vivaldi's Venice series. Friends may call Sunday, April 3, 4-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Service Monday 10am at The Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th St., New York City. In lieu of flowers, family and friends are encouraged to make contributions to The Little Orchestra Society as a tribute to Maestro Anagnost.

OHLER--Caroline Hardenbergh, wife of the late David Ohler died at her home in Pound Ridge, NY on Sunday, March 27. She is survived by her children; Stephen H. Ohler, Caroline W. Ohler, Philip E. Ohler and her grandchildren; Nicholas D. Ohler, Sophia V. Ohler, Haley C. Miller and Henry C. Ohler.
A column last Friday on the former Duke basketball player Jon Scheyer had an incorrect photo credit with the picture. It should be Dana/Dutch Cowgill, not the Chicago News Cooperative.

WASHINGTON -- President Obama's top two national security officials signaled on Thursday that the United States was unlikely to arm the Libyan rebels, raising the possibility that the French alone among the Western allies would provide weapons and training for the poorly organized forces fighting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's government. Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates made his views known for the first time on Thursday in a marathon day of testimony to members of Congress. He said the United States should stick to offering communications, surveillance and other support, but suggested that the administration had no problem with other countries sending weapons to help the rebels, who in recent days have been retreating under attack from pro-Qaddafi forces.

LIBYA While rebel forces began to regroup after a panicked retreat in the east, an atmosphere of paranoia descended on Tripoli, the capital, in the west. After the country's foreign minister, Moussa Koussa, defected on Wednesday, another senior official, Ali Abdussalam el-Treki, defected to Egypt. Mr. Treki had served as foreign minister and as United Nations ambassador. The authorities were taking no chances of additional defections, assigning guards to senior officials to ensure that they did not leave, a former Libyan official said. SYRIA The government announced new measures intended to address the demands of antigovernment protesters, but independent analysts said they were doubtful that the changes, coming a day after President Bashar al-Assad refused to make concessions, would amount to more than window dressing.

SCHACK--Lola. The faculty, students, staff, and extended community of the NYU Schack Institute of Real Estate and the New York University School of Continuing and Professional Studies express our profound sympathies upon the passing of Lola Schack. She was 96. The matriarch of an admirable, generous, and loving family, her support to NYU through the philanthropy of the Lola and Leonard Schack Foundation carrying her name and that of her late husband has had a transformational impact on the life of our institution. Our sincerest condolences to the Schack, Teitelbaum, and Veal families on the loss of their mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She was a radiant woman of valor and spirit. Robert S. Lapiner, Dean, NYU-SCPS and James P. Stuckey, Divisional Dean and Klara and Larry Silverstein Chair, the NYU Schack Institute of Real Estate.

HUMLEKER--Ruth, 88, died peacefully at home in New York City on March 31st, surrounded by her loving children, Ruth Wooden, Richard Humleker, Jr., Christine Scheuerer and John Humleker. She was a grandmother to nine and great-grandmother to two. Ruth had many careers including arts administrator, travel book author and Peace Corps volunteer to Yemen (1990-1991). She was profoundly political, strongly opinionated and utterly fearless. Donations in her memory can be made to: The Center for Discovery, Box 840, Harris, NY 12742. Private family memorial service.

STENBORG HUGHES--Helen. 1925-2011. A funeral service will be held this Monday, April 4th at 10:30am at The Church of The Transfiguration, also known as The Little Church Around The Corner-1 East 29th St., between Fifth and Madison. A committee of American Roman Catholic bishops announced Wednesday that a popular book about God by Sister Elizabeth A. Johnson, a theologian at Fordham University in New York, should not be used in Catholic schools and universities because it does not uphold church doctrine. The book, ''Quest for the Living God: Mapping Frontiers in the Theology of God,'' examines different understandings of God through experiences of the poor and oppressed, Holocaust victims, Hispanics, women and people of religions other than Catholicism. Among the chapter titles are ''God Acting Womanish'' and ''Accompanying God of Fiesta.''

Nearly a year after hosting ''Saturday Night Live'' to great acclaim - and nearly 20 years after starring in ''The Golden Girls'' - Betty White is heading back to NBC. Ms. White will host a hidden-camera show for the network sometime next season. The network said Thursday that the show, tentatively titled ''Betty White's Off Their Rockers,'' would feature seven senior citizens who pull pranks on people their grandchildren's age. It is based on a European format that has been sold in countries around the world.

SHEPHERD--Dr. Herman (Shep) R. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Albert B. Sabin Vaccine Institute note with deep sorrow the passing of our Founding Chairman, friend and colleague, Dr. Herman (Shep) R. Shepherd at the age of 89. Shep died peacefully after a brief illness. He is survived by his beloved wife of 68 years, Carol Ruth Shepherd, and their four children. Shep was proud of having grown up in Brooklyn. He received his Bachelor of Science degree from Cornell University and later served in the U.S. Army during World War II. He received Honorary Doctorate degrees from Villanova University and The George Washington University. He was internationally renowned for his pioneering work in aerosol technology, which resulted in pivotal breakthroughs in a variety of areas, most notably in the treatment of asthma. Shep was a close friend of Dr. Albert B. Sabin, the discoverer of the oral polio vaccine, whose lifelong work in the field of vaccines inspired Shep to found the Sabin Vaccine Institute, along with Dr. Sabin's widow, Heloisa Sabin. Dr. Shepherd served as Chairman of the Institute's Board of Trustees for over 15 years and as its President for eight years. He was passionately committed to the Institute's mission to reduce the needless suffering of the world's poorest one billion people from vaccine-preventable and neglected tropical diseases. Under his visionary leadership, the Institute is developing new vaccines, advocates for the use of existing vaccines and helps provide treatments to hundreds of millions of people around the globe. He will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Carol Ruth, his children John, Marjorie, Elizabeth and Benjamin, his extended family and many friends and admirers. The family has requested that contributions in honor of Shep be made to the Sabin Vaccine Institute. (www.sabin.org) Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Philip Russell, MD, (Maj. Gen. U.S. Army Ret.), Immediate past Chairman Michael Marine, (U.S. Amb. Ret) Chief Executive OfficerPeter Hotez, MD, PhD, President Ciro de Quadros, MD, Executive Vice President

An article on Tuesday about the increase in the number of maternity tourists, women who pay thousands of dollars to deliver their babies in the United States so the infants are automatically granted American citizenship, misstated the effect such citizenship has on the babies' parents. When such children turn 21, they may petition the United States government to grant their parents permanent residence status, not citizenship.

On Thursday, the New York Yankees began their regular season at Yankee Stadium, a gleaming $1.5 billion behemoth that opened in the Bronx in 2009 as the new home of one of the richest franchises in sports. But next to the stadium is a lingering eyesore - a protracted construction project that was supposed to have been transformed into three public ball fields months ahead of opening day. Instead, some coaches and neighborhood residents say, it remains a joyless Mudville.

8 P.M. (CBS) CHAOSFreddy Rodriguez (''Six Feet Under'') stars as Rick Martinez, a C.I.A. spy whose dream job is eliminated on Day 1 but who is saved just in time by the agency's deputy director, H. J. Higgins (Kurtwood Smith). Higgins thinks the new guy would be a perfect addition -- as a mole -- to the roster of unruly agents in the Clandestine Administration and Oversight Services. Otherwise known as Chaos, the division is assigned to handle threats to national security, the biggest of which seem to be its own bureaucratic gridlock and incompetence. But when the agents dig up dirt on Rick, he finds himself playing their game. Eric Close portrays Michael Dorset, a psychologist turned operative motivated by paranoia; James Murray is Billy Collins, a Scot who was decommissioned from the British Secret Service and banished; Tim Blake Nelson (above right, with Mr. Close, center, and Mr. Rodriguez) is Casey Malick, whose understated demeanor serves to camouflage his ability to transform into a ''human weapon''; and Christina Cole is Adele Ferrer, who seems to have Rick's best interests at heart. But perhaps most dangerous is Fay Carson (Carmen Ejogo), an alluring agent with an uncanny ability for getting at the truth. 8 P.M. (Disney) PHINEAS AND FERB: PHINEAS'S BIRTHDAY CLIP-O-RAMA! As a birthday present to Phineas, Ferb puts together clips from previous episodes that show off the boys' best inventions. New animated segments tie it all together.

Phish, the popular improvisational rock band, announced Thursday that it plans to play a three-day festival over the July 4 weekend at the Watkins Glen International racetrack in Watkins Glen, N.Y. The festival, to be called Super Ball IX, would be Phish's first festival on the East Coast since the Coventry festival in Vermont in 2004. (The roman numeral refers to the fact that this would be Phish's ninth festival overall.) Phish's festivals have routinely attracted tens of thousands of fans to remote locations around the country over the years, even though the band does not invite other musical acts to perform.

HALLAM--Linda Sanders. Funeral services for Linda Sanders Hallam of Gainesville, FL, formerly of Des Moines, IA, and formally of Morrow, LA, will be held at 11:00am Saturday, April 2, 2011. The service will take place at the Big Cane Baptist Church, Big Cane, LA,with the Rev. Joseph Bordelon officiating. Burial will follow in the Church Cemetery. Arrangements are under the direction of Hixson-Ducote Funeral Home of Bunkie. Mrs. Hallam, 59, passed away on Tuesday, March 29, 2011. Her parents, Richard and Annetta Fisher Sanders, preceded her. Survivors include her husband Stephen Hallam of Gainesville; her two sons, Dallas Hallam and wife Michelle of Los Angeles, CA, and Steven Forrest Hallam of Des Moines, IA; and her siblings, Susan Riemer and husband Owen of Morrow, and Dorothy Boger and husband William of Washington, D.C. and their families. Mrs. Hallam was born in Alexandria, LA in 1951 and graduated with distinction from Louisiana State University in 1973. In 1974 she entered the LSU master's program in journalism, and was quickly hired as a reporter for The Clarion-Ledger newspaper in Jackson, MS. In 1984 she began a twelve year career at Southern Living magazine in Birmingham, AL, that culminated when the September 1996 issue published the story most beloved to her in all her career: A Year in the Land of Cotton. At the end of 1996 Mrs. Hallam moved her family north as she took on the role of Book Group Senior Editor for the Meredith Corporation. It was there that she wrote and edited twenty-two books under the Better Homes and Gardens and Traditional Home imprints. Before leaving Meredith in 2008, Mrs. Hallam worked for three years as the Senior Design Editor for Traditional Home, and spent five years editing Special Interest Media. It was during her last year in Des Moines that she enrolled at Drake University to finish her master's degree. She graduated in May of 2008 with a Master's of Public Administration degree and a 4.0 GPA. After earning her MPA, Mrs. Hallam was accepted into the doctoral program at the University of Florida, Gainesville, where she taught Introductory Journalism courses and researched her doctoral thesis in media, health information, and public policy. She wrote and taught until the time of her passing. Friends may call from 5:00pm until 10:00pm on Friday and 8:00am until 10:30am on Saturday at Hixson-Ducote Funeral Home of Bunkie. Memorial donations may be made to the Animal Rescue League, the Humane Society, or the LSU Alumni Scholarship fund. Also, Mrs. Hallam would prefer that donations be made in lieu of flowers. Online condolences may be sent to: www.hixson-ducote.com.

SPREADING THE RISK JPMorgan Chase has fully syndicated its $20 billion loan to AT&T for the cellphone carrier's bid to buy T-Mobile USA, spreading it across 11 other banks, according to a regulatory filing. The move could allay fears that JPMorgan could face a big credit risk if it were forced to hold the loan -- the biggest ever by a single bank -- on its books. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

9:27 p.m. | Updated | Lionsgate, the studio behind the critically acclaimed AMC drama ''Mad Men,'' said Thursday that it had signed a long-term deal with the creator of the series, Matthew Weiner. The new deal ensures that Mr. Weiner will continue running the show for two more seasons, and includes an option for a third. That option would take ''Mad Men'' through its seventh season. The deal was said to be worth $30 million, one of the biggest payouts of its kind in cable television.

An article on March 21 about a report on efforts by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to remedy earlier discrimination against female faculty members paraphrased incorrectly a comment by the dean of the School of Science, Marc A. Kastner, about the university's reliance on outside recommendations. Superlative recommendations from at least 15 outside scholars are necessary for tenure, Dr. Kastner said, not for hiring.

ELLIS ISLAND IMMIGRATION MUSEUM (Friday through Sunday, and Thursday) With Tartan Week celebrations about to begin, the time to bring out your inner Scotsman or Scotswoman is now. The history of tartan -- a colorful identification with a region or clan -- will be told in the exhibition ''A Celebration of Tartan,'' at the museum through Sunday. The display features 15 garments, including those with the Ellis Tartan especially commissioned for the show, as well as interpretative panels of prints and other material (above, a watercolor by Kenneth MacLeay from ''The Highland Clans for the Royal Family,'' published in 1870). Sponsored by the Clan Currie Society, the weekend will also feature performances by Highland dancers, pipers, drummers and others each day from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Beginning on Thursday, the museum will also present ''Forgotten Gateway: Coming to America Through Galveston Island,'' an exhibition on the immigration history of Galveston, Tex., a point of entry into the United States for many immigrants from the mid-1800s to early 1900s. The display, running Sept. 5, is also inspiring discussions, tours and lectures. Both exhibitions can be viewed daily from 9:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m. Museum admission is free; ferry tickets to Ellis Island are $13; $10 for 62+; and $5 for those 4 to 12; ferry information: statuecruises.com. ''A Celebration of Tartan'' information: tartandayonellisisland.com. The wearing of tartan will be most welcome. (Anne Mancuso)

Matteo, an American dancer and choreographer who specialized in Spanish dance and became an authority on ethnic dance forms, died on Thursday in Englewood, N.J. He was 92. He died of complications of a stroke at the Lillian Booth Actors Home, where he had moved from Manhattan in 2008, said his great-niece Gwendolyn Dunaif.

Almost everything about the psychiatric process is apparently open to interpretation, even the status of a television series about it. On Wednesday night, reports surfaced that HBO had canceled its drama ''In Treatment,'' which has starred Gabriel Byrne as the psychotherapist Dr. Paul Weston, and featured a rotating roster of actors including Hope Davis, Debra Winger and Mia Wasikowska as his patients. Dianne Wiest and Amy Ryan also starred, as Dr. Weston's own therapists. And while a cigar is sometimes just a cigar, HBO seemed to suggest that this cancellation was not necessarily a cancellation. In a statement, the network said: ''It's true that we have no plans to continue with 'In Treatment' as previously formatted. However, we are in continued conversations with the executive producers to find another way to continue telling these rich stories.'' ''In Treatment,'' which is adapted from the Israeli series ''BeTipul,'' was broadcast on multiple nights of the week and focused on the story of a different patient on each night, so it was possible that HBO was somehow seeking to consolidate this format. But like a strict Freudian, the network declined to comment further.

RICHARDSON--Dr. John J.,74, died on March 27 of lung cancer. A retired podiatrist affiliated with St. Vincent's Hospital, he gave sensitive care and comfort to thousands of patients over the course of his long career. Jack was a fifth generation Greenwich Village resident with a fierce loyalty to his neighborhood, a selfless provider for his family, an avid collector of medical antiques, and a prolific craftsman of wooden boxes. A devoted husband to the late Mary Ann Richardson, his unstinting care of her during her 16 year illness was one of his life's finest accomplishments. He is survived by his daughter, Martine Sacks, MD and her partner, A.J. Zelada: his son, Justin Richardson, MD and his husband, Peter Parnell; and his granddaughters, Lita Sacks and Gemma Parnell-Richardson. Viewing: Reddens, 325 W. 14 St., Wednesday 7-9pm, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral: St. Patrick's Old Cathedral, 263 Mulberry St., Friday 1pm.

Looking to capitalize on the fast-growing region, global hedge fund managers have started to descend on Brazil. The industry's biggest players are wooing top talent, opening new offices and buying local firms - all part of a broader effort to expand their investment reach.

Warren E. Buffett is an old-school capitalist with a rock star's aura, a global celebrity who is revered like a small-town hero. 5:04 p.m. | Updated Bill Moyers' retirement from weekly television last year may not last long. He has received preliminary approval for a major grant to return to PBS with a half-hour show with the working title ''Something Different With Bill Moyers.'' The Carnegie Corporation of New York, in an announcement this week on its Web site (the release has since been changed to remove references to Mr. Moyers), said its board had voted to give Mr. Moyers' production company a $2 million, 29-month grant for the show.

The gun-toting federal marshal Raylan Givens, the litigator Alicia Florrick and the consulting detective Sherlock Holmes may not share much when it comes to righting wrong-doings, but television series featuring those characters were all named winners of the 70th annual George Foster Peabody Awards on Thursday. Peabody Awards, bestowed by the University of Georgia Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication and recognizing excellence in electronic media, were given to the FX series ''Justified'' and the CBS drama ''The Good Wife,'' as well as ''Sherlock: A Study in Pink,'' a 21st-century spin on Sherlock Holmes seen on the PBS series ''Masterpiece/Mystery!'' Other winners included the HBO movie ''Temple Grandin,'' about that autism advocate, as well as the World War II mini-series ''The Pacific'' and the Spike Lee documentary ''If God Is Willing and Da Creek Don't Rise,'' about life in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, both shown on that cable network. C-Span was named the winner of an award for its searchable video library and CNN for its coverage of the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico; Peabodys also went to the arts series ''American Masters'' for ''LennonNYC,'' about John Lennon, and ''Elia Kazan: A Letter to Elia,'' directed by Kent Jones and Martin Scorsese. The awards will officially be given out at a ceremony in New York on May 23.

Brooke Shields will continue her run as high-profile replacement actress on Broadway this summer when she takes over the role of Morticia in ''The Addams Family'' musical from Bebe Neuwirth, who will depart the show after 15 months. For the final 15 minutes of an hourlong practice on Saturday, the Rangers engaged in a 3-on-2 drill. This was not a repetition of odd-man rushes, but a test of what N.H.L. coaches often refer to as "battle level." For 30 to 45 seconds each shift, all within the offensive blue line, three forwards would work the puck deep against two teammates and the goaltender Henrik Lundqvist. The drill would end with a goal, or at least a few quality scoring opportunities.

My Sunday column argues that there are indeed lots of uncertainties and legitimate criticisms of President Obama's operation in Libya -- but weighed against it are the many lives that it has saved, and the prospect that it will ultimately remove Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. On balance, I think the intervention was not only essential but maybe a step toward the emergence of a bit more of an international conscience, the growth of the doctrine of the "responsibility to protect." As for the argument that we're inconsistent in our interventions: of course we're inconsistent, but would you rather we consistently save no one?

Perhaps no aspect of baseball has received more statistical scrutiny over the last decade than pitchers' control over the outcomes of balls in play. Ever since a paralegal named Voros McCracken posted a theory on the Internet in 1999 that pitchers could exert influence only on their strikeouts, walks and home runs allowed - leaving everything else up to fielders and luck - researchers have pored over a century's worth of data on batting averages on balls in play. It turns out that McCracken and his detractors were partly right: although some pitchers are in fact more hittable than others, figuring out which ones they are while they are active is exceedingly hard.

In our book, "Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method," we analyzed the championship games or series of the N.F.L., N.B.A., Major League Baseball and N.H.L., and the major finals in golf and tennis, to identify championship characteristics. Based on that research, we are again focusing on the factors that might help predict the winner of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament. Last year's analysis correctly predicted that Duke would win the championship, and that Butler would be a threat to Michigan State in the semifinals.

In an earlier post, I noted that Warren Harding has become an unlikely hero of the right, with claims that his hands-off response to the 1920-21 recession was the right role model for our times. As I noted, even a quick look at the actual facts shows that 1920-21 bears no resemblance to 2008-?, and instead looks like 1981-82: a recession was brought on by tight monetary policy aimed at limiting inflation, and was followed by a rapid recovery when monetary policy was relaxed.

As the college basketball world descends upon Houston this week for the men's Final Four, preparations are under way for the 2012 edition in New Orleans. Next year will be the city's first time hosting the event since 2003, which also means it will be the first time since Hurricane Katrina struck in 2005. The city has hosted major sporting events since Katrina - including the N.B.A. All-Star game in 2008 and N.C.A.A. men's tournament games in 2007, 2010 and 2011 - but is just now getting back into the Final Four (and Super Bowl) rotation.

If only CBS had thought of this when Charlie Sheen was still on one of its shows: taking a page from rival networks like ABC, CNN and Comedy Central, which have used Twitter to draw in and keep viewers watching shows like ''Piers Morgan Tonight'' and events like the Academy Awards or ''The Comedy Central Roast of Donald Trump,'' CBS announced on Thursday that it would have eight nights of programming emphasizing that platform. During that period some of its performers and personalities will post on Twitter in real time. #CBSTweetWeek, as the network is calling it, will run from Sunday through April 11 and spotlight events like Sunday's Academy of Country Music Awards (for which the musicians Dierks Bentley and Julianne Hough will post comments and answer questions on Twitter) and Monday's N.C.A.A. Division I men's basketball national championship game (during which the CBS Sports analysts Greg Anthony and Seth Davis will both be on call).

FOREIGN Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about refugees from Ivory Coast who have been fleeing into neighboring countries referred incorrectly to the area of Ghana that borders Ivory Coast. It is western Ghana, not eastern Ghana. An obituary on Thursday about Thomas Eisner, an authority on insects, referred incorrectly to spiders and millipedes, which were among the creatures he studied. They are members of the arthropod phylum, which includes insects; they are not insects.

''Ghost Brothers of Darkland County,'' a long-in-the-works musical by the horror writer Stephen King, right, and the rock musician John Mellencamp, below, will have its world premiere in April 2012 at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta, according to the theater's Web site. The musical, which has been at least 11 years in the making, has been described as a Southern Gothic work based on a true story that Mr. Mellencamp wanted to fashion for the stage in the spirit of Tennessee Williams, one of his longtime influences. The musical's plot concerns a 40-year-old tragedy that has haunted the character Joe McCandless: the deaths of his two brothers, who hated each other, and a girl. With music and lyrics by Mr. Mellencamp, a book by Mr. King, and music direction by T Bone Burnett, ''Ghost Brothers'' had previously been announced for a 2009 production at the Alliance but was delayed for unspecified script problems. The 2012 production, which was first reported by Playbill.com on Thursday, will be directed by the Alliance's artistic director, Susan V. Booth. The run is scheduled for April 4 through May 13, 2012.

ANAGNOST--Dino, on March 30, 2011. Maestro Anagnost is survived by his business partner of 45 years, John Kordel Juliano of New York City and Livingston, NY, a brother Dick Anagnost, a sister Debra Anagnost, a sister-in-law Demetria and three nephews Alexander, Stavros and Dimitri, all of Bedford, NH. Dr. Anagnost was music director and conductor of The Little Orchestra Society of New York for 32 years. During that time he touched the lives of thousands of children with his uniquely designed concerts. He also created innovative and compelling concerts for adults, including the well known Vivaldi's Venice series. Friends may call Sunday, April 3, 4-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Service Monday 10am at The Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th St., New York City. In lieu of flowers, family and friends are encouraged to make contributions to The Little Orchestra Society as a tribute to Maestro Anagnost.

Keith S. Brown, the father and former manager of the 5 Browns, the sibling quintet of classical pianists, was sentenced on Thursday to at least 10 years in prison after pleading guilty to sexually abusing his daughters when they were children, The Associated Press reported. The 5 Browns, consisting of sisters Desirae, 32, Deondra, 30, and Melody, 26; and brothers Gregory, 29, and Ryan, 25, had ended their professional relationship with their father in 2008. In February, Mr. Brown, 55, pleaded guilty to a first-degree felony count of sodomy and two second-degree felony counts of sexual abuse of a child. His daughters said in a statement at that time that they went to the authorities ''out of concern for the welfare and protection of other young women and girls.''

''The Anarchist,'' a new play by David Mamet, left, about a female prison inmate who was once part of a Weather Underground-like group and is now pleading for parole before the prison's female governor, will have its world premiere in London this fall, a team of American and British producers announced on Friday. The Daily Mail reported on Friday that the producers were seeking two star actresses in their 50s for the lead roles, whose casting would be subject to Mr. Mamet's approval. This is the third Mamet play to debut in London; his ''Glengarry Glen Ross'' opened in 1983 at the National Theater, and ''The Cryptogram'' in 1994 in the West End. The lead producers are Playful Productions, Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel.

MAGAZINE An article on Page 32 about the recent protests and fighting in Benghazi, Libya, misidentifies in one instance an agricultural administrator who was captured by government soldiers and tortured. He was Emad al-Imam, not Mahdi Ziu, another rebel sympathizer who took part in a suicide bombing. The article also misstates the name of a Libyan city. It is Ajdabiya, not Adjabiya.

6:25 p.m. | Updated The primary public television station in Orlando, Fla., WMFE-TV, said Friday that the station was being sold to an undisclosed buyer, in a sign of the continuing financial strains in public broadcasting. The move is yet another blow for PBS, marking the second station it has lost in a top 20 market in the past three months. In a statement, PBS confirmed that the station would leave PBS under the new owners, saying that ''PBS' goal is to have a financially stable service in the Orlando market.''

As a new state law making electronics manufacturers responsible for offering free recycling programs takes effect, many residents of New York City are likely to continue relying on so-called collection events to get rid of their e-waste. For harried city dwellers, such events save time that would otherwise be spent visiting individual manufacturers' Web sites to study their take-back policies. Instead, they can dump computers, monitors, printers, keyboards, mice, cables, TV sets, fax and copying machines, DVD players and other outdated or broken items all at once.

Hermes -- the French maker of Birkin and Kelly handbags that is fending off advances from the LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton luxury conglomerate -- said Friday it had begun talks to sell its 45 percent stake in the Jean Paul Gaultier fashion house. Hermes has received expressions of interest from several international luxury firms that develop global brands, and from non-luxury Asian firms that know the region, for its holding in the Gaultier brand, which has been recovering from a sharp drop in sales after the financial crisis hurt its bottom line.

She was the loving daughter of the late Francine Pickard, who died February 24, 2011, and Leonard Pickard; the beloved mother of Heather Diamond and husband Adam Diamond; wonderful sister to Dr. Janet Pickard Kremenitzer, Mark Pickard, and sister-in-law Kristina Pickard. Dedicated aunt of Becky, Jason, David, and Jared. Maxine was a kind and compassionate woman who was always generous in her actions towards others. Her motto was "family first" and she will be sorely missed by the family she leaves behind. She was a humble human being with a beautiful soul. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, 12:45pm, at Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Rego Park, NY.

The FiveThirtyEight column on Tuesday, comparing the chances of Virginia Commonwealth University's reaching the men's Final Four with those of previous long shots in N.C.A.A. tournament history, miscalculated the odds faced by the University of Pennsylvania in 1979. The odds, which should have been based in part on an Associated Press poll released three days before the tournament, were 537-1, not 420-1. The incorrect figure was based on that season's final A.P. poll, which was released four days after the tournament started. (A corrected chart appears at nytimes.com/FiveThirtyEight.)

Tax season often delivers more than the usual set of headaches for same-sex couples. But it's about to get incredibly more complicated for couples living in California, Nevada and Washington. There is an upside, though. Many of them will save thousands of dollars in federal income taxes. Here's what's happening: Same-sex couples who are living in the three states that have both community property laws and recognize registered domestic partnerships or same-sex marriage must now follow their state's community property laws on their federal tax returns (if they're officially partnered). In community property states, generally all income and property acquired during a partnership or marriage is treated as equally owned by both individuals.

NEW YORK A picture caption in some editions on Friday with an article about the difficulty faced by prestigious colleges more than a century ago in recruiting students misstated the year in which a classified advertisement from Vassar, seeking students, was published in The New York Times. It was 1867, not 1967.

Andrei Makine, one of France's most celebrated novelists, whose books, including ''Dreams of My Russian Summers,'' have been translated into English, revealed this week that he has published four novels under the name Gabriel Osmonde, the newspaper Le Figaro reported. Mr. Makine, a Franco-Russian author who was awarded the prestigious Prix Goncourt in 1995, was ''leading a literary double life,'' Le Figaro said. He kept the secret for more than 10 years; Osmonde never showed himself in public and even one of his publishers, Albin Michel, said he had never seen or spoken to him. A prolific author often compared to Chekhov and known for his limpid French prose, Mr. Makine has used the pen name since 2001 to write novels about the world's cruelty and the human quest for transcendence. The fourth, ''Alternaissance,'' was published in March. In France critics and publishers had speculated for years about the author's identity. Mr. Makine came clean about writing under the other name after a French scholar said publicly that excerpts from one Osmonde book had been inspired by ''Dreams of My Russian Summers.'' Explaining the need for a pen name, Mr. Makine told Le Figaro: ''I wanted to create someone who lived far from the hurly-burly of the world.''

TAUB--Henry, age 83, of Tenafly, NJ, formerly of Paterson, NJ, passed away on Thursday, March 31, 2011. Beloved husband of Marilyn S. Taub; devoted father of Judith and Ronald Gold, Steven and Benay Taub, and Ira and Shelley Taub. Loving "Zayde" of Samantha, Jessica, and Evan Gold, Matthew, Eliana, Joshua and Sarah Taub, and Sydney, Alex, and Julia Taub. Devoted brother of Joseph Taub and his wife Arlene. Born in Paterson, New Jersey in 1927, Mr. Taub graduated from New York University in 1947. In 1949 he founded the Automatic Data Processing Company (ADP). He served as its President from 1949 to 1970, Chairman & CEO from 1970 to 1977, Chairman from 1977 to 1985 and is currently Honorary Board Chairman. ADP is America's largest independent computer service company. Mr. Taub is a member of the Board of Trustees of New York University. Mr. Taub has been honored with the Madden award by NYU, and has been awarded an honorary degree by the Technion/Israel, Hebrew University/Jerusalem and Ben Gurion University/Israel. Mr. Taub served as Chair of the International Board of Governors, of the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology from 1991-2003. He has previously served as a member of the Board of the Rite-Aid Corp.; Hasbro, Inc.; Bank Leumi and Trust Co. of New York; Interfaith Hunger Appeal and The New York Shakespeare Festival/Public Theater. He has also served as Chairman and President of The Board of Directors of The American Joint Distribution Committee (1981-1986) and in a similar capacity with the United Israel Appeal ( 1986-1990). Mr. Taub has been active in philanthropic endeavors in Paterson, NJ. He founded the Paterson Alumni Foundation which was subsequently merged into the Paterson Education Fund, organizations committed to improving the schools and education system in Paterson. He also helped to establish the "I Have a Dream" program at School #

9 P.M. (Starz) EAT PRAY LOVE (2010) Julia Roberts, above with Javier Bardem, subduing her usual glamour but not extinguishing it entirely, stands in for Elizabeth Gilbert, the real-life author of the best-selling memoir about post-divorce globe-trotting, adapted here by Ryan Murphy. Billy Crudup is the husband Liz leaves before embarking on her journey of liberation; James Franco is the soulful young actor who makes it only too clear that she is drifting further and further from her intended course. And Mr. Bardem is Felipe, the Brazilian expatriate at the end of the road, after she has eaten her way through Italy, meditated in India and apprenticed herself to an elderly shaman (Hadi Subiyanto) in Bali. ''Will her feelings for Felipe cause her to abandon the self-sufficiency that had been the point of her quest?,'' A. O. Scott pondered in The New York Times. ''And because 'Eat Pray Love' builds its climax around this question, does that mean, in the end, that it reverts to the man-centric romantic-comedy formula? Yes and no.'' He added: '' 'Eat Pray Love' is unlikely to change anybody's life or even to provoke emotions anywhere near as intense as those experienced, early and late, by its intrepid heroine. Its span may be global, but its scope is modest, and it accepts a certain superficiality as the price of useful insight. Watch. Smile. Go home and dream of Brazilians in Bali.'' 10:30 A.M. The Intiman Theater in Seattle, right, which is fighting for its survival, announced on Thursday that it had raised just over $450,000 in a seven-week emergency fundraising campaign and would stay open. The Intiman had previously said that it needed to raise $500,000 by the end of March and another $500,000 by September to keep operating, but apparently this was close enough. A news release said that the remaining $50,000 would be added to the next benchmark. ''Raising more than $450,000 in seven weeks and over $250,000 in one week is a clear signal that encourages us to keep moving forward,'' the board president, Kim Anderson, said in a statement. The theater was helped by a $100,000 challenge gift from an anonymous donor, which the theater said it had met. The Intiman also announced that it had hired a turnaround expert, Susan Trapnell of the Arts Consulting Group, to help the board and the artistic director, Kate Whoriskey, come up with a financial plan for the theater.

TAUB--Henry. The NYU Community mourns the passing of its friend, alumnus, and generous benefactor, Henry Taub. An astute, forward-looking, and much admired businessman and a veteran of the US Navy, his connection with NYU began more than 60 years ago as a student at NYU's business school. His involvement carried on throughout his life as an adjunct faculty member, a Stern School Overseer, and a University Trustee. A great philanthropist, his generosity encompassed NYU and many other institutions. He shall be deeply missed by the NYU community, but his name and his commitment to scholarship will live on through such programs as the Taub Center for Israel Studies, the Henry and Marilyn Taub Professor of Public Service and Leadership at the Wagner School, and the Taub Scholarship Fund at the Stern School of Business. Our hearts go out to his wife Marilyn, his children, and all his loved ones and friends in their time of sorrow; they are in our thoughts and prayers. Martin Lipton, Chair, NYU Board of Trustees John Sexton, President, NYU

SADOW--Bernard D.,85, a native of New Bedford, MA died of cancer on March 30, 2011. During WWII he served in the Navy in the South Pacific. His unit did aerial photography that aided in the making of invasion maps. Most of his work life he was in the luggage business in sales, design and innovation. He had many patented inventions, but his most famous was wheels on luggage. He traveled the world looking for material and making connections. He was admired and loved by most who knew him for his boyish enthusiasm and his eternal optimism. He is survived by his wife, two children and a granddaughter. Contributions to his memory should be directed towards Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 311 North St., Ste 204, White Plains, NY 10605. Services will be held Sunday, April 3rd at 12:30 at Tifereth Israel Congregation, 145 Brownell Ave., New Bedford. Shiva will be held at the home of Richard Sadow, 9 Country Way, So. Dartmouth, MA following the burial. Services by Sugarman-Sinai Memorial Chapel.

BOWE--Edward T.,MD. The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and the NewYork-Presbyterian Sloane Hospital for Women mourns the passing of our esteemed and beloved colleague Dr. Edward T. Bowe, Professor Emeritus. Dr. Bowe was a gifted obstetrician and gynecologist who had a deep dedication and longstanding commitment to patient care, education and research. He played an integral role in the development of the subspecialty of Maternal-Fetal Medicine particularly with reference to fetal monitoring and fetal PH balance. He retired in 2000, but remained as teacher and special lecturer for many years. He was also an accomplished musician who played to the delight of many in our Department. He will be forever remembered through his tireless leadership and dedication as a mentor to generations of physicians. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire family. Mary E. D'Alton, MD, NewYork-Presbyterian Sloane Hospital for Women, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, Chair Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology.

TAUB--Henry. It is with deep sadness that the Kaplen JCC on the Palisades mourns the loss of Henry Taub, a remarkable man, deeply devoted to Jewish life, Jewish community and the Kaplen JCC on the Palisades. With epic vision and intellect, Mr. Taub promoted Jewish scholarship and maintained a passionate belief that we should leave the world a better place than we found it. He was immensely generous and philanthropic and will always be remembered for his kindness, compassion and commitment to making a difference. Founder of Automatic Data Processing (ADP), the leading provider of computerized payroll services in the U.S, Henry Taub was a founder and the first president of the JCC in its Tenafly location (1980-1984). During his presidency, he solidified the JCC as a focal point for Jewish life in our community. He instituted our system of contributory memberships which continue to support our Center, as well as a comprehensive committee structure that brought hundreds of volunteers and future leaders to our Center. Our Judaic-Scholar-in-Residence program and numerous cultural and athletic programs were also established during his presidency, bringing an influx of new families to the JCC. In their devotion to the arts and culture, Henry and his wife Marilyn (Mickey) dedicated the Taub Auditorium, which they recently refurbished as part of the JCC Gift of Community Campaign. In memory of Mickey's parents and their love of seniors and Yiddish music, the Taubs created the Esther and Julius Adler Semi-Annual Yiddish Concert Series, which is attended by more than 1,000 people each year. Growing up in Paterson, Henry and his family lived among hundreds of Holocaust survivors. Profoundly touched by the vulnerability of the Jewish community, he became a lifetime supporter of institutions and causes that espouse Jewish values. A pillar of the community, Mr. Taub provided extraordinary philanthropic support to the UJA Federation of Northern New Jersey (and its predecessors) for over 40 years. Among the many programs he created and funded was the Synagogue Leadership Initiative. He served as president of the Joint Distribution Committee and United Israel Appeal. Henry Taub was the first American to hold the position of chairman of the International Board of Governors of the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology. He also established the Henry and Marilyn Taub Foundation, which supports important charitable endeavors, including the Taub Institute for Research on Alzheimer Disease and the Aging Brain at NY-Presbyterian/Columbia Hospital and the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University. Henry Taub will be remembered for his extraordinary generosity and for inspiring a new generation of leaders. He possessed a rare gift of greatness and truly left the world a better place. We will remember him always for the indelible mark he left on all our lives. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Mickey; children Judy, Ron, Steven, Benay, Ira, Shelley, 10 grandchildren and his brother Joe. He was deeply loved and will be sorely missed. May his memory be for a blessing. Pearl Seiden, President; Avi A. Lewinson, Executive Director

Tim Ryan has been sucked into a vortex of bad tax luck. Last week, we reported that some taxpayers were facing delays in getting refund checks, due to computer snafus in processing their repayment of the 2008 first-time home buyer tax credit. Many of those filers, the Internal Revenue Service says, should begin getting their refunds in April. When it comes to home décor, the quintessentially English fashion designer remains true to her aesthetic -- casual simplicity and utility crossed with high-quality heritage materials. Her 1961 Modernist country retreat in East Anglia is filled with the streamlined midcentury pieces she loves and peppered with vintage flea market finds. ''It's quite a tiny house,'' she says, ''but it's well laid out, airy and open, and being here helps me connect with nature.'' SANDRA BALLENTINE

CHAT with shopkeepers in Lynchburg, Va., and you'll probably get an earful on the city's history. Vendors all seem to know their building's original function: a blacksmith shop, a Civil War hospital, tobacco storage. Developers in this town of about 75,000 have taken pains to preserve the historic feel of the downtown area, which, until a few years ago, was mired in decay. Now, loft apartments, art studios, restaurants and a tearoom fill the hulking warehouses and factories along the banks of the James River. But not everything on the riverfront has changed: during a recent visit, I could hear the whistle of a passing coal train over the clatter of brunch. COLLEEN KINDER

Last week in The Appraisal column, Christine Haughney wrote about perilous words and phrases that fair-housing experts advise real estate agents to avoid in advertisements. Among the forbidden descriptions: ''traditional neighborhood,'' ''restricted,'' ''executive building,'' ''empty nesters,'' ''sophisticated'' and, curiously, ''fisherman's retreat.'' Dozens of readers shared their experiences on the City Room blog. Below are some of our favorites: In Westchester listings, ''Walk to worship'' is an actively used code word for ''near Orthodox synagogues.''

JOHNSTONE--John W. John W. Johnstone, 78, of Palm City, Florida died March 27, 2011 at his residence. Born in Connecticut, he was a resident of the Palm City for six years coming from New Canaan, Connecticut. Before retiring he was the president, CEO and chairman of the board of Olin Corporation, Stamford, Connecticut. He also was an executive with Hooker Chemical Company and Airco, Inc. He received a BA in Chemistry and Physics and an honorary doctorate from Hartwick College, Oneonta, New York and the advanced management program at Harvard University. He was a member of the Church of the Advent Episcopal Church, Palm City; Harbour Ridge Country Club; Blindbrook Country Club, Purchase, New York; Woodway Country Club, Darien, Connecticut; Clove Valley Rod and Gun Club, LaGrangeville, New York; the Rolling Rock Club, Ligonier, Pennsylvania; the Chemical Heritage Foundation; the Chemical Manufacturers Association and the Soap and Detergent Association. Survivors include his wife Claire Johnstone of Palm City; sons, Thomas E. Johnstone and James R. Johnstone, both of Ridgefield, Connecticut and Robert A. Johnstone of Newtown Square, Pennsylvania and 6 grandchildren. Service: There will be a memorial service at 3:00pm on April 8, 2011 at the St. Marks Episcopal Church, New Canaan, CT 203-966-4515. For those who wish, contributions may be made to Hartwick College Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 4020, Oneonta, New York 13820, USA; 607-431-4000 in Mr. Johnstone's memory.

TAUB--Henry. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Henry. A familial friendship spanning decades and generations has left us with memories never to be forgotten. We will treasure his wisdom, laughter and guidance, but most important the lessons regarding making the world a better place for others. Our love to Mickey, Judy, Steven and Ira and their families. The Shirvan Family
A review on March 20 about ''The Information,'' James Gleick's history of data organization, misstated the surname of the founder of cybernetics. He was Norbert Wiener, not Weiner.

Normandy's D-Day Sites and Beyond My sister and I are planning a spring or early summer trip to Normandy. Our main interest is World War II sites, but we would also like to visit more of Normandy's attractions while there. Bayeux seems the obvious choice to be near the D-Day tours. Honfleur also looks interesting. Any suggestions?

Someday someone will make a movie about the colorful life of Ford Wheeler. And when that day comes, pity the poor production designer. Wheeler, who is himself a production designer, has worked on projects as varied as ''Let Me In,'' last year's remake of a Swedish vampire film, and the intensely messy drama ''Rachel Getting Married.'' He also ran Craft Caravan, the now-closed but once wildly popular SoHo emporium for African design objects and art. He has lived in no fewer than 17 different houses and apartments in and around San Francisco, where he spent his 20s - including an authentic Victorian with a taxidermied elk in the dining room - and various New York City lofts. He has a country compound in the quaintly named upstate New York town of Dairyland, and he recently picked up a colonial house in Merida, Mexico. And that's just for the location scout to deal with. Then there is the stuff - the rolling pins, rulers, folk art, African statuary, religious icons, globes, clowns, cases of Pee cola from Ghana, obscure LP's, Kewpie dolls, Ford hubcaps, false eyelashes, hot-water bottles, knitted bottle covers in the shape of poodles. These things have a way of finding Wheeler, and he graciously makes a home for them. Or, in the case of the faux Wedgwood elephant-shaped cake topper from ''Rachel Getting Married'' that now sits on the sideboard in his loft, he finds or designs them for a movie and then can't let them go. ''That plant over there in the corner?'' he says, pointing to a night-blooming cereus in a ceramic pot. ''That was my mother's. She died when I was 20, and now I'm 65. I don't like to throw things out. It's very difficult for me.''

HELLER--Norman Norman Heller, July 3, 1927-March 25, 2011, corporate executive, gifted photographer, impassioned jazz enthusiast, beautiful swimmer, enthusiastic sailor and skier, exemplary husband, father, and grandfather, died of pneumonia, age 83. His life was an extraordinary, inspirational journey from Brighton Beach, Brooklyn--where he met the love of his life, Rosalyn Breg Heller, on the elevated subway platform when they were both headed to the NYU Heights campus--to homes in Los Angeles, California; Livingston, New Jersey; Stamford, Connecticut; London, England; New York, New York; Highland Beach, Florida; and finally, Maplewood, New Jersey. The son of a jeweler who'd immigrated alone from Austria as a boy, and the grandson of a woman who peddled fish from a cart on the Lower East Side, he rose to become one of the first Jewish executives at a major American corporation and one of the first Jewish members of the University Club. As Senior Vice President, Western Hemisphere of PepsiCo International in the 1970s and later as President and Chief Executive Officer of PepsiCo Wines and Spirits, International through 1987, he helped introduce Pepsi to the USSR and Eastern Europe and first imported Stolichnaya Vodka in the west. He loved business, but was a cultured intellectual with passionate interests in the arts, especially. Ever positive, his favorite word was "phenomenal," and he was, above all, phenomenally devoted to his wife of 62 years, his sister Judy Coleman, his three children, Karen Abada, Nanci McAlpin, and Matthew Heller, and their spouses, and his six grandchildren--all of whom adored and survive him. There will be a memorial in June, to be announced.

STAHL--Irwin H.,89. Gifted composer and beloved former teacher at Westchester Conservatory, formerly of Woodstock, NY, passed away peacefully in Laguna Hills, CA on March 19, after living in courage with a stroke condition. Survived by his partner Jeanne, sister Dorothy Aaron, nephews Mark and Scott Aaron. Services on June 18, 11am at the Unitarian Congregation in Kingston, NY.

ASSAEL--Salvador J.,on April 1, 2011 passed away peacefully after a brief illness. Born in 1923, Salvador fled Italy with his family in 1938, first to Paris, then to Portugal, where they boarded a ship to Cuba. The family lived in Havana until the communist revolution in 1957, when they moved via Miami to New York where they continued their diamond and jewelry business. A World War II veteran, as a member of Cannon Company, 311th infantry Regiment, 78th Infantry Division, he participated, endured and survived the Battle of the Bulge, December, 16th, 1944 January 25, 1945, The U.S. campaign in Africa, and the Battle of Remagen in March 17-25, 1945. He received the Purple Heart and other medals for distinguished service from the U.S. Government. 1949 Mr. Assael began trading in left over U.S. Army watches with Japan. He was paid in pearls, which is how he started the pearl business. In 1972 he took over the business from his family, and founded Assael International. In 1973, he became a producer of the Tahitian Black pearls together with Frenchman, Jean Claude Brouillet in French Polynesia. Today Assael International is one of the leading pearl Houses in the world. In June 1998, he became a Chevalier of the Order of Tahiti Nui. He received the GIA League of Honor Sovereign in 1996 and 1998. Mr. Assael was a founding member of the South Sea Pearl Consortium. Mr. Assael was involved in many charities. In 1993 he purchased land for the founding of Temple Dorette Assael in Papeete, Tahiti, the only Sephardic Synagogue in the South Pacific. He gave the only Sephardic exhibit at the Jewish Museum in New York; built the Azata Library in Beer Sheba, Israel; donated a wing of the Sephardic Home's Adult Health Care Center in Brooklyn, New York; donated the Atrium of the GIA World Headquarters in Carlsbad, California and donated a room at "Our House" Hospice in Los Angeles, California. Mr. Assael is mourned by his wife, Christina Lang Assael, his children, Sophia and Robert Lang Assael, and Arlette Assael and his loyal staff Alex Rodrigues, Elisabetta Golonko and Yaneli Gusman. Our sincere thank you to Doctor Ralph Gibson, his dedicated nurses, Moira Turck, Noreen Curran, Mary Ford, Pauline Gilroy, Margaret Gaine, Aneta Konopka and his trainer, Job Berrara. Services will be held on Sunday, April 3rd, at 12 Noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York, NY 10023. Phone: 212-362-6600. Shiva will be held at 485 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10022 on Monday and Tuesday from 2pm to 9pm.

SKULNIK--Renee, of Elmwood Park, NJ and Lake Worth, FL. Predeceased by her beloved Louis. Survived by her sons; David, Martin, Howard; and daughter Linda Gaer; brothers Solomon and Leonard Tenzer; sister Lauri Cooper; 11 grandchildren; and 13 great-grandchildren.

If anyone knows how to mark an occasion, it's the Italians. For the 50th anniversary of the Salone del Mobile, the fair that has come to be the epicenter of the global contemporary design market, they're turning Milan into a giant stage to display what they do best. Among the attractions will be a retrospective of Italian design, co-curated by Alberto Alessi, at the Triennale Design Museum and an eight-room installation, designed by Denis Santachiara, at the Piazza Duomo that highlights ''creative potential channeled through scientific principles.'' The Salone even has a smartphone app, which you can find at cosmit.it. Ultimately, though, the fair is about selling furniture, and when this year's 2,500-plus exhibitors gather from April 12 to 17 to show off their latest innovations, that should provide excitement enough. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

ATTICUS FINCH, the heroic lawyer at the heart of Harper Lee's Pulitzer -winning ''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' is best remembered for his colorblindness in the face of small-town racism. In his 1962 Oscar-winning portrayal of Atticus, Gregory Peck wore a pair of tortoiseshell-style spectacles that aptly symbolized the clarity and wisdom so central to his character. Now, as the film's 50th anniversary approaches, Oliver Peoples is introducing a Gregory Peck frame at the suggestion of his son, Anthony, who owns the original pair. The bookish style ($315 at Barneys New York and oliverpeoples.com) is available in four muted colors, made from a transparent acetate that resembles tortoiseshell with a bit more polish. The Peck family is donating its proceeds from the project to the Los Angeles Public Library. BRUCE--PASK

TAUB--Henry, Founder of Automatic Data Processing (ADP) in Paterson, NJ, 1949 at 21 years of age, pioneering provider of payroll data services. Company now employs more than 45,000 people in 23 countries. He was a brilliant company leader, compassionate philanthropist admired throughout the American business world. A treasured friend to all who knew him, beloved father, husband and brother. Although he is no longer with us, we will always love and remember him as a model of great modesty and warmth. He set a standard of character rarely found but should always be emulated. U.S. Senator, Frank R. Lautenberg

KEVIN LONG, A K A SPANKY, 26: This was the day I came back from the hospital, with third-degree burns on my chest and my back. They took skin to graft from the back of my head. We were just messing around, and the person that lighted my shirt on fire felt really bad. I knew it was bad; I had no idea of how bad, because it took a few days for the pain to completely set in. I was supposed to leave for Australia for a skateboarding tour, and I thought I was getting on a plane the next day. I had to stay in the hospital for, like, two weeks.

Anyone lucky enough to be invited to Camp Topridge, the cereal heiress Marjorie Merriweather Post's 207-acre Adirondack camp, was greeted - upon arrival by water on her private launch - by an elaborate two-story, five-bay boathouse. Built in the 1920s with natural cedar logs with bark cut directly from local woods, it was decorated with a profusion of intricate twigs and branches. Later, a second boathouse was added. Like other boathouses along the Adirondacks' 11,000 lakes and ponds, Post's was the front door to a glamorous vacation getaway. Boathouses were often the only visible part of a camp, with the main house and guest cottages hidden from view among the trees. A mix of opulence and rustic whimsy, they were also a necessity when roads were scarce, making boats the sole means of reaching the camps (even if, like Post, you could afford to fly in on a float plane). The buildings' second floors served as massive playrooms where guests could sip drinks while their children swam and fished. Some boathouses were even grander than their camp's main house.

TAUB--Henry. He will be missed by many. His kindness was exceeded only by his desire to help those less fortunate and our seniors and elderly were the privileged recipients of his generosity and compassion. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Marilyn, his children Judy and Ron, Steven and Benay, Ira and Shelley, his brother Joe, his grandchildren and his entire family. Henry's legacy will include the many fine institutions and programs he helped conceive and steward. May his memory be for a blessing. Ary Freilich, Chairman Sandra Gold, President, JHR Charles P. Berkowitz, President & CEO

9 P.M. (Showtime) THE BORGIASJeremy Irons, above, who had a recurring gig on American television recently in ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,'' camps it up as Rodrigo Borgia, the ruthless chief of the corrupt Italian clan, in this new series filmed by Neil Jordan (''The Crying Game''). The story begins in 1492 with the death of Pope Innocent VIII and ''lavishly depicts how Rodrigo used bribery, poison and other tricks (scrolls carrying offers of bribes stuffed into the snouts of suckling pigs) to become Pope Alexander VI,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. But although a cynical, black-hearted pope, Rodrigo was a doting father, naming his son Cesare (François Arnaud) a cardinal; assigning another, Juan (David Oakes), to lead the papal army; and putting his daughter Lucrezia (Holliday Grainger) to work, through strategic marriages. ''This glossy, gossipy look at the Renaissance in the time of Machiavelli isn't a history lesson,'' Ms. Stanley added, ''it's a lurid family drama that happened to change the course of history.'' 9 A.M. Kimi Raikkonen, the 2007 Formula One world champion, has requested and received approval to run in a Nascar Camping World Truck Series race at Charlotte Motor Speedway on May 20, said Amanda Jones Ellis, a spokeswoman for the series. Turun Sanomat, a newspaper in the racer's native Finland, reported Tuesday that Raikkonen, 31, is expected to race with a new team in the truck series, followed perhaps by a move to the Nationwide Series and then into the Sprint Cup Series, the big leagues of stock-car racing. Raikkonen did not disclose how many truck series races he planned to drive this season.

The silent star of the 1948 hit film ''Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House'' is a handsome Colonial with bright clapboard walls and dark shutters. Cary Grant and Myrna Loy co-starred as the New York City adman Jim Blandings and his wife, Muriel - up-to-date apartment dwellers whose relationship with early-American style personified the hopes and struggles of moviegoers from coast to coast. The Blandings' country home became so popular that Kellogg's cereal boxes offered a cardboard cutout model, and Manhattan charity fund-raisers oversaw the construction of a full-scale Dream House knockoff on a vacant lot in Midtown. As the backdrop for a 1949 fashion photo in Cosmopolitan magazine, the suburban colonial parked at the corner of 48th and Fifth now seems quaintly surreal, but at the time it was shot, this ''back to the New Look'' tableau would have made perfect sense to passers-by. Colonial-inspired design loomed surprisingly large on Gotham's aesthetic skyline from the 1920s until the aftermath of World War II, a prominence ignored by conventional histories that rate Art Deco and Modernism as the era's only shows in town. Such scenarios routinely cast Colonial Revival architects and other traditionalists as doddering throwbacks to effete ideas. A more evenhanded appraisal of the latter camp - and its active engagement in contemporary social and cultural issues - informs ''The American Style: Colonial Revival and the Modern Metropolis,'' an exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York (June 14 to October 30). The museum's own home, a 1932 redbrick Colonial Revival landmark, rightly figures as a prime artifact. ''A lot of people look at Colonial Revival as kind of a joke, as if it were all spinning-wheel chairs,'' says Donald Albrecht, who curated the show with Thomas Mellins. ''We're saying it is a style of high quality with its own masters - and it's the ur-example of architecture and design as a narrative art.''

A review on March 20 about ''The Most Human Human,'' by Brian Christian, misattributed a paraphrased line of poetry. TAUB--Henry. It is with deep sadness that the Kaplen JCC on the Palisades mourns the loss of Henry Taub, a remarkable man, deeply devoted to Jewish life, Jewish community and the Kaplen JCC on the Palisades. With epic vision and intellect, Mr. Taub promoted Jewish scholarship and maintained a passionate belief that we should leave the world a better place than we found it. He was immensely generous and philanthropic and will always be remembered for his kindness, compassion and commitment to making a difference. Founder of Automatic Data Processing (ADP), the leading provider of computerized payroll services in the U.S, Henry Taub was a founder and the first president of the JCC in its Tenafly location (1980-1984). During his presidency, he solidified the JCC as a focal point for Jewish life in our community. He instituted our system of contributory memberships which continue to support our Center, as well as a comprehensive committee structure that brought hundreds of volunteers and future leaders to our Center. Our Judaic-Scholar-in-Residence program and numerous cultural and athletic programs were also established during his presidency, bringing an influx of new families to the JCC. In their devotion to the arts and culture, Henry and his wife Marilyn (Mickey) dedicated the Taub Auditorium, which they recently refurbished as part of the JCC Gift of Community Campaign. In memory of Mickey's parents and their love of seniors and Yiddish music, the Taubs created the Esther and Julius Adler Semi-Annual Yiddish Concert Series, which is attended by more than 1,000 people each year. Growing up in Paterson, Henry and his family lived among hundreds of Holocaust survivors. Profoundly touched by the vulnerability of the Jewish community, he became a lifetime supporter of institutions and causes that espouse Jewish values. A pillar of the community, Mr. Taub provided extraordinary philanthropic support to the UJA Federation of Northern New Jersey (and its predecessors) for over 40 years. Among the many programs he created and funded was the Synagogue Leadership Initiative. He served as president of the Joint Distribution Committee and United Israel Appeal. Henry Taub was the first American to hold the position of chairman of the International Board of Governors of the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology. He also established the Henry and Marilyn Taub Foundation, which supports important charitable endeavors, including the Taub Institute for Research on Alzheimer Disease and the Aging Brain at NY-Presbyterian/Columbia Hospital and the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University. Henry Taub will be remembered for his extraordinary generosity and for inspiring a new generation of leaders. He possessed a rare gift of greatness and truly left the world a better place. We will remember him always for the indelible mark he left on all our lives. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Mickey; children Judy, Ron, Steven, Benay, Ira, Shelley, 10 grandchildren and his brother Joe. He was deeply loved and will be sorely missed. May his memory be for a blessing. Pearl Seiden, President; Avi A. Lewinson, Executive Director

WILLIAM D. COHAN There is the crowing about AT&T's $39 billion proposed acquisition of Deutsche Telekom's wireless business -- one of the largest acquisitions in years. Is this what Washington was hoping would happen when it chose to recapitalize the banks in October 2008 with taxpayer money? That they would be helping the giants arrange even bigger deals, reducing competition and -- likely -- existing jobs? Which brings us to the still-absurd level of Wall Street compensation. Bonus payments in 2010 hovered close to $150 billion. There are even reports that the war for talent has resumed, with the return of multiyear, multimillion dollar contracts. And yet, there has not even been a baby step toward holding Wall Street's top executives fully accountable for their actions -- by asking them to once again put their entire net worth on the line as they did in days of yore. Another lost opportunity.

There's no real signage outside Dock Kitchen, Stevie Parle's restaurant above Tom Dixon's shop in a Victorian wharf building that overlooks a canal in Ladbroke Grove. But that hasn't stopped the crowds from coming to indulge in his eclectic cooking -- Parle's menu features English classics as well as dishes from far-flung locales like Sri Lanka and Japan. ''My food is the opposite of fusion,'' says the once-peripatetic chef, who now lives on a houseboat in Hammersmith with his wife and young son. ''I try to keep the integrity of every ingredient I work with.'' His cookbook, ''My Kitchen: Real Food From Near and Far'' (Lyons Press), comes out stateside this month. MAURA EGAN
