''IT'S in the details,'' said Dave Bull, the caretaker of a former military bunker on the island of Jersey in the English Channel. He heaved open a cast-iron door and ran a hand over its bolts and heavy wrench-like handle. ''This was all built by slave labor, by prisoners the Nazis marched here from Europe.'' The bunker in question is located on the ground floor of a radio tower on Jersey, erected by occupying German forces during World War II. The stout concrete structure still keeps a quiet vigil over the channel.

THE NEWSPresident Obama defended American and allied airstrikes in Libya in a televised speech, saying it was in the national interest to stop a potential massacre that would have ''stained the conscience of the world.'' BEHIND THE NEWS The emphasis on acting to protect civilians raised thorny questions about who in the chaos of Libya is deemed a civilian. Still, he said, ''I refused to wait for the images of slaughter and mass graves before taking action.'' But he warned against using military force unilaterally to drive out Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi: ''To be blunt, we went down that road in Iraq.''

I open my window and this is the house, in the depths of central Cairo, that looks back at me. The people who live in the city's working-class neighborhoods are not ashamed of being poor. Instead, in this house I look at from my window, I see heroic efforts in the fight against poverty. For the most part the residents are tradesmen or public employees. There was a time when they earned enough to enjoy a comfortable life, but the waves of hardship rose suddenly and they drowned. Originally the window on the house's first floor was ornate glass. It was broken and repaired more than once. The last time, to keep costs down, the house's owner put up a piece of wood in place of the glass.

Contributions may be made in her memory to the City College Fund of CUNY.

Perhaps no aspect of baseball has received more statistical scrutiny over the last decade than pitchers' control over the outcomes of balls in play. Ever since a paralegal named Voros McCracken posted a theory on the Internet in 1999 that pitchers could exert influence only on their strikeouts, walks and home runs allowed - leaving everything else up to fielders and luck - researchers have pored over a century's worth of data on batting averages on balls in play. It turns out that McCracken and his detractors were partly right: although some pitchers are in fact more hittable than others, figuring out which ones they are while they are active is exceedingly hard. Far less attention has been paid, however, to the other side of the balls-in-play coin: offense. Clearly, hitters control their averages on balls in play far more than pitchers do. A hard-to-hit pitcher like Barry Zito and an easy one like Carlos Silva are separated by about 40 points of career average on balls in play. For batters, the gap is twice as large. Pedro Feliz and Alex Cora have hit .268 and .269 on balls in play, and Derek Jeter and Ichiro Suzuki are at .358 and .359.

Everyone loves a good rivalry, and in this case the competition has pitted one fancy New York City address against another: The mighty 15 Central Park West, a relatively new architectural star, and the Plaza Hotel Residences, which come with the white-glove cachet of being located at the century-old Plaza. Since they went on sale, at roughly the same time in the real estate boom, the two have often been compared because they were considered among the most ambitious luxury condominium projects in decades. Apartments were quickly snapped up - sight unseen - at astronomical prices.

TAUB--Henry. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the loss of our former President, Chairman of the Board, and revered friend, Henry Taub. A passionate philanthropist, businessman and Jewish leader, Henry's dedication to Israel, educational causes, and scientific advancement were hallmarks of his benevolence. Through his outstanding leadership and vision, he helped establish and vigorously supported JDC's Taub Center for Social Policy Studies in Israel, one of the country's leading independent think-tanks and socioeconomic research institutes. Henry's boundless generosity also ensured opportunity for countless disabled Israelis through JDC Supportive Communities, which he caringly sustained. Henry's stalwart efforts to help those in need included, among others, his founding of the Paterson Alumni Foundation and his service on the Boards of New York University and Technion-Israel Institute of Technology. The Chairman-Founder of Automatic Data Processing Company (ADP) and the Henry & Marilyn Taub Foundation, Henry's insight and wisdom permeated all his endeavors. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Marilyn; his son, and JDC Board Member, Steven and his wife, Benay; his son Ira and his wife, Shelley; his daughter Judith and her husband, Ronald; and his ten grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing. Dr. Irving A. Smokler, President Judge Ellen M. Heller, Chairman of the Board Steven Schwager, Chief Executive Officer

An article on March 20 about American and European military strikes against Libyan government forces described incorrectly three Navy submarines stationed in the Mediterranean, which were among 11 American warships that had fired the initial salvo of cruise missiles at Libyan targets. Two submarines, the Scranton and the Providence, are fast-attack submarines; the third, the Florida, is a guided-missile submarine. Not one is a ballistic missile submarine, which is capable of launching long-range missiles equipped with nuclear warheads.

HURVITZ--David, died on March 25, 2011 after a long battle with cancer. David was born in Cleveland, Ohio on September 9, 1948, and grew up on Long Island. He graduated from the University of Chicago in 1970. He did years of field research in Africa, and obtained his Ph.D. in Anthropology from Princeton University in 1980. David's dissertation was among the earliest of scholarly works about the Anjoaty, an ethnic minority of Madagascar, and subsequent scholars have built on his research. David decided to leave academics and enter the business world in New York City. He joined Leadership Directories, Inc., a content publishing company, in 1988. He worked his way up to become Publisher, President and Chief Executive Officer. David married the love of his life, Martha Klein, RN, in 2003, and retired to northwestern Connecticut in 2009. He was a patron of opera and the arts, a scholar, a mentor, a lover of nature and wildlife, and a highly ethical businessman and manager. David was a unique and much loved person. He valued the truth and treated everyone with reason, fairness and tolerance. David was predeceased by his father Martin; he is survived by his adoring wife Martha, by his nieces and nephews Talia, Joshua, Kate, Zachary and Mollie, sister Karen and mother Ethel. In lieu of flowers, and for those who wish to make donations in David's memory, contact The University of Chicago Odyssey Fund, Gift and Record Services, 1427 East 60th St., Suite 120, Chicago, IL 60637 or gifts@uchicago.edu.

In lieu of flowers, family and friends are encouraged to make contributions to The Little Orchestra Society as a tribute to Maestro Anagnost.

SOMETIME last year, I was in line at a smoke stand to play Lotto when the man ahead of me suddenly turned from the cashier and said, ''Hey, do you remember me?'' I looked him up and down. A typical neighborhood guy, a deli and bodega guy, 60 or so. ''He doesn't remember,'' he laughed to his friend behind the counter. ''Well, I remember you! A long time ago you used to buy cigarettes from me. On 14th Street! Remember?''

ROSNER--Dorothy Abel, 88, died peacefully at home March 28, 2011, devoted children Barbara and Andy at her side. She was born December 27, 1922 in Brooklyn, NY, to Samuel and Mollie Abel, and is predeceased by her husband Harry (1996), brother William Abel and sister Ada Sterling. A first generation American, she graduated Thomas Jefferson High (1938); Brooklyn College (1942); and Teachers College Columbia (1945) with an MA in Foods and Nutrition. A brief stint teaching Home Economics in New York City was followed by a tour with the American Red Cross in the Philippines and on Okinawa as Club Director (Typhoon Terrace) in Services to the Armed Forces (1945-46), while her brother served overseas. She married Harry Rosner, CPA and lawyer in 1950. They moved from Brooklyn to New Rochelle, NY to raise their family: Barbara and Andy of N. California, David (Gloria) of Irvington, NY, and Martha of Boulder, CO. She was renowned for her hospitality, and her horticultural and culinary talents. She later worked as a nutritionist in the WIC program at New Rochelle Hospital. Her last professional assignment was real estate associate for Coldwell Banker in Larchmont, NY. In 2003 she relocated to San Jose, CA to be close to her California children. In San Jose she was active in the Willow Glen AARP chapter, serving two years as President. She will be greatly missed by Barbara and Andy, family and friends. Memorial service to be held in California.

BOWE--Edward T.,MD. The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and the NewYork-Presbyterian Sloane Hospital for Women mourns the passing of our esteemed and beloved colleague Dr. Edward T. Bowe, Professor Emeritus. Dr. Bowe was a gifted obstetrician and gynecologist who had a deep dedication and longstanding commitment to patient care, education and research. He played an integral role in the development of the subspecialty of Maternal-Fetal Medicine particularly with reference to fetal monitoring and fetal PH balance. He retired in 2000, but remained as teacher and special lecturer for many years. He was also an accomplished musician who played to the delight of many in our Department. He will be forever remembered through his tireless leadership and dedication as a mentor to generations of physicians. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire family. Mary E. D'Alton, MD, NewYork-Presbyterian Sloane Hospital for Women, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, Chair Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology.

SYRIA Security agents have arrested dozens of people, mostly in and around the capital, Damascus, and increased security after thousands took to the streets across the country in pro-democracy marches, activists told The Associated Press on Saturday. The arrests began early Saturday in the hours after the protests broke up, the activists said. The militant group Hamas issued a statement reiterating its support for Syria's leadership. YEMEN The opposition proposed a transition plan Saturday for President Ali Abdullah Saleh to hand power over to a vice president while steps are taken toward a national unity government and new elections, Reuters said. There was no immediate word of a response from the president, who has ruled for 32 years. Earlier Saturday, demonstrations for and against Mr. Saleh drew thousands to Sana. Antigovernment protesters hurled stones at riot police officers backed by tanks in the southern province of Aden.

COPELAND--Lillian (nee Plonsky), on April 1, 2011 in her 97th year in Pompano Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Jack Copeland, daughter of the late Ben and Bessie (Weissman) Plonsky, sister of the late Samuel Payne, survived by beloved nieces and nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews.

It's impossible to describe Judy Kameon's career in 25 words or less. Kameon, who lives and works in Los Angeles, has been a painter, a retailer, a stylist-costumer and (for two weeks) the proprietor of an underground restaurant. Today she's a garden designer who has created domestic landscapes for clients like Sofia Coppola, Mike D of the Beastie Boys and the hotelier Sean MacPherson, and public ones for the fashion houses Marc Jacobs and Balenciaga as well as the Parker Palm Springs hotel. In addition to her design firm, Elysian Landscapes, she owns Plain Air - a company that makes Modernist-influenced outdoor furniture - with her husband, Erik Otsea, a photographer. All these lives inform her current one, in which she is a combination designer/artist/plant geek/avid cook/hostess/mother hen who is happy to describe the properties of a particular variety of cactus in her garden while she offers a plate of freshly baked scones or negotiates a play date for her 5-year-old son. For Kameon, it all grows together. By her own description, Kameon's garden, on a narrow street in Elysian Park, near downtown L.A., has been her laboratory for 20 years. From the street, which is lined with modest houses, you open a tall wooden gate, and suddenly you're in an enchanted backyard. By terracing the hillside, Kameon created outdoor living spaces, like an al fresco dining area under a huge California pepper tree, a comfortable patio behind the house and an egg-shaped swimming pool that is surrounded by greenery. And almost all of it - except for the very old pepper tree - is Kameon's invention.
Art Randy Kennedy

Tesla Motors, the electric vehicle manufacturer based in Silicon Valley, filed a lawsuit this week in Britain against the BBC's popular ''Top Gear'' television program. Suing for libel and malicious falsehood, Tesla took issue with a December 2008 episode that depicted problems with the brakes, cooling system and limited range of its Roadster sports car. The company is seeking up to 100,000, or about $160,000, in damages and a ruling to stop the BBC from rebroadcasting or packaging the episode for sale.

MARX--Ruth Lynn (nee Sperber). Died peacefully on April 2nd, 2011. Devoted wife of the late Abraham. Cherished mother of Roberta and Eric Delson. Beloved grandmother of William Delson. Loving sister of Laura and Bertha. Devoted aunt. Proud graduate of Hunter College class of 1939. Recipient of a Masters Degree in Botany from Cornell University. She excelled in everything she did. She taught at Hunter College, Grover Cleveland High School in Queens and Great Neck North Senior High School. She loved art and beautiful things and was deeply admired by all who knew her. She will be greatly missed. Services 11:30am Sunday, April 3rd at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (Opposite L.I.R.R.), Great Neck, NY.

The N.F.L. draft is one of the most exciting events in a young player's life. Soon, it may also become the most tiring. The league traditionally invites high-profile prospects to the first round of the draft. When a draftee's name is called, he walks to the podium like an Academy Award winner in his tailored suit, accepts a team hat or jersey, smiles for photographs with the commissioner and team executives, then receives congratulations from his (often very extended) family.

LUTHER--Crocker (Kerry), a longtime Darien resident, passed away peacefully at his home after a brief illness on Monday, March 21. He was pre-deceased by his beloved wife, Mary Hebard Luther, in 1978. The son of Willard Blackinton Luther and Josephine Crocker Luther of Cambridge, MA, he was a graduate of the Fessenden School, followed by graduating in 1949 from The Loomis School and the Harvard Business School in 1962. After graduation, he began a professional career that spanned the world of banking with Marine Midland Bank in Manhattan from 1962 to 1982 and with Manufacturers Hanover Bank from 1983 until his retirement. Friends and family are invited to celebrate his life at a memorial service on Saturday, April 16th at 4pm at St. Luke's Parish, 1864 Boston Post Rd., Darien, CT 06820 - followed by an evening reception at The Wee Burn Country Club, 410 Hollow Tree Ridge Road, Darien, CT 06820. He is survived by his daughter, Sandra Brinton Luther, of Leesburg, VA, his son, Douglas Crocker Luther, of Brownfield, ME, his brother, Michael Luther, of Woodbridge, CT, his sister, Anne von Rosenberg, of Belmont, MA and by his granddaughter, Sierra Rose Luther, of Sarasota, FL. Memorial Contributions may be made to the: "Darien Library, 1441 Post Rd., Darien, CT 06820", "The Harvard Business School, Attn: Stefanie Hollister, Soldiers Field, Boston, MA 02163", "The Metropolitan Opera Guild/Access Opera, Director of Development, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, 6th Floor, New York, NY 10023".

HIRSCH--Doris Mayer Low, Born: October 31, 1920. We mourn the death and celebrate the life of a warm and kindhearted woman. Doris passed peacefully on March 25th, surrounded by three generations of devoted friends and family. Doris brought grace to all she did: social work, tennis, cooking and family. She was an tireless walker, in NYC or Nauset Beach; an avid supporter of her alma maters, Brearley and Smith College; a steadfast advocate for social justice; and a multi-decade volunteer at Planned Parenthood. Everyone who knew Doris felt her selflessness, her energy, and her love. Doris is survived by her older brothers Bob (Frances) and Stuart (Myra) Low; her beloved children Betsy (Bill), Catherine (James), Tom (Cheryl) and Susie (Susan); grandchildren James, Hayden, Jessica, Peter and Henry, and all of the extended family and friends she touched with humor, grace and wisdom. She was predeceased by her husband of 56 years, James C. Hirsch. Contributions can be made in Doris's memory to: Planned Parenthood of Stamford, CT, 1039 East Main Street, Stamford, CT, 06902 or the UCSF Aging and Memory Clinic, PO Box 45339, San Francisco, CA, 94145. A memorial gathering will be in June in Connecticut.

Next month, the Indianapolis Museum of Art will open to the public the house that Eero Saarinen designed for the industrialist J. Irwin Miller and his wife, Xenia, giving design pilgrims one more reason to visit Columbus, Ind., the mecca of Modernist architecture that Miller sponsored. The stone- and glass-walled house, which Saarinen completed in 1957, includes about 14 acres of landscaping by Dan Kiley and meticulously preserved interiors by Alexander Girard, who sank the world's first conversation pit into its living room. The Eames Aluminum Group chairs were designed for the Millers, whose dining table was a precursor to Saarinen's Tulip pedestal series. The couple lived in the house until their deaths (his in 2004, hers in 2008) and left behind a portrait not just of enlightened 20th-century arts patronage but of family life as well. ''It's not like the Farnsworth House, which was a weekend getaway, or the Glass House, which is purely an architect's personal expression of his ideas,'' says Bradley Brooks, the museum's director of historic resources. ''It had to accommodate entertaining and employees and five kids, and yet it was still resolved so beautifully. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SINGER--Ruth, 87, died on March 15, 2011. Ruth spent most of her life in the Bronx and Manhattan, where she was involved in the human rights struggles of both the Black and Jewish communities. During WWII, she was a draftsman in ship building. Drafting led her to the Port Authority of NY & NJ, where she also worked in the Model Cities Program, as well as the Audio Visual and Public Relation Departments in the World Trade Center. While working she obtained her masters at Empire State College, where she also served as President, Executive member and was a founder of the Alumni/Student Association. She retired from PANYJA after about 25 years. Her last few years were spent peacefully in Baldwin, L.I., near her family. Ruth is survived by her son Bob, daughter-in-law and three grandchildren. A memorial will be planned.

In certain cultures, voodoo objects were commissioned to solve anything that vexed you - from failed crops to failed romance. Approximately 100 such tools of divine intervention are at hand this month when the Fondation Cartier in Paris presents ''Voodoo'' (April 5 to Sept. 25), an exhibition culled mostly from the collection of Jacques Kerchache, a legendary curator and champion of primitive art. The show's focus is on the Republic of Benin, where voodoo orginated, and the objects can be mind-boggling in their dense, everything-but-the-kitchen-sink assemblage. But according to the exhibition's co-curator, Leanne Sacramone, we can now only imagine the circumstances of their creation. The figure above, made of wood, rope, animal bones, terra cotta pots, plants, feathers, cotton threads, shells, cloth, hair, beads and chain, might have done wonders for a fashion designer in need of inspiration. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Dr. Rhett worked for Bank of New York and NYU, was Dean of California Western University and President of the University for Humanistic Studies in California. He was loved and respected. He leaves his wife Alice Runping Zheng; his sons by previous marriages Leigh Jr., Haskell, Henry, William, and Randolph.

TAUB--Henry. With great sadness, UJA Federation of Northern New Jersey, its Officers, Board, and staff mourn the passing of Henry Taub, a devoted friend and longtime supporter of the Jewish people. Mr. Taub was born in 1927 Paterson, NJ. It was in Paterson where Mr. Taub first became involved in Jewish Federation life. A long-time resident of Tenafly, NJ, Mr. Taub regarded the Federation as the nerve center of Jewish life in northern New Jersey. He is the founder of UJA Federation's Synagogue Leadership Initiative, which was designed to train visionary leadership that could change the synagogue in order to meet the needs of the present and future Jewish communities. We extend our sincere condolences to Mr. Taub's wife, Marilyn, and to his children, Ira and Shelly Taub, Judy and Ron Gold, and Steven and Benay Taub and the entire Taub family. UJA Federation of Northern New Jersey Alan Scharfstein, President, David Gad-Harf, Interim Executive Vice President

THREE cyclists from two local racing clubs, defiant and ready to take a stand, rolled into Central Park near 110th Street, and were promptly arrested. It was a summer morning in 1881, and bicycles were not permitted in the city's vast park. Fellow cycling enthusiasts, gathered to witness this act of civil disobedience, cheered as the police hauled them away, setting the stage for a battle over biking and its proper place in the park, and on the nation's roads.

PASS--Marjorie (nee Goldner) April 2 at age 93. Beloved wife of the late Seymour (Sy). Loving mother of Edward, and Jane (Leigh) Gates. Grandmother of Laurel and the late Jeffrey. Graveside Service, 1pm today at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ.

TAUB--Henry. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) deeply mourn the tragic loss of Henry Taub of Tenafly, N.J. A giant in our organization and in the international Jewish community, Mr. Taub held the most influential offices and was recognized with the highest ATS and Technion honors during his decades of dedicated leadership and inspiring support. He served as ATS national president from 1974 to 1976, and chair of the Technion International Board of Governors from 1990 to 2003. He gave inspiring leadership during a time of dramatic expansion and scientific advancement at the university. At the time of his passing, he held the title of Honorary Chair of the Technion International Board of Governors, and was a member of the ATS National Board of Directors and New York Metropolitan Region Board. Mr. Taub and his wife, Marilyn, have spearheaded numerous projects including the Henry and Marilyn Taub and Family Science and Technology Center, a Technion campus landmark and home to its Faculty of Computer Science, considered one of the best in the world; the Leaders in Science and Technology Faculty Recruitment Program; and the Henry and Marilyn Taub Fund for the Future. Mr. Taub was awarded the Technion Medal, a Technion honorary doctorate, and a Technion honorary fellowship. A special ATS celebration in 2004 at the Plaza Hotel in New York City was held in tribute to Mr. Taub's lifetime of brilliant and dedicated service. A legendary business leader, Mr. Taub founded Automatic Data Processing (ADP), a global provider of integrated computing and business outsourcing. He served as president and chief executive officer and subsequently chairman of the board for many years. He was active in many local and national Jewish and community organizations dedicated to wide-ranging causes, and took leadership roles in several. He was also co-owner of the New Jersey Nets of the National Basketball Association from 1978-1998. We extend our sincere condolences to Mr. Taub's beloved wife Marilyn Taub, his children Ira Taub, Judith Gold and Steven Taub, his grandchildren and the entire Taub family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joel Rothman,President Joan Seidel, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

Environmentally conscious travelers often have one question when faced with, say, a sushi menu: Is any of this seafood the product of overfishing? A free app from the Monterey Bay Aquarium in Monterey, Calif., offers an instant answer. The Seafood Watch app, which is new to Android and has been recently upgraded for iPhone and iPod touch users, gives diners recommendations for sustainable seafood options across the United States, automatically sorted by geo-location. And a crowd-sourcing feature, Project FishMap, allows users to share the locations of ocean-friendly restaurants and marketplaces.

''April showers bring forth May flowers'' that much is uncontested. But the variety of wet weather with which spring confronts us would test even an Eskimo's powers of description. To aid the discussion of precipitation, we present below some of pluvial terms to be found in the inestimable ''Oxford English Dictionary.''

A few months ago, Pilar Viladas, our brilliant design editor, came to an editorial meeting with a clutch of pictures of a Georgian manor house in Somerset, England, that the interiors whiz Ilse Crawford had recently reworked for a young family. The project was spectacular in its grand but subtle blending of the minimal and the baroque: the ballroom turned family kitchen was particularly envy-making to a staff of square-foot-challenged New Yorkers. But two images really grabbed our attention: one was of a small child reaching up to open a one-off marquetry cabinet, and the other was of a glorious mess of a playroom. The latter -- the former basement kitchen at Dinder House -- was immediately deemed our cover. What we saw in that room was imagination, spontaneity, persistence (all those open-ended projects) and heart. We saw, in essence, the underpinnings of great design. (There's plenty more to see in ''Family Style,'' Page 74.) It would be extraordinary to see the rooms Ford Wheeler played in when he was growing up in Southern California in his parents' Modernist house. The production designer and downtown New York legend, profiled on Page 86 by Alix Browne, is one of those rare collectors of vernacular and artisanal everything who actually understands how to create a seamless and emotionally compelling backdrop from amassed ephemera. It's hardly surprising that his collaborations with Jonathan Demme (most recently ''Rachel Getting Married'') are memorable for their characters and not their ceramics. His three homes are a moving tribute to a life well lived and well loved.

IF the photograph above right did not make your heart skip a beat, you are either beyond fearless, a professional window washer or both. And if it did not make your heart break a bit, you probably do not know the back story, The man in the picture, Roko Camaj, an Albanian immigrant who adored his job washing windows at the World Trade Center -- so infectiously that he became the subject of a children's book -- was killed on Sept. 11, 2001. No one could have anticipated peril of that magnitude. But window washing in a city of skyscrapers is an inherently dangerous prospect and an inherently dramatic subject for photographers. Few other laborers report to work at such tenuous precipices. They clear panoramas for the rest of us by putting their lives on the line. In turn, they command our attention.

IN the bungling and bellicosity that constitute the back and forth of history, worsened by natural disasters and unprovoked cruelty, humble citizens pay the highest price. To be a traveler in such circumstances can be inconvenient at best, fatal at worst. But if the traveler manages to breeze past such unpleasantness on tiny feet, he or she is able to return home to report: ''I was there. I saw it all.'' The traveler's boast, sometimes couched as a complaint, is that of having been an eyewitness, and invariably this experience -- shocking though it may seem at the time -- is an enrichment, even a blessing, one of the life-altering trophies of the road. ''Don't go there,'' the know-it-all, stay-at-home finger wagger says of many a distant place. I have heard it my whole traveling life, and in almost every case it was bad advice. In my experience these maligned countries are often the most fulfilling. I am not saying they are fun. For undiluted jollification you bake in the sun at Waikiki with a mai tai in your fist, or eat lotuses on the Côte d'Azur. As for the recognition of hard travel as rewarding, the feeling is mainly retrospective, since it is only in looking back that we see how we have been enriched. At the time, of course, the experience of being a bystander to sudden political or social change can be alarming.

FAWCETT--Bessie Bray, 75, died on March 29 of cancer in Tucson, AZ. A retired New York schoolteacher, she lived in Tucson and Manhattan. She was born to Frank and Elsie Bray in Pierce, CO, and grew up on the family farm in Greeley, attending Colorado State College, now the University of Northern Colorado, there. After receiving her degree in education in 1960, she taught for three years in West Germany for the United States Army before working in the Washington office of Senator Gordon Allott of Colorado. She resumed her career in education, teaching in New York State and New York City, her last assignment 23 years at Louis D. Brandeis High School on the West Side of Manhattan, where she taught English and business education, including basic computer use. The beloved wife of the late Jackson Fawcett, she moved with him to Tucson in 1991 and remained there after his death in 1998, though she also maintained a New York apartment. She will be remembered for her passion for ballroom dancing; for years she and her husband would frequent dancehalls like Equus and other New York nightspots. She is survived by her step-daughters, Susan Fawcett Sosin and Cynthia Fawcett; her step-grandchildren, Clifford Sosin, Tyler Sosin and Clarissa Sosin; and her sisters, Katherine Stone, Ruby Johnson, Wilma Bolden, Doris Rowland, Barbara Burrough, Helen Gouge, Joyce Ingersoll and Carol Harding. Donations may be made to a hospice of your choice.

ATTICUS FINCH, the heroic lawyer at the heart of Harper Lee's Pulitzer -winning ''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' is best remembered for his colorblindness in the face of small-town racism. In his 1962 Oscar-winning portrayal of Atticus, Gregory Peck wore a pair of tortoiseshell-style spectacles that aptly symbolized the clarity and wisdom so central to his character. Now, as the film's 50th anniversary approaches, Oliver Peoples is introducing a Gregory Peck frame at the suggestion of his son, Anthony, who owns the original pair. The bookish style ($315 at Barneys New York and oliverpeoples.com) is available in four muted colors, made from a transparent acetate that resembles tortoiseshell with a bit more polish. The Peck family is donating its proceeds from the project to the Los Angeles Public Library. BRUCE PASK

Margate, a town in the far southeast corner of England, may soon become a cultural destination thanks to a new, ambitious gallery inspired by and named after a native artist. For years, the seaside town was a summertime getaway for the English, including the 19th-century artist J. M. W. Turner, who attended school there and used it as the backdrop for some of his most memorable landscapes. Over the last few decades, the town has experienced an economic decline. The organizers behind the Turner Contemporary (turnercontemporary.org), scheduled to open April 16, hope the gallery will help spur a revival.

A graduate of the University of California at Berkeley, USC in California who eventually became an author, professor, fund raiser and philanthropist. Private memorial services will follow in Philadelphia and Tennessee.

GEER--Viola Culbertson, March 21, 2011 age 89 of Riverside, CT. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 200 Riverside Ave., Riverside, CT on April 9, 2011 at 1:00pm.

Sebastian Errazuriz, the Chilean-born designer and artist, became famous for his Bilbao shelf, in which a real tree branch was attached to a wall to create an organic display unit. In his latest design, the Metamorphosis shelf, Errazuriz really goes out on a limb. The inspiration for the limited-edition Baltic birch plywood shelf (which is hand-carved by the Italian company Horm) came from his grandmother's ivy-covered garden. ''The dark branches that crawled along the walls were so thick that I would use them as natural shelves for my garden toys,'' Errazuriz said. Given the $75,000 price tag, however, your spade and trowel had better be by Faberge. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article last Sunday about reality television shows aimed at men misstated part of the name of one such program in one instance. I'VE always considered shoe catalogs to be a relatively safe pleasure, if only because a new pair of shoes, unlike new clothes, can be counted on to provide a jolt of fashion without leaving one breathless with anxiety. Or so it used to be until the appearance of Bergdorf Goodman's spring shoe catalog. From the first item on, which is a crazy-quilt of a Dries Van Noten sandal that rings in at $920, it is clear that one should beware all enterprises requiring new shoes. Which is not to say that there isn't the occasional bargain, like a Manolo Blahnik ballet flat for $665 (!). But if you're looking for the kind of footwear that will knock somebody's socks off (i.e., Azzedine Alaïa's bootie, above), the new normal hovers around $2,000. And then there's Alexander McQueen's gold T-strap wedge, set on a 5 1/2-inch heel, which calls for an outlay of $3,495. If you think too hard about any of this, it can make you weep. DAPHNE MERKIN

Out of the past comes the springtime fox-fur scarf that glamorized fashion from 1910 to 1950, when the show was stolen by the mink stole. In Paris, while $5,000 real fox scarves are still being worn, they have been outfoxed by a fabulous $500 fake in stripes and colors from Prada.

HERMAN--Philip L. beloved father, father-in-law and grandfather passed away unexpectedly March 30, 2011 in Miami Beach, FL. Born April 15, 1937 in the Bronx, NY, he attended Stuyvesant High School and City College, New York and worked his lifetime as a money manager. Phil was known to feed and look after the homeless in his neighborhood in Manhattan and for his exceptional generosity of spirit to all in his life. Phil split his time between Manhattan, NY and Aventura, FL and was at every Miami Heat game of the season. He was respected, admired and made a difference in the lives of many. Phil will be greatly missed. Phil is survived by his loving son Josh, daughter-in-law Rachel and two grandchildren, Gabriella and Isaac, all living in San Diego, CA and long time companion Denise Broughton of Aventura, FL. A memorial will be held Sunday, April 3, 2011 in Aventura, FL. Our family requests that in lieu of your loving gifts of remembrance, that you please make a donations in his memory to: Camillus House, 336 Northwest 5th St., Miami, FL 33128.

Courtney Applebaum, 24, studied social theory at the New School - which is, in crucial ways, ideal training for an interior decorator. Her relationships with clients can be intensely personal, and it shows in the spaces she creates. ''I don't want people to walk into a space and say, 'Courtney did this,' '' she says. ''I just want it to be beautiful, and for the people who live there to be comfortable.'' The Los Angeles native already has half a dozen projects under her belt and at least that many in the works, some very high profile. But while her taste can be daring, she is the picture of discretion. The only names you'll hear her drop are those of Prouve and Nakashima. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

KREIZBERG--Yakov Yakov Kreizberg, died on March 15th, 2011 at his home in Monte Carlo surrounded by his loving wife and two sons. One of the most interesting and exciting conductors of his generation, Yakov Kreizberg conducted most of the major orchestras throughout Europe, North America and Asia. At the time of his death he held the posts of Artistic and Music Director of the Orchestre Philharmonique de Monte-Carlo, and Chief Conductor and Artistic Advisor of the Netherlands Philharmonic and Netherlands Chamber orchestras. He had previously held the posts of Principal Conductor and Artistic Advisor of the Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra, Principal Guest Conductor of the Wiener Symphoniker and Generalmusikdirektor of the Komische Oper Berlin. In Europe, Yakov Kreizberg worked with the Berliner Philharmoniker, the Munchner Philharmoniker, Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra, Symphonieorchester des Bayerischen Rundfunks, Staatskapelle Dresden, Gewandhausorchester, Orchestre National de France and WDR Sinfonieorchester. In the UK he worked with the London Symphony, BBC Symphony, London Philharmonic and the Philharmonia orchestras. He was a frequent guest at London's BBC Proms and last appeared there in 2008 with the Netherlands Philharmonic Orchestra. In North America Yakov Kreizberg conducted, amongst others, the Philadelphia, Boston Symphony, Chicago Symphony and Minnesota orchestras, as well as the Los Angeles and New York Philharmonics. In Asia he worked with orchestras such as the NHK and Yomiuri Nippon Symphony. Equally at home in the opera house he conducted productions at the Chicago Lyric Opera, Canadian Opera, English National Opera, Bregenz Festival, Glyndebourne Festival Opera, De Nederlandse Opera and the Royal Opera House. Yakov Kreizberg encouraged and dedicated time to inspiring youth in music and for a number of years he was Music Director of the Jeunesses Musicales World Orchestra. In October 2007 he was bestowed the "Ehrenkreuz" by the Austrian President in recognition of his achievement in the Arts. A prolific recording artist, he leaves behind an extensive and award-winning discography. His most recent recordings were recorded for the Orchestre Philharmonique de Monte-Carlo's new label OPMC Classics launched in autumn 2010 with a triple CD of Stravinsky's major ballets. This was followed by a Ravel and Debussy compilation in 2011. His many and much admired recordings for PentaTone included symphonies by Shostakovich (Nos. 5 and 9), Dvorakk (Nos. 5 - 9), Schmidt (No. 4 a piece with which he was closely associated) and a number of discs in collaboration Julia Fischer. He also recorded for Decca, Orfeo and Oehms Classics. Born in St. Petersburg, on October 24th, 1959, Yakov Kreizberg studied conducting privately with the legendary Ilya A. Musin, before emigrating to New York city in 1976. There he was awarded conducting fellowships at Tanglewood with Bernstein, Ozawa and Leinsdorf, and at the Los Angeles Philharmonic Institute with Michael Tilson Thomas. In 1986 he won first prize in the Leopold Stokowski Conducting Competition in New York. Yakov Kreizberg is survived by his wife, Amy Andersson, their two sons, sister-in-law Tanya and neice Liza. Yakov and Amy met 28 years ago where they studied conducting at the University of Michigan Music School. It was love at first sight. They married on April 24, 1988 at the Regency Hotel in New York City. They honeymooned in Germany at the Bayreuth Festspiel where they saw the complete Ring Cycle by Wagner. Some of their happiest times were the summer festivals in Weikersheim where they were able to conduct operas on opposite nights, watching each other's conducting of La Traviata, Carmen, and La Boheme in the summers of 2001, 2003, and 2005. On holidays, Yakov enjoyed swimming and boogie boarding with his two boys, and taking long walks along the beach with his wife. He had many friends to whom he was very faithful to, especially ones he met when he first arrived in New York City 35 years ago. Yakov loved Woody Allen movies, Haagen Dazs coffee ice cream, telling jokes, and spending time with dear friends and family. Condolences can be shared through: yakovkreizberg.com

I'm pretty sure you don't know what ''head and tail bands'' are. I didn't, anyway: I had never heard the term before, and if I'd ever seen one, I hadn't noticed it. They're the tiny strips of cloth that lie at the top and bottom of a book, between the back of the paper and the spine. They were originally meant to cover up imperfectly hand-cut pages, but now that commercial bookbinding is done by machine, they've become mostly decorative, and most books don't have them anymore. You may be wondering how I learned this; you're almost certainly wondering why it matters. I know it because Gerhard Steidl explained it to me, at great speed and considerable length, pulling down books of sample head and tail bands from a shelf above his desk, pointing out who makes the best ones, what colors they come in, how much they cost, why they are seldom used and why he uses them. And it matters because it's Steidl's attention to details like these - the look of a spine, the smell of ink, the way different kinds of papers feel on one's fingertips - that makes him one of the world's great publishers.

Let's face it - as trendy as taxidermy has become, it can also be a little creepy. Enter Anna-Wili Highfield (above), a Sydney, Australia-based artist whose hand-painted paper bird and horse sculptures are a perfect vegan alternative to the formaldehyde-filled, flea-bitten critters inhabiting hip hotels, restaurants and bars. Formerly a scenic painter at Opera Australia, the 30-year-old Highfield made her first ''fairy wren'' in 2008. Since then, she has created scores of avian and equine wonders out of thick cotton paper and copper or brass wire. Highfield doesn't have a gallery, but thanks to a few mentions in design magazines down under, there's a sizable waiting list for her work. Hermes recently commissioned two large Pegasus sculptures for its store in Brisbane, but despite this haute horsy endorsement, the artist's favorite winged muses aren't of the hooved variety. ''Raptors fascinate me,'' she says. ''Hawks, eagles, owls - they have an intensity that I try to capture in my pieces. I like to think they look alive.'' Go to annawilihighfield.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

ABRAMOWITZ--Mildred W. Mildred W. Abramowitz, Ph.D., former New York City secondary school principal, attorney, and expert on Eleanor Roosevelt, died at age 94 on March 29th. Mildred was 15 when she first heard Eleanor Roosevelt speak, and many years later, in 1970, Mildred received a Ph.D. from NYU, writing her doctoral thesis on Eleanor Roosevelt. Mildred counted as her blessings giving birth to twins Margaret and Anne (Penny) Sablove, passing the New York City principal's exam, having two long marriages, first to Leo Sablove and then to Mortimer Abramowitz, former Great Neck superintendent of schools, becoming an attorney in her 60s, and being a grandmother to Margaret's children, William and Oliver Sablove. Mildred's life was enriched by deep and enduring friendships with Pearl Myers, Claudia Macari, and four of her high school students in the class of 1949 Joe Intile, Joan Kosan, Roy Solaski, and Emeline Angevine. Born four years before women got the vote, at the age of 91 Mildred cast her vote for Hillary Clinton in the California 2008 primary election. Mildred said that her one regret was, "not living long enough to see a woman become president of the United States." Donations can be made to the Eleanor Roosevelt Papers Project at George Washington University.

GEORGES DAMBIER, whose work is the subject of a delightful exhibition at the Bonni Benrubi Gallery on East 57th Street (through May 14), liked to use Paris as the backdrop for his fashion photographs. Or Cannes or Marrakesh. This was the postwar world of jazz clubs, existentialists, cheap travel, uncrowded streets, beautiful cars, artists and, of course, Paris couture. With his Rolleiflex, Mr. Dambier, who will be 86 on Tuesday, captured all of this with honest joie de vivre, publishing his fashion images in French Elle. And he worked with some of the era's great beauties: Suzy Parker, Dorian Leigh, Bettina, Marie-Hélène Arnaud, Capucine, Ivy Nicholson and Brigitte Bardot.

AS the daughter of divorced parents, I wasn't sentimental about weddings or marriage. I had no visions of myself wearing a white dress. My thoughts on the subject instead tended toward pre-nups, counseling and custody. Yet when I fell in love and decided to marry at 35, rather than elope I allowed my fiancé, Ken, to talk me into a small ceremony in our hometown, Berkeley, Calif. We agreed to keep it simple: local park, vegetarian buffet, 70 guests.

TAUB--Henry. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of our great friend Henry Taub, whose generosity and foresight allowed us to establish The Taub Institute for Research on Alzheimer's Disease and the Aging Brain. When Jonathan Ive, Apple's senior vice president of industrial design, was a boy, a Braun juicer designed by Dieter Rams (above) made a big impression: ''At a glance, you knew exactly what it was and exactly how to use it.'' So it's fitting that Ive, whose own work reflects the German master's principles, wrote the introduction to ''As Little Design as Possible: The Work of Dieter Rams,'' to be published by Phaidon in June. Written by Sophie Lovell and Klaus Kemp, the book examines Rams's ''less but better'' philosophy, as illustrated by the hundreds of products (like the coffee grinder shown here) that he produced for Braun, as well as by the iconic 606 shelving system for Vitsoe, still in production after 50 years. On May 2, the Vitsoe shop at 33 Bond Street will open an exhibition of early 606 pieces, while Braun is producing watches - including the one shown here - inspired by models that Rams and Dietrich Lubs designed in the 1970s. Go to ameico.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Precocious and self-possessed, Charlotte Perriand was a girl among men, admitted to the ranks of the architects whose names would become synonymous with the new century, at an age when her outlook on design and the world was still in formation. In what would prove to be one of Modernism's signal images, she reclines in the chaise longue she designed in collaboration with Le Corbusier and his cousin Pierre Jeanneret. It was, in Le Corbusier's utopian terms, a ''machine for resting in,'' and as if to remind us that it's the chair, not the woman, being presented for our consideration, her face is turned away; she is at once familiar and unrecognizable. That the design of their now-famous furniture was for many years attributed to Le Corbusier alone, that most of her architectural projects never made it past the drawing board, that her far-ranging commissions defied easy classification, that her most significant projects are either gone or off the beaten path: all this only contributed to the enigma. Now, 12 years after her death, at 96, ''Charlotte Perriand: Photography: A Wide-Angle Eye,'' by Jacques Barsac (5 Continents Editions), offers an intimate glimpse of the woman and the workings of her mind. Perriand would have been the first to admit that she wasn't a photographer, and Barsac and the essayists who weigh in here stop short of calling her one. She was, however, convinced that photography and cinema were the forms best suited to capturing the spirit of the new age, and in her hands the camera became an extension of her eye and brain. Taking pictures, she could think without words, as looking turned into seeing and objects viewed from uncommon angles revealed themselves. There is, as Barsac notes, ''an almost primitive dimension . . . a sense of wonderment'' that runs throughout her photos. Every scene, every object is made new, seen with ''the fresh eye of a child who discovers the world with innocence and imagination.''
A stylish night's rest -- and a place to stack that bedtime reading.

Since I moved to New York six years ago, I have toned my tolerance muscles. If I allowed myself to get cranky every time someone barreled down the wrong side of the sidewalk or had a way-too-personal phone conversation on the M15 bus, I'd be one unhappy New Yorker. But the one thing I still cannot abide in this city is spitting. Just the other day - one of the few warm ones in late March - I was enjoying the freedom of walking outside coatless when a young man in front of me, nice looking enough in khakis and a polo shirt, turned his head to the side and let fly a spinning glob that landed dangerously close to my left shoe.

RED trousers have been one of those under-the-radar microtrends riding alongside obsessions like camel-colored everything. This spring, however, it has reached critical mass. Maybe it all started with the sleek cigarette style by The Row or a cherry-legged and leather-jacketed Agyness Deyn. Either way, tucked among blue jeans at Mother, Genetic Denim and Uniqlo are ruby red shades that can't be resisted any longer -- like these cayenne-colored stiletto Current/Elliott jeans ($187 at bergdorfgoodman.com). It's time to go shopping. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

LAMB--Margaret (Mimi), English professor, died on March 22, 2011 at the age of 75. She grew up in a small farming town in North Dakota, the eldest of seven children, and at 18 took the long train trip to Vassar College, in Poughkeepsie, NY, where she was Phi Beta Kappa. After graduation, she moved to New York, a city she loved, and over the years earned an MA and Ph.D. at NYU, joined the English department at Forham University/Lincoln Center and married Fred Garel an activist for the poor, who died in 2006. Associate Professor Lamb, a playwright, novelist and essayist, taught at Fordham for 35 years, until February 12, when she was diagnosed with acute leukemia. A learned, witty, generous woman, Mimi Lamb is dearly remembered by her family, friends and many students.

Late last year, the artists and rug designers Brad Davis and Janis Provisor of Fort Street Studio traveled to Morocco to shop for the tribal rugs known as boucherouites, which are made of everything from wool to synthetic fabrics to scraps of plastic. The rugs' abstract, wildly colorful, intensely personal designs make them catnip to creative types like Davis and Provisor. They came home with 33 rugs, which they are exhibiting at their SoHo showroom for two weeks beginning April 28. Along with the boucherouites, the show will include the spoils of one of the couple's frequent trips to China, where Fort Street's factory is located: seven Chinese art rugs from the 1980s, including one by LeRoy Neiman that depicts the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Go to fortstreetstudio.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Dinder House, a historic Georgian building in Somerset, England, is like a child's drawing of a house: three stories high, with floor-to-ceiling windows and a slate roof. Completed in 1801 for the Rev. William Somerville (think Jane Austen), it sits on 23 acres of landscaped and walled gardens, in a valley with a Constable-worthy view of the church spire in the village after which it is named. Like many large old English houses, Dinder House was converted to commercial use (in this case by a shoe company rather than, say, a hotel) in recent times, but in 2004 it was bought by Chris and Jo Mycock, the owners of a successful I.T. company. Four years (and five architects) later, they finally moved in, once the soul of the building had been restored - as a family house, for a modern family - by the London designer Ilse Crawford. When the Mycocks, who are from Lancashire, in the north of England, decided that they wanted a big house for themselves and their four small sons, they also decided that it should be Georgian. ''They make the best family houses,'' Chris explained. ''The rooms are the right size. They are full of light. The proportions work.'' They saw a photograph of Dinder House in Country Life and snapped it up.

HICKEY--Lawrence Francis, Lawrence Francis Hickey, 90, died peacefully at home in New York City. Cherished husband of the late Jean Hogan Hickey, his bride of 56 years, adored father of Elizabeth Hickey Lavin of Pelham Manor, NY, Frank Hickey, Magee Hickey Salembier and Jane Hickey Sexton, all of New York City, and beloved father-in-law of Tom Lavin, Rick Salembier and Mason Speed Sexton. He was the devoted grandfather of 11: Tom, Kate, Meg, Jack and Janie Lavin, Lily and Floy Salembier, Mason, Buckman, Keats and Daisy Sexton and beloved grandfather-in-law of Scott Phillips. He was a special friend of Miao Hua Zhou. He was lovingly cared for by Felicidad Collado, Astou Diop, Nur Purnamawaty and so many others. Mr. Hickey, born in Brooklyn, was a graduate of the University of Notre Dame class of 1942. He served in World War II as a lieutenant senior grade USN in the Pacific. He received the William D. Reynolds Award in 1992 from Notre Dame and was the Notre Dame Club of New York "Man of the Year" in 1993. He also received an Honorary Degree of Doctor of Humane Letters in 1995 from St. John's University. After retiring from his family's concrete business, M.F. Hickey Company, which was founded by his grandfather in 1896, Mr. Hickey spent the last three decades helping the mentally retarded and emotionally disturbed children of New York City. He served on the Board of the Kennedy Child Study Center for decades. Mr. Hickey was head of the Parish Council, Eucharistic Minister, lector, and altar server at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church. He was also a member of the board of Astor Services for Children for many years. During that time, he oversaw the purchase and renovation of a two-room, Victorian Gothic schoolhouse known as "The Little Red Schoolhouse." It was renamed in honor of him and is now called the Lawrence F. Hickey Center for Child Development, a therapeutic early childhood development program. In addition, Mr. Hickey was a past president of the Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter, The Amateur Comedy Club and The Jones Wood Association. He was chief Honorary Usher and a lector at St. Patrick's Cathedral, a Knight Equestrian of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem and a Knight of Malta. The Daughters of Charity recognized him for his work at the Kennedy and Astor facilities by naming him an "Affiliate" of the Order in 1990. Mr. Hickey was a member of the Friends of Cardinal Cooke Guild and an early member of the Bishop Fulton J. Sheen Foundation promoting the case for sainthood. When asked why he spent his retirement years helping others, Mr. Hickey wrote: "Lessons learned on the campus of Notre Dame, from my Irish Catholic background, and a tour of 49 months in the Navy in WWII, convinced me that we all must help God's less fortunate." And in his final years, nothing made him happier than to be surrounded by his large and adoring circle of family and friends in his weekend home in Millerton, New York. The wake will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Thursday from 6 to 9pm. The Funeral Mass will be held at Saint Patrick's Cathedral at 10am, Friday. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Lawrence F. Hickey Center for Child Development, 4010 Dyre Avenue, Bronx, NY 10466 or the Kennedy Child Study Center, 151 East 67th Street, New York, NY 10065.

TO hear Robert Marc, the luxury eyewear designer whose sunglasses are worn by a host of celebrities, talk about his apartment at 165 Charles Street, it's a little hard to understand why he is selling. He bought the three-bedroom on the 10th floor of the 16-story Richard Meier tower five years ago for $7.32 million. Now he is listing it with John Burger of Brown Harris Stevens for $7.95 million. He described it as a ''prized piece of art that you can actually live in'' and ''the best place I have ever lived.''

The Architect: Charlotte Macaux Perelman, who founded Studio CMP in Paris after stints with the hotel-world heavyweights: Philippe Starck and Andre Balazs. More than 150 years ago, Charles Dickens published "Hard Times," a novel centered around the students of an English schoolmaster named Thomas Gradgrind, who had no use for play or any sort of imaginative pursuit. For Gradgrind, if something did not demonstrably add to the productive capacity of the nation and could not be justified with facts and statistics, it had no place in a child's education.

On Saturday, during halftime at the NCAA semi-finals, a reporter asked the Connecticut coach Jim Calhoun how his team had managed to build up a 10-point lead. He replied, more or less, We played good defense, although we didn’t get enough rebounds. What will you have to do in the second half?, the reporter queried brightly. Add rebounds to the good defense was the answer.

Blake Griffin is the reigning dunk champion of the N.B.A., but Julius Erving was the innovator. With his array of spins, leaps and gravity-defying dunks, he won three championships, one in the N.B.A. with the Philadelphia 76ers and two in the American Basketball Association with the Nets. He also won four Most Valuable Player awards in the two leagues and two A.B.A. scoring titles. Erving, who retired in 1987, was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1993. Erving, who was honored recently at the Thurman Munson awards in Manhattan, turned 61 earlier this year.

If ever there was a man whose character finds opportunity in crisis, that man is Ahmet Davutoglu, Turkey's foreign minister. Like Turkey itself, he finds his natural role sandwiched between powers, managing conflict and building relationships. Where does it hail from, that hospital ship bearing the wounded away from besieged Misrata, Libya? It hails from Turkey, of course, and is named after the capital, Ankara. What country has both urged Qaddafi to go, yet maintained a very active embassy in Tripoli? Turkey again. (It was also a crucial go-between in aiding in the release of our own Times colleagues from Libyan captivity the other week.) Which country (and major NATO member) has performed the trick of strongly opposing NATO involvement in any Libyan action - then embracing exactly that? And so on.

With their win over the Nets Friday, the Philadelphia 76ers clinched a playoff berth. Yet by Sunday, their playoff chances -– already slim, given the strength of Philadelphia’s likely first-round opponent, Miami or Boston –- had taken a significant hit with Lou Williams’s strained right hamstring. Williams was forced to leave the Sixers’ game against the Bucks during the third quarter, and an already limited Philadelphia team had one less scoring option. "The only place I don't cook in is my bathtub," Rachel Khoo marvels. A trained pastry chef, twice-published author and self-christened food creative, Khoo hosts lunches at La Petite Cuisine à Paris, or the Little Paris Kitchen, in her 226-square-foot apartment in Paris's Belleville neighborhood. The "little kitchen" concept might be a considerable hindrance to most chefs, but Khoo has made the most of it. "It's like I'm on a constant camping holiday," she says of the two gas rings and toaster oven at her disposal, and the resourcefulness that has sprung from them. She has whipped up Eton mess à la française, lemon and lavender roast chicken, tonka bean soufflé, and croque madame muffins. Khoo's favorite dish so far, pot au feu fajitas (melt-in-your-mouth beef stew and fresh vegetables in a tortilla with sauce from the pot au feu), summarizes the spirit of her book: "It's not quite French, but it takes on the initial French flavors."

Barbara Hannah Grufferman was in her late 30s when she married and had children. She was in her mid-40s when she made what she describes as the “heart- and stomach-wrenching decision to quit my job as president of a small but growing international conference company to be a full-time mother of two daughters.” Seven years later she looks back on the decision and says: “The challenge … that many women — including me — didn’t think through was this: If I decide to remove myself from the workforce for a period of time, will I be  able to get back in?”

As I read reports about the release of more than 11,000 tons of radiation-laced water into the sea from the damaged nuclear plant in Japan, I recalled reporting I did more than a decade ago on the many uses of silt barriers — essentially curtains suspended in water — to hold back everything from oil slicks to the bursts of polluted runoff flowing into coastal waters from city storm drains after heavy storms (the water can be pumped and treated once the system is not overloaded).

SHANGHAI — A triptych oil painting by Zhang Xiaogang sold for $10.1 million on Sunday at a Sotheby’s auction in Hong Kong. The sale broke the record for a piece by a living Chinese artist, and was the latest sign of China’s phenomenal ascent in the global art market.

Apparently, it’s official: Katie Couric will no longer anchor the “CBS Evening News.” It’s hardly a surprise. She has been hinting at a move for ages, and speculation that she wouldn’t last has been gurgling pretty much since her first day in the anchor’s chair five years ago. But rarely was she ever so open with her ambivalence about the job as she was in an interview with Andrew Goldman, which appears in the April 10 issue of the magazine but which we’re publishing online now. Goldman conducted it on Friday, March 25, the day before Couric took off for a pre-big-news vacation to Turks and Caicos. Although she wouldn’t confirm that she was leaving the show — she was more interested in discussing her new book, “The Best Advice I Ever Got: Lessons From Extraordinary Lives” — she expressed some regrets about trying to push the nightly-news genre too far too fast and she floated a theory (though she wouldn’t put her name behind it) that CBS’s local news lead-ins might have kept her mired in third place.
Bound by a mutual love for animated animals — and profits — Jeffrey Katzenberg, chief executive of DreamWorks Animation SKG, has joined Zynga’s board, the company announced Monday.

Newly discovered 1840s murals of inlets, willows, lighthouses and sailing ships are being extricated this week from a house in East Baldwin, Me., for transfer to the Rufus Porter Museum and Cultural Heritage Center in nearby Bridgton. The owners have donated three roomfuls of the scenery, painted by the muralist Rufus Porter's nephew Jonathan Poor, along with underlying layers of plaster and lath, fireplace mantels and an entire staircase. The museum is raising $60,000 for the dismantling work, by the salvager David Ottinger, and is renovating an 1830s house that will accommodate the acquisition. Poor died in his early 40s, soon after completing the work for a local physician, perhaps because mural painting was a hazardous profession. "My supposition is that all the materials they worked with were poisonous," Julie Lindberg, the Porter museum's curator, said.

Last week was a busy one for those following the battle over rules limiting the fees banks can charge to process debit card transaction. On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, acknowledged that the board, swamped by public comments on its proposed rules, would miss its deadline for completing those rules. "Architecture has always been my inspiration," says Paige Novick, who has been designing her eponymous line of costume jewelry for the past four years. This fall she will unveil Phyne, her first fine jewelry collection, adding precious stones into pieces made from metals like sterling silver alloy, more often found in factories than in your mother's jewelry box. The delicate black rhodium and diamond speckled octagonal rings, geometric earrings spiraling with precious stones and metal and gem-tiered cuffs were created, she says, with the Empire State Building in mind, but there may be another muse who deserves some credit here. "My mother is a fine jeweler," Novick explains with a smile. "It's in my DNA."

The Academy of Country Music Awards led Sunday night in the ratings for CBS, as an average of 13 million viewers tuned in to the award show broadcast from 8 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS won the night over all, drawing 10.3 million to lead the 7 p.m. time slot as well with “60 Minutes.” ABC placed a solid second, as 9.7 million watched “Secret Millionaire” at 8, followed by “Desperate Housewives” (8.8 million) and “Body of Proof” (8.4 million) at 9 and 10. NBC ranked third, with 8.5 million for “The Celebrity Apprentice” from 9 to 11 but lower ratings for “Dateline” at 7 (5.2 million) and “America’s Next Great Restaurant” at 8 (3.9 million). Fox was fourth with mostly reruns of its animated comedy lineup.

SANTIAGO, Chile — Latin America loves smart, tough female rappers: Anita Tijoux on Saturday and, on Sunday afternoon, Mala Rodríguez from Spain. Ms. Rodríguez performed wearing a kind of corset, along with pink knee socks, but in her songs she is no bimbo. Her delivery — mostly rapped, occasionally sung — is rapid-fire enough to leave most rappers breathless; her message is self-realization without apologies, limits or inhibitions. It’s bragging, flirting, philosophizing and flinging ultimatums. When she called for the crowd to join in, it was to chant “Fuerte!” — “Strong!”

Bill James is rattling his sabremetrician-ness again. On Wednesday, he published an essay in Slate, "Verlander and Shakespeare." It's pretty great for reasons highlighted by its subtitle, "Why are we so good at developing athletes and so lousy at developing writers?" Throw a brush-back pitch like that and you're sure to start a conversation. So much to argue with! The premise itself. Two gross assumptions underlying the premise. Then, another level down, the issue of what "developing" means. And "good." And "lousy." And "we" - who does that refer to, exactly? Just wait till you get to the actual arguments.

Over the weekend I wrote an article for Sunday Styles about new Web services that deal with a new problem — online reputation management. These businesses have cropped up over the past few years to address one major negative aspect of our online world: As quickly as images, blog posts, commentary, status updates and photos are posted on the Web, they are replicated by algorithms and search engines, and dissipate like an airborne virus. The Internet is a permanent record of our past, and it never forgets anything posted online.

SANTIAGO, Chile - Lollapalooza Chile has introduced me to a world-class party band: Chico Trujillo, a local favorite who had a huge crowd shouting along. Every party band needs a rhythm, and Aldo Asenjo, the band's leader and singer, relies on cumbia, the beat heard in countless variations across Latin America. Cumbia often trots calmly, but Chico Trujillo's version gallops, bounding along; now and then, the music switches into rumba, equally upbeat. Mr. Asenjo sings lyrics as chattery and percussive as some hip-hop, taking on the ups and downs of love and life, with his voice answered by chortling horns -- did he borrow the arranging idea from ska bands? -- and a tootling, circusy organ. Syncopation, momentum and a way of romping through pain -- a party band needs them all, and Chico Trujillo has them.

Mandi Schwartz, the Yale player who confronted her leukemia with support from hockey fans from Connecticut to western Canada, died Sunday in Regina, Saskatchewan. She was 23. Her death was confirmed by the university. Schwartz learned in December 2008 that she had acute myeloid leukemia, and her teammates organized drives to find a bone-marrow donor on the Yale campus and across North America. In January 2010, she regained enough strength to return to practice, but in April her cancer returned. She had a stem-cell transplant in September, but in December, a biopsy showed that her cancer had returned. THOMAS KAPLAN

KLEIN--Fannie, President and co-founder of the Manhattan real estate company, Harfay Management Corp., died Saturday night at her Manhattan home at the age of 99, surrounded by her loving family. The eldest of nine children, Fannie was a second generation New Yorker, born September 9, 1911 in The Bronx. As a teenager, Fannie met Harry Klein and later worked in his butcher shop. They married in 1930. With Harry, she built the family business one building at a time, creating vast real estate holdings in Manhattan. After her husband died in 1986 she assumed sole management of the company, working every day until she retired at the age of 95. She was a New York classic who walked to work, vacationed in Miami Beach, and played poker with the girls. Fannie never missed an opportunity to play the piano, dance or jump rope. In her final years, she'd wistfully remark on her younger days: "I wish I were 80 again." Fannie donated and raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She is survived by her loving sons Irwin and Murray Klein; grandchildren Jamie Klein Kapel, Sherry Klein, David Klein and Melissa Klein; great-grandchildren Brandon, Jared and Lindsey Kapel; Garson and Moss Klein; and Katherine and Benjamin Klein; siblings Tessie Nerenberg, Estelle Kamhi, Samuel Berman, Shirley Nadler, and Julius Berman. She was predeceased by her sisters Diana Monaco and Essie Baum. Services are Monday, 12pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

GOLDSTEIN--Ann Lubin, January 1, 1928 - April 1, 2011. 83, of Sarasota formerly of Mamaroneck, NY, died April 1, 2011. She was the loving oldest daughter of Evelyn and Joseph Lubin. Beloved wife, for 63 years of Alfred Goldstein; Mother of Wendy Cohen, Steven and Richard Goldstein. She was the devoted grandmother of Stacey Weckstein, Dana Yaphe, Heather Sugarman, Pam Cohen, Jessica, Zachary and Jordan Goldstein and the cherished great grandmother to Ella and Amina Torres and Aiden and Soren Yaphe. Ann and her husband, Alfred are philanthropic pillars in their community, supporting the arts, education, seniors, and religious establishments. Ann has always been active in her community by donating her time to several charities as well as running the the gift shops at The Albert Einstein School of Medicine in New York and the Mote Marine Aquarium in Sarasota. She was a gifted artist working in several mediums. A private funeral will be held.

Stanley Bogdan, a maker of fly fishing reels so coveted that anglers were willing to spend years on a waiting list to buy them and then to pay far more than they would have for reels of only ordinary excellence, died March 27 in Nashua, N.H. He was 92 and a lifetime Nashua resident. His death was confirmed by his son, Stephen.

SPORTS An article in some editions on Friday about the Rangers' 6-2 loss to the Islanders on Thursday night misstated a distinction that the three New York metropolitan area N.H.L. franchises would earn if the Rangers missed the playoffs. It would be the first time all three teams missed the playoffs in the same season; they did not do so in 1982-83, when the Devils moved to New Jersey. That year, the Islanders beat the Rangers in the Patrick Division final and went on to win the Stanley Cup. The article also misstated the number of goals the Rangers have scored in their last five games. It is 1, 1, 1, 0 and 2, not 1, 1, 1, 0 and 1.

ASSAEL--Salvador J.,on April 1, 2011 passed away peacefully after a brief illness. Born in 1923, Salvador fled Italy with his family in 1938, first to Paris, then to Portugal, where they boarded a ship to Cuba. The family lived in Havana until the communist revolution in 1957, when they moved via Miami to New York where they continued their diamond and jewelry business. A World War II veteran, as a member of Cannon Company, 311th infantry Regiment, 78th Infantry Division, he participated, endured and survived the Battle of the Bulge, December, 16th, 1944 January 25, 1945, The U.S. campaign in Africa, and the Battle of Remagen in March 17-25, 1945. He received the Purple Heart and other medals for distinguished service from the U.S. Government. 1949 Mr. Assael began trading in left over U.S. Army watches with Japan. He was paid in pearls, which is how he started the pearl business. In 1972 he took over the business from his family, and founded Assael International. In 1973, he became a producer of the Tahitian Black pearls together with Frenchman, Jean Claude Brouillet in French Polynesia. Today Assael International is one of the leading pearl Houses in the world. In June 1998, he became a Chevalier of the Order of Tahiti Nui. He received the GIA League of Honor Sovereign in 1996 and 1998. Mr. Assael was a founding member of the South Sea Pearl Consortium. Mr. Assael was involved in many charities. In 1993 he purchased land for the founding of Temple Dorette Assael in Papeete, Tahiti, the only Sephardic Synagogue in the South Pacific. He gave the only Sephardic exhibit at the Jewish Museum in New York; built the Azata Library in Beer Sheba, Israel; donated a wing of the Sephardic Home's Adult Health Care Center in Brooklyn, New York; donated the Atrium of the GIA World Headquarters in Carlsbad, California and donated a room at "Our House" Hospice in Los Angeles, California. Mr. Assael is mourned by his wife, Christina Lang Assael, his children, Sophia and Robert Lang Assael, and Arlette Assael and his loyal staff Alex Rodrigues, Elisabetta Golonko and Yaneli Gusman. Our sincere thank you to Doctor Ralph Gibson, his dedicated nurses, Moira Turck, Noreen Curran, Mary Ford, Pauline Gilroy, Margaret Gaine, Aneta Konopka and his trainer, Job Berrara. Services will be held on Sunday, April 3rd, at 12 Noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York, NY 10023. Phone: 212-362-6600. Shiva will be held at 485 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10022 on Monday and Tuesday from 2pm to 9pm.

Butler beat V.C.U. on Saturday to return to the N.C.A.A. Men's Basketball Championship for the second straight year. Shelvin Mack, above left, who celebrated with Chase Stigall, led the Bulldogs with 24 points. Butler will face the Connecticut Huskies in Monday's game. BUSINESS DAY An article on Friday about Ireland's struggling banks misstated the number of euros needed to shore up four of them. It was 10.5 billion for Allied Irish Banks, 3.7 billion for Bank of Ireland and 4.5 billion for two smaller institutions, not 18.8 billion, 5.2 billion and 4.2 billion, respectively.

GROSSMAN--Marshall S.,professor of Renaissance English literature, Milton scholar, author, connoisseur of fine bourbons, classic jazz and Nathan's hot dogs, passed away on March 29, 2011. His friends and family honor and admire his intellect and his accomplishments, and are awed by the scope of his scholarly achievements. We will always cherish his wit and his whimsy, his integrity, his directness and his honesty. Marshall shot straight and true, but never unkindly. He is survived by his son, Jacob Grossman, his companion, Karen Imler, his mother, Evelyn Grossman, and his brother Steven Grossman and sister Julie Grossman and their families.

Learning how to grow tomatoes in New York and can them is one thing. Finding out the best way to entertain a coop of chickens or when best to oust a queen bee from an urban hive falls into an entirely different realm of community gardening. ''You either have to find her and kill her, or allow the colony to requeen itself,'' said Sara Katz, one of the teachers of Beekeeping Basics.

Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, may move one of his long-running concert series this summer because of opposition over the shows' noise and a proposal for a huge new amphitheater there. Seaside Summer Concerts, one of two free series presented by Mr. Markowitz, has been held at Asser Levy/Seaside Park, on the border of Coney Island and Brighton Beach, since 1991, and has had appearances by the Beach Boys, Smokey Robinson and the B-52s. But last summer two synagogues across the street from the stage sued to stop the concerts, saying that the shows were in violation of a city law prohibiting amplified sound within 500 feet of a school or house of worship. The synagogues, and some other community leaders, also opposed a $64 million new amphitheater in the park, saying that it would draw too much traffic to the area.

POMERANTZ--Isidore (Irving), 104, March 31, 2011, Brooklyn, NY. Self-made entrepreneur in clothing business. Founding partner with Sy of Syms Clothing. Philanthropist, ethical and religious man of humble origin, who defied all odds with enduring spirit and humor. Predeceased by his wife of 36 years, Eve, and his son Stephen. Survived by son, Melvin, grandchildren, Seth and Eve, and daughter-in-law, Kukiko. Sustained in his final years by dear friends, Irma Albarran and Moshe Adelman.
