WALDHUTER--Jeffrey, 58, died unexpectedly on April 1, 2011. Jeff was a retired electrical engineer, who had formerly worked in telecommunications at Verizon. Jeff was a very skilled craftsman who spent hours at hobbies such as carpentry in his free time. He was loved by his many good friends, and was a loyal friend. He was always there when a friend, or his community, needed help. His energy and his exuberance will be missed.

TURK--Robert B.,80, of Morristown, NJ died Friday, April 1st at Morristown Memorial Hospital. Mr. Turk, son of the late Rose and Peter Turk, was born and raised in South Orange, NJ and graduated from Columbia High School in 1949. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia Law School, he was in private practice in New Jersey for more than forty-five years, specializing in commercial real estate law. In 1964, Mr. Turk married Joan Gerstl Turk and they resided in Maplewood, New Jersey for thirty-eight years, moving to the Convent Station Section of Morris Township four years ago. Mr. Turk is survived by his wife, Joan and his children, Abby R. Turk of Hoboken, NJ and Peter J. Turk and his wife Dana of Summit, NJ. He is also survived by his beloved grandchildren, Anna and Owen Turk of Summit. He was pre-deceased by his brother, William H. Turk and survived by his eldest brother, Abner of Weston, Florida. He is also survived by seven nephews and two nieces and their families, cousins and many dear friends. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, April 5th at 11am at the Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ 07039.

COPELAND--Lillian (nee Plonsky), on April 1, 2011 in her 97th year in Pompano Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Jack Copeland, daughter of the late Ben and Bessie (Weissman) Plonsky, sister of the late Samuel Payne, survived by beloved nieces and nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews.

STAFFORD--Sidney Bacon, died in her home in Brookhaven, Long Island, NY on April 1 after a brief illness with cancer. She was born on November 30, 1935 in New York. Sidney was the daughter of financier F M Bacon III and famed photographer Toni Frissell, one of the first woman photo journalists in WWII. She continued in her mother's footsteps as a successful professional photographer. Sidney graduated from Foxcroft boarding school where she was an accomplished horse woman. She lived most of her life on Long Island growing up in the idyllic community of St. James, Long Island, NY. Sidney bred show dog dachshunds and was active in the show circuit as both a presenter and a judge. She was recently honored with a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Dachshund Club of America. Sidney was generous with both her time and her involvement in the Birch Family Camp for children and families living with HIV/AIDS, diabetes and homelessness. Her loving nature and generosity will be missed by everyone who knew her well. Sidney is survived by her son, Montgomery Brookfield, her daughter Brent Loyer, her brother Varick Bacon, and eight grandchildren. The funeral service will be held on Tuesday at 11:00 o'clock at the Episcopal Church in St James, LI. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Birch Society in memory of Sidney Stafford (www.oneheartland.org). Please designate online contributions to Sidney's program that she has supported for so many years. Donations can also be mailed to: Birch Family Camp c/o One Heartland, 2101 Hennepin Ave., Ste. 107 Minneapolis, MN, 55405. For questions or to make a donation over the phone, please call One Heartland at 1-800-724-HOPE.

HALL--Richard D.,on March 29, 2011. Born December 5, 1924, in New York. Noted television commercial producer, first at Horn/Griner, then as executive vice-president of Griner/Cuesta and Griner/Cuesta & Schrom. A founder of the Association of Independent Commercial Producers and twice served as its national president. Survived and will be greatly missed by his wife, sisters, two children, three stepchildren, and five grandchildren. Donations in his honor may be made to Hospice Care of Nantucket.

LIBYA At least two of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's sons are proposing a resolution to the Libyan conflict that would entail their father relinquishing power for a transition to constitutional democracy under the direction of his son Seif el-Islam el-Qaddafi, according to a diplomat and a Libyan official. It is not clear whether Colonel Qaddafi agrees with the plan, and some observers wonder whether there is a power struggle going on inside the family. YEMEN The United States, which has tried to keep President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen in power in the face of deadly protests, has quietly shifted positions and is working behind the scenes to remove him, White House and Yemeni officials say.

EMBER--Norman, age 85, of Manhattan, NY, passed away on Saturday, April 2, 2011. Private investor, former garment industry leader, World War II hero, Columbia University graduate. Son of Max and Ida, brother of Melvin and Gloria, husband of Susan, father to Max, Peter, Richard and wife, Marie-Claire. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., on Tuesday, April 5, at 11:30am. Interment to follow. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Norman and Susan Ember Foundation.

Off Broadway's New York Theater Workshop on Friday announced two additional productions for its 2011-12 season: a play about a Palestinian family preparing for a wedding in the politically volatile West Bank, and a modern retelling of Homer's ''Illiad'' that will feature, on alternating nights, the Tony Award winners Denis O'Hare (''Take Me Out'') and Stephen Spinella (''Angels in America'') as the piece's sole actor. The workshop had previously disclosed that the first show of the season will be Elevator Repair Service's latest novel-based production ''The Select - The Sun Also Rises,'' made up of swaths of dialogue and prose from Hemingway's classic about American expatriates in France and Spain after World War I. Elevator Repair Service had a major critical hit this season at the Public Theater with ''Gatz,'' a word-for-word rendition of Fitzgerald's ''The Great Gatsby.'' Previously at the workshop, the theater troupe mounted a production based on the first section of Faulkner's ''The Sound and the Fury.''
ANHOLT--Robert J.,"Bob, Daddy, Opa, Uncle Bob", died peacefully, March 27. We love you always, you will never be forgotten. Your beloved family.

(Showtime) THE GHOST WRITER (2010) In this moody tale from Roman Polanski, Ewan McGregor, above, is ''at his ingénue best,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, portraying a scribe for hire. His job is to clean up the unfinished memoir of Adam Lang, a former British prime minister played by ''a superb Pierce Brosnan,'' after the previous writer has washed up on an American beach. Olivia Williams is Lang's wife, a brainy beauty with secrets whose marital relationship is meant to invoke that of Cherie Booth and Tony Blair. ''The parallels with Mr. Blair and Lang spice up the story, especially as references to Iraq, torture and the Central Intelligence Agency are folded into the mix, and placard-waving protesters gather outside Lang's hideaway,'' Ms. Dargis wrote. ''Fingers are pointed, though sometimes it seems not only at Lang but also at Mr. Polanski,'' who at the time of the film's release was under house arrest in Switzerland waiting to see if he would be extradited to Los Angeles to face sentencing for his 1977 sex crime. Mr. Polanski delivers ''this pulpy fun at such a high level that 'The Ghost Writer' is irresistible, no matter how obvious the twists,'' Ms. Dargis added. ''The pleasures of a well-directed movie should never be underestimated.'' 8 P.M. (A&E) INTERVENTION IN-DEPTH: PREGNANT AND ADDICTED The series travels to the Nexus Recovery Center, a substance-abuse treatment clinic for women in Dallas, where four patients discuss coping with addiction and pending motherhood. In the premiere of ''Relapse,'' at 9, coaches try to prevent high-risk former addicts from reverting to previous behavior. And ''Heavy: Where Are They Now?,'' at 10, follows up with weight-loss participants from Texas.

There are many bumps in the road on the way to building a successful business. Many of the challenges are right in front of you — like finding business, delivering the product or service on time, hiring the right people, and financing the whole to-do. One of the most surprising, upsetting, and dangerous challenges is trying to collect money owed (as we discuss in a small-business guide published today). Now the neighborhood is crammed with fashion boutiques, gourmet coffeehouses and, most recently, high-style hotels. Casa Camper opened last January, with 51 brightly colored rooms, an Asian tapas restaurant and a 24-hour rooftop lounge. Kevin O’Callaghan, an instructor at New York’s School of Visual Arts, not long ago came across an auction on eBay at 3 in the morning for church pews and interior elements from a church in Newark. Any interested party had exactly 24 hours to bid or the items would be destroyed. On a whim, O’Callaghan put in a bid for $500 for the entire church interior and, to his surprise, he won. Within 24 hours, with the help of his students, he drove away with 32 pews in a 24-foot truck and brought them to a workshop at the school.

Fine art and fashion make a pretty agreeable cocktail. For the photographer Steven Sebring, each is an ingredient in a body of work that spans several decades and a multitude of photographic techniques. Mr. Sebring takes a painterly approach to portraiture in his current show of monumentally scaled images of American cultural icons — poets as he calls them — who have left indelible mark on the Manhattan’s downtown culture. Viewed at close range, his subjects radiate light like stained glass — hence the title of the show, “Illuminations,” at Milk Studios in Chelsea. At a distance, the features of his subjects — writers and musicians including Jim Carroll, Joey Ramone, Richard Hell and Patti Smith — seem almost animated, swimming into focus as the viewer backs away.

When the state comptroller began an audit of the city’s high school dropout rate, there was some expectation that its findings would be explosive. It was started after allegations that the city might be artificially plumping up the graduation rate through a paperwork sleight-of-hand, classifying some students who had dropped out as “discharges,” meaning they simply left the school for another school. While dropouts are counted against the graduation rate, discharges are not.

Within 15 seconds of entering Sunday’s game against the Phoenix Suns, George Hill had made his first basket. After 35 seconds more, he had made another. Minutes later, Hill was in the midst of a full-blown explosion, as he dropped a pair of pull-up three-pointers, hit a short jumper, and then successfully executed the patented, controversial “rip move” to earn three foul shots and pull off an 11-2 run all on his own. Toss in an extra basket and a technical free throw, and Hill concluded his six-minute stint in the first quarter with 16 points and spotless shooting from the field and the free throw line.

A two-hour installment of “Dancing With the Stars” attracted an average of 21.4 million viewers on Monday, lifting ABC to first place in the night’s ratings ahead of CBS and its college basketball coverage, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although final audience figures for CBS’s live broadcast of the N.C.A.A. men’s championship game were not immediately available on Tuesday, preliminary overnight estimates were down slightly compared with last year, when 23.9 million watched the title matchup on CBS. Despite that modest decline, the game’s ratings were still high enough that CBS might have led the night over all were it not for lower ratings preceding the basketball coverage for sitcom reruns at 8 and 8:30, “The Big Bang Theory” (9.6 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (7.4 million). The repeats lagged in comparison with ABC’s 10 p.m. audience for “Castle” (11.7 million) following “Dancing With the Stars.” NBC ranked third with “Harry’s Law” at 10 (7.4 million) following a rerun of “Chuck” at 8 (2.5 million) and “The Event” at 9 (3.9 million). Fox was fourth with repeats of “House” (4.4 million) and “The Chicago Code” (3.9 million).

Let's say it is your friend's birthday. Should you ask her what she wants and simply buy her that present, or should you thoughtfully think of something yourself and surprise her? An article in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology suggests the first route is best. Francesca Gino and Francis Flynn conducted 5 separate studies and found that people were more pleased by gifts they explicitly requested. They were also quite pleased by gifts of cash. Givers believe that people like surprises but giftees just want what they want.

The overwhelmingly male field of angel investing is about to become a bit more diverse. Ten women, including some business owners (TechCrunch has the full list), will soon learn the secrets of angel investing during the Pipeline Fund Fellowship’s inaugural six-month program for aspiring female angels. Beginning this month, the group, chosen from among 50 applicants, will attend monthly workshops on issues like due diligence and valuation, and will be paired with mentors who are seasoned male and female investors. The program, held in New York, will culminate with an investment by the group in a women-led, profit-making, socially conscious venture.

The shoegazer singer Tamaryn, who started a North American tour with the Raveonettes last week, has learned a thing or two about stage makeup. “I don’t always use primer on my eyes, and I never wear powder — I like everything to be a little dewy and sexual looking,” said the singer during a pretour shopping spree in SoHo. (Stops included M.A.C. and Sephora.) She recently discovered Super, Dr. Nicolas Perricone’s new collection, at its flagship in Berkeley, Calif. — the band is based in San Francisco — and swears by the First Blush Brightening Serum: “I’ve been using it over makeup to set it and have a bit of a glow.” Other must-haves include Osis Mattifying Powder (“I sprinkle it in my hair and it looks teased”), Stila Kajal Eye Pencil in black (“looks better the next day”), Frederic Malle Une Rose (“androgynous but romantic — plus the traditional Goth girl scent is rose water”) and Tom Ford Bruised Plum Lip Color (“it’s like neu-Goth, because it’s sheer”). But the singer is always looking to evolve with her look: “I really want to start wearing brown lipstick. I’ve been watching a lot of ‘My So-Called Life’ lately, and they all have that brown lipstick! I think the ’90s are what it’s all about right now.”

Molly Bloom’s wandering soliloquy in James Joyce’s “Ulysses” was the inspiration for “The Sensual World,” the title song from Kate Bush’s 1989 album, but at the time the Joyce estate would not give her approval to use the words in her lyrics. Now Ms. Bush has received the long-awaited permission to use the text, and she has rerecorded the song, which she renamed “Flower of the Mountain,” according to BBC News. Ms. Bush said she was “delighted” to have the chance “to fulfill the original concept.” The new track will be released in May on “Director’s Cut,” her first new album in six years.

Representative Paul D. Ryan,  Republican from Wisconsin, released a dramatic new deficit-reduction proposal Tuesday, one that would slash $5.8 trillion from spending levels over the next decade. Among the more controversial highlights is a cap on Medicare and Medicaid spending, by giving individual Medicare recipients vouchers of a certain amount, and block grants to states for Medicaid. The pundit consensus seems to be that Mr. Ryan's plan will be the framework for thinking about how to resolve budget issues -- in David Brooks's words, "the standard of seriousness for anybody who wants to play in this discussion."

Former Senator George LeMieux of Florida announced in an Internet video on Tuesday that he would challenge Senator Bill Nelson, a Democrat, next year. In the video, Mr. LeMieux said: "Most people know that Washington has a spending problem. Let me tell you, it's worse than you think." Mr. LeMieux, who served as chief of staff to Gov. Charlie Crist, was appointed to the Senate in 2009 by Mr. Crist to replace Mel Martinez, who retired. Mr. LeMieux served 16 months and is now looking to be elected to the chamber in his own right (he did not run in November, when Marco Rubio was elected to the seat). Mr. LeMieux joins Mike Haridopolos, president of the State Senate, in what is likely to be a crowded Republican field for the right to face Mr. Nelson in 2012.

Chicken Littles on the left have lately been aligning with the right (where the sky is not only falling, it has crashed to the ground and suffocated all reason and logic) on the issue of “fixing” Social Security.

You do not have to like the long-term budget that Paul Ryan and the House Republicans have released this morning. There's plenty in the plan for liberals to hate, moderates to doubt, and conservatives to question. But you do have to respect it. As my colleague David Brooks writes today, it is "the most comprehensive and most courageous budget reform proposal any of us have seen in our lifetimes." It puts flesh on the bones of the standard-issue conservative pledge to limit government's growth, and it does so not with evasive pledges on process (like the risible idea of a balanced budget amendment) or dishonest suggestions that the deficit can be erased by defunding N.P.R. and slashing foreign aid, but by attacking entitlement spending deeply and directly. George W. Bush touched the third rail of American politics with his Social Security gambit, and lived to regret it. With their proposal to transform Medicare from an open-ended entitlement to a system that provides support for seniors' premiums, Ryan and the Republicans are reaching out and grabbing it with both hands. In the process, they are being brutally honest with the American people, in ways that the Obama White House has repeatedly refused to be, about the scale of the deficit challenge and the scope of the reforms needed to address it.

Dogged efforts by the composer Joseph Bertolozzi to turn the Eiffel Tower into one big musical instrument are paying off. Mr. Bertolozzi, who has created a piece of music by harvesting percussive sounds from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Mid-Hudson Bridge near Poughkeepsie, N.Y., said he recently received approval from the Eiffel Tower Operating Company (the Société d’Exploitation de la Tour Eiffel) to record samples from the tower. The samples would then be assembled into a piece of music, with the ultimate goal of performing it live on the tower itself. Mr. Bertolozzi traveled to Paris in the fall to present his project, and he received a letter of approval last month. The tower operating company said it was open to the idea of a live concert but was making no promises. Now, Mr. Bertolozzi said, all he has to do is raise the money. He said his aim was to have performances in 2014, the tower’s 125th anniversary.

The current fads for artisanal liquor, louche bars and everything ‘‘Mad Men’’ must have inspired ‘‘Cocktail Culture: Ritual and Invention in American Fashion, 1920-1980,’’ an exhibition that opens Friday (and continues through July) at the Museum of Art at the Rhode Island School of Design. It features more than 220 artifacts, including a Dansk ice bucket, a Norman Bel Geddes soda siphon, Paco Rabanne purses and lots of little black dresses (as well as the red one shown below, by Norman Norell). The show begins in the 1920s, when American cocktail culture was mostly confined to the home, and the French, with their beaded cocktail dresses and René Lalique Art Deco glass, set the standard for a night on the town. But the most durable pieces, the ones that you’d still want to break out for guests today, date from the 1950s, when every hour was happy hour and cocktail design was strained through a Modernist sieve. Consider Donald Colflesh’s 1959 silver-plated pitcher for Gorham (below), whose sleek form seems to respond only to one request, essential and elegant: martini, straight up.

This week A. O. Scott looks back at “The French Connection. The 1971 film follows the New York City police detective Popeye Doyle (Gene Hackman) as he goes after Brooklyn drug dealers and uncovers an international drug ring. “The French Connection” was based on a real-life case that the director, William Friedkin, “stripped down and also opened up,” Mr. Scott said. “He focuses on the details of police work and puts together car chases that have become the stuff of cinematic legend.” Have you seen “The French Connection?” Please share your thoughts.

Jürgen Mayer H. has been on a roll. Ever since winning the prestigious Audi Urban Future Award last fall, the 45-year-old architect — who is based in Berlin and who is known for his sometimes challenging experiments (both visually and technologically) with shape and color — is racking up one plum commission after the other. There is the inauguration of a new airport in Mestia, Georgia (the country, not the state); a special line of asymmetrical eyewear (looks better than it sounds); and last week, after almost seven years of planning and construction and much political wrangling, the opening of his biggest project to date, the Metropol Parasol, a 150,000-square-foot mushroom-shaped, mixed-use public plaza in the heart of Seville, Spain. Made of polyurethane-coated timber, it successfully marries an archaeological site with a farmers’ market, multiple bars and restaurants, and a terrace with breathtaking views of the Andalusian capital.

Like Atrios, I am not looking forward to this. It’s going to be just like the Social Security fight, only worse: once again, Very Serious People will pretend not to notice that the Republican plan is a giant game of bait-and-switch, dismantling a key piece of the social safety net in favor of a privatized system, claiming that this is necessary to save money, but never acknowledging that privatization in itself actually costs money. And we’ll have endless obfuscation, both-sides-have-a-point reporting that misses the key point, which is that the putative savings come entirely from benefit cuts somewhere in the distant future that would, in all likelihood, never actually materialize. (What do you think will happen when retirees in 2025 discover that their Medicare vouchers aren’t enough to buy insurance?)

3:50 p.m. | Updated The new AMC series, ''The Killing,'' got off to a grim start on Sunday for the homicide detective Sarah Linden and Rosie Larsen, the student whose murder prompts its story. But it was a bright start for the cable network: AMC said on Monday that ''The Killing'' was watched by 2.7 million total viewers for its two-hour debut, making it the network's second-most-watched premiere for an original series, behind its horror drama ''The Walking Dead,'' which was consumed by 5.3 million viewers when it started in October. That's good news for ''The Killing,'' adapted from the Danish series ''Forbrydelsen,'' and for the network, given that AMC has some time to fill before rolling out its next batch of original programming: a fourth season of ''Breaking Bad'' isn't due until the summer, while a second season of ''The Walking Dead'' and a new series, ''Hell on Wheels,'' are likely to arrive in the fall. And a fifth cycle of ''Mad Men'' -- lest we remind you -- isn't coming until next year.

SPORTS An article on Monday about the Knicks' clinching an N.B.A. playoff berth for the first time in seven seasons misstated the number of coaches the team has cycled through since its last playoff victory, in 2001. It is seven, not eight.

SHANGHAI -- A triptych oil painting by Zhang Xiaogang sold for $10.1 million on Sunday at a Sotheby's auction in Hong Kong. The sale broke the record for a piece by a living Chinese artist, and was the latest sign of China's phenomenal ascent in the global art market. Mr. Zhang, who is 52 and based in Beijing, is now among a handful of living artists to have a work sell for more than $10 million. Less than a decade ago, many of his works were selling for $60,000 or less. He joins a group that includes Lucian Freud, Damien Hirst, Jasper Johns, Jeff Koons, Takashi Murakami and Gerhard Richter, according to Artprice.com.

TURKELTAUB--Cindy. The leadership and staff of Continuum Cancer Centers of New York (CCCNY) and the Department of Social Work at Beth Israel Medical Center acknowledge with deep sadness the passing of our beloved friend and colleague, Cindy Turkeltaub, Coordinator of Social Work Services for the Beth Israel Cancer Center. Throughout her award-winning, 22-year career, Cindy worked tirelessly to provide important supportive services to our cancer patients and their families. In particular, her efforts to advance early diagnosis among women in the Orthodox Jewish community made her a trustworthy figure for those often too fearful to come for screening mammograms. To Cindy's devoted husband, Robert, the entire Turkeltaub family and all of her loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Harris M. Nagler, MD, President Beth Israel Louis B. Harrison, MD Physician-in-Chief, CCCNY and Chairman, Charles & Bernice Blitman Dept. of Radiation Oncology Fran Silverman, Director Dept. of Social Work and Home Care Services Susan Gold, Corporate Vice President for Cancer Services, Continuum

Pfizer said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its Capsugel unit, which makes a variety of capsules for drugs, to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company for $2.375 billion in cash. Capsugel was acquired by Pfizer as part of its $90 billion acquisition of Warner-Lambert in 2000. The unit manufactured more than 180 billion hard capsules last year and generated about $750 million in revenue.

More people watched the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament through Saturday's Final Four than in any year since 2005, which makes sense. For the first time, four networks -- CBS, TNT, TBS and truTV -- have been carrying the tournament, instead of just CBS, as a result of a new CBS-Turner deal that goes through 2024. Through Saturday, an average 9.9 million viewers watched each game, up from 9 million last year and the best in six years. The Final Four averaged 15.4 million viewers, tying last year for the best since 2005, according to Nielsen. Connecticut's victory over Kentucky was seen by 16.7 million viewers.

ASSAEL--Salvador J.,on April 1, 2011 passed away peacefully after a brief illness. Born in 1923, Salvador fled Italy with his family in 1938, first to Paris, then to Portugal, where they boarded a ship to Cuba. The family lived in Havana until the communist revolution in 1957, when they moved via Miami to New York where they continued their diamond and jewelry business. A World War II veteran, as a member of Cannon Company, 311th infantry Regiment, 78th Infantry Division, he participated, endured and survived the Battle of the Bulge, December, 16th, 1944 January 25, 1945, The U.S. campaign in Africa, and the Battle of Remagen in March 17-25, 1945. He received the Purple Heart and other medals for distinguished service from the U.S. Government. 1949 Mr. Assael began trading in left over U.S. Army watches with Japan. He was paid in pearls, which is how he started the pearl business. In 1972 he took over the business from his family, and founded Assael International. In 1973, he became a producer of the Tahitian Black pearls together with Frenchman, Jean Claude Brouillet in French Polynesia. Today Assael International is one of the leading pearl Houses in the world. In June 1998, he became a Chevalier of the Order of Tahiti Nui. He received the GIA League of Honor Sovereign in 1996 and 1998. Mr. Assael was a founding member of the South Sea Pearl Consortium. Mr. Assael was involved in many charities. In 1993 he purchased land for the founding of Temple Dorette Assael in Papeete, Tahiti, the only Sephardic Synagogue in the South Pacific. He gave the only Sephardic exhibit at the Jewish Museum in New York; built the Azata Library in Beer Sheba, Israel; donated a wing of the Sephardic Home's Adult Health Care Center in Brooklyn, New York; donated the Atrium of the GIA World Headquarters in Carlsbad, California and donated a room at "Our House" Hospice in Los Angeles, California. Mr. Assael is mourned by his wife, Christina Lang Assael, his children, Sophia and Robert Lang Assael, and Arlette Assael and his loyal staff Alex Rodrigues, Elisabetta Golonko and Yaneli Gusman. Our sincere thank you to Doctor Ralph Gibson, his dedicated nurses, Moira Turck, Noreen Curran, Mary Ford, Pauline Gilroy, Margaret Gaine, Aneta Konopka and his trainer, Job Becerra. Services will be held on Sunday, April 3rd, at 12 Noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York, NY 10023. Phone: 212-362-6600. Shiva will be held at 485 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10022 on Monday and Tuesday from 2pm to 9pm.

VAN DE BOVENKAMP--Sue Erpf, noted art and environmental philanthropist and president of the Armand G. Erpf charitable foundation, died peacefully April 2nd in her Park Avenue apartment at the age of 82. Born on October 16, 1928 in New York, she attended Cooper Union Art School, then moved to Rome, where she painted portraits, modeled for the fashion house of Valentino and acted in films such as La Dolce Vita. Upon her return to the U.S., she met and married Armand G. Erpf, the late pioneering New York financier and advisor to U.S. presidents. A resident of the Upper East Side for over forty years, Mrs. Erpf Van de Bovenkamp was an avid supporter of New York City museums and cultural institutions such as the Whitney, The New York Public Library and The Museum of Modern Art. She was also an avid world traveller, antiques collector and nature advocate, with a great amount of her life spent at her beloved home in the Catskills. She was a driving force of the Catskill Center for Conservation and Development, the World Wildlife Fund and the Wildlife Conservation Society. She is survived by her daughter, Cornelia Erpf-Forsman of New York, her son, Armand Bartholomew Erpf of New York, and five grandchildren. For funeral services information, please email services@erpf.net.

LOWENBERG--William J. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the death of its Vice Chairman Emeritus William J. Lowenberg. A survivor of Auschwitz and Dachau, he was a "founding father" of the Museum and instrumental in its creation. Appointed by President Reagan to the Museum's governing board in 1983, Mr. Lowenberg was named Vice Chairman in 1986 and served through the Museum's opening in 1993. He was deeply committed to the cause of Holocaust remembrance and education, and a highly respected community leader with a long history of involvement in civic and Jewish organizations. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife Fern, their children, David (Jacqueline), and Susan (Joyce), their grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. Tom A. Bernstein, Chairman Joshua B. Bolten, Vice Chairman Sara J. Bloomfield, Director United States Holocaust Memorial Museum

To the Editor: In ''Do You Have Free Will? Yes, It's the Only Choice'' (Findings, March 22), John Tierney presents us with a stark choice: Do we have free will or are we utterly determined? I would offer a third alternative. Our wills are not entirely free, but are constrained, both by nature's laws and by the choices that we and others make. If it weren't for constrained will, I'd be starting a second career at first base for the Houston Astros, and I would flap my arms and fly to intercept would-be home runs.

As reports continue to swirl about an impending departure from her anchor position at CBS News, Katie Couric is to embark Tuesday morning on a long-planned trip to Iraq, where she will report on the military and political situation eight years after Baghdad fell to invading American forces. The trip, which CBS is expected to announce Tuesday, comes even as CBS and representatives of Ms. Couric repeat their recent denials of an imminent resolution of her current status at the network. Her contract with CBS ends June 4.

Newly discovered 1840s murals of inlets, willows, lighthouses and sailing ships are being extricated this week from a house in East Baldwin, Me., for transfer to the Rufus Porter Museum and Cultural Heritage Center in nearby Bridgton. The owners have donated three roomfuls of the scenery, painted by the muralist Rufus Porter's nephew Jonathan Poor, along with underlying layers of plaster and lath, fireplace mantels and an entire staircase. The museum is raising $60,000 for the dismantling work, by the salvager David Ottinger, and is renovating an 1830s house that will accommodate the acquisition. Poor died in his early 40s, soon after completing the work for a local physician, perhaps because mural painting was a hazardous profession. ''My supposition is that all the materials they worked with were poisonous,'' Julie Lindberg, the Porter museum's curator, said. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

GOLDSTEIN--Ann Lubin. The Pace University community extends our heartfelt sympathy at the passing of our friend and generous benefactor, Ann Lubin Goldstein. Together, Ann and her husband Al spent three decades improving the lives of students at Pace and beyond. During their long affiliation with Pace, they have established the School of Law Goldstein Family Scholarship and the Goldstein Fund at the Lubin School of Business. On Pace's Pleasantville campus both the Goldstein Academic Center and The Ann and Alfred Goldstein Health and Fitness Recreation Center are named in their honor. They have been regular and generous supporters of a variety of special projects and events at Pace. Ann was the daughter of the late Joseph Isaac Lubin, who, in appreciation for his education at Pace, became a Trustee of the University. In return for his generosity and years of service to Pace, the business school was renamed the Lubin School of Business. Ann will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Ann's husband Al and her family. Aniello Bianco, Chair, Pace University Board of Trustees Stephen J. Friedman, President, Pace University

Scharf, President Josh S. Weston, Honorary Chairman Robert Kaswell, Chairman Rabbi Ronald Gray, Exec. V. P.

MATTANA--Geoffrey, 83, on April 3. Loving husband of Pauline, beloved father of Stuart, David and Jonny and grandfather of Joshua, Maxine, Zoe and Phoebe. Attended the City of London School and Marlborough College before winning a scholarship to Cambridge University, England. Immigrated to America in the late 1950's to pursue a career as a commodity trader. Was a member of all the New York exchanges and held numerous leadership positions. Patron and lover of the cultural and classical arts. Loved to travel, play golf and play bridge. Great joke and story teller. Admired by all he knew for his kindness, generosity and positive outlook on life.

FRONT PAGE An article on Saturday about the jobs report for March misstated a statistic from a Brookings Institution analysis of the report. Real earnings have fallen 1.1 percent since last October, not ''in the last year.'' (Before October, as the analysis noted, real earnings were trending slowly upward.)

Bound by a mutual love for animated animals -- and profits -- Jeffrey Katzenberg, chief executive of DreamWorks Animation SKG, has joined Zynga's board, the company announced Monday. Mr. Katzenberg, below, whose production company is behind hits like ''Shrek'' and ''Kung Fu Panda,'' is joining a board that includes Zynga's chief executive, Mark Pincus; its executive vice president, Owen Van Natta; LinkedIn's founder, Reid Hoffman; a Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers partner, Bing Gordon; and Brad Feld, a managing director at the Foundry Group. EVELYN M. RUSLI TWO FUNDS CLOSING The venture capital firm Insight Venture Partners announced on Monday that it was closing two new funds, which together represent $2 billion in new commitments. The firm said about $1.5 billion of the new capital would go to Insight Venture Partners VII, focusing on software and Internet services. The second fund, Insight Venture Partners Coinvestment Fund II, holding $450 million in commitments, will pursue large deals. EVELYN M. RUSLI
GRIEVE--Marvin M. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Marvin M. Grieve. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family.

WEIL--Kenneth Milton, passed away at the age of 87. A resident of Stamford, CT, for 39 years, he died in serenity in Stamford Hospital surrounded by his loving wife son and caregiver after living with Parkinson's Disease for 19 years. He was a graduate of Phillips Academy in Exeter, NH and Yale University class of 45W. He was a veteran of the second World War, United States Navy. He served as a communications officer during the invasion of Okinawa, retiring with the rank of lieutenant JG. After the war he spent many years as a stock broker in New York and retired as a senior vice-president from Smith Barney in 2000. He is survived by his loving wife Susan Granat Weil and son Andrew Kenneth Weil and his wife, Jeannette Aniceto Weil, his mother-in-law, his brother-in-law and his spouse and his long time caregivers. Funeral services will be held at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford on Wednesday, April 6 at 10am. Burial will be private. Calling hours will be from 4 to 7pm on Tuesday at the funeral home. For those who wish, memorial contributions may be sent to: The Parkinson's Disease Foundation, Attn: Robin Elliott, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, NY 10018.

The Academy of Country Music Awards led Sunday night in the ratings for CBS, as an average of 13 million viewers tuned in to the award show broadcast from 8 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. CBS won the night over all, drawing 10.3 million to lead the 7 p.m. time slot as well with ''60 Minutes.'' ABC placed a solid second, as 9.7 million watched ''Secret Millionaire'' at 8, followed by ''Desperate Housewives'' (8.8 million) and ''Body of Proof'' (8.4 million) at 9 and 10. NBC ranked third, with 8.5 million for ''The Celebrity Apprentice'' from 9 to 11 but lower ratings for ''Dateline'' at 7 (5.2 million) and ''America's Next Great Restaurant'' at 8 (3.9 million). Fox was fourth with mostly reruns of its animated comedy lineup. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Security experts said Monday that millions of people were at increased risk of e-mail swindles after a giant security breach at an online marketing firm. The breach exposed the names and e-mail addresses of customers of some of the nation's largest companies, including JPMorgan Chase, Citibank, Target and Walgreens.
5:37 p.m. | Updated The Belgian chemical company Solvay said on Monday that it had agreed to buy Rhodia of France for $4.8 billion, gaining a greater exposure to high-growth emerging markets.

10 P.M. (Bravo) PREGNANT IN HEELS Rosie Pope (right, with a client) is a designer of maternity fashions who runs MomPrep, a company on the Upper East Side of Manhattan that guides expectant mothers through preparations for their newborns, from hiring the perfect nanny, to breastfeeding and promoting infant development to ''baby fingers sign language class.'' But her advice doesn't stop with the basics, according to this new reality series, in which Ms. Pope and her team help two clients each episode tackle subjects like planning a shotgun wedding, designing a rock 'n' roll nursery, leading a ''Daddy boot camp'' and even providing the how-to for entering a baby into the lists of British aristocracy. 8 P.M. YEMEN Security forces and plainclothes government supporters opened fire on tens of thousands of protesters in the city of Taiz, killing at least 12 people. In the western port city of Al Hudaydah, two protesters were shot and killed by plainclothes government supporters. The violence broke out amid signs that the United States had concluded that President Ali Abdullah Saleh should be eased from office. LIBYA A senior rebel leader sharply criticized NATO for bureaucratic delays that he said were putting civilians' lives at risk and complicating rebel efforts to fight the forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The official, Ali al-Essawi, made his remarks as the rebels' disorganized fight again stalled in the eastern town of Brega.

DIMOND--James Rex, loving husband of Ellen Leddy-Dimond, passed away on March 22. Rex's favorite passtime was painting, and now he is painting brilliant night time stars. At thirteen, Rex was knocked out by polio. Determined to live a strong and purposeful life, he worked hard to build himself up, later becoming a medic and lieutenant in the 82nd Airborne. Completing the mandatory eleven paratrooper jumps, he went on to complete 23 jumps. He jokingly fantasized about writing a book called "From Polio to Paratrooper". After leaving the Airborne, he graduated from Cornell University with a degree in horticulture and floriculture. Rex was an avid painter and he had shows in major galleries. Rex was a James Joyce scholar and theater buff. His friends will recall his big heart, love for animals and his unique sense of humor. Over the past twenty years, he lived out his passion as a horticulturist, being surrounded by nature working for the New York City Parks Department. A few years ago, however, he developed Post Polio Syndrome. Often in pain, he never complained. He will be missed deeply by family, and friends and his beloved Dachshunds, Alexandria and Dylan. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Jonas Salk Foundation for Polio Research. Memorial services will be held on Tuesday, April 12 at 5pm. St. Peter's Church, 22 Barclay St. in Lower Manhattan (Between Church and Barclay St.).

Meet Zach Anner, a 26-year-old filmmaker from Austin, Tex., who just won his own television show on Oprah Winfrey's new network. He's handsome, smart and funny - oh, and he gets around in a wheelchair. Mr. Anner has cerebral palsy, ''the sexiest of the palsies,'' as he puts it in his audition video. That line, along with a spoof of a failed TV show about yoga, has won him legions of online fans. (''This isn't yoga,'' he tells the camera as he writhes on the floor. ''I'm just putting on pants.'')

POHS--Arnold C. Arnold C. Pohs, former CEO of CommNet Cellular, died at age 82 on April 2, in Scottsdale, AZ. An early pioneer in the wireless industry, Arnold led CommNet Cellular in the 1980s and 90s, and the company quickly became the premier rural wireless telecommunications provider in the US. Arnold was the first chairman of the Cellular Telecommunications and Internet Association (CTIA) Wireless Foundation and he also served as chairman of the CTIA. During his tenure, he received the 1994/95 President's Award and the 1999 Industry Achievement Award for outstanding leadership, and the Public Relations Society of America named him CEO of the Year in 1996. Arnold served as a member of the executive board of directors of the Barbara Davis Foundation for Childhood Diabetes, and he was a member of the Children's Hospital Foundation executive board, and the American Diabetes Association Colorado Chapter board of directors. Arnold is survived by his beloved wife of 60 years, Constance, who he met as a student at the University of Michigan. A University of Michigan graduate, his love for the Michigan Wolverines was only surpassed by his love for the New York Yankees; Arnold was an avid New York Yankees fan his entire life. Arnold is also survived by his daughter, Wendi Pohs, her husband, Mike Kilgore, his son Glenn Pohs, wife Jill Degen Pohs, and by his grandchildren, Meghan Taevs, Erin Chapman, and Lara, Jamie, and Jacob Pohs. Services will be held at Messinger Pinnacle Peak Mortuary 8555 E. Pinnacle Peak Road, Scottsdale, Arizona, on Wednesday, April 6 at 11am. Donations can be made to the Children's Diabetes Foundation of Denver (www.childrensdiabetes foundation.org/support/ index.html) or the American Cancer Society: www.cancer.org/involved/ donate) in lieu of flowers.

TUFFIELD--Mildred P.,passed away on April 2, 2011. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister and aunt. Milly will be remembered for her fierce intelligence, spirit and love of family. Services 12:30pm, Thursday, April 7 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY.

A federal judge scolded Roger Clemens and his former personal trainer Monday for speaking to the news media about Clemens's pending perjury trial and reminded all parties that they were not to comment publicly about the case. United States District Court Judge Reggie B. Walton said that he did not think Clemens and Brian McNamee, the former trainer, committed clear violations of his instructions, but said, ''These statements cannot go unaddressed out of concern that the public discussion of this case by these individuals will escalate even further.'' Walton said he would not allow the case ''to be tried in the media.'' Clemens, who is suspected of lying to Congress about his steroid use, spoke about the case last week to ESPN Radio, saying that he was looking forward to the trial because it would give him a chance to clear his name. McNamee also gave a radio interview last week in which he defended his decision to speak to Congressional investigators about what he claims is Clemens's steroid use. Clemens has been charged with three counts of making false statements, two counts of perjury and one count of obstruction of Congress. His trial is scheduled to begin in July.

AKIN--Barbara, 91, on March 24, 2011. Retired from U.S. Trust Co. Long time vestrywoman, Church of the Ascension. Founding board member "Voices of Ascension" choral music group. Equally at ease monitoring a homeless shelter or student performances at the Metropolitan Opera. Scrupulous fiduciary. Loving aunt. Loyal friend. Memorial: 3pm, Saturday, April 9, Ascension Church, Fifth Ave. and 10th St. Donations to Voices of Ascension, 12 W. 11th St., New York City 10011.

A filmmaker and a rock group who have never been shy about expressing themselves will be represented in new offerings at the Tribeca Film Festival, the festival's organizers announced on Monday. ''Detachment,'' a new feature from Tony Kaye, the director of ''American History X,'' will make its debut as part of the festival's narrative program. The film, which stars Adrien Brody and features Christina Hendricks, Lucy Liu, James Caan, Marcia Gay Harden, Blythe Danner, Tim Blake Nelson, William Petersen and Bryan Cranston, chronicles a substitute teacher at a failing public school whose life is altered by his interactions with a student, another teacher and young runaway.

GRIEVE--Marvin M. Died on April 2 at his home in Calverton, NY at age 89. Born in New York City on July 22, 1921, Marvin spent his early years in Brooklyn and Manhattan. He joined the Army Air Corps in 1942, serving as a B-26 pilot in North Africa and Italy. He flew 60 bombing missions and was shot down twice, emerging without a scratch. After the war he lived in Paris for a year and then worked in his father's picture framing and antiques business, before starting his career in television program syndication in the early 1950's. In 1969 Marvin founded MG films, focusing on children's programming, and in 1980 he partnered with Richard Perin forming MG/Perin, producing and distributing syndicated TV programs. After his retirement he took great pride in helping build homes on the east end of Long Island with Habitat for Humanity. Marvin loved life and lived his to the fullest. Predeceased by his sister Marjorie, Marvin is survived by his beloved wife of 35 years, Holly. He will be fondly remembered by his sister-in-law Valorie Dawson, and by the many friends of all ages whose lives he touched. A private memorial service will take place in the near future.

About a year ago, there was a girl in my Spanish class who was a foreign exchange student from Santiago, Chile. She gave a brief PowerPoint presentation about her life back home, replete with pictures of mountain ranges and colonial architecture. During the Q. and A. session, one student asked, ''How much is a year of college tuition there?'' ''About $3,000,'' she estimated. The class laughed. ''What?'' she asked, bewildered. ''Is it less expensive here?''

TEPPER--Martin, died on March 31, 2011. Survived by his wife Cathe, brother Jerrold, daughters Arielle and Abby, son-in-law Ian, and grandchildren Izzy, Jonah and Sasha. First and foremost, he was a loving husband, father and grandfather--nothing brought a bigger smile to his face than the sight of one of his kids or grand kids. Martin spent the majority of his career in real estate turning nothing into something by renovating coops in the New York City area. With a law degree from Rutgers and an MBA from The Wharton School of Business, it was no doubt that Martin brought with him some serious bargaining skills when working out real estate deals. In 2001, after moving to Florida Martin continually looked for real estate opportunities, but what he loved most was spending time with Abby and doing the crossword puzzles with Cathe and trying to figure out how to skype with his grandkids in New York City. He will be sorely missed by us all. A private funeral service will be held in Florida.

COLLINS--J. Anthony, age 71, of Old Saybrook, CT died peacefully at home on April 2 attended by his adoring wife, Alva Greenberg, after a 17 month battle with brain cancer. An international business executive in the printing and publishing fields, he founded and led many successful companies, most recently Colortone and Brook and Whittle both of North Branford. Born in Preswich, England, Anthony graduated from the University of Manchester with a degree in Printing and Technology. He moved to Dublin in 1964 and to Connecticut in 1982. Anthony's many friends remember him as an incomparable host and raconteur. His lifelong passion for sailing included annual voyages on his Hinckley between Newport and Tortola as well as on a trans-Atlantic crossing in 1994. Though told that he would only survive a diagnosis of stage 4 Glioblastoma for six to welve months, at eight months Anthony was climbing a 3,200 foot mountain and at eleven months he had just returned from a trip to Turkey. He may not have won the war against this disease, but he came out on top of most of the skirmishes with his jacket and kerchief unsullied. In addition to his wife, Alva, he is survived by his four children, Jonathan, Andrew, Matthew and Sarah and their spouses; his nine grandchildren, his mother Anne Collins and sister Susan Absalom, both of Lithum St. Anne's, England, his former wife Fionuala Collins of Dublin and three step-children Ben, William and Gwyn Gahagan. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, April 7, 11am at the Norma Terris Theater in Chester, CT. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Outreach to Haiti, 199 Broadway, Norwich, CT 06360. Fulton-Theroux Funeral Home Old Lyme is handling the services. Please visit www.fultontherouxoldlyme. com for photos, tributes and service information.

Sbarro, the private-equity-owned pizza chain, filed for bankruptcy on Monday as it looked to cut its debt and restructure its balance sheet. The restructuring, according to a court filing, will allow Sbarro to reduce its debt by $195 million, or more than half. The company will also get a $30 million capital infusion.

Every day in the Manhattan Criminal Courthouse, convicted murderers are sentenced to hard time for taking the lives of people who never asked to die. I noticed on Deadline Hollywood Tuesday night that R.J. Cutler, the director of “The September Issue,” has signed to make a feature film of Lee Tulloch’s “Fabulous Nobodies,” a satiric novel set in the New York of the late ’80s, when fashion and clubbing were the main events. Ms. Tulloch, who has lived between Australia and New York, went on to write other books, but “Fabulous Nobodies” seemed to strike a chord with people who were in New York (or wanted to be) at that time. More interesting to me is how difficult it has been for a filmmaker to capture the fashion scene. What are the great fashion films? The producers for the “Fabulous Nobodies” adaptation are Julie Anne Quay, the former executive editor of V magazine; Gail Lyon (“Erin Brockovich”); and Mr. Cutler.

Some researchers subscribe to what is known as the parasite stress hypothesis. This holds that over the course of evolution the body faced a trade-off between maximizing intelligence and maximizing the power of the immune system. To test this Christopher Eppig, Corey Fincher and Randy Thornhill compared the IQ levels and disease stress in various American states. Sure enough, states where people have to guard against more infectious diseases (presumably because of climate) had lower average IQs. This is one of those studies where it is important to remember that correlation is not causation. Still, the researchers did find that after controlling for education and wealth, disease stress was the best predictor of state IQ.

Abrams is not a big fan of disclosing the plot details of new films he’s directing (see “Super 8″) or producing (“Cloverfield”) before they’ve been released, so don’t expect any spoilers — or even a title — for a new novel on which he’ll be collaborating. The publisher Little, Brown said on Wednesday that it had acquired a book that Mr. Abrams, the director of “Star Trek” and a creator of the television series “Lost,” “Alias” and “Felicity,” had conceived and will be written by Doug Dorst, the author of the supernatural crime novel “Alive in Necropolis.” A release from the publisher happily cited Mr. Abrams’s film and television credits and mentioned that Mr. Dorst is a graduate of the Iowa Writers’ Workshop and a three-time “Jeopardy!” champion. And Mr. Abrams said in a statement that “Doug is a genius,” adding that he “could not be more excited to collaborate with him on this completely original project.” Just what that project is neither Mr. Abrams nor Little, Brown is indicating, except to say that it is planned for a fall 2012 release on the Mulholland Books imprint. Watch for further clues as soon as we know where to find them.

A new installment of “NCIS” topped the ratings on Tuesday night as 18.8 million viewers watched the show on CBS at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen estimates. CBS led the night over all despite broadcasting a rerun of “NCIS: Los Angeles” (12.6 million) at 9 p.m. opposite ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” results episode (15.6 million). ABC’s new series “Body of Proof” won at 10 p.m. with 11.1 million viewers, outperforming “The Good Wife” on CBS (10.6 million) and “Parenthood” on NBC (4.7 million). ABC’s “No Ordinary Family” (5.7 million) lagged behind the first half of NBC’s “Biggest Loser,” which averaged 7.3 million viewers from 8 to 10. NBC ranked third for the night, behind CBS and ABC but ahead of repeats on Fox.

When Don Hill, who opened his eponymous downtown club in 1993 (and before that, the Cat Club and Kenny’s Castaways), died last Thursday, social media were buzzing with words of remembrance. Many people knew him as the man at the end of the bar, drinking tequila and Heineken, occasionally playing video games. “We did parties last month for the First Precinct and the Hells Angels,” said Paul Sevigny, who, along with Nur Khan, began working with Hill about seven months ago to bring some new blood to the place. “That’s how universally loved he was.” Loved, yes, but also a mystery even to those who knew him — details about his family and childhood remain fuzzy. “You’d go in there with someone who’d never been and you’d be like, ‘Oh, there’s Don!’ And people would be like, ‘There’s actually a Don Hill?’” said the makeup artist Mike Potter. “People didn’t know he was a real person.” Like many, Potter, a club regular in the ’90s, has Don Hill’s to thank for his career: After John Cameron Mitchell recognized him from the SqueezeBox party, the two became friendly, which led to Potter doing the makeup for “Hedwig and the Angry Inch.” Brendan Manning, of the New York City chapter of the Hells Angels, points out that Hill, whose memorial service is tonight at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in NoLIta, had booked — for $200 a week — “a guy named Bruce Springsteen,” back in the Kenny’s Castaways days. The Moment asked a few who knew Hill personally to tell us about him (in more than 140 characters).

My company, TerraCycle, has a very unusual business model. We turn the world’s waste into new products. We collect non-recyclable waste, some straight from manufacturers and some from schools, charities and other community groups, and we partner with other manufacturers to recycle or “upcycle” that material into new products — like plastic lumber from juice pouches and shower curtains from sewn-together granola wrappers. GOLDSTEIN--Ann Lubin. The Trustees of Syracuse University and Chancellor Nancy Cantor, on behalf of the entire Syracuse community, mourn the loss of our friend and esteemed alumna Ann Lubin Goldstein. Together with her husband Al, the Goldsteins were major benefactors of the University over many decades. Among the many buildings named in their honor are the Ann and Alfred Goldstein Auditorium, the Ann and Alfred Goldstein Student Center, South Campus, the Goldstein Alumni and Faculty Center, the Joseph I. Lubin School of Accounting and the Joseph I. Lubin Floor in the Whitman School of Management Building. Ann was the first of three generations to attend Syracuse. She was followed by her daughter, SU Trustee Wendy Cohen, as well as sons, Steven and Richard, and grandchildren, Heather and Zachary. Ann is the daughter of Joseph I. Lubin who was a lifetime Trustee of SU and generous supporter of the University. Among his many contributions was the donation of 11 East 61st Street, now called "Lubin House", expressly for SU to establish a greater presence in the New York metropolitan area. Our deepest condolences go out to Al and the entire family.

A former Italian television producer who has achieved notoriety by claiming to dig up the bones of cultural figures like Caravaggio and Dante has set his sights on the woman believed to be the model for the Mona Lisa, The Associated Press reported. Tradition holds that the da Vinci painting is a portrait of Lisa Gherardini, wife of a Florentine cloth merchant named Francesco del Giocondo; it is believed that he commissioned it, but for some reason Leonardo did not deliver it to him. Several years ago, an amateur historian discovered a death certificate showing that Gherardini was buried at a convent in central Florence. Now the former producer, Silvano Vinceti, who runs a private organization called the National Committee for the Promotion of Historic and Cultural Heritage, has announced plans to unearth Gherardini's remains.

INSIDE THE TIMES A capsule summary on March 27 about Ana Matosantos, California's youngest budget director, misidentified her political party affiliation. Ms. Matosantos is a Democrat, not a Republican.

Molly Bloom's wandering soliloquy in James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' was the inspiration for ''The Sensual World,'' the title song from Kate Bush's 1989 album, but at the time the Joyce estate would not give her approval to use the words in her lyrics. Now Ms. Bush has received the long-awaited permission to use the text, and she has rerecorded the song, which she renamed ''Flower of the Mountain,'' according to BBC News. Ms. Bush said she was ''delighted'' to have the chance ''to fulfill the original concept.'' The new track will be released in May on ''Director's Cut,'' her first new album in six years. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

CHIANG MAI, Thailand -- William Young, a missionary's son who mixed evangelical zeal with covert missions for the C.I.A. in Southeast Asia and who helped organize the ''secret war '' in Laos for the United States during the Vietnam War, died on Friday at his home here in northern Thailand. He was 76. The Thai police said he apparently killed himself. Mr. Young was found dead from a gunshot wound, a handgun next to his right hand and a crucifix in his left, the police said. He had been suffering from emphysema and numerous other ailments, his friends said.

Sean Hayes, the ''Will and Grace'' star, Tony Awards show host and Tony-nominated performer for last year's revival of ''Promises, Promises,'' is set to play Larry, the frizzy-haired, fiddle-playing member of the Three Stooges in a new ''Three Stooges'' movie to be directed by Bobby and Peter Farrelly (''There's Something About Mary,'' ''Hall Pass''). The Hollywood Reporter said that Mr. Hayes will join Will Sasso, of ''MAD TV'' and ''$#*! My Dad Says,'' who is set to play the follicularly deficient Curly Howard. The movie is not a biographical film and will instead feature a slapstick trio in new comedy sketches based on the original Stooges. It has already taken a few eye gouges en route to the big screen: at one time, the planned cast included Sean Penn as Larry, Jim Carrey as Curly and Benicio Del Toro as Moe, but that fell apart like a high-society pie dinner after Mr. Penn withdrew from the project. A new actor to play Moe and a release date for ''The Three Stooges'' ain't yet soiten (and they haven't been determined either). This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

BUSINESS DAY An article on Monday about Radio Caroline, a onetime pirate station now seeking an AM designation in Britain, misstated the name of a political party that has endorsed the effort. It is Plaid Cymru, or Party of Wales -- not the Welsh National Party.

The New York Philharmonic has yet again canceled a proposed trip to Cuba, and this time it may be for keeps. The orchestra was tentatively planning to go in June, but no charter planes big enough to take it were available, said the Philharmonic spokesman, Eric Latzky. In addition, the school year will have ended, making it too difficult to gather children for a planned youth concert, he said. ''I think the Philharmonic may go to Cuba some day but certainly not in the foreseeable future,'' Mr. Latzky said. The Philharmonic was forced to cancel a trip last year after the United States Treasury Department declined to allow orchestra patrons to go along. It later granted a license when the Philharmonic designated the patrons as docents for the educational concert, putting them in the realm of what United States sanctions permit for visitors to Cuba.

In a finding that challenges the conventional wisdom about the risks of some hormones used in menopause, a major government study has found that years after using estrogen-only therapy, certain women had a markedly reduced risk of breast cancer and heart attack. The research, part of the landmark Women's Health Initiative study, is likely to surprise women and their doctors, who for years have heard frightening news about the risks of hormone therapy. But most of those fears are related to the use of a combination of two hormones, estrogen and progestin, which are prescribed to relieve hot flashes and other symptoms of menopause, and have been shown to increase a woman's risk of breast cancer.

Lamar hired the former Texas Tech coach Pat Knight, Bob Knight's son. Knight, 40, was fired after going 50-60 in three seasons at Texas Tech. Connecticut's 53-41 win over Butler in the N.C.A.A. men's championship game Monday on CBS attracted an average of 20.1 million viewers, down by 19 percent from last year's 23.9 million when Duke beat Butler by 2 points in a more compelling game. The tournament -- which was carried for the first time by CBS, TNT, TBS and truTV -- averaged 10.2 million viewers a game, an increase of 7 percent from last year and the best performance since 2005. Meredith Vieira, the co-host of NBC's ''Today'' show, is likely to leave the top-rated morning show this year, two people with knowledge of her deliberations said Tuesday. Ms. Vieira's contract ends in September, and she has made no secret that she dislikes the early morning wake-up calls and the stress of the position. She has not notified NBC of a decision, but is leaning toward leaving, according to the people, who insisted on anonymity to avoid affecting the outcome. If Ms. Vieira, 57, does leave, the news anchor on ''Today,'' Ann Curry, 54, would be a leading contender to replace her.

Mort Sahl may not have wanted his comedy album ''At Sunset'' to be recorded, but it is now headed for a permanent place in the audio archives of the Library of Congress, along with works by Tammy Wynette, Captain Beefheart, Al Green, Steely Dan and De La Soul, as well as one of the earliest recordings of ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game.'' The library plans to announce on Wednesday that among 25 ''culturally, historically or aesthetically significant'' entries that have been added to the National Recording Registry are ''At Sunset,'' the album by Mr. Sahl, above, recorded in 1955 at the Sunset Auditorium in Carmel, Calif., and later withdrawn because it was not authorized. Also being added are recordings of ''Dark Was the Night, Cold Was the Ground'' by Blind Willie Johnson; ''Tipitina'' by Professor Longhair; Henry Mancini's ''Peter Gunn'' theme music; De La Soul's ''3 Feet High and Rising''; and ''Trout Mask Replica'' by Captain Beefheart and His Magic Band. Lest it be accused of skewing too hip, the library has also selected Edward Meeker's 1908 recording of ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game,'' performed with the Edison Orchestra and including the rarely heard second verse, which, says the library, reminds us ''that the song is about a baseball-loving woman.'' The entries were chosen by the librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, and the library's National Recording Preservation Board.

BIGELOW--Edward. The New York City Ballet and the School of American Ballet mourn the passing of our long-time friend and colleague Edward Bigelow. Eddie began his studies at the School in 1941 and went on to dance with several of the early companies created by George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein prior to the formation of New York City Ballet in 1948. He originated roles in works by Balanchine, Robbins and others, including both the Mouse King and Mother Ginger in Balanchine's legendary production of "The Nutcracker." After leaving the stage, Eddie joined the NYCB administration, becoming an indispensable associate to both Balanchine and Kirstein. Throughout his life Eddie was a devoted and dedicated friend and supporter of both NYCB and SAB, and will be deeply missed by generations of artists who so greatly benefited from his unwavering compassion and commitment over the years. All of us extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Carla, family and friends.

SANA, Yemen -- Security forces and armed men in civilian clothes clashed with antigovernment demonstrators in the city of Taiz on Tuesday, opening fire on crowds calling for President Ali Abdullah Saleh to step down, witnesses said. It was the third straight day of violence in Taiz, where more than 10 protesters were killed by gunfire on Monday. Boshra al-Maqtari, one of the protest leaders, said that at least 20 people were wounded by gunfire on Tuesday, but that there had been no deaths.

Dogged efforts by the composer Joseph Bertolozzi to turn the Eiffel Tower into one big musical instrument are paying off. Mr. Bertolozzi, who has created a piece of music by harvesting percussive sounds from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Mid-Hudson Bridge near Poughkeepsie, N.Y., said he recently received approval from the Eiffel Tower Operating Company (the Societe d'Exploitation de la Tour Eiffel) to record samples from the tower. The samples would then be assembled into a piece of music, with the ultimate goal of performing it live on the tower itself. Mr. Bertolozzi traveled to Paris in the fall to present his project, and he received a letter of approval last month. The tower operating company said it was open to the idea of a live concert but was making no promises. Now, Mr. Bertolozzi said, all he has to do is raise the money. He said his aim was to have performances in 2014, the tower's 125th anniversary. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SCHWARTZ--Irving L.,MD. We at The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and longtime colleague, Irving L. Schwartz, MD, the Lamport Distinguished Professor and the first Dean of the Graduate School of Biological Sciences. He was Dean from 1965 to 1980, when he became Dean Emeritus. Under Dr. Schwartz's early leadership, Mount Sinai grew as a center of excellence in translational research. He believed in the "vital interdisciplinary interactions among clinicians, basic scientists, medical students, and graduate students within one institution." Dr. Schwartz was also the first Chair of what is now the Department of Structural and Chemical Biology at Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Director of the Mount Sinai Center for Polypeptide Research. His work evolved from whole animal and organ physiology to molecular science. His studies on peptides ranged from bedside observations, to biochemical mechanisms of action, to the definition of the three-dimensional structure of such molecules in solution and in the crystalline state. After retiring in 1989, Dr. Schwartz continued to actively support the intellectual vitality of the Graduate School. He drew upon his worldwide network of scientific colleagues, inviting them to Mount Sinai as distinguished speakers and guests. The Mount Sinai community extends its condolences to Dr. Schwartz's family and friends. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and Chief Executive Officer, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; and Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs, The Mount Sinai Medical Center.

MUSEUMS A picture caption in the special Museums section on March 17 with an article about plans by the Cunningham Dance Foundation to sell works of art used in productions by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company misidentified, using information from the foundation, a dancer in the Cunningham work ''Minutiae,'' which featured a Robert Rauschenberg work by the same name. FOREIGN An article in some editions on Sunday about a retraction by the leader of a United Nations panel that investigated Israel's invasion of Gaza two years ago misstated a detail about the angry Jewish reaction to the panel's report, which was directed at the leader, Richard Goldstone, a prominent South African jurist. After protesters threatened to picket outside his grandson's bar mitzvah last year, Judge Goldstone said he would not attend; there was no attempt to bar him from the bar mitzvah. (The judge did attend after protesters agreed not to picket.)

WILKENS--Frank Jr.,81, of Osterville, MA, and Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Greenwich, CT died on April 3rd at home surrounded by his loving family. Born July 19, 1929 in Chicago, IL and raised in Hayward, WI, he was the son of the late Imogene and Frank Wilkens. He is survived by his loving wife of 52 years Maureen Murphy Wilkens; son Frank Wilkens III of Putney, VT; son Stephen Wilkens and wife Karen of Palm Beach Gardens, FL and granddaughter Emily; son Daniel Wilkens and wife Sandra of Lake Oswego, OR and grandsons Jakob and Logan; and son David Wilkens and wife Molly Pindell of Stowe, VT and grandchildren Juliette and Soren. In addition, he is survived by his brother James Wilkens and wife Mary-Alice of Titusville, PA, brother Thomas Wilkens and wife Betty of Georgetown, TX, and sister Mary-Susan Bishop of Elletsville, IN. Frank was a 1947 graduate of Hayward High School. He attended Wheaton College, in Wheaton, IL and graduated from the University of Wisconsin at Madison in 1951. He received his MBA from Harvard Business School in 1957. In 1957 he began working as the controller in General Tire's Respro plastics division in Cranston, RI. In 1959 he went to Akron, OH to work for John O'Neil, the son of the founder of General Tire, in their General Investment Group as an investment board member and manager. They were at the forefront of investing profit sharing and pension funds in-house. In 1962 he was transferred to New York and continued to work for General Tire until 1971. He then founded Wilkens and Nanovic, which managed corporate pension funds. He later moved the firm to Greenwich, CT. Visiting hours will be in the John-Lawrence Funeral Home 3778 Falmouth Road, (Rte.28) Marstons Mills, MA on Friday, April 8, 4-7pm. A funeral service will be Saturday, 1pm in the Osterville Methodist Church, Pond St. Osterville, MA. Burial will follow in Marstons Mills Cemetery.

Nicky Dawda rented a nice storefront in Greenwich Village, planning to do some renovations and open a tearoom with the tea expert Kiley Holliday. Simple enough? That was 18 months ago. Now after dealing with city codes, their tearoom, Bosie Tea Parlor, will open on Thursday with about 100 of Ms. Holliday's hand-selected L'Age de The teas in golden canisters on the shelves. She also brews a mighty fine cup. To accompany the teas in the cafe area, in the dark wood bar or to take home, are exquisite pastries made by Damien Herrgott, who worked at Laduree in Paris and Bouley Bakery in New York. And, with some extra time to tweak his restaurant, Mr. Dawda has hired Chris Siversen, the chef and an owner of Maritime Parc in Liberty State Park in New Jersey, as a consultant to work with Mr. Herrgott on the savory side of the menu.

TEPPER--Martin, died on March 31, 2011. Survived by his wife Cathe, brother Jerrold, daughters Arielle and Abby, son-in-law Ian, and grandchildren Izzy, Jonah and Sasha. First and foremost, he was a loving husband, father and grandfather--nothing brought a bigger smile to his face than the sight of one of his kids or grand kids. Martin spent the majority of his career in real estate turning nothing into something by renovating coops in the New York City area. With a law degree from Rutgers and an MBA from The Wharton School of Business, it was no doubt that Martin brought with him some serious bargaining skills when working out real estate deals. In 2001, after moving to Florida Martin continually looked for real estate opportunities, but what he loved most was spending time with Abby and doing the crossword puzzles with Cathe and trying to figure out how to skype with his grandkids in New York City. He will be sorely missed by us all. A private funeral service will be held in Florida.

On April 8, 1861, the same day that President Lincoln notified South Carolina’s governor that he intended to resupply Fort Sumter, ratcheting up the possibility of an armed Southern response, he also met with the governor of Pennsylvania, Andrew G. Curtin, at the White House. The president had more than Sumter on his mind: according to Curtin’s account, reported in the Times, Lincoln stated he had “information of a design to attack the city of Washington,” and urged the governor — a close Republican Party ally — to ready his state’s militia for a quick deployment to the Union capital.

For pants, go to contextclothing.com.If you want to listen to Pablo Picasso’s first record, go to the band’s Web site and download it for free. It was meant to be consumed that way — no record label, no distribution, no expensive studio time, just free MP3s. “I don’t really have much hope of making money from our music,” says Eugene Wasserman, the band’s guitarist. “And we just thought it would be better to do it ourselves.” The band — Wasserman, Darius Greyson (vocals), Keegan Monaghan (bass) and Oto Gillen (drums) — recorded the whole thing in their New York practice space. “I think the live show is the most important thing anyways,” Greyson adds. “The record just sounds the way we play them onstage.”

Bryson Voirin, a doctoral student at the Max Planck Institute for Ornithology in Germany and a fellow at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama, writes from Panama, where he is studying sleep in wild frigate birds.

JPMorgan Chase paid Jamie Dimon, its chief executive, a total of $20.8 million last year, a substantial increase from $1.3 million he received in 2009, the bank disclosed on Thursday afternoon in a regulatory filing.

When the cast of “Jersey Shore” gets back from Italy later this year, three of the cast members will start work on their own reality shows. MTV said Thursday that it had ordered two such spin-offs, one featuring Paul DelVecchio, known as DJ Pauly D, and the other featuring Nicole Polizzi and Jenni Farley, known as Snooki and JWoww.

A group of Asian-American journalists has started a new blog, Our Chinatown, that seeks to bring comprehensive and immediate news coverage to a complicated and intriguing city neighborhood that is often overlooked by reporters.
After Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus teed off, the first round of the 2011 Masters was under way.
Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

For readers who are following the science of sea-level rise, a new overview paper has been published that makes indispensable reading. One of the great experts in the field, John A. Church of Australia, and his collaborator Neil J. White analyze records from instruments called tide gauges, starting in the 19th century and running into the 21st, and they also incorporate the satellite measurements of sea level that have been available since 1993.

The ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, Representative John Conyers of Michigan, on Thursday released a 78-page Justice Department report about a much-disputed voter-intimidation case involving the New Black Panther Party, a radical fringe group.

Last week I wrote about how cyber politics and crime on the Internet had been foreseen with eerie accuracy by science fiction writers. For example, the computer scientist Vernor Vinge’s classic 1981 novella “True Names” described the impact of the Net long before most people had personal computers, let alone an Internet connection.
For the second time in less than a week, rebel fighters say NATO warplanes mistakenly attacked their troops.
