The New York state education commissioner, David M. Steiner, said Thursday that he would be resigning from his position in August.
Rolling Stone’s Web site has a free stream of Robbie Robertson’s new album, “How to Become Clairvoyant,” his first since 1998.
My wife went to New York City last week to see a show. Afterward, she went to dinner with some friends who ran into some other friends and they all dined together.

The New Statesman has published an article by the actor — and tabloid victim — Hugh Grant, who managed to secretly tape a former News of the World journalist (now a pub owner, how perfect) saying that the News of the World’s editor at the time knew all about the phone hacking going on at the paper. You can read a little bit of the story on the New Statesman’s Web site — the rest is behind its pay wall (enough said) — but The Guardian spills most of the beans. And this is a good moment to have another look at our magazine’s excellent piece on the hacking scandal.

The director Kelly Reichardt is one of very few women in American independent cinema who has managed to have a sustained career making full-length features. Her small-scale, slow-burn tales of the lost and dispossessed, like “Old Joy” and “Wendy and Lucy,” have garnered critical acclaim for their larger social and political relevance. In her latest film, “Meek’s Cutoff,” opening Friday in New York, the lost are a group of pioneers crossing the Cascade Mountains in 1845, who find themselves wandering the high plain desert after they decide to take a shortcut. Here, Reichardt discusses her unorthodox take on the Western genre, starring her frequent collaborator Michelle Williams.

A Gypsy punk metal band from Seattle provided a few hours’ relief from the ethnic, political and social tensions in Bosnia.

Same-sex couples are one step closer to receiving protections that heterosexual married couples get when they receive long-term care through Medicaid - that is, the healthy partner will be able to keep some of the ailing partner's money and remain in their home.
David D. Kirkpatrick reports on recent NATO airstrikes and the disorganized rebel forces in eastern Libya.
It’s been a big week for Bob Dylan news.

The big news of the day, at least in the realm of education, is that Cathleen Black is stepping down after just a few months as New York City’s schools chancellor. To the opponents of education reform who vilified her — and who are now most likely celebrating her departure — Black was a perfect emblem of the reform movement’s arrogance, a power-suited publishing executive who had never attended, let alone worked at, a public school. To the reformers, this was at least part of her virtue. She was further proof that what is needed to repair our badly broken public schools is the fresh perspective of an outsider.
In some countries, couples put padlocks on bridges and throw the keys in the river to symbolize their enduring love. Including this one.

Two years ago, Corbyn Hanson Hightower was earning six figures. Then the Great Recession hit, and Ms. Hightower and her husband sold their car, found a cheaper, draftier home, canceled cable and Internet, worked odd jobs, depleted their savings and “stripped ourselves to the bare minimum” while supporting three children.

There is no evidence that safety investigations conducted by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration have been influenced by former agency officials who now work for automakers or the former auto officials who work for the agency, said a report released on Thursday by the Office of the Inspector General for the Transportation Department, which oversees N.H.T.S.A.

Once the network of female protagonists in unexpected professions and/or  life-or-death situations, Showtime continues its transition to the network of offbeat celebrity casting that we’re willing to at least give a chance. (And also “Gigolos.”) Adding to a roster of original programming that includes “The Borgias,” “Shameless,” “Weeds” and “The Big C,” Showtime said on Thursday it had picked up the first seasons of two new series: “House of Lies,” a comedy starring Don Cheadle and Kristen Bell, and “Homeland,” a drama starring Claire Danes, Damien Lewis and Mandy Patinkin.

In what is believed to be a first for an e-book, “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” by the Swedish novelist Stieg Larsson, has sold more than a million copies in its digital format, Knopf said on Thursday. Knopf, part of Random House, said the combined digital sales for all three books in the blockbuster “Millennium” series, which includes “The Girl Who Played With Fire” and “The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest,” is now more than three million copies. The trilogy is selling at a clip of more than 500,000 copies a month in all formats. “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” which went on sale in the United States in September 2008, has sold more than 300,000 copies in hardcover.

“Since I was a little girl, I’ve been collecting flowers and floral fabrics,” says Emilie Bon, the swimwear designer behind the year-old lingerie-inspired line Lilibon. The latest collection of eight petal-printed items includes bandeau and pinup-style maillots and bikinis trimmed in lace and tulle. Bon’s inspiration? A pressed anemone she found among her childhood keepsakes.

When I was young, I always thought “robot” meant something with arms and legs and a head. I can still remember feeling cheated when I saw an automotive factory “robot” on TV that was nothing more than an arm that drilled holes. And I’ll bet I’m not alone. I’ll bet all kinds of children encounter that moment of disillusionment when they first encounter robot inflation.

The Salone del Mobile design fair in Milan starts this week, and every year it’s a similar story: chairs and sofas as far as the eye can see and yet not so many places to sit and relax. In a nod to the once-abundant greenery in this city, Marni has installed a courtyard oasis in front of its shop at Via Spiga 50.

BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, Thursday announced that Thomas K. Montag, President of Global Banking and Markets at Bank of America, has joined the firm’s board of directors. Out are other high-profile bank executives Sallie Krawcheck and Mark Linsz. Read more »

Most destinations for the Disney Cruise Line promise sun and sand (the Bahamas, Grand Cayman) or stunning scenery (Alaska, the Mexican Riviera). But a different set of attractions — and perhaps a little big-city attitude — characterizes the newest addition to its lineup of ports of call: New York City. Starting in May 2012, the Disney Magic cruise ship, which accommodates about 2,700 passengers, will sail 20 cruises, departing from the Manhattan Cruise Terminal on the Hudson River.

The director Joe Wright narrates a scene from the action thriller "Hanna," starring Saoirse Ronan.

In the action thriller “Hanna,” Saoirse Ronan plays a teenager who was raised in an isolated environment in Finland and trained to be an assassin. This scene is set in Morocco and shows her coming into contact with modern technology for the first time. The director Joe Wright discusses some of the ideas behind the scene and the techniques he used to bring its objects to life.

Overview | What role does slang play in our language? How does slang both shape and reflect culture? In this lesson, students consider the slang words they use daily and the role slang plays in our culture. Then, they explore the etymologies of these and other slang words and display their findings in a visually interesting way, as well as compile a class dictionary.

Even some of the best restaurants in town have had trouble passing health inspections. But Eater reports that Fatty ’Cue, Zakary Pelaccio’s very popular Asian barbecue restaurant in Brooklyn, has been shut down by the city health department after it rang up 115 violation points in an inspection on Monday. (You need fewer than 14 points to get an A, and fewer than 28 to get a B.)

Toyota and Microsoft this week announced a partnership that will expand Microsoft’s penetration in automotive telematics, while providing Toyota with on-board communication, control and entertainment electronics. While this marks the first time the two companies have joined forces to develop in-car systems, they have worked together for more than 10 years on a mobile Internet project for Japan.
Animated GIFs — graphics files that display a simple loop of images — may seem like relics of the early Web era, like a Geocities homepage or a Friendster account.

Sokol, who recently resigned from Berkshire.

Mercedes-Benz has revealed the concept version of its new A-Class, set for display at the coming Shanghai and New York auto shows. The smallest car in the German automaker’s line, the A-Class is a far cry from the original of 1997. That model’s novel architecture set passengers above the drive train, lending it a podlike quality and a resemblance to the cars of the Smart brand owned by Mercedes.
As my colleague Andrew Pollack reports, a 7.1 magnitude aftershock struck off the east coast of Japan on Thursday.

In Thursday’s Times, I write about the impact that cultivating food crops to manufacture biofuels has had on food prices, which have been at or near record highs over the last six months, On Thursday, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization released its latest Food Price Index, which showed a slight decline for the month of March.

Manager Joe Girardi may not like people talking about the right-hander Phil Hughes’s missing velocity, but Hughes isn’t hiding from it. With his second start of the season Friday in Boston, he knows he will need his fastball to pick up the couple of miles per hour it was missing in his 2011 debut.

An acridness hung in the air during the New Group’s revival of Wallace Shawn’s “Marie and Bruce” the other night, something I don’t often experience at the theater. It was the thick, curdled aura of an audience’s collective discomfort.

My interview with the political legend Mario Cuomo in this Sunday’s magazine just went live on The Times’s Web site. In doing some research for the article (I was trying to compare Mario’s inaugural address with his son Andrew’s), I made one of those minor discoveries that leave you feeling so lucky to be living in the Internet age. It turns out that the State of New York recently posted video from the first Governor Cuomo’s inaugural address in 1983. It’s only a few minutes, unfortunately, but it’s still fun to watch if you’re someone who likes political history, if only for the outsize presence of the interpreter for the deaf. (This is before the advent of text crawls.)

Electric cars will play a starring role in many automakers’ lineups for the next few years. But what about the vehicles already out there, burning gasoline and diesel? ALTe Powertrain Technologies, founded by three former Tesla Motors executives, aims to convert those vehicles by the thousands to operate as plug-in hybrids.

The F.B.I. spent nearly two years investigating the 1997 killing of the hip-hop artist the Notorious B.I.G., focusing on a man the bureau suspected may have been the rapper’s assassin, but ended its inquiry in early 2005 after prosecutors decided there was insufficient evidence to pursue a case, according to recently released F.B.I. records reported on by The Associated Press.

6:42 p.m. | Updated The Sharjah Biennial, a sprawling art event in the United Arab Emirates that began in 1993 and is now in the midst of its 10th iteration, has been celebrated as a pioneer in bringing ambitious contemporary art to the Middle East. But its delicate balancing act — allowing artists freedom of expression while respecting a host of cultural and religious sensitivities — seems to be proving harder to maintain.

Scott Hill couldn’t have guessed that the souvenir balsam pillow he purchased on a trip to Maine would be the first step toward opening his shop. But the modest keepsake became a retail catalyst when Hill contacted the manufacturer and custom ordered 50 “Greetings from the Catskills” pillows, which he arranged to sell in a friend’s shop near his country home in Andes, N.Y. Encouraged by the demand for memorable gifts, Hill opened two seasonal stores of his own in Andes, before establishing a permanent East Village flagship.

There’s been a shift in how we think about human evolution. Years ago, people tended to see evolution as a competition for survival of the fittest. But now there is more emphasis on the gentler virtues. People survive because they are really good cooperators. Research into hunter-gatherer cultures has contributed to this new understanding. People once believed that early humans lived in small kinship circles and fought to pass along their common genes.

Fresh from his investigation into the secrets of oven-baked ribs, Steven Raichlen is answering readers’ questions. If there’s anything that the author of “Planet Barbecue” and the host of “Primal Grill” can elucidate for you, leave a question here.

Thanks to the Si Cuba festival, music and dance from the island are everywhere in New York this spring, and though American Ballet Theater isn’t on the festival program, it feels as if the company were doing its part to add to the mix. Its annual spring gala, set for May 16, will feature a tribute to Jose Manuel Carreño, the retiring principal dancer who was born in Cuba, and a one-night-only performance of the Cuban choreographer Jorge Garcia’s “Majisimo.” Cuban-born dancers will be featured in the work, including Xiomara Reyes of Ballet Theater and the sisters Lorena Feijoo (San Francisco Ballet) and Lorna Feijoo (Boston Ballet). Honorary chairs for the evening, which will also feature highlights from the coming spring season, are Michelle Obama, Carolina Herrera, Caroline Kennedy and Blaine Trump. Tickets (starting at $25) to the performance only are available at metoperafamily.org.

Despite the public focus on radiation risks, cost has long been the main obstacle to a substantial expansion of nuclear power generation, and will be even more as a result of Japan’s still-unfolding effort to secure the wave-ravaged Fukushima Daiichi complex.

Giulietta, which had its debut in a whitewashed loft during New York Fashion Week, is helmed by Sofia Sizzi (above, center), a Florentine-born Manhattanite who is driven by a love for lavish Italian fabrics. “Is that really double-knit?” one observer whispered of a black wool suit consisting of skinny flared trousers, a hip-length narrow-lapeled jacket and a long fitted vest that could serve as a minidress to nouveau Twiggys. The 24-look collection includes a black wool sateen dress accented with a Peter Pan collar, a handmade lace widow skirt and a saffron printed pantsuit based on Sizzi’s sketch of a Baroque cathedral ceiling. The shoes — velvet, satin and felt wedges and heels (all vegan, to match the 33-year-old’s lifestyle) in salmon, saffron and cardinal red — attest to what Sizzi learned while working as an accessories designer at Gucci, Calvin Klein and Donna Karan. Clever ’60s proportions and mod collaborations with the milliner Patricia Underwood and the jeweler Thomas Bliven add a bit of nonecclesiastical zing. From $435 at Barneys New York.

Bryan Caplan, an economist at George Mason, is the author of “Selfish Reasons to Have More Kids,” which will be released this week. Mr. Caplan doesn’t believe everyone should have a lot of children. But he does say many parents and future parents should consider having more children than they are currently planning.

Where can a business owner turn to get clear direction? Makers of batteries for plug-in vehicles are in something of a tight spot. They are under considerable pressure to improve their products so that electric vehicles will be attractive to more drivers. But if they actually manage to come up with a radically improved battery, their breakthrough is likely to be met with skepticism — perhaps dealing a permanent blow to their reputation.

In Today’s Times:–The federal government continues to move toward a possible shutdown after a late-night meeting at the White House between President Obama and congressional leaders failed to produce anything more than a pledge to keep negotiating. Carl Hulse and Jackie Calmes report that the House is scheduled to vote today on a stop-gap measure to fund the government for one more week until a budget can be passed, even though Democrats have said the bill would dead-on-arrival in the Senate. If the lawmakers fail to strike a deal, the government will effectively shut down when the clock strikes midnight Saturday.

A new club and performance space is flourishing in Kreuzberg’s Kottbusser Tor area, a bohemian neighborhood in Berlin. In the shadow of a former housing project, Südblock (Admiralstrasse 1-2; 49-30-609-418-53; www.suedblock.org) opened in December with a lineup as diverse as its surroundings. On any given night, one might stumble in to find a video installation, a record release concert, or an evening of Israeli pop for gay partygoers.
It seems that I am always fated to learn about my critical admissions decisions on the slowest possible Internet connection — the one on my cellphone.

SEPANG, Malaysia – I can see the Petronas Twin Towers from my hotel window in Kuala Lumpur. This morning rather than taking three different public transportation lines – a monorail, a train and a metro – to get to the train that takes me to the airport where the race track is located, I decided I would simply walk towards the Twin Towers, where I knew there would be a direct line to the train to the airport.

BUSINESS DAY An article on Tuesday about a major security breach at the online marketing firm Epsilon misstated the information that was exposed from three of Epsilon's clients: JPMorgan Chase, Target and Walgreen. Only e-mail addresses were exposed, those companies said -- not customer names. (Many Epsilon clients reported the exposure of both e-mail addresses and names.) A picture caption with the article repeated the error about one client, JPMorgan Chase.

BERMAN--Myron, 83, formerly of Richmond, Virginia, passed away Tuesday, April 5, 2011. He was the past Rabbi of Temple Beth-El in Richmond from 19651993. In addition, Rabbi Berman was the author of numerous books, including Richmond's Jewry, 17691976: Shabbat in Shockoe. He was a professor at Virginia Commonwealth University and William & Mary. Born and educated in New York, Rabbi Berman joined the Air Force and obtained the rank of Captain. After his service, he held other rabbinical positions before moving to Richmond. Cherishing his loving memory are his devoted wife, Ruth, his daughter Barrie and son-in-law Tony, his son Gregg and daughter-in-law Susy, and his beloved grandsons Peter and Johnny. A private burial will be held in New Jersey.

WICKS--Elizabeth L. (Betty), of Waban and Westwood, MA passed away on April 6, 2011, in Worcester, MA after a long illness. She was the daughter of the late Melvin H. Leonard and Francis T. Cate and predeceased by her devoted husband, David O. Wicks. She is survived by her three children, David O. Wicks, Jr. of New York, NY; Elizabeth T. Wicks of Boylston, MA; and John P. Wicks of Ashland, MA; three granddaughters Perrin and Sara of Brooklyn, NY and Dana of Framingham, MA and two great- granddaughters. She is also survived by her sister, Martha Carl who resides in Natick, MA, and her daughters-in-law Joan G. Wicks and Sarah D. Bliss. Her sister Helen Comstock is deceased. A memorial service will be announced in the future and the family will have a private service in Petit Manan, Maine. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Scholarship Fund at The Brimmer and May School in Chestnut Hill, MA or the Alzheimer's Disease Research Association, Clarksburg, MD.

NATIONAL The Sidebar column on Tuesday, about unruly arguments at the Supreme Court, misidentified, based on a court transcript, two justices who spoke in a right-to-counsel case. The comment ''Maybe Justice Alito can ask his question,'' was made by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., not Justice Antonin Scalia. And the justice who had been trying to get a word in edgewise was Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., not Justice Anthony M. Kennedy.
An article last Thursday about the revival in popularity of typewriters referred incorrectly to a device made by Apple. It is the iPod Touch, not the iTouch.

PIERCE--Ellison C.,Jr., M.D., "Jeep", 82, of Boston, MA on April 3, 2011. Husband of the late Dr. Elizabeth Taber Pierce; Jeep leaves son Charles A. Pierce, daughter Cynthia C. Pierce, sister Rose Marie Whitlock and three grandchildren. For 35 years Dr. Pierce was on staff at the New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston, MA, and served as Chairman of the Anesthesiology Department. He was also a past-President of the American Society of Anesthesiologists and the founder of the Anesthesia Patient Safety Foundation, the pioneer organization dedicated to assuring patient safety. Among his numerous honors were that Jeep was inducted into the Royal College of Anesthetists, was an Associate Clinical Professor of Anaesthesia at Harvard Medical School, received a special citation from the Food and Drug Administration, and accepted awards from the American Medical Association, the Royal Society of Medicine (UK) and the Russian Society of Anesthesiology. Jeep spoke on the topic of safety in the US, Japan, Russia, Europe, South America and Australia and is known to anesthesia students the world over for his appearances in the FDA's safety and training films. A Memorial service will be held at Trinity Church, Copley Square, Boston on Saturday, April 9 at 10am. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations in Jeep's memory to the Anesthesia Patient Safety Foundation, Building One, Suite Two, 8007 South Meridian Street, Indianapolis, IN 46217 or online at www.APSF.org. To leave condolences please visit www.bostonharborsidehome. com.

SULLIVAN--John G.,48, of Manhattan, NY, died on April 5, 2011 at New York Presbyterian Hospital, surrounded by his family, after a brief illness. John is survived by the great joy of his life, his son Quinn Sullivan, and wife Mary Brosnahan also of Manhattan; parents Madeline and John Sullivan of Sleepy Hollow NY; sister Jeanne Sullivan-Gillespie and husband Chris Gillespie of Burlington, VT; sister Madeline Sullivan-Drake and husband Tom of Waterbury, VT. His sister, Joanne Sullivan, predeceased John. He was a loving uncle to his many nieces and nephews. John found great support and fellowship with his friends at AA. A graduate of Sleepy Hollow High School, John was both a quarterback and pitcher for the Headless Horseman. A lifelong athlete and sports' fan, he enjoyed watching the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame, the New York Yankees and the New York Jets. He attended St. Mary's College of Moraga, CA, and graduated Sum Cum Laude from Fordham Graduate School with a MSW. He later became a Licensed Social Worker and therapist. After several years in sales, working for both the Carrier Corporation and Strick Leasing Co, John found his life's calling helping others, particularly the homeless, mentally ill, and those suffering from addiction issues. John spent several years working for Pathways to Housing, and then as the Executive Director for Friends House, providing housing and support services to those formerly homeless living with AIDS. Most recently, John was an Interventionist and Director of Case Management with Gallant and Associates, where he helped hundreds of people towards recovery and a better life. The family will receive friends this Friday at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison and 81st Street, 1-3, 5-8. A celebration of John's life and Mass of Christian Burial will take place Saturday, April 9, at St. Francis of Assisi Church, 135 W. 31st at 11am. Interment to follow at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Sleepy Hollow, NY. Donations in John's memory can be sent to: The Coalition for the Homeless, New York City.

BIGELOW--Edward. Eddie died April 4, 2011 at the age of 93. He leaves his beloved wife Carla Bigelow, of Cornwall, CT; his nephew and niece, Hal and Marion Bigelow; stepchildren Timothy Stevens, Brooke Stevens and wife Karen, Sara Nerone, April Stevens and husband Sandy Neubauer; six grandchildren; and two great- nephews. He spent his career with the New York City Ballet initially as a dancer and then for over 40 years as the company's manager. We will always remember his kindness, strapping good looks and unending generosity. Words cannot express how deeply he was loved or how much he will be missed. Services will be held at the North Cornwall Meeting House, Town Street, Cornwall, at 11am, April 16.

Facebook, Zynga, Groupon, Twitter and LinkedIn have come to define the social Web. Founded within the last five years, the quintet of start-ups is now estimated to be worth more than $71 billion. Behind these companies is a tangle of venture capitalists, founders, engineers and angel investors who stand to profit handsomely if these start-ups go public. For some companies, it is just a matter of when. Groupon is considering a 2011 offering that would value the social buying site at $25 billion, while Facebook has signaled that it will go public next year.

MARK HOGANCAMP died 11 years ago tomorrow, when five men kicked his head in outside a Kingston, N.Y., bar in the early morning hours. He was reborn months later, after he awoke from a nine-day coma, his memory wiped nearly clean of the details of his life -- his early marriage, girlfriends, family, Navy service, thundering alcoholism, homelessness, jail time -- and he had to relearn how to eat, walk and think at age 38. Feeling shunned by the outside world, he created his own world, a tiny society called Marwencol. Made from scraps of plywood and peopled with a tribe of Barbies and World War II action figures, Marwencol grew along the side of his trailer home near Kingston. (Mr. Hogancamp named his new world after himself and Wendy and Colleen, two women he had crushes on.) Narratives surrounding a downed American fighter pilot rescued by Marwencol's all-female population began unfurling against a backdrop that was nominally a World War II setting, in Belgium. The themes, however, were Mr. Hogancamp's own: the brutality of men, the safe haven of a town of women, the twin demons of rage and fear. Mr. Hogancamp captured his stories with thousands of photographs, shooting on an old Pentax with a broken light meter. The noirish images, complete with blood flecks in the snow, are riveting and emotional.
SAN FRANCISCO THOMAS WEISEL doesn't have much personal experience with social media. He has never opened a Facebook or Twitter account, and he has resisted buying an iPhone.

BIGELOW--Edward. For over forty years, a consistent cry at the New York City Ballet was: "Where's Bigelow? Call Bigelow. Get Bigelow"! Eddie served us all with singular devotion and avid loyalty. J. J. Abrams is not a big fan of disclosing the plot details of new films he's directing (see ''Super 8'') or producing (''Cloverfield'') before they've been released, so don't expect any spoilers -- or even a title -- for a new novel on which he'll be collaborating. The publisher Little, Brown said on Wednesday that it had acquired a book that Mr. Abrams, the director of ''Star Trek'' and a creator of the television series ''Lost,'' ''Alias'' and ''Felicity,'' had conceived and will be written by Doug Dorst, the author of the supernatural crime novel ''Alive in Necropolis.'' A release from the publisher happily cited Mr. Abrams's film and television credits and mentioned that Mr. Dorst is a graduate of the Iowa Writers' Workshop and a three-time ''Jeopardy!'' champion. And Mr. Abrams said in a statement that ''Doug is a genius,'' adding that he ''could not be more excited to collaborate with him on this completely original project.'' Just what that project is neither Mr. Abrams nor Little, Brown is indicating, except to say that it is planned for a fall 2012 release on the Mulholland Books imprint. Watch for further clues as soon as we know where to find them. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A new installment of ''NCIS'' topped the ratings on Tuesday night as 18.8 million viewers watched the show on CBS at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen estimates. CBS led the night over all despite broadcasting a rerun of ''NCIS: Los Angeles'' (12.6 million) at 9 p.m. opposite ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' results episode (15.6 million). ABC's new series ''Body of Proof'' won at 10 p.m. with 11.1 million viewers, outperforming ''The Good Wife'' on CBS (10.6 million) and ''Parenthood'' on NBC (4.7 million). ABC's ''No Ordinary Family'' (5.7 million) lagged behind the first half of NBC's ''Biggest Loser,'' which averaged 7.3 million viewers from 8 to 10. NBC ranked third for the night, behind CBS and ABC but ahead of repeats on Fox. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Q.I am planning to do a lot of research soon and will need to make a lot of copies. I would like to scan the documents instead - are there portable scanners that would work?A.If you have lots of loose pages you want to copy and convert to digital files, a slim, portable scanner can tackle the job. These types of lightweight scanners are typically long and flat, and they connect to a computer through the USB port. As you feed sheets of paper into a slot on the device's side, the scanner converts the document into a PDF file in the computer. The Neat Company, Fujitsu and Brother are three of the many companies who make these types of scanners for less than $200.

We are told that beauty is in the eye of the beholder. That also appears to be the standard for determining whether information was ''material'' to establish securities fraud. Materiality has become the focal point in the prosecution of Raj Rajaratnam, the co-founder of the Galleon Group, for insider trading. The defense contends that information prosecutors say was provided to him by insiders was already publicly available to investors, so there could be no fraud if the information could not affect the price of the stocks he traded.

HAHN--Stephen. The art world has lost one of its great dealer-collectors with the passing of Stephen Hahn on April 2, 2011. Stephen was born February 1, 1921 in Hungary and spent his formative years in Paris. He came to New York from post-war Europe and was drawn to art dealing which he learned from his father, who was a well-known art dealer specializing in the works of the Old Masters. During the war, he was deported from Portugal, as a French refugee, to Santo Domingo where he remained for 6 years, finding work as a surveyor. When the war was over, he returned to his shattered family in Paris, eventually studying teaching at the Sorbonne. At age 30, he moved to Greenwich Village in New York City and started buying and selling paintings out of the trunk of his car. He met Jean Dubuffet and became a champion of the relatively unknown painter. Eventually, he established the Stephen Hahn gallery on 75th and Madison, which remained a famous fixture for over two decades. Many well-known people visited the gallery and became clients, including Charles Laughton, Edward G. Robinson, Woody Allen, Edward Albee, Mike Nichols and Greta Garbo. Stephen continued his rise to prominence by representing Norton Simon at Sotheby's and Christie's auctions and he counseled him in the acquisition of many important pieces of his collection. His friends and colleagues included prominent European and American dealers and collectors, including Richard Feigen, Gene Thaw, Bill Aquavella, Thomas Gibson, Daniel Malingue, Alexandre Rosenberg, Leo Castelli, Heinz Berggruen, Klaus Perls, and many others. His personal collection was notable for its extensive depth, breath and quality. It included major works by Cezanne, Picasso, Matisse among other great modern masters, with a particular appreciation for Jean Dubuffet. Many of the paintings which passed through Stephen's hands now hang in the important museums, institutions and private collections of the world. Stephen was one of the founding members and an early president of the Art Dealers Association. He donated works to major cultural institutions both in the US and abroad. Stephen was not just a dealer but also a scholar of impeccable honesty and taste, with an encyclopedic knowledge on the history of any given painting. As such, he was called on many times to validate a painting's authenticity. His eye for quality was universally respected and he was internationally acknowledged as the authority not only on Picasso, but also Degas and Douanier Rousseau, In Clifford Irving's book "Fake" Stephen is mentioned numerous times in relation to a large collection of Picassos. Stephen Daniel Saidenberg and Klaus Perls were all in agreement: 43 of the Picassos hanging on the walls were fake. Stephen had a great passion for the musical arts. He was an opera lover, Wagner in particular. One of his great enjoyments was attending Ring Cycle productions around the globe. His devotion to music was clearly exemplified by his generosity as a benefactor of The Music Academy of the West in Santa Barbara, CA. Many of the young musicians and singers he sponsored have gone onto become some of today's esteemed classical musical talents, including pianist Vassily Primakov and soprano Susanna Phillips, who would often come to stay, practice and perform in his Montecito home. Stephen's legacy at the Music Academy lives on in the beautiful conservatory space he endowed, Hahn Hall, completed in 2008. Stephen's achievements are a testament to his fascinating character and many qualities. His dignity and savor-faire made him preferred among dealers and clients, his intelligence, mischievous wit, and charm made him a favorite at the table. His drive and competitive spirit was manifest in his love of sports. He frequently traveled with a tennis racquet. Stephen approached life with keen observance and thoughtfulness. He was truly kind and generous and very devoted to his family. A man who once wielded substantial power in his sphere entered the twilight of his life with touching grace and a lively glint in his eye. He is predeceased by his sister Agnes Brodie, survived by his wife, Carla, his sister Suzanne, his children, Robert, Elizabeth, Thomas. Isabella and Lily, his stepchildren, Zachary, Brandon, and Katharine O'Brien, six grandchildren, a niece and a nephew. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to; Music Academy of the West, Attention: Gift Processor, 1070 Fairway Rd, Santa Barbara, CA 93108.

Weekly news magazines fared well in the first three months of the year, according to one closely watched industry barometer - except for Newsweek. Newsweek, which is in the midst of a reinvention under a new celebrity editor, Tina Brown, and a new deep-pocketed owner, Sidney Harman, is facing difficulty as it tries to recapture the readership and revenue it lost after years of decline. Figures released on Wednesday by the Publishers Information Bureau showed that the number of advertising pages in Newsweek fell 31 percent compared with the same three months last year.

There were cowboys and country singers, Canadians and cast members of reality shows - even the reining Miss Guatemala was in attendance. But on a runway at a charity party held to promote Scotland in America on Tuesday night in Midtown Manhattan, there were strikingly few pieces of the genuine article. The honorary chairman himself, Sir Sean Connery, was missing from the annual fund-raiser and tartan-splashed charity fashion show, ''Dressed to Kilt,'' held this year at the Hammerstein Ballroom. Partygoers had to settle for a chairman who was only part Scot: Donald J. Trump. Whether the trumpeting of deep Scottish roots has anything to do with his latest venture, the brand new Trump International Golf Links, in Aberdeen, Scotland, is anyone's guess. ''So many of our leaders come from Scotland,'' Mr. Trump said. ''They're warriors.''

COYLE--Thomas, of Ringwood, NJ and Bermuda, passed away peacefully on April 5, 2011 after a long and heroic struggle with cancer. He was and remains the cherished and loving husband of Monica, beloved brother of Mary Coyle Giunco and William Coyle (deceased), treasured brother-in-law of Whitney Norton and Robert Giunco, devoted and joyful uncle to Monica Giunco, Robert Giunco, Jr., Mary DiLeo, William Coyle, Jr., Kathleen Coyle, Catherine Upchurch, Whitney Norton, Jr., Cherie McDonald and Kelly Cappa Coomber, and fun filled great-uncle to their fifteen children. Family and friends will remember him most for his playful celebration of life. Because of Tom, the ordinary became eventful and the simplest event a celebration. His remarkable memory for the trivial and the profound made him an endless source of information for family and friends. It also led him to a Masters from Columbia University in Library Science, and the directorships of the public libraries in Hillsdale, Ramsey and Oakland, NJ. He was happiest when traveling or planning a trip for himself or others. Bermuda and Italy were not only favorite destinations but homes where friends became cherished extended family to Tom and Monica. Born in the Bronx, NY, he loved the city's arts and sports teams, especially New York City Ballet and his beloved New York Rangers. We will miss most the countless ways in which his endless thoughtfulness blessed our daily lives. He is now truly out "riding the big coaster" and we wish him "happy trails" and God speed. Family and friends may visit today, 4:00 to 8:00pm at the Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ, 07450, 201-444-7650. Funeral Gathering Friday, 9:00am at the funeral home, proceeding to St. Mary's RC Church, 17 Pompton Avenue, Pompton Lakes for a 10:30am Funeral Mass. Private cremation will follow. Donations may be made in Tom's memory to the John Theuer Cancer Center at Hackensack University Medical Center (HUMC). Also, donations of platelets and blood may be made at HUMC. www.feeneyfuneralhome.com

What it is: Your smartphone has a high-speed, 3G data connection. Your laptop may only have Wi-Fi. Tethering turns your smartphone into a wireless router, sharing the phone's 3G connection with other devices over Wi-Fi. No more wireless data cards for laptops, and devices like Wi-Fi-only iPads can get on the Internet via a phone. With the arrival of iOS 4.3 for iPhones and iPads, AT&T subscribers are now able to use their iPhones as wireless hot spots for up to five people, something that Verizon users have been able to do for a few weeks now. But what does tethering mean for the average user and should you enable it on your phone?

Q.Is there a simple way to sync my Entourage data with my iPhone?A.If you are using Entourage 2004 or 2008, you can sync your contacts and calendar information to the iPhone using iTunes, but you need to take the intermediary step of sending the data through the Mac's Address Book and iCal programs. To do so, open Entourage, and under the Entourage menu, choose Preferences. In the Preferences box, go to the General Preferences panel and click Sync Services. On the right side of the box, turn on the checkboxes next to the options for synchronizing Entourage contacts with the Mac OS X Address Book program and MobileMe, and for syncing events and tasks with iCal and MobileMe.

The playwright Athol Fugard and the theater executive Philip J. Smith will receive lifetime achievement honors at this year's Tony Awards, and the playwright Eve Ensler, the animal trainer Bill Berloni, Sharon Jensen and the Alliance for Inclusion in the Arts and the Drama Book Shop will also receive special distinctions this year, Tony organizers said on Wednesday. Mr. Fugard is the South African author of plays including ''Sizwe Banzi Is Dead,'' '' 'Master Harold' ... and the Boys'' and ''The Road to Mecca,'' and the novel ''Tsotsi.'' Tony organizers described Mr. Fugard as ''a playwright whose art has always spoken out against racism'' and who ''continues to be an active voice for freedom and equality.''

The audience applauded Bob Dylan's first concert in mainland China on Wednesday night even as some concertgoers questioned the need for him to stick to a set list that would avoid overtly offending that nation's Communist rulers (though it sounds like he was still able to slip in a few cryptically critical songs). Reuters reported that Mr. Dylan's performance at the Worker's Gymnasium in Beijing drew about 5,000 people, mostly Chinese youth as well as many foreigners. Though he stayed away from songs with obvious protest messages, like ''The Times They Are A-Changin','' Mr. Dylan played ''All Along the Watchtower,'' an ominous tune about possible upheaval (at least that's what we think it means) near the end of his two-hour set, and ''Like a Rolling Stone,'' his bitter personal criticism directed at an ambiguous subject.

BIGELOW--Edward. The New York City Ballet and the School of American Ballet mourn the passing of our long-time friend and colleague Edward Bigelow. Eddie began his studies at the School in 1941 and went on to dance with several of the early companies created by George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein prior to the formation of New York City Ballet in 1948. He originated roles in works by Balanchine, Robbins and others, including both the Mouse King and Mother Ginger in Balanchine's legendary production of "The Nutcracker." After leaving the stage, Eddie joined the NYCB administration, becoming an indispensable associate to both Balanchine and Kirstein. Throughout his life Eddie was a devoted and dedicated friend and supporter of both NYCB and SAB, and will be deeply missed by generations of artists who so greatly benefited from his unwavering compassion and commitment over the years. All of us extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Carla, family and friends.

Last year, Kenneth C. Griffin, the founder of the hedge fund giant the Citadel Group, celebrated his second year of double-digit gains. But despite strong performance, Mr. Griffin has not climbed back from the losses endured during the financial crisis. Citadel's flagship fund is still 15 percent below its peak, according to people with knowledge of the firm who were not authorized to speak publicly.

GREENBURGH, N.Y. -- Ryan Callahan, his broken right ankle in a surgical boot, used crutches to get around the Rangers' dressing room Wednesday. Callahan is out indefinitely, but he promised that his teammates would be as fearless as he is, as fraught with peril as that can be. ''That's the style we play,'' Callahan said, almost matter-of-factly, ''and that what we have to do to get victories.''

Britney Spears is still hot. But how hot? Her new album, ''Femme Fatale'' (Jive), released last week, has become her sixth No. 1 on Billboard's chart. That puts her in lofty company: the only women to have that many No. 1 albums are Mariah Carey, Janet Jackson (both with six), Madonna (seven) and Barbra Streisand (nine). And the video for the album's first single, ''Hold It Against Me,'' had been viewed nearly 33 million times on YouTube as of Wednesday afternoon.

There are three very different productions of “Macbeth” under way in New York this month, but admirers of Shakespeare’s lighter work have an alternative: The Acting Company’s production of “The Comedy of Errors,” which begins performances at Pace University on Saturday night after a five-month national tour. Directed by Ian Belknap, this “Comedy of Errors” draws on Charlie Chaplin’s style of visually spare comedy routines as inspiration for staging the plot of two sets of identical twins accidentally separated at birth. The play, produced in association with the Guthrie Theater, is scheduled to run through April 17. It is part of the inaugural season of “Shakespeare at Pace,” a new endeavor that most recently included F. Murray Abraham’s Shylock in “The Merchant of Venice.”

When the designer Gregory Parkinson approached the specialty jeweler Ten Thousand Things to create accessories for his spring 2010 collection, his only request was “riots of color.” The result is a series of coin-size glass enamel talismans, which have since become a permanent fixture at Ten Thousand Things’ meatpacking district studio/boutique. “As you stack them, it becomes like a composition of sorts,” says David Rees of Ten Thousand Things. The Houston Ballet will celebrate the grand opening Saturday of its new Center for Dance, a $46 million project with multiple rehearsal studios, administrative offices, a wardrobe workshop and even a special room for shoes. It also includes a dance laboratory with stadium seating for developing and performing new work. The troupe has been busy on other fronts as well. It has won the Rudolf Nureyev Prize for New Dance, a $25,000 grant intended to encourage large companies to make new works. The company is using the money to commission a piece by Jorma Elo that will have its premiere in October at the Joyce Theater in New York. The prize is awarded by the Joyce Theater Foundation from an endowment created in part by the Rudolf Nureyev Foundation.

How is it that Gary Busey, the “Celebrity Apprentice” contestant and “The Buddy Holly Story” star, came to be regarded as anything less than the DSM-IV definition of sanity, and are there any clues to be gleaned from his Thursday interview on “The Tonight Show”? Is it because he regards the rock singer Meat Loaf, his sometime nemesis on “Celebrity Apprentice,” as “an incredible stage actor” (and can deliver a pretty decent impression of Meat Loaf to boot)? Is it the joyously unhinged cackle he unleashes at around the 2:30 mark in the above video? The fact that he has created a nine-syllable acronym to define a word as simple as fun? If you, too, can claim with a straight face, as Mr. Busey does, that you have found “the truth of my me,” feel free to cast the first stone.

How many children are there in your family? If you have siblings, do you get along with them? A Motherlode blog post reports on the findings of survey by a British parenting Web site that ranks family happiness based on the best combinations of numbers and genders of children. According to the site, “two girls make for the most harmonious family life.” Would you agree? If you don’t have siblings, do you sometimes wish for them? What do you think is the perfect combination of children for family happiness? Why?

The notion of the paperless office has been tantalizing us since the 1970s. Why, in just 10 years, we were told, we would all work in glittering offices uncluttered by desk piles, file cabinets or closets full of cardboard boxes. Every document we’d need would be summoned easily on our computer screens. Unfortunately, the paperless office has remained 10 years away all these decades, and oddly enough, according to my careful calculations, it is still exactly 10 years away.

Why go all the way up to your Web browser’s Bookmarks menu to save the current page among your favorites? In many browser programs, you can just press Control-D (Command-D on a Mac) to summon the dialog box that lets you make a bookmark for the page, rename it and save it to a folder or as a shortcut on the browser’s toolbar.

Strategically placed halfway between the Arc de Triomphe and the Trocadero museum quarter is a discreet cultural center in an elegant town house once owned by the Armenian-born oil industry pioneer and promoter Calouste Gulbenkian. Though modest in size, the Centre Culturel Calouste Gulbenkian (51 Avenue d’Iena; 33-1-53-23-93-93; www.gulbenkian-paris.org) is worth a detour. What’s really striking about Christoph Niemann’s latest piece for the magazine, “The 2011 Easter-Egg Audit” — well, in addition to the delightfulness we’ve come to expect — is how it was composed. All those meticulously painted eggs, in all those weird positions: that was all Niemann. You’ll be able to enjoy the the piece on its own merits, but it becomes that much cooler when you check out behind-the-scenes shots like the ones below. It’s like the world’s best elementary-school art project.

Cheesecake in the Gray Lady? Goodness, no. But in the ‘teens, 20s and 30s, The Times made plenty of room in its Mid-Week Pictorial — a weekly rotogravure supplement — for some saucy publicity shots of female performers. Saucy, mind you. Never naughty. And always in connection with the young women’s appearances in the latest shows.

FAIRMAN--Claire Martin, of Locust Valley, NY passed away peacefully at home on April 2, 2011. Claire was born in Cincinnati, the daughter of Helen and Chester Martin, and was a member of the Hillsdale class of 1950. A 1954 graduate of Radcliffe College and past President of the Harvard-Radcliffe Club of Long Island, she received Radcliffe's Distinguished Service Award in 2004 on the occasion of her class' 50th reunion, of which she was co-chair. After living in New York City in the early years of her marriage, her family resided in Locust Valley. A devoted community volunteer, she served at various times on the Boards of Planting Fields Foundation, Locust Valley Library, Doubleday-Babcock Senior Center, Save the Children Long Island, and the New York Virtuosi Chamber Symphony. She co-founded the Hutton House Lectures at the C.W. Post Campus of Long Island University and retired as Development Officer at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. For many years, she was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. She will be deeply missed by her loving family: her husband of 51 years, Joel; her children Betsy Weyerhaeuser (David), David (Juliette Zener), and Helen; her sisters Helen and Lynne; and five grandchildren. A celebration of Claire's life will be held at Planting Fields on May 21 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Planting Fields Foundation, 1395 Planting Fields Road, Oyster Bay, NY 11771.

MATTANA--Geoffrey. He brought wisdom and light to a large and loving family. Nancy Delman Portnoy, Peter and Barbara Delman, Ariel, Marissa and Jesse Delman and Jane Rose join in remembering his intelligence, courage and spirit, and inspiration for us all. He will always be missed.

BIGELOW--Edward. For over forty years, a consistent cry at the New York City Ballet was: "Where's Bigelow? Call Bigelow. Get Bigelow"! Eddie served us all with singular devotion and avid loyalty. He knew our lives and our secrets. When he left us, he took those secrets with him. Loyal to the end. Barbara Horgan

FRANCIS--Francis. The George Balanchine Trust is saddened by the passing of its European representative and good friend. His dedication to George Balanchine's ballets over the last twenty years was one of deep passion and commitment. Our thoughts are with his wife Astrid, his son Mecky and all those whose lives he touched.

An article last Friday about the controversy in Texas surrounding the use of a new drug in the state's three-drug cocktail for lethal injections incorrectly reported the status of Lundbeck Inc.'s letter to the Texas Department of Criminal Justice about the drug, pentobarbital. The agency did receive the letter.

BERMAN--Myron, 83, formerly of Richmond, Virginia, passed away Tuesday, April 5, 2011. He was the past Rabbi of Temple Beth-El in Richmond from 19651993. In addition, Rabbi Berman was the author of numerous books, including Richmond's Jewry, 17691976: Shabbat in Shockoe. He was a professor at Virginia Commonwealth University and William & Mary. Born and educated in New York, Rabbi Berman joined the Air Force and obtained the rank of Captain. After his service, he held other rabbinical positions before moving to Richmond. Cherishing his loving memory are his devoted wife, Ruth, his daughter Barrie and son-in-law Tony, his son Gregg and daughter-in-law Susy, and his beloved grandsons Peter and Johnny. A private burial will be held in New Jersey.

A Calendar listing on Wednesday, about a fund-raiser scheduled for Saturday for the New Amsterdam Market, misstated the location of the Old Fulton Fish Market, where the fund-raiser is to be held. It is on South Street at Beekman Street, not Beekman Place, an intersection that does not exist.

WATTENBERG--Philip B.,of Florida, formerly of New York City, October 4, 1916- April 6, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Alice Loeb, cherished father of Howard, Pamela, Peter and Amy, grandfather of Christopher, Sony, Aaron and Dana and great-grandfather of Ellie and Mathew. A graduate of New York University School of Law, he served in the United States Army in WWII attaining the rank of Captain. He was a respected attorney in the field of intellectual property and music publishing. He was an avid traveler, golfer and bridge player. A private family service will be held.

Five miles north of Wall Street, a small financial advisory firm, Synergy M&A, has been working on dozens of headline-grabbing deals, including AT&T's recent $39 billion bid for T-Mobile USA. But the 27 deal makers hashing out terms and dissecting numbers are not freshly minted business school graduates or investment banking veterans. They are high schools seniors in a third-floor classroom on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

BEDELL--Robert Kiefer, father, grandfather, husband, engineer, humanist, leftist, WWII veteran, atheist and peace activist died while napping on April 5, 2011. Born in Indianapolis, educated at Reed and Stanford, he married the writer Madelon Berns in 1950. Life-long Brooklyners, they had three children and six grandchildren. Robert loved maple sugaring, blacksmithing and reading the New York Times. He built one of America's first urban solar projects, and, assisted by his wife, threw a famous Christmas party. Robert's presence had the gravity of the sun, and the warmth. A memorial service is planned for April 10th at 2pm at Robert's home in Cobble Hill.

FLOERSHEIMER--Stephen H. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University mourns the death of our friend, Stephen H. Floersheimer. The contributions to Cardozo of this remarkable dairy farmer turned scholar turned banker were countless. Most important was his establishment of the Floersheimer Center for Constitutional Democracy in 2000. Dr. Floersheimer created the Center to advance the understanding, and improve the functioning, of modern constitutional democracies. He cared deeply about the work of the Center and its mission. His vision supported scholarly research, public policy publications and numerous conferences on a wide range of important topics. In ways large and small, the Floersheimer Center has contributed to the intellectual, scholarly and educational missions of Cardozo School of Law, and to the world beyond. Dr. Floersheimer also established the Walter Floersheimer Chair in Constitutional Law, in honor of his father, as well as a scholarship for law students. Dr. Floersheimer, who received an honorary doctorate in humanities from Yeshiva University, was an irreplaceable source of guidance, inspiration, direction and insight. He will be greatly missed. The Yeshiva University community extends our deepest sympathies to his family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President
KELLNER--Zoe. Impossible to believe it has been 4 years. We think of you and miss you every day. Your legacy of loving and being loved by so many will live forever. Love, Mom and John

BRONFMAN--Ann. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of our dear friend Ann Bronfman, a dedicated philanthropist and respected humanitarian. She will be remembered for her tireless commitment to Jewish life, her devotion to the fields of education and health care, and all she did to help strengthen the Jewish community. Her legacy will live on through her foundation and the generosity of the entire Bronfman family, to whom we offer our deepest condolences. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO
BATTERBERRY--Michael C. Remembering my beloved Michael on his birthday. Adored by all that knew him. Ariane

FLOERSHEIMER--Dr. Stephen H.,died peacefully at his home in Switzerland on Wednesday, April 6, 2011. He was surrounded by his loving son and daughter, Daniel Floersheimer and Barbara Rothschild. He is survived by Barbara and Richard Rothschild of New York, Daniel and Beverly Floersheimer of Greenwich, CT, and Mark and Jeannette Floersheimer of Maryland. He leaves seven grandchildren, David and Robert Rothschild, Carolyn, William and Andrew Floersheimer and Andrea and John Floersheimer. DIMON'S PAYDAY JPMorgan Chase paid Jamie Dimon, its chief executive, a total of $20.8 million last year, a substantial increase from $1.3 million he received in 2009, the bank disclosed Thursday in a regulatory filing. Mr. Dimon's paycheck included a $5 million cash bonus for 2010, according the bank's annual proxy statement. He received no cash bonus in 2009 as the financial crisis lingered. Mr. Dimon's compensation included $14.2 million in restricted stock and options awarded in 2010. His salary remained unchanged at $1 million.

Thanks to the Si Cuba festival, music and dance from the island are everywhere in New York this spring, and though American Ballet Theater isn't on the festival program, it feels as if the company were doing its part to add to the mix. Its annual spring gala, set for May 16, will feature a tribute to Jose Manuel Carreno, the retiring principal dancer who was born in Cuba, and a one-night-only performance of the Cuban choreographer Jorge Garcia's ''Majisimo.'' Cuban-born dancers will be featured in the work, including Xiomara Reyes of Ballet Theater and the sisters Lorena Feijoo (San Francisco Ballet) and Lorna Feijoo (Boston Ballet). Honorary chairs for the evening, which will also feature highlights from the coming spring season, are Michelle Obama, Carolina Herrera, Caroline Kennedy and Blaine Trump. Tickets (starting at $25) to the performance only are available at metoperafamily.org. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

10 P.M. (Science) BUILD IT BIGGER The architect and professor Danny Forster, below, has risen to great heights and sunk to even greater depths to explain the design and construction challenges of some of the world's most celebrated structures, from the 1,356-foot Al Hamra Tower in Kuwait, the tallest twisting structure on Earth, to the Mponeng gold mine in South Africa, the deepest of its kind at more than 2.3 miles down. In this Season 5 opener, Mr. Forster travels 150 feet underneath New York City to examine the expansion of the subway system. Ruth Bernstein, his 95-year-old grandmother and an Upper East Side resident who apparently knows a thing or two about mass transit, makes a cameo appearance. 8 P.M. (NBC) WHO DO YOU THINK YOU ARE?Ashley Judd explores the branches of her family tree in this season finale, which finds her parsing the tales of her paternal great-grandmother, tracing the journey of an ancestor who confronted tragedy on the battlefield as a member of the Union Army, and discovering a link to the country's first settlers.

They built a dress for Harvey Fierstein, but alas, audiences did not come in numbers substantial enough to keep the Broadway revival of ''La Cage aux Folles'' running: that musical's producers released a statement on Wednesday evening saying that it would close on May 1: ''We're sorry to have to announce the final weeks of this exuberant production, which has brought great joy to audiences for the last year, as well as to everyone who has worked on the show, on stage and off.'' This ''La Cage'' revival opened last year at the Longacre Theater on April 18, starring Kelsey Grammer as the nightclub emcee Georges and Douglas Hodge as his cross-dressing spouse and star performer, Albin; it went on to win the Tony for best musical revival, as well as awards for Mr. Hodge and for its director, Terry Johnson.

AUGUSTA, Ga. - With high-definition television and super-slow-motion replays increasingly playing a role in how golf's rules are implemented, the sport's governing bodies took a step back Thursday, revising a rule so that some golfers in unique situations would be only penalized, not disqualified. At issue is the occasion when a player is not aware he has breached a rule and could not reasonably be expected to have known. Recently, with the use of advanced video technologies, minor breaches of the rules have been discovered on television. In the past, a player who signed a scorecard without applying the appropriate penalty was disqualified. Under the new interpretation, the player would still receive the penalty but not a disqualification. ''This is a solution to a modern phenomenon that the rules never contemplated,'' said Mike Davis, executive director of the United States Golf Association. ''These are things that could not happen in day-to-day competition and couldn't be discovered without specialized cameras that zoom in and make a golf ball look the size of a basketball.'' Earlier this year, Padraig Harrington was disqualified after he shot an opening-round 65 at the Abu Dhabi Championship when a slow-motion replay on high-definition television revealed that his ball moved ever so slightly as he was removing his ball mark on the green. Harrington was unaware the ball moved and none of his playing partners or anyone else on the green reported the ball moving. If they had, a two-stroke penalty should have been assessed. Because the rules violation was not assessed at the time, Harrington signed an incorrect scorecard, which led to a disqualification. With Thursday's change, which was announced just before the first round of the Masters and goes into effect immediately, Harrington would still have two shots added to his score but could have continued to play. Another celebrated case this year involved Camilo Villegas, who was disqualified for signing an incorrect card after a television viewer noticed he had tamped down a divot near where his ball was rolling down a slope. Villegas would still be disqualified under the new rule because the rules violation in this case was for not knowing a rule. ''Ignorance of the rules is not what this interpretation applies to,'' Peter Dawson, chief executive of the Scotland-based R&A, which along with the U.S.G.A. announced the new rule. ''It is for a limited number of circumstances. We don't think it will arise too often. But we were troubled by disproportionate disqualification penalties for small breaches of the rules.'' The change is not actually to the Rules of Golf, but to the large book of decisions on the rules that guides officials in specific cases. The new interpretation is of Decision 33-7/4.5 and in practice it gives officials far greater latitude when determining if a player should be disqualified. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Once the network of female protagonists in unexpected professions and/or life-or-death situations, Showtime continues its transition to the network of offbeat celebrity casting that we're willing to at least give a chance. (And also ''Gigolos.'') Adding to a roster of original programming that includes ''The Borgias,'' ''Shameless,'' ''Weeds'' and ''The Big C,'' Showtime said on Thursday it had picked up the first seasons of two new series: ''House of Lies,'' a comedy starring Don Cheadle and Kristen Bell, and ''Homeland,'' a drama starring Claire Danes, Damien Lewis and Mandy Patinkin. In ''House of Lies,'' Mr. Cheadle (of the ''Ocean's Eleven'' movies) plays a ruthless management consultant and Ms. Bell (''Veronica Mars'') plays a colleague at his firm. ''Homeland'' casts Ms. Danes (who is forsaking HBO, the network that put her in ''Temple Grandin'') as a C.I.A. officer with doubts about the recent rescue of a missing United States soldier (Mr. Lewis); Mr. Patinkin plays her C.I.A. boss and mentor. Both new shows are scheduled to begin production this summer.

BLUMBERG--Baruch. The Members and Staff of the American Philosophical Society, the nation's oldest learned society founded by Benjamin Franklin in 1743, are deeply saddened by the death of Baruch S. Blumberg, who served as President of the Society from 2005-2011, and who was elected a Member in 1986. Dr. Blumberg's vitality, inquisitiveness, distinction as a scientist, and dedication to our founding mission of "promoting useful knowledge" enhanced his years of leadership and service on the Society's behalf. He believed that "a passion for exploration is deeply rooted in the American character" and established the Lewis and Clark Grants for Exploration and Field Research at the APS in 2004. To date, this program has supported the work of more than 250 younger scientists and scholars. At the request of Dr. Blumberg's family, memorial contributions may be made to the Baruch S. Blumberg Research Grant Fund c/o the American Philosophical Society, 104 South Fifth St., Philadelphia, PA 19106. The APS community sends heartfelt condolences to Dr. Blumberg's wife Jean, their four children, and nine grandchildren. Mary Patterson McPherson, Executive Officer American Philosophical Society

A chart on Thursday about six Republican members of the House freshman class misstated a title held by Representative Tim Scott of South Carolina. He is a class co-liaison to the House leadership. He is not class president, a title held by Representative Austin Scott of Georgia.

An article on March 25 about the suspension of an air traffic controller at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport who was thought to have been asleep when two passenger jets landed without guidance from the tower misstated Federal Aviation Administration staffing requirements for airport control towers. The F.A.A. determines staffing according to traffic at each airport; it does not require all airports with scheduled commercial traffic to have towers.

After remarks by Alec Baldwin on Monday night suggested that the end of ''30 Rock'' was in sight, causing apoplectic fans to threaten to cancel their subscriptions to Kabletown, he has dialed back his comments, saying that he hopes the NBC comedy series will continue, but implying that his own time on the show was winding down. On Thursday morning, Mr. Baldwin wrote on his blog at The Huffington Post: ''I want to take the opportunity to state that although my days on network TV may be numbered, I hope '30 Rock' goes on forever. Or at least as long as everyone involved desires.''
I take full responsibility for the fact that this has not worked out as either of us had hoped or expected. MAYOR MICHAEL R.BLOOMBERG,

The commander, Gen. Abdul Fattah Younes, said he was waiting for an apology from NATO, which said it was investigating. SYRIA Thousands of people in towns near Damascus, the capital, demonstrated in what activists said were preparations for larger protests on Friday in Douma, a working-class suburb where at least 15 protesters were killed by government security forces last Friday.

Apparently, banks in the United States don't think their boardrooms were the problem. That's the obvious interpretation when so little has shifted at them since before the crisis. Many directors clearly lacked the educational or work backgrounds needed to understand the derivatives and other complex products whose risks eventually overtook their institutions. Worse, they forgot or never learned the many lessons of past bubbles and manias. And industry knowledge on bank boards is no more extensive today than it was four years ago. At nine big American banks, including Goldman Sachs and Wells Fargo, only about one of every seven nonexecutive directors has any financial expertise, roughly the same percentage as in 2007, according to research by Nestor Advisors. That compares to nearly one in three at a comparable sampling of large European banks, where there has been improvement since the crisis.

An article on Monday about the most senior New York City police detective still assigned to day-to-day, street-level police work misstated a statistic about police casualties in 2009 and 2010. In that period, no officers were killed by suspects' bullets; it is not the case that no officers were killed or injured by bullets.

A report in the National Briefing column on Wednesday about the sentencing of a man who defaced a petroglyph in Arizona known as ''Descending Sheep panel'' understated the age of the rock art. It is thought to be more than 1,000 years old, not more than a century.

In what is believed to be a first for an e-book, ''The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,'' by the Swedish novelist Stieg Larsson, has sold more than a million copies in its digital format, Knopf said on Thursday. Knopf, part of Random House, said the combined digital sales for all three books in the blockbuster ''Millennium'' series, which includes ''The Girl Who Played With Fire'' and ''The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest,'' is now more than three million copies. The trilogy is selling at a clip of more than 500,000 copies a month in all formats. ''The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,'' which went on sale in the United States in September 2008, has sold more than 300,000 copies in hardcover. No other major publisher said it had yet sold one million e-books of a single title. Several publishers said they had individual authors, like Nora Roberts of Penguin Group USA, who has sold more than a million digital copies of all her combined books.

Time Warner Cable and Viacom each filed lawsuits on Thursday that seek to resolve a stormy dispute in the television business over the right to stream channels to new devices like iPads. Cable companies like Time Warner Cable say their existing contracts with channel owners like Viacom cover devices like iPads that can be turned into television sets. Some of the channels owners disagree, and they have been exchanging threats with Time Warner Cable ever since its TWCableTV app was released in mid-March.

A few days ago, the Connecticut club printed a fake front page of The New York Times that included what purported to be a major scoop: to close the federal deficit, Senator Charles E. 6:42 p.m. | Updated The Sharjah Biennial, a sprawling art event in the United Arab Emirates that began in 1993 and is now in the midst of its 10th iteration, has been celebrated as a pioneer in bringing ambitious contemporary art to the Middle East. But its delicate balancing act - allowing artists freedom of expression while respecting a host of cultural and religious sensitivities - seems to be proving harder to maintain. Officials in Sharjah announced Wednesday that Jack Persekian, the director of the Sharjah Art Foundation, which runs the biennial, had been fired on orders from Sheik Sultan bin Muhammad al-Qasimi, the ruler of Sharjah, after numerous complaints from the public about an artwork in a public square that included sexually explicit Arabic slogans and poetry, some making reference to Allah.

And, yes, that’s meant ironically. My Sunday column argues that the latest budget battles have been a supreme example of dysfunction. At the last minute Friday night, the two sides agreed to a budget deal and averted a government shut-down, but this is still a wretched way to run a superpower. And while I particularly blame the Republicans for threatening to shut down the government (a threat that Democrats did not make during the Bush years), it’s also true that the Democrats are at fault for not passing a budget and spending bills when they should have last year before the fiscal year began, when they controlled both houses in Congress.

I would like to thank John Boehner, Harry Reid and President Obama for vindicating my decision not to write about the budget negotiations this week, on the assumption that the talk of a shutdown was mostly sound and fury, and then when the deadline hit a deal of some sort would be struck. I based that assumption primarily on my reading of the Speaker of the House, who made it abundantly clear — in word, deed, and especially body language — that he wanted the government shut down about as much as Indiana Jones wants to be locked in a room full of cobras. Given that the two sides weren’t that far apart in the closing days, in Boehner I trusted, and he didn’t let me down.
