SYRIA People in dozens of communities across Syria turned out to protest in what activists said were by far the largest and bloodiest demonstrations to date against the government of President Bashar al-Assad. Both the size of the protests and their level of coordination suggested that the country's fragmented opposition movement had achieved new levels of coherence and organization. In the southern city of Dara'a, security forces opened fire on demonstrators, killing at least 18. EGYPT Tens of thousands of demonstrators turned out in Tahrir Square in Cairo for one of the largest demonstrations since President Hosni Mubarak stepped down two months ago. Many have questioned the military's standing as a defender of the revolution, saying that its actions reflect the authoritarian tactics of the past and that it is either unwilling or incapable of ushering in an era of democratic reform.

DUBSKY--Dora, 96, passed away on April 6, 2011, with family at her side. Dora moved to NYC from Europe and became an acclaimed (and published) Creative Movement specialist and music teacher. She taught at the 92nd Street Y and in and around New York - the city that sheltered her and became a true home. Her gifts of friendship and humor will remain in the hearts of the many people, young and old, whose lives she enriched and who also gave her so much. Her two sisters predeceased her; she is survived by their children, loved and mourned by them, her dear friends, and her devoted caregivers. Gathering Sunday, Riverside Memorial Chapel at noon.

John Lennon may be better known as a writer of songs like ''Strawberry Fields Forever,'' ''I Am the Walrus'' and ''Imagine,'' but he was also a prolific composer of correspondence that will be compiled for the first time in a book that Little, Brown is preparing for next year. The publisher said Friday it will release ''The Lennon Letters,'' containing a selection of the writing the musician sent ''to his friends, family, strangers, newspapers, organizations, lawyers and the laundry,'' in October 2012. The collection has been permitted by Lennon's widow, Yoko Ono, and will be edited and introduced by Hunter Davies, the writer of the authorized biography ''The Beatles.''

McMAHON--Margaret M.,89, on April 7th, peacefully at her residence. Margaret was class of 1943 Manhattanville College and former executive with the New York City Health Department; sister of the late Catherine V. Hayes and sister-in-law of Dennis Hayes. She will be greatly missed by her dear friends and devoted caregivers. Reposing, Friday, 3-5pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian burial, Saturday, 10am at St. Agnes of R.C. Church, 143 East 43rd Street. Interment to follow at the Calvary Cemetery.

The Houston Ballet will celebrate the grand opening Saturday of its new Center for Dance, a $46 million project with multiple rehearsal studios, administrative offices, a wardrobe workshop and even a special room for shoes. It also includes a dance laboratory with stadium seating for developing and performing new work. The troupe has been busy on other fronts as well. It has won the Rudolf Nureyev Prize for New Dance, a $25,000 grant intended to encourage large companies to make new works. The company is using the money to commission a piece by Jorma Elo that will have its premiere in October at the Joyce Theater in New York. The prize is awarded by the Joyce Theater Foundation from an endowment created in part by the Rudolf Nureyev Foundation. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation is leading an international effort to call for the release of Ai Weiwei, the Chinese Conceptual artist who was taken into police custody in Beijing after he was detained on Sunday while trying to board a flight for Hong Kong. It has gathered the support of the museum community, including the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, the Tate in London along with the American Association of Art Museum Directors. ''By using Ai Wei Wei's favored medium of 'social sculpture,' we hope to hasten the release of our visionary friend and artist,'' the Guggenheim Foundation said in a statement on its Web site. The foundation and the museums said in a letter posted with the petition on Facebook and Twitter on Friday addressed to the Minister of Culture of the People's Republic of China, Cai Wu: ''We members of the international arts community express our concern for Ai's freedom and disappointment in China's reluctance to live up to its promise to nurture creativity and independent thought, the keys to 'soft power' and cultural influence.''An artistic adviser for the Olympic National Stadium in Beijing, Mr. Ai has clashed with the Chinese government before. After using his work to raise questions about how officials dealt with the May 2008 Sichuan earthquake, in which thousands of schoolchildren were killed in their classrooms, he was beaten by the police in 2009 before he was scheduled to testify at the trial of Tan Zuoren, a writer and activist who was investigating the same issue.

The ''Heart & Soul'' tour, a pairing of Rod Stewart and Stevie Nicks, is pure nostalgia, a valentine for the middle-aged and what they listened to from 1976 to 1978. Not a judgment, just a fact. But the really outmoded part about the concert is that the link between them is the radio. Remember the radio? We submitted to it completely. It made the connections for us. Besides Los Angeles, teased blond hair and a tremendous talent for the exaggerated courtly stage bow, what Mr. Stewart and Ms. Nicks really have in common is that they are singer-songwriters, articulating consciousness through words and melody, and they are fundamentally different at that job.
KELLNER--Zoe. Impossible to believe it has been 4 years. We think of you and miss you every day. Your legacy of loving and being loved by so many will live forever. Love, Mom and John

MACK--Ruth Kaufman, passed away of natural causes in Palm Beach Florida on April 7, 2011. She was born in Manhattan on November 28, 1914 and spent her youth in Williamsberg Brooklyn. She graduated at the age of 15 with High Honors at Eastern District High School in Manhattan. She walked the Williamsberg Bridge to school most days to save two cents for public transportation. She attended Hunter College in Manhattan. Her life was totally devoted to her family and Jewish charities of which the charities were: Yeshiva University where she received an honorary doctorate. Along with her husband, H.B. Mack, they were founders and benefactors of Long Island Jewish Hospital (now known as North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System); Boys Town of Jerusalem; Albert Einstein College of Medicine; and benefactor at the Jewish Theological Seminary. She taught Hebrew at the Hillcrest Jewish Center where she and her husband were founders and benefactors. Ruth Mack was amongst the leadership of the UJA and the Federation of Jewish charities. She was a member of the Board and Vice President of Temple Emanuel of Palm Beach. She is survived by her four sons: Earle, William, David and Fredric; six grandchildren: Richard, Stephen, Hayley, Jason, Andrew and Beatrice; and three great grandchildren: Harrison, Dylan and Tucker. A private funeral for family will be held Sunday. The Family will be receiving friends at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, NYC on Sunday from 4:30 to 7:30pm and on Monday and Tuesday between 5:30pm and 8:00pm.

The City National Corporation, a commercial lender based in Los Angeles, bought a failed Nevada bank, and another financial institution was seized, as this year's tally of shut-down banks reached 28. City National bought the Nevada Commerce Bank of Las Vegas and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency closed a bank in Illinois, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said. The two transactions drained $62.9 million from the F.D.I.C.'s deposit-insurance fund. City National paid a 0.71 percent premium for Nevada Commerce's more than $136 million in deposits, the F.D.I.C. said. The O.C.C. closed the two branches of Western Springs National Bank and Trust, based in Western Springs, Ill. The Heartland Bank and Trust Company of Bloomington bought the failed lender, adding more than $180 million in assets and deposits, according to the F.D.I.C.

St. John's Coach Steve Lavin, who took the Red Storm men's basketball team to its first N.C.A.A. tournament since 2002 in his debut last season, was found to have an early stage of prostate cancer, but he is expected to keep coaching and to make a complete recovery. In a statement released Friday, the university that said Lavin, 46, received the diagnosis last fall but opted to delay treatment until after the season. The statement said Lavin would undergo an unspecified treatment in the coming weeks.

There will be no climbing on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art this summer. Nor are there likely to be lines of eager, sneaker-clad visitors hoping to glimpse Central Park from new heights. Last summer 631,064 visitors trekked through ''Big Bambu: You Can't, You Don't, and You Won't Stop,'' the huge sculpture created by the identical-twin artists Mike and Doug Starn. It grew and changed and received visitors until the end of October.

7:15 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO - After deliberating for about six hours, the jurors in Barry Bonds's perjury trial left the courthouse for the day, headed for a weekend off and a tough week ahead. The panel - eight women and four men - did not return a verdict to end its first day of deliberations and the third week of the trial. But throughout the day, it asked two questions that left the prosecutors and defense lawyers wondering which way the jury was leaning.

OSUNA--Jess. An American actor passed away at home in Greenwich Village on April 2, 2011. Predeceased by his beloved wife Mary Anne. Jess was a devoted father, grandfather, brother and friend. He will be missed by the New York acting community and numerous relatives in California. Funeral services include: Visitation at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, NYC, Sunday, April 10, 2-5pm with a Vigil Service from 7-9pm; Funeral Mass: Monday, April 11, at 10am at Our Lady of Pompeii Church, 25 Carmine St, NYC; interment at Calvary Cemetery.

8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: DIRECTED BY ELIA KAZAN As a theater and film director, Kazan helped bring into focus the method acting style of Marlon Brando, James Dean, Karl Malden and Eli Wallach. Widely honored, his movies earned 22 Academy Awards and 62 nominations. Yet he became a polarizing figure when, in 1952, he appeared as a witness for the House Un-American Activities Committee investigation into Communist influences in Hollywood. The reverberations of his testimony were felt even at the 1999 Oscar ceremony, during which the presentation of an honorary award to Kazan was greeted by both standing ovations and stony silence. This four-film tribute begins with ''Splendor in the Grass'' (1961), the William Inge drama, starring Natalie Wood and Warren Beatty (above with Ms. Wood), about sexual repression in small-town Kansas during the 1920s. ''The Sea of Grass'' (1947), with Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy as a husband and wife on the American frontier, follows at 10:15; ''America, America'' (1963), a fictionalized account of Kazan's family's immigration to the United States, at 12:30; and ''A Face in the Crowd'' (1957), with Patricia Neal as a radio reporter who turns a folk-singing drifter (Andy Griffith) into a media star, at 3:30. The hosts Robert Osborne and Alec Baldwin explain why the films are required viewing. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Lucky Severson reports on a group of clergy that has been speaking out in support of Second Amendment rights and against gun control, and another group that is pushing to close loopholes in weapons sales. The Rev. James Martin, the culture editor of America magazine, discusses ''Of Gods and Men,'' a film about French Cistercian Trappist monks in Algeria who were threatened by Islamic militants. And Catherine Mandell discusses foods to avoid during Lent.

In the face of a lawsuit from the AARP Foundation, the Department of Housing and Urban Development has backed off an apparent policy change that was putting some widows and widowers on the brink of foreclosure. The dust-up involves reverse mortgages, financial products that allow older Americans with a decent amount of home equity to tap some of that equity if they are at least 62 years old. Unlike a home equity loan, where you have to pay the money back, with a reverse mortgage the bank pays you, say in a lump sum or in monthly payments. Once you no longer live in the home, you or your executor (if you're dead) sells it and pays the bank back.

Enough of Violet and Bobby, live from the nest - you know, the red-tailed hawks at New York University with the video feed. Inquiring minds want to know what's with Pale Male and all the girlfriends. The Ann Landers of red-tailed hawk sociology, as John Blakeman calls himself, cleared his throat and talked about mate-swapping.

An article on Page 34 about Middle School 223 in the South Bronx and the reforms established by its principal, Ramón González, misidentifies the New York University graduate school from which Mr. Gonzalez enlisted a class to help M.S. 223 develop a plan for a local boarding school. It is the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service, not the business school. The article also contains an outdated reference to Cathleen P. Black. On Thursday, after the article went to press, she resigned as schools chancellor of New York City.

Mrs. Bronfman was instrumental in Blythedale's development through her personal support and fund raising efforts for the construction of our current facility in Valhalla, New York. McMENEMY--Faith on April 7, 2011, of New York City. Beloved wife of James. Funeral private.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday misidentified the Chopin work that will be played by the pianist Evgeny Kissin as part of the Met Orchestra's program at Carnegie Hall on Monday night. It is Chopin's First Piano Concerto, not his second.

An article on Friday about the first round of the Masters misidentified a golfer who, at two under par, was among nine golfers tied for 14th place with the defending champion, Phil Mickelson. He is Kyung-Tae Kim, not Anthony Kim, who finished the first round at one over par.

When the cast of ''Jersey Shore'' gets back from Italy later this year, three of the cast members will start work on their own reality shows. MTV said Thursday that it had ordered two such spin-offs, one featuring Paul DelVecchio, known as DJ Pauly D, and the other featuring Nicole Polizzi and Jenni Farley, known as Snooki and JWoww. Each show will ''chronicle the lives all three lead away from their summer shares and housemates,'' MTV said in a news release. The network ordered twelve episodes of each show.

Citibank says it will change the way it processes customers' checks, a move that could result in fewer fees for bounced checks for account holders. Customers are being notified this week in their bank statement mailings that as of July 25, the bank will process checks in order of ''low to high''-that is, it will pay checks in order of smallest dollar amount to the largest. Currently, Citibank - as do most banks - pays checks in order of highest dollar amount to the lowest. The thinking has been that big checks are often covering important bills like mortgage or car payments.

An article on Friday about efforts to influence the redrawing of Congressional districts by state governments misstated the impact on the United States House of Representatives of a 2003 Texas redistricting plan. The addition of Republican seats helped the party strengthen its control of the House in 2004. The party did not gain control that year. (Republicans had gained control of the House in 1994.)

The musicians of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra will take a major pay cut and will be reduced in number but will not have their jobs redefined to require teaching, coaching and other forms of community outreach, according to details of a new contract agreement released by the symphony on Friday. The agreement, reached late Sunday night, ended a bitter six-month strike at the orchestra. It was approved in a vote by the players that ended on Friday afternoon, a union spokesman said. The orchestra has hastily organized free concerts on Saturday and Sunday, the first since last season, in the orchestra's home, the Max M. Fisher Music Center. Minimum salaries were $104,650, although principal players generally made more. Now, the minimum will be $79,000 next season and go up to $82,900 in the third and final year of the contract. However, each player can earn up to $6,900 more a year if they choose to take part in community outreach activities - something that many already do.

MACK--Ruth. Ruth's vitality, generosity and good will were a blessing to all. She lived a long and fruitful life and will be fondly remembered by her family and friends. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Mack family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Thomas S. Kaplan, President Matthew Bronfman, Chairman, Program Committee Sol Adler, Executive Director

Because of an editing error, an article last Saturday about the removal of the sports channel SNY from Dish Network misstated, in some copies, the games carried by SNY. It carries Mets and Big East games, not Jets games. The error was repeated in some editions in a report in the baseball roundup.

Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com. Familiarity can lead to making decisions without thinking through the consequences. The neighbors use their hands to unplug the snow blower or drivers are convinced that they can text and drive at the same time. They all know better, but every year 1,000 people lose a finger or two to snow blowers anyway, and 20 percent of car crashes with injuries are due to distracted driving.

A decades-long insider trading scheme that was fed by a corporate lawyer who worked at some of the nation's most prestigious law firms mysteriously came to a halt in 1999 before resuming five years later, the government has said. The defendants were apparently worried in 1999 that investigators might be on their trail. While the government would not arrest them until more than a decade later, it was no idle fear: The trader who federal prosecutors say turned the lawyer's tips into $32 million in illicit profits had been accused of insider trading by a brokerage firm that year.
International NATO EXPRESSES REGRET

The movie-palace splendor of Radio City Music Hall made an appropriately majestic backdrop for Explosions in the Sky, an instrumental rock band from Austin, Tex., whose music can swell to fill any grand space. The group was headlining a triple bill -- with the band Low and a solo-piano set by Eluvium, a k a Matthew Cooper -- that elevated modest brooding to monumental scale. The big-hall concert was in part a reward for indie-rock perseverance: Explosions in the Sky released its first recordings in 2000, Low in 1994. Explosions in the Sky played a continuous 74-minute set, segueing nine compositions with no encore: an unbroken reverie. The pieces began quietly, often with just a lone guitar outlining a basic chord or repeating a single note, as if meditating on the possibilities within consonance. Then other layers materialized from two more guitars, bass and drums: overlapping arpeggios, brief melodic lines, drumbeats that tapped lightly and grew increasingly martial and, sooner or later, the frenetic shimmer of tremolo-strummed chords. Loops and echoey recorded sounds, including garbled voices, could also join the mix, and eventually some pieces boiled over into crashing distortion.

MACK--Ruth. To Bill and Richard Mack, The partners and principals of AREA Property Partners express our deep condolences on the loss of your mother and grandmother. We are grateful for the full life she led and the legacy that continues on in your family and in the community.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the sale of individual cigarettes in New York City misstated the timing of the city's ban on smoking in parks and pedestrian plazas and on beaches. It goes into effect May 23; it is not currently in effect. The article also misstated, in some copies, the history of a 1975 ban on smoking in movie theaters in New York. It was imposed by state law, not by the Bloomberg administration.

It's time for the annual June wedding invitations. And although you know that your love is a love that will last forever, and that there has never been a love like yours, the truth is that half of us get divorced, and get invited to weddings. Whenever I see that thick, creamy envelope with calligraphy on it, I open it with dread. The first thing I look for is the second envelope, which either includes the words ''and guest'' or omits it. I don't blame the folks who invite only me in this time of very expensive weddings. Why should they care if, alone and cranky, I sit with married couples?

The ''In the Region'' article in some copies last Sunday, about the redevelopment of the old Curtiss-Wright aircraft-engine plant in Wood-Ridge, N.J., by AvalonBay, misstated the number of units to be contained in two new apartment buildings. It is 266, not 166. The article also misstated the status of 55,000 AvalonBay rental units around the country. They are built; they are not ''in the works.''

STRAUS--Dr. Eugene. Physician, teacher, researcher and author passed away after a long illness on April 2 in NYC. He was a Renaissance man who was Chief of Digestive Diseases at the State University of New York Health Science Center, co-chair of Dept. of Medicine and director of the largest Digestive Disease training program in the country. A gastroenterologist by training, he had a brilliant career as a biomedical researcher developing a unique test for TB used around the world. Working with Sol Berson and Rosalyn Yalow, the first woman to win a Nobel Prize in Medicine, they developed revolutionary new techniques in radioimmunoassay. Straus taught at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and other Medical Centers in NYC, co-chaired Dept. of Clinical Sciences at Montefiore with Yalow, was an Honorary member of the Endocrine Society and recently honored by SUNY Downstate for his life's work in Medicine. He published 150 medical research papers and two books, Rosalyn Yalow/Nobel Laureate & Medical Marvels, written with his son Alex Straus and illus. by Bette Korman. He is survived by his wife of 20 years Bette Korman/founder Children's Museum of Manhattan, his son Alex Straus, daughter's Sylvie StrausFigueroa and Allegra Sherrod, stepdaughter Radha Korman, six grandchildren and sister Ruth Gainer. He will be missed and mourned by all.

MARK--Manny, 89, Beloved husband of the late Judith, brother of the late Ann, the late Sidney, the late Felice and brother of Bernard and Elaine, cherished father of Bernard (Sharon) Mark, Diane (Sion) Elalouf, adored grandfather of Caryn (Hank) Finley, Jamie (Jon) Fishman, Leah (Josh) Wurzburger and Seth Elalouf. Marvelous great-grandfather of Sammy, Daniel and Hannah Wurzburger and Julia and Eve Fishman. He will be remembered for his most extraordinary generosity; his love of life; his devotion to his family; his magnificent sense of humor and for always having such a good time. Dad was one of a kind and we were so lucky to have him. Funeral service 12:00 noon, Monday at Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard, 66th Avenue, Rego Park, NY.

FLON--Sally. Passed away on March 27th after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of Jack, cherished and adored mother of Brian and Jamie (Lusher), mother-in-law of Nicholas, proud grandmother of Benjamin and Chloe, special aunt to Sharon, Vicki and Penny, and dear friend to numerous others. She will be remembered for her unquenchable zest for life, brilliant intellect, and her deep love and loyalty to her family and friends. She left an indelible mark on all those who knew her, and her generous heart, compassion and quick wit will be hugely missed. Sally served in the navy during WWII, was a talented writer, voracious reader, devoted daughter of Israel, and devotee of Jazz. A special thanks to the Veterans' Hospital for their excellent care - they called Sally their "National Treasure".

SPERO--James Sterling, 84, of Kendal at Ithaca, NY passed away Thursday, March 31, at Cayuga Medical Center after a cardiac arrest. Born August 26, 1926 in New York, NY, he was the son of Sterling D. Spero and Louise Rothschild Spero. He attended elementary and high school at the Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University in New York City where he met Cecile H. Schiffer. They were married in 1948 and lived happily until his passing. Jim attended undergraduate school as part of the Navy V-12 program at Wesleyan University and Yale University. He received an Honorable Discharge from the U.S. Navy in 1946 and was a Commissioned Ensign, U.S. Naval Reserve in 1947. He received a BA in Sociology from Yale University in 1947 and an MS in Rural Sociology at the University of Wisconsin in 1950. Jim spent his career working for Cornell Cooperative Extension, first as Count 4-H Agent in Orange County, NY and then as Senior Extension Associate, working with Cornell faculty and administrative staff on campus, in New York City, and other metropolitan areas of the state on nutrition education, urban gardening, consumer education and housing programs. He was actively involved in volunteer work with the United Way, the Tompkins County Mental Health Board, HOMES Inc. and Family and Children's Service of Ithaca. He was also appointed to the Kendal at Ithaca Board of Trustees in 2005. In 2009, Family and Children's Service of Ithaca created the Spero Family Fund for Child Psychiatry to honor Jim and Ceil for their loyal and dedicated support in advancing mental health initiatives, in children's mental health and psychiatry. In November, 2010 Jim and Ceil were chosen as Philanthropists of the Year by the Association of Fundraising Professionals, New York Finger Lakes Chapter. They have made significant gifts that transformed services and lives. Jim particularly enjoyed spending time at their cottage on Cayuga Lake with family and friends. He was a truly unforgettable man who knew how to live life fully with integrity and joy. His love for his family, great sense of humor and practical mind helped everyone around him through good times and bad. He was predeceased by his daughter Jean Spero and his brother Robert Spero. In addition to his wife, Ceil, he is survived by his children: Bette Spero of Buffalo, NY, Donald Spero (Julie Cooper) of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, Nancy Spero (Rob Sullivan) of Ithaca, NY; his grandchildren Susannah Spero and Samuel Spero; his sister Ellen Roman, his sisters-in-law Miriam Spero and Herma Shore; his first cousin Richard Cohn; his six nieces and nephews; his eight grand nieces and nephews; and many special friends. There will be no calling hours. Friends are invited to attend a celebration of his life at Kendal at Ithaca on Saturday, April 23, 2011 at 2pm. Memorial contributions may be made to "The Spero Family Fund for Child Psychiatry" at Family & Children's Service, 127 West State Street, Ithaca, NY 14850 and Kendal at Ithaca (for the Rainy Day Fund), 2230 N. Triphammer Rd., Ithaca, NY 14850. Contact Bangs Funeral Home, 607-272-1922 for more information.

The Mortgages column on March 27, about the new Good Faith Estimate disclosure form for borrowing costs, misstated the transfer tax for residential property in New York City. The combined state and city tax is 1.825 percent for properties over $500,000, not 3.025 percent, which is the combined transfer tax on such commercial property.

For Anglophiles who can't make it across the pond to celebrate the April 29 nuptials of Prince William and Kate Middleton (right), New York City has its own share of events to mark the day. It would help to be an early riser: the wedding begins at 11 a.m. in London -- 6 a.m. New York time. The New York Palace hotel (newyorkpalace.com) in Midtown gets things started at 5:30, with a formal breakfast. Revelers can watch the ceremony on several televisions while tucking into scones with marmalade and scrambled eggs with Devonshire cream. The meal ends with a Champagne toast, and attendees will receive a scented candle with a crown logo as a wedding favor. Tickets are $150.
Pop Nate Chinen

OTTENBERG--James S. Died peacefully on April 9 in Manhattan. Born February 28, 1918, this lifelong New Yorker attended Horace Mann and Lincoln, obtained a BA from Swarthmore College (1939), a JD from Harvard Law School (1942), and an MPA from NYU (1963). A World War II Air Force veteran, Jim served in the European theatre. He practiced law, but politics and public service were his passion. He worked in the New York City government at Marine and Aviation and as Deputy Commissioner of Mental Health. He became Director of the Child Study Association, and for 20 years an administrator in the psychiatric department of Bronx Lebanon Hospital. An ardent Democrat, Jim participated in many campaigns, including the Stevenson and Kennedy Presidential runs. He co-authored The Lexington Democratic Story and You, Your Child and Drugs. In his 80s and 90s, Jim served on the Auxiliary Board of Metropolitan Hospital. An avid jogger, devoted Broadway and swing jazz fan, he suffered and gloried in the football Giants. But most of all, this remarkable man was the beloved husband of Margaret Davies for 70 years; father of Jeffrey, Susan, Betsy Cherkasky, and Jill Muscat; grandfather ("Papa Jim") of Eli, Ethan and Dinah Cherkasky, Susannah Cherkasky Heyworth, Neil and Timothy Muscat; great-grandfather of Cecilia and Philippa Heyworth; father-in-law of Michael Cherkasky and Josh Muscat, and grandfather-in-law of James Heyworth and Lyndsea Cochrane Cherkasky. A Memorial Service will be held at the John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont on Sunday, May 15 at 11:00am.

BOWE--Edward T.,M.D. In memory of Edward T. Bowe, MD, 80, who died peacefully on March 26, 2011. Beloved husband of CarolSue, loving father of Deirdre, Daphne, Ashton, Christopher and Cordelia. Dedicated physician, Emeritus Professor at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons, passionate musician. A memorial concert will be held on April 28, 2011, from 5 to 7pm at the Myrna J. Daniels Auditorium, Vivian & Seymour Milstein Family Heart Center, 173 Ft. Washington Avenue, New York City. Donations: Stockbridge Symphonia, Ed Bowe Memorial Fund, 44 Taconic Avenue, Lenox, MA 01240.

L JUBLJANA, the capital of Slovenia, may wrap around the foot of its medieval castle, but more contemporary attractions are within walking distance of the city's true heart, the banks of the Ljubljanica River. Students still convene under the statue of the beloved Slovene poet France Preseren at the river's edge, but many head just a few blocks away to an abandoned jail and a former adult movie house that have been transformed, respectively, into a hip youth hostel and thriving art film complex. The city's newest gathering place lies just upriver from the historic triple bridges known as Tromostovje: The recently opened Butcher's Bridge, with its sleek glass-bottomed construction (women wearing skirts or dresses beware!) connects pedestrians to an indoor-outdoor market designed by the Slovene architect Joze Plecnik. As in Florence and Paris, Ljubljanans participate in a romantic phenomenon known as ''love locks'' -- couples affix padlocks inscribed with messages on the bridge railing and toss the keys into the river. AMANDA SUMMER SLAVIN
RYE COLONIAL $1,695,000

LONGTIME stargazers learned the basics of the night sky the hard way -- with pencils, star charts and lots of patience with their telescopes. Now high-tech equipment and smartphone apps are making the task a lot less daunting for beginners.

The parks glow with cascades of forsythia and fields of daffodils, and fashion is at last stepping out of its winter cocoon. Light wool trench coats take on any chill, and high-hemmed trousers steal the thunder from skirts. Dangling earrings and flowing nun's habits flutter in the breeze.

AFTER falling for two years in the wake of the financial crisis and the recession, executive pay is soaring again. The median salary for C.E.O.'s at about 200 big American companies rose 12 percent last year, while the average was up 20 percent, according to data compiled by Equilar. By comparison, average pay for American workers in the private sector rose 2.1 percent in 2010, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Many large corporations have not yet publicly disclosed compensation, so paydays for other executives could surpass those of the 30 C.E.O.'s listed below. For instance, Leslie Moonves of the CBS Corporation made $43 million in 2009, which would have easily earned him one of the top spots that year. But the company had not disclosed his pay in time for publication.
Manhattan Upper West Side $350,000

FRONT PAGE A Diplomatic Memo article last Sunday, about the growing possibility that, even without an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement, the United Nations General Assembly might approve a resolution in September granting statehood to Palestinians on Israeli-controlled land referred incompletely to the options available to the United States for blocking such a resolution. It has no veto power in the General Assembly, as the article stated, but such a resolution would first require a recommendation from the Security Council, where the United States could exercise a veto.

Last year the N.H.L. general managers acknowledged that something was wrong about the shootout, the postgame penalty-shot contest it installed in 2005, when it abolished tie results. They ruled that this season, shootout wins would be thrown out if teams were tied in the standings, and it was under that proviso that the Rangers entered their last game behind Carolina in the race for the final Eastern playoff spot. They had the same number of points, but the Hurricanes were ahead because they had more nonshootout victories.

NOT content with being the first to fly solo across the Atlantic in 1927, Charles Lindbergh was determined to improve navigation for those at sea as well as in the air. After his history-making flight, he contacted Longines, the Swiss watch manufacturer, to create a timepiece to help calculate one's location using longitude. The reissue of the Lindbergh Hour Angle watch ($4,725) features the oversize textured crown. The 42 hours of power reserve, longer than the duration of Lindbergh's original flight, should outlast a plane trip these days, whether flying solo or crowded in coach. BRUCE PASK
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel abandons students' advice on London for more mature haunts, including shops, restaurants and museums.

An article last Sunday on Texas' Republican delegation in Congress listed an incorrect committee assignment for Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison. She is the senior Republican on the Commerce, Justice, and Science subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee, not the senior Republican on the Military Construction and Veterans Affairs subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee.

BLUMBERG--Baruch. The Members and Staff of the American Philosophical Society, the nation's oldest learned society founded by Benjamin Franklin in 1743, are deeply saddened by the death of Baruch S. Blumberg, who served as President of the Society from 2005-2011, and who was elected a Member in 1986. Dr. Blumberg's vitality, inquisitiveness, distinction as a scientist, and dedication to our founding mission of "promoting useful knowledge" enhanced his years of leadership and service on the Society's behalf. He believed that "a passion for exploration is deeply rooted in the American character" and established the Lewis and Clark Grants for Exploration and Field Research at the APS in 2004. To date, this program has supported the work of more than 250 younger scientists and scholars. At the request of Dr. Blumberg's family, memorial contributions may be made to the Baruch S. Blumberg Research Grant Fund c/o the American Philosophical Society, 104 South Fifth St., Philadelphia, PA 19106. The APS community sends heartfelt condolences to Dr. Blumberg's wife Jean, their four children, and nine grandchildren. Mary Patterson McPherson, Executive Officer American Philosophical Society

THE long-running joke about opera is that a performance is not over until the fat lady sings. But some up-and-coming singers are determined to keep that fat under control. Dr. Jenny Cho, one of several physicians who are on hand during Metropolitan Opera performances, said opera's deep notes required core strength and a good cardiovascular system. ''Singing comes from the lower abdominal muscles, and without strong abs, it's hard to do it well and control the breath,'' Dr. Cho said. ''You also need large lung volume to generate sound, which requires stamina.''

The 30-Minute Interview last Sunday about Glenn J. Rufrano, the chief executive of Cushman and Wakefield, misstated the amount of space leased by Beijing Vantone at One World Trade Center. It is 200,000 square feet, not 1.25 million square feet, which represents the total amount committed to by Beijing Vantone and another prospective tenant, Condé Nast.

An article last Sunday about long-distance assessments of Japan's nuclear crisis by experts in atomic forensics misspelled the surname of an executive vice president of Areva NC, who is a nuclear engineer and visiting scholar at Stanford University. He is Alan Hanson, not Hansen.

FOR two scorching days in Paris last May, the Champs-Élysées was closed to traffic, covered over with grass. Visitors traipsed through a forest of Lebanese cedar trees and snapped photos of goat pens and stacked pyramids of vegetables, with the Arc de Triomphe looming above. It was all part of Nature Capitale, a large-scale installation created by the French street artist Gad Weil, who timed it to coincide with International Biodiversity Day, an annual event sponsored by the United Nations. The spectacle drew two million visitors, among them two surprise guests: the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, and his wife, Carla Bruni, who wore jeans and an untucked oxford shirt with rolled-up sleeves, providing a bit of barnyard chic in the Eighth Arrondissement. The event -- the next Nature Capitale is scheduled for June in Lyon -- was equal parts ecological celebration and fund-raiser for two groups: Jeunes Agriculteurs, an organization of young French farmers, and France Bois Forêt, devoted to the French forest and timber industries. In typical French fashion, it also included a protest against a dip in agriculture prices. Despite its reputation for fur and foie gras, Paris had begun to embrace the ecological movement with the earnestness of leading eco-minded cities like Copenhagen and Vancouver.

Started by a group of friends from a fantasy league to write about basketball for fun, FreeDarko ended up becoming the first of what became a long line of irreverent basketball blogs. After countless posts over the years and two successful books about the N.B.A., the site will publish its final post Monday.

BOLAND--James P.,MD, FACS. Dr. James P. Boland of Charleston, WV passed away peacefully at home on April 5th, 2011 after a long battle with metastatic urothelial cancer. He was born and raised in Philadelphia, PA, where he graduated from St. Joseph's University and subsequently Jefferson Medical College in 1956 with his Medical Degree. He completed his residency in Surgery at Graduate Hospital Philadelphia and completed a Cardiothoracic Surgery Fellowship at Parkland Hospital in Dallas, TX in 1963. During this time, he cared for Gov. Connally, shot during the assassination of John F. Kennedy and is listed in the Warren Report in this capacity. He served in the Navy on the US FDR from 1958-1960, worked at Bethesda Naval Hospital during Operation Desert Storm, and was in the Navy Reserves until 1996. His life and career have been defined by serving his country, the underserved, and he has dedicated his life to the care and training of others, travelling to many countries to establish local surgical training programs and teaching advanced surgical technique, including trips to Vietnam in 1972, Nigeria and Egypt in 1975, Guatemala in 1976, Taiwan in 1980, Haiti in 1985, and worked on a Sioux Reservation in South Dakota in 1979. Throughout this time, he was a Professor and Chairman of the Department of Surgery of West Virginia University, Charleston Division. He founded the department and surgical residency program in Charleston and served as Chief of Staff for several years. More notable than any specific accomplishment is the pattern of service and education throughout his life, focused not on the most glamorous aspects of medicine but instead targeted on serving underserved areas. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Kathryn Watts Boland of Dallas, TX; his brother Rev. Msgr. John P. Boland of Philadelphia, PA; his six children; and nine grandchildren. He was a dedicated teacher, mentor, and advocate for his trainees and patients. It is unquestionable that his was a life of service to his family, his community, his state, and unwaveringly to his country. He was well loved by all and will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, please send your contributions to the James P. Boland, MD, Department of Surgery Endowed Research Fund c/o Jackie Rosencrance, WVU Robert C. Byrd HSC, 3110 MacCorkle Ave., Charleston, WV, 25304. Questions regarding donations can be sent to: jrosencrance@hsc.wvu.edu.

HALPERIN--Dr. Anthony Lionel Paul. With immense sadness, family and friends of Dr. Anthony Lionel Paul Halperin mourn Anthony's untimely passing on April 7, 2011. The beloved son of Dr. Edward and Beth Weingast Halperin, brother of Alexander Halperin and Dr. Anna Halperin Rosen, nephew, grandson, and friend to many, Anthony will be deeply missed by his family and loved ones. A graduate of New Rochelle High School, Brown University, and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School, Anthony was an incredibly bright and talented young man who was recognized for his leadership, intelligence, and patience. He loved to travel and he studied and worked in Europe as well as South America connecting to people of different ages and backgrounds. Anthony possessed a unique curiosity about the world, he asked questions as a scientist, a humanist, and as a friend. He found the good in everyone. A funeral service will be held on Monday, April 11 at 10:00am at Beth El Synagogue, 1324 North Ave., New Rochelle, NY 10804.

Hotel guests may want to think twice now before walking off with that bathrobe. Linen Technology Tracking, a company in Miami, has patented a washable RFID chip that can be sewn into towels, robes and bed sheets, allowing hotels to keep track of their linens. So far, three hotels -- in Honolulu, Miami and Manhattan -- are using the chip, said Linen Technology Tracking's executive vice president, William Serbin. He said the hotels did not want their names used.

COHN--Martin B.,90, former president of QED Appliance Distribution Co., died peacefully at home in Sarasota, FL, on March 27, with his wife and sons at his side. A Bronx native, he graduated from Baruch College and served in the Army Air Corps in the Pacific in WWII. A former vice president of Welbilt Corp., his career spanned six decades. He long resided in Rockville Centre, NY. He is terribly missed by his loving family: wife Marion; sons Kenneth, Roger, and Lewis; five grandchildren; great-granddaughter; and others.
GRONER--Miriam. April 8, 2011. Holocaust survivor. Survived by loving family. Services at 9am Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 76 St.

In a spruced-up former garage on a bleak section of the Via Prenestina in Rome, diners use injera, the traditional Ethiopian sourdough bread, to scoop up richly spiced stews. Is it an atypical Roman meal? Yes and no. The Italian capital is packed with restaurants and trattorias serving local specialties. But, of course, not every Rome dweller is Roman.

THE Swedish automaker Saab, which went through a near-death experience as it left General Motors ownership a little more than a year ago, has temporarily shut down production as it negotiates with suppliers who have gone unpaid. ''The interruptions are caused by shortages in material shipments in part related to the tight liquidity situation,'' Saab said in a statement last week. ''The company is confident to soon resume normal operations, with the additional funding that we expect to secure.''

BIGELOW--Edward. Eddie died April 4, 2011 at the age of 93. He leaves his beloved wife Carla Bigelow, of Cornwall, CT; his nephew and niece, Hal and Marion Bigelow; stepchildren Timothy Stevens, Brooke Stevens and wife Karen, Sara Nerone, April Stevens and husband Sandy Neubauer; six grandchildren; and two great- nephews. He spent his career with the New York City Ballet initially as a dancer and then for over 40 years as the company's manager. We will always remember his kindness, strapping good looks and unending generosity. Words cannot express how deeply he was loved or how much he will be missed. Services will be held at the North Cornwall Meeting House, Town Street, Cornwall, at 11am, April 16.

The Slipstream column last Sunday, about advances in visual analytics, misstated the relationship of Stamen Design, a firm in San Francisco, to mondowindow.com, which shows airline passengers a satellite map of the landscape below them. Stamen designed the site for a client; it does not own it.

George Washington High School Valedictorian, Hunter College graduate, dancer with Martha Graham, New York City schoolteacher and award winning artist. She will be deeply missed by her loving family: her children Ellen Freyer Poss (Sam), Carol Mendez (Paul), her grandchildren: Daniel (Joanne), Adam, Jonathan (Karen), and Caryn (Rod) and her great-grandchildren: Spencer, Dylan, Payton, Brett, Dylan, Harrison and Cameron.

A review on March 27 about ''Future Babble: Why Expert Predictions Are Next to Worthless, and You Can Do Better,'' by Dan Gardner, misstated the university affiliation of Philip Tetlock, whose work Gardner takes as his starting point. Tetlock is a professor at the University of Pennsylvania, not a retired professor at the University of California, Berkeley, where he previously worked.

Sidney Lumet, a director who preferred the streets of New York to the back lots of Hollywood and whose stories of conscience -- ''12 Angry Men,'' ''Serpico,'' ''Dog Day Afternoon,'' ''The Verdict,'' ''Network'' -- became modern American film classics, died Saturday morning at his home in Manhattan. He was 86. His stepdaughter, Leslie Gimbel, said the cause was lymphoma.

WHO needs Westminster Abbey? If you want to be among the throngs celebrating the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton, all you need is a MetroCard and an alarm clock. New York restaurants, hotels and event spaces will open as early as 5 a.m. on April 29 for royal-wedding viewing parties (live coverage of the wedding ceremony begins at 11 a.m. London time, or 6 a.m. New York time). At night, the events will continue in restaurants and ballrooms, with dancing and video highlights from the ceremony. So don a fascinator and ready yourself for William and Kate look-alike contests, royal trivia, breakfast bangers, tea, scones and, of course, Champagne.

THERE is no evidence that safety investigations conducted by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration have been influenced by former agency officials who now work for automakers or the former auto officials who work for the agency, said a report released on Thursday by the Office of the Inspector General for the Transportation Department, which oversees N.H.T.S.A. The report was the result of an investigation that was requested by Congress last year during its hearings into sudden acceleration on Toyotas and whether the safety agency had acted properly in its investigation.

MACK--Ruth Kaufman, passed away of natural causes in Palm Beach Florida on April 7, 2011. She was born in Manhattan on November 28, 1914 and spent her youth in Williamsberg Brooklyn. She graduated at the age of 15 with High Honors at Eastern District High School in Manhattan. She walked the Williamsberg Bridge to school most days to save two cents for public transportation. She attended Hunter College in Manhattan. Her life was totally devoted to her family and Jewish charities of which the charities were: Yeshiva University where she received an honorary doctorate. Along with her husband, H.B. Mack, they were founders and benefactors of Long Island Jewish Hospital (now known as North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System); Boys Town of Jerusalem; Albert Einstein College of Medicine; and benefactor at the Jewish Theological Seminary. She taught Hebrew at the Hillcrest Jewish Center where she and her husband were founders and benefactors. Ruth Mack was amongst the leadership of the UJA and the Federation of Jewish charities. She was a member of the Board and Vice President of Temple Emanuel of Palm Beach. She is survived by her four sons: Earle, William, David and Fredric; six grandchildren: Richard, Stephen, Hailey, Jason, Andrew and Beatrice; and three great grandchildren: Harrison, Dylan and Tucker. A private funeral for family will be held Sunday. The Family will be receiving friends at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, NYC on Sunday from 4:30 to 7:30pm and on Monday and Tuesday between 5:30pm and 8:00pm.

An essay on March 27 about the responsibilities of the mainstream media in an era of partisan coverage misstated the role of James O'Keefe in the recent so-called sting aimed at National Public Radio, during which an NPR executive voiced his dislike of Republicans and the Tea Party. O'Keefe arranged for two of his associates to pose as donors to NPR; he did not pose as one himself.

9 P.M. (13, 49) UPSTAIRS DOWNSTAIRS ''Masterpiece Classic'' returns to 165 Eaton Place in London, almost 40 years after the premiere of the landmark series on PBS, with new characters and a couple of familiar faces (including Nico Mirallegro, above) in this three-part sequel, set in 1936. Jean Marsh reprises her Emmy-winning role as the parlor maid Rose Buck, rehired as the housekeeper by the new residents, Sir Hallam Holland (Ed Stoppard) and his wife, Lady Agnes (Keeley Hawes). Eileen Atkins, who created the original show with Ms. Marsh, takes on the role of Lady Maud Holland, Hallam's imperious and eccentric mother, whose return from India with a Sikh secretary and a monkey in tow interferes with her daughter-in-law's management of the house. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley said Ms. Marsh and Ms. Atkins are ''exactly what this delightful and absorbing drama requires.'' The new ''Upstairs Downstairs'' ''sticks to the rules established by the original,'' she added, ''and defies the odds by being as good, and in some ways, even better.'' 7 P.M. (CBS) 60 MINUTES No one is allowed to borrow from the Vatican Library, except the pope. (Those who wish to view documents must apply.) And no wonder: the archive holds some of the world's most precious works of art and treasure, including the Codex Vaticanus Graecus 1209, the oldest-known nearly complete manuscript of the Bible; a copy of a letter from St. Peter, written by a disciple in 200 A.D.; and religious figures depicted in the Greek New Testament Bible, above. Morley Safer reports.

THE Salone del Mobile design fair in Milan starts this week, and every year it's a similar story: chairs and sofas as far as the eye can see and yet not so many places to sit and relax. In a nod to the once-abundant greenery in this city, Marni has installed a courtyard oasis in front of its shop at via Spiga 50. ''We wanted to pay tribute to Italian flora and encourage the return of plants to our urban centers,'' said Consuelo Castiglioni, the label's designer, about the lavender, kitchen herbs and mulberry bushes that replaced the camellia trees that typically decorate the space.

CHEMTOB--Linda Shapiro, of Manhattan, and Honolulu died on April 6, 2011. Formerly of Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, and Baltimore, she was the daughter of the late Alex Grass, the founder of the Rite Aid drugstore chain, and Lois Lehrman Grass. She is survived by her husband, Claude, a Professor of Psychiatry at New York University School of Medicine; her daughter Rachel Shapiro, and her husband Christopher Grymes; and her son Adam Shapiro. In addition, she is survived by her sister, Elizabeth Grass Weese, and her brother Roger Grass. She received her BA from Clark University, her MA from the University of North Carolina, and her JD from Catholic University's Columbus School of Law. She was a corporate attorney for many years. She had a long-standing commitment to classical chamber music; this became her professional and philanthropic focus. For this, she was the recipient of numerous awards recognizing her for public leadership in articulating the needs and goals in music and art education. She was founding Executive Director of Concertante, an internationally acclaimed chamber music ensemble that performs and expands the string sextet repertoire. She founded the Arts for Talented Youth (ATY) program at the Peabody Institute. ATY was one of the first secondary school music program to develop and use a structured curriculum integrating dancers, instrumentalists, and singers. Until her death, she was a Vice-President of the Elaine Kaufman Cultural Center, as well as serving as the Chairman of the Special Music School's Participating Board. The Special Music School is the only school in the United States that integrates a public school education with structured musical instrument training (the musical education is supported by the Kaufman Center-the private partner). Linda served as a member of the board of Concert Artists Guild, Chamber Music America, Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, Mid-Atlantic Arts Foundation, the National Guild of Community Schools of the Arts, and the Peabody Institute.

The crossword on March 13 provided an erroneous clue for 93-Across, seeking the answer ''Nausea.'' The clue should have read, ''Sartre novel'' -- not ''Novel for which Sartre declined the Nobel Prize.'' (The award he declined in 1964 was for his body of work, not for that particular novel.)

Saturday, 4:42 p.m. | Updated Supporters of New York City's parks and gardens have long asked residents of nearby buildings to help pay for the upkeep of these green spaces. Consider the tulips, cherry trees and begonias along the median of Park Avenue. Mary Woodard Lasker, a philanthropist and a champion of medical research, was considered a pioneer in the 1950s when she urged her fellow citizens to make donations for the plantings on the avenue. That led to the creation of the Fund for Park Avenue, which, like the Central Park Conservancy and other groups that raise money for city parks, depends on annual donations from neighboring buildings and their residents.

Flyover Additional images atnytimes.com/magazine. The jagged topography and semiarid climate that make farming an exercise in adaptability in the remote Monegros region of northeastern Spain also make it a painterly abstraction. High concentrations of gypsum in the foothills -- an indication that the area was once a seabed -- contrast sharply with flatter farmland. The area is planted with what grows despite a scarcity of water: cereal grains like wheat, barley and corn. For several days in June 2010, the photographer Edward Burtynsky says he rented ''a pilot, a fuel truck and a helicopter'' and, from 2,000 feet up, documented the haphazardly patterned and colored crop fields roughly carved into the spaces between darker rock formations, after the crops were harvested. ''You can still see a little bit of the earth and the color of the dried crop,'' Burtynsky says. ''I think the combination of those two things really created the kind of color palate that I like.''

A picture caption with an article last Sunday about the memoir by the former baseball player and executive Bill White misstated the status of Stan Musial with the St. Louis Cardinals in 1964. He did not play with the team; he had retired as a player after the previous season and become a Cardinals' vice president.

ALONG the shores of the Indian Ocean, as the coastline east of Adelaide, Australia, wends its rocky way toward Melbourne, lies one of the world's classic drives: the Great Ocean Road. Here, brutal, slicing surf and weather pound malleable limestone and sandstone, eating away at the Australian continent, and leaving mile after mile of sweeping vistas of sculptured cliffs, towers and arches framed against the roiling turquoise sea. I first traveled the Great Ocean Road in 2002, and I still remember beams of sunlight cutting through the clouds to illuminate 150-foot stone pillars jutting out of the sea, the last stalwarts of land in its eternal losing battle with the ocean. As my wedding approached last fall, that indelible image was enough to convince me that the drive would be the perfect way to begin a two-month honeymoon through Australia and New Zealand; we'd camp on the beach, take surfing lessons, hike alongside kangaroos and koalas and luxuriate in a landscape so blissful and majestic that we'd be in full honeymoon mode by the time we reached Melbourne.

There are certain popular diversions -- television, video games, the Internet -- that we pursue so deliriously we end up hating ourselves for loving them. Others we brightly recast as the duties of citizenship: newspapers, public radio, sports. All the while, cottage industries crop up to freak us out about our every last cultural pursuit. In recent years, it's Internet use that's been styled as potentially sick, and ''Internet addiction'' a new reason for self-hatred.
We want to see real structural, cultural-type changes tied to this debt ceiling. We're not interested in a one-off kind of savings, or anything small. REPRESENTATIVE

BAKER--Howard, passed away suddenly while vacationing in Jupiter, Florida, on February 28th, with his beloved Cynthia by his side. The cause of death was heart failure. Howard was known for his deep generosity, courage, humor, and intellect. During World War II, at a time when the Navy was suffering its most severe casualties from kamikaze attacks on Okinawa, Howard volunteered to join the Navy at the age of 17. He served for two years, with a commitment and humility which would characterize his many relationships and contributions during his 83 years. Howard was a New York State licensed professional Engineer. He was a proud graduate of Cornell University, where he received his Bachelor of Science in Engineering degree in 1951. Together with his brother, Norman, he began a successful construction business based in Long Island City. During his 50 years as a contractor in New York, Howard worked on many of the cities most prominent landmarks, including Morgan Post Office, Trump Tower, The Museum of Natural History, and the Brooklyn Bridge. Howard was also reknowned for taking on dangerous projects which other contractors declined, accomplishing the restoration of structures in danger of imminent collapse. In addition to his professional pursuits, Howard was an avid athlete, who for many years served as a volunteer on the National Ski Patrol. He was a director of the United States Amateur Ski Association, winning many races himself. He supported the U.S. Ski Team, and created standards for safer skiing. He was a dedicated member of the Miramar Ski Club in Waitsfield, Vermont, and also served as their president. Additionally, Howard was a board member of the Queens Businessman's Chapter of the American Red Cross and was honored for his many years of service to that organization. Howard suffered from Parkinson's Disease for 15 years. Despite the many physical trials from this disease, Howard maintained his signature humor, grace, and unflagging energy. When Howard could no longer pursue his many athletic interests, he and Cynthia became more active in the Conservative Synagogue of Fifth Avenue. Until his death Howard served as both a Board Member of the synagogue and recently as First Vice President. One business associate summed up his remembrance of Mr. Baker by saying that "In the 25 years I knew him, I never heard him say anything bad about anyone, and never heard anyone say anything bad about him." Howard's generosity to family, friends, business associates, and to the many charities he supported will long be remembered. In addition to Cynthia, Howard is survived by his brother Norman, who was his lifetime business partner, and by his nephews Daniel Baker (Emmy), and Mitchell Baker (Thom), and niece Elizabeth Atwood (Bill) and cherished grandnieces and nephews Olivia, Emeline, Jacob, and Emil. Donations can be made in Howard's memory to the National Parkinson's Foundation for Research and to the Conservative Synagogue of Fifth Avenue.

BOYLAN--Brendan James, D.D.S.,died on Thursday, the 31st of March, 2011 in his home in Ghent, NY from complications of Parkinson's Disease. He was born in The Bronx, NY, on the 4th of February, 1928 to the late James Aloysius Boylan and Margaret R. Boylan. He maintained an exclusive practice of Orthodontics on the 26th floor of the Fuller Building at 57th & Madison over a career that spanned 50 years. He proudly served in The Marines from 1946-1948. He matriculated to the University of Vermont whereupon he completed a B.A. degree in Psychology in 1951. He was graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a D.D.S. degree in 1955 and a Certificate of Orthodontics in 1957. Dr. Brendan (or "Mickey", as he was affectionately known) Boylan was a member of the Sigma Phi fraternity at the University of Vermont as well as the dental honor fraternity Omicron Kappa Upsilon and president of the dental fraternity Delta Sigma Delta. He was a member of the American Association of Orthodontics and past president of the New York Academy of Dentistry. He was the beloved husband of Micheline H. Boylan with whom he resided in the Upper East Side of Manhattan as well as their home in Ghent, NY. He was predeceased by his parents and beloved sister Joan R. Mancusi. He was the loving brother of James Aloysius Boylan, Jr.; the loving father, born by Joan A. Millang, of daughter Tracy Ann Zaccario, son Brendan Neil Boylan, and daughter Jennifer Joan Anderson. He was the loving grandfather of Vincent James Zaccario and Anthony Michael Zaccario of Valrico, FL; Henry MacLeod Boylan of Los Gatos, CA; and Corinne Emily Anderson and Connor James Anderson of Delmar, NY. A memorial service was held at St. James Parish Catholic Church in Chatham, NY on Saturday, the 2nd of April. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the University of Pennsylvania School of Orthodontics or to kageno.org, a multi-faceted community development project that transforms impoverished communities into places of opportunity and hope.

WIENER--Doris, 88, died in her sleep on April 6, 2011 after a brief illness. Renowned dealer in Indian and Southeast Asian art. Born to Morris and Bertha Levin during the Russian Civil War, she was raised in the Bronx with her two brothers, Edward and Louis. In 1944, she married the late Ed Wiener, a prominent modernist jewelry designer. They began their careers in the art circles of Greenwich Village and Provincetown during the early days of abstract expressionism. A pioneer in her field, Mrs. Wiener first traveled to India and Southeast Asia in 1966, at a time when there were few professional opportunities for women. It was against this backdrop that, starting in the late 1960s, she organized ground-breaking sale exhibitions of Indian and Southeast Asian sculpture and painting. Among her many clients were John D. Rockefeller III, Igor Stravinksy and Jacqueline Kennedy. Iconic works of art from The Doris Wiener Gallery formed the basis of many major museum collections of Asian art world-wide. These include The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Cleveland Museum of Art, The Norton Simon Museum of Art, Asia Society and The Brooklyn Museum, among others. Mrs. Wiener remained a leading dealer in her field until her death. She is survived by two daughters, Michele Caplan and Nancy Wiener, their husbands, Jonathan Caplan and Corwith Hamill, and three grandchildren: Daniel Caplan, Jeffery Caplan, and Jonathan Hamill. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to charity.

Many travel companies offer discounts and deals through their Facebook pages. Expedia, however, is upping the ante: It has created a sweepstakes that offers more than $1 million in prizes, including five trips that each cost $100,000 or more. To make the sweepstakes engaging, the company turned the competition into a game called Expedia FriendTrips, said Tim MacDonald, Expedia's senior vice president. The rules are fairly straightforward: at facebook.com/expedia, ''fans'' of Expedia can start a plane (becoming its pilot) and point it toward one of the 13 destinations offered as prizes. Pilots can then invite their friends to join them on the plane, each of which holds five passengers. Everyone on the plane is eligible to win.

The answer to a reader's question in the Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the origin of the name of the Lathrop, a building at 46 West 83rd Street, described imprecisely the home of Isaac Polstein, a developer of the building, before he arrived in the United States. It was in a section of the province of Vilna that is now in Belarus. He was not from the city of Vilna, now Vilnius, Lithuania's capital.

The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports for April 1-7. 1. AS UCONN PLAYS ON, PRIZED RECRUIT NATE MILES FLOUNDERS A life playing basketball seems unlikely. Miles says he cannot afford to play at a local recreation center because he lacks the $10 fee.

FRENZE--Stanley B.,85, died on March 28, of complications from heart surgery. He grew up in Garden City, NY, but has lived in Philadelphia, PA, and East Hampton, NY, for the past 35 years. His academic studies were interrupted when he left Cornell University and served as an electronic technician on the U.S.S. Nevada during WWII. He returned to graduate from Cornell and Cornell Law School in 1951. His 30 year career as a corporate lawyer for the General Electric Co. included working in G.E. Capital and G.E. International divisions. He is survived by his wife, Nancy, three sons, Christopher, Gerard, and David, one daughter, Jenifer Donahue, and 11 grandchildren. Family and close friends will remember his sharp wit and a remarkable sense of humor which he managed to maintain throughout his ordeal.

''In the Region'' article in some copies on March 27, about MediterraneanTowersSouth, a Fort Lee co-op whose board wants to convert it to a condominium, quoted incorrectly from comments by a board member, Denis Glennon. He did not describe a neighboring co-op, Mediterranean Towers North, as ''in hock.''

SMOLER--Eleanor (nee Grotsky). We mourn the passing of Eleanor Smoler 91, of Palm Beach, Florida and formerly of Harrison, NY. Wife of the late Sidney Smoler. Loving mother of Charles(Carol) and Joanne Sterling Feldman (Ron). Loving grandmother of Adam and Marc. Beloved aunt of 19 nieces and nephews.

To the Editor: Re ''A Paris Farewell'' by Amy M. Thomas (March 27), Mademoiselle Amy, you have lived my dream of a sojourn in Paris. I am now 70 years old, but your images will keep my dream alive. I still have tomorrow.

Tweeting Since January 2007Followers 3,365Twitter Bio Dir. of tech innovation @ NYSenate.gov; co-founder/partner of @NuAMS;@digidem advisor; member of #BikeNYC,#TN2020 & @RSAorg. The five-year history of Twitter is short, especially when compared to the life, so far, of Noel Hidalgo, who describes himself as ''old enough to remember when friends had black-and-white TVs and push-button cable boxes.'' Yet Mr. Hidalgo has already embodied four different Twitter accounts: @TaxiNYC, where he chronicled his path to becoming a taxi driver in 2008; @NewAmsterdamize, his former feed of cycling nerdom; @noneck, his primary public Twitter identity; and a private Twitter persona where he composes personal messages ''without hindrance.''

DELSON--Gertrude, 88. Loving wife, mother and educator. Survived her husband Barney and son Matthew. Survived by her son Sam. Memorial service 2:15pm April 10, Plaza Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

RICE--James D.,Memorial Service for James D. Rice, Former Commissioner of Human Rights for Nassau County, will be held April 15, 2011, 7-8:30pm at Memorial Presbyterian Church: 189 Babylon Turnpike, Roosevelt, NY.

BARNES--Theo. Theo Barnes A.K.A. Theodore Barnes Stinchecum, AEA, ASCAP. Acted in leading character parts, including the title role in the national tour of "Hadrian VII." General Director of Theater Practice, where he trained actors and originated new performance works and plays. Part of the core company of the Judson Poets Theater in its heyday. Elsewhere he directed, designed and translated for the stage. Barnes graduated from St. John's College, Annapolis, MD. From Baltimore, he is survived by sister, Ida Belle Combs, nieces and nephews, former wife, Amanda Mayer Stinchecum, and his longtime partner, the Rev. Jerry Fargo. A celebration of his life is scheduled at Trinity Church (Episcopal), Asbury Park, NJ, Saturday, April 16 at 1pm. fargo--barnes@verizon.net
MACK--Ruth. We extend our love and condolences to the entire Mack family. Ruth will always be remembered by her devotion to her family and to Jewish charities. Love, The Krauss Family

To the Editor: Once again a glowing article was written about Seattle in ''36 Hours in Seattle'' (March 27), and once again Seattle has proved itself unwilling or unable to live up to the promise. It is raining as I write, and rain is forecast all weekend. Why not showcase someplace that can deliver on the sunshine, like San Diego, Las Vegas, Dallas or Miami, and leave us alone in our damp and cold exile?

Juan Manuel Garcia Delgado, 20: At that moment we were talking about the death of a friend, and I was just thinking what a bummer it was. The day it went down, we told Chino not to go, because there was going to be a soccer game where there was no security, smack in the middle of neighborhoods that had a history of violence. He went to play, and just after the game ended, they killed him. Shot him in the body, then after he died, in the head.

Here's a reader's response to Neil Genzlinger's comic essay about television reality shows -- actual and made up. ''How about 'I'll Eat It (if You Don't Want It)': People who have recently ended up on the street after losing their homes and savings compete with one another for food left on tables or thrown into the Dumpsters outside exclusive Beverly Hills eateries. And 'Dancing With the Fat Cats!': Wall Street pirates, banksters and other corporate thieves get to tell their individual tales of fleecing the public, and then kick up their heels in a weekly dance competition. As in everything else, they contemptuously disregard all the rules.''

DELAMATER--Charles Hall, of Mystic, CT, formerly of Weekapaug, RI, and Jupiter Island, FL passed away on March 10 at his home. Born in Manhattan on October 1, 1911 to Charles H and Ethel P Delamater, he is predeceased by his beloved wife Eleanor Ainslie Delamater. He is survived by a much-loved son, Charles R. Delamater and step daughters, Gay W. Squire and Susan W. Mackay as well as grandchildren, Roger W. Squire III, William C. Squire, Ainslie M. Sugarman and Benjamin Mackay. Charlie attended the Collegiate School in Manhattan, the Dean School in Santa Barbara and Berkshire School, Sheffield, MA graduating in 1930. In the 1930's, Charlie resided in Manhattan and was a trooper in Squadron A, New York State's first mounted militia. During World War II, he served three years with the 9th and 12th Army Air Forces as a Major in the Mediterranean Theatre. His tour of duty took him through North Africa, Sicily, Italy, France and Germany. Following the war, Charlie lived for several years in Manhattan where he met and married Eleanor. They moved to West Hartford, CT where he established his own business, Delamater Distributing Corp., which he ran until his retirement in 1978. Very much a sportsman, Charlie enjoyed many pursuits. He was an accomplished golfer and horseman, enjoyed hunting, fishing, wildlife photography and in his younger years, tennis. Through his life he was a member of many clubs including the Racquet Club, the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, The Hartford Golf Club, The Misquamicut Club, The Seminole Golf Club and the Tequesta Country Club. From 1977 to 1986, he served as Chairman of the Green Committee at the Misquamicut Club, Watch Hill, RI, a task he much enjoyed. He was, as a friend remarked, "truly a gentleman of the old school" and he will be long remembered by many for his wit and charm. A celebration of Charlie's long and colorful life will be held on Saturday, July 16 at the Misquamicut Club, Ocean View Highway, Watch Hill, RI. In lieu of flowers, gifts to the Weekapaug Foundation for Conservation or the Salt Ponds Coalition would be appreciated.

STRAUS--Dr. Eugene W.,Emeritus Professor of Medicine at SUNY Downstate, author, and infinitely generous father, died April 2nd. Surviving are his five grandchildren, three children, sister, and wife. A Memorial will be held May 1st, 11am at the New York Academy of Medicine.

A review on March 13 about ''Day of the Oprichnik,'' by the provocative Russian novelist Vladimir Sorokin, referred incorrectly to a collection of his writings that are accompanied by a series of photographs depicting bestiality. The writings, in the book ''Deep Into Russia,'' are short texts in a variety of Russian literary and linguistic styles -- not all of them are poems, and they do not ''glorify the motherland.'' The review also erroneously identified Sorokin himself as the man in the photographs -- it was in fact his collaborator in the project, the conceptual artist Oleg Kulik.

OIL and gas stocks helped propel the returns of three of the top-performing mutual funds in the first quarter. Only one of the three -- the Fidelity Select Energy Portfolio-- is, by charter, a dedicated energy investor. The others -- the FPA Capital fund and the Metzler/Payden European Emerging Markets fund -- have more freedom to roam, but their managers unearthed values in the sector and seized them. Rebound for Refiners

THE current fads for artisanal liquor, louche bars and everything ''Mad Men'' must have inspired ''Cocktail Culture: Ritual and Invention in American Fashion, 1920-1980,'' an exhibition that opens April 15 and continues through July at the Museum of Art at the Rhode Island School of Design. It features more than 220 artifacts, including a Dansk ice bucket, a Norman Bel Geddes soda siphon, Paco Rabanne purses and lots of little black dresses (like the one the model Suzy Parker wore, above).

SIEGEL--Gloria, of New York City and formerly of Penobscot, Maine and West Orange, NJ. Gloria passed away at home at the age of 88 on April 7, 2011. Gloria was the beloved and loving wife for 68 years of Leo Siegel. She was the devoted mother of Barbara and husband Gary Schwartz, Dick and wife Karen Siegel, Elise and husband Sam Glazer and grandmother of Luke Schwartz, Juliet Glazer and Arden Siegel. Gloria was a delight and dear friend to many. She exited this world peacefully and will be sorely missed. Memorial services will be held at 1pm Monday, April 11, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 630 Amsterdam Ave.

BRONFMAN--Ann L.,Philanthropist and beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother passed away at age 78 on April 5, 2011 in Washington, DC surrounded by her five children. Mrs. Bronfman, the daughter of John L. Loeb, Sr. and Frances Lehman Loeb, was born on September 19, 1932 in New York City. Her father was a leading member of the investment community who served as the head of the Wall Street firm of Loeb, Rhoades & Company, a predecessor of Shearson Lehman/American Express. Her mother, the daughter of Arthur Lehman of the Lehman Brothers banking firm, was New York City's Commissioner for the United Nations and the Consular Corps for 12 years in the 1960's and 1970's. Mrs. Bronfman devoted her life to numerous philanthropic efforts, including funding and directing programs through the Ann L. Bronfman Foundation, which she founded and ran. She supported a range of causes, from education to senior citizens to underserved youth to victims of domestic abuse to the arts, among others. Mrs. Bronfman served as a Trustee of Rosemary Hall and was presented with the school's Alumnae Award in 1999 for "demonstrating outstanding achievement in her given field of endeavor." She was the benefactor of the Ann Loeb Bronfman Gallery at the Washington, DC Jewish Community Center. The gallery offers exhibitions and programs that enhance Jewish identity, examine issues of social importance and develop community. In 2010, Mrs. Bronfman was honored by the Teamwork Foundation for her many years of support. The Bronx, NY based organization, which includes the world famous New York Gauchos basketball program, provides after-school and summer programs to inner city boys and girls. "Ann Loeb Bronfman is living proof that greatness is not inherited; it is achieved," wrote "JCA Today," a publication of the Jewish Council for the Aging, in 2006. "By refusing to rest on others" laurels, Ann has literally changed the world, adding compassion to an otherwise uncaring place. Her singleness of purpose and generosity of spirit teach us all that we, too, possess the power to change the world if we, like Ann, listen to our hearts." Mrs. Bronfman graduated from the Rosemary Hall school, then of Greenwich, CT, in 1950 and attended Bennington College in Bennington, VT before marrying her husband, Edgar M. Bronfman, in 1953. Mr. and Mrs. Bronfman were divorced in 1973. Mrs. Bronfman divided her time between her homes in Washington, DC and Mackinac Island, MI. She was an avid sailor and spent many happy times on her boat. In addition to her five children, Sam Bronfman of Atherton, CA, Edgar Bronfman, Jr. of Manhattan, Holly Bronfman Lev of Charlottesville, VA, Matthew Bronfman of Westchester, NY and Adam Bronfman of Park City, UT, Mrs. Bronfman is survived by 25 grandchildren; two great-grandchildren; a sister, Deborah Brice of London, England; and two brothers, the Honorable John L. Loeb, Jr. and Mrs. Bronfman's twin, Arthur Lehman Loeb, both of Manhattan.
