REID--William Lewis Jr. 96, a New Canaan, CT resident since 1952, died Tuesday, March 29th, at Norwalk Hospital. Born December 5th, 1914 in Winston Salem, North Carolina, Bill, 96, was the middle child of three sons of William Lewis Reid, Sr. and Rillie Garrison Reid. Mr. Reid graduated from the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, North Carolina in 1936. He was a member of the Beta Theta Pi fraternity and received his Doctor of Jurisprudence in 1938. In October of 1941, he married Margaret Elizabeth Parry in Grace Church, New York. In 1942 he was commissioned in the US Navy and served as a Lt. Commander in the Pacific during World War II. He left the Navy as a commander and began his business career in New York's famed Flatiron building in the 1940s. Being a man of independent and entrepreneurial spirit, Reid founded his own business, The William Reid Company; he worked closely with his associates in the British Isles, where Driway Weather Coats began its long and prosperous life, spanning five decades. Reid was elected to membership in The British-AmericanChamber of Commerce in 1958. His loyal customers included such industry icons as J. Press, Paul Stuart, and Brooks Brothers. Active in the New Canaan community, Reid was a devoted member of St. Mark's Church where he served on the vestry and was one of the founding fathers behind the now famous St. Mark's Strawberry Festival & Fair. At that time, the church was located in the old building on God's Acre. He served on the board of the Visiting Nurse Association for several years and was an active member of The New Canaan Senior Men's Club and Woodway Country Club of Darien. He was renowned for his woodworking skills, creating unique pieces of furniture cherished by friends and family; his largest project was a traditional, two-story barn which graces his property on Jelliff Mill Road. Reid's mother's ancestors, the Garrisons, were knighted in France by Henry of Nevall. French Huguenots, they migrated in the 1680s, settling in what is now Garrison, NY across from West Point on the Hudson River Mr. Reid loved to entertain family and friends with stories of his family's involvement in the Civil War, or the War Between the States, as he insisted on calling it. His grandfather, Captain Richard Walker Reid, was a member of Jeb Stuart's famous Calvary, CSA (Confederate States of America). On the other side, his grandfather Garrison, of St. Louis, Missouri, donated land for a home at 912 North Garrison Street for William Tecumseh Sherman. Reid is survived by his wife, Barbara Smith Reid of Greenwich: two daughters and their husbands, Betsy Reid Creedon and Gaylord Creedon of Grosse Pointe, MI, and Margaret Reid Ogden and Dayton Ogden, Jr. of New Canaan; four grandchildren: Dayton Reid Ogden, and his wife Laura of New Canaan, Margaret Ogden Hughes and her husband, Iwan of New Canaan, Catherine Parry Creedon of Brooklyn and Reid Miller Creedon and his wife Sarah of Washington, D.C.; four great-grandchildren; Eirlys Margaret Hughes, Dayton Palmer Ogden, William Parry Hughes and Virginia Ann Ogden all of New Canaan; and many beloved nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. Reid was predeceased by his first wife of 30 years, Margaret Parry Reid. He then married Betina Ferris of New Canaan who died shortly thereafter. Family members will remember Mr. Reid as a devoted father and grandfather who was a "larger than life" magnetic character, a man always grateful for the many blessings in his life. A memorial service was held on Sunday, April 3rd at St. Mark's Episcopal Church. Contributions in memory of Mr. Reid may be made to St. Mark's Episcopal Church or a charity of your choice. For online condolences, visit: www.hoytfuneralhome.com.

HAHN--Stephen. The art world has lost one of its great dealer-collectors with the passing of Stephen Hahn on April 2, 2011. Stephen was born February 1, 1921 in Hungary and spent his formative years in Paris. He came to New York from post-war Europe and was drawn to art dealing which he learned from his father, who was a well-known art dealer specializing in the works of the Old Masters. During the war, he was deported from Portugal, as a French refugee, to Santo Domingo where he remained for 6 years, finding work as a surveyor. When the war was over, he returned to his shattered family in Paris, eventually studying teaching at the Sorbonne. At age 30, he moved to Greenwich Village in New York City and started buying and selling paintings out of the trunk of his car. He met Jean Dubuffet and became a champion of the relatively unknown painter. Eventually, he established the Stephen Hahn gallery on 75th and Madison, which remained a famous fixture for over two decades. Many well-known people visited the gallery and became clients, including Charles Laughton, Edward G. Robinson, Woody Allen, Edward Albee, Mike Nichols and Greta Garbo. Stephen continued his rise to prominence by representing Norton Simon at Sotheby's and Christie's auctions and he counseled him in the acquisition of many important pieces of his collection. His friends and colleagues included prominent European and American dealers and collectors, including Richard Feigen, Gene Thaw, Bill Aquavella, Thomas Gibson, Daniel Malingue, Alexandre Rosenberg, Leo Castelli, Heinz Berggruen, Klaus Perls, and many others. His personal collection was notable for its extensive depth, breath and quality. It included major works by Cezanne, Picasso, Matisse among other great modern masters, with a particular appreciation for Jean Dubuffet. Many of the paintings which passed through Stephen's hands now hang in the important museums, institutions and private collections of the world. Stephen was one of the founding members and an early president of the Art Dealers Association. He donated works to major cultural institutions both in the US and abroad. Stephen was not just a dealer but also a scholar of impeccable honesty and taste, with an encyclopedic knowledge on the history of any given painting. As such, he was called on many times to validate a painting's authenticity. His eye for quality was universally respected and he was internationally acknowledged as the authority not only on Picasso, but also Degas and Douanier Rousseau, In Clifford Irving's book "Fake" Stephen is mentioned numerous times in relation to a large collection of Picassos. Stephen Daniel Saidenberg and Klaus Perls were all in agreement: 43 of the Picassos hanging on the walls were fake. Stephen had a great passion for the musical arts. He was an opera lover, Wagner in particular. One of his great enjoyments was attending Ring Cycle productions around the globe. His devotion to music was clearly exemplified by his generosity as a benefactor of The Music Academy of the West in Santa Barbara, CA. Many of the young musicians and singers he sponsored have gone onto become some of today's esteemed classical musical talents, including pianist Vassily Primakov and soprano Susanna Phillips, who would often come to stay, practice and perform in his Montecito home. Stephen's legacy at the Music Academy lives on in the beautiful conservatory space he endowed, Hahn Hall, completed in 2008. Stephen's achievements are a testament to his fascinating character and many qualities. His dignity and savor-faire made him preferred among dealers and clients, his intelligence, mischievous wit, and charm made him a favorite at the table. His drive and competitive spirit was manifest in his love of sports. He frequently traveled with a tennis racquet. Stephen approached life with keen observance and thoughtfulness. He was truly kind and generous and very devoted to his family. A man who once wielded substantial power in his sphere entered the twilight of his life with touching grace and a lively glint in his eye. He is predeceased by his sister Agnes Brodie, survived by his wife, Carla, his sister Suzanne, his children, Robert, Elizabeth, Thomas. Isabella and Lily, his stepchildren, Zachary, Brandon, and Katharine O'Brien, six grandchildren, a niece and a nephew. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to; Music Academy of the West, Attention: Gift Processor, 1070 Fairway Rd, Santa Barbara, CA 93108.

If there were a classified section published for athletes, you might see a listing like this:Free-agent pitcher looking for work. Eight-time All-Star, three-time Cy Young Award winner and 2004 World Series champion. Contact Pedro Jaime Martinez at a fishing pier in the Dominican Republic or Miami. Martinez, 39, who last pitched for Philadelphia against the Yankees in the sixth game of the 2009 World Series, has never officially retired and is waiting for a call to help a team win a World Series. He has an academy in the Dominican Republic and the Pedro Martinez and Brothers Foundation.
HAPPY days are back -- in the corner office, at least. After shrinking during the 2008-9 recession, paychecks for top American executives are growing again -- in many cases, significantly so.

A review on March 27 about the Inn at Dos Brisas in Washington, Tex., misstated its location. It is west of Houston, not east. The review also misstated the role that Dos Brisas' chef, Craig Shelton, had played at the Ryland Inn in Whitehouse, N.J. Mr. Shelton took over the Ryland Inn in 1991, as chef and operating partner; he did not open it.
The Evening Hours column last Sunday misidentified a guest at the Young Concert Artists event on March 29. She is Paulina Mejia, not Rita Mehos.

MACK--Ruth. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with great sadness the passing of Ruth Mack, beloved wife of H. Bert Mack, z''l, whose dedication to Jewish life and learning served as an inspiration to both her family and the entire community. Upholding her humanitarian ideals, philanthropic legacy and commitment to leadership are her children, David and Sondra, Earle and Carol, Fredric and Tami, and William and Phyllis; her grandchildren; and her great-grandchildren. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Mack family. May Ruth's memory be a comfort and a blessing. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. A SNEAKER'S style quotient can usually be expressed as a function of its retro charm, and an inverse of its underlying technology. As Nike's answer to the barefoot-running movement, the Free aims to biomechanically mimic an unencumbered stride.

THE NEWS Scores of older-model Boeing 737s, the world's most widely used jetliner, were pulled aside for special inspections after one tore open in flight and subsurface cracks were found in the fuselages of five more. BEHIND THE NEWS Boeing said the problem -- tied to metal fatigue in the aluminum skin and the joints that support it -- was appearing much sooner in the planes' service life than expected, after only 40,000 takeoff-and-landing cycles instead of 60,000 or more. At least 175 of the planes will now have to be checked once every 500 flights until the cracking problem is better understood.

AS gray-haired fashion moguls know, success lies in finding a look and repeating it, with minor variations, for years. Don't frighten the horses! Creators of reality television also favor this formula. At least eight reality fashion shows and one scripted series are in development, following on the stilettos of ''Project Runway'' and the stylist Rachel Zoe. As if to underscore the dearth of originality in the fashion world, Bravo has picked up the tentatively titled ''It's a Brad Brad World,'' based on Ms. Zoe's former assistant Brad Goreski, and ''Mad Fashion'' with Chris March, the costume designer who appeared on ''Project Runway.'' Given his fondness for cartoonish creations, and his ability to execute them, Mr. March could prove to be the Buddy Valastro of TV fashion. His series could be entertaining if he keeps the frosting thick and tasteless.

DIAMOND--Israel, February 5, 1917-March 4, 2011, beloved husband of Olga Frankel, MD with whom he had three children: Mark, Paul and Katherine; grandfather of Olivia, and father-in-law to Carol. Married 44 years to Dr. Frankel, who predeceased him, and 25 years to Irma Davis. He enjoyed handball, swimming, and other athletic pursuits. In later years Irma and he traveled extensively and danced often. An avid photographer, winning several competitions and the admiration of all who knew his work. He had a life-long connection with the 92nd Street Y, including theater critic and editor-in-chief for the Y's newspaper, "The Bulletin," and where he formed friendships that endured until the end of his life. CCNY graduate (1947). Worked for BMI for 25 years, retiring as Director of Logging & Research. He also taught night courses in business at Baruch College. When he brought one of his classes to IBM, he became the first person to defeat IBM's checkers-playing computer. He later worked for Peer-Southern Music as Director of the Spark record label, and for ASCAP as Manager of Licensing where he compiled their first Biographical Dictionary. He is survived by his wife, children and granddaughter. Donations in his honor may be made to the 92nd St. Y (www.92y.org) or the Adam Scott Weiss Cancer Memorial Fund: (www.aswcmf.com).

BAGHDAD -- A day after Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates suggested that American troops could remain here for years, tens of thousands of protesters allied with Moktada al-Sadr, the radical anti-American Shiite cleric, flooded the streets demanding an end to the American military presence. The protests were scheduled before Mr. Gates's comments -- made on Friday during a visit to troops in northern Iraq -- although his statements may have fueled some of the day's fervor. The protesters were whipped up by comments drafted by Mr. Sadr, who is continuing his religious studies in Iran but who sent a message to the crowd threatening to reconstitute his militia, the Mahdi Army, if the American military did not leave this year.

A picture in an array with an article on March 27 about the potential of the National League baseball teams, particularly the Florida Marlins, to be playoff contenders in the 2011 season was published in error. The picture showed the Marlins' outfielder Josh Kroeger, not the team's center fielder, Chris Coghlan, who was the top rookie of 2009.

FAIRMAN--Claire Martin, of Locust Valley, NY passed away peacefully at home on April 2, 2011. Claire was born in Cincinnati, the daughter of Helen and Chester Martin, and was a member of the Hillsdale class of 1950. A 1954 graduate of Radcliffe College and past President of the Harvard-Radcliffe Club of Long Island, she received Radcliffe's Distinguished Service Award in 2004 on the occasion of her class' 50th reunion, of which she was co-chair. After living in New York City in the early years of her marriage, her family resided in Locust Valley. A devoted community volunteer, she served at various times on the Boards of Planting Fields Foundation, Locust Valley Library, Doubleday-Babcock Senior Center, Save the Children Long Island, and the New York Virtuosi Chamber Symphony. She co-founded the Hutton House Lectures at the C.W. Post Campus of Long Island University and retired as Development Officer at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. For many years, she was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. She will be deeply missed by her loving family: her husband of 51 years, Joel; her children Betsy Weyerhaeuser (David), David (Juliette Zener), and Helen; her sisters Helen and Lynne; and five grandchildren. A celebration of Claire's life will be held at Planting Fields on May 21 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Planting Fields Foundation, 1395 Planting Fields Road, Oyster Bay, NY 11771.

Imagine that you and your best buddy are missile tracking engineers working for the Pentagon (nice steady job in these times!). The two of you played hoops for rival schools in your youth, and each of you believes he is better than the other. You challenge each other to a one-on-one grudge match in your backyard, the winner entitled to bragging rights forever. All your colleagues show up, some with video cameras to film the historic showdown. It’s an intense match, and both of you are giving it all you’ve got. The game goes right down to the wire. You are one point behind, and with just a few seconds to go, you uncork a buzzer beater. The ball travels in a graceful arc towards the basket. To your eyes, it seems certain to go in. At that very moment, a hefty twig descends from the tree above, strikes the ball and deflects it away. The buzzer sounds.

In June 2007, Julian Dibbell published an article in the Sunday Magazine about the shadow economy in virtual goods, focusing on “gold farmers” in China — workers hired by Chinese companies to play huge, multiplayer online games for the sole purpose of acquiring loot that could then be sold at a profit to regular players who didn’t have the time or the inclination to do it themselves and who use this purchased loot to increase their chances and status in these games. “For years now, the vast majority of virtual goods has been brought to retail not by players selling the product of their own gaming but by high-volume online specialty sites like the virtual-money superstores IGE, BroGame and Massive Online Gaming Sales — multimillion-dollar businesses offering one-stop, one-click shopping and instant delivery of in-game cash,” Dibbell wrote. “These are the Wal-Marts and Targets of this decidedly gray market, and the same economic logic that leads conventional megaretailers to China in search of cheap toys and textiles takes their virtual counterparts to China’s gold farms.”

James Richardson has received this year's Jackson Poetry Prize, a $50,000 award presented to an American poet by Poets & Writers, a nonprofit organization for creative writers. Mr. Richardson's latest collection, ''By the Numbers: Poems and Aphorisms,'' was released by Copper Canyon Press in November and was a finalist for the 2010 National Book Award. His previous collections include ''Interglacial: New and Selected Poems and Aphorisms'' (Ausable, 2004), a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, and ''Vectors: Aphorisms and Ten-Second Essays'' (Ausable, 2001). The prize has been awarded since 2007 by a panel of three distinguished poets. This year's panelists were Mark Doty, Rita Dove and Gerald Stern. Previous winners were Elizabeth Alexander, Tony Hoagland, Linda Gregg and Harryette Mullen.

MACK--Ruth Kaufman, passed away of natural causes in Palm Beach Florida on April 7, 2011. She was born in Manhattan on November 28, 1914 and spent her youth in Williamsberg Brooklyn. She graduated at the age of 15 with High Honors at Eastern District High School in Manhattan. She walked the Williamsberg Bridge to school most days to save two cents for public transportation. She attended Hunter College in Manhattan. Her life was totally devoted to her family and Jewish charities of which the charities were: Yeshiva University where she received an honorary doctorate. Along with her husband, H.B. Mack, they were founders and benefactors of Long Island Jewish Hospital (now known as North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System); Boys Town of Jerusalem; Albert Einstein College of Medicine; and benefactor at the Jewish Theological Seminary. She taught Hebrew at the Hillcrest Jewish Center where she and her husband were founders and benefactors. Ruth Mack was amongst the leadership of the UJA and the Federation of Jewish charities. She was a member of the Board and Vice President of Temple Emanuel of Palm Beach. She is survived by her four sons: Earle, William, David and Fredric; six grandchildren: Richard, Stephen, Hailey, Jason, Andrew and Beatrice; and three great grandchildren: Harrison, Dylan and Tucker. A private funeral for family will be held Sunday. The Family will be receiving friends at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, NYC on Sunday from 4:30 to 7:30pm and on Monday and Tuesday between 5:30pm and 8:00pm.

CABADO--Elaine (nee Rothstein), 88, on April 7, 2011 in Santa Monica, California, formerly of New Rochelle, NY. Retired, highly respected New Rochelle High School teacher of Spanish and French for generations of students. Sorbonne and University of Madrid educated, she will be remembered for her fierce intelligence, spirit, and love of Spain, her students, and, above all, her family. Beloved sister of Stanley Rothstein and the late Hermine Shapiro, aunt, and great-aunt.

LUBELL--Harold. Loving husband to Ruth, beloved father to Shari and Abbe, devoted "Babbo" to Sophia and Halle, dear uncle and brother-in-law and steadfast friend. He was a prominent real estate lawyer in Manhattan, a member of the Real Property Section of the NYS Bar Association and taught at Fordham University Law School for many years. He always took special care to offer kindness, laughter and support to anyone he thought might need it. He will be terribly missed, but will remain a source of love and inspiration to all who knew him. Services at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St. Tuesday, April 12, 11:15am.

HALPERIN--Dr. Anthony Lionel Paul. With immense sadness, family and friends of Dr. Anthony Lionel Paul Halperin mourn Anthony's untimely passing on April 7, 2011. The beloved son of Dr. Edward and Beth Weingast Halperin, brother of Alexander Halperin and Dr. Anna Halperin Rosen, nephew, grandson, and friend to many, Anthony will be deeply missed by his family and loved ones. A graduate of New Rochelle High School, Brown University, and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School, Anthony was an incredibly bright and talented young man who was recognized for his leadership, intelligence, and patience. He loved to travel and he studied and worked in Europe as well as South America connecting to people of different ages and backgrounds. Anthony possessed a unique curiosity about the world, he asked questions as a scientist, a humanist, and as a friend. He found the good in everyone. A funeral service will be held on Monday, April 11 at 10:00am at Beth El Synagogue, 1324 North Ave., New Rochelle, NY 10804.

The same rule, by and large, has applied to the architecture of cloud computing - the massive, energy-hungry data centers and servers that power services like Google, Facebook, Twitter and Amazon, which companies treat as proprietary secrets. But Facebook is opening the design of its custom-built servers and soon-to-be new data center in Oregon to others in the industry.

OTTENBERG--James S. Died peacefully on April 9 in Manhattan. Born February 28, 1918, this lifelong New Yorker attended Horace Mann and Lincoln, obtained a BA from Swarthmore College (1939), a JD from Harvard Law School (1942), and an MPA from NYU (1963). A World War II Air Force veteran, Jim served in the European theatre. He practiced law, but politics and public service were his passion. He worked in the New York City government at Marine and Aviation and as Deputy Commissioner of Mental Health. He became Director of the Child Study Association, and for 20 years an administrator in the psychiatric department of Bronx Lebanon Hospital. An ardent Democrat, Jim participated in many campaigns, including the Stevenson and Kennedy Presidential runs. He co-authored The Lexington Democratic Story and You, Your Child and Drugs. In his 80s and 90s, Jim served on the Auxiliary Board of Metropolitan Hospital. An avid jogger, devoted Broadway and swing jazz fan, he suffered and gloried in the football Giants. But most of all, this remarkable man was the beloved husband of Margaret Davies for 70 years; father of Jeffrey, Susan, Betsy Cherkasky, and Jill Muscat; grandfather ("Papa Jim") of Eli, Ethan and Dinah Cherkasky, Susannah Cherkasky Heyworth, Neil and Timothy Muscat; great-grandfather of Cecilia and Philippa Heyworth; father-in-law of Michael Cherkasky and Josh Muscat, and grandfather-in-law of James Heyworth and Lyndsea Cochrane Cherkasky. A Memorial Service will be held at the John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont on Sunday, May 15 at 11:00am.

Popular software sites have long included manufacturers of products for personal and small-business use, like Photoshop and other design software from Adobe, and the Norton security tools from Symantec. People enjoy less weighty sites, too, like Fun Web Products, which offers free emoticons and cursors by the thousands. As social media and mobile technology have expanded in scope over the last five years, the top 10 list has shifted to include sites like Conduit, above, which develops apps and custom toolbars, and Six Apart, which makes blogging software. Since Quora, a question-and-answer start-up , was first introduced last June, it has become something of a Web darling among tech denizens, engineers and early adopters. But the conversations on Quora have quickly fanned out beyond new media and technology. A spin through the site reveals a wide range of topics currently under discussion, including white chocolate, the rapper Lil Wayne's ascent to stardom and ways to alleviate car sickness in babies. That last category - medical and health questions - is one the company has decided to zero in on. On Monday, the company announced several new features aimed at helping the service expand its discussions in those areas. In a post to its users, Quora said it would initroduce legal and medical disclaimers and policies around legal and medical questions. In addition, the company included language in its terms of service to provide protection for doctors and lawyers who chose to write answers.
WELSH--James W. July 5, 1923 April 6, 2011, Summit, NJ inventor. Loved always by Marie, Laurie, Jon, Jeff, Chett and Jackie.

SYRIA Security forces and pro-government gunmen killed four protesters in the port city of Banias, The Associated Press reported. Hundreds of antigovernment protesters gathered, undaunted by the government's use of deadly force to quell more than three weeks of unrest, witnesses said. According to one witness, the protesters had assembled near a mosque when security forces and armed men in civilian clothes opened fire on them. Dozens of people were wounded. LIBYA Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's military forces appeared to falter in eastern Libya on the second day of an assault against the strategic rebel-held city of Ajdabiya. Opposition fighters aided by NATO airstrikes retook their positions and claimed the checkpoints at the city's approaches. Other than an apparent mortar attack against a rebel checkpoint, the loyalists' artillery and rocket batteries were mostly silent.

LOS ANGELES -- It seems fair to ask why Sidney J. Sheinberg, 76 years old and long retired as president of MCA Inc., the erstwhile parent of Universal Pictures, spent much of last May tromping through the swamps of Louisiana with the crew of a little monster movie called ''Creature.'' ''If you put me under sodium pentothal, I'd have to conclude I was doing it to be sure I could still do it,'' said Mr. Sheinberg, who spoke last week by telephone from Washington, where he was out of the mud and doing public advocacy work with the group Human Rights Watch, of which he is a vice chairman.

9 P.M. (13, 49) THE GREAT FAMINE When a devastating famine descended on Russia in 1921, Americans responded with a two-year relief campaign, championed by a new secretary of commerce, Herbert Hoover, a k a the great humanitarian. Nearly 300 relief workers, nicknamed Hoover's ''boys,'' encountered a railroad system in disarray, a forbidding climate and a ruthless government suspicious of their motives. By the summer of 1922 Americans were feeding nearly 11 million Russian citizens a day in 19,000 kitchens. This ''American Experience'' documentary from Austin Hoyt tells the story of an operation hailed for its efficiency, determination and generosity within the context of the Russian Revolution and examines the roots of the rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union that would dominate the second half of the 20th century. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) CIVIL WARRIORS: FAMILIES AT WAR In this three-hour program descendants of soldiers investigate their heritage, starting with Roger Fisk, whose ancestor fought in the Union Army to help free slaves. In other segments Christian Latham, a 22-year-old descendant of a private, tries to experience what his ancestors did 150 years earlier in their struggle for freedom. And Tim Sawyer questions whether his great-great-grandfather, a Civil War surgeon, could have saved the life of President Lincoln.

MARK--Manny, 89, Beloved husband of the late Judith, brother of the late Ann, the late Sidney, the late Felice and brother of Bernard and Elaine, cherished father of Bernard (Sharon) Mark, Diane (Sion) Elalouf, adored grandfather of Caryn (Hank) Finley, Jamie (Jon) Fishman, Leah (Josh) Wurzburger and Seth Elalouf. Marvelous great-grandfather of Sammy, Daniel and Hannah Wurzburger and Julia and Eve Fishman. He will be remembered for his most extraordinary generosity; his love of life; his devotion to his family; his magnificent sense of humor and for always having such a good time. Dad was one of a kind and we were so lucky to have him. Funeral service 12:00 noon, Monday at Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard, 66th Avenue, Rego Park, NY.

TEITELBAUM--Rose Lea Harnick Died at 97 in her sleep on April 9th. A true matriarch, Rose was a touchstone for her family. "When one of my chickadees falls from the nest," she said cupping her hands, "I gently bring them back." Even in her later years, Rose provided a joyous welcome not only to family but friends of family, young and old. A high school drop out, Rose was an enthusiastic reader and a curious traveler, accompanying family to many foreign cities. After 30 years, as a corsetiere at small specialty shops, Rose became a popular docent at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. There, until she was 94, Rose led awed visitors through the 6 story tenement building, recalling the lives of its immigrant residents. She also volunteered at The Family Center and Coney Island Hospital. Raised by poor immigrants in Brownsville, Brooklyn, Rose moved at the age of 84 to Manhattan to be nearer her son, Herbert and his family. Calling the Upper West Side a lebedik place, she reveled in long walks along Broadway. This year, Rose moved to St. Louis where her older son, Steven and his family reside. In addition to her sons, Rose leaves daughters-in-law Marilyn Teitelbaum and Ruth J. Abram; grandchildren: Caren, Aaron, and Noah Teitelbaum; Rebecca Wallace; Anna Kaye; four great-grandchildren: Amelia Rose and Stella Rose Kaye, Jonah Teitelbaum and Leo Wallace as well as grandchildren's spouses: Gordon Kaye, Lila Teitelbaum and John Wallace. On April 13, following a private burial, a memorial service will be held at the Tenement Museum. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to the Lower East Side Tenement Museum 91 Orchard Street, New York City, 10002 c Rose Leah Harnick Teitelbaum Fund.

Americans are right to be concerned about a huge data breach at an online marketing company, Epsilon, which resulted in the theft of names and e-mail addresses for customers and employees of some of the nation's largest businesses, including Citibank, Disney and Verizon. Epsilon issued a statement assuring that no other information was compromised. But millions of consumers could still be vulnerable to sophisticated identity-theft ploys -- ''spear phishing'' -- in which scammers target e-mails to specific people and make it appear as if they came from a company they trust. Familiarity can lure victims into clicking on links, downloading malware, or responding to requests for account numbers or passwords.

A music review on Thursday of the New York Philharmonic presentation of ''The Thomashefskys: Music and Memories of a Life in the Yiddish Theater,'' in which Michael Tilson Thomas tells the story of his pioneering grandparents, misstated the name of a multimedia educational project that Mr. Thomas leads as music director of the San Francisco Symphony. The N.F.L. and its players are expected to learn in the next few days where and under whose control they will restart mediated negotiations. Judge Susan Richard Nelson, who held a conference call with both sides in the labor dispute Friday, will decide who will oversee the negotiations, with players pushing for litigation settlement talks to be held under her auspices in Minneapolis, and the league hoping for a return to the federal mediator George Cohen in Washington and for the talks to seek what it has called a ''global'' resolution to the differences. Both sides have said they are willing to return to talks, and the league has moved away from its position that it would talk to players only in the form of collective bargaining, which would require the reformation of the now dissolved union. JUDY BATTISTA

WEINBERGER--Herbert Beloved husband of Beulah Weinberger, cherished father of Nancy Isserlis, father-in-law of Maurice Miller, adored grandfather of Drew and Michael Isserlis and Arielle and Scott Weinberger, died peacefully on April 9, 2011. A distinguished World War II veteran, retired commodities futures trader and member of the New York Mercantile Exchange, Herbie Weinberger set an example of humanity to all who had the privilege of knowing him. His love of and dedication to his family, great sense of humor, amazing generosity, brilliant business instincts and rock solid faith in his family and friends, will be greatly missed by all. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, April 12, 2011 at 1pm at Boulevard-Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers or food, the family asks that donations be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

On the evening of April 12, 1861, Walt Whitman attended a performance of Gaetano Donizetti’s opera “Linda di Chamounix” at the Academy of Music, on 14th Street and Irving Place in Manhattan. Just before midnight he was walking down the west side of Broadway, toward the Fulton Ferry to return to his home, in Brooklyn. Suddenly, he later recalled, he “heard in the distance the loud cries of the newsboys, who came presently tearing and yelling up the street, rushing from side to side more furiously than usual.”

Mikhail Baryshnikov’s magic extended beyond the stage on Tuesday morning when a panoramic cityscape of St. Petersburg, Russia, by the 19th-century painter Petr Petrovich Vereshchagin sold at Sotheby’s for $746,500. Until October 2005, dueling Chapter 11 plans were a theoretical possibility, but a rare occurrence in reality. The Federal Bankruptcy Code contemplated that a debtor might lose its exclusive right to propose a plan, but bankruptcy courts routinely extended exclusivity and the debtor typically proposed the only plan in the case. The plan was often the result of negotiation and might look very different from the first plan proposed by the debtor, but there was only one plan.

The Danish recording artist Oh Land performed an hour or so worth of songs at a small gallery space on the Bowery. Hosted by VS magazine, the event was packed elbow to elbow with fans curious to hear the new artist’s work, including her hit single “Sun of a Gun.” Oh Land, a stunning blonde, led a minimal band — synth player, a percussionist and three classical musicians; she herself hit notes alternately on a xylophone, a drum machine and what looked like a vintage miniature finger organ. A cloud of white balloons behind her on the stage sometimes carried projections of her face. As sweet as she looks (she was dressed in a shirt adorned with plush toucans), she asked the crowd, earnestly, to keep it down during the quieter songs.

This week A. O. Scott looks back at the trial and execution of St. Joan as recounted in the silent classic by the Danish filmmaker Carl Theodor Dreyer in “The Passion of Joan of Arc” (1928). The film is based on the transcripts from the trial and explores it from a political and religious perspective. “There’s something powerful and mysterious about beholding the image of a human face,” Mr. Scott says about the film’s use of close-ups to build a kind of spiritual intensity. The entire first half is a succession of close-ups, which, Mr. Scott says, “create a feeling of intimacy and confinement. And the drama, even the narrative itself, are contained within these faces.” The film is ultimately more concerned with emotion than politics, making it that much more of a human story. “‘The Passion of Joan of Arc’ creates an uncanny, unforgettable, almost unique sense of connection to its main character,” Mr. Scott says. “We may not ultimately understand Joan, but we know her.” Have you seen the film? Please share your thoughts.

From handmade hair accessories to artisanal pickles, there’s a metaphorical back-to-the-land movement for every profession. For graphic design, it’s letterpress, a labor-intensive printing process that creative types are taking up as an antidote to days spent staring at their iMacs. Produced on antique presses and characterized by heavily impressed lettering on thick paper, letterpress cards and stationery — if you’ve received a wedding invitation from an even vaguely arty couple in the past few years, chances are it was letterpress printed — are the graphic design equivalent of slow food. For designers who want to unplug, literally, letterpress is a chance to spend time refining their craft using a method that was considered old-fashioned long before the days of Photoshop. “People miss the hands-on experience of printing,” says Daniel Gardiner Morris, a fourth-generation letterpress printer and the founder of the Arm, the Williamsburg studio where many local printers have learned the basics of handling Industrial Revolution-era machinery. “Even if you don’t know anything about the process, when you pick up something that was printed on a letterpress, you know there’s something different about it. It was touched by human hands.” Here, the lowdown on five printers who are getting their fingers inky.

Attorney General Chris Koster, defying his party, urged a judge to invalidate the central provision of the new law.

Japan decided to raise its assessment of the accident at the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant from 5 to the worst rating of 7 on an international scale.

To the Editor: Denise Grady's article ''Radiation Is Everywhere, but How to Rate Harm?'' (April 5) is excellent as far as it goes. But missing from her analysis is any mention of the radioisotope polonium 210 -- the most lethal component of tobacco and surely the most destructive ionizing radiation to which world populations are ordinarily exposed. Inhaled and circulating to every tissue and cell, it emits alpha particles and is a powerful toxin. Nuclear plants deserve careful control, but action must be taken to stop the sale of cigarettes.

There is a certain symmetry to Stan Kroenke's purchase Monday of a controlling stake in a certain London soccer club. Kroenke's team in Major League Soccer, the defending champion Colorado Rapids, plays its games in a stadium on the site of the old Rocky Mountain Arsenal in Commerce City, Colo. His newest acquisition is a club founded in 1886 by workers at the Royal Arsenal in Woolwich, England, a club known around the world as the Gunners.

TEITELBAUM--Rose Lea Harnick Died at 97 in her sleep on April 9th. A true matriarch, Rose was a touchstone for her family. "When one of my chickadees falls from the nest," she said cupping her hands, "I gently bring them back." Even in her later years, Rose provided a joyous welcome not only to family but friends of family, young and old. A high school drop out, Rose was an enthusiastic reader and a curious traveler, accompanying family to many foreign cities. After 30 years, as a corsetiere at small specialty shops, Rose became a popular docent at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. There, until she was 94, Rose led awed visitors through the 6 story tenement building, recalling the lives of its immigrant residents. She also volunteered at The Family Center and Coney Island Hospital. Raised by poor immigrants in Brownsville, Brooklyn, Rose moved at the age of 84 to Manhattan to be nearer her son, Herbert and his family. Calling the Upper West Side a lebedik place, she reveled in long walks along Broadway. This year, Rose moved to St. Louis where her older son, Steven and his family reside. In addition to her sons, Rose leaves daughters-in-law Marilyn Teitelbaum and Ruth J. Abram; grandchildren: Caren, Aaron, and Noah Teitelbaum; Rebecca Wallace; Anna Kaye; four great-grandchildren: Amelia Rose and Stella Rose Kaye, Jonah Teitelbaum and Leo Wallace as well as grandchildren's spouses: Gordon Kaye, Lila Teitelbaum and John Wallace. On April 13, following a private burial, a memorial service will be held at the Tenement Museum. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to the Lower East Side Tenement Museum 91 Orchard Street, New York City, 10002 c Rose Leah Harnick Teitelbaum Fund.

The Drilling Down column on Monday, about a survey by two media measurement firms that found Americans are spending about 20 percent more time consuming radio, television and Internet content than they were a decade ago, misidentified one of the firms. It is Edison Research, not Edison Media Research. The article also misidentified the firm that employs Tom Webster, who commented on the trend. It is Edison Research, not Arbitron, the other firm that joined in the study.

Glencore, the commodities trader, has yet to start its initial public offering in Hong Kong, but is already acting like a local. It has talked with big investors about taking a stake ahead of a share sale of up to $12 billion in return for staying put for a few months. Those investors, called ''cornerstones,'' are de rigueur in Hong Kong, though they serve little purpose. A company of Glencore's stature can afford to break with tradition.

SHAPIRO--Lilian, W.,74, formerly of Chestnut Hill, MA, died of cancer on April 10, 2011, in New York City. She was surrounded by her loving husband, Joseph and their two children, Kenneth Shapiro of Westport, CT and Kimberly Konigsberg of NYC and their spouses. She will be deeply missed by her adoring grandchildren Alex, Andre, James and Samantha. She was also survived by her sister-in-law, Lotti Rubin, her husband and family and her devoted cousins, Nancy and Arnold Smoller and their children. Lilian was born in London, England, September 4, 1936 to Gerard and Elfreda Wolfe who emigrated from Heilbronn-Sontheim, Germany. Ultimately they settled in the United States in 1940, via Cuba and the Dominican Republic. She was raised in Brookline, MA and graduated from Beaver Country Day School, Hood College and Simmons College School of Social Work. After receiving her MSW, she was a social worker at The Massachusetts General Hospital working with burn victims and terminal pediatric cancer patients. Despite her professional accomplishments, her proudest achievement was her devotion to her family. Lilian and Joseph were married 50 years and were the best of friends. They enjoyed doing the activities they loved together: visiting with their grandchildren; traveling; appreciating art, antiques and laundry ephemera. Their last passion culminated in an exhibit, "Blue Monday: Doing Laundry in America," at the National Heritage Museum in Lexington, MA in 2005. Over a thirty year period Lilian and Joe scoured flea markets and antique shows throughout the country, where Lilian was affectionately known as the "Laundry Lady." She was readily recognized for her Tide detergent sneakers and her yellow and red bakelite, laundry pin depicting washing implements. She was truly unique: a compassionate, elegant lady with beauty, intelligence and refined taste! A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, April 15th at 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Donations may be made in honor of Jimmie Holland, MD for the Geriatric Psychiatric Fund at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

Until February, Nathan and Elisa Bond were about as ordinary a 30-something couple as you could find in Brooklyn. Mr. Bond, 38, was a teacher and an artist; Ms. Bond, 36, worked for a real estate broker; their daughter, Sadie, had turned 1 in the fall. The last thing on their minds was cancer. Indeed, when Nathan Bond started having gastrointestinal problems last summer, he figured it might be lactose intolerance. Then an infectious-disease doctor diagnosed a parasitic infection, continuing to treat it even as the symptoms kept getting worse.

When, if ever, are people just too old to benefit from cancer screening? The question keeps arising and has never been satisfactorily answered. Now it has come up again, in the context of a provocative new study on the popular P.S.A. test for prostate cancer. The paper, published in The Journal of Clinical Oncology, finds that men in their 70s are being screened at nearly twice the rate of men in their 50s -- and men ages 80 to 85 are being screened as often as those 30 years younger.

To the Editor: Re ''Illness More Prevalent Among Older Gay Adults'' (Vital Signs, April 5): Health disparities among older gay people are the direct result of disparities in equality. There is no question about the cost of discrimination to the human body: increased stressors lead to increase in illness. The remedies are clear. To begin with, let's put an end to institutionalized discrimination. Repeal laws like the Defense of Marriage Act. Lift the bans on same-sex marriage. Make it illegal to discriminate based on sexual identity, sexual orientation or gender expression in employment, housing, accommodation and credit. Our health care system can't afford it.

LONDON - British banks should hold more capital and better shield individual customers from losses in other parts of their business, a government-backed commission said on Monday. The proposals stopped short of any significant new regulations, like requiring a full split of retail and investment banking, which some banks had feared.

Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, quietly made his presidential ambitions official Monday by forming an exploratory committee to run for president in 2012 and declaring in a video that ''it is time that we put America back on a course of greatness.'' Mr. Romney, a top contender in the 2008 presidential campaign, has so far been content to remain largely quiet while other Republicans seek the media spotlight. At this stage, Mr. Romney tops most polls as the Republican front-runner and his advisers saw little need to compete for the boost in name recognition that comes with an early declaration.

As a filmmaker, Bernardo Bertolucci has had a lasting impact on how audiences think of Asia and Africa, Buddhism and butter, but he has never won a Palme d'or - the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival. It is a gap on his trophy shelf that the organizers of the festival said they intended to correct at this year's celebration. Mr. Bertolucci, whose films include ''The Last Emperor,'' ''The Sheltering Sky,'' ''Little Buddha'' and ''Last Tango in Paris,'' will be given an honorary Palme d'or at the opening ceremony of this year's festival, it was announced on Monday. The festival has previously presented honorary awards to filmmakers including Woody Allen (in 2002) and Clint Eastwood (in 2009), and starting this year plans to make the distinction an annual tradition. In a statement, the festival's president, Gilles Jacob, and its director, Thierry Fremaux, cited ''the quality of his work, which appears today in all its uniqueness and the extent of this work we perceive every day more vividly'' and ''the strength of his commitment to cinema and the ties that bind him to Cannes.'' Mr. Bertolucci will receive his award at the festival's opening ceremony on May 11 from Robert De Niro, who is serving as the president of this year's jury and starred in his film ''1900.''

A quick departure for Michael Scott probably would be better for productivity at Dunder Mifflin, but NBC isn't letting go of Steve Carell, who has played that beloved if inept character on ''The Office'' for seven seasons, that easily. On Monday the network said it would extend the running time of the April 28 episode of ''The Office,'' on which Mr. Carell bids farewell to the series, to run about 50 minutes total, including commercials; it will be followed by an extended 40-minute episode of ''Parks and Recreation,'' a regular 30-minute episode of ''30 Rock'' and zero minutes of ''Outsourced.'' Mr. Carell's character proposed to his girlfriend, Holly Flax (played by Amy Ryan), in the March 24 episode of ''The Office,'' presumably setting the stage for Michael Scott's exit. On Thursday, Will Ferrell beginsa four-episode arc on the series that includes Mr. Carell's final show, building up to a May 19 season finale filled with guest stars like Ricky Gervais and Will Arnett. Though NBC hasn't exactly discouraged speculation that one of these guests might be Mr. Carell's permanent replacement, producers for ''The Office'' have yet to formally announce if or how they will fill his vacancy.

Charleston, S.C. Hundreds of Confederate re-enactors moved into tent cities around town this week, and it is not uncommon to see men in gray uniforms, with prop rifles, at the Burger King. They have been camping out, waiting for the hour before sunrise Tuesday, when an antebellum 10-inch mortar is to fire a starburst shell over Charleston Harbor, just like in 1861, in effect bombing Fort Sumter a second time.

LUBELL--Harold A. The entire family of Bryan Cave, and its New York predecessor firm, Robinson Silverman, Pearce, Aronsohn & Berman, is deeply saddened by the unexpected loss of Harold A. Lubell, one of our most respected and beloved colleagues. After having served as Assistant General Counsel of New York Life Insurance Company and subsequently as head of the Bureau of Real Estate Financing of the New York State Attorney General's office, Harold became our partner (recently Of Counsel) in 1980. Harold was responsible for the unprecedented growth and development of our firm's cooperative and condominium practice during which we acquired national preeminence representing the most prominent and successful cooperative/condominium developers in New York. Harold loved being a scholar and practitioner and over the course of his career published dozens of articles and treatises, became an adjunct professor at Fordham University School of Law, and Chair of the Real Property Section of the New York State Bar Association (which awarded Harold its Lifetime Professionalism Award in 2005). He was an active member of the American College of Real Estate Attorneys and the American Land Title Association and served several terms on the NYC Rent Guidelines Board. He mentored many young lawyers and was a wonderful, decent, generous, witty and warm hearted person who shared these gifts every day. He exemplified the finest of our profession. Harold is survived by Ruth, his wife of over fifty years, his daughter Abbe (he was tragically predeceased by a lovely daughter, Shari) and two delightful granddaughters, Sophia and Halle, who were the light of his life. Each of us at the firm will miss Harold greatly.

Known for the unearthly menace he brings to the characters he portrays on television's ''Boardwalk Empire'' and off Broadway's ''Mistakes Were Made,'' it's only natural that Michael Shannon would end up as an alien villain in Zack Snyder's new ''Superman'' movie. Warner Brothers Pictures said on Sunday that Mr. Shannon, an Academy Award nominee for ''Revolutionary Road,'' will play General Zod, an evildoer who comes from Superman's home planet of Krypton. The studio said the film, whose previously announced cast includes Henry Cavill (''The Tudors'') as Superman and Amy Adams (''The Fighter'') as Lois Lane, will be titled ''Man of Steel.'' Mr. Snyder, whose previous films include ''300'' and ''Sucker Punch,'' said in a statement, ''Zod is not only one of Superman's most formidable enemies, but one of the most significant because he has insights into Superman that others don't. Michael is a powerful actor who can project both the intelligence and the malice of the character, making him perfect for the role.''

8 P.M. (ABC) JAMIE OLIVER'S FOOD REVOLUTION Mr. Oliver, the chef and author, continues on his quest to educate Americans -- particularly children -- about obesity, heart disease and diabetes, and the benefits of healthy eating. In this Season 2 opener, he heads to Los Angeles, where the city's school district, the second-largest in the nation, decides to deny his film crew access to schools where Mr. Oliver hoped to work as a consultant and to bring fresher, healthier food to the students. He opens a kitchen in the Westwood neighborhood, above, where he intends to provide educational tools to combat obesity; he also attends a school lunch convention and is horrified to discover a seminar advocating flavored milk. Not one to abandon hope, Mr. Oliver gives a dramatic demonstration about what's wrong with that picture and tries to create a healthy fast-food menu at a local drive-in. 9 P.M. (WE) BRAXTON FAMILY VALUES The R&B singer Toni Braxton prepares to reboot her career with the help of her four younger sisters, Traci, Towanda, Trina and Tamar. The first item on the agenda is a benefit concert in Bermuda. The second is a temper tantrum from Tamar when Toni doesn't attend rehearsals, and Tamar's husband, a producer, seems unsupportive of her own career. Traci complains that she feels like Jan of ''The Brady Bunch'' when she is left out of the performance. To the Editor: Private meteorite hunters are not the bane of science (''Black Market Trinkets From Space,'' April 5). As a result of the harvesting done by Bedouins, Berbers and others, 32 specimens from Mars and 43 specimens from the Moon have been discovered in the deserts since the mid-1990s. The number of such specimens recovered by scientists beforehand? Not one. Since the mid-1990s? Just four. It has been argued that there is no other scientific discipline where researchers have been aided as much by the private sector.

MACK--Ruth. Yeshiva University acknowledges with great sorrow the passing of Ruth Mack, a Grand Lady, whose deeply held belief in Jewish life and learning is so intertwined with the core values of our University. Together with her beloved husband H. Bert Mack, she touched the lives of generations of Yeshiva University students. Her fierce commitment to Jewish education and culture resulted in her generous support of University scholarships with special focus on students at the Cardozo School of Law. Ruth's generosity was boundless. She was a Benefactor, supporting the Cardozo School of Law, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and other schools and programs at the University. In recognition and gratitude for the extraordinary breadth of Ruth's contributions, Yeshiva University awarded her an honorary doctorate. We will miss our cherished friend Ruth and we extend our deepest sympathies to her children, Earle and Carol, David and Sandra, William and Phyllis, and Frederic and Tami who have carried on her legacy of leadership at Yeshiva University, and to her grandchildren and great- grandchildren. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor
MACK--Ruth. Our deepest condolences to the Mack family on the loss of a wonderful mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. Dan & Peggy Cremins

The Ivory Coast strongman Laurent Gbagbo, who was finally captured on Monday, defied nearly everybody: the United States, the European Union and the African Union. But right to the end, Mr. Gbagbo had defenders in the West, and they notably included several prominent conservative Christians. It is impossible to know for sure if the group sided with Mr. Gbagbo because he is a Christian; his rival, Alassane Ouattara, recognized internationally as the winner of last year's presidential election, is a Muslim. But to judge by the recent comments of Senator James M. Inhofe of Oklahoma, the Rev. Pat Robertson, the Christian broadcaster, and Glenn Beck, the Fox News television personality, religion did play a role in their support.

CAPUTO--Dante S.,of Riverdale, NY passed away on April 7, 2011. He was born in New York City, February 10, 1920, the son of Maria and Angelo Caputo. He was a graduate of the Horace Mann School and Williams College, class of 1942. He served in the Army Signal Corps from 1942-1945 and achieved the rank of Captain. He was an agent at The New York Life Insurance Company for over 60 years. Beloved husband of the late Kathleen Buckner Caputo and the late Emily Stull Caputo. He is survived by his daughter, Kathleen Caputo and son Thomas Caputo, three grandchildren, Kathleen Caputo, Maria Mulvehill and Alexander Freeman, and two great-grandchildren, Makenzee Freeman and Adelaide Mulvehill. He is also survived by Patricia Anderson, Pengwynne Blevins, Pamela Potter, Paul Potter and Peter Potter, (children by marriage) five additional grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He was an avid tennis and platform tennis player, and a member of long standing at The Riverdale Yacht Club in Riverdale, NY where he was a former Commodore and served as the Treasurer for over 40 years. He was also the Treasurer of The Williams Club in New York City and served on the board of The Riverdale Neighborhood House. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:00am on May 7, 2011 at Christ Church in Riverdale, NY. Donations may be made to The Maria and Angelo Caputo Scholarship Fund at Williams College or Christ Church, Riverdale, New York.
SANTIESTEBAN--Armand. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Armand Santiesteban, associated with The New York Times from January 20, 1969 until retiring on February 1, 1980.

MACK--Ruth. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of a grand lady who exuded dignity, kindness and humility. Ruth was totally devoted to her late husband and partner in life and philanthropy, H. Bert Mack. Her commitment to family was supreme. Ruth, together with Bert, were Chai Founders of Boys Town, and with the continued generous support of the entire Mack family, BTJ has been able to fulfill its mission of turning young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures. At a Boys Town dinner honoring the Mack family, Ruth took special pride in hearing her grandson Andrew recount how his grandfather gave BTJ's founder, Rabbi Alexander Linchner, the money to travel to Israel to begin what was to become a school providing hope and opportunity to thousands of youngsters from difficult circumstances. Ruth will be sorely missed, but never to be forgotten. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire Mack family. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Josh S. Weston, Hon. Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Robert Kaswell, Chairman Rabbi Ronald Gray, Exec. V. P.

ALESSANDRINI--Flora. The Forbidden Broadway family mourns with sadness the passing of Flora Alessandrini, beloved mother of writer/creator Gerard Alessandrini. Flora was treasured by all who knew her. We send our deepest sympathy to Gerard, his father, and the entire Alessandrini/Miano family.

Days after his historic and headline-generating concert debut in mainland China, Bob Dylan played his first performance in Vietnam on Sunday night, eliciting criticism but drawing only moderate crowds. BBC News reported that Mr. Dylan, whose Sunday show at RMIT University in Ho Chi Minh City was his first ever in that Communist country, once again played a set list that had to be approved by the government there, a stipulation he had agreed to with the Chinese government for his concerts in Beijing and Shanghai last week. (Sunday's show included spirited tunes like ''A Hard Rain's a-Gonna Fall'' and ''Highway 61 Revisited,'' but no obvious protest songs like ''Blowin' in the Wind.'') Appearing in a performance space that could hold about 8,000 people, Mr. Dylan played to a crowd only half that size, The Associated Press said, a low turnout that could be attributed to the fact that tickets cost more than many Vietnamese make in month, or the fact that half its population is younger than 30 and has no memory of the Vietnam War era or Mr. Dylan's stature during it.

MACK--Ruth Kaufman, passed away of natural causes in Palm Beach Florida on April 7, 2011. She was born in Manhattan on November 28, 1914 and spent her youth in Williamsberg Brooklyn. She graduated at the age of 15 with High Honors at Eastern District High School in Manhattan. She walked the Williamsberg Bridge to school most days to save two cents for public transportation. She attended Hunter College in Manhattan. Her life was totally devoted to her family and Jewish charities of which the charities were: Yeshiva University where she received an honorary doctorate. Along with her husband, H.B. Mack, they were founders and benefactors of Long Island Jewish Hospital (now known as North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System); Boys Town of Jerusalem; Albert Einstein College of Medicine; and benefactor at the Jewish Theological Seminary. She taught Hebrew at the Hillcrest Jewish Center where she and her husband were founders and benefactors. Ruth Mack was amongst the leadership of the UJA and the Federation of Jewish charities. She was a member of the Board and Vice President of Temple Emanuel of Palm Beach. She is survived by her four sons: Earle, William, David and Fredric; six grandchildren: Richard, Stephen, Hailey, Jason, Andrew and Beatrice; and three great grandchildren: Harrison, Dylan and Tucker. A private funeral for family will be held Sunday. The Family will be receiving friends at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, NYC on Sunday from 4:30 to 7:30pm and on Monday and Tuesday between 5:30pm and 8:00pm.

HAGGERTY--Marti Kerr, died on April 5, 2011 in Middlebury, VT. She was 77 and suffered from Alzheimer's disease. A successful real estate broker/realtor with Caldwell Banker, Marti was among the first to be inducted into the NJAR distinguished sales club, which honors members who had million dollar sales more than 10 times in their career. Born in Newark, NJ, she was a 32 year resident of Summit and Sea Girt, NJ before relocating to Weybridge, VT in 2005. She is survived by her husband of 56 years, Edward, her son, Richard of Winooski, VT, four daughters and their husbands: Gwenne and James Dawson of Midlothian, VA, Beth and Gregg Beldock of Charlotte, VT, Carol and James Reardon of Darien, CT, and Moira Keshishian of Gallatin Gateway, MT and eight grandchildren. A funeral mass will be held at 9:00am on Saturday, April 16, 2011, at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, Charlotte, VT. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Elderly Services Inc., Middlebury, VT.

On March 28, 1961 a six-mile, two-hour parade wended its way through Jackson, Miss. — the largest public event in state history — to mark the centennial of Mississippi’s secession and the beginning of the Civil War. Tens of thousands of white Mississippians lined the route, greeting the festooned marchers with rebel yells of “Yiiiii Hoooaaah!” Women from the Mississippi Delta region, dressed in their Old South finery, rode on a float and sipped mint juleps as they toasted sending their men “off to war.” The South that day, noted the Jackson Clarion-Ledger, “rose again, in all its Confederate splendor.”

I had a great Civil War Centennial. I was eight years old in 1961, and my parents took our family on trips to Gettysburg and Antietam and Manassas. I had blue and gray toy soldiers, and Civil War trading cards, and I watched Johnny Shiloh and Johnny Yuma. From this, a life-long interest was born.

Broadway’s revival of “Anything Goes” won’t be going anywhere any time soon. On Wednesday, Roundabout Theater Company announced that its production of that Cole Porter musical, starring Sutton Foster as the evangelizing nightclub singer Reno Sweeney and Joel Grey as the milquetoast gangster Moonface Martin, will extend its run by about six months. The revival, directed and choreographed by Kathleen Marshall, is now planned to play at the Stephen Sondheim Theater through January 8; it was originally scheduled to close after July 31. (That’s roughly 184 more performances of cruise-ship based musical farce, so let’s hope everyone packed some additional swim trunks.) Reviewing this production of “Anything Goes” for The New York Times, Ben Brantley wrote that it “exudes the effervescence of a freshly poured gin fizz,” adding that when Ms. Foster “turns her toothy, triumphant smile on the audience there’s no doubt that she’s made many converts.”

According to Nielsen’s estimates, 19.2 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for “NCIS” on CBS; during the 9 p.m. hour, that network’s “NCIS: Los Angeles” (15.3 million) finished just slightly behind ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” results episode (15.5 million). At 10,“Body of Proof” (11.3 million) on ABC edged “The Good Wife” on CBS (10.9 million). ABC placed second for the night, lagging behind at 8 with the second season premiere of “Jamie Oliver’s Food Revolution” (5.3 million). NBC ranked third, averaging 7.2 million viewers for “The Biggest Loser” from 8 to 10, followed by “Parenthood” (5.1 million). Fox was a distant fourth among the networks with mostly reruns.

During the recent New York fashion shows, the blogger Hanneli Mustaparta posted a snapshot of Andreea Diaconu wearing a panda bear brooch that looked like a relic from the Atari age. After numerous Google searches (no luck), inquisitive e-mails (no luck) and one (lucky) Facebook search, we found the maker of the pin: 19-year-old Taj Melendez in Brooklyn, New York. “During art class in elementary school, we would do projects like these with perler beads,” says Melendez, who, like Space Invader, the street artist with a similar aesthetic, seems to shy away from attention rather than seek it out. He made his first pin, a replica of the men’s restroom icon, when he was 16. “I just wanted to start something, I wanted to stand out.” He sells his designs — bow ties, barrettes and an assortment of brooches like a thought bubble or a football — through his Web site ($55 to $75; go to bytaj.com). “I want to keep them special — that’s why I don’t create too many too fast.” When asked how Diaconu got her hands on that darling panda face, he shrugs with disbelief. “I have no idea,” he says. “But I sure was happy.”

Anastasia Vogt Yuan studied substance abuse among blacks and whites. In the journal Sociological Spectrum, she reports that blacks have lower rates of drug use than whites during early adolescence, but this gap gets inverted as they age. That is to say, whites are more likely to age out of drug use—they stop as they get older. Blacks, perhaps because of work, economic and family conditions, age out less, so by middle age they are using drugs more than whites. This would seem to put a dent in the theory that blacks suffer higher rates of drug use because they are more likely to grow up in single parent homes. If that were true, you’d see the effects in early adolescence. The evidence would seem to point to broader social influences.

Are bullies amoral or are they simply cruel? That is to say, do they bully others because they don’t know the difference between right and wrong, or simply because they don’t care about other people’s feelings? Gianluca Gini, Tiziana Pozzoli and Marc Hauser studied this question for the Journal Personality and Individual Differences. They studied 719 children between the ages of 9 and 13 and found that those who engaged in bullying had advanced moral competence. They could make sophisticated distinctions between moral and immoral conduct. They scored low on measures of compassion, though. This reinforces a growing body of research that suggests knowing right from wrong is not necessarily connected to behaving rightly or wrongly. Moral lectures don’t work well, but telling people stories designed to arouse compassion might.

Durra, a 34-year-old Londoner who studied film at New York University, says her own cultural influences — she’s of mixed Middle Eastern and Bosnian descent — inspired the film’s protagonist, Asya. Asya (played by the French actress Élodie Bouchez) is a downtown artist who has lumped together her Palestinian, Bosnian, Jordanian, Lebanese and Parisian heritages into some familiar Manhattan mystique.

A number of conventional beliefs simply don’t fly, like: political elections equal democracy, or you can’t time the stock market. Superstitions involving black cats are easily discredited, but still die hard. (If you step on a crack, you probably won’t break your mother’s back.) Then there’s fortune cookie-esque wisdom: a stitch in time saves nine, I guarantee it.  But slow and steady doesn’t necessarily win the race, especially if steroids are involved.

LUCERNE, Switzerland — Lucerne is having a yearlong affair with Brahms. Through the various parts of the Lucerne Festival, Bernard Haitink has been conducting the Chamber Orchestra of Europe in a comprehensive Brahms cycle. During the piano festival in November, they presented the two piano concertos (with Emanuel Ax as soloist) and the two serenades. In the current Easter festival, they performed the second of three programs on Monday evening, and they offer the third on Wednesday. In the summer festival, in August, they will add two final concerts amid a smattering of Brahms performed by others (Claudio Abbado and the Lucerne Festival Orchestra, Christian Thielemann and the Dresden Staatskapelle).

In the week since Paul Ryan’s budget proposal hit Washington, there’s been significant liberal pushback against the idea that Ryan and the rest of the House Republican leadership deserve to be called “serious” or “brave.” If Ryan and Co. were actually courageous, the liberal argument goes, they would have proposed raising taxes, or demanded Medicare cuts for current seniors, or otherwise taken on more conservative shibboleths and right-leaning interest groups. Political bravery, in this view, requires more than just proposing a more rigorous version of your own faction’s usual proposals. It requires breaking out of the partisan box completely, and risking the ire of your own side’s ideologues as well as the wrath of your political opponents.

ALBANY -- Dennis M. Walcott came to the Capitol two months ago to shepherd around New York City's new schools chancellor, Cathleen P. Black, and to sit by her side as she testified before lawmakers. On occasion, when lawmakers posed particularly technical questions, Mr. Walcott stepped in to answer. On Tuesday, in a return visit, Mr. Walcott answered all of the questions himself. And unlike Ms. Black, he was eager to take on any subject.

WALLACH--Miriam G.,born April 2nd, 1949, passed away peacefully at home in New York City on Monday evening, April 11th. Miriam was born in Romania and then lived in Belgium until she was four years old, when she moved to New York with her parents. Miriam graduated Phi Beta Kappa and with honors from Barnard College and then from the University of Pennsylvania Law School. Miriam practiced law for many years in New York City, principally at Shearman & Sterling, where she was a Counsel at the time of her retirement. She met her husband, Eric Wallach, at their first law firm, Webster & Sheffield. They were married in 1976 and have been inseparable for over 35 years. Miriam's greatest joy and satisfaction was watching her three children grow and progress and, most recently, having the happiness of becoming a grandmother. Beyond that, Miriam's special pleasure was in spending time at the couple's lovely home in Rhinebeck. In addition to her husband, Eric, Miriam is survived by her loving children, Katie, Emily and Peter, son-in-law Jason Ginsburg, daughter-in-law, Brittany Wallach, granddaughter Ellie Ginsburg, sister-in-law, Marina Ein, brother-in-law Daniel Ein, niece Jackie Newmyer and nephew Tory Newmyer. Miriam loved reading great literature, eating and cooking gourmet food, and traveling with her family. Miriam, who was a woman of unique style and grace, will be greatly missed by all those who knew her. The service will be held at Frank E. Campbell funeral home at 1076 Madison Avenue in New York City at 3:30pm on Wednesday, April 13th.

A year and a half into a campaign to rebuild Morgan Stanley, some shareholders are losing patience with James P. Gorman, the firm's chief executive. Despite a flurry of management changes and a big hiring spree to bolster its trading business, a big Wall Street money maker, the company's stock price is lower than when Mr. Gorman took over in early 2010. Analysts have been cutting their earnings forecasts for Morgan Stanley's first-quarter results, which the company is scheduled to report next week. On Tuesday, Goldman Sachs chimed in, cutting sharply its estimates for the bank.

Mikhail Baryshnikov's magic extended beyond the stage on Tuesday morning when a panoramic cityscape of St. Petersburg, Russia, by the 19th-century painter Petr Petrovich Vereshchagin sold at Sotheby's for $746,500. The dancer bought the painting in 1978 and recently donated it to the Baryshnikov Arts Center in Manhattan, which he established in 2005. The buyer was an unidentified German collector bidding by telephone who paid well above the $500,000 high estimate. Before the auction Mr. Baryshnikov said selling the painting was his way of using ''old art to generate new art.'' The proceeds will go toward new programs at the center, a laboratory and performance space for multidisciplinary artists at 450 West 37th Street.

8 P.M. (Sundance) THE GIRL ON THE TRAIN (2009) An unemployed, vacant-eyed young woman (Émilie Dequenne, above left, with Catherine Deneuve) who lives with her distant mother (Ms. Deneuve) near a train track in the Paris suburbs pretends to be the victim of an anti-Semitic attack after a relationship with a thuggish athlete (Nicolas Duvauchelle) sours. This seductive drama from André Téchiné was based on the real-life case involving Marie-Léonie Leblanc, a 23-year-old who claimed in 2004 that she had been the victim of an anti-Semitic attack by six men of North African and African origin on a train outside Paris. The French president at the time, Jacques Chirac, condemned the attack, and the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, urged French Jews to leave for Israel to ''escape the wildest anti-Semitism.'' Then the woman admitted that she had lied. ''I wanted my parents to take care of me,'' she explained, ''my boyfriend to take care of me.'' Manohla Dargis, reviewing the film in The New York Times, said: ''Mr. Téchiné isn't pretending that he understands what people do. But by showing us what they do, the flowers they pick and the people they love, he makes us notice them more intently.'' 9:30 A.M. (CUNY) CITY TALK In a two-part episode about baseball, repeated at 4:30 and 9:30 p.m., Doug Muzzio interviews the journalist Jimmy Breslin about his new book, ''Branch Rickey,'' about the manager and executive who helped break the sport's color barrier by signing Jackie Robinson (above with Rickey) to the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947. Though the biography breaks no factual ground, ''what Breslin has done, with his usual gritty perception, is revive a story of enormous consequence,'' David Oshinsky wrote in The New York Times Book Review. Rickey, ''a white man, is rarely mentioned when the great civil rights leaders are discussed. His politics were small-town Republican, his judgments often puritanical. He had numerous reasons for integrating baseball, Breslin reminds us, not all of them noble. But without his vision and persistence, civil rights may have taken an even slower, rougher path.''

TEITELBAUM--Rose Lea Harnick Died at 97 in her sleep on April 9th. A true matriarch, Rose was a touchstone for her family. "When one of my chickadees falls from the nest," she said cupping her hands, "I gently bring them back." Even in her later years, Rose provided a joyous welcome not only to family but friends of family, young and old. A high school drop out, Rose was an enthusiastic reader and a curious traveler, accompanying family to many foreign cities. After 30 years, as a corsetiere at small specialty shops, Rose became a popular docent at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. There, until she was 94, Rose led awed visitors through the 6 story tenement building, recalling the lives of its immigrant residents. She also volunteered at The Family Center and Coney Island Hospital. Raised by poor immigrants in Brownsville, Brooklyn, Rose moved at the age of 84 to Manhattan to be nearer her son, Herbert and his family. Calling the Upper West Side a lebedik place, she reveled in long walks along Broadway. This year, Rose moved to St. Louis where her older son, Steven and his family reside. In addition to her sons, Rose leaves daughters-in-law Marilyn Teitelbaum and Ruth J. Abram; grandchildren: Caren, Aaron, and Noah Teitelbaum; Rebecca Wallace; Anna Kaye; four great-grandchildren: Amelia Rose and Stella Rose Kaye, Jonah Teitelbaum and Leo Wallace as well as grandchildren's spouses: Gordon Kaye, Lila Teitelbaum and John Wallace. On April 13, following a private burial, a memorial service will be held at the Tenement Museum. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to the Lower East Side Tenement Museum 91 Orchard Street, New York City, 10002 c Rose Leah Harnick Teitelbaum Fund.

SCIENCE An article on Tuesday about the risks and benefits of prostate cancer screening for men in their 70s and 80s misstated the academic affiliation of Dr. Bruce Roth, who said doctors should consider a man's overall health and not just his age in deciding whether to order the test. He is a professor of medicine at Washington University in St. Louis, not at the University of Washington.

Unlike an actual brushstroke, there is nothing spontaneous about David Bouley's new Japanese restaurant of the same name. Brushstroke, which has been serving tryout dinners to invited guests in TriBeCa and will open to the public on April 20, took nearly a decade to develop. Even the name has been waiting in the wings since 2007. Last week, Mr. Bouley explained that years ago, when he was visiting the Tsuji cooking school in Osaka, Japan, he suggested to Yoshiki Tsuji, who runs the school, that they might do a restaurant together. ''Mr. Tsuji liked the idea,'' Mr. Bouley said.

Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts and Senator John McCain of Arizona on Tuesday made a bipartisan call for new legislation to protect consumer privacy on the Internet. In introducing the Commercial Privacy Bill of Rights Act of 2011, Mr. Kerry cited the 107 trillion e-mails that were sent last year and the nearly 600 million Facebook users as proof of how much consumers used the Internet.
