In his lyrics and music Robbie Robertson, the Band guitarist turned solo singer-songwriter, has told the tales of the Confederate soldier Virgil Cane and a mysterious new arrival to a town called Nazareth, but he has never fully unpacked his own life story until now. On Tuesday the Crown Publishers imprint of Random House said that it had acquired a memoir from Mr. Robertson, - one that he plans to write himself after a few curtailed efforts at collaborating on a biography with other writers and journalists. ''I thought, nobody can tell these stories as good as I can tell them,'' said Mr. Robertson, 67, who could recall at least four previous attempts at a personal history that he halted at various stages of development. ''And it doesn't make sense for me to be going through an interpreter on this. I need to, when I'm ready, do this myself.''

The children filed out of yellow school buses and descended the stairs to the basement of a Jewish community center in Queens, where they put on plastic aprons and paper chef hats in preparation for a lesson on how to make matzo. But the trip was not really about baking. It was a dose of religious education, offered free to public school students - during school hours, outside their school's buildings - under a long-running program known as ''released time.''

A gilded statue of Tutankhamun that was stolen from the Egyptian Museum in January has been returned, along with three other objects, Egypt's minister of antiquities, Zahi Hawass, announced on Tuesday in a news release on his Web site. The figure is from a statue of the king standing in a boat throwing a harpoon. The looters had broken the figure of the king off the boat, which they left in the museum. The news release, which did not explain how the objects were recovered, said that the figure had been slightly damaged, with a part of its crown and pieces of the legs missing, and that the whole statue would be restored. It was among several dozen objects looted from the museum on Jan. 28, in the midst of the protests in Tahrir Square in Cairo.

COSTANZO--Gesualdo (Al), died April 10, 2011 at his home in Vero Beach at the age of 94. He was born in the Edgewater section of Birmingham, Alabama, and was the eldest son of Italian immigrants. Dr. Costanzo had resided in Vero Beach for more than 30 years, after relocating from New Canaan, Connecticut. He retired as Vice Chairman of Citicorp of New York and its principal subsidiary of Citibank of New York in 1980. A 1937 graduate of Birmingham Southern College with a degree in economics, Dr. Costanzo earned a Doctorate in Economics from the University of Virginia and later served as a research fellow at the Brookings Institute. During World War II, he was a lieutenant in the Navy and served as a Japanese language specialist. After the war, he returned to his passion, economics, and worked for the U.S. State Department, served as a U.S. Treasury Representative in Italy, and served as the American member of the Greek Currency Board in Athens, Greece under the Marshall Plan. Dr. Costanzo engineered the 1951 devaluation and economic reform in Greece ushering in the "golden age of the drachma", ten years of rapid economic growth that brought prosperity to Greece. Prior to his arrival at Citibank in 1961, Dr. Costanzo served as deputy director of the Western Hemisphere Department for the International Monetary Fund. During his 19 year tenure at Citibank, Dr. Costanzo led the growth of the banks international businesses around the world interfacing with economic and political leaders at times in unstable and even volatile political environments. Dr. Costanzo attracted and nurtured many young bankers and worked with economic and political leaders. During his career, Dr. Costanzo also served as the Chairman of the Mercantile Bank of Canada, and on the Board of Directors for Owens-Illinois, Beatrice Foods, National Cash Register Corporation, Gindlays Bank in the United Kingdom and S.K.F. in Sweden. He was predeceased by his wife of 44 years Lillie Costanzo, and is survived by his brothers Armand and John Costanzo of Birmimngham, Sam Costanzo of Macon, Georgia, and Henry Costanzo of Ithaca, NY; daughter, Mary Balliet and grandson Brian Balliet, Jr. Private family services will be at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Lillie Costanzo scholarship fund of Birmingham Southern College, 900 Arkadelphia Road, Birmingham, AL 35254-0002.

SHAPIRO--Lilian, W.,74, formerly of Chestnut Hill, MA, died of cancer on April 10, 2011, in New York City. She was surrounded by her loving husband, Joseph and their two children, Kenneth Shapiro of Westport, CT and Kimberly Konigsberg of NYC and their spouses. She will be deeply missed by her adoring grandchildren Alex, Andre, James and Samantha. She was also survived by her sister-in-law, Lotti Rubin, her husband and family and her devoted cousins, Nancy and Arnold Smoller and their children. Lilian was born in London, England, September 4, 1936 to Gerard and Elfreda Wolfe who emigrated from Heilbronn-Sontheim, Germany. Ultimately they settled in the United States in 1940, via Cuba and the Dominican Republic. She was raised in Brookline, MA and graduated from Beaver Country Day School, Hood College and Simmons College School of Social Work. After receiving her MSW, she was a social worker at The Massachusetts General Hospital working with burn victims and terminal pediatric cancer patients. Despite her professional accomplishments, her proudest achievement was her devotion to her family. Lilian and Joseph were married 50 years and were the best of friends. They enjoyed doing the activities they loved together: visiting with their grandchildren; traveling; appreciating art, antiques and laundry ephemera. Their last passion culminated in an exhibit, "Blue Monday: Doing Laundry in America," at the National Heritage Museum in Lexington, MA in 2005. Over a thirty year period Lilian and Joe scoured flea markets and antique shows throughout the country, where Lilian was affectionately known as the "Laundry Lady." She was readily recognized for her Tide detergent sneakers and her yellow and red bakelite, laundry pin depicting washing implements. She was truly unique: a compassionate, elegant lady with beauty, intelligence and refined taste! A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, April 15th at 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Donations may be made in honor of Jimmie Holland, MD for the Geriatric Psychiatric Fund at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

It's almost enough to make you dizzy: Francis Ford Coppola announced yesterday that his Rubicon Estate, formerly known as the Niebaum-Coppola Estate, will heretofore be known as Inglenook. Say what?--Well, it actually all makes perfect sense. Inglenook, before it went to corporate brand-name heaven (or is that hell?) was the historic name of one of Napa Valley's pioneering wineries. It was founded in 1879 by Gustave Niebaum, and produced some of the greatest cabernet sauvignons in Napa history, particularly in the mid-20th century under John Daniel Jr., a grand-nephew of Niebaum. Mr. Daniel died in 1971, and eventually the winery, vineyards and Inglenook brand were sold off.--Mr. Coppola, the movie director, purchased the old Niebaum home and part of the original Inglenook vineyard in 1975. Since then, he has been trying to reconstitute the original estate. In 1995, he bought the old Inglenook winery and the remaining Inglenook vineyard, but the brand name eluded him. --The Inglenook brand, like Paul Masson, Martin Ray and other once-great California names, had sadly declined as big corporations used it for cheap factory wines. Today, most people associate it with little airline bottles rather than historic Napa wines.--But with his acquisition of the Inglenook name from the Wine Group, Mr. Coppola has succeeded in restoring the original Inglenook estate. No financial terms were disclosed. --At the same time, in an effort to return Inglenook to the top echelon of Napa wines, Mr. Coppola announced that Philippe Bascaules, the estate director at Chateau Margaux, would this summer assume the position of estate manager and winemaker at Inglenook. Mr. Bascaules has spent 21 years at Margaux, one of the five Bordeaux first growths.--While Mr. Coppola's holdings now constitute the original Inglenook estate, one remaining piece of the historic Inglenook empire, the Napanook Vineyard, lies elsewhere. Napanook was planted in 1836 by George C. Yount, for whom Yountville, Calif., is named. In 1946, Mr. Daniel, then the owner of Inglenook, bought the Napanook estate. When he died, and the remainder of Inglenook was sold off, the Napanook Vineyard remained with his daughters, Robin Lail and Marcia Smith. --In 1982, Ms. Lail and Ms. Smith teamed with Christian Moueix of Chateau Petrus to form Dominus Estate, with the Napanook Vineyard as its basis. Mr. Moueix became the full owner in 1995. -As Mr. Moueix would be the first to say, the transition from Bordeaux to Napa Valley is not simple. --''I was charmed by the beauty of the estate and its unique environment,'' Mr. Bascaules said in a statement. ''I found the tasting of 1959 Inglenook astonishing with regard to its freshness and complexity, and when I tasted some samples of the 2009 vintage, I recognized the incredible potential of this property.''--Mr. Coppola's top wine will continue to be called Rubicon. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

BELKNAP--Mary L. Mary's loving family is deeply saddened by her unexpected passing on Sunday following a cerebral hemorrhage. Only hours before, she was enjoying an intimate dinner at a favorite local restaurant with Norton, her beloved husband of 61 years, who is now comforted by their children, Paula, Barry and Randy as well as Mary's brother, William Lonam. Mary was a force of nature who loved and gave her energy, time and many gifts to family, friends, and New York. She maintained a lifelong passion for international affairs, after graduating in the first class of women at Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service. She and her family lived abroad for thirteen years, in Tokyo, Sydney and London where Norton was an executive with Exxon. After returning, and for many years since then, Mary served as a Board Member and Vice Chairman of the Foreign Policy Association. Her love and support for New York, opera and music started with childhood Metropolitan Opera radio broadcasts, and never diminished. Most of all, Mary loved her family and will be sorely missed by all of us. A private funeral service will be held this week. Mary would want any memorial donations to be sent to the Foreign Policy Association, 470 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016.

BEIJING -- In a bizarre move, China's television censors have issued new guidelines that all but ban TV dramas featuring time travel. In a statement (available here in Chinese) dated March 31, the State Administration for Radio, Film & Television said that TV dramas that involve characters traveling back in time ''lack positive thoughts and meaning.'' The guidelines discouraging this type of show said that some ''casually make up myths, have monstrous and weird plots, use absurd tactics, and even promote feudalism, superstition, fatalism and reincarnation.''
SHEFTELL--Fred, M.D. Our condolences to his loving wife Karen, children Lauren and Jason and mother Wilma. Passover will never be the same nor will our lives. The Hall & Guzinski families

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has proposed rules for clawing back compensation paid to executives of ''too big to fail'' financial institutions that do, in fact, fail. The rules are disappointingly weak. And because they are watered down, bank executives may again be encouraged to take excessive risks. Why are these compensation rules important? Clawback rules are needed because the financial crisis was caused in part by insufficient penalties for financial executives' poor performance.

WOOLWORTH--R. Frederick, dies at 79. Born November 20th, 1931. Son of Mr. Mrs. Norman Bailey Woolworth. Graduated from The Taft School, 1950. Joined the firm of Stone Webster where he worked for eight years. Was one of four partners who bought the Detroit Tigers in 1956 and sold his interest in 1962. Purchased many buildings in Old San Juan, Puerto Rico in 1959. Opened Hotel El Convento in Old San Juan, Puerto Rico in February, 1962 and sold in 1972. Opened The Coe Kerr Gallery in 1969 until 1995. Was president of The Art Dealer's Association of America 1986-1991. Was a member of the Arts Advisory Board for the Internal Revenue Service 1982-1984. Survived by eight children, Frederick C, Gigi, Michael, Priscilla, Nena, Pauline, Kingsley and Elizabeth and 12 grandchildren. His constant companion for the last ten years Sharon "Sherry" Mills. Funeral services will be held in the Woolworth Chapel at Woodlawn Cemetery, April 29th, at 10am.

BIGGER STAKE Fiat confirmed on Tuesday that it had obtained an additional 5 percent of Chrysler, increasing its stake to 30 percent after the American automaker reached a sales goal of $1.5 billion in revenue outside of North America. That target is the second one achieved as part of a 2009 agreement between the two carmakers. The first, which prompted Fiat to raise its stake in January to 25 percent, from 20 percent, occurred after Chrysler began producing a fuel-efficient engine at a Michigan plant. CHRIS V. NICHOLSON

7:56 p.m. | Updated Securities America has reached a settlement with hundreds of former clients, a deal that will require it and its parent, Ameriprise Financial, to pay approximately $180 million to people who lost money when two private placements the firm sold turned out to be frauds, according to people briefed on the agreement. The financial advisory firm notified a number of plaintiff lawyers on Tuesday that enough clients had agreed to the settlement terms to make it work, said these people, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak on the record. In late March, Securities America and lawyers representing hundreds of its clients who lost money in the private placements of Medical Capital Holdings and Provident Royalties reached an agreement that would give investors roughly 45 cents on the dollar, or almost $180 million. This settlement was much improved from a previous one that was rejected by a Dallas judge that would have left investors with about 10 cents on the dollar. In order for the richer settlement to go through, however, the vast majority of the claimants had to sign on. Specifically, if clients in arbitration with claims totaling more than $5 million or clients in a class action with combined claims totally $10 million said no, there would be no settlement, according to the people familiar with the terms of settlement. The value of the claims outstanding is roughly $145 million, these people said. Securities America and Ameriprise did not immediately respond to requests for comment. The deadline for clients to sign on was Sunday -- and the vast majority of clients agreed to the settlement.

BLUM--Abbey Friedfeld, passed away on April 11, 2011. She was the beloved wife of Howard (Ward) L. Blum, Jr., mother of Howard III (Tripp) and Ross, daughter of Esther Friedfeld and the late Harry Friedfeld, of Brooklyn, NY, and sister of Howard (Elon). She was a devoted aunt, cousin, family member, and friend to all who knew her. Strong-willed, fashionable, and full of spirit, she enjoyed life and all it had to offer, planning trips around the world and friendly gatherings at home. A daughter of Brooklyn itself, she was graduated from Sheepshead Bay High School and Brooklyn College. Always described as sweet, positive, and radiant by friends and family alike, she will be missed by all those whose lives she touched. She was a long-time supporter of Jewish and educational charities and set a wonderful example by giving to those in need and always thinking of others first. Services will be held Friday, 10am at Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th Street, New York City. The family will be receiving friends Thursday evening from 6pm-9pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, Saturday evening at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, from 6pm-9pm, and Sunday evening at the Harmonie Club from 4pm-8pm. For more information, contact Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 212-288-3500.

FLINT--George W.,MD, died on April 10 just four days after his 91st birthday. George had a very full, productive and creative life as a prominent surgeon on Long Island and then as a successful producer, director and actor, having founded The Renaissance Theater Company in San Diego California. He is survived by his wife Vally Flint and his sons Jonathan and Peter Flint and seven grand children Hannah, Rebecca, Catherine, Tyler, Sarah, Camille and Charlotte.

It is the Fastest Man in Siam, not the king.

On Tuesday, I wrote about B Corps, or benefit corporations.  These are companies that have changed their bylaws to take into account the impact of their decisions on the environment, community and employees, as well as profits.  To become a B Corp, a company must also get a passing score on an assessment of its business practices administered by a nonprofit group called B Lab.  About 400 companies have become B Corps, and the idea is spreading fast.

Lincoln’s Proclamation of April 15 is not a literary masterpiece. Nor was it trying to be. There was more urgent business to attend to — namely, the raising of 75,000 volunteers to defend Washington from attack. And yet, like every public document that issued from his pen, it is suffused with the particular phrasings of his mind. When seen in its handwritten version, below, courtesy of the Library of Congress, it is more clearly something that came from him, and not simply the great bureaucracy he personified as president. There are deletions, and inserts, and all the signs of a writer struggling to get it just right.

“The Mountaintop,” Katori Hall’s play about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will make it to Broadway this fall, but with only one of the two high-profile actors who were expected to appear in it. Producers for the play said on Thursday that Samuel L. Jackson, the Academy Award-nominated star of “Pulp Fiction,” will portray Dr. King in the production, which will be presented at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, with previews beginning Sept. 22 and opening Oct. 13; Kenny Leon, a Tony Award nominee for last year’s revival of “Fences,” will direct. Halle Berry, who was supposed to play Camae, a hotel maid at the Lorraine Motel in Memphis in Ms. Hall’s imagined account of the night before Dr. King’s assassination, will not be participating in the production as had been anticipated. In a statement, producers said “Ms. Berry would not be appearing in the role due to child custody issues,” and that an actor for the role “will be announced shortly.” “The Mountaintop,” which made its debut in London in 2009, won Ms. Hall the Olivier Award for best new play last year. The play is produced by Jean Doumanian Productions, Sonia Friedman Productions, Ambassador Theater Group, Jerry Frankel, Ted Snowdon, Bob Bartner and Tom Wirtshafter.

The brutal beauty of the boxer has long been captured by photographers and filmmakers, most memorably in Bruce Weber’s 1987 cult favorite, “Broken Noses.” Following in this romanticized style comes “Repton Boxing Club,” a short documentary by Alasdair McLellan, the Britain-based fashion photographer. MeLellan’s film — sponsored by Sunspel, a historic English underwear manufacturer — centers on a storied boxing club in London’s East London and in particular on Ryan Pickard, the young, squinty-eyed knockout of a narrator. Pickard and his brother spar and sweat like sprinklers in the sun-drenched ring, wearing singlets, tees and fine cotton boxer shorts from the classic Sunspel line. With training time done, Ryan and his mates head to the local cafe to “get away from the missus,” show off their tattoos and debate who’s the greatest fighter of all time. A day in the life of a fighting lad.

In Iraq, the youth-led uprisings across the Middle East have conjured a range of emotions. Resentment, for the fact that in Egypt and Tunisia and elsewhere the people are seemingly taking control of their future and with their own hands and voices are demanding and achieving change. Iraq, of course, required America’s guns and soldiers to topple an autocratic government. Empowerment, for the events have allowed officials here the confidence to tout their own democracy’s progress, however violent and fragile it still is. And finally, for the youths of Iraq, the inspiration to demand a more perfect country, despite facing an entrenched political elite that has stood in their way.

If you can’t easily locate a pair of squabbling, overeducated married couples to eavesdrop on, and don’t want to move to New York to do it, you can head to your local movie theater in a few months. “Carnage,” Roman Polanski‘s film adaptation of Yasmina Reza’s play “God of Carnage,” has been acquired for distribution by Sony Pictures Classics, which said on Thursday that it plans to release the film at the end of the year. The stage version of “God of Carnage,” which in 2009 won the Tony Award for best play, chronicles two Brooklyn couples who are brought together by a playground fight between their children, leading to a night of arguing, drinking and vomiting. Its original Broadway cast featured Marcia Gay Harden (a Tony winner), James Gandolfini, Hope Davis and Jeff Daniels (all Tony nominees). The film features a script written by Mr. Polanski and Ms. Reza, and will star Jodie Foster, Kate Winslet, Christoph Waltz and John C. Reilly.

When the pop star Shakira toured Mexico City’s new Museo Soumaya, her guide was none other than the museum’s founder, Carlos Slim Helú. A labor of love from Slim, the world’s richest man (who is also a creditor and minority shareholder of The New York Times Company), the museum, named after Slim’s late wife, has certainly got the city — and the art world — talking. Since it opened a couple of weeks ago with a gala attended by President Calderón and Gabriel García Márquez, more than 30,000 curious locals and tourists per day have streamed through its doors. (The museum is free to the public.)

No. 1 Chicago Bulls (62-20) vs. No. 8 Indiana Pacers (37-45)The Bulls finished with 62 wins, the most since Michael Jordan left the organization. The Bulls captured championships in the five other seasons they captured at least 60 wins. Those teams were all led by Jordan. Derrick Rose, who will probably become the league’s youngest M.V.P. winner and would be a college senior at Memphis had he stayed, leads one of the N.B.A.’s most balanced rosters, anchored by the solid defenders Joakim Noah and Luol Deng under the first-year coach Tom Thibodeau. Indiana faces long odds in trying to become the fourth team to beat a top seeded team. The Pacers are in the playoffs for the first time in five years and are the only qualifiers with a losing record, but can still be considered a mild threat. They rallied after firing Jim O’Brien and attaching Frank Vogel as interim coach. Danny Granger is one of the league’s quality wing players, Darren Collison is one of the league’s quickest point guards and the center Roy Hibbert provides scoring and length.

We’re still not entirely sure what Terrence Malick‘s generational drama “The Tree of Life” will be, but we can safely say that it will be one of 19 new films contending for the Palme d’or at the Cannes Film Festival that were announced by the festival’s organizers on Thursday. Also on the feature competition slate for this year’s festival, which runs from May 11 to 22, are Pedro Almodóvar’s “La Piel Que Habito” (“The Skin I Live In”), starring Antonio Banderas as a plastic surgeon seeking his daughter’s rapists; “We Need to Talk About Kevin,” a drama directed by Lynne Ramsay (“Morvern Callar”) and starring Tilda Swinton and John C. Reilly; “Melancholia,” from the Danish filmmaker Lars Von Trier (“Antichrist”); “Sleeping Beauty,” from the novelist turned first-time filmmaker Julia Leigh; and “Ichimei” (“Hara-Kiri: Death of a Samurai”) from the Japanese director Takashi Miike. The festival’s opening night film, which is not shown in competition, is Woody Allen’s “Midnight in Paris.” Other features that will be shown out of competition this year include “Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides,” directed by Rob Marshall, and, just to make things interesting, Jodie Foster’s latest film, “The Beaver,” starring Mel Gibson.

FOREIGN An article on April 7 about peace talks between the Afghanistan government and the Taliban misidentified the recipient of a $50 million donation from the United States government to support reconciliation efforts. It is the National Solidarity Program, not the High Peace Council. (The National Solidarity Program is a joint effort of the Afghanistan government and international donors, to support the Afghan Peace and Reintegration Program, which encourages Taliban fighters to give up their weapons. The High Peace Council provides strategic direction to the Afghan Peace and Reintegration Program.)

BELKNAP--Mary L. Mary's loving family is deeply saddened by her unexpected passing on Sunday following a cerebral hemorrhage. Only hours before, she was enjoying an intimate dinner at a favorite local restaurant with Norton, her beloved husband of 61 years, who is now comforted by their children, Paula, Barry and Randy as well as Mary's brother, William Lonam. Mary was a force of nature who loved and gave her energy, time and many gifts to family, friends, and New York. She maintained a lifelong passion for international affairs, after graduating in the first class of women at Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service. She and her family lived abroad for thirteen years, in Tokyo, Sydney and London where Norton was an executive with Exxon. After returning, and for many years since then, Mary served as a Board Member and Vice Chairman of the Foreign Policy Association. Her love and support for New York, opera and music started with childhood Metropolitan Opera radio broadcasts, and never diminished. Most of all, Mary loved her family and will be sorely missed by all of us. A private funeral service will be held this week. Mary would want any memorial donations to be sent to the Foreign Policy Association, 470 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016.

Q.My DVR box from the cable company sometimes stutters and skips the picture when I watch recorded shows. Is there any way to make it stop doing this? A. Several factors may be causing the problem, but try rebooting the DVR first. The box can often be rebooted by holding down the power button for several seconds, or through an on-screen menu option; check the manual for specifics. Also, make sure all the cables connecting it to the entertainment system are tight, and that nothing is blocking the heat vents on the DVR box itself.

Two of Hollywood's most progressive directors, James Cameron and Peter Jackson, are pushing forward with a new style of shooting that they say will make 3-D movies easier to watch. Film purists are likely to howl, and the majority of movie theaters don't have compatible projection equipment. On Monday Mr. Jackson caused a stir in cinema geek circles by announcing (via Facebook) that he is shooting ''The Hobbit'' at 48 frames per second, or twice the normal rate. Mr. Cameron has also been promoting use of the faster speed for his next two ''Avatar'' movies. Both men say that shooting at 48 frames per second makes a movie look more lifelike and lessens the eye strain that can come from 3-D presentation.

HALL--Terence Gabriel, 66, died peacefully at home in Brooklyn February 15, 2011 from cancer. A celebration of his life will be at The Dubliner, New York City, April 14, 2011 6:00pm. Born in Cairo, Egypt, March 24, 1945, Terence went to Newbridge College, Ireland and then to Trinity College, Dublin. He played rugby for both schools, and for the Bective Rangers where he was captain, 1967-'68 as well as the position of hooker for London Irish, an English major rugby club. His blue water marine insurance career began at Lloyd's, London, then in the US at Frank B. Hall; John P. Tilden Limited; Seaborne International; Aon Risk Services, serving as President of Seatide Brokers, Bain, Clarkson Limited of London. His passions were politics, history, 18th century antiques, Irish literature, and gardening. He was known for his wit and humor, a story-teller par excellence, loving husband, devoted father. He is survived by his wife of 27 years, Linda Faigao-Hall, his 25-year old son, Justin C. Hall, and his brother, Martin Hall of London. He will be missed deeply forever.

When thinking about the candidates for the 2012 Republican nomination, we can divide them into basically three groups. First are candidates in a group I'd call the Fairfax Five, Fairfax being the name of a wealthy Washington suburb in Northern Virginia. These are the candidates who have the seal of approval of the Republican establishment thinkers in Washington. More specifically, they're the candidates endorsed by George F. Will in his March 5 column:There are at most five plausible Republican presidents on the horizon -- Indiana Gov. Mitch Daniels, Mississippi Gov. Haley Barbour, former Utah governor and departing ambassador to China Jon Huntsman, former Massachusetts governor Mitt Romney and former Minnesota governor Tim Pawlenty.These candidates are playing it by the book, hiring staff and developing campaign infrastructures. They get more attention in the mainstream media than in the blogosphere. They are perceived as being electable and holding some reasonable appeal to independent voters -- although I think Haley Barbour, with his track record as a lobbyist and a history of having made what are perceived to be racially insensitive remarks -- is a questionable case.

The national tour of the 2009 Tony Award-winning production of ''Hair'' has added an unusual stop to its schedule: Broadway. The Public Theater announced on Wednesday that ''Hair'' would return on July 5, little more than a year after it closed on Broadway, for a nearly 10-week run at the St. James Theater. (The musical ''American Idiot'' closes there later this month.) Performances will conclude on Sept. 10, after which the producers plan to take ''Hair'' back on the road through the United States. Adding New York to a major national tour is relatively rare for a musical, although ''Dreamgirls'' kicked off its 2009 tour with an engagement at the Apollo Theater in Harlem.

HARMAN--Sidney. It is with much sadness that Baruch College notes the passing of Sidney Harman (Class of '39), whose generosity and vision have transformed our classrooms, our students and the excellence of our academic programs. Sidney Harman endowed the Harman Writer-in-Residence Program in the Weissman School of Arts and Sciences, and through it exposed thousands of Baruch College students to the wisdom and creativity of world class authors such as Edward Albee and Francine Prose. He was a member of Baruch College's "17 Lex Society" and was awarded an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree by the College in 2009. Harman's career spanned the arts, business, and public affairs like no other alumnus since our namesake, Bernard M. Baruch. He was the founder and chairman emeritus of Harman International Industries; he purchased "Newsweek" last year and later merged it with "The Daily Beast." The former Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Technology was a generous philanthropist and a friend to the arts. He gave millions to education, the performing and fine arts and other philanthropies. His transformative gift allowed the Shakespeare Theatre Company in Washington, D.C. to construct the Harman Center for the Arts. Harman liked to quote Maxwell Anderson who wrote, "It is for our arts that we will be remembered." Sidney Harman will be remembered for this and much more. Mitchel B. Wallerstein President, Baruch College

Q.How can you post pictures to Facebook from the iPad's Photos app? The ''Choose File'' button on Facebook is grayed out when I try to select a picture. A.Uploading photos to Facebook through the iPad's Safari browser does not work like it does when using Facebook with a Web browser on a regular computer. The ''Choose File'' button is grayed out here because Facebook's photo-uploader tool looks for files stored within traditional operating systems -- and not on the iPad's iOS system.

HARMAN--Sidney. The family of Sidney Harman sadly confirms his death on April 12th. Born August 5, 1918, he died after 92 and a half remarkable years. Loving husband to Jane. Father to Lynn, Barbara, Gina, Paul, Daniel, and Justine Harman. Step-father to Brian Frank and Hilary Peck. Father-in-law to Bill Cain, Nicole Harman, Philip Coltoff, Andrew Peck, and Lauren Frank. Grandfather to Megan Quitkin, Molly Small, Rachel Quitkin (Dan Smulian), Julia Cain, Isabel Cain, Grace Harman, Jake Harman, Lucy Peck, Will Frank and Henry Peck. The world was a richer place because of him. An audio pioneer, he brought music to the American home as no one had before. An avid believer in human rights, he marched with Rev. King, supported Eugene McCarthy in 1968, joined the Cabinet of President Jimmy Carter, and worked tirelessly to build a better, safer, more humane world for everyone. A committed philanthropist, he believed in bringing opportunity and enrichment, especially to young people. He played golf with only a three handicap, sang with passion (if not perfection), and never, ever stopped moving. At 92, he embarked on entirely new careers as publisher of Newsweek Magazine and founder of the University of Southern California's Academy for Polymathic Studies. A wonderfully unique individual whose passions were many, and whose love of life was ferocious in its intensity, he is, and will be, sorely missed.

WASHINGTON -- President Obama made the case Wednesday for slowing the rapid growth of the national debt while retaining core Democratic values, proposing a mix of long-term spending cuts, tax increases and changes to social welfare programs as his opening position in a fierce partisan budget battle over the nation's fiscal challenges. After spending months on the sidelines as Republicans laid out their plans, Mr. Obama jumped in to present an alternative and a philosophical rebuttal to the conservative approach that will reach the House floor on Friday. Republican leaders were working Wednesday to round up votes for that measure and one to finance the government for the rest of the fiscal year.

The Egg-Bot Kit, designed and sold on the Evil Mad Scientist Web site, prints detailed illustrations on spherical or ellipsoid objects using standard fine-tip markers. Besides eggs, you can ink things like Christmas tree ornaments. The device, in essence, is an updated pen plotter. Designs made in the app, working with Inkscape, an open-source vector graphics editor similar to Adobe Illustrator and CorelDraw, are sent via software built by Evil Mad Scientist to the USB-tethered Egg-Bot. The machine then plots each layer of color on the object, automatically rotating it to wrap the image around. Since the Egg-Bot can hold only one pen at a time, you have to manually switch colors between layers.

JOHANNESBURG -- Mike Campbell, a ferociously independent white Zimbabwean farmer who sued his country's autocratic ruler, Robert Mugabe, to stop the seizure of his land and improbably won, only to lose the farm when the government defied the court ruling, died on Wednesday. He was 78. The cause, the family said, was brain injuries sustained in a June 2008 beating administered by thugs from President Mugabe's party to punish Mr. Campbell for the case he had filed months earlier.
Here Arts Center 145 Avenue of the Americas, at Dominick Street, South Village

The architecture firm Diller Scofidio + Renfro, which seems to get every big commission these days, has been selected for yet another one. Stanford University has chosen the firm to design its new home for the art and art history department, the university is to announce Thursday. The 90,000-square-foot Burton and Deedee McMurtry Building will serve as an interdisciplinary arts hub and further develop the university's ''Arts District'' at the entrance to the campus. The building was named in honor of two alumni who donated $30 million toward the project. The building will consolidate the department's programs in art practice, design, art history, film and media studies, and documentary film, which are currently dispersed on campus. In a statement, Mr. McMurtry praised Diller Scofidio + Renfro - which redesigned Lincoln Center - for its ''creative process of exploration, experimentation and informed risk-taking.''

(NBC) THE OFFICE It's training day at Dunder Mifflin as Deangelo Vickers (Will Ferrell, above center, with Steve Carell, right) tries to step into the shoes -- at least temporarily -- of the incompetent bureaucrat Michael Scott, played by Mr. Carell, who is leaving the series after seven seasons. The Thursday night comedy lineup begins at 8 with ''Community,'' as the study group chooses spring semester electives and Pierce (Chevy Chase) proposes marriage to a mysterious woman (Michelle Krusiec) in his wine-tasting class. ''The Paul Reiser Show'' has its premiere at 8:30. In ''Parks and Recreation,'' at 9:30, Andy (Chris Pratt) and April (Aubrey Plaza) host a dinner party. In ''30 Rock,'' at 10, Liz (Tina Fey) and Kenneth (Jack McBrayer) try to smoke out Tracy (Tracy Morgan) from his hiding place in time to save ''TGS'' from cancellation. WALLACH--Miriam G.,born April 2nd, 1949, passed away peacefully at home in New York City on Monday evening, April 11th. Miriam was born in Romania and then lived in Belgium until she was four years old, when she moved to New York with her parents. Miriam graduated Phi Beta Kappa and with honors from Barnard College and then from the University of Pennsylvania Law School. Miriam practiced law for many years in New York City, principally at Shearman & Sterling, where she was a Counsel at the time of her retirement. She met her husband, Eric Wallach, at their first law firm, Webster & Sheffield. They were married in 1976 and have been inseparable for over 35 years. Miriam's greatest joy and satisfaction was watching her three children grow and progress and, most recently, having the happiness of becoming a grandmother. Beyond that, Miriam's special pleasure was in spending time at the couple's lovely home in Rhinebeck. In addition to her husband, Eric, Miriam is survived by her loving children, Katie, Emily and Peter, son-in-law Jason Ginsburg, daughter-in-law, Brittany Wallach, granddaughter Ellie Ginsburg, sister-in-law, Marina Ein, brother-in-law Daniel Ein, niece Jackie Newmyer and nephew Tory Newmyer. Miriam loved reading great literature, eating and cooking gourmet food, and traveling with her family. Miriam, who was a woman of unique style and grace, will be greatly missed by all those who knew her. The service will be held at Frank E. Campbell funeral home at 1076 Madison Avenue in New York City at 3:30pm on Wednesday, April 13th.

An article on Saturday about a looming fight between the New York real estate industry and the crane operators' union misspelled the surname of a corruption monitor who was appointed after federal racketeering prosecutions of two union locals. He is George Stamboulidis, not Stambolidis.

EGYPT With tensions rising between Egypt's military rulers and demonstrators, the authorities took a major step toward satisfying the demands of protesters by ordering the detention of Hosni Mubarak, the former president, and his two sons. They will be questioned about corruption and abuse of power during Mr. Mubarak's three-decade rule. YEMEN Fighting broke out between rival military factions in Sana, the capital, killing at least two people, Yemeni officials said. It was the first clash between government forces and those commanded by Maj. Gen. Ali Mohsin al-Ahmar, who announced his support for the country's antigovernment protest movement three weeks ago.

ROTTENBERG--A. Enid (nee Bergel), raised in Providence, RI, age 76, of Paramus, NJ, passed away on April 12, with her sons at her side. Predeceased by her loving husband of 49 years, Ira and her beloved daughter, Beth Rappoport. She is survived by her sons and their spouses, Mark and Elise, Hank and Ilene; son-in-law Scott Rappoport; seven adored grandchildren, Jason, Haley, Rachel, Matthew, Jackie, David and Jared; loving cousins and many friends. Her zeal for life and optimism shined like the brightest star and will survive eternally. Donations in her honor may be made to the Beth J. Rappoport Memorial Fund, c/o Benefit Sources, 1952 Rt. 22 East, Bound Brook, NJ 08805.

An Op-Ed article on April 4, about disclosure rules for nonprofit groups that engage in political advocacy, imprecisely described contributions by the billionaire brothers Charles and David Koch to such groups. While they contributed to a predecessor of the conservative group FreedomWorks, they say they have not contributed to FreedomWorks itself.

SPECIAL PAYOUT NYSE Euronext is considering a special dividend to its shareholders as one of several possibilities to win over investor support for its proposed merger with Deutsche Börse, a person briefed on the matter said. The payout to NYSE Euronext shareholders would be before the deal's closing, which is expected by the end of the year. NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Börse are also weighing other ways to pay out shareholders should the deal close, including dividends or share repurchases, people briefed on the matter said. Just two days after the surrender of Fort Sumter, a crowd gathered at City Hill in Worcester, Mass., to rally for war. Lincoln had called for troops to put down the insurrection the day before, and few responded as passionately as Worcester’s citizens — chief among them abolitionist Thomas Wentworth Higginson. “Tonight we have more than enthusiasm,” announced Higginson. “We have unanimity!”

Kicking off this weekend at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, the Fashion in Film Festival will be showing its third series of quality films, “Birds of Paradise.” Focusing primarily on the role of the costume, the festival aims to serve as a visual history lesson for fashion and film buffs with a timeline of European and American cinematic gems. The Seaport Museum New York is in talks with various maritime centers about taking its working vessels on a temporary or permanent basis to help defer costs. The museum — at 12 Fulton Street and formerly named the South Street Seaport Museum — is struggling financially, and in February it furloughed 32 employees, half of the staff. It has held conversations with the Hudson River Maritime Museum in Kingston, N.Y.; with Schooner Inc., a nonprofit maritime center in New Haven; and the Gloucester Maritime Heritage Center in Massachusetts. Frank J. Sciame, the Seaport Museum’s chairman, said through a spokesman that the museum “is exploring various options regarding the maintenance of its historic vessels.” The museum has said that it plans to sell Peking, the museum’s flagship merchant ship.

Back in early 2002, when Gary Taubes was writing a cover story called “What If It’s All Been a Big Fat Lie?” for this magazine, he and I had lunch every couple of months at Les Deux Gamins, a cafe in the West Village. At the time, I was one of those normal people who ate Cheerios for breakfast, but all that changed as I got to know Gary better. My lunches with him were like meetings with a parole officer, only it wasn’t a life of crime that Gary was steering me away from — it was a life of carbohydrates. The first time we went to Les Deux Gamins, the waitress offered us a bread basket. She never did again.

On Wednesday morning I stopped by the SoHo Apple store in New York City to purchase an iPad for a family member. As I had anticipated, a store clerk said they were out of stock and recommended that I check back the following morning. When I asked what time I should arrive, the clerk hesitated, looked around as if about to tell me a secret and said: “Well, do you see that group of people outside? They’re already here waiting for tomorrow’s shipment of iPads.”

This was one of those magical weeks of bedtime reading, when the house got perfectly quiet and my books got very loud and I ended up staying up until 2 in the morning just about every night. I was reading: a big, heavy, three-volume hardcover edition of Samuel Johnson’s “Lives of the Poets”; a newfangled iPhone essay (with pictures, audio, etc.) about ants called “Before the Swarm”; “Father and Son,” Edmund Gosse’s 1907 memoir about growing up with evangelical Christian parents (this was also on my iPhone, via the less high-tech Project Gutenberg); and an advance copy of Nicholson Baker’s erotic fantasy novel “House of Holes: A Book of Raunch.” (This won’t be published until August, but — hoo-boy, people, get ready for this book. It is going to be Talked About. There will be fistfights in the hallways of your local public library. I keep describing it to people as “porny Alice in Wonderland” — an impossible combination of crazy, cheerful imagination and industrial-grade filth. It made me hoot out loud every other page or so, and on a few occasions my mouth actually, literally dropped open. Just get ready.)

Twelve years after “Mad About You,” Paul Reiser made a low-rated return to NBC’s comedy line-up on Thursday. Just 3.3 million viewers tuned in to the premiere of “The Paul Reiser Show” at 8:30 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The new series faces considerable odds, coming after NBC’s similarly ratings-starved sitcom “Community” (3.5 million), at 8 p.m., and occupying a time slot otherwise dominated by “American Idol” on Fox. For the night, NBC ranked a distant third, garnering its best ratings at 9 p.m. for “The Office” (7.7 million), which featured a guest appearance from Will Ferrell. Fox led the night with 21 million viewers tuning for an elimination episode of “Idol” and 11.9 million at 9 p.m. for “Bones.” CBS placed second, despite broadcasting a line-up of all repeats. ABC was fourth, finishing close behind NBC with reruns from 9 to 11 p.m. following a new episode of “Wipeout” at 8 (6.2 million).

T’s Summer Fashion and Beauty issue is loaded with gems. In a “A Diamond in the Roughage,” the photographer Richard Burbridge and the set designer Gary Card transform the model Tati into a floral fantasy worthy of Arcimboldo. (Extra points if you can spot the carats.) For “A Beautiful Mine,” the writer Joshua Levine travels to South Africa with the jewelers behind the Los Angeles line Hoorsenbuhs to look for ethically mined diamonds. But not to be overlooked is our cover star, Cate Blanchett. She is well known, of course, for her portrayals of everyone from Queen Elizabeth I to Katharine Hepburn. In her new film, “Hanna,” she tries the role of ruthless C.I.A. agent on for size. But lesser known perhaps are the slew of roles she plays off-screen, including the co-artistic director of the Sydney Theater Company, an eco-activist who works with the Australian Conservation Foundation and the mother of three young boys. That is what we call multifaceted. See more from the issue >>

The only thing clear about diamonds may be the translucent stones themselves. Everything else is murky and vaguely sinister: where they come from, who dug them up and under what conditions, and, more particularly, if they reek of evil. A diamond isn’t like fur, which can’t do much to hide its origins. But there is a lurking suspicion that, like the gold of the Nibelungs, no good can come from this bright rock. It doesn’t help that the one word that rushes unbidden to stand next to diamond is blood. Diamonds are guilty until proven innocent.

Fashion is many things: beautiful, frivolous, devout, serious — sometimes all at once. It is performance and craft, in whatever style. In photographs and videos, it supplies us with visual intelligence. On May 2, when Daphne Guinness climbs into a window at Barneys New York to prepare for the Costume Institute gala that evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, I hope I have my own frock ready so I can go and watch. Do I think my friend is nutty? Yes, a little. Brave, definitely. And I am far from confident at this stage that anyone can create a performance-art piece with fashion that will mean anything, least of all in a luxury store window on Madison Avenue, and a time when apparel isn’t selling so well. But I’ll go anyway, just to see.

It was deep winter when I began planning this week’s column about holiday lamb, but I didn’t know how exactly I wanted to approach the animal. Tough luck: I got to spend late winter and early spring playing around with the country’s most underappreciated meat. I love roasting shoulder, and I love braising shanks (and neck, which, if you can get it, is one of the best braising meats there is), but as you can see I eventually settled on the leg – roasted leg, to be exact – because after all it seems most appropriate for the holiday table.

Iacopo Falai is on the move again, ready to open Bottega Falai Thursday morning next to his Caffe Falai. Done in his trademark shiny white mosaic tile, and glittering chandeliers, the shop is stocked with mostly Italian products, like dried porcini, sea salts, some herbs and spices, excellent Mancini pasta, olive oils, a selection of Italian cheeses and cured meats, breads, some produce, prepared foods like sandwiches, and the pastries for which Mr. Falai is known. A few tables are available for a snack on the spot but most of the food is to take away. A couple of weeks ago, he also doubled the size of the cafe by taking over an adjacent storefront, adding more seats and a full bar, also done in white tile and sparkle. And for his new Italian cocktail menu, you can watch his bartenders weigh the ingredients for your drink on little scales for better accuracy.

The Village Voice announced that it would present a new annual music festival after 10 years of producing the Siren Music Festival at Coney Island. Now The Voice is to produce the 4Knots Music Festival, on July 16 at the South Street Seaport. The festival will be free, open to all ages, and held rain or shine. (Its name comes from the speed at which the East River flows, The Voice said.)

At the tail end of my interview with Wes Craven, I asked the director about a tawdry little story involving Sharon Stone and his ex-wife that had made its way into his biography on various Internet sources, including Wikipedia. If we believe Craven’s explanation of the incident, the yarn is like so many things one encounters when doing research on the Internet — almost, but not entirely, true.

Siddhartha Mukherjee has a terrific article in this Sunday’s magazine about whether cellphones cause cancer. When he’s not writing, Mukherjee does research and teaches medicine at Columbia University. That makes sense because reading his cellphone story feels a lot like sitting in a riveting college class, where the professor is leading you step by step through the history of what makes for excellent — as well as flawed — scientific research, all the while explaining how to assess the research on brain cancer and cellphones. Mukherjee’s writing is precise and vivid and you feel like you’re in the hands of a very thoughtful, exacting authority. Last fall the magazine published an excerpt from his recent book, “Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer,” which was a finalist last year for the National Book Critics Circle Award and was named one of the 10-best books in 2010 by our Book Review.

There may have been a little bit of damage limitation in the second practice session in Shanghai on Friday as the Formula One teams prepared for the Chinese Grand Prix – but I am beginning to be skeptical about it. I’m referring to how in the first session this morning Sebastian Vettel, the winner in his Red Bull of the last four races — the first to this year and the last two last year — set the fastest time, more than two seconds ahead of the next best car and driver, Lewis Hamilton at McLaren Mercedes.

The off-again-on-again Manhattan club night Ghe20 Goth1k is a creative oasis within New York’s flagging night-life scene. Organized by Venus X Iceberg (née Jazmin Venus Soto), it serves as home base to many recently emerged hybrid rave/hip-hop genres. Soto is also producing a documentary called “Shakedown.” Reminiscent of the ’90s cult film “Paris Is Burning,” it traces the intricacies of black lesbian subculture in Los Angeles. Notably, Soto keeps her love of underground and subculture balanced. As a D.J., she has gained notoriety by mixing news clips from Al Jazeera in with her beats — during a New York Fashion Week gig, she interspersed coverage from the Egyptian revolution. As she puts it, “Even club kids should know what’s going on.”

MORLEY--Christopher R. 57, died Friday, April 8, 2011 after being stricken at his home. He was the husband of Leone T. Young (New York City/Falls Village). Christopher was born September 4, 1953 in Seattle, WA, son of Elsa (Colby) Morley and the late Ralph Morley. In addition to his wife, Christopher is survived by his son Christopher Morley, Jr., New Haven, CT; mother Elsa (Los Angeles), and brother Ralph (Los Angeles). He became a member of Leone's extended family, who he cherished and who greatly miss him as well. Christopher had been employed in the area of fixed income as a trader or salesperson by several Wall Street firms from 1984-2002. He retired in 2002 to pursue real estate and investment interests. During the past nine years he also became a self-taught architect, horticulturalist, artist, dog trainer, and wine connoisseur, among other hobbies. Christopher touched the lives of many through his community service and philanthropy. His work with the Falls Village Children's Theatre, animal rescue, and D.M. Hunt Library were especially important to him. For the many friends and family members who were blessed to have had Christopher as a part of their lives he will be remembered as an inspirational role model, avid conversationalist, and tireless communicator. (Just do not play poker with him!) His sense of humor, keen intellect, and kindness will be dearly missed. Above all else Christopher will be remembered for taking the time to use his many talents to help others. A Celebration of Christopher's life will be held in Falls Village at the convenience of the family. Memorial donations may be sent to the Falls Village Children's Theater (25 Deer Rd, Falls Village, CT 06031) or the Little Guild of St. Francis Animal Shelter (285 Sharon Goshen Tpke, Cornwall, CT 06796). Services under the care of the Newkirk-Palmer Funeral Home, 118 Main St., North Canaan, CT 06018.

Broadway's revival of ''Anything Goes'' won't be going anywhere any time soon. On Wednesday, Roundabout Theater Company announced that its production of that Cole Porter musical, starring Sutton Foster as the evangelizing nightclub singer Reno Sweeney and Joel Grey as the milquetoast gangster Moonface Martin, will extend its run by about six months. The revival, directed and choreographed by Kathleen Marshall, is now planned to play at the Stephen Sondheim Theater through January 8; it was originally scheduled to close after July 31. (That's roughly 184 more performances of cruise-ship based musical farce, so let's hope everyone packed some additional swim trunks.) Reviewing this production of ''Anything Goes'' for The New York Times, Ben Brantley wrote that it ''exudes the effervescence of a freshly poured gin fizz,'' adding that when Ms. Foster ''turns her toothy, triumphant smile on the audience there's no doubt that she's made many converts.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article on Thursday about President Obama's speech outlining his proposal for reducing budget deficits misstated the number of senior citizens who, the president said, would have to pay $6,000 more in health costs to offset the tax cut for each wealthy individual that is part of a competing Republican deficit-reduction plan. He said 33 senior citizens, not 30.

BLUM--Abbey Friedfeld, passed away on April 11, 2011. She was the beloved wife of Howard (Ward) L. Blum, Jr., mother of Howard III (Tripp) and Ross, daughter of Esther Friedfeld and the late Harry Friedfeld, of Brooklyn, NY, and sister of Howard (Elon). She was a devoted aunt, cousin, family member, and friend to all who knew her. Strong-willed, fashionable, and full of spirit, she enjoyed life and all it had to offer, planning trips around the world and friendly gatherings at home. A daughter of Brooklyn itself, she was graduated from Sheepshead Bay High School and Brooklyn College. Always described as sweet, positive, and radiant by friends and family alike, she will be missed by all those whose lives she touched. She was a long-time supporter of Jewish and educational charities and set a wonderful example by giving to those in need and always thinking of others first. Services will be held Friday, 10am at Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th Street, New York City. The family will be receiving friends Thursday evening from 6pm-9pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, Saturday evening at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, from 6pm-9pm, and Sunday evening at the Harmonie Club from 4pm-8pm. For more information, contact Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 212-288-3500.
DEMETRIOU--Niki, on April 13, 2011. Close your angel eyes and dream sweet golden dreams.

An article on Tuesday about the increasing burden of student loan debt misstated the name of an organization whose president, Lauren Asher, described the social consequences of the debt problem. It is the Institute for College Access and Success, not the Institute for Student Access and Success.

We're still not entirely sure what Terrence Malick's generational drama ''The Tree of Life'' will be, but we can safely say that it will be one of 19 new films contending for the Palme d'or at the Cannes Film Festival that were announced by the festival's organizers on Thursday. Also on the feature competition slate for this year's festival, which runs from May 11 to 22, are Pedro Almodovar's ''La Piel Que Habito'' (''The Skin I Live In''), starring Antonio Banderas as a plastic surgeon seeking his daughter's rapists; ''We Need to Talk About Kevin,'' a drama directed by Lynne Ramsay (''Morvern Callar'') and starring Tilda Swinton and John C. Reilly; ''Melancholia,'' from the Danish filmmaker Lars Von Trier (''Antichrist''); ''Sleeping Beauty,'' from the novelist turned first-time filmmaker Julia Leigh; and ''Ichimei'' (''Hara-Kiri: Death of a Samurai'') from the Japanese director Takashi Miike. The festival's opening night film, which is not shown in competition, is Woody Allen's ''Midnight in Paris.'' Other features that will be shown out of competition this year include ''Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides,'' directed by Rob Marshall, and, just to make things interesting, Jodie Foster's latest film, ''The Beaver,'' starring Mel Gibson. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

HARMAN--Sidney. The family of Sidney Harman sadly confirms his death on April 12th. Born August 5, 1918, he died after 92 and a half remarkable years. Loving husband to Jane. Father to Lynn, Barbara, Gina, Paul, Daniel, and Justine Harman. Step-father to Brian Frank and Hilary Peck. Father-in-law to Bill Cain, Nicole Harman, Philip Coltoff, Andrew Peck, and Lauren Frank. Grandfather to Megan Quitkin, Molly Small, Rachel Quitkin (Dan Smulian), Julia Cain, Isabel Cain, Grace Harman, Jake Harman, Lucy Peck, Will Frank and Henry Peck. The world was a richer place because of him. An audio pioneer, he brought music to the American home as no one had before. An avid believer in human rights, he marched with Rev. King, supported Eugene McCarthy in 1968, joined the Cabinet of President Jimmy Carter, and worked tirelessly to build a better, safer, more humane world for everyone. A committed philanthropist, he believed in bringing opportunity and enrichment, especially to young people. He played golf with only a three handicap, sang with passion (if not perfection), and never, ever stopped moving. At 92, he embarked on entirely new careers as publisher of Newsweek Magazine and founder of the University of Southern California's Academy for Polymathic Studies. A wonderfully unique individual whose passions were many, and whose love of life was ferocious in its intensity, he is, and will be, sorely missed.

An obituary on Wednesday about Charles Laufer, the founder of Tiger Beat magazine, omitted the name of a survivor. It is his daughter Teena Naumann. The obituary also misspelled the surname, before her marriage to Mr. Laufer, of his widow. She is the former Dorothy Lacy, not Lacey.
BLUM--Abbey. Go gentle into that good night. We will miss you. Our deepest sympathy to her loving husband and sons. Julie, Robert, and Jonathan Desnick

Even though James P. Gorman was promoted to chief executive of Morgan Stanley last year, he received a $1 million pay cut, as his total compensation fell to $14 million, the firm disclosed Thursday in a regulatory filing. The pay cut comes as Mr. Gorman strives to revitalize Morgan Stanley, where earnings and its stock price have remained under pressure since he took charge at the beginning of 2010.

LAHAGE--Edmund Peter, of Great Neck, NY passed away on April 12th at age 80. Ed was born at home in Hull, MA on August 1, 1930, the youngest of nine children, to Abe and Farida Lahage. He married his wife, Doris Audrey Cosgrove, moving to Washington, D.C. to do deeply classified work during the Cold War, working with his brother Joseph in service of the government. He returned to work in the family restaurant business. Ed's affinity for logic and numbers drew him into the burgeoning field of computers, where he would have a lasting career. Ed was a man of letters - fascinated with political history and current events. He believed that to be a good citizen was to be well-informed. During the 2008 election, Ed worked hard to get out the vote. Ed is survived by his daughter Jean and her husband Reuben Cohen of Manhasset, NY, his daughter Miriam and her husband Rev. Andrew Pakula of London, United Kingdom, his grandson Jesse Cohen and his fiance Liz Schibuk of Pawtucket, RI, his grandson Jacob Pakula of Medford, MA, his sisters Frances Goldie and Evelyn Lahage of Hull, MA, and many loving nieces and nephews. Edmund was predeceased by his wife, his sons, Peter and Joseph, and his siblings, Henry, Alice, Joseph, Felix, George, and Helen. A service celebrating the life of Edmund will be held on Saturday, April16, at 2pm, at First Parish Milton Church, 535 Canton Ave., Milton, MA 02186. In lieu of flowers, donations will be gratefully received for: Unity Unitarian Church, 277A Upper Street, London N1 2TZ, United Kingdom, or Mentoring Partnerships of NY and LI, 150 Motor Parkway, Suite 90, Hauppauge, NY 11788 USA.

Professor of Computer Information Systems, University of Michigan, an empirical researcher who also spent many years developing information retrieval theory in light of philosophy of language. Barbara, Chris, and Alain

FIERSTEIN--Blanche, The AHRC New York City Board of Directors, senior staff and membership mourn the passing of AHRC New York City Board Member, Blanche Fierstein, and extend sympathy to her beloved and bereaved family. Over the last 43 years, Mrs. Fierstein devoted her time, spirit and energy to AHRC New York City and NYSARC Inc. A past president of the New York City Chapter, Blanche held various Board Officer positions over the years, and served on and chaired several Board Committees. She was a member of the NYSARC Inc., Board of Governors and the President of NYSARC Inc., for thirteen years. Blanche was an eloquent, inspirational and outspoken advocate for individuals with developmental disabilities. She was a parent advocate who spoke from the heart as only a parent can. But she was also a consummate professional in the field, holding the position of Principal of the DOE's Queens OTC for many years. Her knowledge, her teaching skills and her ability to "tell it like it is" with candor and wit made her a figure that was well respected by Governors, legislators and government officials. Blanche was married to the late Eugene Fierstein and lived in Woodmere New York. She is survived by her daughter Andrea who resides in an AHRC Nassau group residence, her son Richard, daughter-in-law Penny and grandchildren Russell, Leigh and Jason, Lorie, David and Keith. She will be remembered by her "AHRC family" for giving of herself for over forty years and will be greatly missed. Dr.Melvin Gertner, First Vice President AHRC New York City Michael Goldfarb, Executive Director, AHRC New York City
STIBER--Natalie, Died on April 12, 2011. Much loved mother, grandmother, and friend.

No. 1 Chicago Bulls (62-20) vs. No. 8 Indiana Pacers (37-45)The Bulls finished with 62 wins, the most since Michael Jordan left the organization. The Bulls captured championships in the five other seasons they captured at least 60 wins. Those teams were all led by Jordan. Derrick Rose, who will probably become the league's youngest M.V.P. winner and would be a college senior at Memphis had he stayed, leads one of the N.B.A.'s most balanced rosters, anchored by the solid defenders Joakim Noah and Luol Deng under the first-year coach Tom Thibodeau. Indiana faces long odds in trying to become the fourth team to beat a top seeded team. The Pacers are in the playoffs for the first time in five years and are the only qualifiers with a losing record, but can still be considered a mild threat. They rallied after firing Jim O'Brien and attaching Frank Vogel as interim coach. Danny Granger is one of the league's quality wing players, Darren Collison is one of the league's quickest point guards and the center Roy Hibbert provides scoring and length. No. 2 Miami Heat (58-24) vs. Philadelphia 76ers (41-41)Miami, the team that celebrated in the summer when it created a stir about free agency and power teams, enters its first playoff in the LeBron James-Dwyane Wade-Chris Bosh era as an unknown. Will Miami be the team that dominated in winning 21 of 22 games in one stretch or the one that went 3-8 against Boston, Orlando and Chicago and failed to close late games? Like the Knicks, they have enough stars to win a series when all else goes wrong. The Heat experienced its regular season under the microscope, a lens that will only increase as the playoffs advance. The workman-like 76ers are coached by Doug Collins, who revitalized the franchise in his first year. They spread the offense and the responsibilities. Elton Brand is the team's leading scorer with 15.1 points per game. Brand's average ranked 48th in the N.B.A. Philadelphia's bid at an upset will also be hurt if the valuable reserve Louis Williams (strained hamstring) is not healthy. No. 3 Boston Celtics (56-26) vs. No. 6 Knicks (42-40)The Celtics went a pedestrian 15-12 to end the season after trading their defensive anchor and eternal scowler Kendrick Perkins and showed signs of age, boredom and contentment. Sound familiar? With the same issues (minus Perkins's departure) facing Boston last season in a 27-27 finish to their season, Boston rallied and forced the Lakers to seven games in the finals. The Celtics are again tempting that fine line a team loaded with experience and one that can hold a joint retirement party after the playoffs. Even so, the Celtics handled the Knicks in all four of their meetings this year, including twice since the All-Star Game break. The Knicks hopes lie in Carmelo Anthony, Amar'e Stoudemire and Chauncey Billups all catching fire at least four times in seven games. The Celtics offer the Knicks mismatches. For example, if Mike D'Antoni chooses to guard Rajon Rondo with Landry Fields or Toney Douglas instead of Billups, will Billups be up to chasing the sharpshooter Ray Allen through the myriad of screens that Boston will set? Shaquille O'Neal, who will be available after missing chunks of the season with right leg injuries, also poses another challenge that the Knicks simply cannot match.

SYRIA The government of President Bashar al-Assad withdrew its feared state security forces from the restive coastal city of Baniyas, replacing them with regular army troops. Mr. Assad also met with leaders from the southern city of Dara'a, where the country's growing pro-democracy protest movement began in mid-March, formed a new cabinet and announced an amnesty for prisoners detained in the recent protests. TUNISIA Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, the former leader who fled after a popular uprising forced him out, is now facing 18 legal cases, Tunisia's official news agency said. They include ''conspiring against the state, voluntary manslaughter and drug use and trafficking,'' the news agency quoted the nation's justice minister as saying.

The Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said on Wednesday that they had dismantled a giant international network of computers infected by malicious software, one that was used in an eight-year financial crime spree. The agencies used both legal and technical methods, some of them unorthodox, in what they described as a groundbreaking effort to dismantle the so-called botnet, known as Coreflood. The botnet is estimated to have commandeered some 2.3 million Windows PCs in homes and businesses around the world, including 1.8 million in the United States.

Get out those dancing shoes. Lincoln Center has just announced the lineup for Midsummer Night Swing, its annual salsa, swing, disco, tango, Gypsy jazz and folk dancing festival that takes place under the stars. This year a new dance floor has been installed at the band shell in Damrosch Park on West 62nd Street. A lottery, which you can enter at midsummernightswing.org, will be used to allocate tickets for opening night on June 27, a Monday. The next evening, the 28th, is a tribute to ''Soul Train'' with the saxophonist Pee Wee Ellis and the trombonist Fred Wesley along with Martha High and Fred Ross. Tyrone Proctor, an original ''Soul Train'' dancer, will be on hand to instruct and Biz Markie will be the D.J.

If you can't easily locate a pair of squabbling, overeducated married couples to eavesdrop on, and don't want to move to New York to do it, you can head to your local movie theater in a few months. ''Carnage,'' Roman Polanski's film adaptation of Yasmina Reza's play ''God of Carnage,'' has been acquired for distribution by Sony Pictures Classics, which said on Thursday that it plans to release the film at the end of the year. The stage version of ''God of Carnage,'' which in 2009 won the Tony Award for best play, chronicles two Brooklyn couples who are brought together by a playground fight between their children, leading to a night of arguing, drinking and vomiting. Its original Broadway cast featured Marcia Gay Harden (a Tony winner), James Gandolfini, Hope Davis and Jeff Daniels (all Tony nominees). The film features a script written by Mr. Polanski and Ms. Reza, and will star Jodie Foster, Kate Winslet, Christoph Waltz and John C. Reilly. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Sean Forman is the creator of Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues. Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter is struggling through what is easily the worst hitting stretch of his career. For the 100 games from June 21 of last year to April 13 of this year, Jeter has hit .257 with just a .662 O.P.S. Sabermetricians often combine a player's on-base percentage and slugging percentage as a quick proxy for batting performance. This is well below the current American League average of .712 for all batters and .691 for shortstops. Before his current slump, dating to May 2010, the worst O.P.S. of his career over 100 games was .699 from July 24, 2003, to May 25, 2004, which he rebounded from with an .823 O.P.S. in 2004.

A listing of credits on Thursday with a theater review of ''Sleep No More,'' at the McKittrick Hotel on West 27th Street in Manhattan, misstated the surname of a producer. He is Jonathan Hochwald, not Hochwalk.

People gathered on Thursday along the Hudson River in Newburgh, N.Y., to pray for Lashanda Armstrong and three of her children. They died on Tuesday when Ms. Armstrong drove her minivan into the river with four children inside. A son, 10, escaped by climbing out a window. Earlier, Ms. Armstrong left a message on Facebook saying she was sorry for what she was about to do.

The demise of one of broadcasting's oldest institutions, the daytime soap opera, crept closer Thursday as ABC announced it would end two of its long-running daily serial dramas, ''All My Children'' and ''One Life to Live.'' The decision will leave ABC will just one soap on its schedule, ''General Hospital.'' CBS has eliminated two of its venerable soaps, ''Guiding Light,'' which was dropped in 2009, and ''As the World Turns'' which was canceled last year.

7:04 p.m. | Updated Preparations for the jumbo stock market debut of Glencore International, the commodities producer and trader, took a step forward Thursday when it formally announced its intention to offer shares on the London and Hong Kong stock exchanges later this year.

8 P.M. (Disney) LEMONADE MOUTH (2011) Believe in yourself. Follow your dreams. Celebrate family. And, oh yeah, rock on. Those are just a few of the precepts explored in this Disney Channel original movie about five very ordinary, music-obsessed high school students who meet in detention, do the obvious and form a band -- and become the voice of their generation. The cast, above from left, includes Blake Michael (who landed the role through an open casting call), Adam Hicks (''Zeke and Luther''), Hayley Kiyoko (''Wizards of Waverly Place''), Bridgit Mendler (''Good Luck Charlie''), Naomi Scott ( ''Life Bites'') and Nick Roux (''What Would Jane Do''). 3 P.M. (Fox) THE DR. OZ. SHOW John Quiñones of ''Primetime: What Would You Do?'' on ABC (Fridays at 9 p.m.) reveals how ordinary Americans respond to uncomfortable situations -- in this case, the staged scene of a mother arguing with her daughter about her weight and urging her to undergo a gastric bypass procedure. Two unwitting bystanders explain why they intervened.

FIERSTEIN--Blanche. The entire AHRC Nassau family mourns the passing of beloved board member, Blanche Fierstein. Blanche was a giant in the field of developmental disabilities services, who met each challenge with tenacity, brilliance and unflinching boldness. She served as the longest tenured President of NYSARC, Inc., working alongside families, professionals and state officials for 13 years in creating the highest quality services for people with special needs. She played a integral role as a parent advocate for the implementation of Governor Pataki's New York State CARES initiative shaping the field into a national model of care. Blanche's gift of oration moved and inspired people to take action. Professionally, she was the principal of Queens Occupational Training Center creating quality standards in education and vocational training for people with special needs. For more than 35 years, she served as board member of AHRC NYC and served the last ten years of her life as an officer of the Board of AHRC Nassau. Individuals with disabilities and their families across New York State have lost a great and gifted friend with Blanche Fierstein's passing. Our prayers are with her children Andrea and Richard, her daughter-in-law Penny, grandchildren Russell, Leigh and Jason, Lorie and Keith and David, her great-grandchildren and the entire Fierstein family. AHRC Nassau Board of Directors & President, Howard Jurist, Esq. Michael Mascari, Executive Director

LUGER--Sanford "Sandy", 74, of New York City passed away peacefully at home on Wednesday, April 13, 2011. Husband of Ellen Samuel Luger. Father of Todd and Peter Luger. Stepfather of Mimi Samuel and Joanne Samuel Goldblum. Spectacular grandfather of Jesse, Mollie, and Sherman Goldblum. Avid photographer, world traveler, and card carrying member of the ACLU. Retired Vice President at Merck-Medco. Celebration of life on Friday, April 15 at 2:00pm at Plaza Community Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (at 91st St), New York City. Donations in Sandy's honor may be made to the New Haven Diaper Bank, International Center for Photography, or the ACLU of New Jersey.

BACHMANN--Margot Julie, 97, died at home on April 12th. She is survived by her children Peter, Mona and Nicole, their spouses, and her five grandchildren. Services, Sunday, 2pm. The Riverside: 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

An article in the Square Feet pages on March 23 about the growth of solar energy farms misstated the position of the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities on a proposal by a developer, Ed Walters, to sell solar electricity to residents of an apartment complex he is building in Stafford Township, N.J. It has had preliminary discussions with Mr. Walters; it has not approved the proposal.
