BLUM--Abbey. AJC's Women's Campaign Board is deeply saddened by the death of Abbey Blum, a devoted member for more than 25 years. Her philanthropy and work on behalf of the Jewish people have left a lasting legacy. We send heartfelt condolences to her beloved husband, Ward, and their sons, Tripp and Ross. Mindy Heyer, Chair Elaine Petschek, Honorary Chair

John Schreiber, a media executive, has been selected as the new president and chief executive of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in downtown Newark, the center's board announced on Thursday. Mr. Schreiber, who takes over on July 1, will replace the center's founding head of 22 years, Lawrence P. Goldman, who will lead the center's new subsidiary, the Theater Square Development Corporation. The corporation is focused on developing land adjacent to the center.

Deputy Mayor Dennis M. Walcott was cleared Thursday by the state to become the next New York City schools chancellor. The state education commissioner, David M. Steiner, granted him a waiver (see below) to compensate for his lack of traditional credentials that the state requires of schools chancellors and superintendents.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about challenges facing New York City's new schools chancellor referred incorrectly to a man seen last Friday handcuffed near the Cobble Hill School of American Studies. He had been arrested after an incident in a nearby subway station; he had not been inside the Brooklyn school.

No. 1 San Antonio Spurs (61-21) vs. Memphis Grizzlies (46-36) The Spurs rolled from the beginning of the season, starting 13-1. A late six-game losing streak is deceptive because Gregg Popovich began resting his players. There are two main differences in the Spurs' improvement: their health, an issue in the last two postseasons, held up through the regular season; and Tony Parker and Manu Ginobili can strike fear in any opposing coach. But Ginobili hyperextended his right elbow in the season finale Wednesday night and could be limited. The Spurs are less defensive-orientated and ran more on offense this season to a tune of 103.7 points a game. Tim Duncan is no longer the offensive focal point and averaged a career-low 13.4 points, but is still effective enough to lure double teams. Memphis scored a league-high 51.6 points in the post and its interior size of Zach Randolph and Marc Gasol should pose problems for San Antonio. Memphis will play without its injured star, Rudy Gay, who partially separated his left shoulder Feb. 15. On defense, Memphis is scrappy and averaged a league-high 9.4 steals.

An article on Thursday about the order by a federal judge in Wichita, Kan., to postpone a trial because of the impending birth of a defense lawyer's first child misquoted a portion of a line from Shakespeare's ''The Taming of the Shrew'' that was cited in the order. Judge Eric F. Melgren suggested that the legal adversaries ''strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends,'' not ''drive mightily.''

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the children's author Michael Morpurgo, whose book ''War Horse'' has been made into a play and a movie to be released in December, misstated the number of copies of that book in print in the United States. It is about 200,000, not 500,000, which is the total number of four of his books, including ''War Horse,'' that have been published by Scholastic in the United States.

The Yankees gave Pedro Feliciano two years. He gave them one month. His durable left shoulder, which earned him respect from his Mets teammates and a lucrative contract from the Yankees, has finally betrayed him. Feliciano said Thursday that he would most likely have surgery to repair the torn posterior capsule in his shoulder, which would abort his 2011 season before it began.

FARREN--Patricia Anna White, 82, died on April 12, 2011 peacefully in her sleep at her home in Baldwin, Long Island. Youngest daughter of the late Lillian Wheeler Andrews and the late Herbert Melville White. She is survived by her husband William A. Farren III of Baldwin; a daughter Nancy of Highland Mills; a son James of New York; and a son Andrew of Centre Island. Memorial service 10am on May 7th, 2011 First Presbyterian Church of Baldwin. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Old Westbury Gardens, Old Westbury, New York.

MASON--Alan Jay. born June 8, 1941, departed April 13, 2011. Beloved of his wife Judith (Wright) Mason of 47 years, his children Elisabeth, Norah, Daniel and Ben, and grandchildren Simon and Nathaniel. A stalwart of the Dalton community since 1967, he touched the lives of thousands of its young men and women. Service to be followed by a memorial celebration 2pm Saturday, April 16, 2011, at St. Bartholomew's Church, 325 Park Avenue. Donations can be made to a fund in Alan's name established by the Dalton School.

An article on Tuesday about two new studies that question the overall environmental advantages of natural gas misstated the amount of carbon dioxide produced by burning natural gas instead of oil. Burning natural gas emits about 30 percent less carbon dioxide than oil, not 30 percent as much as oil.

Brandon Dubinsky is getting the playing time and responsibility a team’s leading scorer deserves. But as the Rangers enter Game 3 of their first-round playoff series against Washington on Sunday, Dubinsky will need to put the first two games in his rear-view mirror.

SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — This one seemed tougher than past Sundays, but for me it was worth it. What’s better than a bunch of punchlines from stand-up comedians, humorists and one iconic horror writer? I am a fan of all of the people who contributed theme entries to Matt Ginsberg’s puzzle (even Anonymous), so I really enjoyed today’s puzzle.

My Sunday column is about the ways bottom-up grassroots youth movements can bring about social change, from toppling Hosni Mubarak to curbing teen smoking. I was drawn into the subject out of fascination with the way the Serbian youth movement had developed strategies that spread to the Georgian revolution, the Ukrainian revolution, and the Egyptian revolution. But an equally important application of this approach is in fighting poverty at home and around the world.

5:22 p.m. | Updated The Philadelphia Orchestra’s program Saturday night was to include music from the Berg opera “Lulu,” and the ensemble hopes to avoid the protagonist’s tawdry end. The board of the Philadelphia Orchestra’s program voted Saturday to file for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11. Unlike Lulu, who died at the hands of Jack the Ripper, the orchestra will live on, rehearsing and continuing to give concerts while a bankruptcy court judges considers the case.

Bill Walton, who won two championships at U.C.L.A. under Coach John Wooden, also won two N.B.A. championships, with Portland in 1977 and with Boston in 1986. He was elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1993.

The pink river dolphin is a storied symbol of the Amazon, but local fishermen are slaughtering the animal for catfish bait.

In 1941, Joe DiMaggio of the Yankees put together a 56-game hitting streak that was the talk of baseball. For all the attention he received, DiMaggio’s .357 batting average at the end of the season fell well short of the American League lead, as Ted Williams of the Boston Red Sox famously batted .406.

The United States Postal Service admitted this week that its Lady Liberty stamp actually doesn’t show the famous statue in New York Harbor, but a half-size copy standing in front of a Las Vegas casino. But the post office’s assurances that it “loves” the design anyway may have less to do with aesthetics and more to do with the potential cost of replacing the billions of stamps already printed — to say nothing of making instant collector’s items out of the uncounted number already used on mail.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Mel Taub’s Puns and Anagrams come out only once every few months, so the key here, as they say, is to just relax and enjoy the ride. They also tend to be much easier than cryptics, so they are a good place to start if you find yourself stymied by cryptic cluing.
WET Designs is the originator of some of the world's most famous fountains. Owner Mark Fuller explains his business vision and gives a tour of the meticulously designed WET Campus.

Alina Simone is a folk-pop singer who lives in Brooklyn. Alina Bronsky is a fast-rising European novelist who lives near Frankfurt, Germany. Both are young, both are of Soviet extraction, and both have books coming out this spring. As far as coincidences go, that’s not a stunning one, but it further underscores recent artistic contributions from Soviet diaspora children, a whip-smart group now in their 20s and 30s that includes Regina Spektor, Mila Kunis, Anton Yelchin, the comedian Eugene Mirman (a childhood friend of Simone’s), and the writers Gary Shteyngart, Keith Gessen and Sana Krasikov.

In this week’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan takes a look at the world of private residence clubs and fractional ownership real estate. The most well-known example is Exclusive Resorts, where a hefty sign-up fee plus other levies earn you the right to bed down in fancy vacation homes in exotic locales for several weeks each year.

Bharati Mukherjee’s novel “Miss New India” (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $25) presents the country’s seismic shifts from the perspective of Anjali, a provincial young woman climbing the class ladder. She falls in with a gay expat English teacher and, later, urban arrivistes who watch “Seinfeld” and tell her that Bangalore is just like Los Angeles, you know, “the poor man’s Bombay.” “Fire and Rain” (Da Capo Press, $25), David Browne’s cultural history of 1970, begins with three Beatles finishing “Let It Be” while John Lennon lams it in Denmark. (Paul Simon, meanwhile, amazes N.Y.U. students when he decides to teach a songwriting class.)

At the beginning of last week, the commentariat was in raptures over the Serious, Courageous, Game-Changing Ryan plan. But now that the plan has been exposed as the cruel nonsense it is, what we’re hearing a lot about is the need for more civility in the discourse. President Obama did a bad thing by calling cruel nonsense cruel nonsense; he hurt Republican feelings, and how can we have a deal when the GOP is feeling insulted? What we need is personal outreach; let’s do lunch!

We are only three races into the season but we are growing used to seeing the same man dominate everything, and today’s qualifying session for the Chinese Grand Prix was no different. Sebastian Vettel scored the pole position and his Red Bull dominated the session from the beginning – no contest. Jenson Button and Lewis Hamilton were second and third fastest, for McLaren Mercedes, and Nico Rosberg was fourth fastest in the Mercedes.

The system of playoff expectation in the N.B.A. has long been backward: rather than assuming regular season success translates seamlessly into postseason splendor, playoff teams are treated with skepticism unless they’ve “been there before.” 82 games apparently aren’t enough to create a representative sample of a team’s performance, and those who haven’t made extended postseason runs in the past are required to prove themselves once again before earning the respect of media pundits and basketball fans alike.

GOODMAN--Stanley 91, died at home peacefully in his sleep on April 14th. His loss will be felt profoundly by his family and the many people whose lives he touched. He was predeceased by his wife Muriel, and survived by his wife of 50 years, Anita, his children, Marti (Frank) Patricia (David) Stuart (Cindy) Laurence (Cathy) and his grandchildren, Bernadette, Ben, Molly, Spencer, Gabriel and Nathan. Graduate of the Wharton School, he had a long career in marketing. He was an early innovator in the field of Sales Promotion and was proud of his role as International President of SPEA. He began his career at Decca Records and in the early 1960s founded EGR Communications, a sales promotion agency. Known for his intellectual curiosity and energy he poured himself into a wide range of interests. His photographs and sculpture were works of art. He was past President of Kol Ami, served on President's Council of Westchester Community College, Board of Union for Reform Judaism, and Board of Westchester Philharmonic. He moved to The Osborn in Rye, NY five years ago and quickly became a respected leader of the community: was elected Vice President, founded their newspaper, created "Osborn U" and many other community events. Funeral services will be held Sunday, April 17th at 10am at Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Westchester Philharmonic, 123 Main Street, White Plains, NY 10601.

8:55 PM | Updated Alan G. Hevesi, a former state comptroller, was sentenced on Friday to one to four years in prison for his role in a corruption scheme involving New York State's nearly $141 billion pension fund. In pleading guilty to a single felony count of official misconduct last fall, Mr. Hevesi, a Democrat, admitted that he had approved a $250 million pension investment in exchange for nearly $1 million in benefits from a California businessman, Elliott Broidy. As comptroller, Mr. Hevesi was the sole trustee of the pension fund.

KALLIR, Joyce, age 86, on April 14, 2011. Daughter of Louis Rubin and Elsie (Levine) Rubin; she is survived by her husband John Kallir and her daughters, Barbara and Jane. A native New Yorker, Joyce was an honors graduate of Hunter College and a member of Phi Beta Kappa. She received a masters degree in mathematics from Columbia University, with a thesis on elliptic integrals. Her career began as an instructor at Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute. After a few years, she "graduated" from college to high school and taught mathematics at Seward Park High School, where she eventually became head of the Mathematics Department. After taking the required courses and examinations, she graduated once more and was appointed Assistant Principal, first at P.S. 192 and then at P.S. 115. Throughout her life Joyce took a keen interest in progressive politics, working in the 1948 campaign for Henry Wallace, later as an active member of the Teachers' Union and in opposition to the war in Viet Nam. Donations in her name may be sent to J Street, www.jstreet.org.

INTERNATIONAL Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about canceled plans for a meeting between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the pop idol Justin Bieber misstated the location of a school bus hit on April 7 in a missile attack by Palestinian militants based in neighboring Gaza. It was in Israel, not Gaza. NEW YORK An article on Thursday about a Yale student who was killed in a lathe accident in a campus laboratory misstated the location of Lehman College, the employer of a professor who was quoted about the danger of lathes. It is in the Bronx, not Queens. BUSINESS The State of the Art column on Thursday, about the PlayBook tablet computer by Research in Motion, erroneously attributed a unique ability to the PlayBook. It is not the only tablet that can project PowerPoint-like slides onto a monitor or television screen while showing notes and slide thumbnails on the tablet screen; the iPad and some other tablets can also do so. CULTURE An entry on Friday in a listing of Easter-related musical presentations in New York in some editions misstated the surname of a soprano scheduled to perform in a program last night at New York University's Deutsches Haus and tonight at St. Michael's Church on West 99th Street at Amsterdam Avenue. She is Kathleen Cantrell, not Campbell.

Dennis M. Walcott, the incoming city schools chancellor, was so excited on Thursday night that he had trouble sleeping. He woke up at 3:30 a.m., then again at 5:20, and went out for a two-mile run. By 7:30, he was at Public School 10 in Park Slope, Brooklyn, waffle batter and electric waffle press in hand. Lily Potter, 8, couldn't sleep either. She went to bed at 9 p.m. but kept thinking about the challenge she had issued Mr. Walcott four months ago, when he visited the school and told the children that he loved to cook, particularly waffles. ''Prove it,'' she had told him -- and he agreed.

What had been scheduled as a limited engagement of ''War Horse'' has been extended indefinitely at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center Theater announced on Thursday. ''War Horse,'' which originated at the the National Theater in London, opened in New York on Thursday to positive reviews and has been selling strongly, leading Lincoln Center to extend the show beyond the previously announced June 26 closing date.

PROPPER--Elaine, 87, formerly of Cresskill, NJ. Beloved wife of the late George, devoted mother of Felipa and Larry Bernard, Tracey and Peter Kelley, loving grandmother of David, Geordan, Aaron and Perrin; dear sister of Trudi and Stanley Shippenberg and aunt of Toni Shippenberg. Service Sunday, April 17th, 10am at Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. Memorial contributions may be directed to the Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County, 687 Larch Avenue, Teaneck, NJ 07666.

ARCHER--Yvonne Silverman, age 81, passed away peacefully on April 15, 2011. Beloved wife of 53 years of Joel Strom Archer. Loving mother of Diane Strom Archer and Ellen Lee Archer and mother-in-law of Stephen Presser and Jeffrey Gracer. Loving grandmother of Elizabeth Archer Presser, Michael Archer Presser, Ethan Archer Gracer and Mathew Archer Gracer. Beloved sister of Sidney Benedict Silverman and sister-in-law of Irene Levy Silverman. Founder and Executive Director of the League of Physicians and Surgeons. An amazingly passionate and energetic individual, quick-fire and intense, opinionated and committed to challenging injustice, she is, and will be, sorely missed. As she loved to remind us, "Life is a jest, And all things show it; I thought so once, But now I know it."

SYRIA Protesters thronged Damascus, the capital, in the largest turnout yet in a widening challenge to the government, defying a nationwide crackdown in which hundreds of demonstrators have been killed by security forces. Marches across the country were met with tear gas, beatings and reports of gunfire. Tens of thousands of protesters marched into Damascus from its restive suburbs, in the first large demonstration in the capital. LIBYA Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi have been firing into residential neighborhoods of the embattled city of Misurata with heavy weapons that include cluster bombs, which have been banned by much of the world, according to witnesses as well as physical evidence. The military has also been using ground-to-ground rockets. Colonel Qaddafi's forces fired cluster bombs in Misurata on Friday, amid a fierce barrage of tank, artillery and rocket fire.

Saturday is a big day for New York City: It is getting a new area code [pdf], a catchy little number called 929. The folks at the North American Numbering Plan Administration, in their oracular wisdom and unchallengeable authority, have decreed that five (212, 718, 917, 646, 347) are just not enough. From now on, 929 will be assigned to some people in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens and on Staten Island (notice that Manhattan is not in that list) who request a new service or line.

ARAUJO--Hilary. It is with profound sadness that we announce the untimely passing of Hilary Araujo on April 14, 2011 at the age of 65 after a short illness. Mr. Araujo had been Vice President of Marketing for The Tiffen Company since June of 2004 and was responsible for the company's overall advertising, marketing, and public relations programs during that time. A lifelong member of the imaging industry who was respected and loved by all who had the good fortune to know him, Hilary Araujo began his career at Conrad Photo in the early 1970s, eventually moving on to the marketing division of Berkey Marketing Co. and then taking a position as a marketing executive at GMI. Prior to accepting his pivotal position at Tiffen, Mr. Araujo had been a top marketing executive at Tocad for several years. Hilary Araujo will always be remembered for his keen intelligence, great sense of humor, disarming honesty and easy smile, but most of all for his big heart and unstinting willingness to help other people. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Sandy, and daughter Susan. Funeral services will be held at 11am, Sunday, April 17th 2011 at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY 11797. Besides being a dear friend and a great colleague, Hilary was devoted to our company and will be sorely missed, said Steven Tiffen, president of The Tiffen Company. He made so many contributions to our company, our industry and was a dear friend to all, this is a great loss.

The Village Voice announced that it would present a new annual music festival after 10 years of producing the Siren Music Festival at Coney Island. Now The Voice is to produce the 4Knots Music Festival, on July 16 at the South Street Seaport. The festival will be free, open to all ages, and held rain or shine. (Its name comes from the speed at which the East River flows, The Voice said.) ''We're extremely excited about the launch of the 4Knots Music Festival this summer,'' the Village Voice publisher, Josh Fromson, said in a statement. ''We feel this new festival will not just live up to the glory of our past events but sets the stage for continued success in the future.'' The festival will feature well-known and emerging artists performing live all day. A lineup of the day's events will be announced in coming weeks.

LEWIS--Carol, wife of the late Sandy Lewis, mother of Mark, John and Lynn, grandmother of Jacob, Jordan, Max and Katelyn, passed away on April 14, 2011 at age 86. A woman of varied talents, she was both an eminent psychologist and a writer of children's musicals. A graduate of Wellesley College, with a doctorate in clinical psychology from Rutgers University, she had an intellect as sharp as her sense of humor. She specialized in child psychology, and was the author of the book Listening to Children. Nobody had a bigger heart, as was recognized by the large number of friends she made in her life. A memorial service will be held Sunday, April 17 at 2pm, at the Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel in Livingston, NJ, (973) 422-0600, www. bernheimapterkreitzman.com.

One casualty of the latest federal budget deal: Funds for counseling older Americans seeking reverse mortgages, or loans that let those 62 and over tap their home equity. The latest proposal for the current fiscal year, which is scheduled for final votes in Congress imminently, cuts $88 million from the Department of Housing and Urban Development's budget for loan counseling programs, including for reverse mortgages, a HUD spokesman confirmed Thursday. Some $9 million of that total is reserved for reverse mortgage counseling, which helps borrowers understand the benefits, costs and risks, of such loans, says Barbara Stucki, vice president for home equity initiatives at The National Council on Aging.

STERN--Rabbi Jack. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of our inspirational and beloved Rabbi Emeritus. From 1962 to 1991, Rabbi Stern planted seeds of conscience, wisdom and love within each and every member. An extraordinary teacher and pastor, a passionate upstander for civil rights, he embedded his legacy deep within our congregation and in all who were touched by his exemplary life and work. A rabbi's rabbi, he mentored hundreds of colleagues throughout the CCAR, and his rabbinate reached well beyond our people. Our hearts go out to his children Jonathan (Jamie), David (Nancy) and Elsie (Steven), his grandchildren and the entire Stern family. May his words from a 1983 sermon bring comfort to his many mourners: "Such is the meaning of faith--to know that the melody is playing even when we may not hear it--to know that our beloved are safe even if they are beyond our sight." Details about the funeral and mourning can be found at www.wrtemple.org. Lisa Messinger, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jonathan E. Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor Dan Sklar, Asst. Rabbi/Cantor Mia Davidson, Asst. Cantor

Twelve years after ''Mad About You,'' Paul Reiser made a low-rated return to NBC's comedy line-up on Thursday. Just 3.3 million viewers tuned in to the premiere of ''The Paul Reiser Show'' at 8:30 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. The new series faces considerable odds, coming after NBC's similarly ratings-starved sitcom ''Community'' (3.5 million), at 8 p.m., and occupying a time slot otherwise dominated by ''American Idol'' on Fox. For the night, NBC ranked a distant third, garnering its best ratings at 9 p.m. for ''The Office'' (7.7 million), which featured a guest appearance from Will Ferrell. Fox led the night with 21 million viewers tuning for an elimination episode of ''Idol'' and 11.9 million at 9 p.m. for ''Bones.'' CBS placed second, despite broadcasting a line-up of all repeats. ABC was fourth, finishing close behind NBC with reruns from 9 to 11 p.m. following a new episode of ''Wipeout'' at 8 (6.2 million). This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

After Los Angeles Lakers guard Kobe Bryant directed an antigay slur at a referee Tuesday night from the bench in a game against the Phoenix Suns, the N.B.A. fined him $100,000. Bryant has apologized, saying his words should not have been taken literally. He said he would appeal the fine. Kobe Bryant isn't some great, bigoted monster, as some have implied, but he isn't the innocent victim of some overblown one-off incident about a word that's ''not even that bad,'' either.

(Starz) TOY STORY 3 (2010) As Andy (John Morris) heads to college, Woody (Tom Hanks), Buzz Lightyear (Tim Allen), the Potato Heads (Don Rickles and Estelle Harris), Hamm (John Ratzenberger), Jessie (Joan Cusack) and Rex (Wallace Shawn) find themselves at the Sunnyside Daycare Center -- a place, its seemingly jovial patriarch, Lots-o'-Huggin' Bear (Ned Beatty), above center, explains, where toys are played with every day. Or are they? The movie, which won the Oscar for best animated feature and was nominated for best picture, ''makes remarkably subtle use of 3-D'' and ''explores a range of cinematic techniques undreamed of in the first two chapters, and refined in recent Pixar films like 'Wall-E' and 'Up,' '' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''When the truth about Sunnyside is revealed, the movie has fun evoking prison escape pictures and horror films, darkening the Pixar palette to captivating (and, to some small children, possibly frightening) effect.'' Ultimately, this three-film, 15-year epic ''about the adventures of a bunch of silly plastic junk turns out also to be a long, melancholy meditation on loss, impermanence and that noble, stubborn, foolish thing called love,'' Mr. Scott added. ''We all know money can't buy it, except sometimes, for the price of a plastic figurine or a movie ticket.'' BLUM--Abbey Friedfeld, passed away on April 11, 2011. She was the beloved wife of Howard (Ward) L. Blum, Jr., mother of Howard III (Tripp) and Ross, daughter of Esther Friedfeld and the late Harry Friedfeld, of Brooklyn, NY, and sister of Howard (Elon). She was a devoted aunt, cousin, family member, and friend to all who knew her. Strong-willed, fashionable, and full of spirit, she enjoyed life and all it had to offer, planning trips around the world and friendly gatherings at home. A daughter of Brooklyn itself, she was graduated from Sheepshead Bay High School and Brooklyn College. Always described as sweet, positive, and radiant by friends and family alike, she will be missed by all those whose lives she touched. She was a long-time supporter of Jewish and educational charities and set a wonderful example by giving to those in need and always thinking of others first. Services will be held Friday, 10am at Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th Street, New York City. The family will be receiving friends Thursday evening from 6pm-9pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, Saturday evening at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, from 6pm-9pm, and Sunday evening at the Harmonie Club from 4pm-8pm. For more information, contact Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 212-288-3500.

STERN--Rabbi Jack, born July 27, 1926, in Cincinnati, Ohio, died April 14, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Priscilla R. Stern; brother of the late Melvin Stern; father of Jonathan (Jamie), David (Nancy) and Elsie (Steven); grandfather of Jacob, Nina, Lili, Benjamin, Rebecca, Sarah and Jedediah. He served Temple Beth El of Great Neck, NY; Temple Emanuel of Westfield, NJ; and from 1962-1991, served as senior rabbi of Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, NY. Did you ever hear of Maurice, how he went to work many years ago in a family's rent-controlled apartment on Central Park West in Manhattan, and made a big, lovely mural that very few people have ever had the chance to see until now? (Apologies to Mr. Sendak and ''In the Night Kitchen.'') Mr. Sendak, the children's author and opera designer, hasn't made a career of monumental wall works, but in 1961 he spent months painting a children's-bedroom mural for his friends Lionel and Roslyn Chertoff, a parade-like tableau with a lion and a top-hatted bear and a dog that looks exactly like the white terrier he would later subject to pursuit by a little boy with a fork in ''Where the Wild Things Are.'' (It was the image of Mr. Sendak's own dog, Jennie.)

Did you apply for a loan but receive a higher interest rate than you think you deserve? You're now entitled to receive a few clues about how the lender arrived at its decision. A federal law that went into effect at the beginning of the year requires lenders to make certain disclosures to consumers when they receive less favorable credit terms than those given to borrowers with more pristine credit histories. That may come in the form of a higher interest rate, or a smaller line of credit.

You might be able to take the art out of the streets, but it's tough to take the street out of the art. As was widely expected, the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art's huge ''Art in the Streets'' exhibition -- one of the largest museum surveys of graffiti and its urban offspring ever mounted -- has resulted in a fair bit of uncommissioned, extracurricular artwork appearing on buildings around the museum's Geffen Contemporary wing in Little Tokyo, where the show opens Sunday. The Culture Monster blog of The Los Angeles Times reported that dozens of tags and larger pieces of graffiti have been appearing in the last two days on walls, Dumpsters, light poles and other stretches of municipal canvas, joining some commissioned murals that are part of the show. Jack Richter, a Los Angeles Police Department spokesman, was quoted as having said, ''We respect the rights to have an art exhibition, but we demand the security of other people's property.''

GOODMAN--Stanley L. The musicians, board, and staff of the Westchester Philharmonic mourn the passing of our esteemed board member. He bestowed many blessings upon our organization, among them passion, optimism, and strength. He inspires us still, and will be missed.

Time has a way of turning matronly frumps into style icons. The richly illustrated ''Seeing Gertrude Stein'' (University of California Press, $45), paired with a show coming to the Contemporary Jewish Museum in San Francisco, amounts to a visual history of the writer and art patron. It collects many of the sculptures and paintings she sat for, including that Picasso, along with her bohemian fashion statements: the vests, the brooches, even a custom Balmain frock. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SCHMITT--Margaret Johanna, (known as "Peggy"), was born and raised in Detroit, MI; raised her family in New Rochelle, NY; and passed peacefully in Vero Beach, FL surrounded by life-long friends on April, 14, 2011. She was the loving mother of Peter (Michelle), Stephen (Danielle), and Mary Anne (Donald) Carey, and devoted grandmother of Sara, Brian, Jordan, Zachary, Peter, Hannah, Melissa, Stacey, Maureen, Hugh, and Donnie. Peggy also treasured her sister, Mary Anne Davis, brother, Peter Ulbrich, and dear friends, George Rickert and Ginny Fitzgerald. Calling hours will be held at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY on Wednesday, April 20 between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm. The funeral service will be held at Christ Church, Bronxville on Thursday, April 21 at 3:00pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to the organization that Peggy brought a smile to every week, the Burke Rehabilitation Hospital, 785 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY 10605. Through her consistent actions every day, Peggy taught us all the true meaning of love.

WITTENSTEIN--Jeffrey. Architect and Photographer, April 15, 2011. Dearly loved husband of Pat, devoted father of Keith, Erin, and granddaughter Jennifer, brother Arnold and the late Bruce. Memorial service to be announced.

BLUM--Abbey Friedfeld, passed away on April 11, 2011. She was the beloved wife of Howard (Ward) L. Blum, Jr., mother of Howard III (Tripp) and Ross, daughter of Esther Friedfeld and the late Harry Friedfeld, of Brooklyn, NY, and sister of Howard (Elon). She was a devoted aunt, cousin, family member, and friend to all who knew her. Strong-willed, fashionable, and full of spirit, she enjoyed life and all it had to offer, planning trips around the world and friendly gatherings at home. A daughter of Brooklyn itself, she was graduated from Sheepshead Bay High School and Brooklyn College. Always described as sweet, positive, and radiant by friends and family alike, she will be missed by all those whose lives she touched. She was a long-time supporter of Jewish and educational charities and set a wonderful example by giving to those in need and always thinking of others first. Services will be held Friday, 10am at Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th Street, New York City. The family will be receiving friends Thursday evening from 6pm-9pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, Saturday evening at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, from 6pm-9pm, and Sunday evening at the Harmonie Club from 4pm-8pm. For more information, contact Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 212-288-3500.

A picture with the Q&A column on April 3, about interesting sights in Normandy, was published in error. It is of a copper engraving depicting the 1066 invasion of England by William the Conqueror, Duke of Normandy. It is not of the Bayeux tapestry, at the Musée de la Tapisserie de Bayeux. (The famous tapestry depicts the same invasion.)

Sometimes it's wonderfully easy, sometimes not so very. Deciding to throw that dirty makeup towel on the floor of the hotel bathroom, despite the card detailing the environmental consequences of your wanton gesture in three languages? An ethical conundrum that can sully a whole day (or at least a morning). But slathering your visage with the wholesome-est creams, bedecking yourself in the finest ancient gems and even brooking controversy by maybe daring to don a few vintage pelts, all in service of saving, celebrating - even worshiping - the earth? Simple. It's already the second decade of the new century, and we are dealing with style questions, ethical and otherwise, that would have bedeviled our chic ancestors. We may pay lip service to sustainability and strive for a toddler-size carbon footprint, but who among us is considering the environment when our cupboards are stuffed with nonbiodegradable synthetic Marc Jacobs fetish frocks, shiny plastic Balenciaga houndstooth-check spring coats and truckloads of industrial-strength Spanx made of who knows what mysterious chemical compound? Not to mention the sheer quantities of merchandise that languish in our armoires, living as we do in a time when 30 pairs of shoes don't raise an eyebrow, instead of the measly two (or maybe three or four, if they were really prosperous) that our forebears made do with.

First, some fashion news. Having just spent a month watching the runways, I am certain of one thing: if you are a female reader of this magazine, you will need, by fall, to be in possession of a dress, a frock, with proper sleeves and a hemline that hovers at the knees. It can be bohemian or ''Seven Sisters''; it can be cut from wool or silk or some indefinable double-faced, techno synthetic. But whatever the particulars, you will wear it everywhere and feel ageless and glamorous along the way. In this issue, Angelo Pennetta and Robbie Spencer offer four terrific options from the prefall collections on Page 78; why not be an early adapter? Spencer is also the fashion editor behind Richard Burbridge's extraordinary fantasia of ''green'' beauty and fine jewelry, ''A Diamond in the Roughage'' (Page 66). We started discussing this story last October, and the concept was straightforward: to look gorgeous you don't need science, you need Mother Nature. Lynn Yaeger penned a timely and hilarious piece; and Spencer, Burbridge, Chanel's Peter Philips, Martin Cullen and the set guru Gary Card went to work to turn the model Tati into a thoroughly modern vision worthy of Arcimboldo. (Speaking of Arcimboldo, if in Milan this spring, please take a spin by the Piazza del Duomo to see the artist
'We all agreed that he was using steroids. But the question was did he know he was, and on that, we had no proof.' AMBER REED,

BUTLER--Jay, of New York, NY, died on April 2, 2011. Beloved husband of Carole. Devoted Uncle of Barry Butler of Maryland, Lisa Butler of Colorado, Alexander (Sandy) Myers of West Palm Beach, Florida, Deborah O'Connor of Park City, Utah, and Susan Pollack of Delray Beach, Florida. He was predeceased by his parents, Bernard and Peppie Butler, brother Colonel Herbert Butler, his twin brother Maxwell (Mac) Butler, and his sister Helen Myers. Also survived by great-nieces and nephews. Jay and his brothers were Veterans of World War II. He was born and raised in Brooklyn and was a graduate of James Madison High School, Long Island University, and New York University. He taught in the New York Public School System. His summers were spent working at resorts in the Catskills and Tamiment in the Poconos. Jay and his identical twin brother Mac were heavily involved in sports throughout their lives. It was reported that their resemblance was so strong that their teachers could not tell them apart. Jay was the "righty", and Mac was the "lefty". Jay loved playing ball with all the vets in the park on Bedford Avenue and Avenue X in Brooklyn. All the "Butler" boys are missed.

ALGERIA Security officials said Islamist extremists attacked an army post and killed at least 13 soldiers watching President Abdelaziz Bouteflika's televised speech promising reforms, The Associated Press reported. Officials said two of the militants were killed. EGYPT With its leaders jailed, the once-supreme National Democratic Party has already been relegated to history. However, the Supreme Administrative Court made it official on Saturday, ruling that the party would be dissolved and its assets seized by the government.

AUNG-THWIN--Margaret Hope. A resident of Montreal, died age 91 on April 8, 2011 at her daughter's home in NY of congestive heart failure and cancer. Born December 20, 1919 in Burma, the first of 14 to John Hodgson and Naw Thet Po, Margaret is survived by sisters Edna and Fanny in Burma, brothers Howard and Ralph in Australia, children John (Evelyn) in Canada, Michael (Maria) in Hawaii, Maureen in NYC, 5 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. A graduate of Judson College, Rangoon and later SUNY Cortland, Margaret, a Fulbright Scholar, taught at the Int'l School in Rangoon, Kodaikanal School in S. India, Burmese at Cornell U, and adult education with the Miccosukee in Florida. On her retirement she translated Ma Ma Lay's "Not Out of Hate", the first Burmese novel in English translation published outside Burma. Her passions included Jane Austen, NYC, crosswords, aquafit, Dr Tenenbaum and salt. She will be interred privately at Trinity Cemetery in upper Manhattan. Donations to purchase books on Burma in her memory may be made to the Southeast Asia Program, 180 Uris Hall, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853.
The Trend Le smoking summer. Nothing accentuates wily femininity like a modern tuxedo, dramatically deconstructed at the prefall collections of Burberry Prorsum and Viktor & Rolf.

BLAIR--David C.,beloved husband and father, died after long illness. Born in Salem, OR in 1947. BA Whitman College, WA, Ph.D. UC Berkeley 1979. Professor of Computer Information Systems, University of Michigan, an empirical researcher who also spent many years developing information retrieval theory in light of philosophy of language. Contributions: "Professor David C. Blair Memorial Fund" Gift Administration 2000 Center St. Berkeley, CA 94720. Service: First Presbyterian Church of Ann Arbor (734-662-4466) at 2pm on May 21. Barbara, Chris, and Alain

GOODMAN--Stanley 91, died at home peacefully in his sleep on April 14th. His loss will be felt profoundly by his family and the many people whose lives he touched. He was predeceased by his wife Muriel, and survived by his wife of 50 years, Anita, his children, Marti (Frank) Patricia (David) Stuart (Cindy) Laurence (Cathy) and his grandchildren, Bernadette, Ben, Molly, Spencer, Gabriel and Nathan. Graduate of the Wharton School, he had a long career in marketing. He was an early innovator in the field of Sales Promotion and was proud of his role as International President of SPEA. He began his career at Decca Records and in the early 1960s founded EGR Communications, a sales promotion agency. Known for his intellectual curiosity and energy he poured himself into a wide range of interests. His photographs and sculpture were works of art. He was past President of Kol Ami, served on President's Council of Westchester Community College, Board of Union for Reform Judaism, and Board of Westchester Philharmonic. He moved to The Osborn in Rye, NY five years ago and quickly became a respected leader of the community: was elected Vice President, founded their newspaper, created "Osborn U" and many other community events. Funeral services will be held Sunday, April 17th at 10am at Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Westchester Philharmonic, 123 Main Street, White Plains, NY 10601.

Bharati Mukherjee's novel ''Miss New India'' (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $25) presents the country's seismic shifts from the perspective of Anjali, a provincial young woman climbing the class ladder. She falls in with a gay expat English teacher and, later, urban arrivistes who watch ''Seinfeld'' and tell her that Bangalore is just like Los Angeles, you know, ''the poor man's Bombay.'' ''Fire and Rain'' (Da Capo Press, $25), David Browne's cultural history of 1970, begins with three Beatles finishing ''Let It Be'' while John Lennon lams it in Denmark. (Paul Simon, meanwhile, amazes N.Y.U. students when he decides to teach a songwriting class.) Jean Thompson's ''The Year We Left Home'' (Simon & Schuster, $25) actually spans 30 years in the lives of the fictional Erickson siblings: Anita, who's content to stay in small-town Iowa, and Ryan, who's suffocating. The longtime lovers Georgia O'Keeffe and Alfred Stieglitz exchanged 5,000 letters -- he was ''Dearest Duck,'' she ''My Grand Canyon Madness'' -- the best of which are in ''My Faraway One'' (Yale University Press, $40.) ''A World on Fire'' (Random House, $35) is a doorstop of a narrative history by Amanda Foreman (''The Duchess''), who weaves together the stories of 50,000 Britons who fought on both sides in the American Civil War. And Rebecca Wolff sets her ghost story-cum-bildungsroman, ''The Beginners'' (Riverhead Books, $26), in a New England town still in the shadow of Salem.

Bill Walton, who won two championships at U.C.L.A. under Coach John Wooden, also won two N.B.A. championships, with Portland in 1977 and with Boston in 1986. He was elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1993. A congenital abnormality in his feet hampered his career, and two years ago, he left broadcasting because of back problems. After surgery, Walton, 58, has returned as a spokesman for Guinness and as a broadcaster for the Celtics and the Sacramento Kings.

We aren't trying to be anything other than a diner,'' says Sarah Obraitis, who runs the restaurant M. Wells on an industrial stretch in Queens with her husband, Hugue Dufour. But despite the dining car's site, just steps from the Midtown Tunnel, this is no truck-stop operation. Dufour, a French-trained chef and former co-owner of Montreal's Au Pied de Cochon, churns out ambitious dishes like foie gras tamales, lamb and beef burgers and bone marrow topped with escargot. ''You can't deny the richness of our food,'' Obraitis admits. ''But we do have doughnuts. They're straight up with just cinammon and sugar.'' MAURA EGAN Chrome heart:

WHILE bottled water is still hard to find and the huge video screens in Shibuya remain dark, some inhabitants of Tokyo are beginning to return to their usual joyous style. One Harajuku fashion plate, pointing to his outrageous shirt and huge pendant, wondered out loud if it's O.K. to be having fun. In the days after the March 11 earthquake and tsunami, the city's most creative dressers ditched the pastel colors and heels, and Japan Fashion Week canceled its events. Now a sense of normality is creeping back, as more fashion companies reschedule their shows and Tokyo's youth put their all-black ensembles in the closet. Said Kenta Koizumi as he brushed a streak of Smurf-blue hair out of his eyes, ''Tokyo should be strong for the people in Sendai.'' REBECCA WILLA DAVIS

Cate Blanchett and I are trying to determine whether she's a fake - or whether she's merely as hidden from herself as she seems to be hidden from strangers who would like to capture her essence over breakfast at the Chateau Marmont, tape recorder and pen at the ready. It's the Sunday morning of the Oscars when Blanchett and I meet, and there's a slight fizz of anticipation in the Los Angeles air, a kind of hometown pride that one senses. There have been soirees and private parties going on since Friday night, but in the restaurant at the Marmont everything is calm, cool and collected. The Marmont, I decide, is too hip to be excited, which is probably why Blanchett has elected to stay here with her friend, the makeup artist Jeanine Lobell (creator of Stila), instead of at the Beverly Hills Hotel, where she was initially booked. When she walks in at 10:10, all in black, except for her bright blond crown of boyishly cut hair, no one so much as looks up from their conversation. Then again, despite her singular beauty, she's simply not the kind of actress who begs to be stared at, who enters places with that ''I am somebody'' awareness of herself that demands attention. She's a dignified, pre-red-carpet star caught in a celebrity-tweeting culture, with the result that she's learned how to promote her role of the moment - in this instance, that of a ruthless C.I.A. agent in the thriller ''Hanna,'' directed by Joe Wright - without seeming to be promoting anything, least of all herself. I dutifully bring up the subject of the film and mention that I found it beautiful looking but disappointing. Blanchett says she took ''Hanna'' on ''because it was the best first 20 pages of any script I'd read - brutal, terrifying and suspenseful.'' And then she's happy to move on to other matters. It's an art all its own, this straining toward the shadows of self-effacement when you've been shoved into the limelight, there's no doubt about that. Blanchett is whippet thin and wearing black jeans with a black Gaultier jacket (this much she will divulge) with what she describes as a ''wispy, lacy quelque chose'' underneath. Her face is bare of makeup except for perhaps a smidgen of mascara, and she wears no jewelry save for a striking onyx and gold ring. Her nails are unmanicured, which on her looks like the last word in efficient chic, and I suddenly find myself wondering why I bother with a weekly polish. Mostly, though, I find myself staring at her skin, which has been justifiably much-commented on by interviewers and is, perhaps, the most divalike thing about her: luminous and poreless and the color of a pale peach. Second only to her skin is her bone structure, which is a gift from the gods, and then come her eyes, which are a piercing blue-gray with tiny pupils. Not to mention her generous, mobile mouth. Together these visual assets can be played up or played down, depending on the maquillage - depending, indeed, on whether she wears so much as a dab of lipstick - which is why Blanchett can look alternately wanly attractive, as she does in the 2005 Australian indie film ''Little Fish,'' playing a troubled woman trying to rise above her past, or undeniably stunning, as she does later that night when presenting an Oscar for best costume and makeup, dressed in a haute couture Givenchy gown (one of two gowns that she chose between) that made everyone else look tacky.

The off-again-on-again Manhattan club night Ghe20 Goth1k is a creative oasis within New York's flagging night-life scene. Organized by Venus X Iceberg (nee Jazmin Venus Soto), it serves as home base to many recently emerged hybrid rave/hip-hop genres. Soto is also producing a documentary called ''Shakedown.'' Reminiscent of the '90s cult film ''Paris Is Burning,'' it traces the intricacies of black lesbian subculture in Los Angeles. Notably, Soto keeps her love of underground and subculture balanced. As a D.J., she has gained notoriety by mixing news clips from Al Jazeera in with her beats - during a New York Fashion Week gig, she interspersed coverage from the Egyptian revolution. As she puts it, ''Even club kids should know what's going on.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Service at 9:30am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St., and Amsterdam Ave. Her lively spirit and good humor will be sorely missed.
Dance Claudia La Rocco

Giulietta, which had its debut in a whitewashed loft during New York Fashion Week, is helmed by Sofia Sizzi (above, center), a Florentine-born Manhattanite who is driven by a love for lavish Italian fabrics. ''Is that really double-knit?'' one observer whispered of a black wool suit consisting of skinny flared trousers, a hip-length narrow-lapeled jacket and a long fitted vest that could serve as a minidress to nouveau Twiggys. The 24-look collection includes a black wool sateen dress accented with a Peter Pan collar, a handmade lace widow skirt and a saffron printed pantsuit based on Sizzi's sketch of a Baroque cathedral ceiling. The shoes - velvet, satin and felt wedges and heels (all vegan, to match the 33-year-old's lifestyle) in salmon, saffron and cardinal red - attest to what Sizzi learned while working as an accessories designer at Gucci, Calvin Klein and Donna Karan. Clever '60s proportions and mod collaborations with the milliner Patricia Underwood and the jeweler Thomas Bliven add a bit of nonecclesiastical zing. From $435 at Barneys New York. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
One Word: Plastic

PUTALA--Eugene, 88, a Hamilton College Emeritus Professor of Botany, passed away peacefully on April 1, 2011. His family cherishes his loving memory and remembers his gentle soul.

Rome, March 7, 2011 I'd never been to Rome, so when a friend suggested that we meet there, I jumped at the idea. I was overwhelmed by the sight of the Colosseum, despite having seen pictures and reading about competitions between gladiators there over the years. I listened to the audio guide and spent hours conjuring up images of the past. The experience far exceeded my expectations. Claudia Schellenberg, New York

Among the early surprises in the first days of the Stanley Cup playoffs was the play of three veterans whose best days were supposedly behind them: Montreal's Scott Gomez, Nashville's Steve Sullivan and Detroit's Todd Bertuzzi. Gomez, who was under fire all season for ineffective play, was perhaps the best player on the ice in the Canadiens' Game 1 defeat of the Bruins. He set up Brian Gionta for the game's only two goals and made dangerous rushes and good defensive reads all night.

Tati Cotliar As a child, the Argentine model Tati Cotliar loved to play make-believe: ''I always imagined things that couldn't happen to me in the real world.'' So posing in ''A Diamond in the Roughage'' (Page 66) as an exotic overgrown garden, with rose petals and yellow dandelions on her face, was no great feat for the 22-year-old porteña and cinema nut. Cotliar just walked the fall 2011 runways for Louis Vuitton, Prada and Marc Jacobs.

BARKER--Dr. Harold Grant, died in his home in Rye, NY on March 9, 2011. Since 1953 Dr. Barker had been a faculty member at Columbia and Attending Surgeon at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. He was also Medical Director of Presbyterian Hospital from 1974 to 1982. Dr. Barker was born June 10, 1917 in Salt Lake City. He obtained his M.D. degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1943. He served with the U.S. Army Medical Corps from 1944-46 being discharged as Captain. From 1947-53 he was a Surgical Resident at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. The remainder of his career was at Columbia where he advanced to full professorship in 1968. His research was supported by grants from the NIH for 22 consecutive years. Dr. Barker was a Diplomat of the American Board of Surgery and a member of the Society of University Surgeons, The American Surgical Association and the Halsted Society. He was a member of the Century Association, the Charaka Club, the Manursing Island Club and the American Yacht Club. Dr. Barker's wife the former Kathleen Butler had been vice president of the Garden Club of America and President of the Rye Garden Club. She died on December 2, 2010. Dr. Barker is survived by his daughter, Janet Barker Pinckney, his son Douglas Barker, his grandchildren Meredith Pinckney Kent, Carolyn Pinckney Fox, Thomas Pinckney and by his brother, Clyde Barker.

Nothing says summer like this vivid and versatile hue. Luckily, there's a shade for everyone. Evocative of beachy sunsets, warm-weather cocktails and juicy, just-picked strawberries, the color pink is a virtual harbinger of summer delights. As things heat up this season, a rich, rosy pout is practically mandatory. ''We saw a lot of pink, from deep to bright, on the runways, and it's definitely the statement to make on lips right now,'' says Francois Nars, the founder and creative director of Nars Cosmetics. He equates choosing the right shade with picking any accessory: ''Go with what you're attracted to. Blue-based pinks will brighten any complexion, but it's ultimately more important to select a shade that suits your style, one you feel comfortable with.''A bit of daring can pay off. ''With a shocking or bright hue, teeth appear brighter, as do the whites of eyes,'' Nars says.

Baby-blonde hair may be all the rage, but it's not for everyone. According to Marie Robinson, who counts Emma Stone, Naomi Watts and Michelle Williams among her pale-tressed clients, ''It works best on women who are at least halfway there to begin with, and they need touch-ups every four weeks.'' That said, its brightening effect on the skin is well worth the effort. ''It's rejuvenating,'' says Chelsey Pickthorn, the Orlo Salon colorist who coaxed the model Abbey Lee Kershaw's locks to the perfect platinum. ''But you really need to assess the hair's condition before starting and then proceed slowly, with great care.'' LIKE A VIRGINThese colorists specialize in natural-looking hues.

An article on April 3 about services that manage information about their clients on the Internet misstated the relationship of Julia Allison, the subject of repeated entries on the Web site Gawker, to Time Out New York. She was a dating columnist, not a sex columnist. The article also misstated the Web location of photos of her in lingerie. They were on Gawker, not on her blog. The article also misstated her description of herself. She does not call herself a social media expert.

Walter is survived by his beloved wife, Cathy, his two sons, Chris of Santa Fe, New Mexico and Wally of Helena, Montana, his two daughter-in-laws, Yuki Murata and Valerie Schurter Long, and his five grandchildren. MAYER--Michael F. My husband, partner, and the love of my life has left us. He will be profoundly missed. His integrity will be remembered by all who knew him. He had a distinguished career as a lawyer and civic leader. After graduating from Harvard University and Yale Law School, he proudly served his country in the Army Air Corp during World War II, where he advanced to the rank of Captain and earned an Air Medal for his distinguished service. He practiced law for 57 years, first at Greenbaum, Wolff & Ernst; then Spring & Mayer where he was partner; then Mayer & Bucher where he was also partner; and finally in his own practice, from which he retired in 2003 at the age of 86. He served as Court Examiner in the Supreme Court, Westchester County for more than a decade. From 1958-1968, he was the Executive Director of the International Film Importers and Distributors Association. Mickey also served as a volunteer arbitrator in Civil Court in Bronx and New York Counties. He wrote several books on the law including Divorce and Annulment in the Fifty States, Rights of Privacy, The Film Industries - Legal/Business Problems and the Libel Revolution. Mickey believed that our government could and should play a positive role in our society and was inspired by a desire to serve in public office. In 1973, he was the Democratic candidate for Supreme Court in the 9th Judicial District. He also ran as the Democratic candidate for New York State Senate from Yonkers and for Westchester County District Attorney. Mickey was actively involved in community and civic affairs. He served as the Secretary of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, President of the Beech Hill Neighborhood Association in Yonkers, and as a Board Member of the American Jewish Society for Service. A memorial service will be held on Sunday April 17th at 11am at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home at 2 Maple Avenue in White Plains, NY. In addition, the family will be receiving visitors on Monday, April 18th from 3-6pm at 9 Inverness Road in Scarsdale, NY. Mickey's passion for politics and government continued to light up his life until his death. Mickey and I had 67 wonderful years of marriage together. He was a remarkable man who devoted his life to me and I loved him dearly. He will be missed by all. Mickey is survived by his wife Janet, children Doe (and Jed), Art (and Lauren), Aline (and Gary) and Shelley (and Lee) and his grandchildren Aaron, Julia, Arthur, Daniel, Evan, and Cyrus. Donations in Mickey's honor may be made to the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, the ACLU, and the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence.
UPPER EAST SIDE CONDO $1,295,000

THE NEWS Egyptian officials detained Hosni Mubarak, who was forced out of the presidency in February by a popular uprising, and his two sons for questioning about corruption during Mr. Mubarak's three decades in power. BEHIND THE NEWS One son, Gamal, was said to be in ''total disbelief'' as he and his brother, Alaa, were jailed in the same prison holding many of their closest allies. Their father complained of chest pains during questioning and was hospitalized. All were detained for interrogation for 15 days -- a standard procedure under Mr. Mubarak that could be extended, as it often was.

ABOUNASSAR--Reda Joseph, 85, passed away peacefully on April 12th 2011, at the Hospital in Mississauga, Ontario, Canada. Mr. Abounassar had an exceptional career as a regional executive with American Life Insurance Company and AIG, spanning over 40 years in more than 20 countries, opening up a number of their successful operations and start up businesses in the Middle East, Africa and the United Kingdom. Mr. Abounassar moved from Lebanon with his family to England in 1973 and then to east Africa before settling for retirement in 1990 near his family in Toronto, Canada. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife Noelle (nee Zogheib); his three children May, Zack and Sam, and his seven grandkids, Alexis, Dominique, Nikolas, Noelle, Jacob, Mathew and Alex; his last surviving brother of six siblings, Rizk Abounassar, and 27 nieces and nephews. He will be missed by his expansive circle of family, friends and peers across four continents. A devoted husband, dedicated father, loving grandfather, caring relative, trusted friend, exemplary businessman and a philanthropist, his life is a story to each. His family paid this tribute to him, "Reda was one of the most self-driven individuals, very articulate, well-traveled and admired by his many friends around the world for his strength of character, integrity and wit. He will be sorely missed." Visitation will be held on Sunday April 17th. A Funeral service will be held on Monday, April 18th at the Mississauga Chapel, Scott Funeral Home, 420 Dundas Street, Ontario. Kindly address all arrangements and flowers to Scott Funeral Home or in lieu of flowers, donations made to Our Lady of Lebanon Church 1515 Queen St. West, Toronto, ON M6R 1A5, Canada.

The kids, milling about outside with a coffee and a fag, are perhaps the only sign you're in front of the best fashion school in the world. The building, at 107 Charing Cross Road in London, is otherwise vaguely depressing. ''I had an image in my head of what Central Saint Martins was going to be like,'' a student named Leigh Alexander Fontaine said, ''and it's just shabby. The first time, I walked straight past it.'' With its long hallways and mental hospital layout, the 1938 building gives the feeling of being lost on Shutter Island. On the ground floor, the first-year students are preparing for the White Show, an annual event where they present all-white clothing. Getting to the second floor requires walking through an obscure passageway, past an old elevator that hasn't been used in decades. An instructor with alligator scissor tattoos is giving a boy in a dress advice on cutting a pattern.

Under pressure from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Ford has agreed to recall an additional 1.2 million pickup trucks because the driver's air bag may inadvertently deploy. The models are the 2004-6 F-150s and the 2006 Lincoln Mark LT, a sibling.

A report in the Big Deal column last Sunday about residential buildings and private groups in New York City that give money for the upkeep of nearby parks misstated the objective of one group, the Prospect Park Alliance, when it approached the boards of a handful of large buildings along the park a few years ago. It was seeking donations, not asking the boards to require residents to donate.

JUST a few days ago, the newest and best hope of American solar car racing improbably rested atop four laundry baskets. Quantum, the newest creation of the University of Michigan's solar car team, was designed for the World Solar Challenge in October. If it wins that event, in Australia, it will be the first victorious American entry since General Motors' Sunraycer in 1987.

MATT ABRAMCYK, an owner of the now shuttered Beatrice Inn, has a fascination with kitsch. This led him cross-country to source the interior of Tiny's and the Bar Upstairs, his latest culinary adventure, which opened last week for lunch in a salmon-pink town house on West Broadway. ''We couldn't fight the bones of the building,'' Mr. Abramcyk said of the space, which has a coffee bar with busts of J.F.K., three kinds of vintage wallpaper and an American flag installation in the main dining room, where John Martinez's new American food (i.e., bay scallop crostini with toasted walnuts) will be served next to a blazing fire. 135 West Broadway; (212) 347-1135. When the designer Gregory Parkinson approached the specialty jeweler Ten Thousand Things to create accessories for his spring 2010 collection, his only request was ''riots of color.'' The result is a series of coin-size glass enamel talismans, which have since become a permanent fixture at Ten Thousand Things' meatpacking district studio/boutique. ''As you stack them, it becomes like a composition of sorts,'' says David Rees of Ten Thousand Things. He and his partner, Ron Anderson, create folksy bijoux by fastening the swirling, multicolored pendants onto necklaces. ''It's like we're making stones instead of finding stones, and how fun is that?'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

AS the new gardener for the recently renovated Washington Square Park, I never suspected that I would be spending such a large part of my day chasing people with dogs away from plant beds. As a dog owner myself, I find it almost impossible to tell something as cute as a French bulldog puppy what to do. But it is absolutely necessary if we want our greenery to thrive. I use the phrase ''Excuse me, but did you know that dog pee is bad for plants?'' more times a day than I would ever admit at a dinner party. Although most people respond with surprise and apologies, there is always an entitled minority. Well-dressed and sometimes quite famous people will threaten to call the police, write angry letters or use their powerful connections to protect their inalienable right to allow Miffy to urinate with reckless abandon on every inch of our beautiful city.
Art Karen Rosenberg

The only thing clear about diamonds may be the translucent stones themselves. Everything else is murky and vaguely sinister: where they come from, who dug them up and under what conditions, and, more particularly, if they reek of evil. A diamond isn't like fur, which can't do much to hide its origins. But there is a lurking suspicion that, like the gold of the Nibelungs, no good can come from this bright rock. It doesn't help that the one word that rushes unbidden to stand next to diamond is blood. Diamonds are guilty until proven innocent. That is why Robert Keith and Kether Parker, the men behind Hoorsenbuhs, the Los Angeles-based jewelry line, and I are flying over the northern Kalahari Desert on our way to De Beers's huge Orapa diamond mine in Botswana along with several executives of the company. We are looking for the good diamond, which is to say a diamond unstained by the haunting images of civil wars in places like Angola, Liberia and Sierra Leone. Rival militias, their ranks filled with children, tore one another to pieces. The carnage was often paid for by diamonds dug from the local hills and rivers by so-called artisanal miners with hand tools. These ''blood diamonds'' amounted to a very small portion of the overall trade, but they seeped into the general pool and implicated all diamonds by association. What did your diamond earrings do in the war, Mommy?

SCHOONOVER--Jean Way, pioneer and leader among women in public relations and former president of the YWCA of Greater New York, died on April 3rd at her home in Manhattan. She was 90. Former President of Dudley-Anderson-Yutzy Public Relations and later President of the Public Relations Division of Ogilvy & Mather, she was the winner of many awards for her work. She is survived by her three loving children, Katherine Schoonover of New York City, Daniel Schoonover of Kinderhook, NY, and James Schoonover or White Bear Lake, MN, four grandchildren, Abigail Straus, John, Kevin, and Derek Schoonover, as well as her loving sister and business partner, Barbara Way Hunter of Walpole, NH. A memorial service will be held at the Church of St. Mark's in-the-Bowery, 2nd Ave. and 10th St. on Sat. April 30th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that you consider a contribution to the Way Family Scholarship Fund at Cornell University or to the YWCA of Greater New York.

MASON--Alan. The staff of Single Stop USA is deeply saddened by the passing of Alan Mason, beloved father of Elisabeth Mason, Single Stop's co-founder and CEO. Alan was a dedicated father, grandfather and husband. He was also a compassionate and principled educator who taught Math, English and Theatre at the Dalton School for over forty years, where he also served as Assistant Director of Dalton High School. Alan genuinely cared about the well being of others. He taught his children and his students at Dalton about the importance of making a contribution to the world and to those in it. We send our heartfelt condolences to Elisabeth, her mother Judith Mason, her siblings Norah, Daniel, and Ben, and the entire Mason family. Single Stop USA, Inc.

WOOLWORTH--R. Frederick, dies at 79. Born November 20th, 1931. Son of Mr. Mrs. Norman Bailey Woolworth. Graduated from The Taft School, 1950. Joined the firm of Stone Webster where he worked for eight years. Was one of four partners who bought the Detroit Tigers in 1956 and sold his interest in 1962. Purchased many buildings in Old San Juan, Puerto Rico in 1959. Opened Hotel El Convento in Old San Juan, Puerto Rico in February, 1962 and sold in 1972. Opened The Coe Kerr Gallery in 1969 until 1995. Was president of The Art Dealer's Association of America 1986-1991. Was a member of the Arts Advisory Board for the Internal Revenue Service 1982-1984. Survived by eight children, Frederick C, Gigi, Michael, Priscilla, Nena, Pauline, Kingsley and Elizabeth and 12 grandchildren. His constant companion for the last ten years Sharon "Sherry" Mills. Funeral services will be held in the Woolworth Chapel at Woodlawn Cemetery, April 29th, at 10am.

9 P.M. (HBO) GAME OF THRONES A cast of seemingly hundreds -- kings and queens, knights and renegades, liars and noblemen -- vie for power in the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros in this adaptation of ''A Song of Ice and Fire,'' the fantasy book series by George R. R. Martin. Filmed in Northern Ireland and Malta, the story unfolds as King Robert Baratheon (Mark Addy) asks Lord Eddard Stark (Sean Bean, above) to help run his kingdom after the death of his right-hand man. Meanwhile, Princess Daenerys (Emilia Clarke) and her brother, Viserys (Harry Lloyd), whose family once ruled the kingdoms, are threatening the throne from the east. At the same time, in the north, Jon Snow (Kit Harington), Stark's illegitimate son, has joined the brotherhood of the Night's Watch, sworn protectors of the kingdoms. '' 'Game of Thrones' serves up a lot of confusion in the name of no larger or really relevant idea beyond sketchily fleshed-out notions that war is ugly, families are insidious and power is hot,'' Ginia Bellafante wrote in The New York Times, praising by comparison series like ''The Sopranos,'' ''The Wire'' and ''Deadwood.'' ''If you are not averse to the Dungeons & Dragons aesthetic, the series might be worth the effort. If you are nearly anyone else, you will hunger for HBO to get back to the business of languages for which we already have a dictionary.'' 10 A.M. KALLIR, Joyce, age 86, on April 14, 2011. Daughter of Louis Rubin and Elsie (Levine) Rubin; she is survived by her husband John Kallir and her daughters, Barbara and Jane. A native New Yorker, Joyce was an honors graduate of Hunter College and a member of Phi Beta Kappa. She received a masters degree in mathematics from Columbia University, with a thesis on elliptic integrals. Her career began as an instructor at Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute. After a few years, she "graduated" from college to high school and taught mathematics at Seward Park High School, where she eventually became head of the Mathematics Department. After taking the required courses and examinations, she graduated once more and was appointed Assistant Principal, first at P.S. 192 and then at P.S. 115. Throughout her life Joyce took a keen interest in progressive politics, working in the 1948 campaign for Henry Wallace, later as an active member of the Teachers' Union and in opposition to the war in Viet Nam. Donations in her name may be sent to J Street, www.jstreet.org.

The 14th annual SOFA (Sculpture Objects and Functional Art) Fair, which runs through this weekend at the Park Avenue Armory, offers contemporary decorative design from 55 galleries and dealers. The theme of this year's fair is the use of historical references. Michael Eden's work (shown here) plays on the forms of antique ceramics, like those of Josiah Wedgwood (who was himself a pioneer of the Industrial Revolution), but uses synthetic materials and cutting-edge technologies. The young Dutch designer Joost van Bleiswijk's glass objects are what he calls ''contemporary versions of forgotten objects,'' while Chris Antemann's porcelain vignettes subvert the delicate sensibilities of 18th-century figurines with a satirical look at social taboos. 643 Park Avenue. The stylist Robbie Spencer's summer fashion story in our women's issue, out this Sunday, features four new stars of the European catwalks, in dresses that you can buy now and wear (and wear) until next spring. Here, in this Web exclusive, are profiles of each fresh face. Svea KloosterhofThe 16-year-old schoolgirl Svea Kloosterhof, who hails from the Netherlands, joined a new crop of models on this past fall season's runways. Having walked for Calvin Klein, Prada, Nina Ricci and Roland Mouret, to name only a few, she says Chanel was her favorite. ''The atmosphere backstage and the feel of the show is just so relaxed. And the show itself is always impressive!'' Kloosterhof appeared on the Dutch fashion scene after she was noticed by an art photographer who was a friend of her parents. ''My now mother agent (Marilyn Agency) saw the pictures on the Dutch social network Hyves and invited me to come meet her in Amsterdam. So I did, and she signed me.'' What's next for the super model? ''Nothing at the moment,'' Kloosterhof says. ''I'm much too busy with school!''

Billy Bang, a violinist whose gritty, expressive and spirited playing earned admiration in contemporary jazz circles, died on Monday at his home in Harlem. He was 63. The cause was complications of lung cancer, said Jean-Pierre Leduc, his friend and agent.

PAMELA LOVE, the jewelry designer, is known for her rough-around-the-edges aesthetic. (Think fierce talon bracelets and rings.) But Ms. Love's first pre-fall collection is full of firsts. For starters, there is her signature tribal spike cuff, now in turquoise, her favorite color (above, $195); shiny gold sun cuffs; even shinier rings that resemble a punk royal crest; and multichain skull necklaces in red, purple, mint and, of course, turquoise. ''I think it's a nice time for a breath of fresh air,'' said Ms. Love, a C.F.D.A. fashion fund finalist and recent Ecco Domani winner. ''I like the contrast of aggressive jewelry in fun or pretty colors.'' For information, go to pamelalovenyc.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

When Charlotte Dellal married last summer, the bride picked leopard-print pumps as her ''something new,'' with ''something blue'' piping along the heels. Of course, when you're the designer behind the retro-glam, neo-burlesque shoe brand Charlotte Olympia, a little fashion arts and crafts is par for the course. The cute and quirky footwear spurred one matrimonially inclined guest to ask Dellal for a pair in purple. ''I think there's a big gap in the bridal market,'' she says. ''So much thought goes into the lingerie and bouquet. Why not your shoes, too?'' This month she unveils a nuptial-minded collection: classics like the Dolly and Paloma, in sky blue, scarlet and, naturally, leopard, along with a heart-shaped getaway bag to toss them in. We can't think of any reason not to say, ''I do.'' From $730; call 011-44-207-499-0145. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Alina Simone is a folk-pop singer who lives in Brooklyn. Alina Bronsky is a fast-rising European novelist who lives near Frankfurt, Germany. Both are young, both are of Soviet extraction, and both have books coming out this spring. As far as coincidences go, that's not a stunning one, but it further underscores recent artistic contributions from Soviet diaspora children, a whip-smart group now in their 20s and 30s that includes Regina Spektor, Mila Kunis, Anton Yelchin, the comedian Eugene Mirman (a childhood friend of Simone's), and the writers Gary Shteyngart, Keith Gessen and Sana Krasikov. Simone, whose family left the Soviet Union in 1976, when she was 1, says she can't always identify with this bunch. ''I kind of have this insecurity - I'm not Russian enough,'' she says. '' My friends are pretty much all Americanized. We like to go to Brighton Beach and buy the vodka bottles shaped like Kalashnikovs and get all the food that our grandmothers cooked.''

''The report pulls back the curtain on shoddy, risky, deceptive practices on the part of a lot of major financial institutions.'' Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan and co-chairman of a Senate panel that released a 650-page report titled ''Wall Street and the Financial Crisis: Anatomy of a Financial Collapse.'' ''A lot of people will still be paying off their student loans when it's time for their kids to go to college.'' Mark Kantrowitz, publisher of FinAid.org and Fastweb. com, who has compiled estimates of student debt, which outpaced credit card debt for the first time last year. Student loan debt is likely to top a trillion dollars this year as more students go to college and a growing share borrow money to do so.

An article on April 3 about this year's starting pitchers for the Philadelphia Phillies, which included comparisons with the greatest pitchers of all time, misstated the pitching arm of the Hall of Famer Carl Hubbell. It was his left, not his right.
