OBITUARIES An obituary on Sunday about the filmmaker Sidney Lumet contained an incorrect credit. Although Mr. Lumet did direct the 1957 movie ''12 Angry Men,'' the 1954 television drama on which that film was based was directed by Franklin J. Schaffner, not by Mr. Lumet. The obituary also contained incorrect information about a survivor. Mr. Lumet is survived by a great-granddaughter, not a great-grandson.

This spring, stripes - which have come back, according to the fashion press, at least four times in the past six years - are back again. Evidently, we are deeply fond of stripes. The mystery is, why? In this fame-crazed, multiplatform era, when a person can at any embarrassing moment find herself on YouTube or Flickr, you'd expect fashionable women to insist on patterns that scale well - from iPhone to Imax. But just look at Comme des Garcons' adorably demented half-gray jacket. The half that isn't gray shimmers with blue-and-white pajama stripes that will turn you into a walking moire effect on Facebook. Or imagine, for the moment, some celebrity braving the red carpet in one of Prada's graphic striped shifts, many framed with baroque flourishes of monkeys and bananas. Our celebrity will command attention, sure, but who will remember her face, her name or her signature scandal once those eye-popping colors burn themselves into the collective retina? Could this love affair with stripes be toxic?

Here's a sampling of reader responses to John Anderson's article about how hard it is to keep the surprise endings of today's movies a secret. ''Spoilers rarely have meaning for me for the films that I most enjoy. Even knowing the plot of 'Vertigo' does not change the tone of mystery, malaise and meaninglessness that haunts viewing the film now -- even 53 years after its release.''

METROPOLITAN An article last Sunday about Peter G. Peterson, who has a foundation to educate Americans about the national debt, referred imprecisely, in some copies, to a relationship between Mr. Peterson and The Washington Post. The newspaper has published articles by The Fiscal Times, a publication that Mr. Peterson finances, but the foundation does not have a ''partnership'' with The Post. The article also misstated a former role of Mr. Peterson with the Council on Foreign Relations. He is an ex-chairman, not an ex-president.

IT is highly unusual in the West Village, even more so on a street only one block long, to see two neighboring town houses go on the market at the same time. They are at Nos. 18 and 20 Jones Street, which is not to be -- but often is -- confused with Great Jones Street. If bought together and combined, the two Greek Revival-style houses would make up a single 42-foot-wide town house with 6,800 square feet of space.

MASON--Alan. The Dalton School community is deeply saddened by the passing of Alan Mason, a passionate educator, a dedicated administrator and an adored advisor to generations of students over 44 years. He will be greatly missed. We have lost a beloved member of the Dalton family. Ellen C. Stein, Head of School

Michael C. Latham, an expert on international nutrition and tropical health who waged a long campaign against the use of infant formula and for the practice of breastfeeding in developing countries, died on April 1 in Boston. He was 82 and lived in Newfield, N.Y. The cause was pneumonia, his son Mark said.

An article on April 10 about rising pay for chief executives misstated the title of an expert, Bruce H. Goldfarb. He is president and C.E.O. of Okapi Partners, a proxy solicitation and investor response firm. He is not a compensation consultant.

ADLER--Lucille (Imber). Lucille, 86 years too soon to leave us. We know you tried and we encouraged you. As my sister-in-law, you welcomed me into the Imber family in 1948 and continued to make me feel an important part of the family. You leave behind so many people who loved you. I shall miss you oh so much! Rest in peace my dear friend and sister. Love, Dotty Imber

NATIONAL An article last Sunday about the planned construction of a tunnel in Seattle to replace an aging viaduct misstated the level of support in a recent poll for another proposal, to repair the viaduct or replace it with a new one. It drew the support of 38 percent of respondents, not most of them. The article also misstated the cost of demolition of the viaduct and construction of a tunnel. It is $3.1 billion, not $4.2 billion, which includes the cost of nearby construction related to the project.

Yakov Kreizberg, an internationally known conductor praised for the depth and intensity of his interpretations, died on March 15 at his home in Monte Carlo. He was 51. The death, after a long illness, was announced on Mr. Kreizberg's Web site.

For designers and clients alike, some clothes are just money in the bank. My favorite fashion reading of the last few years has been Caroline Weber's ''Queen of Fashion: What Marie Antoinette Wore to the Revolution.'' An impeccably researched history of the manner in which the dauphine-turned-queen used her clothing to manipulate her fate, daring the French population to simultaneously loathe and respect her, the book is a defiant rebuttal of plainness, of the drab and dreary. What would she wear today? A white Prada capelet detailed with blue monkeys? A neon poppy trench coat by Zac Posen? An operatically ruffled silk blouse by Oscar de la Renta? These are the designers you visit again and again when you need some ego-propping flash and dazzle. But what about the designers whose clothes don't shout? Rather, they murmur at the back of the closet, not begging to be worn - because they will be worn until threadbare.

In 1941, Joe DiMaggio of the Yankees put together a 56-game hitting streak that was the talk of baseball. For all the attention he received, DiMaggio's .357 batting average at the end of the season fell well short of the American League lead, as Ted Williams of the Boston Red Sox famously batted .406. Kevin Love, a Minnesota Timberwolves forward, may know how DiMaggio felt.

SPORTS An article last Sunday about golfers who have been ranked No. 1 or are in the Hall of Fame but have never won the Masters misstated the number of times that José María Olazábal won the Masters. It is two times, in 1994 and 1999. He is not among those who have never won the Masters.

For the Chicago-based retailer, whose eponymous store stocks the likes of Azzedine Alaïa (a close friend), Comme des Garçons and Nina Ricci, fashion is a family affair. Next month, the shop moves to a sprawling, multilevel space in the city's Gold Coast area. ''The first floor will feel like your mom's super-giant closet,'' Goldman says, while the second floor will contain a cafe and a gallery curated by Goldman and her husband, Josh. The third will house a playroom for their sons. Like the new store, the family's River North home is filled with vintage and modern pieces, and is as inviting to designer-clad adults as it is to the highchair set. SANDRA BALLENTINE
Pop Jon Pareles

When it goes live this month, Motilo.com will use features like videoconferencing to allow users to shop with friends and create complete outfits, even if the items are from different online stores. And thanks to social networking components, users' shopping predilections will be broadcast to the world, allowing anyone to become a trendsetter. To kick-start the process, Motilo's chief executive, Sofia Barattieri di San Pietro, commissioned a bevy of pretty young ''It'' girls and stylists, including Valentine Fillol-Cordier, Anna Dello Russo and the D.J. Bip Ling, to share their picks with Motilo's users. ''Soon we want to involve different women, with different backgrounds, ages and charisma,'' Barattieri says. ''It is only the beginning.'' Above, Fillol-Cordier wears a Carven silk-bourette pantsuit and a Lanvin brushed-satin floral brooch, all available at Motilo.com. At age 27, Fillol-Cordier, a Paris-born beauty and stylist who contributes to hip magazines like Dazed and Confused, is already a major force in the fashion world. In addition to consulting and acting as contributing editor to the fashion and culture magazine Dossier, in her free time Fillol-Cordier models for some of the most respected photographers in the industry, having appeared in Purple, Elle and Teen Vogue. Recently she's started contributing to the new social shopping destination Motilo.com, where she shares her personal style and expertise with the site's users.

Baltimore had vexed Abraham Lincoln for months. The city was the secessionist heart of slaveholding, nativist Maryland, a state in which the new president had run fourth in the 1860 election, garnering fewer than 3,000 votes. Maryland’s population was one-quarter African-American, evenly divided between slaves and free blacks. And yet Lincoln desperately needed the state: without it in the Union, Washington would be completely within foreign — and, after April 12, enemy — territory.

After being rejected by the board at 812 Fifth Avenue, she has spent nearly two years fighting to get back her deposit on the $3 million apartment.

Nestlé, the world’s biggest food company, has taken a step toward strengthening its position in China by agreeing to acquire 60 percent of the Yinlu Food Group. The family-owned Yinlu had sales of $829 million last year, and its acquisition gives Nestlé broader access to a fast-growing segment of the Chinese market, Reuters reports.

For the third season in a row, the Metropolitan Opera is offering recitals instead of full-scale operas for its free summer parks series. The Met announced in a statement on Monday that the soprano Angela Meade, the mezzo-soprano Jennifer Johnson Cano and the tenor Dimitri Pittas would perform on July 11 in Central Park and on July 13 in Brooklyn Bridge Park. Three other singers would present programs in Crotona Park in the Bronx (July 19); Clove Lakes Park on Staten Island (July 21); Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens (July 26); and Jackie Robinson Park in Harlem (July 28). Those performers will be Layla Claire, a soprano; Renée Tatum, a mezzo-soprano; and Ryan Speedo Green, a bass-baritone. The pianist Bradley Moore will be the accompanist for all of the concerts. The statement said the Met would also present free outdoor screenings of its high-definition broadcasts from Lincoln Center from Aug. 27 to Sept. 5. The last full Met opera in the park was in the summer of 2007. In 2008, the Met presented a lone recital by the soprano Angela Gheorghiu and the tenor Roberto Alagna.

She’s not Sarah Palin. She’s not Hillary Rodham Clinton or Michele Bachmann, and needless to say, she’s not Joe Biden or Dick Cheney, either. But Julia Louis-Dreyfus will play a female vice president of the United States in “Veep,” a new HBO comedy series that the network announced on Monday it had picked up.

The newsmagazine “60 Minutes” delivered the largest audience in prime time on Sunday as CBS won the night’s ratings over its network competitors. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 10.6 million viewers tuned in at 7 p.m. for an edition that featured an investigation into the accuracy of Greg Mortenson’s book “Three Cups of Tea.” CBS then also won the 8 p.m. hour with its reality show “The Amazing Race” (8.7 million). ABC ranked close behind CBS in second place for the night, leading during the 9 p.m. hour with “Desperate Housewives” (8.8 million). NBC placed third over all, garnering an average of 7.4 million viewers for “The Celebrity Apprentice” from 9 to 11. Fox was fourth with its animated comedy lineup, although “Family Guy” (6 million) earned the night’s highest ratings in the demographic of adults 18 to 49.

Even among the Warhol Superstars, Candy Darling was a standout. Her spot-on embodiment of a ’40s-era Hollywood starlet — demure, mysterious, quiet — stood in contrast to the pretty-little-rich-girl routine of Edie Sedgwick, the drug-fueled silver-tongued cheek of Brigid Berlin and the Teutonic otherness of Nico. And the fact that she was a transgendered woman from Long Island only added to her mystique. Her fame spread via the Paul Morrissey films “Flesh” and “Women in Revolt,” and she was immortalized by Lou Reed in the songs “Candy Says” and “Walk on the Wild Side.” She died in 1974, from leukemia connected to unsafe hormone treatments, at the age of 29.

Massimo Vitali’s photographs are transporting. When I see one of his pictures, I want to be in it. Partly this is because the settings are so often happy gathering spots: beaches, lakes, pools and other watering holes, ski slopes, gardens and assorted sightseeing sites. Usually there’s sunlight; always there’s color. Above all, there’s clarity — I’m convinced that if I look hard enough, I can see everything and forever.

They say behind every successful man stands a woman. In the case of Michael Kors, it’s his mother, Joan, a former model and Kors’s perennial muse. Now he has designed a bag worthy of carrying not just her wallet and sunglasses but also her name. The Joan, which comes in a variety of colors (including the mocha embossed leather version seen here) and is modestly priced at $398, meets Joan’s strict standards: “I always look for an outside pocket for my phone and keys,” she says, “and I love a zip closure.” But she adds, “I certainly wouldn’t mind being surprised with a crocodile version!” Joan says she plans to celebrate Mother’s Day on the West Coast with a fabulous arrangement of peonies and dinner with Michael. The greatest gift he’s ever given her? “Not having to go shopping for the past 30 years.”

Another book in the Sarah Palin canon is weeks away from publication. Howard Books, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, announced on Monday that on May 24 it would publish “Blind Allegiance to Sarah Palin,” an account of Ms. Palin’s time as governor and as a vice-presidential candidate, written by Frank Bailey, one of her former aides. In a statement, Howard Books called it “a chilling exposé of Palin and the story of one man’s slow drift from his most cherished beliefs to his ultimate redemption.” Mr. Bailey’s book will come before a widely anticipated book about Ms. Palin, “The Rogue,” by the author and the journalist Joe McGinniss, which is expected to be released by Crown in September.

My column today includes an estimate, taken from this Congressional Budget Office report, of what a median-income family would pay in taxes over the next few decades under the “current law baseline” — a scenario in which tax rates rise fast enough to cover the budget deficit without any kind of entitlement reform. The median income figure the C.B.O. used (see Table 4-4 on p. 65 of the report) is $94,900 for a family of four, which (as a number of readers have noted) seems much higher than the usual estimates for median income in a four-person household. It turns out that I didn’t catch a crucial footnote in the C.B.O. document: “All income is assumed to be from compensation, which includes employment-based health insurance and the employer’s share of payroll taxes.” That is to say, the $94,900 in income includes the estimated value of the median family’s health care plan as well as their salary, which is not what most people think of when they hear the term “median income.” I apologize for the confusion.

PRINEVILLE, Ore. — This small town in the high desert of central Oregon has seen better days. The community of about 9,000 once had five saw mills employing some 1,200 people. Today all the saw mills are gone, and so are their jobs. Three years ago, Les Schwab, the town’s best-known business, moved its headquarters to nearby Bend, taking with it about 100 well-paying jobs. In the last 18 months, more than 1,000 residents left the town and the county, which has the highest rate of unemployment in Oregon at roughly 20 percent.

In the pantheon of fantasy and science-fiction projects that Joss Whedon helped create, the Internet musical “Dr. Horrible’s Sing-Along Blog” can be easy to overlook: it’s not his beloved television series that ran a healthy seven seasons (“Buffy the Vampire Slayer”), or its beloved spinoff (“Angel”), or his misunderstood television show that was canceled before its time (“Dollhouse”) or his other misunderstood television show that was canceled before its time and spawned a misunderstood movie (“Firefly” and “Serenity”). “Dr. Horrible” is simply a three-act musical about an aspiring super-villain (played by Neil Patrick Harris), his smug do-gooding nemesis (Nathan Fillion) and the woman who comes between them (Felicia Day). Dreamed up by Mr. Whedon, his brothers Zack and Jed, and Maurissa Tancharoen during the 2007-8 writers’ strike and produced on his own dime, it is the pure expression of what they wanted to make at the time, without any outside interference.

Who says poetry doesn't pay? The Poetry Foundation has awarded the translator and poet David Ferry the $100,000 Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize for lifetime achievement. Born in Orange, New Jersey in 1924, Mr. Ferry is an emeritus professor at Wellesley College and continues to teach at both Boston University and Suffolk University. He is midway through a new translation of Virgil's Aeneid and has a new collection of poems, ''Bewilderment,'' due out next year.

McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY on Wednesday, April 20 between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm. The funeral service will be held at Christ Church, Bronxville on Thursday, April 21 at 3:00pm. STRONGIN--Ned. Co-Inventor of Connect Four died on April 9, 2011 at almost 92. He was a renowned independent toy designer, who worked with all of the major Toy Companies over several decades. Though Connect Four remains his biggest success, he was involved in designing many other items, including Weebles ("Wobble But They Don't Fall Down"). He was a great businessman, husband, father and grandfather.

RIVES--Lloyd Michael 'Mike', of Boston, a World War II Veteran, age 89, died Thursday, April 14, in Boston after a short illness. He is lovingly survived by his niece, Peach Warren of Hopedale, MA, and his Nephews, John H. Rives of Worcester, MA, and Peter Rives of Gilford, NH. Mr. Rives was a graduate of Princeton University and worked for the U.S. Government as a Foreign Service Diplomat for many years. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Lloyd Michael Rives to The Preservation Society of Newport County, Attn: Development Office, 424 Bellevue Ave., Newport, RI 02840, or The Fresh Air Fund, 633 Third Ave., 14th Floor, NY, NY 10017.

Iconoclastic and opinionated, with a love of books and her grandchildren: Kate, Emma, Colin, Erin, Martina, and Tyrone. It's pretty well established that walking does more for your golf game than riding in a cart. And obviously, it offers more exercise. There is the rare case, however, in which riding in a cart might give you the chance to run for your life. According to a story in The Baxter Bulletin of northwestern Arkansas, an exploding golf cart interrupted a golfer as he was playing the seventh hole at the Rivercliff Golf Course in Bull Shoals in mid-February. The cart was acting up and witnesses said they heard some popping noises. Then there was an explosion and fire, according to the newspaper, which quoted the course owner and local fire chief. There were no serious injuries.

WEEKEND A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday, about a concert at 6:30 p.m. on Tuesday at St. Thomas Church, West 53rd Street and Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, misstated the performers. Ryland Angel will be the countertenor soloist in Stabat Mater by Vivaldi, and Scott Dispensa the baritone soloist in Bach's Cantata No. 82; the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys will not perform. The entry also misidentified the instrument from which John Scott will conduct the vocal soloists and the Sinfonia Players. It is the continuo organ, not the harpsichord.

BLUMBERG-HOLLAND--Helen. The Blumberg Family mourns with deep sadness the loss of Helen Blumberg Holland on April 16 in Palm Beach after a brief illness. One of the seven children of David and Sarah Isacowitz, she was born on March 17, 1912 and attended Erasmus Hall, the Palm Beach Academy, and Skidmore College. In 1932 she married Jack Blumberg, son of Max and Lena Blumberg. Their honeymoon of four months in Europe, North Africa and the Middle East, was the first of many travels. Residing in Hewlett Harbor, Long Island, and later in Manhattan and Palm Beach, she expressed her creative gifts as a sculptor, painter, gardener, and floral arranger, for which she won several tricolors. After the untimely loss of her husband in 1970, she married Joseph Rose and later Irving Holland, who predeceased her. She was truly a matriarch within her family, providing leadership, encouragement, sound values, a nobility of spirit, humor, the appreciation of music and art, and a love of family that was still evident in her last hours when she blessed her three sons. She is survived by sons Thomas A. Blumberg, Max Blumberg, and David Blumberg, daughter-in-law Lanie Leviton Blumberg, grandchildren Betsy Blumberg Watson (Doug), Karen Blumberg Shaevitz (Jonathon), Ben Blumberg (Sue), Kenneth Blumberg (Alissa) and Jennifer Gersten, great-grandchildren Emily, Rachel and Caroline Watson, Jack and Rebecca Shaevitz, Sam and Lena Blumberg, Jesse and Jordana Blumberg, her beloved sister Shirley Leviton, and many dear nieces and nephews. A memorial service will take place on Wednesday, April 20 at 11:30am at Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave at 81th St., New York, followed by interment at the Blumberg Mausoleum at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

SEVIN--Geraldine. She is survived by her loving children, Ilisa, Seth and Susan, and her adoring grandchildren Benjamin and Lizabeth. Services, 1pm on April 20, Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

In many countries around the world, if you break the law by stealing copyrighted content you can be sentenced to prison and heavily fined. But if Google catches you breaking copyright laws, the punishment is more akin to being caught smoking in the boys room in high school: You're forced to take an online class at YouTube's Copyright School. Copyright School isn't your normal edition of detention. Copyright violators are asked to watch a four-and-a-half minute minute video and then required to take a multiple choice quiz that asks questions pertaining to copyright. One question, for example, asks if music videos and photographs fall under copyright protection.

When Sidney Harman was found to have an aggressive form of leukemia several weeks ago, he sat down to write a short essay for Newsweek about his determination to beat the disease. But Mr. Harman, the 92-year-old owner of Newsweek, decided not to publish the article, thinking that he had years left to live. He saw no reason to alarm anyone about an illness he believed he could outlive.

As Adam Scott made his charge up the leader board in the final round of this year's Masters, golf seemed closer than ever to having its first winner of a Grand Slam event who wielded a long putter. But Scott would have crossed a clear boundary with that 49-inch putting stick.

The writing is blurred and the paper nearly translucent, but the scene it portrays is vivid. In a recently discovered letter, Mary Custis Lee, the eldest daughter of Robert E. Lee, describes how her father wrestled with the decision to resign his commission in the United States Army and side with the South. The letter, found in a folder of fragments at the Virginia Historical Society, was written in 1871 to Charles Marshall, Lee’s former aide-to–camp, as he prepared to write a biography of the great general.

Three new productions in New York have announced weeks-long extensions. “Sleep No More,” an interactive theater piece by the British company Punchdrunk that is performed throughout three renovated warehouses on West 27th Street, has extended through June 25. Provinces in central and southwestern China may face their worst electricity shortages in years this summer due to intensifying coal shortages and drought, state officials warn. Fuel supplies are dwindling due to steadily rising prices and transportation problems, while meager rainfall during March has left hydroelectric facilities generating significantly below peak capacity. A major copper producing region is already suffering regular power shortages, hampering production. [Reuters]

If the equivalent of an Academy Award were offered for best performance as a muse to artists, Marie-Thérèse Walter would surely have won one. She was 17 years old in 1927, when she met a strangely charismatic, short man with mesmerizing eyes, sporting a handsome red-and-black striped tie, on the sidewalk outside the Galeries Lafayette department store in Paris, where she’d gone to buy a Peter Pan collar and cuffs. “You have an interesting face,” he told her. “I’d like to do your portrait.” The name Picasso meant nothing to her, but she kept the appointment they made at his studio the next day, igniting a passion that would change the course of his art.

Even with three blocks, that’s an underwhelming line, and Anthony’s typical lack of points and boards is part of the reason why he’s often incorrectly grouped with Miami’s less-than-productive supporting cast.

The conservative columnist and author Ann Coulter has vowed to “take on the liberal mob” in her new book, “Demonic,” whose publication was announced on Tuesday. The book is scheduled for release on June 7 by Crown Forum, part of Random House. The publisher says Ms. Coulter will address topics including “the Democratic Party’s coddling of violent mobs,” the “false history of civil rights given by the media” and the “truth about the original Tea Party.” Ms. Coulter’s last book, “Guilty,” spent nine weeks on The New York Times best-seller list. According to Nielsen BookScan, which tracks roughly 75 percent of retail sales, it sold 121,000 copies in hardcover and 16,000 in paperback. Crown Forum’s authors include former Senator Fred Thompson, Joe Scarborough and George F. Will.

The cast of “The Dark Knight Rises,” Christopher Nolan’s third and final entry in his series of Batman movies, is looking increasingly like the cast of his 2010 summer blockbuster “Inception,” with Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Marion Cotillard now officially on board for that superhero film. Warner Brothers Pictures said on Tuesday that Mr. Gordon-Levitt, who played one of Leonardo DiCaprio‘s dream-invading accomplices in “Inception,” will play John Blake, a Gotham City beat cop, in “The Dark Knight Rises”; Ms. Cotillard, who played Mr. DiCaprio’s enigmatic wife in “Inception,” has been cast as Miranda Tate, a board member at Wayne Enterprises who is allied with Bruce Wayne. Tom Hardy, another member of the “Inception” gang, was previously announced to play the villain Bane, and Michael Caine, who had a brief role in that film (or did he? No, wait, he did) has played the butler Alfred in all of Mr. Nolan’s Bat-films.

A 90-minute edition of “Dancing With the Stars” dominated the ratings on Monday as 19.6 million viewers tuned in to ABC from 8 to 9:30 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC easily led the night over all despite a diminished audience after the dancing competition for its sitcom “Cougar Town” at 9:30 (8.5 million). CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” led at 10 p.m., drawing 10.9 million viewers and outperforming ABC’s “20/20” special (7.6 million). CBS ranked second, earning modest ratings for its comedy lineup from 8 to 10, including “How I Met Your Mother” (6.4 million), “Mad Love” (5.6 million) and “Mike & Molly” (9.7 million), while a repeat of “Two and a Half Men” attracted 7.3 million viewers at 9. Fox was third with “House” at 8 (8.6 million) and “The Chicago Code” at 9 (6.4 million). The album, which does not yet have a title (can we humbly suggest “Careful, Man, There’s A Beverage Here”?) will be recorded with the producer T-Bone Burnett, who first met Mr. Bridges on the set of “Heaven’s Gate,” and selected music for the “Big Lebowski” soundtrack and co-wrote songs for “Crazy Heart,” including the Oscar-nominated track “The Weary Kind.” Blue Note Records said in a statement that Mr. Bridges “will contribute several of his own compositions” and perform songs by Stephen Bruton and John Goodwin, Greg Brown, Bo Ramsey, Tom Waits, and others. Though we wouldn’t hold out much hope for the Dude’s Creedence cassettes, Mr. Bridges’s album is planned for a late summer release.

Around the same period, I also stopped watching “One Life to Live” regularly, following the heart transplant that Victoria Lord Riley Burke Riley Buchanan Buchanan Carpenter Davidson received thanks to the untimely death of the love of her life and sixth husband, Ben, who lay comatose in a hospital bed for months after being accidentally shot in the head during an attempt to save Viki from a kidnapper. Still, I was taken aback by last week’s news that after more than 40 years of showing them five days a week, 52 weeks a year, ABC was axing both shows, one by September and the other by January 2012, leaving just “The Young and the Restless,” “The Bold and the Beautiful,” “Days of Our Lives” and “General Hospital” to carry on the daytime-serial legacy.

The buy-low, sell-high mantra is one of the most overused in fantasy sports. No one in any league worth playing in will deal you Carl Crawford, Kevin Youkilis or Carlos Gonzalez at a discount just because of two bad weeks. In order to get an actual bargain, then, you need to aim at players whose market values have declined since draft day for good reason and about whom even you are worried. While buying low usually isn’t possible, buying lowest typically is.

For a long time after Eddie Adams won a Pulitzer Prize for "Saigon Execution," he wouldn't speak of it. He turned away questions about the picture, grumbling some dismissive rebuff like, "Everything's already been said about it." Or: "There's nothing new. I don't want to talk about it now." I experienced this firsthand in the 1970s as a college student. At an Indiana University seminar, I asked him about "Saigon Execution." Before an auditorium packed with photojournalism students, Eddie cut me off at the knees, then pointed to the next raised hand.

(49)THE SILENCE In this ''Frontline'' edition, the producer Tom Curran and the reporter Mark Trahant follow one of Bishop Donald Kettler's trips of ''atonement,'' mandated by a 2010 bankruptcy settlement involving the Fairbanks Roman Catholic Diocese, to apologize for decades of abuse of American Indian and Alaska Native children by priests and church workers. Among victims who have spoken out are, above, Elsie Boudreau, left, and Alberta Steve. Also, Miles O'Brien follows up on ''Flying Cheaper,'' a January report on the outsourcing of repair work by major airlines to independent maintenance operations in the United States and abroad that cost less. In addition, Mr. O'Brien inquires into the case of the Chinese artist and critic of the government Ai Weiwei, who was detained by police on April 3. 8 P.M. (ABC) JAMIE OLIVER'S FOOD REVOLUTION Since Mr. Oliver's permits to film his reality show at local high schools were revoked this year, because the Los Angeles Unified School District said he had failed to present a proposal of his plans, Mr. Oliver tries to rally parental support by dressing as a tomato and distributing free, nutritious lunches. One school, run by an independent partnership, finally allows him to teach its students about healthy cooking -- as long as he doesn't enter the cafeteria or kitchen.

She's not Sarah Palin. She's not Hillary Rodham Clinton or Michele Bachmann, and needless to say, she's not Joe Biden or Dick Cheney, either. But Julia Louis-Dreyfus will play a female vice president of the United States in ''Veep,'' a new HBO comedy series that the network announced on Monday it had picked up. In ''Veep,'' which is planned to make its debut next year, Ms. Louis-Dreyfus (an Emmy Award-winner for ''Seinfeld'' and ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'') will play Selina Meyer, a United States senator who is elected to the country's second-highest office.

As he turns his attention to his American adaptation of ''The X Factor,'' Simon Cowell is bowing out, at least partly, from the British version of the show he created. This year, Mr. Cowell, the acerbic music and television producer, ''will not be a weekly judge'' on the British program on ITV, that network's director of television, Peter Fincham, told The Sunday Mirror.

And now, another example that no good deed goes unpunished. On July 8, 2009, Richard Ravitch was hastily sworn in as New York's 75th lieutenant governor, filling a vacancy that occurred the previous year when David A. Paterson succeeded Eliot Spitzer as governor. Mr. Paterson filled the position to end a deadlock in the State Senate's leadership and recruited Mr. Ravitch both to enhance his own sagging political credibility and to help solve the state's increasingly dire fiscal crisis.

BLUMBERG-HOLLAND--Helen. The Blumberg Family mourns with deep sadness the loss of Helen Blumberg Holland on April 16 in Palm Beach after a brief illness. One of the seven children of David and Sarah Isacowitz, she was born on March 17, 1912 and attended Erasmus Hall, the Palm Beach Academy, and Skidmore College. In 1932 she married Jack Blumberg, son of Max and Lena Blumberg. Their honeymoon of four months in Europe, North Africa and the Middle East, was the first of many travels. Residing in Hewlett Harbor, Long Island, and later in Manhattan and Palm Beach, she expressed her creative gifts as a sculptor, painter, gardener, and floral arranger, for which she won several tricolors. After the untimely loss of her husband in 1970, she married Joseph Rose and later Irving Holland, who predeceased her. She was truly a matriarch within her family, providing leadership, encouragement, sound values, a nobility of spirit, humor, the appreciation of music and art, and a love of family that was still evident in her last hours when she blessed her three sons. She is survived by sons Thomas A. Blumberg, Max Blumberg, and David Blumberg, daughter-in-law Lanie Leviton Blumberg, grandchildren Betsy Blumberg Watson (Doug), Karen Blumberg Shaevitz (Jonathon), Ben Blumberg (Sue), Kenneth Blumberg (Alissa) and Jennifer Gersten, great-grandchildren Emily, Rachel and Caroline Watson, Jack and Rebecca Shaevitz, Sam and Lena Blumberg, Jesse and Jordana Blumberg, her beloved sister Shirley Leviton, and many dear nieces and nephews. A memorial service will take place on Wednesday, April 20 at 11:30am at Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave at 81th St., New York, followed by interment at the Blumberg Mausoleum at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

Even then, 235 years ago, Congress worried about spending. All right, officially it was still the Continental Congress when it approved the new nation's first official monument, a monument that ended up in Lower Manhattan. But right there, in its instructions to Benjamin Franklin, it said to watch the cost. He did his best. Later on, when the sculptor complained that he was underpaid, Franklin himself paid the shipping and handling to send the completed monument from France to the barely united states.

What do Nora Ephron and the Wikipedia co-founder Jimmy Wales (both at left) talk about when they get together? Maybe they reminisce about their appearances on ''The Colbert Report,'' he says he loved ''Sleepless in Seattle,'' she complains about the accuracy of her Wikipedia entry, and then they get around to judging independent films. That's what the Tribeca Film Festival would have us believe. On Monday, the festival's organizers announced the 38 members of its six juries for its competitive film categories, and they are, as usual, the motliest of crews:-Jurors for the festival's world narrative competition include the Malian filmmaker Souleymane Cisse, the ''Your Highness'' director David Gordon Green, the ''Saturday Night Live'' star Jason Sudeikis and the Academy Award winner Dianne Wiest.-Whoopi Goldberg, Michael Cera and the ''September Issue'' director R. J. Cutler will be among the jurors for the world documentary category.- Rainn Wilson, Atom Egoyan, Anna Kendrick, Paul Dano and Zoe Kazan get to weigh in on the emerging narrative competition.-Lauren Hutton will sit on the emerging documentary jury.-Patrick Wilson and Agnes Gund will help evaluate the documentary and student short film competitions.-And Ms. Ephron and Mr. Wales will join Denis Leary, Fran Lebowitz and the director David O. Russell (''The Fighter'') on the narrative short film jury.This year's Tribeca Film Festival opens on Thursday and runs through May 1.

To a certain slice of New Yorkers, it's the kind of gossip that is whispered over lunches at Bergdorf's and mentioned during air kisses at fund-raisers: being rejected by a Fifth Avenue co-op board. But a Turkish businesswoman's story is a bit different. After being rejected by the board at 812 Fifth Avenue, she has spent nearly two years fighting to get back her deposit on the $3 million apartment. The case turned on whether the woman, Demet Sabanci Cetindogan, had tried to sabotage the board interview - that is, deliberately made a bad impression so the board would turn down the deal.

Lawyers for Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire co-founder of the Galleon Group accused of making tens of millions of dollars on insider tips, rested their case on Monday without calling Mr. Rajaratnam as a witness. Though the defense had raised the prospect that Mr. Rajaratnam might testify, he remained silent throughout the biggest insider trading trial in a generation, offering only a rare laugh or a smile from his seat behind the defense table.

For the third season in a row, the Metropolitan Opera is offering recitals instead of full-scale operas for its free summer parks series. The Met announced in a statement on Monday that the soprano Angela Meade, the mezzo-soprano Jennifer Johnson Cano and the tenor Dimitri Pittas would perform on July 11 in Central Park and on July 13 in Brooklyn Bridge Park. Three other singers would present programs in Crotona Park in the Bronx (July 19); Clove Lakes Park on Staten Island (July 21); Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens (July 26); and Jackie Robinson Park in Harlem (July 28). Those performers will be Layla Claire, a soprano; Renee Tatum, a mezzo-soprano; and Ryan Speedo Green, a bass-baritone. The pianist Bradley Moore will be the accompanist for all of the concerts. The statement said the Met would also present free outdoor screenings of its high-definition broadcasts from Lincoln Center from Aug. 27 to Sept. 5. The last full Met opera in the park was in the summer of 2007. In 2008, the Met presented a lone recital by the soprano Angela Gheorghiu and the tenor Roberto Alagna. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

BRESSLER--Sidney. Age 90, of New York City and Goshen, CT, formerly of Tenafly, NJ. Born in Paterson, NJ, he attended the London School of Economics and graduated from Ohio State University. More than 55,000 Facebook users ''like'' the new Broadway musical ''Sister Act,'' which, like most major theatrical productions today, has its own page, as well a Twitter account (1,300 followers), YouTube channel (30,000 uploaded views) and set of apps. (Photoshop your face into a nun's wimple and win free tickets!) Yet how many 50-year-old white female tourists -- the average Broadway ticket buyers -- are plunking down money for ''Sister Act'' because @MzzzD17 wrote on Twitter that seeing it ''made me want to go back to church! :-)''? Ask Broadway insiders to say how many tickets have been sold as a result of all this social networking, and the look on their faces reads, ''Server not found.''

The number of people treated in hospitals in the United States for problems related to medication errors has surged more than 50 percent in recent years. ''We didn't have a massive short against the housing market,'' Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, insisted at a Congressional hearing last year. Ever since, politicians, pundits and professors have been calling him a liar. FRONT PAGE An article on Sunday about the search by the United States and its allies for a country to accept Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi should he leave Libya misstated the possible role of the International Criminal Court in the Hague in any indictment of Colonel Qaddafi in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland in 1988. The court could not indict him. (Under the Rome Statute, the treaty that created the court, there is no retroactive jurisdiction for crimes committed before July 1, 2002, when the statute took effect.)

Another book in the Sarah Palin canon is weeks away from publication. Howard Books, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, announced on Monday that on May 24 it would publish ''Blind Allegiance to Sarah Palin,'' an account of Ms. Palin's time as governor and as a vice-presidential candidate, written by Frank Bailey, one of her former aides. In a statement, Howard Books called it ''a chilling expose of Palin and the story of one man's slow drift from his most cherished beliefs to his ultimate redemption.'' Mr. Bailey's book will come before a widely anticipated book about Ms. Palin, ''The Rogue,'' by the author and the journalist Joe McGinniss, which is expected to be released by Crown in September. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MAGUIRE--Arthur Thomas, of Harrison, NY died on April, 17 2011. Born February 13, 1930 to Elizabeth Wall and Arthur Maguire of the Bronx. He married his beloved Nina Iannotti, September 5, 1955, they shared 55 glorious years together. Survived by his wife, Nina and three children; Arthur and wife Mary, James and wife Francine, Regina and husband Kevin Moynihan; brother John and wife Mary Jane. Pre-deceased by his eldest daughter Elizabeth Anne and brothers James Peter and David. Loving Grandfather to Matthew, Elizabeth, Kristen, Kaylee, James Pierce, Caitlin, Teagan and Finn. A proud graduate of Fordham Prep '47, University '51 and Law School '56. An avid runner during his early years, he was New York City champ in the 400 and 800 yard. He served his country as a Second Lieutenant in the United States Army during the Korean War and was honorably discharged in 1953. A gifted Tax Attorney, he was Head of the International Tax Division for WR Grace where he worked for over 30 years before his retirement. Wake will be held Tuesday at the Coxe and Graziano Funeral Home, 767 E. Boston Post Rd., Mamaroneck, NY from 2-4 and 7-9pm. BURRIS--Ruth Ellen, (nee McQuiston), 80, beloved wife for 55 years of James E. Burris, M.D., died peacefully in her sleep and surrounded by family on April 16 after a long and difficult illness. Formerly of White Plains, New York, she was, for the past ten years, a full-time resident and devoted community leader in her much beloved Town of Madison, Connecticut where she spent her happiest days with family and friends. Ruth received her Bachelor of Arts degree from Mount Holyoke College and her Master's Degree from Manhattanville College. She began her professional career as a teacher in the Newton, Massachusetts public school system. Later, after raising her children, she served as an addiction and alcoholism counselor for the State of New York and then went on to support her husband's medical practice as his office manager. She was best known, however, as a steadfast and spirited community leader. Initially supporting her children, she was actively involved in their school districts and served in such capacities as Girl Scout Leader and PTA President. Later, she dedicated herself to the White Plains Hospital Auxiliary in a variety of chairman and officer positions including the Presidency and, as such, held a seat on the Hospital's Board of Directors. She served for four years as Representative of the Northern Metropolitan Region for the Healthcare Association of New York State Committee on Healthcare Auxiliaries and also gave of her time to the YMCA of Central and Northern Westchester, where she was honored with the Community Service Award in 2001. She continued her community work in Madison, serving as President of the Board of Directors for the Madison Ambulance Association; a member of the Board of Directors, Long Range Planning Committee, and the Millennium Fund for the E.C. Scranton Memorial Library; the Board of Directors and Building Committee for the Senior Citizens Commission; Zoning Board of Appeals for the Town of Madison; Board of Corporators and Development Committee for Middlesex Hospital; Treasurer of the Madison Winter Club; as well as Tennis Chair, Follies Chair and Follies Business Manager for the Madison Beach Club, where she was honored to hold the position of Governor for many years. Along with her devoted husband, who was the love of her life, she is survived by six children, Karen Lennon (Michael), of White Plains, Susanne Burris of New York City, Laura Desmarais (John) of Mt. Kisco, NY, James Burris, III (Erin) of Madison, Sara Libonati (Andrew) of Ridgefield, CT and Raymond Burris (Sonia) of New York City. She is also survived by nine grandchildren: Lauren and Katie Lombardi, Jack and Julia Desmarais, James and Jennie Burris, Elisabeth and Andrew Libonati and Raymond Burris II, all of whom brought her tremendous joy. In addition, she is survived by her sister Joan Twiss (Robert) of Craftsbury Common, VT, her brother-in-law John Jay Burris (Dorothy) of Jacksonville, FL, her sister-in-law Pauline Elkins of Wilmington, DE as well as her many adored nieces and nephews from the Burris, Elkins, and Mahon families. She was a treasured in-law and surrogate grandmother to numerous loved ones in the Lennon, Cavanna, Costabile, Blake, Libonati, and Massol families. She was predeceased by two of her life-long friends Myra Mahon, of New York City and Madison, CT who died a few months earlier and Jean Till of Kansas City, KS. An avid gardener, knitter, reader, bird watcher, beachcomber and shopper, she enjoyed all things beautiful, especially when it came to fashion and jewelry. Those who knew her best would describe her as a true force of nature - in complete command of the room, the situation, and her own destiny at all times. A memorial service will be held on Monday, April 25, 11:00am, at The First Congregational Church of Madison, 26 Meeting House Lane, Madison, CT 06443 with a reception to follow. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Middlesex Hospital, c/o Office of Philanthropy, 28 Crescent Street, Middletown, CT 06457, or to the Madison Ambulance Association, 35 Bradley Road, Madison, CT 06443.

On a warm summer afternoon in 2005, Bryant Austin was snorkeling in the blue waters of the South Pacific by the islands of Tonga, looking through his camera at a humpback whale and her calf swimming less than 50 yards away. As he waited for the right moment, the playful calf swam right up to him, so close that he had to lower his camera. That's when he felt a gentle tap on his shoulder. Turning around, Mr. Austin found himself looking straight into the eye of the mother whale, her body bigger than a school bus. The tap had come from her pectoral fin, weighing more than a ton. To Mr. Austin, her gesture was an unmistakable warning that he had gotten too close to the calf. And yet, the mother whale had extended her fin with such precision and grace -- to touch the photographer without hurting him -- that Mr. Austin was in awe of her ''delicate restraint.''

Teenagers are notoriously bad drivers, accounting for 10 times as many crashes as middle-aged ones. But short of keeping them off the road entirely, is there a way to make their driving safer -- for them and for the rest of us? New research suggests that there is. A nationally representative sample of more than 800 crashes involving teenage drivers shows that almost two-thirds were due not to reckless behavior like speeding or joyriding but to three novice driving mistakes: failing to scan the road, misjudging driving conditions, and becoming distracted.

Medicare.gov gets up to 2.8 million visitors a month who use the Web site to do everything from ordering new cards to learning how many problems inspectors found at local nursing homes. Though the information it provides is comprehensive and valuable, the section was ''hard to navigate and hard to read,'' said Brian Smart, account manager for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.

DAITCH--Hilda F.,95, passed away peacefully at her home in Rye Brook, NY on April 17, 2011. Beautiful and beloved wife of Herbert B. Daitch for 75 years. Gracious and loving wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother and mother-in-law to Herbert, Sandra, Larry, Susan, Jimmy, Meinar and Murray. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY Wednesday, April 20 at 12:00 noon. Shiva to be observed at the home of Herbert B. Daitch, 33 Doral Greens Dr. West, Rye Brook, NY following funeral service and 7-10pm, Thursday 1-4pm and 7-10pm.

HOLLANDER--Dr. Vincent Paul, distinguished cancer researcher, died at his home in New York City last Thursday. He was 93. Dr. Hollander made important contributions to the understanding of the fundamental behavior of cancers including breast cancer, prostate cancer, leukemia and lymphomas, and elaborated their favorable response to treatment with various hormones. After serving as a Captain in the Air Force during the Korean War, he became the American Cancer Society Professor at the University of Virginia. He was a Founding Director of the Research Institute at the Hospital for Joint Diseases in New York City and was Professor of Medicine at the Mt. Sinai Medical School. For many years he served as a volunteer for the American Cancer Society research programs. He graduated from the Stuyvesant High School, New York City, and remained a strong supporter of its academic programs. His singing abilities, although never professionally recognized, continued to delight his friends and family. In addition to his wife Ina Kahn Hollander, he is survived by his sons Tom and Vincent Jr, daughters Lucille and Marie, stepson Mikah and two grandchildren, Eric and Michael.

How much personal information about you is available online? You might be surprised — and you might want at least some of it to disappear. On April 21, secessionist William B. Gulick, a clerk in the Interior Department, wrote North Carolina Gov. John W. Ellis to inform him about the precarious state of affairs in Washington. There’s no disputing the socialite bona fides of Maggie Betts, the daughter of the film producer and Chelsea Piers developer Roland Betts and a fixture of Gotham’s party scene. But Betts, a 36-year-old Princeton graduate, is also a passionate advocate for AIDS awareness in Africa who has spent long periods on the continent bearing witness to the epidemic. Her first film, “The Carrier,” which premieres Thursday as part of the Tribeca Film Festival, is the culmination of five years of research. The documentary tells the story of a Zambian woman, Mutinta Mweemba, who tries desperately not to pass on her HIV infection to her unborn child. Here, Betts is interviewed by the designer Prabal Gurung, her good friend and the recently appointed Goodwill Ambassador for the nonprofit group Maiti Nepal.

The Coach Duffle bag, which was designed in the 1970s by Bonnie Cashin, is just the sort of no-logo, no-hardware, no-nonsense bag that no one is making anymore. Not even Coach, which saw fit to put this workhorse out to pasture in 1997. But starting June 15, Net-a-Porter is bringing back the Duffle, as well as four other seminal styles from that era, as the Coach Classics collection. Fans of the original will notice only one minor adjustment: an ad for Neiman Marcus in The Dallas Morning News from the ’70s listed the Duffle for $36. This summer it will set you back $398.

We are not just eating a steak, or an omelet, when our fork lands, tines down, into our food. We, as conscious consumers, are eating all of the resources it took to raise that cow and transport those eggs from farm to fork. So, as trends go, it is somewhat encouraging, if not a bit beguiling, to see such a rudimentary ingredient as hay (yes, plain old barnyard hay) begin to appear on menus around the country, as well as Europe. We have effectively cut out the middleman (the ruminant cow) and gone straight to the pasture.

Downtown mainstays including Philip Glass, Laurie Anderson, Patti Smith, Rufus Wainwright and Sean Lennon, and – straight from the Battle of Agincourt – Henry V will all be part of the 10th River to River Festival, the annual celebration of arts in lower Manhattan, its organizers said on Wednesday. The festival of free events, which runs from June 19 through July 16, will begin with the Bang on a Can Marathon at the World Financial Center Winter Garden, with performances by Mr. Glass, top, with the Bang on a Can All-Stars. The Castle Clinton National Monument in Battery Park will host concerts featuring Vijay Iyer (on June 23); Ms. Anderson, above, with Bill Laswell (June 30); and Ms. Smith (July 14). Rockefeller Park will be the setting of a June 22 tribute to the Bottom Line, featuring Rosanne Cash, Dar Williams and Marshall Crenshaw. Mr. Wainwright and soloists from the New York City Opera will perform excerpts from his opera “Prima Donna” at the World Financial Center Winter Garden on June 28. Mr. Lennon’s band the Ghost of a Saber Tooth Tiger will perform at the Seaport on June 24. And New York Classical Theater will present a two-castle production of Shakespeare‘s “Henry V” at Castle Clinton in Battery Park and Castle William on Governors Island (with free ferry service between the locations). A complete schedule and other information can be found at the festival’s Web site, rivertorivernyc.com.

The United States Department of Transportation is set to announce new regulations designed to protect air passengers. “Although the rules do not set limits on how much carriers can charge for items like bags, ticket changes and seats,” Susan Stellin writes, “they do require airlines to more clearly disclose these and other fees in advertisements and on their Web sites. As a rule, digging beneath the surface of modern Rome turns up ancient buildings. Excavations conducted in 2007, just steps from the traffic hub of Piazza Venezia, revealed two Imperial era villas embellished with mosaics, polychrome wall veneers, fountains and frescoes. Dating back to the second and third centuries, these opulent dwellings were abandoned in late antiquity, filled with landfill, and unknowingly used as foundations for the 16th-century Palazzo Valentini, now seat of the Province of Rome’s offices.

The cast of ''The Dark Knight Rises,'' Christopher Nolan's third and final entry in his series of Batman movies, is looking increasingly like the cast of his 2010 summer blockbuster ''Inception,'' with Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Marion Cotillard now officially on board for that superhero film. Warner Brothers Pictures said on Tuesday that Mr. Gordon-Levitt, who played one of Leonardo DiCaprio's dream-invading accomplices in ''Inception,'' will play John Blake, a Gotham City beat cop, in ''The Dark Knight Rises''; Ms. Cotillard, who played Mr. DiCaprio's enigmatic wife in ''Inception,'' has been cast as Miranda Tate, a board member at Wayne Enterprises who is allied with Bruce Wayne. Tom Hardy, another member of the ''Inception'' gang, was previously announced to play the villain Bane, and Michael Caine, who had a brief role in that film (or did he? No, wait, he did) has played the butler Alfred in all of Mr. Nolan's Bat-films. In a statement, Mr. Nolan said: ''When you collaborate with people as talented as Marion and Joe, it comes as no surprise that you would want to repeat the experience. I immediately thought of them for the roles of Miranda and Blake, and I am looking forward to working with both of them again.''

Martin's best-selling ''Song of Ice and Fire'' novels and produced by David Benioff and D. B. Weiss.
