In the pantheon of fantasy and science-fiction projects that Joss Whedon helped create, the Internet musical ''Dr. Horrible's Sing-Along Blog'' can be easy to overlook: it's not his beloved television series that ran a healthy seven seasons (''Buffy the Vampire Slayer''), or its beloved spinoff (''Angel''), or his misunderstood television show that was canceled before its time (''Dollhouse'') or his other misunderstood television show that was canceled before its time and spawned a misunderstood movie (''Firefly'' and ''Serenity''). ''Dr. Horrible'' is simply a three-act musical about an aspiring super-villain (played by Neil Patrick Harris), his smug do-gooding nemesis (Nathan Fillion) and the woman who comes between them (Felicia Day). Dreamed up by Mr. Whedon, his brothers Zack and Jed, and Maurissa Tancharoen during the 2007-8 writers' strike and produced on his own dime, it is the pure expression of what they wanted to make at the time, without any outside interference. For that reason alone, ''Dr. Horrible'' holds a special place in Mr. Whedon's heart. (Another sign of his affection: he made time to talk to about it when he really should have been preparing to direct his superhero mega-movie ''The Avengers.'') In these excerpts from a recent conversation, Mr. Whedon spoke to ArtsBeat about the making of the musical, its recently released companion volume ''Dr Horrible's Sing-Along Blog: The Book'' and his future online ambitions. (O.K., so we asked about ''Avengers,'' too.)Q.How are you?A.I am super-tired. I just have insomnia, so I'm like, [zombie voice] ''Uhhhh. Prepping.'' Q.It's been almost three years since ''Dr. Horrible'' was first released. What does it mean to you now?A.It means, what the hell have we been doing? Where's the damn sequel? The shame. Mostly that. And it remains one of the purest experiences of my life. It just makes me happy all the time. It wasn't like anything else.Q.As much as the project was initiated by the writers' strike, was it also in some way an acknowledgment that you couldn't produce something like ''Dr. Horrible'' anywhere but on the Web?A.My ideas are always slightly left-of-center. I like to think that I'm a populist entertainer, but I'm a little bit idiosyncratic and sometimes the networks wouldn't really roll with that. I was trying to - this was during the strike - make a deal with a big Internet company that had expressed interest in doing some low-budget production, and I laid out these ideas that I had, that I thought they might be interested in, the last of which was ''Dr. Horrible.'' I said, ''And here's the one you're definitely not going to want to do.'' And they said, ''Yes. We don't.'' It became clear that nothing was going to happen with this company before the strike was over. So I got more and more obsessed with ''Dr. Horrible'' and asked my wife, ''Honey, would it be O.K. if-'' And she said, ''Hells yeah.'' We just eliminated the middle man. Or actually, the top man.Q.This was totally financed out of your own pocket?A.Mm-hmm. I'm like, hey, you know what? Some mid-life crises are cars. They cost about this much. Mine has songs in it.Q.I was amazed to see, in the book, your original handwritten lyrics to ''My Freeze Ray,'' which contain no crossed-out words, changes or even misspellings. Did all the songs emerge from your head fully-formed like Athena?A.I'm shocked about the misspelling thing. And yes, it was fully-armored. But I usually write things in my head before I ever write them down. When I write it out, usually I've already figured out what it is I'm trying to do. Sometimes I'll forget to write them down, and then I'll be like, ''Here's how this song goes: Uh. I don't remember.'' I'm that organized. Also, it's a pretty simple lyric. There are other song sheets with many scribble-outs. But that one just sort of formed in my head pretty quickly. Not quickly enough. It was actually more painful than that page would express.Q.Were there other numbers that were written but didn't make it to the final cut?A.I don't think there were, because we didn't want to write anything extra. When I first thought of ''Dr. Horrible'' I had worked on a couple of other songs that didn't make it - I didn't even pitch them to the other writers because they didn't work in the structure we'd come up with. There wasn't a lot of ''Well, what if?'' We wrote exactly what we wanted to say and as many songs as we could, knowing exactly where, structurally, they had to go. We were going to cut up some of my endless monologue for Neil, or at least intercut it with things, but he just rocked that one take so well. And we liked the idea people would be settling into the idea of a guy doing a blog when the first musical number started that we ended up leaving it.Q.Was Wonderflonium, the mystery material that Dr. Horrible wants to steal, the most ridiculous name you had heard of before you saw ''Avatar''?A.[laughs] Ah. The thing in ''Avatar'' was also in ''The Core'' so let us give ''The Core'' its credit. ''Avatar'' was not the first to come up with Unobtanium. However, I believe Zack first referred to the mysterious substance as Bananatonium. So Wonderflonium was our nod to real science. It's more grounded.Q.When you look at the success of ''Glee,'' do you feel like that couldn't have happened without things like the ''Buffy'' musical episode ''Once More, With Feeling''?A.No, but boy am I going to tell people that now. I'm going to run that theory up a flagpole. There's other things like ''High School Musical'' that were more influential. However, let's just say I invented television and leave it at that.Q.You don't feel you've played any role in -A.Legitimizing musicals on TV? Maybe. Before ''Once More, With Feeling,'' you couldn't not say ''Cop Rock.'' Nobody was giving it cred, so there is an element of, Oh, it's cool now. That wasn't there. Was I a snowflake in the avalanche? Yes, I was. Am I going to take credit for the whole thing? Possibly not.Q.There have been performances of ''Dr. Horrible'' at conventions - has it been licensed for schools and other stage productions?A.We did a little agreement, and many schools and some professional troupes have done it around the country. We actually had to put a pause on it, because people were starting to sell DVDs and stuff, so we had to figure out more complex legal language, which hopefully we'll be done with soon. Obviously, we love the idea that people and schools are doing it, but if people are making money off it, then we go, ''Hmmm, wait a minute. Isn't there a rule about this?''Q.What about producing it Off Broadway? Or even on Broadway?A.We have spoken of that much. Especially every time Jed comes back from New York - ''We've just got to do it! Come on, we just write some more songs to make these longer!'' Because some of us have sat through ''Spider-Man.''Q.Does that include you?A.[after a pause] I neither confirm nor deny. And you kind of go, ''Hey, let's do something for no money.'' Which is the same feeling we had about TV and movies when we made ''Dr. Horrible.'' But I would say my heart is more in the idea of the sequel. We've done a lot of work on it.Q.Really?A.Oh, yeah. We've got several songs near completion and we've got a very specific structure. We've just all got jobs. And it's not like Neil, Nathan and Felicia ain't busy either. We get together at Christmas and family occasions, and then play each other our partial songs and go, ''Yup, that's still exactly as it was the last time we played it. We're great.'' It's bad.Q.Is there anything you can say yet about what the ''Dr. Horrible'' sequel will be?A.It's going to be ''Dr. Horrible and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull.'' And it's going to be just as good as the other one. I don't know why people are upset about that title. And by the way, by the time we finish it, Neil will be just as old. No, I'm not saying anything.Q.You've had otherprojects that ended, perhaps, in ways you didn't want them to, or before you wanted them to-A.I'm sure I don't know what you mean.Q.-so after something like ''Dr. Horrible,'' are you ever tempted to chuck it all and only produce things for the Internet?A.I'm more than tempted. I'm a little obsessed. And after ''Dr. Horrible,'' I thought, well, somebody will come around. I talked at great length and planned at great length the idea of a portal and putting shows together, having an Internet identity and starting my own little micro-studio. Nobody in town was interested, and then by the time they were, ''Avengers'' came around. I was and will continue to work on a very, very different Internet mini-thing that I was writing with Warren Ellis, and I have a lot of ideas for things I want to put up there. I still believe it's a viable financial model, and a creative playground and I miss it. But in the year that I was supposed to do that, I instead decided to make this little Sundance movie that I'm making.Q.I certainly hope you find distribution for it.A.You know, I'm looking at the Independent Film Channel very closely. Knock wood.Q.Did you happen to keep up with the March Madness tournament on io9.com, in which readers voted ''Serenity'' the top fantasy film of all time, over ''The Empire Strikes Back''?A.I have been alerted to this fact by certain of my friends. When I saw us going up against ''Empire Strikes Back,'' all I could think was, ''Oh, they're gonna hate it. They're gonna hate us. They're gonna call our fans names.'' But while ''Empire Strikes Back'' is for me the more seminal film, ''Serenity'' at least has an ending. I don't know when ''The Matrix'' got voted down - that's my favorite. It is starting to be a double-edged sword. There's no greater sadness than not still being on board that ship with that crew, in my career. All I can think is, maybe someday, someone at Universal will say, ''Hey, we made money. Let's do that again.'' So I'm glad that it lives. But I also know that every time it gets in one of those polls, against beloved movies, we just get flamed. I feel sad, too.Q.It's like being a parent, and letting your child find its way in the world.A.I can't control how beautiful and popular my child is. What can I do?Q.Since there's not much you can discuss about ''Avengers'' right now, what can you tell me about the status of your long-awaited horror film ''The Cabin in the Woods''?A.I know that MGM is talking to people about it. Because MGM is, Everything must go - they've lost their lease. And I believe that there is some interest from other companies in acquiring it and distributing it. More than that, I cannot say, but I have hope that ''Avengers'' may not be the only thing I get to put out next year.Q.Can you say when you start production on ''Avengers''?A.We're just a hardscrabble bunch. Guerilla filmmaking. I start production a week from Monday. I'm going to get started on the script now. Apparently that's a thing. I don't get it. Improv stunts are always way more exciting-looking.

Bijan Pakzad, the ritzy fashion designer whose by-appointment-only Rodeo Drive boutique is billed as ''the most expensive store in the world,'' died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 71. Mr. Pakzad had a stroke on Thursday and was admitted to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, his company said in a statement.

ABBATE--William S.,74, of Boca Raton, FL passed away April 19, 2011. He was the beloved husband for 23 years to Susan P. Abbate, son of Frances C. Abbate, loving father to Frances Jacks and her husband Louis Jacks, her children Michelle, Louis and Amanda; Ronald Abbate and his children Jackie Abbate Wood; Doreen, Debra, Christopher and Robert; Lisa McLoughlin and her children, Joseph, Christopher and Daniel and great-grandchild, Madison. Daughter-in-law Ann Abbate; brother Ronald Abbate; sister-in-law Doris Abbate. Bill was President and CEO of Structural Display Inc. taken over from his father Ronald Abbate. With his charm, wit and determination he brought the company up to a multi-million dollar business with innovative design, a great manufacturing facility with the best employees he could find. He treated his staff with kindness and generosity. Many stayed at SDI for several years since it became a second home. Bill was very interested in antique cars and was a member of many cars clubs. His last car was a 1932 Packard Roadster Coupe which he sold only a few days prior to passing. He and his wife Susan also enjoyed boating and took several trips before his health deteriorated. He traveled with Susan to many countries, but after 9/11 decided to see more of America. They tried to visit as many states as possible and enjoyed meeting people along the way. He was the life of every party and loved to dance, tell jokes with various dialects making everyone laugh until their sides hurt. He was always the first to help his family and circle of friends - always lending a helping hand with no strings attached. If there was story on the news about someone having hard times, he was always the first to call the station with a donation. The lady who had no place to live, a veteran who tried to keep afloat, a clinic that needed donations to keep going, all the major charities were recipients of extremely large donations. If a church needed a chalice, he would always send them a check. He was larger than life and this gentle soul touched the lives of everyone privileged to know him. He will be greatly missed. Donations in his memory can be made to the American Heart Association and the American Lung Association. Services will be Thursday, April 21, 2011 at 11:00am at the Gardens Memorial Park, 4103 N. Military Trail, Boca Raton, 33431, 561-989-9190. Services by Riverside-Gordon-Kendall.

SYRIA At least two people died in Homs, the country's third largest city, when the police and army cleared a square where protesters had been determined to stage an Egyptian-style sit-in, witnesses said. Hours later, the government tried to placate the protesters with declarations of sweeping reforms. YEMEN Security forces fired on a demonstration in the central city of Taiz, killing one protester and wounding two others, according to witnesses, while in Sana, the capital, a protester died in a clashes with security forces and plainclothes government supporters. Meanwhile, government officials met in Abu Dhabi with officials from a six-nation regional bloc, the Gulf Cooperation Council, that is seeking to broker an end to the political crisis.

The Nasdaq OMX Group and the IntercontinentalExchange disclosed full terms of their unsolicited $11.1 billion takeover bid for NYSE Euronext on Tuesday, including a breakup fee, in their strongest effort yet to win over shareholders in the operator of the Big Board. The proposed 67-page merger agreement released by Nasdaq and ICE is meant to counter NYSE Euronext's concerns about their earlier proposal, which was rejected for being ''loosely worded'' and ''highly conditional.''

NEW YORK An article on Tuesday about the connection between the Mafia and the culinary arts practiced by Italian-Americans that is reflected in a mob trial under way in United States District Court in Brooklyn misstated the middle initial of the presiding judge. He is Nicholas G. Garaufis, not C.

PARIS -- Since his first season as director of the venerable Théâtre du Châtelet in 2006, Jean-Luc Choplin has been seeking to marry the sophisticated with the popular, the daring with the safe. It has meant bringing in a gospel choir from the South African township of Soweto to sing Mozart's ''Magic Flute''; a Russian video artist to stage the Mozart version of Handel's ''Messiah''; Plácido Domingo to star in the classic ''Cyrano de Bergerac''; and the British alternative band Gorillaz with its opera, ''Monkey: Journey to the West,'' sung in Chinese.

Three new productions in New York have announced weeks-long extensions. ''Sleep No More,'' an interactive theater piece by the British company Punchdrunk that is performed throughout three renovated warehouses on West 27th Street, has extended through June 25. Ben Brantley called the piece, in which audience members wear masks while exploring some 100 rooms and environments, ''a voyeur's delight, with all the creepy, shameful pleasures that entails.'' Two well-reviewed Off Broadway shows have been extended through May 7: the Keen Company's revival of Michael Frayn's drama ''Benefactors,'' at the Clurman Theater, and Soho Rep's production of Debbie Tucker Green's play ''Born Bad.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
ARTS The Critics' Choice column on Tuesday, about new CDs, misidentified the record label that released the album ''Whokill'' by Tune-Yards. It is 4AD, not Matador.

The Metropolitan Opera, after saying its tour this June to Japan was in jeopardy because of safety concerns, announced on Tuesday that it would go ahead with the trip. Peter Gelb, the Met's general manager, said in a message to the company that its decision was based on a recent advisory from the State Department that ''health and safety risks'' outside of a 50-mile radius around the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant ''are low and do not pose significant risks.'' The State Department had previously urged United States citizens to defer travel to Japan. The decision also took into account ''official and scientific reports that the areas around Tokyo and Nagoya are safe,'' Mr. Gelb said. The company plans to perform in both places. The three-week tour has its first performance on June 4 and will be the first by the Met to Japan since 2006, its seventh there over all. Mr. Gelb added that the Met would continue to keep track of the situation. ''If it should worsen, we will re-evaluate,'' he said, adding that an expert, Dr. David Brenner, who is the director of the Center for Radiological Research at Columbia University Medical Center, would visit the Met next week to answer questions. Mr. Gelb listed other countries that have lifted travel advisories and arts groups that were moving ahead with plans to go to Japan.

NATIONAL The On Education column on Monday, about leaders of the public school ''reform movement'' who attended private schools, misstated the name of the advocacy group founded by one such leader, the former Washington, D.C., schools chancellor Michelle A. Rhee. It is StudentsFirst, not Sunshine First. The column also misstated the name of the organization founded by Whitney Tilson, a hedge fund manager and Democratic fund-raiser. It is Democrats for Education Reform, not Democrats for Educational Reform. In addition, the article misspelled the given name of the chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents. She is Merryl Tisch, not Merryll Tisch.

Iacopo Falai is on the move again, and will open Bottega Falai on Thursday at 7 a.m., steps from Caffe Falai. Done in his trademark shiny white mosaic tile and glittering chandeliers, the shop is stocked with mostly Italian products, like dried porcini, sea salts, herbs and spices, excellent Mancini pasta and olive oils. A selection of cheeses and cured meats, breads, produce, prepared foods like sandwiches and the pastries for which Mr. Falai is known will also be sold. A few tables are available for a snack on the spot, but most of the food is to take away. A couple of weeks ago, he also doubled the size of his cafe by taking over an adjacent storefront and adding more seats and a full bar, also done in white tile and sparkle. And for his new Italian cocktail menu, you can watch his bartenders weigh the ingredients for your drink on little scales for better accuracy.

SCIENCE An article on April 12 about eating disorders among young Orthodox Jewish women erroneously attributed a distinction to the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, which issues the O.U. kashrut stamp for food. It is the largest organization that handles kashrut certification; it is not the only one.
$4.75 MILLION 469 Atlantic Avenue (between Nevins Street and Third Avenue)

OBITUARIES Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about the Nobel Prize-winning chemist William N. Lipscomb Jr. misstated the universities where Linus Pauling, with whom Dr. Lipscomb had worked, taught. Dr. Pauling taught at the California Institute of Technology, the University of California at San Diego and Stanford University; he did not teach at Harvard.

BLOOM--Dorothy J. (nee Rosenberg), our mother, passed away April 19 after a brief illness. Dorothy was predeceased by the love of her life Herbert H. Bloom and devoted daughter Barbara Bloom. She is survived by her sister Georgette Bloom, her loving daughters Pat Comerford (Vincent) and Joan Frederick (Bob), adored grandchildren Ross, Jay, Carolyn, Hallie, great-grandmother to Lexi, "Uncle" to Jon and Jim Bloom, and many loving friends. We thank every nurse at White Plains Hospital for their gentle care. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, please give to the charity of your choice.

The conservative columnist and author Ann Coulter has vowed to ''take on the liberal mob'' in her new book, ''Demonic,'' whose publication was announced on Tuesday. The book is scheduled for release on June 7 by Crown Forum, part of Random House. The publisher says Ms. Coulter will address topics including ''the Democratic Party's coddling of violent mobs,'' the ''false history of civil rights given by the media'' and the ''truth about the original Tea Party.'' Ms. Coulter's last book, ''Guilty,'' spent nine weeks on The New York Times best-seller list. According to Nielsen BookScan, which tracks roughly 75 percent of retail sales, it sold 121,000 copies in hardcover and 16,000 in paperback. Crown Forum's authors include former Senator Fred Thompson, Joe Scarborough and George F. Will. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

STRONGIN--Ned. Co-Inventor of Connect Four died on April 9, 2011 at almost 92. He was a renowned independent toy designer, who worked with all of the major Toy Companies over several decades. Though Connect Four remains his biggest success, he was involved in designing many other items, including Weebles ("Wobble But They Don't Fall Down"). He was a great businessman, husband, father and grandfather.

Gummy Swedish fish, it turns out, have lots of company. Sockerbit, a new shop, has a vast and colorful collection of at least 139 other kinds of chewy, melty, jellied, sticky, crackly, nubbly, gooey and otherwise alluring little candies from Sweden. They are all on display in bins, sold by the pound and set off by the whiteness of this Swedish candy store. It's owned by Stefan Ernberg, from Sweden, and his wife, Florence Baras (she is from Argentina). The name, Ms. Baras said, means ''sugar cube'' in Swedish and she pointed out the dense, square little marshmallow, white with rounded corners, that looks like a sugar cube, as the icon. Each little bin gives a brief description of the candy it contains. Fruit and chocolate flavors dominate, and licorice lovers will be in heaven.
EISENSTEIN--Rita, on April 18, 2011, of cancer. Sister-in-law of Bonnie Brand Eisenstein, aunt of David and Michael Eisenstein. Donations can be made to the American Cancer Society.

The N.F.L. released the 2011 schedule Tuesday, but perhaps it should be written in pencil. With a lockout having shut down the league since March 12, and owners and players battling in court and at the negotiating table, there is no guarantee that the two most recent Super Bowl champions - the New Orleans Saints and the defending champion Green Bay Packers - will open the season as scheduled on Thursday, Sept. 8, in Green Bay.

The Disney Channel star Demi Lovato is leaving her popular television show, ''Sonny With a Chance,'' the channel confirmed Tuesday. ''I don't think going back to 'Sonny' would be healthy for my recovery,'' Ms. Lovato told People magazine. ''Being in front of a camera would make me nervous.''

PINES--Ethel Schnall. June 23, 1919-April 18, 2011. Beloved mother of Alice Seidman (Stanley), Wayne Pines (Carol), Larry Pines (Joyce). Survived also by seven grandsons and five great-grandchildren. Dedicated her life to education, retired as assistant principal in New York City school system.

For many, Grete Waitz, the nine-time New York City Marathon champion who became synonymous with the race, was much more than a world- class athlete. In the hours after her death Tuesday, they shared their recol- lections of chance meetings with Waitz, on and off the course, describing her humility, acts of generosity and mo- ments of inspiration. Here are some of them, edited and condensed. In the early 1980s, as a young high school girl in rural America, I ran because I was lonely. I ran because I didn't fit in. I ran be- cause I really didn't know what else to do. I used my newspaper route money and pur- chased a subscription to a running maga- zine to follow Grete. I didn't have the natu- ral talent and grace that she possessed, but I did well enough that I felt as though I had become a part of something good. I give thanks for her example during a time when it was really needed. Still Running, Michigan

Charles Isherwood's Theater Talkback post last week, about the dearth of good musical theater voices, was prompted by what he called the ''vocally vacuous'' concert version of ''Company'' staged by the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Isherwood wrote that for most of the evening, ''accomplished singing was all but absent.'' The post generated some emotional responses. ''I love beautiful, powerful singing voices,'' wrote one reader. ''I won't support any musical that doesn't employ them.''
ROGALIN--Wilma Clare (nee Sivertsen), born December 7, 1916; deceased April 17, 2011. Services at Pound Ridge Community Church, Pound Ridge, NY, on Monday, April 25, 2011, at 10:00am.

A year ago, the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig exploded, gushing nearly five million barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico before it was finally capped three months later. It was by most accounts a disaster. But when it comes to wrecking our oceans, the accidental BP spill was small compared with the damage we do with intent and ignorance. I recently talked about this with two men who specialize in ocean affairs: Carl Safina, the author of ''A Sea In Flames'' and the president of the Blue Ocean Institute; and Ted Danson, (yes, that Ted Danson), who recently published Oceana (the book) and is a board member of Oceana, the conservation organization he helped found. As Safina said, ''Many people believe the whole catastrophe is the oil we spill, but that gets diluted and eventually disarmed over time. In fact, the oil we don't spill, the oil we collect, refine and use, produces CO2 and other gases that don't get diluted.''

An article last Wednesday about the San Pellegrino World's 50 Best Restaurants list quoted incorrectly from comments by Lars Peder Hedberg, the chairman of one of the regional juries that select the restaurants. He said he had told Swedish tourism officials that, to promote Swedish restaurants for inclusion on the list, they should invite regional chairmen and journalists on free trips to try the restaurants; he did not say that the journalists invited should be limited to those who are jurors for the list. The article also misstated the number of jurors whom the Swedish tourism bureau brought on an all-expenses-paid trip to eat at several of the country's leading restaurants in 2010. There were 8, not 11. (The 3 other guests were not jurors.) The article also omitted two countries included in the regional jury led by Mr. Hedberg. They are Denmark and Norway, in addition to Sweden. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the surname of a regional chairman who said he had accepted a free trip from Swedish tourism officials. He is Steve Dolinsky, not Dolinksy.

The last time Judy Garland was on Broadway, it was August 1967 and she was back at the Palace Theater performing some of her greatest standards: ''The Trolley Song,'' ''The Man That Got Away,'' and, of course, ''Over the Rainbow.'' Over the 20 months that followed, Garland moved to London, had a five-week nightclub stand, married Mickey Deans and struggled with the pill addiction that would lead to her fatal drug overdose in June 1969. Now the producers of ''End of the Rainbow,'' a popular London play with music about Garland's final months, are aiming to return her (as a character) and those numbers and more to Broadway in the spring of 2012.

DI BARI--Angelo, on April 16, 2011. Beloved husband of Brenda. Devoted father of Gabriella, Veronica, Isabella, Donato and twins Francesca and Angelina. Dear son of Donato and Angela Maria. Loving brother of Maddalena. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, New York City. Friends may call Thursday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. For online condolences visit us at: perazzofuneralhome.com

INTERNATIONAL An article on April 6 about a telephone invitation to visit Israel from Israel's interior minister, Eli Yishai, to Richard Goldstone, the jurist who led a United Nations panel accusing Israel of possible war crimes in Gaza but who recently recanted some of its harshest conclusions, misstated Mr. Goldstone's response in some copies. Mr. Goldstone accepted the invitation; he did not say, as Mr. Yishai originally told Israel's Army Radio, that he also agreed to work to annul the panel's report. (Mr. Yishai corrected his account of the conversation after the article was published.)

The battle for the New York Stock Exchange appears to be a natural outcome of the global capital markets. Citing competitive pressures as exchanges around the world consolidate, Nasdaq OMX and a partner, the IntercontinentalExchange, are trying to break up a proposed tie-up between NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Borse by offering 19 percent more.

I still wouldn't eat the food. It's all the same people working there, but they have hats now. KELLY JOHNSTON, a senior at Pace University, where a cafeteria has reopened under a new manager after health violations. [A20]

POWERS--Seymour, a true business pioneer in the greater Danbury, CT area, whose accomplishments made him a legend in the development of commercial real estate, attracting fortune 500 companies and creating vast numbers of employment opportunities through his own, Commerce Park, numerous industrial business properties and his overall contribution to the prosperity of the business community of Danbury for over 50 years, passed away at the age of 92 in his home in Boca Raton, Florida on Monday, April 18, 2011. His prominence as a captain of Industry and Real Estate was equaled only by his philanthropic endeavors. A leading contributor and fundraiser for Ben Gurion University, an ardent supporter of Israel, Mr. Powers served as a past chairman of the UJA, and member of the King David Society. Seymour Powers was a recipient of the 1999 Cecil J. Previdi Award and was awarded an Honorary Doctorate for his efforts with Ben Gurion University. He was honored for his philanthropy, his commitment to the Jewish community and the Zionist cause, as well as for his ongoing support of the University. Seymour and his wife, Alice, established the Alice and Seymour Powers Joint Israel-Russia Laboratory for Energy Research and the Alice and Seymour Powers Career Development Chair in Basic and Clinical Oncology. In addition to playing an active role in the development of the Southeast Region of the AABGU, he was also the recipient of the BGU Negev Award, amongst many others. An avid sailor and yachtsman, having served in WWII in the Navy training other personnel in Radar, Seymour built and enjoyed the boat of his dreams, The Prime Rate IV. He is survived by his loving wife, Alice Powers, his children: Garry, Melvyn, Stuart, Nancy and Sandee; his grandchildren: Melissa, Lauren, Alicia, Holly, Mia, Ana, Maxx, Joshua, Justin and Jordan; and great-grandchildren: Ben, Noah, Talia, Mason, Luca and Olive; and his sister, Sylvia Malvin of Boca Raton, Florida. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, April 21, at 11am, in Rubin Memorial Chapel, 7340 Boynton Beach Blvd in Boynton Beach, Florida, 561-496-3000. After the memorial, a processional with interment services will follow at Eternal Light Memorial Garden.

KONO--Bella, 101 years young, after a brief illness, passed away on April 19. Beautiful and beloved mother to Roberta Geula (David), Carl Kono (Jean), Harvey (deceased) Kono (Francine). She also leaves ten grandchildren, Marc, Eric, Evan, Jon, Amberly, Susan, Jacob, Jessica, Nicole and Monica, and eleven great-grandchildren. She was proud of her work as a Board Member of Long Beach Hospital for more than 25 years. Rest in peace mom with your beloved husband Jack. Burial will be graveside 11am on Thursday, April 21, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Friends welcome Thursday April 21, 4-7pm at 254 East 68 St. apartment 17F. Shiva April 27, 4-7pm at same address.

DAITCH--Hilda F.,95, passed away peacefully at her home in Rye Brook, NY on April 17, 2011. Beautiful and beloved wife of Herbert B. Daitch for 75 years. Gracious and loving wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother and mother-in-law to Herbert, Sandra, Larry, Susan, Jimmy, Meinar and Murray. Daitch, 33 Doral Greens Dr. West, Rye Brook, NY following funeral service and 7-10pm, Thursday 1-4pm and 7-10pm.

FRONT PAGE A picture credit on March 15, with a photograph of soldiers evacuating a victim from the earthquake and tsunami in Japan, misstated the name of the newspaper whose photographer took the picture, based on information from The Associated Press. It is Yomiuri Shimbun, not Shiyo. The same erroneous credit, which resulted from a computer problem at The A.P., was also published with a different picture on March 17, showing the northern port city of Kamaishi the day after the tsunami. (This correction was delayed by difficulties in determining the source of the error.)

MILAN -- Pietro Ferrero, who with his brother ran Ferrero, the family-owned producer of Nutella, Tic Tacs, Ferrero Rocher and other sweets sold worldwide, died on Monday while riding a bicycle in South Africa. He was 47. The company said Mr. Ferrero, an avid cyclist, was riding a bike on his usual training run on a road in Cape Town when he fell off. The company gave no other details.

SABNANI--Raj ("Ronnie"). We have lost our dear friend of Universal Aero Management Corporation on April 17, 2011. Deeply mourned by family and friends.

GELLER--Daniel 91, died on April 18 in Chapel Hill, NC. Husband for 65 years of Suzanne; father of Jeffrey (Merle Brandzel), Bradley, Matthew (Diana Kingsley); grandfather of Noah, Jesse, Bram, Jamarie, Aubree, Luke. A 1940 graduate of UNC, he served four years in the Army during WWII, discharged as a Captain. He spent his working years in New York at Andrew Geller Shoes, contributing to the success of the family business in retail and manufacturing. Daniel was a champion tennis player, an avid skier, a fine golfer-and he knew his way around a toolbox. Daniel was guided by a sense of fairness and equality. He was an extraordinarily intelligent, caring, well-liked, and quiet man, with a dry sense of humor. We all loved him and will miss him terribly. ''We didn't need dialogue! We had faces!'' The famous lines spoken by Gloria Swanson's decrepit silent-movie goddess Norma Desmond sprang to mind the other night at Avery Fisher Hall during the New York Philharmonic's concert version of ''Company.'' I imagined there might be a few old-time Broadway performers in the audience muttering similar sentiments to themselves as they watched Lonny Price's vocally vacuous presentation of the Stephen Sondheim-George Furth musical. ''Back in my day, we had voices!'' I could picture one seething through his or her teeth to a colleague at intermission. Patti LuPone's powerhouse, this-is-how-it's-done-kids performance of her big solo, the show's celebrated ''Ladies Who Lunch,'' seemed infused with determination to give the aficionados of full-throttle Broadway vocalizing something to cheer about. For much of the rest of the evening, accomplished singing was all but absent, a particular oddity in a production backed by the full forces of a world-class orchestra.

We are all deeply saddened by the loss of Tim Hetherington and Chris Hondros.

In the early 2000s, years before he made “Restrepo,” his Oscar-nominated documentary about an American platoon in Afghanistan, and before his work as a photojournalist had become much of a career at all, Tim Hetherington hunched behind an old-fashioned camera, his head under a cloth, on a war-ravaged street in Monrovia, Liberia. United Nations troops patrolled the city in tanks, keeping a tenuous peace, and the husks of buildings loomed around him, but Tim was posing Monrovians for portraits with this quaint bit of equipment, following some private artistic vision and offering his subjects a strange interval of formality and tranquility amid the city’s menacing anarchy.

Chris Hondros’s photograph of a little girl bloodied and traumatized after her parents were killed by American soldiers with the 25th Infantry Division in a shooting on Jan. 18, 2005, is one of the most unforgettable images to come out of the Iraq war. His photograph transcends any written account of the tragic event. Photographers like Chris put their lives on the line so that we can understand the reality of war through images like this. To view more of his work, take a look at the tribute set up by The Times’s Lens blog.

Pick up a book about a young New York artist these days, and you’re likely to spot Brendan Dugan’s name in the fine print. As the founder of the graphics firm and indie publishing imprint An Art Service, Dugan has become a go-to designer for galleries like Gagosian and Hauser & Wirth, or for virtually anyone in Dan Colen’s crowd. Now he’s slowly making his presence known with Karma (21 Downing Street; open Thursday-Sunday from noon to 7 p.m. or by appointment), a tiny shop in the front of his office where he sells his own catalog of gritty pop-minimalist art books and posters alongside books and objects that inspire him. Dugan started the publishing arm of his business in 2009 as an additional platform for the artists whose Web sites, books and ephemera he was already designing. “Allan Kaprow, Ed Ruscha and a lot of the Fluxus artists were designing all these amazing objects to help support their projects,” he says. “I guess I think of us as trying to help continue that lineage.”

Gary Taubes, the author of last week’s cover story (“Is Sugar Toxic?”) as well as an anti-carb cover story from 2002 (“What If It’s All Been a Big Fat Lie?”) and the book “Why We Get Fat,” has plenty of critics. But no one could accuse him of failing to practice what he preaches. His is a steak-and-egg-heavy diet, without the pasta and potatoes. If you fear for his arteries, you can check out an analysis of his blood lipids posted on his blog. When I talked to Gary this morning, he was in Los Angeles, visiting family for spring break, and (in addition to answering hundreds of sugar-related e-mails) was preparing breakfast: scrambled eggs and bacon for his wife; scrambled eggs, bacon, Italian sausage and black coffee for himself; Cheerios, raisins and Italian sausage for the kids. He did cop to this rare, vacation-related indulgence: last night he ate a chocolate macaroon. It’s Passover, after all. He reports that it was delicious.

The Lyric Opera of Chicago has named a new general director, Anthony Freud, who has been running the Houston Grand Opera for the past five years. Mr. Freud, 53, will take over in the fall for William Mason, 69, the general director since 1997, who said in July he would retire after this season. Mr. Freud, a onetime record company executive and former chairman of the jury for the BBC Cardiff Singer of the World Competition, ran the Welsh National Opera before coming to Houston in 2006. A Londoner, he has become a key insider in the American opera world and is chairman of the Opera America service organization. In Houston, he was credited with increasing attendance and fund-raising; overseeing premieres by Jake Heggie and André Previn; programming a survey of Benjamin Britten operas; and planning for the company’s first “Ring” cycle, which is scheduled for 2014.

“Home Show, Revisited,” opening this month at the Santa Barbara Contemporary Arts Forum in California, puts a new spin on the expression “mi casa, su casa.” Now in its third iteration, the site-specific exhibition pairs 10 Los Angeles artists with 9 area residences, inviting the artists to explore the notion of home. Some of the work, like the circular swimming pool that Piero Golia built in the yard of an updated Spanish-style gem or Jennifer West’s experimental surf films, which will screen at sundown at a Carpinteria surf shack, makes direct references to life in Southern California. Other installations play with personal space: the sculptor Ry Rocklen’s tiled floor piece speaks to the work of the mosaic artist who is hosting him, and Bettina Hubby (above) has created curtains — depicting her “living” inside a Montecito Tudor — that will hang outside the windows, “providing privacy for the owners but exposing me,” she says. For info on self-guided tours, go to sbcaf.org.

Two of the best art shows in Beijing at the moment aren’t necessarily the newest. “The Unknown,” which opened April 1 (at the tail end of China Fashion Week) at the Ullens Center for Contemporary Art, is the fashion photographer Peter Lindbergh’s first solo exhibition in China. “The Unknown” is not a Lindbergh retrospective,” says the museum’s director, Jerome Sans, “but a body of work specifically assembled to mark his first experience with China.” A gigantic remix without order or chronology, the installation is a visual journey through decades of the photographer’s career, including photos of supermodels like Naomi Campbell, Christy Turlington and Linda Evangelista, most of which were commissioned for Italian Vogue by Franca Sozzani (who was present for the opening). Visitors enter the exhibition in a space surrounded by video images from Lindbergh’s recent cinematic series, “Invasion,” a film that depicts a crowd in slow motion moving into a cloud of smoke. Visitors to the exhibit suddenly realize they have become part of the silent choreography, as they watch their own shadows entering and exiting the images projected onto the walls.

About two dozen prominent film directors and producers, including James Cameron, below, Michael Bay and Peter Jackson, joined in an open letter Wednesday challenging a plan by four studios to make some films available via video on demand shortly after their release in theaters. ''As leaders in the creative community, we ask for a seat at the table,'' said the letter, which called on others to join in opposition to any rush toward on-demand services that might undercut the viability of films in theaters. The letter campaign was organized by the National Association of Theater Owners, an industry trade group that has voiced strong opposition to a plan by Sony Pictures Entertainment, 20th Century Fox, Universal Studios and Warner Brothers to show a small number of their films on a premium on-demand service as soon as two months after their release. DirecTV has said it will start an on-demand service, called Home Premiere, with the four studios on Thursday. The first title to be shown on that service will be ''Just Go With It,'' which stars Adam Sandler and Jennifer Aniston. ''Careers that are built on the risks that can be taken with lower-budget films may never have the chance to blossom under this cutthroat new model,'' warned the opposing filmmakers in their open letter, which was to be posted on the theater owners Web site.

WASHINGTON -- A Republican invitation for Israel's prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to address Congress next month is highlighting the tensions between President Obama and Mr. Netanyahu and has kicked off a bizarre diplomatic race over who will be the first to lay out a new proposal to reopen the stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. For three months, White House officials have been debating whether the time has come for Mr. Obama to make a major address on the region's turmoil, including the upheaval in the Arab world, and whether he should use the occasion to propose a new plan for peace between Israelis and Palestinians.

CULTURE A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday, about the $100,000 Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize for lifetime achievement, erroneously attributed a distinction to the award. At least one other poetry honor, the Kingsley Tufts Award from Claremont Graduate University, carries the same financial reward; the Lilly Prize is neither ''the largest'' nor ''the biggest'' poetry award.

Joseph Selame, who created a wide array of familiar logos and brand identities for dozens of companies and nonprofit organizations, including Apple Bank, Goodwill Industries, Kodak and CVS Pharmacy, died on March 29 in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 86. He had been suffering from dementia for several years, said his son Ted, who confirmed the death. He lived in Chestnut Hill, Mass., and New Seabury, Mass.

A television review on Wednesday about a documentary on Frederick Law Olmsted, using information from a publicist, misstated its title. It is ''Olmsted and America's Urban Parks,'' not ''The Olmsted Legacy: America's Urban Parks.''

Plenty of people want to build a popular Web site and become the next Mark Zuckerberg. But some technology entrepreneurs have a more old-fashioned goal: they want to make something you can hold in your hand. Like, actual stuff.

LEMLE--Edna F.,of Waikoloa, Hawaii and New York City, died peacefully on April 17 in Hawaii. She was 95 years old. Born on April 11, 1916 on Riverside Drive in NYC. Edna was a loving mother and grandmother. She graduated from Barnard College in 1937; having spent her junior year abroad in London at LSE. She founded the international holiday World Gratitude Day on September 21st which has since become International Peace Day. She authored "Precious Memories" a memoir of her relationship with Rabbi David and Tamar de Sola Pool. She also wrote a book of poems called "Dandelions" and, "The Dues and Dunce of Money". Edna danced with Martha Graham and painted, having had one woman art shows in Paris and New York City in 1961 about "The Universal Woman". She loved travel, dancing and sailing, international politics and all social engagements. In 2001 Edna received recognition for her work and efforts with international peace which also involved creating art shows at the United Nations with multi -national children's drawings for peace. She received this award from Metro International, now; "One to World". Edna is survived by her children, Florence Lemle, Mickey Lemle, Deanne Bosnak, Douglas Lemle and her grandchildren: Learka Bosnak, David Bosnak, his wife, Cheryl Stanley Bosnak, Jake Lemle, Aaron Lemle, and her nephews: Glenn Fuerth and Tommy Fuerth and their families. Friends are invited to a memorial service at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Manhattan, on Friday, April 22 at 11:15am. Donations may be made to "One to World" in her honor.
ROLLER--Abraham. Dad, you would have been 90 today. H.B. So sad you didn't make it. Loving and missing you every day. Cheryl

GLENN--Jane (nee Montag), died April 15, 2011 from a massive stroke. Jane was quietly competent, devoted to her family and friends. Her career spanned many years at LaGuardia Hospital and the United Nations. Contributions to Hospice Inn, Melville, NY or UNICEF.

FREEDMAN--Alfred M. New York Medical College mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Alfred M. Freedman, M.D., Chairman of the Department of Psychiatry from 1960 to 1988 and upon his retirement, Professor Emeritus. Dr. Freedman was an international leader in his field, serving as president of the American Psychiatric Association, the American Psychopathological Association and the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology, and founding editor of the Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry. He received the first Terence Cardinal Cooke Award from New York Medical College and the APA's Human Rights Award. We extend our condolences to his wife Marcia, his sons Paul and Daniel, and his grandchildren. Ronald F. Poe, Chairman Board of Trustees Karl P. Adler, M.D. President and Chief Executive Officer Ralph A. O'Connell, M.D. Provost and Dean, School of Medicine Joseph T. English, M.D. Chairman, Department of Psychiatry

A theater review on Wednesday about ''High,'' a drama starring Kathleen Turner that opened Tuesday night on Broadway, misidentified the theater in Hartford where the reviewer saw the premiere production last summer. It was TheaterWorks, not Hartford Stage.

GIVEN the comeback of fur, real and faux, on the streets and fashion runways, a furry dandelionlike necklace by Jun Takahashi of Undercover is an approachable way to test-drive the trend without committing to a three-year lease. This bit of fluff comes in the blush hue shown here, a blue jewel tone and a deep burgundy.

The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission on Monday approved controversial changes to the interior of the former Manufacturers Hanover Trust building on Fifth Avenue at 43rd Street. Preservationists had objected to revisions of the 1954 building's interior, which was designated a landmark in February. The vote was 8-0 in favor of the plan to reuse the space for a retail store, Joe Fresh. Three members of the commission were absent for the vote; at least one of them, Margery Perlmutter, had questioned the developer's proposal to change the escalators to an east-west direction from the current north-south configuration. ''We're replacing a real genuine work of art with a cheap reproduction,'' said Theodore Grunewald, the founder of the Coalition to Save Manufacturers Hanover Trust. ''If we're going to call New York a world-class city, we've got to preserve our history.'' The commission had twice asked the developer, Vornado, to revise its plans to respect the historical fabric. Vornado returned with refinements to the Fifth Avenue entrances and additional restorative work to the interior but stuck with its plan to move the escalators.

NEW YORK An article on Monday about Victor Toro, an advocate for immigrants and the needy who faces deportation to Chile, misstated the occupation of Danilo Lachapel, who works at a Bronx church where Mr. Toro volunteers and said he doubted Mr. Toro would ever mute his radicalism. He is the church's social outreach worker, not its assistant pastor.

Tabbed browsing is a great invention, but what do you do with too many tabs? It's not uncommon for people to pop open 30 or more on a daily basis, including many they check regularly, like the bookmarks of 10 years ago. Most browsers now let you group tabs to help organize them, but navigating through groups of tabs atop the browser is only slightly less of a distraction.

Q. I want to install a program on my computer, but it requires a certain version and service pack of Windows XP to run. How can I find out if I have the version and service pack it needs? A. You can quickly find out what version of Windows your computer is running by going to the Start menu, clicking into the Run box and typing ''winver.exe'' (without the quotation marks). Click the OK button to call up the About Windows box, which should list the version of Windows XP and service pack installed on the machine.

GIBBS--Dr. Judith Abbie Pediatrician, passed away in Toronto, Ontario on Wednesday, April 6, 2011, at the age of 69, after a lifetime of service to infants and children. Dr. Gibbs was born the eldest child of three to George and Irma (nee Margot) Hartmaier in Long Island, New York, on June 15, 1941. She was followed by her sisters, Leslie and Abbie. Judith was an award-winning violinist as a child and later a published poet. Moving with her family to Oxford, PA in 1954, she attended public school and was a merit scholarship finalist. She received a B.A. degree in biochemistry from the University of Delaware in 1963 and did research at the Sloan Kettering Institute in Manhattan. She received an M.A. in Russian Studies from Johns Hopkins University in 1968, and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. In 1968, Dr. Gibbs emigrated to Canada, where she graduated with honours from the McGill University medical school in Montreal. She received advanced training in paediatrics and neonatology at McGill and was awarded an MRC research fellowship to Oxford University, in England. In 1978, Dr. Gibbs was appointed Assistant Professor of Paediatrics and Obstetrics at McGill University. Dr. Gibbs returned to the United States in 1980 to establish a neonatal intensive care unit at the Allentown Pennsylvania Hospital. She later established a similar unit in Camden, New Jersey. Dr. Gibbs returned to university and received a J.D. in Law from Villanova University in Pennsylvania in 1987. She was elected to the Law Review and Moot Court, and called to the bar in 1987. Dr. Gibbs then decided to return to her greater love, paediatric medicine. She practised paediatrics for several years in the Poconos in Pennsylvania. In 1990, she returned to Canada and joined the Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto. Later she opened her private paediatric practice in Toronto. During this time she was also on call as a neonatologist at St. Michael's Hospital, saving many babies' lives. Until her death, she continued to do the work which was most meaningful to her, and to show her great and enduring love for infants, children and their families, and her dedication to their health and wellbeing. Her death from a stroke was unexpected. The family and friends of Dr. Gibbs express their deepest gratitude to the doctors, nurses and staff of St. Michael's Hospital, for the care and support they gave her during her final illness. She leaves behind her two sisters, Leslie Galambos (Pennsylvania), Abbie Hartmaier (Massachusetts), and Mary Barratt, her loving partner of many years. A private service was held on Wednesday, April 20, 2011 in the Humphrey Funeral Home A.W. Miles Chapel in Toronto 1-800-616-3311. If desired, donations in memory of Dr. Gibbs may be made to a charity of your choice. Condolences and memories may be forwarded through: www.humphreymiles.com.

ON a damp evening in late March, at the opening night of the ''Balenciaga and Spain'' exhibition at the de Young Museum in San Francisco, Dede Wilsey, the philanthropist and president of the museum's board, was standing by the front door wearing a white satin and black lace dress by Oscar de la Renta. (The show, which began at the Queen Sofi a Spanish Institute in New York, was conceived by Mr. de la Renta.) Mrs. Wilsey has given millions of dollars to help rebuild the de Young, and the diamond drop earrings and matching necklace that cascaded into her bodice seemed to make it clear that this had not been a hardship. As gilded young San Franciscans like the Gettys swirled through the building, mixing with politicians and business moguls, Mrs. Wilsey was convinced her investment had paid off. ''We decided to break the barrier,'' she said. ''We charged $2,500 a ticket, and some donors gave $100,000.''Along with money, there was a high ogle factor at the event, with Gwyneth Paltrow, Maria Bello, Orlando Bloom and Anna Wintour (in Balenciaga) in attendance.

GARMENT--Sara Elizabeth, 51, April 1, 2011. In her 20s, while attending Harvard Divinity School and beginning to write and paint, Sara was stricken with the diabetes that would end her life. The disease limited her artistic work; but she created a greater work in her courage, grace in suffering, and generous spirit. She is survived by her father, Leonard Garment; her brother, Paul Garment; and her sister, Ann Garment. To her family and friends she gave emotional support, wise counsel, and moral example. Friends may donate in Sara's memory to the American Diabetes Association.

FOR the husband-and-wife team behind Fleet Ilya, a London company that makes leather bondage accessories (think a dog mask with hardware), introducing softer shapes and colors was a perfectly natural progression. After all, Ilya Fleet trained as a saddlemaker in a Coventry village; his wife, Resha Sharma, has a design degree from Central Saint Martins. Their new fashion accessories, carried by shops like Colette in Paris and Opening Ceremony in New York, may be rooted in fetish wear, but they're charming and covetable. They include slim cutout belts and waist cinchers, strappy satchels and money belts, all in sorbet shades of coral and peppermint. Sort of sweet, no? Money belt, right, $389 at Opening Ceremony, 35 Howard Street (Broadway); openingceremony.us. Cutout belt, above, $610 from Condemned to Be Free; (646) 572-8004; condemnedtobefree.com.

8 P.M. (13) LA FANCIULLA DEL WEST One hundred years after its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera, Puccini's Wild West opera returns in this ''Great Performances at the Met'' program, taped in January and shown in theaters as part of ''The Met: Live in HD'' series. Set in a mining camp during the California Gold Rush, this 1991 production, above, by Giancarlo Del Monaco stars Deborah Voigt as Minnie, the saloon owner with the ravishing voice, who has her sights set on the mysterious Dick Johnson (Marcello Giordani). And nothing -- not horses, hangmen or a high-stakes poker game -- can stop her. ''On this night, thanks in large part to the stylish, nuanced and sensitive conducting of Nicola Luisotti, the score emerged as arguably Puccini's most subtly written and boldly modern music,'' Anthony Tommasini wrote in his December review in The New York Times. He added: ''As always, Ms. Voigt's singing will stir debate within the opera world. Given the competition around right now, I cannot think of a soprano who could sing any better this demanding role, which requires luscious legato phrasing, a powerful top range and stamina.'' The opera's debut on Dec. 10, 1910, was the first world premiere presented by the Met. Puccini, who was sitting alone in a box, joined the cast after Act I for 14 curtain calls. The stage director then was David Belasco, from whose play ''The Girl of the Golden West'' the opera was adapted; the leads were Emmy Destinn and Enrico Caruso; the conductor, Arturo Toscanini. Similar pandemonium broke out at the end of the other two acts, Mr. Tommasini noted. 8 P.M. (NBC) COMMUNITY As the school year ends, the study group reminisces about its favorite times together. In ''The Paul Reiser Show,'' at 8:30, Paul tries to smooth the feathers of a brute (Henry Rollins) who believes Paul has wronged him. In his penultimate appearance on ''The Office,'' at 9, Michael (Steve Carell) trains Deangelo (Will Ferrell) to host the Dundie Awards. In ''Parks and Recreation,'' at 9:30, Ann (Rashida Jones) persuades Leslie (Amy Poehler) to sign up with an online dating service, which matches her with someone she already knows. And the 100th episode of ''30 Rock,'' at 10, finds Liz (Tina Fey) and the crew doing their best to prevent ''TGS'' from being canceled.

A picture caption on April 7 with an article about a party for Don Hill, the nightclub impresario who died on March 31, referred imprecisely to the people shown. They were guests at a MisShapes party at the Don Hill's nightclub; they were not the MisShapes themselves, a D.J. trio.

Medical tests revealed no new concerns for Amar'e Stoudemire or Chauncey Billups on Wednesday, and their status for the Knicks' playoff game Friday night against the Boston Celtics remains largely unchanged. Stoudemire, the Knicks' star forward, has a pulled muscle in his back, according to a magnetic resonance imaging exam taken Wednesday, the team said. He is being listed as day to day, but is expected to play Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

With tennis season approaching, parents will be hovering at courtside, cameras raised, hoping to get the photo that reveals their little slugger as a budding Serena Williams or Rafael Nadal. It's not going to be easy. ''I have shot every sport you can think of,'' said photo pro Chris Nicholson. ''Tennis is still the hardest sport I've shot.''

Downtown mainstays like Philip Glass, Laurie Anderson, Patti Smith, below, Rufus Wainwright and Sean Lennon, and -- straight from the Battle of Agincourt -- Henry V, will all be part of the 10th River to River Festival, the annual celebration of arts in lower Manhattan, its organizers said on Wednesday. The festival of free events, which runs from June 19 through July 16, will begin with the Bang on a Can Marathon at the World Financial Center Winter Garden, with performances by Mr. Glass with the Bang on a Can All-Stars. The Castle Clinton National Monument in Battery Park will host concerts featuring Vijay Iyer (on June 23); Ms. Anderson with Bill Laswell (June 30); and Ms. Smith (July 14). And New York Classical Theater will present a two-castle production of Shakespeare's ''Henry V'' at Castle Clinton in Battery Park and Castle William on Governors Island (with free ferry service).

The crowded latter half of the Broadway season has its first high-profile closure: Matthew Lombardo's play ''High,'' starring Kathleen Turner, right, as a nun whose faith is tested while working with a young drug addict, will close on Sunday, press representatives for the show said on Wednesday. The production, directed by Rob Ruggiero, opened on Tuesday at the Booth Theater, and though the play received mixed notices, there was some praise for Ms. Turner's performance. In a review for The New York Times, Charles Isherwood wrote that, in her role as Sister Jamison Connelly, Ms. Turner was ''all but smacking her lips like a gourmet savoring al dente pasta'' as she made ''a feast of largely unexceptional dialogue.'' For the week ending April 17, ''High'' played to about 79 percent capacity but grossed just $91,000 in ticket sales, meaning that tickets were being heavily discounted. The show will have played 28 previews and 8 regular performances at its closing. It is Mr. Lombardo's second play to see a short life on Broadway; last season his Tallulah Bankhead drama, ''Looped,'' closed after 27 previews and 33 regular performances, though its star, Valerie Harper, went on to receive a Tony nomination for best actress in a play.

CAMPIFORMIO--Anthony John, age 70, passed away on April 9 after a long illness. Tony was the son of the late Patrick Campiformio and late Jennie Lello Campiformio of Greenwich, CT. He is survived by his wife, Lois, many aunts, cousins, a niece and nephew. After graduating from Greenwich HS in 1958, Tony served in the U.S. Marine Corps as an air navigator until his honorable discharge in 1962. He graduated from Iona College in 1966 and started in sales for Bunker Ramo eventually rising to a senior sales management role. In 1988 he joined ILX Systems, as its first head of global marketing and sales and was instrumental in its early success. Tony was on his college golf team and remained an avid golfer throughout his life. His love of life was boundless and he will be missed. A celebration of Tony's life will be held at the Tillman Chapel, 777 UN Plaza, NYC on May 5 at 6pm.

There is not a whole lot of golf being played in Upper Manhattan. Harlem, Washington Heights and Inwood are devoid of golf courses and driving ranges. But for two cousins from Washington Heights, this time of year means unpacking the clubs and swinging away, right here in the inner city.

For the most part declining album sales are bad news for the music industry. But there's one way in which they can benefit musicians: with everybody selling fewer records, it can be easier for an artist to climb higher on the charts. This week the Foo Fighters scored their first No. 1 album with ''Wasting Light'' (Roswell/RCA), which sold 235,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That's a lower sales total than the band had for its last chart peak -- ''In Your Honor,'' which reached No. 2 with 311,000 sales in 2005 -- but this week it carried the band to the top spot. Other artists also hit personal highs on the charts this week. Alison Krauss and Union Station opened at No. 3 with 83,000 sales of ''Paper Airplane'' (Rounder). Ms. Krauss had reached No. 2 for her album with Robert Plant four years ago but never rose so high with Union Station, her longtime band. Paul Simon had his highest opening-week ranking ever -- as a solo artist, or with Simon & Garfunkel -- with ''So Beautiful or So What'' (Hear Music/Concord), which sold 68,000 copies to reach No. 4. On Billboard's singles chart Katy Perry's ''E.T.'' was bumped from No. 1 after a three-week run at the top by Rihanna's ''S&M,'' which more than doubled its download sales from last week, to 293,000. ''E.T.'' fell to No. 2 with 284,000 downloads, and the Black Eyed Peas' ''Just Can't Get Enough'' was No. 3 with 172,000.

DALIS--Mandell, fifty years of true friendship will never be forgotten, dear friend. Part of our own life was lived with Juliet, Beth, Leslie, Bruce and their children to whom we offer our heartfelt condolences and love - Gladys and Sidney Berger and family.

POWERS--Seymour, a true business pioneer in the greater Danbury, CT area, whose accomplishments made him a legend in the development of commercial real estate, attracting fortune 500 companies and creating vast numbers of employment opportunities through his own, Commerce Park, numerous industrial business properties and his overall contribution to the prosperity of the business community of Danbury for over 50 years, passed away at the age of 92 in his home in Boca Raton, Florida on Monday, April 18, 2011. His prominence as a captain of Industry and Real Estate was equaled only by his philanthropic endeavors. A leading contributor and fundraiser for Ben Gurion University, an ardent supporter of Israel, Mr. Powers served as a past chairman of the UJA, and member of the King David Society. Seymour Powers was a recipient of the 1999 Cecil J. Previdi Award and was awarded an Honorary Doctorate for his efforts with Ben Gurion University. He was honored for his philanthropy, his commitment to the Jewish community and the Zionist cause, as well as for his ongoing support of the University. Seymour and his wife, Alice, established the Alice and Seymour Powers Joint Israel-Russia Laboratory for Energy Research and the Alice and Seymour Powers Career Development Chair in Basic and Clinical Oncology. In addition to playing an active role in the development of the Southeast Region of the AABGU, he was also the recipient of the BGU Negev Award, amongst many others. An avid sailor and yachtsman, having served in WWII in the Navy training other personnel in Radar, Seymour built and enjoyed the boat of his dreams, The Prime Rate IV. He is survived by his loving wife, Alice Powers, his children: Garry, Melvyn, Stuart, Nancy and Sandee; his grandchildren: Melissa, Lauren, Alicia, Holly, Mia, Ana, Maxx, Joshua, Justin and Jordan; and great-grandchildren: Ben, Noah, Talia, Mason, Luca and Olive; and his sister, Sylvia Malvin of Boca Raton, Florida. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, April 21, at 11am, in Rubin Memorial Chapel, 7340 Boynton Beach Blvd in Boynton Beach, Florida, 561-496-3000. After the memorial, a processional with interment services will follow at Eternal Light Memorial Garden.

IT turns out that those neon chartreuse dresses that nearly blinded the runways back in September are having a full-on Day-Glo moment as cocktail wear for spring. At a Net-a-Porter party in New York, Natalie Massenet, the company's founder, chose a fluorescent green lace dress by Alessandra Rich, and Sylvana Ward Durrett of Vogue (near right) wore Proenza Schouler's acid yellow shibori-print top with skirt to match. If you are tempted to try the look, be bold. Play with clashing color combinations, as on the Proenza Schouler and Christopher Kane spring runways. Or keep the look chic by accessorizing with another shocking shade. Ms. Rich paired a neon orange lace dress with a fluorescent green belt; a wicked yellow Miu Miu dress was shown with a neon green belt. It's a great way to be known for your acid wit -- without hurting anyone's feelings.

SCHENKER--Roberta, 69, passed away peacefully in Los Angeles on Saturday, April 17, 2011 from complications associated with a very, very rare neurodegenerative disorder called Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP). Roberta was born in Brooklyn, NY on August 28, 1941 to Sylvia and Jacob Brodsky. Roberta lived most of her life in the New York City area until in 1979, she and her husband moved to Tokyo, Japan. Upon leaving Japan they did not want to return to the "shoveling of snow" in New York City, so they settled in Southern California (Irvine). In 1985 they founded a direct marketing company called DAMI and six years later sold it and retired to Los Angeles, CA. Roberta is survived by Larry, her much loved husband, companion and business partner of 30 years; her brother Dr. Harold Brodsky (Boca Raton, FL) with whom she shared many happy times; her very cherished twin nieces Lauren Brodsky (Boston, MA) and Debra Brodsky Shigley (New York City) and husband Erich. Her beloved step-daughters Lynn Schneider (Ridgefield, CT) and Cindy Nydell (Tustin, CA) and their husbands Alan and Lee. Her treasured grandsons Jason Schneider (New York City), Eric Schneider (New York City) and Brandon Nydell (Lansing, MI) for whom she did everything to make their lives productive and happy. She was a loving wife, sister, aunt, step-mother and grandmother. She will be greatly missed and always loved. A "Celebration of Life" will be held at the Hilton Hotel, Melville, NY (631-845-1000) at 2pm on Saturday, April 23, 2011. Private graveside services will be at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY on Sunday, April 24, 2011. Donations in Roberta's memory may be made to the Roberta Schenker Fund at CurePSP, 800 457-4777. Larry can be always contacted at: lschenker@gmail.com.

THEBAN--Kathryn M. (Kay) Born: November 23, 1927, Died April 17, 2013. Predeceased by her husband, John Theban and parents Joseph and Ellen Magee. She is survived by her sister Mary J. Schroeder, nephews Joseph (Jeanine), Frank and Colin Schroeder and great-nephews Mac and JD Schroeder. Kathryn received a diploma as a Professional Registered Nurse from Roosevelt Hospital School of Nursing and was Director of Nursing Services there for 20 years. She went on to earn her Master's in Public Health from Columbia University and then worked for the Dominican Sisters Family Health Services. She oversaw special programs that included outreach to mothers and babies and service to HIV/Aids patients in the South Bronx as well as programs in Westchester and Suffolk Counties. She earned her second Masters Degree in Psychiatric/ Mental Health Nursing from SUNY Stony Brook and completed a two year dynamic psychotherapy training program at Karen Homey Psychoanalytic institute. She then worked as a psychotherapist until she retired in 2008. Kathryn's devotion to her profession was never more evident than in her work with the indigent and addicted individuals. She was a member of the Board of Directors at Dominican Sisters Family Health Services. In addition, she devoted a good portion of her adult life to assisting alcoholics in their recovery. Kathryn was a great fan of the opera, theater and all of the arts New York City offers. Over the years Kay traveled extensively throughout the world. She was a woman of unbridled curiosity and wonderment. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her and those she touched. Friends may call on Saturday from 2-7 at Frank E Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC. Her funeral mass will be held Monday at 11:00am, Church of the Holy Name of Jesus, corner of 96th St. and Amsterdam Ave. NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to Coalition for the Homeless, 129 Fulton St, NYC 10038 or Heifer International, P0 Box 8059 Little Rock, AK 72203.

BENGHAZI, Libya -- A PKT machine gun, a weapon designed to be mounted on a Soviet tank and fired electronically by a crew member inside, has no manual trigger, no sights and no shoulder stock. That does not prevent many Libyan rebels from carrying it as if it were an infantryman's gun, even though it cannot be fired. A Carcano cavalry carbine -- probable refuse from Italian colonization in Libya between the world wars -- is chambered for a dated rifle cartridge that the rebels have not been able to procure. That did not deter four rebels recently seen wandering the battlefield with these relics, without a cartridge to fire.

INTERNATIONAL Because of an editing error, an article and a headline on Tuesday about the presidential election in Nigeria characterized incorrectly the victory of the incumbent, Goodluck Jonathan. He was elected, not re-elected. (Mr. Jonathan was sworn in as president in May 2010, when, as vice president, he took over for President Umaru Yar'Adua, who had died.)

It was not Edvard Munch's ''Scream.'' It was not Michael Jackson's ''Scream.'' And it was not even Howard Dean's infamous Iowa scream. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, as a crowd witnessed on Wednesday, is apparently not one for screaming.

In what may be the strongest signal yet of the new pro-labor orientation of the National Labor Relations Board under President Obama, the agency filed a complaint Wednesday seeking to force Boeing to bring an airplane production line back to its unionized facilities in Washington State instead of moving the work to a nonunion plant in South Carolina. In its complaint, the labor board said that Boeing's decision to transfer a second production line for its new 787 Dreamliner passenger plane to South Carolina was motivated by an unlawful desire to retaliate against union workers for their past strikes in Washington and to discourage future strikes. The agency's acting general counsel, Lafe Solomon, said it was illegal for companies to take actions in retaliation against workers for exercising the right to strike.

KATZ--Irving H.,of Deerfield Beach, formerly of Woodmere and Brooklyn, passed away April 20. He will be remembered as a violinist, educator, businessman and pillar of our family. Irv's sweet music will live within all of us. Star of David Chapels, W. Babylon, NY, April 22, Noon, 631-454-9600.

A manager for the pop-music parodist Weird Al Yankovicsaid on Wednesday that Lady Gaga had granted Mr. Yankovic permission to include a parody of her song ''Born This Way'' on his new album. Mr. Yankovic had described in a post on his blog how he'd approached Lady Gaga's management about his parody song, called ''Perform This Way''; he said Lady Gaga's representatives responded that they would have to hear the song before they could approve it. After completing an Australian tour and canceling a family vacation to work on the song, Mr. Yankovic said he finished the track on April 11 and submitted it to Lady Gaga's team. (Sample couplet: ''I might be wearin' Swiss cheese or maybe covered with bees/It doesn't mean I'm crazy -- I perform this way.'') But her managers initially rejected the song. Mr. Yankovic said in a phone interview that he could not release his new album until he had ''a hit single.'' He added, ''I thought this was it, and we all thought, 'Gee, if Lady Gaga makes us go through all this trouble, she's certainly not going to tell us no.' '' A press representative for Lady Gaga did not immediately reply to a request for comment.

The long-awaited demise of an extraordinary winter has released a pent-up spring. The days are longer and softer. Flowers are opening, the birds are back and the courting season has begun in earnest. Spring’s sprung and New York City is giddy with it. I imagined every structure in every borough suddenly being freed from its stodgy, frozen-at-right-angles shackles as well. Straight lines are for winter. Spring is all about curves and things that wiggle and grow — like everything in “Spring City.”
Changes in the health care landscape have left Dr. Ronald Sroka with a family practice he cannot sell.

The order to destroy Stanley, the rolling toolbox that had become a bullpen mascot for the Mets in spring training, came right from the top. Jeff Wilpon, the Mets’ chief operating officer, who is in charge of the daily operations of the team, ordered the demolition Thursday as a way to turn around the team’s atrocious luck.

Dr. Ronald Sroka has practiced family medicine for 32 years in a small red-brick building just six miles from his childhood home, treating fishing buddies, neighbors and even his elementary school principal. But doctors like him are a dying breed, as rising health care costs are driving thousands of doctors in small private practices out of business, reports Gardiner Harris.

The new titles in the lists this week are another example of the diversity of graphic novels. There’s literally something for everyone. On the hardcover list is “Mister Wonderful,” by Daniel Clowes, about the search for human connection as seen through a blind date. The story was originally serialized in the Sunday magazine of The New York Times. Those installments are available here, but the hardcover collection, at No. 1, contains 40 pages of new material. Also on the hardcover list is “Invincible: Ultimate Collection,” Vol. 6, by Robert Kirkman and Ryan Ottley, who created the critically-acclaimed comic book series “The Walking Dead,” which became a critically-acclaimed AMC television series. Invincible, at No. 10, is about a young super-hero learning about himself, his father (another super being) and life (college, relationships, work).

Ethan Stiefel, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will withdraw from performances with the company this spring. In a statement released by the company on Friday, Mr. Stiefel, 38, said he had decided to withdraw so that he could focus on his duties as dean of dance at the University of North Carolina School of the Arts. This is Mr. Stiefel’s final year as dean. He is to take on the role of artistic director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet in September. “Leading the U.N.C.S.A. School of Dance through a critical period of transition has required the type of energy and attention that has kept me from properly focusing and physically preparing for my upcoming performances,” Mr. Stiefel said in the statement. “I am truly disappointed not to be performing with my colleagues at ABT and for the New York audiences.” This season he was scheduled to dance opposite Alina Cojocaru in “Giselle” in May and Natalia Osipova in “Coppelia” in June. Mr. Stiefel, who joined Ballet Theater in 1997, has also withdrawn from American Ballet Theater’s tour of Japan in July.

The Congressional Budget Office is out with a new study that should quell some of the deficit hysteria that seems to be taking over the national discourse. It points out that a major part of the current budget deficit is caused by what it calls "automatic stabilizers" that respond to economic weakness.

You’d have to be in a permanent state of savasana (corpse pose) not to realize that yoga is big business. For those of us who relish the little bit of peace and quiet it offers from what sometimes feels like the relentlessness of our days, that can be a bit of a drag. Apparently, the government of India feels the same way. The country recently created a database of 1,300 yoga poses for use by international patent offices, the Times of India reports, apparently in an effort to reclaim the ancient practice from western “yoga gurus.”
